and thus there is no contention.

**Original Text Translation:**

Do not esteem rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,
so the people will not become thieves.

Rare and difficult-to-obtain goods refer to what lies beyond one’s natural endowment.
To seek what cannot be had is futile—thus they are called difficult to obtain.
He who does not rest in his natural allotment,
but covets what he lacks,
has already strayed from his nature—
how can this not be theft?

Let things be used according to their nature,
and let actions accord with one’s abilities,
then rare and difficult-to-obtain goods will lose their allure,
and the essence of life will not be stolen.

**Commentary (疏):**
Humans, upon receiving life, are endowed with a natural portion.
The materials and faculties they inherit are their own body and treasure.
To seek beyond one’s allotment is futile—
thus they are called difficult to obtain.

If one does not abide by his nature,
but aspires to brilliance beyond his endowment,
he loses his true essence
and becomes a thief by private inclination.

Now, if the wise and foolish follow their natural inclinations,
and abilities align with their capacities,
with no desire to exceed their portion,
they will naturally disregard rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,
for they are already content with what they possess—
who would then be a thief?

Thus, Zhuangzi said:
*"The unvirtuous steal the essence of life and glut themselves on wealth and honor."*

It is also explained:
If the ruler does not esteem pearls, rhinoceros horn, or precious gems,
his governance will be pure and tranquil,
and the people, transformed by this, will naturally abandon greed.
Each knowing their sufficiency,
they will not become thieves.

Do not present what is desirable,
so the heart remains undisturbed.

Since there is no pursuit of the virtuous nor coveting of rare goods,
there is nothing visibly desirable to incite confusion in the heart.

**Commentary (疏):**
To aspire to brilliance is to see what is desirable—
when desire stirs, how can the heart not be disturbed?
Now, if one neither elevates ability nor seeks beyond his portion,
there will be nothing desirable to provoke confusion in the heart.

Thus, the Sage’s governance.

**Commentary (疏):**
This speaks of the Sage’s governance over the realm and self,
establishing it as the foundation of teaching.
What more is there to governance of the realm?
Only governance of the self.

Thus, empty the heart and fill the belly,
cut off desire and forget knowledge in *wuwei*,
and nothing will remain ungoverned.

Empty the heart.
When the heart is not disturbed by what is desirable, it is empty.

**Commentary (疏):**
To labor the mind after external things is to be obscured by worldly affairs,
but to cultivate stillness and preserve purity is to let desires not arise—
when desires do not arise, the heart is empty.
Zhuangzi said: *"An empty room gives birth to white."*—
meaning that when the heart is empty, pure clarity arises naturally.

Thus it is said:
Empty the heart, fill the belly,
let virtue and power internally suffuse—
then there will be no arrogance or contrivance,
just as one who eats until satisfied will stop,
generating no further greed.

**Commentary (疏):**
The belly, when full, does not crave more;
when virtue and power internally suffuse,
no greed arises—
thus it is said, *fill the belly*.
*"Eating until satisfied and stopping"* comes from the *Spring and Autumn Annals*,
where Yan Mo and Ru Kuang advised Duke Wuzi of Wei:
*"Use the belly of a commoner to govern the heart of a noble—
when satisfied, there will be no further greed."*

Weaken the will.
When the heart is empty, the will grows weak.

**Commentary (疏):**
The will is the mind’s affair—
when the mind has something to act upon, it is called will.
To let the mind adhere to gentleness and weakness is to know
that when the heart is empty, the will weakens.

Strengthen the bones.
When the belly is full, the bones grow strong.

**Commentary (疏):**
The bones are the body’s framework.
Since virtue and power internally suffuse,
and there is no greed,
the belly remains full—
when the belly is full, the bones grow strong.

Always let the people be without knowledge and without desire.
Always let them lack the knowledge of contention and esteem,
and the desire for acquisition.

**Commentary (疏):**
The Sage’s teaching of emptying the heart and filling the belly
seeks to make the people naturally free from the knowledge of contention
and the desire for acquisition,
so they may transform on their own.

Let those who know dare not act.
Through tranquil transformation, when knowledge and desire are exhausted,
even those who possess knowledge will not dare to act.

**Commentary (疏):**
Those without knowledge and desire are already tranquil—
thus, those who possess knowledge will gradually be refined by pure transformation,
daring not to act in pursuit of traces or greed,
but instead practicing *wuwei*.

To act in *wuwei* is to govern perfectly.

To act in *wuwei* while letting people return to their nature,
pure transformation will naturally ensue.

**Commentary (疏):**
To act while abiding in *wuwei*—
even if acting, it is still *wuwei*.
Since the pursuit of the virtuous is abandoned,
and rare goods are not sought,
people follow their natural portions,
and things retain their authenticity—
in *wuwei*, what is there to arrogate or contrive?
Though without fame or repute,
people do not recognize it,
yet who can say the pure wind does not prevail?

Du Guangting said:
*"Not esteeming the virtuous prevents contention.*
*Pursuing traces*—this means artificiality.
Once the principle of esteeming the virtuous arises,
artificial men will inevitably appear.
Why? Because the virtuous are difficult to discern.
The cunning feign trustworthiness,
the flatterers feign loyalty—
how easy is it to distinguish them?

The *Classic* says:
*'Wisdom produces great deceit.'*
Thus, when the ruler values wisdom,
the people respond with deceit;
when the ruler values the virtuous,
the people respond with artificiality.
It is better to rectify oneself and lead by example,
governing through *wuwei*,
nurturing with the Great Harmony,
transforming through tranquility—
then worthy ministers will naturally serve their roles.

This is what is meant by *clouds following the dragon, winds following the tiger*.
Clouds follow the dragon and winds follow the tiger—
this is Confucius’ interpretation of the *Book of Changes*’ *Qian* hexagram,
where the fifth line says: *The flying dragon in the sky.*
Since it can broadly influence all things,
water flows to dampness,
fire turns to dryness,
clouds follow the dragon,
winds follow the tiger.
Each follows its kind, responding naturally—
this illustrates the Son of Heaven ascending to the fifth position,
and all under heaven coming to his court.

The Sage acts, and all things behold him—
those rooted in Heaven turn upward,
those rooted in Earth turn downward.
This speaks of water, which is yin—
when flowing on Earth, it seeks dampness.
Fire, which is yang—
when burning wood, it seeks dryness.
Though these two things lack awareness or sentiment,
they are moved by *qi* and respond thus.
Again, the dragon is a water creature,
and clouds are water *qi*—
when the dragon roars, mist rises.
The tiger is a fierce beast,
and wind is a moving force—
when the tiger howls, valley winds arise.
These two things, though possessing awareness and sentiment,
share the same *qi* and kind as those without—
thus they respond in the same way.

「When the Sage descends into the world, the flying dragon soars through Heaven,
and the worthy and virtuous support one another—
all things respond in harmony, thus expanding their influence.

Emperor Yao of the Tang dynasty, surnamed Yiqi and named Fangxun,
was known as Emperor Tao of the Tang clan.

Emperor Shun of the Yu clan,
a descendant of Zhuanyu, grandson of Qiaoniu,
son of Guying, born to Mother Yuleng at Yaochu,
was thus surnamed Yao and named Zhonghua.

The eight **Yuan** and eight **Kai** were his ministers.
In ancient times, the High Xin (尧) clan had eight talented sons:
Bo Feng, Zhong Kan, Shu Xian, Ji Zhong,
Bo Hu, Zhong Xiong, Shu Bao, Ji Li—
loyal, solemn, reverent, and harmonious,
spreading benevolence and grace—
the people of all under Heaven called them the eight **Yuan**.

The High Yang (舜) clan had eight talented sons:
Cang Shu, Tui Gu, Dao Jie, Dai Lin,
Long Jiang, Ting Jian, Zhong Rong, Shu Da—
virtuous and broad-minded, wise and sincere—
the people of all under Heaven called them the eight **Kai**.

These sixteen clans united in their excellence,
and their renown did not fade.
Yet Yao did not trust them,
and instead raised Shun as his minister,
appointed the eight **Yuan** to propagate the Five Teachings to the four quarters,
and assigned the eight **Kai** to govern the **Hou Tu** (后土, the Earthly Realm).

The **Tai** and **Heng** (台衡) were the expectations of the Son of Heaven—
he established the Three Ministers (三公) to symbolize the Three **Tai** (台, celestial palaces).
He did not value rare and difficult treasures,
so the people did not become thieves.

Human life originates from the vital essence of Heaven and Earth,
and those who receive the clear, bright, and pure *qi* become Sages and worthy ones,
while those who receive the turbid, stagnant, and confused *qi* become foolish and lowly.
The Sages and worthy ones possess vast divine intelligence,
while the foolish and dim-witted are clouded in ignorance.
Thus, there are inherent differences in human nature.

Laozi said to Confucius:
*"The Way generates people and all things,
and birds, beasts, insects, and all creatures have their odd and even—
this refers to differing *qi*.
But common people do not know its nature,
only those who grasp Dao and virtue can trace its origin."*

The *Wenzi* (文子) says:
*"Clear *qi* is Heaven, turbid *qi* is Earth,
harmonious *qi* is humanity.
Within harmonious *qi*, there is brightness and darkness—
thus, there are the worthy and the foolish.
If the foolish seek to emulate the worthy, they exceed their nature—
this is called *yue fen* (越分, transgressing one’s limits).
If the dark seek to replace the bright, they make false demands—
this is called *mang qiu* (妄求, presumptuous desire).
This is the act of stealing the essence of life
and greedily coveting wealth and honor—
words from the *Zhuangzi*’s *‘Pianmu’* (骈拇, ‘Extra Thumbs’) chapter."*

Wealth and honor are coveted because they can be seized,
but when there is no higher path to aspire to,
people accept their lot,
acting according to their ability and receiving tasks accordingly—
how much less would they transgress their limits
to greedily steal what is not their due!

A ruler does not value pearls, rhinoceros horns, or rare treasures—
this prevents the people from becoming thieves.
He does not display what is desirable,
so his heart remains undisturbed.
To covet and admire is to envy brilliance.

Human nature is limited,
yet to envy wisdom is to transgress one’s nature—
this is called *desire* (欲).

Again, those who cultivate the Dao,
in their early stages,
though their practice is incomplete,
their refinement not yet mature,
fear what is desirable,
being drawn by the realm of phenomena—
thus, they retreat into mountains and forests,
avoiding the clamor of the world.
But when their hearts are tranquil and their wills steadfast,
the realm cannot entice them—
they move through the day with ease,
never wearying.
This is the saying:
*"Small retreat in the mountains, great retreat in the marketplace."*

Unable to sever desire,
fearing the pull of phenomena,
they hide in mountains and forests to avoid what they see—
until their hearts are purified and their thoughts still,
their minds dwell on the true and genuine,
free from external disturbances,
preserving inner serenity—
even amidst the bustling markets,
name and gain do not touch their hearts;
even amidst the worldly paths,
controversies do not disrupt their intentions.
Mingling with the city,
how does this harm the cultivation of the genuine?

Thus, the Sage’s principle:
*"The True and Perfect Man said to the Yellow Emperor:
‘I have never heard of a man who cultivates his body
yet fails to bring order to his state.’
The body of one man is a microcosm of his state—
the chest and abdomen are like palaces and halls,
the four limbs like boundaries and territories,
the bones and joints like officials.
The spirit is like the ruler,
the blood like the ministers,
and the *qi* like the people.
To govern the body is to govern the state—
loving the people secures the state,
cherishing the *qi* preserves the body.
If the people scatter, the state falls;
if the *qi* is exhausted, life dies.
What has fallen cannot be restored,
what is dead cannot be revived—
thus, the Perfect Man extinguishes breath before it arises,
and treats ailments before they manifest.
*Qi* is difficult to nurture yet easily corrupted,
the people are hard to gather yet easily dispersed—
governance must begin before chaos arises,
not after it has already passed."*

**Reflect upon this!**

**Empty your heart.**
Only when the Dao gathers in emptiness does emptiness embrace the Dao.
When the Dao gathers in the heart,
the spirit plays with transformation,
the heart communicates with Heaven,
and all things spontaneously transform below—
the Sage rests in harmony above.
This is the ultimate principle of governance.

*"The empty room produces whiteness"*—
words from the *Zhuangzi*’s *‘Renjian Shijie’* (人间世, ‘The World of Man’) chapter.
The room is the heart—
to see what is present as if it were absent is to empty the heart.
When the heart is emptied,
pure whiteness naturally arises.
Pure whiteness is the appearance of great clarity and openness.

The *Inner Observation Scripture* (内观经) says:
*"The heart is neither green nor red,
neither white nor yellow,
neither long nor short,
neither round nor square—
it encompasses Heaven and Earth,
yet enters the finest hairs.
Restrain it, and it ceases;
release it, and it runs wild.
Calmness and stillness bring life,
turbulence and agitation bring death.
It illuminates the eight directions,
or it confuses even one corner.
Humanity’s greatest difficulty lies in the heart—
thus, teaching people to cultivate the Dao is to teach them to cultivate the heart.
Teaching people to cultivate the heart is to teach them the Dao.
The heart cannot be stilled,
but through the Dao it is stilled;
the heart cannot be seen,
but through the Dao it is illuminated.
The dual paths of good and evil,
all worldly laws arise from the heart and perish in the heart—
those who practice the Dao still the heart and attain the Dao,
while the common folk indulge the heart and endanger themselves."*

The heart gives rise to chaos, its extinction brings order—
thus the Son of Heaven establishes officials,
clarifies laws and punishments,
sets rewards and calamities,
and hangs omens of fortune and misfortune,
all to guide humanity—
for these are measures against the heart’s unruliness.

The heartless are without commandments,
the steadfast-hearted are without doubt,
the still-hearted act not at all,
the restrained-hearted are not disordered,
the rectified-hearted are not perverse,
the purified-hearted are not defiled,
the empty-hearted are not attached.

To grasp these seven principles,
one may speak of the Dao,
one may speak of cultivating the heart.

Fill the belly.

The heart’s desires are boundless,
the belly’s capacity is sufficient.
The heart is boundless, so empty it.
The belly is sufficient, so fill it.
An empty heart gives rise to no cravings,
a full belly halts greed of its own accord.

Cherish loyalty and sincerity,
embrace simplicity and purity—
thus virtue is complete within.

*The *Chūnqiū* is the name of the annals of Lǔ.
When Yán Mò and Rǔ Kuān remonstrated,
it was in the twenty-eighth year of Duke Zāo of *Chūnqiū*,
when Wèi Xiànzǐ of Jìn, Shū by name,
held office and appointed his son Wù as Great Officer of Gěngyáng—
now Jìnyáng.
In winter, there was a case in Gěngyáng,
and Wù could not decide it,
so he brought the matter before Xiànzǐ.

The plaintiff’s elder, with female musicians as tribute,
intended to give them to Wèi Zǐ.
Wù said to the two ministers Yán Mò and Rǔ Kuān:
*"Our lord is renowned among the thousand lords for his refusal of bribes—
yet to accept tribute from Gěngyáng would be the height of greed.
My lords must remonstrate!"*
Both agreed.

After the court audience, he awaited them in the hall. The tribute was presented, and Wèi Xiànzǐ summoned the two ministers to dine. When the food was served, he sighed three times. After eating, he had them sit.

Wèi Xiànzǐ said, *"I have heard from my elder kinsmen that there is a saying: 'Only when eating does one forget worries.' When my lords placed the food before me, they sighed three times. Why is this?"*

They answered with identical words: *"When others gave the two lesser men wine, they did not eat at night, and when the wine arrived, they feared it might not be enough—thus the first sigh. In the middle of the meal, they reproached themselves, saying, 'Should the General’s food be deemed insufficient?'—thus the second sigh. When the tribute was fully presented, they wished that their own bellies might serve as the virtuous mind of a noble one, and they prayed earnestly for it to cease—thus the third sigh."*

Wèi Xiànzǐ declined the tribute from Gěngyáng.

*Sprinkled* is the word for posthumous title. The *Chūnqiū* records: *"Wù Zǐ, whose given name was Wèi, was posthumously titled Wù."* The two ministers, Yán Mò and Rǔ Kuān, remonstrated with Wù Zǐ, wishing that their own bellies might serve as the virtuous mind of a noble one. The belly is easily filled, yet the mind is hard to satisfy—this was their desire to curb his greed and not accept the tribute from Gěngyáng. Even when lesser men’s bellies are full, they still know to stop; how much more should a noble one’s mind be content!

The *Chūnqiū* praised this act.

The Wèi clan’s rise was due to their accepting remonstrance. Their resolve was weakened.

The *Shī Xù* states: *"What arises in the heart is called resolve."* What the heart gives rise to is resolve; what it acts upon is deed. If the heart is soft and yielding, then there will be no reckless, hasty, or contentious affairs—all will be in harmony.

Harmony in affairs is the foundation of governance. Strengthen their bones.

If their resolve is weakened, then their virtue and gentleness will not be sullied by external temptations. If their bones are strengthened, then their firmness and preparedness will be rooted within. Those who follow the Dao will have sinews and bones that are strong and resilient—no hundred maladies can invade them.

A full belly strengthens the bones; the harmonious *qi* is abundant. In governing the realm, clear administration brings peace to the people, and frugal expenditures ensure their strength is plentiful.

Peaceful people are those whose resolve is weakened. Abundant strength is those whose bones are strengthened. Always let the people be without knowledge or desire.

Greed and avarice give rise to strife; knowledge sparks action.

The strife and desires being absent, clarity and tranquility will naturally manifest. Let those who possess knowledge dare not act.

When the lower follows the upper, it is like the wind bending the grass—pure and harmonious, universally permeating, all returning to the state of *non-action*. To act in *non-action* is to have nothing left ungoverned.

The principle of *non-action* is vast indeed! *Non-action* does not mean withdrawing so that nothing comes, or pushing so that nothing stays, or forcing so that there is no response, or moving so that nothing shifts, or being rigid and stagnant so that nothing flows, or being coiled and damp so that nothing scatters.

It means that private desires do not intrude upon the public Dao, that appetites do not pervert proper methods. To act in accordance with principle, to establish merit through resources, to complete deeds without self-praise, to achieve feats without claiming renown—this is *non-action*.

If water is used with a boat, sand with a cart, mud with a sled, and mountains with a wheelbarrow, if one cultivates summer fields and winter ponds, follows elevation for tillage and depression for reservoirs, then this is not what I call *action*—it is *non-action*.

The *non-action* of the Sage follows naturally, relies upon the people, demands without toil, plans without error, acts without omission. Their words are refined as writings, their deeds as models, their advancement and retreat suit the times, their movement and stillness follow principle. They neither favor beauty nor detest ugliness, nor do their rewards and punishments stem from personal likes or dislikes. Each has their own appointed name, each fulfills their own proper function. Matters arise from nature itself, without deviation from the self. They conform to Heaven’s timing, adapt to Earth’s traits, and follow humanity’s inclinations.

Thus, ministers gather like spokes to a wheel, the worthy and unworthy each employing their talents. The ruler gains means to govern his ministers, the ministers gain means to serve their ruler—this is the Dao of *non-action* in governing the realm.

The unheard and unscented is the *Shijing* [Book of Songs]—[大雅] [Great Odes]—[文王篇] [Wenwang’s Chapter]. It speaks of Heaven’s Dao being difficult to know: the ears do not hear its sounds, the nose does not perceive its fragrances. If one follows the rituals of Wenwang, then the world will naturally trust and comply.

The unrecognized and unknown is the *Shijing*—[大雅] [Great Odes]—[皇矣篇] [Huangyi’s Chapter]. It speaks of those who do not acknowledge the past nor comprehend the present, yet act in accordance with Heaven’s laws.

This says that Heaven’s Dao values sincerity, esteems nature’s essence, and does not exalt the worthy nor hold wealth in high regard—this aligns with it.

The Song emperor Daozong said: *"Not exalting the worthy leads to the people not becoming thieves."* Exalting the worthy brings many who know, to the point where the world is greatly alarmed, and Confucianists and Mohists all rise up. Valuing wealth brings many desires, to the point where daylight thefts occur, and robbers lurk even at midday.

Not exalting the worthy means the people each settle into their own appointed nature and fate, without striving to surpass others, hence they do not contend.

Not valuing wealth means the people each find contentment in their own natural inclinations and fates, without coveting what they do not possess, hence they do not become thieves.

Zhuangzi said: *"Trim the deeds of the Ru historians, and muzzle the mouths of Yang and Mo."*

The virtue/power of the world thus begins to return to its original unity.

*The Traveling Wolf* says: *"Do not exalt the strange and devalue the useful; only then will the people be content. Do not show them what is desirable, lest their hearts be disordered."*

When people have desires, they will even contest their very nature and fate—plundering, deceiving, and committing every outrage. Boyi, seeing the allure of fame, starved to death beneath Chief Yang’s hill; Zhi, seeing the lure of profit, met his end on Dongling’s heights. Their passions burned like wildfire, their coldness froze like ice, and so their hearts were shattered, reckless, and uncontrollable.

Yet the Sage does not pursue profit, does not shun harm, does not rejoice in longevity, nor lament early death. He does not prize advancement nor despise obscurity. Then what is there to desire? When desires do not arise, my heart is serene. When stirred, it responds; when still, it is unobstructed. In motion, it does not chase; at rest, it does not resist. What can disturb it?

Confucius was forty and free from doubt; Mencius, forty and no longer troubled in heart—both had attained this.

Thus, the Sage’s governance aims to keep the people in a state of *wu zhi* (無知) and *wu yu* (無欲). The valley is empty and thus responsive; the mirror is empty and thus reflective. The gourd is empty and thus can receive; the ear is empty and thus can hear; the eye is empty and thus can see; the nose is empty and thus can smell. If filled, they become obstructed.

The Sage, when compelled to govern the world, treats all with equal benevolence, strengthens the near while uplifting the distant, follows what is natural, and lets things unfold of their own accord—what need for scheming? Yao’s elevation of Shun and execution of Gun nearly achieved this.

When the heart is empty, it listens impartially and observes without bias, free from likes and dislikes. When the belly is full, the mind is content and at ease, free from greed. Why exalt the worthy or blame the unworthy?

The Sage nourishes the belly, not the eyes. The belly, unselective, can contain all. The will is the mind’s knowledge; the bones are the body’s foundation. A strong will may lead one to relentlessly pursue fame or wealth, to boast of one’s abilities or flaunt one’s achievements—ever farther from the Mysterious Dao. Weak bones cause erratic movement, clashing with others until one is exhausted and cannot return.

The Sage’s will is ever humble, yet others exalt him. Ever yielding, yet others honor him first. Knowing strength, he embraces weakness; knowing glory, he embraces disgrace. This is called weakening the will to still it—nothing can then displace it. Firmly grasping it, nothing can overturn it. The unbroken essence, like that of Guangchengzi, lived twelve hundred years without decay—this is called strengthening the bones.

Zhuangzi said: *"In harmony with the unknowing, virtue does not depart. In harmony with desirelessness, this is called pristine simplicity. Pristine simplicity, and the people’s nature is preserved."*

The Sage’s governance seeks only to let the people preserve their nature. Excessive knowledge disrupts the appointed nature and fate; excessive desire drowns their natural inclinations. This is called governance, yet what chaos is greater?

Thus it is said: *"Keep the people in a state of wu zhi and wu yu, so that the learned dare not act, the eloquent dare not speak, the brave dare not display their strength, the capable dare not boast of their talents, the clever dare not scheme, and those who pride themselves on cleverness and cunning dare not multiply laws to exploit the people."* The Sage prohibits and stops all this—this is called *"the learned dare not act."*

When the Nine Virtues are fully cultivated and the talented are in their proper offices, is this not because knowledge is not prized? Simply executing the ruler’s commands and delivering them to the people—then there is nothing that cannot be governed.

The Sage’s governance is not about abandoning people and things, suddenly standing alone in a realm of non-action. It is about acting from non-action.

The transformations of all things occur in the realm of the manifest. The Sage embodies the Dao, standing above all things, unifying their completion, and ordering them. Things arise; follow them to observe their return. Things are born; guide them to their fulfillment. How could there be anything ungoverned?

When governance is supreme, the sun, moon, and stars follow their courses. When governance is supreme below, birds, beasts, grasses, and trees each fulfill their nature.

Wang Anshi said: *"Not exalting the worthy prevents contention among the people."* Discussing what is meant by *"not exalting the worthy"*:

The Sage’s heart has never sought to subdue the world through the worthy, yet the world submits to him—never without the worthy. If the people of the world are made to serve the world’s affairs, and the worthy are not exalted, then what reliance is there for governance?

The people, even in infancy, possess a natural inclination toward goodness. If they are not taught by the worthy, they cannot fully illuminate the world’s goodness. Once goodness is clear within oneself, how could the worthy not be revered? Thus, even if the laws and institutions remain, they are sufficient to restrain later chaos. If the worthy are exalted throughout the world, how could the people contend?

His intent is to make all under heaven clearly understand goodness, yet he does not advocate exalting the worthy. Still, the world is not so uniformly equal, and if the laws of exalting the worthy are abandoned, people may not necessarily understand goodness. Alas, the worthy cannot alone remedy the flaws of the unworthy—who knows the worthy who can make all under heaven sincerely and willingly submit?

Qi Huan Gong asked Guan Zhong: *"If I, alas, reach a point of no return, to whom should I entrust the state?"* Qi Huan Gong favored Yi Ya, but Guan Zhong said that Yi Ya, whom he did not often consult, was not as loyal as Xi Peng. If one elevates those who forget their superiors and rebel below, what greater harm from exalting the worthy could there be?

Some may say: *"Is this not what he means? He merely argues against its drawbacks."*

The Sage above does not prize rare and hard-to-obtain goods to the point of disturbing the heart. To exalt the worthy sparks contention; rare goods provoke theft. Both arise from what the heart desires. Thus, the Sage in governance does not command people to exalt the worthy or prize rare goods. If these two things are unseen, then the heart alone may remain undisturbed.

To exalt the worthy is good, but to prize rare goods invites theft—evil. Why reject both? For good and evil are opposites. Where there is good, there is also its opposite; both must be made to vanish.

There are two kinds of desire in the world: the desirable desire and the undesirable desire. As Mencius says, the desirable is called good—yet the eye’s delight in color, the ear’s in sound, the nose’s in scent—these are undesirable desires.

*The Explanation of Characters* states: *"谷 (gǔ) can receive; 欠 (qiàn) signifies lack."* That which can receive and endure, yet is not full—this is desire. Laozi says: *"Do not exalt the worthy, lest the people contend. Do not prize rare goods, lest the people steal. Do not display the desirable, lest the heart be disturbed."* These are Laozi’s one-sided, unbalanced words.

The ancient kings neither exalted the worthy nor despised it; neither prized rare goods nor rejected them; neither displayed the desirable nor concealed it. Yet Laozi’s words speak of the formless Dao: not exalting the worthy prevents burdening oneself with goodness; not prizing rare goods prevents burdening oneself with profit. Only thus can one remain undisturbed by the desirable.

Mencius said: *"The desirable is called good."* When goodness accumulates and fills to the divine, reaching this divine state, one no longer sees the desirable. Thus, the Sage’s governance strengthens the bones.

To empty the heart is to clarify that the worthy are not exalted; to fill the belly is to show that rare goods are not prized; to strengthen the bones is to demonstrate that the desirable is unseen.

The hearts of people differ in worthiness and unworthiness. If one exalts worthiness and unworthiness, contention arises. Thus, emptying the heart erases the distinction between worthy and unworthy, and so the worthy are not exalted. The belly, which can receive, if filled, makes rare goods mere trifles of food, sound, and color. All that is desirable becomes desire itself. Weakening the will prevents seeking; strengthening the bones ensures stability. Only by having no desires does one not see the desirable, yet remain steadfast. To have no desires yet stand firm—this is what the noble value.

If one constantly makes the people ignorant and desireless, empties their hearts, weakens their wills, and fills their bellies while strengthening their bones, the people will have no knowledge or desires. Even the wise will dare not act. If all the people are without knowledge or desire, even the wise among them will not dare to act. To act without action is to govern without fail. To act yet do nothing, to do nothing yet achieve all—this is the Sage’s way of *wuwei*, and thus nothing remains ungoverned.

Su Yingbin said: *"Not exalting the worthy prevents contention; strengthening the bones is the end."* If the worthy are exalted, the people will shame themselves for not measuring up and thus contend. If rare goods are prized, the people will suffer from lack and thus steal. If the desirable is displayed, the people will suffer from not obtaining it and thus rebel. Yet though the world knows these three as afflictions, if one seeks to abolish them outright, it is delusion.

The Sage does not act thus. Though the worthy are used, they are not exalted; though rare goods exist, they are not prized; though desirable things are present, they are not displayed. Thus, the worthy are employed yet the people do not contend; rare goods and desirable matters are before them, yet theft and chaos do not arise. Is this not the result of emptying the heart yet not filling the belly, weakening the will yet not harming the bones?

Now, if one were to exalt and display the worthy, treasure and prize goods, and flaunt the desirable, then both heart and belly would be filled. If one were to abolish them outright, then will and bones would weaken. When heart and belly are full, the people contend. When will and bones are weak, there is no foundation to stand upon.

If one constantly makes the people ignorant and desireless to the point where they dare not act, and does not flaunt these three things, then the people will know nothing to covet, their desires will be tranquil, and even the clever will have no schemes. To act without action is to govern without fail. This is to follow the natural course of these three things while neither exalting, prizing, nor displaying them—this is *wuwei*.

Lü Jifu said: *"Not exalting the worthy prevents contention."* The Sage knows that beauty is also ugliness, goodness also ungoodness, yet holds no private favor. Though he bestows all under heaven’s titles, he simply assigns duties, and the worthy are not exalted. The people’s contention always arises from comparing themselves to others in worthiness. Knowing the worthy are not exalted by the ruler, they do not contend.

*"Not prizing rare goods prevents theft."* Gathering all under heaven’s wealth is merely to nourish the people, yet rare goods are not prized. The people’s theft always arises from greed. Knowing goods are not prized by the ruler, they do not steal.

*"Not displaying the desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed."* Confucius said: *"If a man does not desire it, even if rewarded, he will not steal."* The desires of the noble are for the worthy alone.

The petty man’s desires are for wealth alone.
If I do not show what is desirable to him, then his heart will not be disturbed.

Yet this is not to abandon the worthy and leave them unused in the wilds,
Nor to discard rare goods and abandon them on the ground.
It is simply that within, they are not cherished in the heart,
And without, their traces are not left behind.

Thus, the Sage’s governance strengthens the bones.
The heart houses the spirit, and the abdomen is the heart’s dwelling.
To empty the heart is to preserve the spirit, and the abdomen becomes full.
The bones house the will, and the bones are the remnants of the kidneys.
To weaken the will is to steady the essence, and the bones grow strong.

If one always keeps the people without knowledge and without desire,
Then there will be nothing that is not governed.

The wise know that the worthy are not prized by the ruler,
And that wealth is not valued by him,
And that serving him brings no gain—
Thus, they dare not act.

Only thus can there be non-action and yet nothing remain ungoverned.

Master Lu the Farmer said:
*"Not prizing the worthy prevents contention among the people.
Abandon wisdom and discard knowledge, and the people’s profit increases a hundredfold.
Abandon benevolence and discard righteousness, and the people return to filial piety and kindness.
This is what is meant by not prizing the worthy, so the people do not contend;
Not valuing rare goods, so the people do not steal.
Abandon cleverness and discard profit, and thieves and robbers will cease.
This is what is meant by not valuing rare goods.
Not showing what is desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed.
If the people do not see goodness as desirable, then there will be no contention and disorder.
If they do not see profit as desirable, then there will be no theft and disorder.
Thus, when the Sage’s governance is complete, there will be nothing that is not governed.

The heart has knowledge and makes choices,
The abdomen has no knowledge but contains,
The will has desires and moves,
The bones have no desires but stand firm.
Therefore, the Sage’s governance empties the heart,
Fills the abdomen,
Weakens the will,
Strengthens the bones.
Empties what has knowledge,
Fills what has no knowledge—
Thus, the people can always be kept without knowledge.
Weakens what has desires,
Strengthens what has no desires—
Thus, the people can always be kept without desire."*

Master Wang Yuanze said:
*"Not prizing the worthy prevents contention among the people.
The worthy are those who excel among others—
If they are prized, the people will boast and emulate them from afar,
And contention will arise.
Not valuing rare goods prevents theft among the people.
When the people’s clothing and food are sufficient, their nature settles.
If rare goods are falsely prized, their pursuit will never cease,
And they will inevitably turn to theft.
Indeed, the people’s loss of their nature comes from false distinctions.
This chapter seeks to equalize all things,
So the people may return to their true nature.
Not showing what is desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed.
The ignorant falsely perceive what is desirable,
Which causes the heart’s dissolution and disorder.
Only the Sage knows that all things are not truly real,
Thus viewing all appearances with equal indifference and without preference.
Therefore, the heart’s mirror remains undisturbed,
And how can external things disorder it?
Thus, the Sage can neither prize the worthy nor value wealth.
Emptying the heart means no distinctions are made—
This further explains *not prizing the worthy*.
Filling the abdomen means nothing is sought or valued—
This further explains *not valuing rare goods*.
Strengthening the will leads to boasting and striving for victory,
Weakening the will means no scheming for external gain—
This again explains *not prizing the worthy*.
Strengthening the bones is for self-establishment,
And when one stands firm, external things cannot sway them—
This again explains *not valuing rare goods*.
Always keeping the people without knowledge and without desire:
Knowledge leads to false perceptions,
Desire leads to external seeking—
Once these are removed, nature and emotion settle.
If one does not prize the worthy and transforms them,
They can be made to reach a state of no desire.
Thus, the wise will not dare to act.
Those whose wisdom disrupts the masses should be restrained and stopped.
Non-action, yet nothing remains ungoverned—
Non-action is not true inaction; action lies in not acting,
With the aim of restoring their true nature.

Examining this closely, after the Three Dynasties,
There were no people who did not lose their true nature.
Thus, the noble strengthened their will and loved goodness,
Seeking the worthy without end;
The petty weakened their bones and craved profit,
Chasing wealth without satisfaction.
Strengthening the will leads to excessive knowledge,
Weakening the bones leads to excessive desire—
Whether one has knowledge or desire,
Though their pursuits differ, their harm to their true nature is the same.
The Sage is not thus.
Weakening the will means rejecting what is seen,
Lowering oneself to seek what is near,
And considering oneself as having no desires,
While the Dao suffices within.
Strengthening the bones is not for self-establishment as the worthy,
But to overcome desires for profit,
And to honor innate virtue.
Only then can fame not sway them,
Profit not drown them,
And their nature remain steadfast."*

Master Liu Zhongping said:
*"Not prizing the worthy reaches the point where the people do not steal.
Not prizing the worthy prevents contention among the people.
Not valuing rare goods prevents theft among the people.
This is the ancient Way.
Can the sages of later generations also restore it?
It is easy to not value rare goods,
But difficult to not prize those called ‘worthy.’
It is a matter of timing.
Yet there is a method to prizing the worthy.
Only when they are truly worthy should they be prized,
And yet none should be valued above others.
Thus, the world will trust this,
And contention will cease.
The *Book of Documents* says:
‘Not treasuring distant goods makes distant people respectful.’
This is not valuing wealth.
What is treasured is only the worthy,
Then near people are content—
This is prizing the worthy.
Distant people respectful means the people do not steal.
Near people content means the people do not contend.
Not showing what is desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed.
What is desirable is goodness,
What is not desired is not-goodness.
The Sage guides people with what is desirable,
And thus desire ceases.
What is desirable is understanding principle,
Without desire is fulfilling nature.
What is desirable can be spoken of to begin with people,
But cannot be demanded of them to the end.
To end with what is desirable is also to return to what is not-good.
Laozi said:
‘Not showing what is desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed.
What is desirable is goodness,
Thus it is said: *All under heaven know goodness as goodness,
And thus what is not-good already exists.*’"*

「To know the reason why goodness is goodness, one must deeply understand this truth.

Thus, when the Sage’s governance reaches its peak, there is nothing left ungoverned.
To empty one’s heart is to extinguish the love of evil,
And when the love of evil ceases, one’s resolve becomes tranquil and unified with the Dao.
Emptying the heart and weakening the resolve is how one nurtures the spirit.
Filling the belly and strengthening the bones is how one preserves one’s vital essence.

Yet the Sage always ensures the people have no knowledge and no desire.
The common people, once they know desire, cannot naturally rid themselves of it—
Only the Sage can make them so.
To empty the heart and weaken the resolve is to make them without knowledge;
To fill the belly and strengthen the bones is to make them without desire.

Moreover, the Sage ensures the people always abide by goodness.
For those who know, shame prevents wrongdoing—
When the Sage does not exalt virtue, yet the people contend, or when they covet wealth and steal,
It is because the Sage makes those who know dare not act.
If the people always abide by goodness, then even those who know dare not act—
And if they dare not act, this is truly the Dao.

The Sage does not speak of desire,
For desire arises from knowledge itself.
To act with *wu wei* (non-action) is to ensure nothing remains ungoverned.
To act with *wu wei* means to make those who dare act refrain from doing so.
When those who dare act refrain, the people without knowledge and desire find peace in their nature—
This is how the Sage governs.

The previous chapter spoke of the Sage using affairs and teaching as what should be done,
And exaltation of virtue and valuing wealth are merely remnants of such teaching—
Hence the next step: not to exalt virtue.
This chapter speaks of the Sage governing himself to transform the people,
Making them reach a state of no knowledge and no desire—
Then virtue and wealth are but external matters.

In later ages, when exaltation of virtue and valuing wealth cannot be abandoned,
Yet if the ruler can empty his heart and weaken his resolve,
Even if he complies with self-interest and merely exhausts the people to feed them,
Filling the belly and strengthening the bones will make valuing wealth difficult—
He must not enrich himself at the expense of others,
Nor hoard jade and pearls to bring ruin upon himself.
If this is so, then those who govern the people will feed them—
Who would make them contend?
If there is abundance yet no scarcity,
And boundaries are fixed, who would make them steal?

The *Chongning* commentary states:
*"When the Sage does not exalt virtue, the people do not contend, and thus all under heaven is governed without fail.*
Human beings are born in stillness—
This is the nature of Heaven.
When moved by external things, desire arises—
This is the nature of humanity.
The Sage in power does not exalt virtue nor value wealth,
So the people are not burdened by striving for goodness or profit.
If the heart is not emptied, it becomes disturbed;
If the belly is not filled, desire arises;
If the resolve is not weakened, rigidity remains;
If the bones are not strengthened, the body cannot stand.
To fill the belly is to have no craving for desire.
Mencius said:
*'If an action does not satisfy the heart, one must not do it.'*
And again:
*'When people have no hunger or thirst, the heart is still their greatest affliction.'*
Zhuangzi said:
*'The deeper one’s love of song, the shallower one’s connection to Heaven’s vital mechanism—
Shallowness brings constraint.'*
To weaken the resolve is to not exhaust one’s *qi*.
And again:
*'The scholar holds fast to his resolve.'*
But why does this text speak of weakening the resolve?
Mencius spoke of this in terms of the scholar’s conduct,
So I advance it.
Laozi spoke of this in terms of returning to the origin,
So I retreat it.

Liu Ji said:
*"When the Sage does not exalt virtue, the people do not contend, and thus all under heaven is governed without fail.*
Not to exalt virtue is to forget reputation,
And when reputation is forgotten, the people have nothing to boast or aspire to—
Thus they do not contend.
Not to value wealth is to forget profit,
And when profit is forgotten, the people have nothing to covet—
Thus they do not steal.
Not to show what is desirable is to make people rest their hearts from love and desire—
Thus they remain undisturbed.
When these three evils are removed, nature and emotion are settled.
Then one can empty the heart and fill the belly.
To empty the heart is to forget both self and external things;
To fill the belly is to preserve one’s spirit within.
To forget both self and external things is to have no desires or thoughts—
And thus the resolve naturally weakens.
To preserve one’s spirit within is to have a robust body—
And thus the bones naturally strengthen.
To weaken the resolve is to value the state of no knowledge;
To strengthen the bones is to value the state of no desire.
Hence, the Sage always ensures the people have no knowledge and no desire.
When the people have no knowledge and no desire,
They embrace simplicity and purity, and are thus born into the Dao."*

The Sage’s Dao is empty and natural, beyond contrivance.
To contrive is to ruin it; to grasp is to lose it—
Thus the wise dare not act at all.

To act without acting,
Then what is done arises from non-action,
And the marvelous workings of Nature
Leave nothing untended.

This is what Zhuangzi called:
*"Let the heart wander in simplicity,
Merge the qi with emptiness,
Follow things in their natural course,
And harbor no private schemes—
Then the world is governed,
For it has attained the Dao’s boundless, void-like power."*

Thus, the next step is to align with the Dao’s path.

Zhao Shiyuan remarked:
*"First, do not employ clever stratagems.
One: Eliminate rhetoric and sophistry.
Do not exalt the worthy, lest the people contend."*

The previous chapter spoke of the Sage’s non-action governing the world,
Yet when the work is done and not claimed,
It is the true, eternal function at play.
How could it rely on external force?

Thus, the Sage is not necessarily transcendent—
For there is no such thing as the Sage.
The wise are not discarded—
For there is no such thing as wisdom.
Only emptiness of mind remains.

Observe the Three Dynasties onward—
No one spoke of non-action.
Thus, they packed provisions for a thousand-li journey,
Sought worthy advisors to plan governance.

Laozi lamented their failure to grasp the root,
So he followed with *"Do not exalt the worthy."*

To entrust great matters does not mean entrusting small ones.
To be a Sage does not mean being merely worthy.
The great embodies the Dao’s non-action—
This is the Sage’s affair.
The small relies on cleverness and boasting—
This is the worthy’s affair.

Thus, the great Sage acts,
Governed by non-action’s root,
Letting the people each find their natural state,
And severing the hearts of ambition, rivalry, and contention.

As the *Yijing* says:
*"The Way of Heaven’s transformation—
Each returns to their true nature."*

When nature is rectified,
It remains pure and constant,
With no scheming mind—
Then who could distinguish the worthy from the unworthy?

If I wish for non-action,
I dull their ears and eyes;
If I wish for governance,
I unify their sincere hearts.

When cleverness arises, deceit follows;
When cunning intentions form, contention stirs.
When these shift,
How could they surpass governance?

The middle way of human nature can rise or fall—
Guided by the Dao, it returns to purity;
Lured by the worthy, it advances to contention.
Contention breeds contention—
The people’s nature shifts.

Though one might exalt the worthy,
Yet forbidding the people from knowing too much
Is not the same as nurturing true understanding,
Nor is it the same as teaching falsehood as virtue.

Thus, *"Do not exalt the worthy"*—
This is the operation of the most divine.

In the ancient times, rulers heard no mention of ministers.
Even the succession of Xīn and Nóng had none.
Yet when Huangdi fought at Yǒuqí,
Wind Master and Strength Master first appeared as ministers,
And when asked about governance,
He had More Area and Qi Bo as teachers.
Later, though the Sage’s Way still lingered,
The demand for assistance grew urgent.
The *Odes* say:
*"South has fine fish—
Then music and the worthy are cherished."*
*"South Mountain has a terrace—
Then music and the worthy are rejoiced in."*
Yet in *"The Simple One,"*
It criticizes the neglect of the worthy.
*"In the Hills There Is Hemp"*
Criticizes the exile of the worthy.
*"The Sly Boy"*
Criticizes not consulting the worthy in affairs.
Thus, when Great Simplicity had scattered,
The worthy could not be neglected.

Laozi, in the declining Zhou,
Wished to restore purity and return to simplicity,
So he spoke of *"not exalting the worthy."*
Not for any other reason—
Let the people be pure and simple, and they will not contend;
Let the people value things lightly, and they will not covet.

In all, it was to remedy the ills of his time.

Thus, exalting the worthy and employing the capable
Were the ancient kings’ establishment of proper rites, morality, laws, and institutions.
Not exalting the worthy, not employing the capable—
Laozi sought quietude and non-action.

Though their paths differed,
Their governance was one.

Thus, carrying a jar to water the garden,
Answering Zǐgōng’s inquiry;
Plowing fields without seeking office,
Fleeing Bóchéng’s pursuit.
And *"Horsehoof"* and *"The Thief"*—
All were scorned by the common people.

Two: Eliminate love of gain.
Do not prize hard-to-obtain goods,
Lest the people become thieves.
Do not exalt the worthy,
Lest the people contend.
Do not display desirable things,
Lest the heart be disordered.

This passage is called *"The Three Laws of Mysterious Unity."*
The first two sentences speak of governance;
The last speaks of self-cultivation.

First, master the way of self-cultivation,
Then one may govern the people.

To govern is to rectify—
Rectified, there is no deviation;
No deviation, there is no desire;
No desire, the heart is empty;
An empty heart does not stray;
When none stray, all things submit;
When all submit, clever schemes are unnecessary.

What need is there for the worthy?

Goods are exchanged for mutual benefit,
And sustenance for self and others is complete—
Though gold and jade may be prized,
They cannot fill hunger.
Guided by the Dao, each receives their due,
Without letting the low usurp the high,
Or the poor overpower the rich.
If there is competition,
Then nature’s true state is violated,
And they boast of strange, extravagant things.

This must lie in the ruler’s reverence for simplicity,
Not indulging in splendor.
When the people of the world transform without coercion,
Like Han Wen’s return of the thousand-li horse,
Or Jin Wu’s burning of the pheasant-feather robe,
Then the world’s love of goods is already stirred.

Thus, perfect governance does not rely on the three treasures.

Hanzi said:
*"The essential Way resides in the four cardinal virtues."*
Jia Yi’s extreme argument:
*"Cultivate the self with no desire,
Then the mind has no affairs—
No affairs, then tranquility arises."*

Thus, the clever dare not boast of their wisdom,
The capable dare not boast of their talents—
Who could then cater to their preferences?

Former rulers did not embody the ultimate Way,
But sought to outdo others with desires,
And deceitful ministers gained favor by indulging them—
None escaped ruin through this path.

Tai Jia said:
*"Desire destroys measures, enslaves the ears and eyes—
This is what desire does."*
Duke Zou also said:
*"Following desire is called the Way—
Exhausting it utterly."*

If one follows what others desire,
Without restraint or limit,
Then the world’s Way is exhausted by indulgence.

The Sage’s governance—
If one can eliminate desire and empty the heart,
Then the divine mind shines brightly,
Knowing the four directions is not far.

**III. Rectifying Nature and Emotions**

To see nothing desirable,
So that the heart remains undisturbed.
This means not letting any single thing weigh upon the heart—
Then the heart itself will be without attachment.

When one speaks of "seeing," it is not merely seeing with the eyes.
The six senses all perceive;
From perception arises desire,
And excessive desire disturbs the heart—
The heart is inherently impure.

Now, the eye is the foremost of the six senses.
Though called the "seeing root," the eye itself perceives,
And what it perceives—dust, objects—becomes its *jing* (境).
Though the ear is said to "listen," listening is truly a form of seeing,
And what it perceives—dust, objects—becomes its *jing*.
Though the nose is said to "smell," smelling is truly a form of seeing,
And what it perceives—dust, objects—becomes its *jing*.
Though the tongue is said to "taste," tasting is truly a form of seeing,
And what it perceives—dust, objects—becomes its *jing*.
Though the body is said to "touch," touching is truly a form of seeing,
And what it perceives—dust, objects—becomes its *jing*.
Though the mind is said to "discern," discernment is truly a form of seeing,
And what it perceives—dust, objects—becomes its *jing*.

This is called the six senses (*liùgēn* 六根).
The six senses generate six dusts (*liùchén* 六塵),
And the six dusts correspond to six *jing*s—
This is called the thirty-six *jie* (界) and eighty-one *lún* (輪) of rebirth,
The causal conditions of birth and death.

Though the objects of awareness differ,
They are all called *awareness*.
Though the objects of perception differ,
They are all called *perception*.

The six desires arise from the same mind,
And from the mind’s tendencies,
The three realms are but a single *shi* (識).

The six senses take in *jing*s,
Storing them in the mind—
The mind itself is the *zang* (藏) of *shi*.
The six senses are called the six *shi*,
With seven added above, totaling eight.

The seven *shi* are those that,
For the six *shi*, manage their functions and return to the eighth *shi*,
Also called *yi* (意).
The eighth *shi* holds the three *zang* (能藏, 所藏, 藏执),
And depends on all defiled and pure *dharma*s—
Thus it is called *zǐ* (種子).

The seven and eight *shi* are both called *yi* or *xin* (心).
Thus, the six desires defile and disturb one’s true nature—
Nature is the birth of the heart,
And the heart is the true nature itself.

From beginningless time,
You have prevented me from returning to the true Dao,
Because of your six *shi*’s insatiable grasping,
Causing this heart to ceaselessly labor,
Chasing the winds of love,
Never pausing in its frenzy.

Between looking up and down,
It flutters beyond the four seas,
Like a lamp flame in the wind, never still—
Thus, like disordered threads in the wind,
It cannot be tamed.

When the heart is not mastered,
It follows *jing*s endlessly,
Turning without rest,
Exhausting the spirit,
Daily drifting into delusion,
Transforming into strange forms,
With no way to return to its origin.

How grave is desire’s harm to nature—
Should one not be cautious?

For desire was not accumulated in a single day,
Nor was nature defiled in a single day—
Within lies *wúmíng* (無明), ruling as master.
From beginningless time until now,
Even from the moment of entering the womb,
Arising from impure *jing*s,
Karma and retribution are the cause,
And love gives birth.

From the moment of entering the womb,
Love is already present,
And within love lies desire,
Which gives rise to this heart.
By the time of infancy,
Though emotions are not yet fully awakened,
Joy and anger already stir within the heart.

Swiftly, one begins to distinguish affairs,
And the six desires arise,
Splitting into six *chù* (處),
Using one *jing* to receive,
Desire generating one mind—
Since the arising *jing*s are boundless,
The mind is also boundless.

Yet this single mind
Does not know where it dwells—
For desire prevails, and the heart is disordered.

Thus, the three realms’ first six heavens
Are called the *yùjiè* (欲界).
The first, the *Tàihuáng Yǔngzēng Tiān* (太皇黄曾天人),
Has all six sense-desires defiled.
The *Tàimíng Yùwán Tiān* (太明玉完天人),
Has one sense-desire coarse and pure,
And five coarse and defiled.
The *Qīngmíng Hétóng Tiān* (清明何童天人),
Has two sense-desires coarse and pure,
And four coarse and defiled.
The *Xuāntāi Píngyù Tiān* (玄胎平育天人),
Has three sense-desires coarse and pure,
And three coarse and defiled.
The *Míngwén Jǔ Tiān* (明文举天人),
Has four sense-desires coarse and pure,
And two coarse and defiled.
The *Shàngmíng Qīyào Tiān* (上明七曜天人),
Has five sense-desires coarse and pure,
And one coarse and defiled.

These six heavens are called the *yùjiè*.
The *Tàizhēn Kē* (太真科) says:
The first two heavens below are still coarse in retribution,
Where even bodily contact is desire.
The next two heavens take hand-holding as desire,
The fifth takes speech as desire,
And the sixth takes mere sight as desire.

Now, through these six desires,
One feels these six heavens.
For each sense-desire that is coarse and pure,
One ascends to a higher heaven.
When all six desires are transcended,
One enters the *sèjiè* (色界).

Only then does nature fully dissolve,
And one ascends to the *wúsèjiè* (無色界) heavens.
When called "without color," it means "without desire."

Indeed, at the start of cultivation,
Eliminating desire is difficult.
From the six realms to becoming human,
From the human path to sainthood,
The gate of transcendence is gradually consumed.

The *Sutra* says: *"Few desires, little selfishness,"*
The *Yì* (易) says: *"Restrain anger, suppress desire."*
The *Sutra* speaks of gradual refinement,
The *Yì* speaks of reduction.

Though scholars cultivate thus,
Those who harmonize with things like flowing water,
Without arising in thought to sever them—
Without roots, who has dust?
Without dust, who has *jing*s?
Understanding this,
One becomes a true person.

**Next, the Essentials of Governance**

**1. [Rectifying the foundation of governance]**
Thus, the Sage’s governance—
The first three sentences expound the three methods of profound meaning,
The last four sentences establish the four affairs of governance.

The character *shì* (是以) connects what follows,
Meaning the Sage understands these three principles,
And practices *xūxīn shífù* (虛心實腹),
*ruòzhì qiánggǔ* (弱志強骨)—
Thus, the Sage’s path is clearly articulated.

To not exalt the worthy is to eliminate cleverness and wisdom;
To not treasure wealth is to eliminate rare and strange things;

To see no desirable things, one’s heart finds peace.
These three principles form the foundation of governance.
Without this foundation, how can one seek stability?

The art of kingship has long been practiced.
These three principles, even the Sage has often heard them.
To hear them is to resolve to act upon them,
And their enactment lies in the four affairs.

Thus, Zengzi said:
To honor what one has heard brings clarity and brilliance,
To act upon what one knows brings radiance and grandeur.
What is meant by grandeur is to enact these four affairs:
The first is to empty the heart,
The second is to fill the belly,
The third is to weaken the will,
The fourth is to strengthen the bones.

**2. [The Depth of Emptiness]**
**Emptying the Heart**
Emptying the heart has four interpretations—three are false, one is true.
The first three are incorrect; the fourth alone is correct.

The first says: *"Like the emptiness of boundless space."*
The second says: *"Like the emptiness of a hollow valley."*
The third says: *"Like the emptiness of a tiger on a hill."*
The fourth says: *"To regard *One* as emptiness."*

The emptiness of boundless space, of hollow valleys, of a tiger on a hill—
These are all incorrect.
They cannot be likened to the void of *One*.
For if one’s heart is as empty as boundless space,
Even the solitary awakened may weary of vexation,
And though they bear no burden in their minds,
Sitting to observe the void—
The void stretches endlessly, yet nothing can be done.
How could the Sage of governance guard such emptiness as true emptiness?
This is the first error.

Again, if one takes the emptiness of a hollow valley as emptiness,
It is but a mountain’s hollowed-out cavern.
The valley’s resonance echoes with emptiness,
And when sound arises, it too is empty—
The two emptinesses merge, and only then do they respond.
Though this may seem a fine metaphor,
Scripture says: *"The spirit of the valley does not die."*
When we speak of the spirit of the valley,
We mean there is a spirit within the valley—
Not merely an empty hollow.
If the valley had no spirit,
What then would be this so-called divine essence?
When I call and it responds in harmony,
Could there be governance without a leader to initiate it?
If there is no leader yet harmony exists,
This is unnatural.
Thus, the emptiness of a valley cannot compare
To the Sage’s heart of governance.
This is the second error.

*The Book of Characters* says: *"Empty, and the hill becomes empty."*
Empty, and none dare approach.
The affairs of the king encompass the world as one family,
Not favoring only his kin,
Not cherishing only his children—
All are to be loved and benefited,
Until all under heaven turn toward him.
Could this be likened to a tiger’s isolation on a hill,
Severing all to create emptiness?
This is the third error.

Now, what is spoken of as *One* is indeed emptiness.
*One* is solid when in *Kàn* (坎), empty when in *Lì* (离).
Water and fire generate each other—
The movement of spirit and essence
Cannot for an instant be separated.
Thus, the Sage’s movement of spirit and the workings of the heart
Follow the unfathomable patterns of water and fire—
*One* is their origin.
The Dao produces *One*, and *One* is emptiness,
Not generating yet the source of all generation,
Without use yet the ancestor of all utility.
*One* is the sovereign—
In the *Xiàng* (象), three strokes form *Qián* (乾),
And three threes, two twos—
The three powers transform and adapt.
From *One* to three, to six,
Up to the three hundred eighty-four lines—
*One* encompasses all.

*One* is the divine.
To respond to emptiness with emptiness is useless—
Yet is it truly useless?
The Sage’s Way enslaves others without being enslaved,
Commands things without being commanded—
*One* without a second,
Mastering fate.
The *Han Stratagems* say: *"Fate"*—
Only the Sage can enact it.
*One* without disorder is the utmost stillness.
Stillness without change is the constant of the Way.
Change without change is the function of the Way.
When things change and I remain still, I guard *One*.
When I remain still and things move, I observe their return.
Thus, *One* is non-action,
Yet non-action is not non-doing.
The sovereign’s heart penetrates the Three Mysteries,
Enacting the four affairs—
Who would say emptiness and non-being are not governance?
This is the truth of *One* as emptiness.

**3. [The Dao is Fully *Qián*]**
**Filling the Belly**
The eight trigrams regard *Kùn* (坤) as the belly,
For it transforms into the five materials—
On earth, forming shape, *Kùn* is the storehouse,
Thus it is called the belly.
Again, the back is *yáng* (阳), the belly is *yīn* (阴),
And since it governs storage,
It holds what has passed—
Thus, it is the belly.

Earth governs intention, issuing forth as new,
Returning as what has passed—
All govern storage.
Because it holds much, it is called *filling the belly*.

Again, observing the two symbols *Kàn* (坎) and *Lì* (离),
*Kàn* is filled within—
It bears the symbol of a filled belly,
*Lì* is empty in heart—
It bears the symbol of an empty heart.
*Kàn* is firm, *Lì* is yielding—
Thus, the heart and belly are firm and yielding.

Scripture says: *"Man follows Earth,"*
And the *Yì* says: *"The way of standing on Earth is yielding and firm."*
Yet what is solid without emptiness to permeate it
Lacks divinity,
Thus it is said: *"Yellow Center, the harmony of principles."*
If emptiness does not tread upon solidity,
It cannot reach the pure, clear, awakened state.

The Commentary says:
An empty heart listens impartially and observes without bias,
Free of likes and dislikes—
This is the birth of clarity.
*Lì* is fire, the fire of enlightenment—
The Sage faces south to govern the world.
A filled belly is abundant and tranquil,
Without covetous desires,
Its capacity is public—
*Kùn* is the belly, and the belly governs receptivity—
The Sage’s central rectitude in observing the world is thus.

What was previously discussed—
Emptying the heart, filling the belly—
Reveals the Sage’s governance in action.

The functions of emptiness and fullness
In humans are affairs,
In the trigrams are *Kàn* and *Lì*,
In *qi* are *yīn* and *yáng*.
Their application in human affairs is as described,
Yet their application in *Kàn* and *Lì* differs in law.

Moreover, *yáng* is full, *yīn* is empty—
The alchemical method refines the two *bā* (八) of *yīn*,
Extending the nine *sān* (三) of *yáng*—
When *yáng* is pure, one becomes immortal;
When *yīn* is pure, one dies.
*Kàn*’s interior and exterior are *yīn*,
*Lì*’s interior and exterior are *yáng*—
Fire above, water below is *Unfinished* (未济),
Descending fire to meet water is *Completed* (既济).

From the Dao of Heaven and Earth,
From *Zǐ* to *Wǔ* it shifts to pure *yáng*,
From *Wǔ* to *Hài* it shifts to pure *yīn*—
This is the natural course of things.

Thus it is said:
Heaven and Earth move in accordance with the Way,
This is the constant method by which they transform.

Yet in the human body,
Does it not follow Heaven and Earth’s *yīn* and *yáng*?

To follow Heaven and Earth’s *yīn* and *yáng*
Is yet to have not attained the method of *zhì* (制).
One cannot but drift along with *zào huà* (造化),
Not knowing that the power to govern life lies within oneself.

The Dao of *yīn* and *yáng*:
To follow it leads to death,
To oppose it leads to life.

The Master of Taibai said:
*"Five Phases in Reverse—*
*The Dragon emerges from fire.*
*Five Phases not in order—*
*The Tiger is born in water.*
This is opposition—
Opposition brings life."

The *Tàishàng* (太上) speaks thus:
*"Water and fire align with the true substance of the Dao.*
*Their application is governed by technique,*
*So that the one *bǔ* (补) within *Kàn* fills *Lì*’s empty heart,*
*Transforming *Lì* into *Qián*—*
*Thus the Dao is complete.*
*If the heart remains empty,*
*Then *Lì* and *Kàn* are but lost in confusion.*
*The True Person says:*
*‘*Kàn*’s *yīn* is lost in confusion,*
*One *yáng* in *Lì* reveals its form.’*
*Píngshū (平叔) says:*
*‘*Point-transformation within *Lì*’s palace,*
*Deep in the *yīn* of the belly.’*
*Ultimately, it rests in attaining the One.*
*Once the One is attained,*
*It depends on the fire’s timing—*
*If the fire’s timing is insufficient,*
*How could it be supplemented?*

Some say:
*The Classics do not extend this far,*
*Only discussing the Sage’s governance.*
*How then does this relate?*
*They do not know that the Five Thousand Words*
*Are the essence of longevity.*
*Applied outwardly, they govern the world,*
*Applied inwardly, they lead to immortality.*
*Anqi Sheng was a strategist,*
*Zhang Zifang a kingmaker—*
*Anqi was not employed by Chu,*
*Zhang achieved great success in Han,*
*Yet both ascended to immortality—*
*This is the Dao of withdrawal and engagement.*
*How could the ignorant comprehend this?*

**Four: Gentle Submission and Self-Cultivation.**
*Weaken the will.*
Mencius said:
*"The will is the commander of *qi*.*
*The Commentary states:*
*The strong-willed may pursue fame without rest,*
*Or chase wealth without satisfaction.*
*Now, those who rush or retreat—*
*This is *qi* in motion.*
*If *qi* is made harmonious,*
*Internally it calms the spirit,*
*Externally it does not oppose things.*
*If not harmonious,*
*How could it avoid clenching fists and harming others,*
*Or raging and offending people?*
*It is not *qi* acting of itself—*
*The will commands it.*
*Thus it is said:*
*The will is the commander of *qi*.*

*Laozi* takes meekness and humility as the standard,
Saying the will must not be strong.
Yet in terms of governance,
If will and intent are not vast,
And understanding is not far-reaching,
How could one handle great matters?
One must be firm—
Firmness resolves softness.
Is it not that firmness alone is not enough?
Softness returns to firmness.
The Sage embodies Heaven’s alternating firmness and softness,
Each giving rise to the other.
If not decisive, it is not firm;
If firm, the Dao of *Qián* is complete.
Yet if firmness is excessive and unbalanced,
Excess brings regret.
*Qián*’s *yǔ* (用) of Nine
Reveals Heaven’s pattern—
Those who can employ Nine
Are said to have a weak will.
Yang Xiong said:
*"Seeing virtue and acting clearly—*
*The firm see virtue and clarify the Dao.*
*If the Dao is clear within me,*
*Then will and *qi* naturally grow vast.*
*In the gentleman, this is guarded with caution,*
*Hidden as if empty.*
*Thus it is guarded with weakness.*
*If one cannot guard it with weakness,*
*Then *qi* erupts and becomes impure.*

The Dao of nurturing *qi*
Finds its foundation in gentleness.
The Classic says:
*"Joyful as winter crossing a river,*
*As if fearing the neighbors."*
*So that the inner does not violate the outer,*
*Like a maiden in seclusion—*
*Otherwise, joy and anger attack each other,*
*And the harmony is injured.*
*The essence of longevity*
*Is most cautious here.*

Why not observe *Qián*’s Nine-Five—
*The Flying Dragon in Heaven,*
*Firmness in its proper place—*
*Advancing without excess,*
*For excess brings regret.*
*Dàyóu*’s Upper Nine
*Should be firm yet balanced.*
*Yet it follows sincerity and thinks of compliance,*
*Thus Heaven aids it—*
*Good fortune without hindrance.*

Still, this is timing,
Yet nature lies within it.
If one weakens the will to guard the One,
Unless one attends to it with *qi*,
It will surely reverse itself.

**Five: Establishing Virtue and Clarifying the Dao.**
*Strengthen the bones.*
What was previously called *"not valuing the worthy"*
And *"the able knowing"*—
*Peace of heart and below,*
*These four are the able in action.*
*But to strengthen the bones*
*Truly reveals the able.*

How so?
*Strong bones stand firm.*
*The Classic says:*
*"Sincerity issues from the will."*
*Mastering sincerity brings firmness.*
*Again it says:*
*"Heaven’s movement is vigorous,*
*The gentleman strengthens himself without rest."*
*Embodying *Qián*’s Dao,*
*He moves without obstruction,*
*Acts without haste—*
*Sincerity governs it.*
*Without sincerity, one does not stand.*
*This is what the supremely firm and great can practice.*

*From peace of heart and filling the belly,*
*To weakening the will in cultivation,*
*Until here—*
*This is nurturing the vast *hàorán* (浩然) *qi*,*
*Filling Heaven and Earth,*
*So mighty it cannot be uprooted.*
*Who could resist it?*
*The Classic says:*
*"The resolute have will."*
*This is first cultivating with softness,*
*Then attaining supreme firmness.*
*The Classic employs firmness before softness,*
*Laozi employs softness before firmness—*
*Each has its proper application.*

*The kidneys are one water, one stone—*
*Water is soft, symbolizing the will,*
*Stone is firm, symbolizing the bones.*
*From softness to firmness,*
*The transition is clearly seen:*
*One *yáng* arises in the depths of extreme *yīn*—*
*Softness at its extreme becomes firm.*
*One *yīn* arises in the depths of extreme *yáng*—*
*Firmness at its extreme becomes soft.*
*Thus one knows the alternating use of firmness and softness.*

*If one holds to this without acting,*
*It is called self-obscuring.*
*Self-obscuring—*
*How could it benefit the world and future generations?*

*The Sage observes Heaven’s Dao,*
*Prepares with compliance,*
*Wind, thunder, clouds, and rain applied in Heaven,*
*Rites, music, punishments, and governance applied in humanity—*
*Yet internally, one must not be firm to stand alone.*

The bones grow strong to stand firm,
Yet weakness guards them,
And uprightness guides their movement.

If one stands outstandingly erect,
Then it differs from the roots of desire.

Observe how many scholars of the Dao there are in the world—
Some know it, yet cannot guard it;
Guard it, yet cannot act upon it.
There is no other reason—
For the heart’s desire for gain overpowers,
And the Way of clarity and emptiness becomes difficult to return to.

Strengthen the will yet weaken the bones—
Like hoarding wealth without trade,
Shutting doors to guard it,
Yet unable to exchange it—
How then could one grow rich?

**Commentary:** *"The bones grow strong, yet their movement scatters and shifts—*
*This is to say there is no steadiness below."*

Only those who persist in self-strengthening
Can truly embody this.

The Three Governments’ teachings reach far—
Ever making the people without knowledge, without desire.
This sentence summarizes the preceding meaning,
While the next demonstrates the method.

Ever make the people without knowledge, without desire—
This is to emphasize:
*"Do not value the worthy,
Do not prize wealth,
Do not show what is desirable,"*
Thus achieving a hollow heart and full belly,
A weak will and strong bones.
The Sage, governing the world, relies on these seven principles—
Nothing else is needed—
Making the people without knowledge, without desire.

To value the worthy brings excessive knowledge,
Until the world is in uproar—
Confucians and Mohists arise in chaos.
To prize wealth brings excessive desire,
Until one risks life and nature for gain,
Seizing and deceiving without restraint.
To see names and profits as desirable—
All are deviations from the Dao.

Only the Sage can abandon these three,
And thus the people naturally have no knowledge,
Nor any desire.

Yet human nature is thick,
And circumstances shift with things.
For those above, cleverness and artifice
Are taught and refined—
But when carried to excess,
Laws and punishments cannot correct them.

**Master Dong said:**
*"When laws are issued, deceit arises;
When orders are given, fraud follows."*
This stems from past rulers’ poor instruction,
And the deep corruption of customs—
Not something that can be changed in a day.

Now, even if one tries to suppress it with laws,
Or reinforces it with decrees,
Their deceitful hearts remain—
Only the Dao can transform them.

Laws began with Fu Xi and were perfected by Yao,
Fully developed in the Zhou—
Yet cleverness reached its peak.
Thus it is known that when the Zhou declined,
The Dao faded.

Laozi composed the *Classic*,
Its intent here.
Yet it was not merely for his time—
It was meant as an oracle for all ages.

When chaos arose, it was no different from the Warring States—
The excess of valuing the worthy, prizing wealth, and excessive desire.

**Confucius said:**
*"The people can be made to follow, but not to understand."*

**Emperor Yao heard a child’s song:**
*"Unknowing, unknowing,
Following Heaven’s patterns."*

If those above are knowledgeable and desiring,
Yet wish the people to be without knowledge or desire—
This is impossible.
It is like hating drunkenness yet forcing wine—
Truly, nothing is better than
Using utmost sincerity to transform them,
Purity and simplicity to guard them.
If those above act as if foolish,
The people below remain unknowing—
As Zhuangzi said:
*"The ruler like a tree branch,
The people like wild deer—
What use is there for rewards and punishments?"*

Forced effort and rigid conduct,
Separating from the world and customs—
The people begin to doubt.

**Second Point: Restraining cleverness and artifice.**
Make the knowledgeable dare not act.

The *Classic* says:
*"I will deceive them with simplicity—*
*The people are hard to govern because their cleverness is excessive."*

**Zhuangzi said:**
*"When the Dao prevails in the world, the Sage completes it;
When the Dao does not prevail, the Sage arises."*

Excessive knowledge and desire
Throw the world into chaos—
Until the people lose their natural nature,
And punishment is used to suppress them—
This is the root of greater disorder.

The Qin poisoned the world—
Their cleverness was supreme,
Yet they could not use benevolence and righteousness,
Only punishment and coercion,
To govern the world—
Their kindness did not reach the people,
So their downfall came swiftly.

Yet the people were not without knowledge—
It could be hidden and unused.
Only if those above do not provoke it,
Then those below, though knowing, dare not act.

*The Yinxu Classic* says:
*"Cut off the root of gain,
And ten armies will be useless."*
This is what is meant.

If those who know dare to act,
Then even strict prohibitions are insufficient.
To this point, even if one wishes to punish them,
There are those punishment cannot reach.

Thus it is said:
*"I take no action, yet the people transform themselves."*

**Fourth: Displaying the function of *wuwei*.**

1. *Transformation proceeds without display.*

*Wuwei* yet action—
This sentence summarizes the entire meaning,
To show that the Sage, though governing through *wuwei*,
Is never without action.

*Wuwei* cuts off external interference,
Action aligns with affairs—
What is not the Dao becomes the Dao in practice.

To act without showing traces of action,
To govern without displaying governance—
This is the pinnacle.

How then does one act without showing traces,
Or govern without displaying function?

*The Book of Changes* says:
*"Motionless yet responsive,
Stirred and thus in harmony."*

The unmoving is nature,
The responsive is emotion.
Nature is originally *wuwei*—
The essence of the Dao.

The Dao as nature
Is formless in reality,
Yet at its extreme, it manifests—
From Heaven and Earth to all things,
None arise without this.

*The Commentary* says:
*"All things flourish,
Yet they all stem from *wuwei*—this is the Dao."*

Emerging from the Sage’s heart,
Responding to the divine in sequence—
Penetrating Heaven, Heaven responds;
Penetrating Earth, Earth responds—
Nothing but the movement of spirit.

What is seen in the movement of spirit—
This is action.
What moves yet shows no progress—
This is originally *wuwei*.

Moreover, if one does not act,
Could the world’s affairs be neglected for a day or two?
Neglect leads to disorder.
If one governs each matter,
Inspects each thing—
