**Volume Nine of *Zhēnyì Jiéyì* [Collected Meanings of the True Classic of Dao and Virtue]**

**Chapter: *Dàochōng* [The Dao’s Purity]**

Master Yǒngyuǎn, with profound virtue along the Dao’s mysterious path, supervised the compilation by Sì Wěiyǒng, a minister of the *Guōnmì Yùanshū* [Imperial Secretariat]. The text was annotated by Dīng Yìdōng, a former *Tàifǔ Shì Bù* [Treasury Bureau Clerk] and *Guōnmì Yuàn Biānxiū* [Editor of the Secretariat], with critical notes appended.

**Critical Notes:**
The *Héshànggōng* [Master of the Yellow River] composed the *Chapter of the Nameless Source*, while Zhào Shí’ān [Master of the Real Forest] wrote the *Chapter on the Propagation of the Harmonious Dao*.

**Emperor Xuānzōng’s Commentary:**
The previous chapter elucidated that nobility and rank are not to be pursued—non-action reveals the ultimate truth. This chapter expounds that the wondrous origin’s function lies in action without contrivance. It begins with *Dàochōng* [The Dao’s Purity], demonstrating the principle of supreme emptiness as the root of all things. Next, it speaks of *cuòjiě* [dulling and releasing], clarifying how purity in application resolves discord, concluding with the analogy of the *Xiàngdì* [August Sovereign] to guide all to its intent.

**Du Guāngtíng’s Exegesis:**
The Dao’s operation is boundless—vast as heaven and earth, subtle as a hair’s tip. In its natural repose, it neither lacks nor overflows. Applied to the body, it merges light and dust into unity; within the self, it transforms sharpness into harmony. Stretching across countless eons, it precedes even the *Xiàngdì*, standing first among all teachings. Thus, all existence finds its ultimate refuge in the Dao.

*Qu* [trend/tendency] means *xiàng* [to turn toward].

**Zhang Chōngyìng’s Interpretation:**
This chapter teaches that from the sovereign to the commoner, all who embody the natural Dao must recognize its boundless, infinite nature—mysterious and formless, yet ever-present. Hence, it is called *wúyuán* [the Nameless Source].

The Dao’s purity, when applied, is never full—
Deep as the source, it seems the origin of all things.
Dulling their sharpness,
Releasing their entanglements,
Harmonizing their brilliance,
Unifying their dust.
Vague as if it exists—
I do not know whose child it is,
Yet it precedes the *Xiàngdì*.

**Critical Notes:**
*"Or not full"* (*huò bù yíng*)—alternate readings: *"as if not full"* (*sì bù yíng*), *"seems not full"* (*sì bù yíng*).
*"Vague as if it exists"* (*kān xī sì cún*)—alternate: *"seems to exist"* (*sì rú cún*).
*"Whose child"* (*shéi zhī zǐ*)—alternate: *"whose child, indeed"* (*qí shéi zhī zǐ*).

**Héshànggōng’s Explanation:**
*The Dao’s purity, when applied*—
*Purity* (*chōng*) means *zhōng* [centrality].
The Dao conceals its name, hides its merit—its function lies in centrality, never full.
*"Or"* (*huò*) means *cháng* [constant].
The Dao is ever modest and empty, never overflowing.
*Deep as the source*—
The Dao’s depth is unfathomable, yet it seems the ancestral root of all things.
*Dulling their sharpness*—
*Sharpness* (*ruì*) means *jìn* [advancement].
When people eagerly strive for fame and gain, their ambition must be tempered—this is the Dao’s way, not self-imposed.
*Releasing their entanglements*—
*Entanglements* (*fēn*) mean *jiēgēn* [rooted conflicts].
One must reflect on the Dao’s non-action to dissolve them.
*Harmonizing their brilliance*—

「Though one may possess a singular insightful wisdom (*dújiàn zhī míng*), one must know the depths of obscurity (*ànmèi*), lest they disrupt others with their arrogance (*bù dāng yǐ ruì luàn rén yě*).
**Equalize with the common dust.**
One must align with the multitude in their filth and dust (*tóng yú zhòngshù tóng gòuchén*), not set oneself apart in singularity (*bù dāng zì bié shū*).

**Serene as if it exists.**
Speak of it with tranquil stillness (*zhàn yān ruì ruò cún*), thus enduring eternally without decay (*gù néng chángcún bù wáng*).

**I do not know whose child it is.**
Laozi says, *"I know not whence it springs."* (*Wú zhīshì shuō bù zhī qí shēng*)

**Resembling the Sovereign before the Emperor.**
The Dao exists prior to the Celestial Sovereign (*Tiān Dì zhī xiān*), thus declaring the Dao as born before Heaven and Earth (*dào zì zài tiān dì zhī qián, cǐ yán dào nǎi xiān tiān dì shēng yě*).

**To this day, it abides—**
Because it remains serene and tranquil (*néng zhànrán ānjìng*), unburdened by labor, it seeks to guide people in refining their conduct (*xiūshēn fǎdào*).

**Heshang Gong’s further elucidation:**
The Dao’s purity, when applied—
Resembling the Sovereign before the Emperor (*zhì xiàng dì zhī xiān*).
He who grasps only one household’s measure (*zhí yījiā zhī liàng*) cannot govern the household;
He who grasps only one kingdom’s measure (*zhí yīguó zhī liàng*) cannot establish the kingdom.
**Exhausting strength to lift heavy burdens, yet failing to serve its purpose.**
Thus, though one may know all things are governed (*rén suī zhī wànwù zhì yě*), if governance does not follow the **Two Principles** (*èr yí zhī dào*), it cannot endure (*zé bù néng shàn yě*).
Earth, though substantial in form (*xíngpò*), without conforming to Heaven’s **virtue** (*dé*), cannot preserve its eternal tranquility (*bù néng wánqí níng*).
Heaven, though refined in essence (*jīngxiàng*), without conforming to the Dao’s **virtue** (*dé*), cannot sustain its purity (*bù néng bǎo qí jīng*).
**Purity applied—its use cannot be exhausted.**
**Fullness begets solidity, yet solidity brings overflow; thus purity applied again does not overflow—its boundless nature is now fully revealed.**
Though form be vast, it cannot encumber its essence (*xíng suī dà bù néng lèi qí tǐ*);
Though deeds be frequent, they cannot fill its measure (*shì suī yīn bù néng chōng qí liàng*).
All things abandon this and seek their sovereign—
Where is their sovereign’s abode?
Is it not profound as if resembling the root of all things (*bù yì shàn wànwù zhī zōng hū*)?

**The Commentary says:**
To temper without loss, to disperse without effort—
**Harmonizing its brilliance** without staining its essence (*hé guāng ér bù wū qí tǐ*),
**Equalizing with the dust** without altering its truth (*tóng chén ér bù yú qí zhēn*).
Is it not serene as if it exists (*bù yì zhàn yān ruì cún hū*)?

Earth adheres to its form (*xíng*), yet its **virtue** (*dé*) cannot surpass its capacity to sustain (*zài*).
Heaven upholds its essence (*xiàng*), yet its **virtue** (*dé*) cannot surpass its coverage (*fù*).
Neither Heaven nor Earth can reach it—
Is it not resembling the Sovereign before the Emperor (*bù yì shàn dì zhī xiān hū*)?
**Emperor** (*Dì*), here meaning the **Celestial Sovereign** (*Tiān Dì*).

**Emperor Tang Ming Huang’s Explanation:**
The Dao’s purity, when applied—
**Or** (*huò*) means **constantly** (*bù yíng*).
The Dao moves through **purity** (*chōng*), generating **harmonious qi** (*héqì*), and its use brings forth all things (*yòng shēng wànwù*), yet it never overflows with its merit (*yǒu shēngchéng zhī gōng, zēng bù yíngmǎn*).
**Saying "or" as if it exists**—
This is the Dao’s ineffable essence (*yú dào bù gǎn zhèngyán yě*).
**Profound as the source**—
**Profound** (*yuān*), here meaning **deep and tranquil** (*shēn jìng*).
The Dao constantly generates all things yet never overflows (*dào cháng shēng wànwù ér bù yíngmǎn*), its wondrous origin being profound and tranquil (*miàoběn yuān shēn jìng*), thus resembling the sovereign root of all things (*gù shì wànwù zhī zōngzhǔ yě*).

**The Commentary further expounds:**
Purity (*chōng*) is **emptiness** (*xū*).
It means the Dao employs **emptiness** (*xū*) as its function (*wéi yòng yě*).
**Harmonious qi**, being pure and empty (*héqì chōngxū*), thus serves as the Dao’s use (*gù wéi dào yòng*).
Its use generates all things (*yòng shēng wànwù*), and all things receive its merit (*wù bèi qí gōng*).
When discussing merit, things seem to doubt its brilliance (*lùn gōng zé wù yí qí guāngdà*), yet when speaking of purity, the Dao remains ever unoverflowing (*yǔ chōng zé dào cháng bù yíngmǎn*).
**Or** (*huò*), its wondrous origin being profound and tranquil (*miàoběn shēnjìng*), constantly as the root of all things (*cháng wéi wànwù zhī zōng*).
**Saying "or" as if it exists**—
The Dao has no fixed form (*dào fēi yǒu fǎ*), thus it cannot be spoken of directly (*gù bù zhèngyán ěr*).
All else follows this pattern (*tā jiē fǎng cǐ*).
**Tempering their sharpness, dispersing their entanglements.**
The Dao, through **purity** (*chōng*) and **harmony** (*hé*), can suppress the **advancing** (*jìn*) and **sharp** (*ruì*), release the **rooted conflicts** (*jiēgēn*).
If the **common scholars** (*súxué*) seek to restore, their entanglements only deepen (*ruò súxué qiú fù, zé mí jiégēn yě*).

**The Commentary says:**
**Temper** (*cuò*) means **suppress** (*yì zhǐ*).
**Sharp** (*ruì*) means **advancing** (*jìn*).
**Release** (*jiě*) means **dispel** (*shì sàn*).

The **purity and emptiness** of the Dao’s function knows no resistance—thus, the **advancing and sharp** hearts, the **entangled and chaotic** affairs, all naturally **suppress and disperse** when one contemplates the Dao’s **purity and harmony**.

This is how one **guides humanity** to understand the Dao’s function.

**The Commentary says:**
The **common scholars** seek to restore their original nature (*súxué qiú fù qí chū*), yet their **advancing sharpness** and **entangled chaos** arise from desire—thus, contemplating the Dao **suppresses and disperses** them, while **common learning** only **deepens the knots**.

**Harmonizing its light, blending with the dust.**
The Dao is nowhere absent, yet wherever it is, it is always **non-existent**.
In light, it is one with light; in dust, it is one with dust.
One with light and dust, yet neither light nor dust.
**Deep and vast**, as if something exists.

**Harmonizing its light and blending with the dust**, yet its **mystic origin** remains **unobstructed**—thus, it appears **deep and vast**, as if something persists.

**The Commentary says:**
The Dao’s **purity and emptiness** in its function is **unexhausted** in all things.
In light, it merges with light; in dust, it merges with dust.
Nowhere is it absent, yet wherever it is, it is always **non-existent**.
Through **purity and harmony**, it can **blend light and dust**, yet its **mystic origin** remains **deep and still, unmixed**.
Thus, it is said to appear as if something exists.

**I do not know whose child I am, yet I resemble the Emperor before creation.**

I do not know my origin—**the Dao is not born**, for it has no form.
The Dao seems to exist before the Emperor, for the Emperor is the **sovereign of all things**.
**Resemble** means **to appear as**.

**The Commentary says:**
**"I"** refers to Laozi’s self-designation.
**Resemble** means **to appear as**.
Laozi says: *"I see the Dao’s purity and emptiness, giving rise to all things together.
Seeking its source, I cannot fathom its origin.
Since the Dao has no father, who could know it as a child?
All things depend on the Dao for birth, thus it seems to exist before the Emperor."*

**The Commentary says:**
The Emperor is the **sovereign of all transformations**.
*The Book of Changes* says: *"The Emperor emerges from **Zhen (☳)**."*
**Zhen** is the **eastern hexagram**, the **minor yang qi**, the **source of transformation and birth**.
Now, the heir apparent resides in the **eastern palace**, in the **minor yang position**, ascending to the throne as the **period of Zhen’s emergence**—this symbolizes the **beginning of heaven and earth nurturing all things**.

**Manifesting as an image** is called **resemblance**—**the unseen is qi**, **manifesting form is image**, the **first of all things**.
The **first of all things**, resembling the Emperor, stands before him.
The **Great Dao’s purity and emptiness** is the **root of all things**.
The Dao is always **humble and unfilled**, **pure and harmonious**, **serene and still**, dwelling within—**deep, mysterious, and tranquil**, the **sovereign of all things**.
Thus, if things lose the Dao’s **purity and harmony**, they will **decay and perish**.
If a person loses the Dao’s **purity and harmony**, they will **die and be extinguished**.
If a ruler loses the Dao’s **purity and harmony**, governance will be **disordered and the people will scatter**.
If a subject loses the Dao’s **purity and harmony**, their **reputation will vanish and they will be humiliated**.

Thus, one knows that the Dao of **purity and harmony** is what all things **rely upon for stability**—it is the **root of all things**.
Speak of its **function in all things**, and it is **bright and vast**.
Seek its **mystic origin**, and it is **deep and ever-empty**.
The Dao cannot be **directly spoken of as existing**, yet all things have the Dao.
**Following this pattern**, one does not dare speak of it directly.

**Suppressing their sharpness, dispersing their entanglements.**
Governance through the Dao of **purity and harmony** means there is no **advancing sharpness** to harm things, no **chaotic affairs** to harm people.
If no harm comes to things, then **all nations will come to court**, the **four barbarians will turn to transformation**, **weapons will not rise**, and **grievances will not arise**.
They will not **pursue territorial expansion or conquest**, nor **oppress the weak or few**.

If no harm comes to people, then **they will be governed in due season**, **taxes and labor will be light**, and **families will be ample, people sufficient**.

For those who **govern themselves**, they **dispel entanglements and suppress sharpness**—
externally, there is no **competition or intrusion**,
internally, they **embrace clarity and emptiness**,
their **spirit is at ease, their body secure**,
and they **find tranquility in natural ease**.

**Guiding humanity to clarify the Dao’s function** is to show that **humanity must depend on the Dao**.

As *Zhuangzi’s* **"Xiu Xing" chapter** says: *"The common scholars seek to restore their original nature"*—
once humanity has become entangled in worldly affairs, yet they wish to **recover their primordial nature through worldly learning**, their pursuit only **further distorts the Way**.
**Common learning** only **deepens the knots**—
the **advancing sharpness** and **chaotic affairs**, if not **suppressed and dispersed by the Dao**, will only **bind tighter in worldly entanglement**, becoming **unbreakable**.

**Common scholars** are those who **pursue worldly knowledge**, not the **Way of daily diminishment**.

**Harmonizing its light until it is deep and vast, as if something exists.**
The Dao of **purity and harmony** pervades all beings,
**vast and unobstructed**, yet all things are within it—
this is **harmonizing light and blending with dust**.
**Light** is **clarity and purity**; **dust** is **chaos and confusion**.
The **virtuous person** does not **stand out rigidly**, but **aligns with the multitude**.
**Buon** means **lacking**.

Though the Dao pervades all beings, its **mystic origin** remains **congealed in stillness, pure and empty**, never **exhausted or absent**—
thus, it is said to **persist as if something exists**.

**I do not know whose child I am, yet I resemble the Emperor before creation.**
The Emperor is the **first of all transformations**, the **original sovereign**, whose **form and image first emerged**, whom **rulers shepherd**—
thus, it is said to **resemble the Emperor**.

The **Great Dao’s purity and emptiness** gives rise to all transformations—
thus, it exists **before the Emperor**.
The **Great Sage Laozi**—could he not know the **root of the Dao**?
He **feigns doubt and resemblance** to **awaken those lost in worldly affairs**.

As before, the **Great Dao cannot be directly spoken of**.

*The Book of Changes* says: *"The Emperor emerges from **Zhen (☳)**—all things are born.
**Uniform in Xun (☴)**, all things are purified.
**Encountered in Li (☲)**, the sage faces south, bringing enlightenment.
**Fulfills its role in Kun (☷)**, all things are nourished.
**Explains itself in Dui (☱)**, all things find joy."*

Following, **correctly expounding** the **subtle application**.

One: **diminishing stillness, obscuring response**.
Dulling its sharpness,
unraveling its chaos,
harmonizing its light,
equalizing its dust—
these four are all **human affairs**,
yet human affairs do not depart from the Dao.
Using the Dao in balance to respond to them.

The **Commentary** says:
*"To harmonize all under heaven’s intentions,
so that none enter without finding their own fulfillment."*

Now, these four:
respond externally yet apply internally,
all are matters of **nature’s division**.

Dulling its sharpness—
**One *qi*** generates humanity,
filling the four limbs abundantly,
*qi* within us—
none are not fully filled.

If one does not nourish it with evenness,
harmonize it with nature,
then strife will arise at times—
when it arises, it overflows outward as **excessive rigidity**,
and excessive rigidity harms things.
Those who understand this
will, when encountering rigidity, naturally restrain themselves.

Thus it is said, *"Dull its sharpness"*—
**dulling one’s own sharpness**.

**Unraveling its chaos**—
All things fill the space between heaven and earth,
none without affairs.
When myriad affairs press upon me,
I must know them,
and contain them within **Oneness**,
then they will quiet and cease.
If I follow them with movement,
they will harmonize and flow.
To quiet and cease them brings clarity,
but to follow and drift drowns one.
Thus, **unraveling chaos** means
**containing them within Oneness to still them**.

**Harmonizing its light**—
Light is the scattering of clarity.
If inner sincerity does not falter,
form and strategy manifest as light.
Light within me,
like carrying the sun and moon while walking,
seeking to overcome others’ light with my own—
how could one know that others’ light also illuminates my light?
Better to forget oneself in Dao/Way’s art—
what difference is there between you and me?

**Equalizing its dust**—
Human life has never lacked distinctions of high and low.
If distinctions exist, nearly all will argue.
If one does not cling to them,
nearly all will align.
Thus, **unequal** is the division of high and low,
while **equalizing** is the matter of virtue/nature.
In essence, what the **Noble One** aligns in is only nature’s division.

As the saying goes:
*"The Noble One harmonizes yet does not align,
the petty aligns yet does not harmonize."*

**Two: Embracing emptiness to respond.**
**Deep and vast, as if it exists.**

When things overflow,
in affairs, it is excess.
When water overflows,
in vessels, it spills.
Neither excess nor spilling—
only **deep and vast**, and that is all.
**Deep** is clarity.
Illustrating the **Dao’s essence**.

The Dao is not an affair,
nor is it water.
To call it clarity is not clarity,
to call it obscure is not obscure.
When it is sensed, it communicates—
**as if it exists**, yet only seems so.

**Later clarity, without beginning.**
**One: Manifesting without a master.**
I do not know whose child it is,
emerging from the **Great Emptiness**.
The **Great Emptiness** has no name—
whose father could it be?

**Two: Independent and profound darkness.**
**Embodying the Sovereign before all.**
This chapter first speaks of application,
then of subtlety—
thus, subtlety is revealed through application.
When subtlety is revealed,
it lies in *"I do not know whose child it is,"*
**embodying the Sovereign before all.**

The **Commentary** says:
*"Embodiment is the first appearance of things,
the Sovereign is the divine response to things.
With embodiment and things—
could this be the Dao?
The preceding text merely initially speaks of application,
then of calming the heart,
until ‘not overflowing or seeming to exist,’
all correctly expounding the Dao’s great essence."*

**Not overflowing** is not reaching the limit of numbers to overflow.
**As if the root of all things**, yet not assuming responsibility for affairs.
**Deep and vast, as if it exists**—
being and non-being cannot exhaust it.
Then, embodying the Sovereign cannot precede it,
whose child it is cannot be known.

**Shao Ruo Yu** says:
*"The Dao is boundless in its application,
as if it does not overflow until it embodies the Sovereign before all."*

The **Great Dao** with boundless *qi* transforms into **One Qi**.
**One Qi** divides into yin and yang.
Yin and yang generate transformation,
receiving **One Qi** as their master—
thus knowing that **One Qi** dwells within yin and yang,
hence it is called **boundless qi**.

The **Great Dao** applies boundless *qi*—
like heaven covering, earth bearing,
the sun shining, the moon attending,
winter’s cold, summer’s heat,
spring’s birth, autumn’s gathering—
all are the application of boundless *qi*.
Boundless *qi* is **present yet formless,
absent yet precise**,
between heaven and earth—
neither overflowing nor deficient.

**Deep and vast, as if the root of all things**—
Those who study seek boundless *qi*:
they must dull their heart’s sharpness.
When sharpness ceases, the will rests,
thus able to unravel affairs’ chaos.
With a tranquil will and few desires,
one harmonizes light;
without contending with things,
one equalizes dust.
With neither inner nor outer defilement,
**deep and vast**—
only a **single heart** remains.
Though its traces are unseen,
**as if it exists**.

The **Buddhist School** likens it to a bright lamp and moon,
**alchemists** call it the **Great Elixir, Golden Pill**,
**Mencius** called it **浩然之气**—
speaking of the utmost greatness and rigidity,
nurtured upright without harm,
filling heaven and earth—
this *qi* aligns with virtue and the Dao.

**Laozi** points to *"deep and vast, as if it exists"*—
this is the **One Qi** transformed by the **Great Dao**.
*"I do not know whose child it is"*—
this embodies the **Sovereign of all things** before yin and yang.

**Wang Zhi Ran** says:
*"The Dao is boundless in its application,
as if it does not overflow until it embodies the Sovereign before all."*

Heaven and earth are vast,
all things are numerous—
the **One Qi** of all under heaven,
where is it not the Dao?
Humans dwell within their domain,
receiving the proper yin and yang,
boundless, harmonious, yielding, and compliant—
this is **humanity’s middle**,
born with heaven and earth,
sharing substance with all things.
If one applies it with balance,
it is called **the Middle Dao**;
if one attains its constancy,
it is called **the Constant Dao**.

**Boundless** is **middle**—
neither excess nor deficiency,
always within the appropriate measure,
boundless, expansive, and limitless,
pouring in yet never full,
drawing yet never exhausted,
upright in the divisions of **ren** and **yi**,
penetrating the essence of nature and life.

The ignorant do not know,
thus **Laozi** repeatedly emphasizes this,
while scholars often fear losing their way.

**Nurturing nature correctly**—
when still, it shares virtue with yin;
when moving, it shares waves with yang.
Sometimes dispersing, sometimes differing,
sometimes gathering, sometimes ceasing—
even in speech and silence,
affairs must have a master,
words must have a root.
**Root** is the root of this,
**application** is the application of this.

Moreover, the Dao generates all things,
yet the Dao never departs from things,
things never depart from the Dao.
Like rivers differing yet all returning to the sea,
or myriad teachings differing yet all returning to the Dao.

The Dao as a thing—
only **dim and indistinct**,
constantly dwelling between being and non-being,
cannot be pointed to in definite terms,
thus it is said: *"Deep and vast, as if the root of all things."*

「Some say it is deep yet seems as if it might exist,
its use is like the unfilled—this is the nature of it.

To blunt its sharpness, to untangle its confusion,
Zhuangzi said: *"The sage dwells among things without harming them,
and things cannot harm the sage.*
The sharp—if it has this, it need not be blunted,
for what sharpness remains?
The sage empties himself to wander in the world,
serene yet boundless,
all beauties follow him,
yet he does not engage with things,
dissolving like ice melting away.
The confused—if it has this, it need not be untangled,
for what confusion remains?"
Ah! The scholars of old and those of today
have differing words.

The ancient **Perfect Ones** (*zhìrén*) do not pursue profit,
do not abandon harm,
do not boast of prominence,
do not lament obscurity,
do not hoard judgments of right/wrong or good/evil.
Internally upright, they follow Heaven’s **Dao** (*Tian’s Way*),
externally adaptable, they follow humanity’s **Dao**.
Filled yet luminous, they shine without dazzling,
never uttering abrupt or extravagant claims.
The so-called "shining" is not without harmony,
the so-called "dusty" is not without unity—
how could they strive to force harmony and uniformity?
Just as Liezi dwelled in Zheng for forty years,
and no one recognized him,
the king and ministers, nobles and officials,
regarded him no differently than the common folk.
Laozi spoke of neighboring lands where
the sounds of roosters and dogs could be heard,
yet the people lived and died without ever visiting one another.
This may truly be called dwelling in ease and following the natural order,
finding their proper place.

Now, there are things that blend into unity,
born before Heaven and Earth,
silent and vast,
self-sufficient and unchanging.
Laozi said of himself: *"I do not know whose child I am,
I am before the **Archetypal Sovereign** (*Xiàngdì*)."*
The formless form, the symbol without substance—
this is the **Archetypal Sovereign** (*Shén Dì*) as the first emperor,
the **Dao** before any beginning.
*"I do not know myself"*—then who can I say I am?
This is not the **Dao**’s own origin,
yet how could it be otherwise?
Scholars should know what comes first and what follows,
striving earnestly to seek it out.

Huang Maocai said: *"The **Dao** is boundless, and its application reaches before the **Archetypal Sovereign**.
Yin and yang together are called **Dao**.
Boundless is the harmony of yin and yang’s **qi**.
Its use is like the unfilled—
empty, yet able to respond.
Deep, like the root of all things,
stillness can encompass all existence.
To blunt its sharpness—
not to compete with things.
To untangle its confusion—
each has its own order, yet nothing is disordered.
To harmonize its light—
to conceal it within oneself.
To blend with the dust—
to merge with the common.
Deep yet seems as if it might exist—
constantly existing yet never destroyed.
‘I do not know whose child I am, before the **Archetypal Sovereign**’—
this is the **Dao**.
The **Dao** originally has no name,
some call it the **Transforming Artificer** (*Huàgōng*),
some call it the **Creator** (*Zàowù*),
some call it before the **Archetypal Sovereign**—
all are forced names."*

Cheng Tai said: *"The **Dao** is boundless, and its application reaches to the root of all things.
Boundless is the opposite of full—
humble yet boundless, youthful yet boundless, vast yet boundless,
**harmonizing qi** is boundless—
all mean not to be extreme in fullness.
Zhuangzi likened the **Dao** to filling Heaven and Earth.
If it is both filling and full,
then its fullness is manifest.
Fullness is the **Dao**’s presence in all things.
Since fullness is honored,
yet boundless is also honored,
the more one uses the **Dao**,
the more one should be thus.
Like saying ‘knowing the male while guarding the female,
knowing the white while dwelling in the black’—
this is having both the male and female
yet resting in the female,
having both the white and black
yet dwelling in the black.
This is to be boundless in fullness,
seeking emptiness in the midst of it.
Thus it is called **boundless application** (*chōngyòng*).

Zhuangzi said: *"Carve and polish to return to simplicity,
do not be a **nominal sage** (*míngshī*)—
a name without substance,
do not be a **scheming strategist** (*móufǔ*)—
a mind without purpose,
do not be a **taskmaster** (*shìrèn*)—
a role without responsibility,
do not be a **master of knowledge** (*zhīzhǔ*)—
a scholar without true understanding.
To exhaust what Heaven bestows
yet show no trace of gain—
this is also emptiness.
Heaven’s single nature can fully possess all things,
yet it seems as if it has never gained anything—
this is to be boundless in fullness,
seeking to reach emptiness.
Thus, the **scheming strategist**,
the **taskmaster**,
the **master of knowledge**—
those who tread in its traces yet are truly substantial,
are indeed those who
have no inability yet never willingly probe to the end.
Is this not blaming fullness
and seeking emptiness instead?
All things under Heaven are born from existence,
existence from non-existence—
thus non-existence is the root of all things.
Once one has applied the **Dao**,
it emerges as **virtue** (*dé*),
and **virtue** divides into
**ren** (*仁*), **yi** (*义*), and **li** (*礼*).
How then can one rightly call it non-existence?
If one cannot contain non-existence,
then one should seek its nearest likeness—
only boundless can approach it.
‘The unfilled’—
this is not truly lacking,
merely doubt.
‘Seems as if it might exist’—
this is not daring to assert a definite claim.
The unfilled—
it is not yet able to swiftly reach non-existence,
thus it only seems like it.
This is all speaking of the **Dao**’s presence in humanity,
matching it to the **Dao** itself.

To blunt its sharpness, to untangle its confusion.
Sharpness—
the outward form of talent and wisdom,
with thorns and angles.
Confusion—
the details of affairs,
entangled and complex.
This is what Zhuangzi called the **sticky and agitated** (*jiāojiāo rǎorǎo*).
To blunt its sharpness—
to be thick and solid without exposure,
to untangle its confusion—
to be simple yet not disjointed.
To harmonize its light—
good faith fills one’s substance,
reaching luminosity.
The universe is stable and settled—
emanating from Heaven’s light,
its depth and brilliance vary,
yet its radiance is unified within and without.
If one embodies the **Dao**’s fullness
and manifests it in practice,
then its light is clear as the sun and moon—
people will not be able to approach it at all.
Shining yet not dazzling—
this is to seek unity with things.
Zhuangzi expounded the **Original Abode** (*Xuánshě*), rising from his seat,
and spoke of the light arising from form—
was this not also about harmonizing light and setting restraints?
To blend with the dust.»

「The dust is neither earth nor mere vapor,
but when aligned with worldly affairs,
its drifting and polluting nature is revealed.
If one can harmonize with it,
then even whiteness may enter *nirvana*,
while those who expose their nakedness,
unable to be cleansed,
are beyond reach.

Yet if one adorns wisdom to dazzle the foolish
or refines the body to reveal impurity,
it is contrary to this principle.

Deep and tranquil, as if something exists—
when sharpness is blunted and confusion untangled,
its response to things is natural, yet its function unseen.
When light blends with dust,
it mingles with the vulgar, unable to distinguish itself.
At first glance,
the **Dao/Way** seems distant from humanity.
But upon closer inspection,
its tranquil purity without admixture
shows that the **Dao/Way** is never truly absent.

Great fullness is like emptiness—
this is its proper state.

The later passages on *守雌* (keeping the female) and *守黑* (keeping the dark)
all speak of the constant **virtue/power** that is never lost—
this aligns with the present discussion.

When it says *"seems"* and *"as if,"*
it refers to what people cannot fully grasp.

If one gazes and is startled by its keen discernment,
quick wit, and agility,
it is merely talent and intelligence—
not the **Dao/Way**.

I do not know whose offspring it is,
nor whether it precedes the *Xiàngdì* (August Sovereign).
The **Dao/Way**’s essence is nonexistent—
truly the mother of Heaven and Earth,
yet Zhuangzi expands it, saying *"shén guǐ shén dì shēng tiān shēng dì"* (the divine spirits, divine sovereigns give birth to Heaven and Earth),
so the **Dao/Way** must indeed have existed before the August Sovereign.

The world has a beginning,
and this is called the mother of the world.
Having obtained its mother to know its offspring,
all things that arise from the **Dao/Way**
are its children.

This passage discusses the **Dao/Way**’s application,
summarizing the original and the nonexistent from the previous chapter,
and extending it to humanity.
If a person embodies the **Dao/Way** and can
make it empty so it does not overflow,
and obscure so it seems as if something exists,
then what they contain is nearly nonexistent.

If one is a person,
I do not know who could be its child.
Approximating its equal rank,
it might even precede the August Sovereign.
To speak deeply of **virtue/power** and align with the **Dao/Way**,
the world will find none who can surpass it.
To grasp its utmost excellence,
one might even precede the August Sovereign.

Discussing those who act in the world,
their affliction lies in their sharpness and swiftness
not being able to keep pace with events.
Yet the teachings of Laozi suppress and conceal,
fearing any exposure,
so their self-conduct is gentle, weak,
feminine, dark,
humble, lowly, and solitary—
unwilling to receive blame,
to take the lead, or to dare to act first.
This is not merely about
responding to events with non-interference—
there is a deeper principle.

The **Dao/Way** originates from nonexistence,
yet those who follow the **Dao/Way** all engage with existence.
If they dwell in existence and act in existence,
it is like using oil to wash oil—
only adding more filth,
with no way to attain purity.
Thus, one must root in nonexistence to govern existence,
and seek to eliminate existence to approach nonexistence.

Practicing with gentleness and resting in emptiness,
though not yet fully nonexistent,
is near to it.

When it says *"obtaining the mother to know the child,"*
and then *"knowing the child while still guarding the mother,"*
there is good reason for this.

From nonexistence, one observes existence,
and through existence, one comprehends nonexistence—
the inner and outer are always in accord.

It also says:
*"The weak are the **Dao/Way**’s application—*
the world’s myriad things are born from existence,
existence from nonexistence.
This is why the weak replace the strong,
knowing that existence must return to nonexistence."

The first chapter establishes the dual names of *有* (existence) and *无* (nonexistence),
summarizing the essence of the great **Dao/Way**.
This chapter contrasts *冲* (emptiness) and *盈* (fullness),
summarizing the practice of the **Dao/Way**.
If a person embodies the **Dao/Way** and reaches this point,
then Heaven and Earth cannot claim them as their children,
and entering from nonexistence to the original,
from the original to the wondrous,
there is nothing unattainable.

Zhān Qiūpǔ said:
*"The **Dao/Way** is empty, yet its application reaches before the August Sovereign.
The chapter on 'no source' states that the **Dao/Way** uses emptiness and subtlety,
so as not to overflow or be excessive,
but to be profound and hidden, nurturing all things as their sovereign root.
It must blunt its sharpness to become simple and unadorned,
untangle its confusion to become orderly,
then it can harmonize and illuminate,
mix with the dust of the world,
and this **Dao/Way**, profound and boundless,
is without source.
I do not know where it originates,
nor whether it precedes the August Sovereign’s authority—
how could one encounter it without seeing its beginning?"*

Zhāng Chōngyìng replied:
*"The **Dao/Way** is empty, yet its application reaches before the August Sovereign.
Earth follows Heaven,
Heaven follows the **Dao/Way**,
and the **Dao/Way** follows natural spontaneity.
The **Dao/Way** of natural spontaneity flows without interruption,
leaving no trace or form—
its emptiness is boundless,
its application ceaseless.
In spring, it is harmonious;
in summer, it is warm;
in autumn, it is clear;
in winter, it is frozen—
yet the yang nourishes and the yin distributes,
without any partiality or excess.
Humans, confined in their blood-flesh bodies,
endowed with yin-yang *qi*,
reach upward to Heaven,
walk downward on Earth,
and within hold natural spontaneity.
If one can empty this **Dao/Way** and apply it,
leading to no overflow or loss,
then the **Dao/Way** is profound and subtle,
and the body unifies with Heaven and Earth.
How could the myriad things fail to take it as their root?
Thus, when ambition is sharp,
one must retreat to blunt it—
lest Jiè Tuī perish in fire,
or Chú Nǚ die for a tree.
When affairs are chaotic,
one must simplify to resolve them—
lest the Six States be provoked to attack Qin,
or Jian Li die for a bright reputation.

To harmonize its light—
not relying on one’s own brilliance
to extinguish others’ brilliance,
one should be like the sun and moon shining together
without any loss of clarity.
To blend with the dust—
not relying on one’s own purity
to defame others’ purity,
one should be like pearls and jade falling into mud
without risk of harm or suspicion,
then this mind is deep and tranquil,
clear and without residue,
unaffected by chaos,
and the **Dao/Way** remains constant within it.

Thus, aligning with Heaven and Earth to enjoy longevity—
yet I do not know whose offspring it is,
preceding Heaven and Earth in establishing the **Dao/Way**,
and so embodying the August Sovereign’s authority before them."*

Zhāng Língyìng said:
*"Boldness and sharpness are the root of harmful *qi*;
chaos and excess are the source of lost essence."*

「To rely on one’s own brilliance is to risk injuring one’s spirit;
to be arrogant risks damaging one’s body.
Those who wish to learn the **Dao/Way** must be cautious here—
when encountering sharpness, they must blunt it,
when encountering chaos, they must dissolve it,
blending their light with that of others,
merging their dust with the common dust,
then the *qi* will not be harmful,
the essence will not be lost,
the spirit will not be injured,
and the body will not be damaged,
thus fulfilling the hope of longevity.

The *Dexing* ["Classic of Virtue"] in the chapter "Mysterious Virtue" again cites these four principles,
for those who seek to attain the realm of **Dao/Way** with virtue
must also heed these warnings.

Bái Yùchán said:
*"The **Dao/Way** is vast yet finds application—
sometimes appearing insufficient.
Within emptiness, it is profound.
Like the source of all things, it is the mind itself.
Blunt its sharpness, gather the spirit.
Dissolve its chaos, still the thoughts.
Blend its light, conceal the mind within the mind so it is unseen.
Merge its dust, blend the mind with the myriad things.
Deep and tranquil, it seems to exist—
preserving the spirit in the formless.
I do not know—
whose offspring it is,
embodying the August Sovereign’s authority before them."*

Liáo Cuìrán then replied:
*"The **Dao/Way** is vast yet finds application—
its *qi* is originally boundless and unrestrained,
yet it is without form to serve its purpose.
Sometimes it seems insufficient.
Profound, it is like water’s clarity and depth,
neither full nor overflowing,
appearing as the source of all things.
At rest, it is like the sea receiving all rivers;
in motion, all rivers flow toward the sea.
Blunt its sharpness—
when thoughts arise, strike them with one cut,
with the wisdom-sword that has no blade,
capable of severing all demons.
Dissolve its chaos—
all concerns vanish instantly,
not a thread remaining,
purifying the subtle vision,
bathing and nurturing the Golden Elixir.
Blend its light—
returning reflection inward,
desiring to restore its brilliance."*

「To grasp the origin of the elixir’s birth—
the moon’s glow shines night and day upon the Western Lands.
To blend with its dust.

Mind and body as one, form and virtue united,
the *block-and-fire* alchemy reversed—
dragons emerge from flames.
When the Five Phases act disorderly,
tigers are born in water.
Deep and still, it seems to linger yet persist.
Pure and unadulterated, its stillness is boundless,
its nature clear as heaven’s brilliance.
I do not know whose child it is,
yet it precedes the Sovereign’s likeness.
Who dares cast off the old and fails to recognize their own face?
This is ultimately called what?

The Supreme Way’s natural roots run deep—
immovable, where is it not honored?
Chen Bìxū said:
*"The Dao/Way is vast yet finds application—
sometimes it seems insufficient.
Vast (*chōng*), it is empty (*xū*), yet also central (*zhōng*).
Sometimes (*hù*), an undefined term—
also meaning constant (*cháng*).
It speaks of the Dao/Way using vastness and emptiness as its application.

For the *qi* of harmony is vast and empty,
thus it serves as the Dao/Way’s application.
The Sage attains the use of vast emptiness,
so the myriad chariots abandon their wealth.
The commoner attains the use of vast emptiness,
so the humble dwelling forgets its poverty.
Though seated in halls of power,
their mind is as still as those in mountain caves,
their body clad in coarse rags,
yet they do not differ from the adorned.
This is the profound attainment of vast emptiness,
yet it is never full or overflowing.

Yán Jūnping said:
*"To act as vast (*chōng*) yet not be vast,
to act as harmonious (*hé*) yet not be harmonious—
not acting as vast or harmonious,
yet truly attaining vastness and harmony.
Vastness resides in emptiness,
harmony has no fixed abode.
To be able to empty and to have no abode,
vastness overflows beyond measure.
To be able to have no abode and to empty,
harmony is ever-present.

This is the true attainment of the Dao’s vast and harmonious use,
yet it is never full or overflowing.
Central (*zhōng*), it means the application lies in harmony—
the Dao/Way, or perhaps, one who dares not speak its name.
Deep and still, it seems the source of all things.
Deep (*yuān*), it is profound stillness.
*Fū* (*兮*)—
a profound, resonant phrase to extol the Dao.
Understanding this Dao of vast emptiness,
neither lacking nor overflowing,
its nature congealed and deep beyond measure,
thus it is called *yuān* (deep).
The logic of the unfathomable—
neither existence nor non-existence,
hard to name definitively,
thus it is spoken of as if it were.

In daily life, it permeates all things,
pouring forth as boundless clarity,
embracing all phenomena,
guarding against harm and evil,
both motion and growth returning to it—
thus it is the source of all things.
To blunt its sharpness—
to suppress and curb its forward thrust,
its keen ambition for fame and gain.
To dissolve its chaos—
when thoughts rage and entangle,
inner and outer turmoil,
those who embody the Dao’s deep stillness
release its bonds, dissolve its chaos,
deep and clear, returning to its original nature.
Chaos (*fēn*), in the *River Master’s* text, is *fèn* (anger),
a knot of resentment.
It speaks of hidden malice and wrath,
anger and resentment tightly bound—
if one harbors the Dao’s vast harmony,
then all dissolves like ice in spring.

To blend its light—
deep and still, it seems to linger yet persist.
The Dao of utmost emptiness,
using vast harmony as its application,
its effects boundless yet never seen as full—
thus it never appears as overflowing.
The Dao’s measure is profound depth,
containing all things without distinction,
vast and minute, high and low—
all are embraced within.
Thus it is called the source of all things.
All things reverence the Dao.

To blunt its sharpness—
suppressing its outward edges,
no rigid angles.
To dissolve its chaos—
removing inner entanglements,
no clinging disturbances.
To blend its light—
penetrating both surface and core.
To blend with its dust—
merging with the common world.
Deep and tranquil, vast and boundless—
the Dao lies here.
Visible yet unseen,
heard yet unheard—
thus it is said to linger yet persist.
I do not know whose child it is,
yet it precedes the Sovereign’s likeness.

The Dao is within heaven and earth,
yet heaven and earth follow this Dao.
The Dao is within all things,
yet all things are born from this Dao.
Beyond the sky and soil,
back to the ancient beginning—
who can know the Dao’s origin?
This is unknowable.
Yet in metaphor, it precedes the Heavenly Sovereign.

It has been said:
There is the *beginning* (*shǐ*),
the *unbeginning* yet beginning (*wèishǐ yǒu shǐ*),
and the *unbeginning* yet *unbeginning* (*wèishǐ yǒu wèishǐ*).
In the ancient chaos,
dim and indistinct,
the Sage named it *Great Ease* (*Tàiyì*), vast and boundless,
flowing endlessly without end.
Then it was called *Great Initial* (*Tàichū*), the womb of confusion,
where presence and absence merge.
Then it was called *Great Commencement* (*Tàishǐ*), where sensation reveals itself,
sometimes existing, sometimes vanishing.
Then it was called *Great Purity* (*Tàisù*), neither turbid nor clear,
neither yin nor yang.

Only when reaching *Great Polarity* (*Tàijí*)
does it contain the Three as One,
all things’ original nature,
none lacking.
From this point onward,
generation endures without exhaustion.
Yet all are born from the Dao,
not able to birth the Dao.
One can be the Dao’s father,
yet cannot be its child.
One can be the Dao’s lord,
yet cannot be its subject.
Thus, the Dao truly has no origin—
where does it come from?」

「The Dao acts according to its own nature—
if birth is the Dao, then who else could it be?
Thus I say: *Before the beginning was the beginning* (*Wèi shǐ yǒu fú wèi shǐ yǒu shǐ zhě yě*).

Lin Yongzhi’s *Chang* states:
*The Dao is boundless yet its function reaches to the form before the Sovereign’s creation.*
Boundless (*chōng*) means emptiness (*xū*). Though the Dao’s essence is empty,
its function is inexhaustible—
sometimes overflowing, sometimes not,
adapting to the times without fixed measure.

Not saying “overflowing” or “not overflowing,”
but “sometimes overflowing, sometimes not,”
the very word *sometimes* reveals its meaning.

This is the art of language.
Deep (*yuān*) is beauty.
*Seem* (*sì*) is the use of ambiguous words to praise.

The root of all things (*wàn wù zhī zōng*)
is the *Great Master* (*Dà zōngshī*) as Zhuangzi speaks of it.
This Dao is sometimes present, sometimes absent—
if one does not understand the Dao,
they cannot know why it is called *the root of all things*.

*Dull its sharpness* (*cuò qí ruì*)—
its edges are worn smooth without any angles.

*Unravel its chaos* (*jiě qí fēn*)—
it remains orderly even amid confusion.

*Shine without revealing* (*guāng ér bù lù*), hence *harmonize its light* (*hé qí guāng*).
*Without dust yet not self-cleansing* (*wú chén ér bù zì jié*), hence *equalize its dust* (*tóng qí chén*).

*Profoundly subtle and faint* (*zhàn rán wēi máng*), yet unseen—
sometimes existing, sometimes vanishing,
seemingly present yet seemingly absent,
hence *profoundly, like existence* (*zhàn yī sì ruò cún*).

This is the *dim and indistinct* (*huǎng yī huò*).
Within it, there is substance.

I do not know whose child it is—
another ambiguous phrase to praise its mystery.

*Form* (*xiàng*) means *seem*.
*Sovereign* (*dì*) is *Heaven*.
It is said to exist before the Sovereign’s creation,
for its essence is empty yet its function boundless.

The words *form* and *seem* both describe
what is visible yet invisible,
knowable yet unknowable,
using such language to depict its marvel.

Fan Yingyuan says:
*The Dao is boundless yet its function reaches to the root of all things.*
Boundless (*chōng*) means emptiness (*xū*) and harmony (*hé*).
Deep (*yuān*) is profound.
*Seem* (*sì*) is because the Dao cannot be pointed to or named.

Its function is empty yet pervasive,
sometimes seemingly not overflowing—
for it is formless.
Yet profoundly deep, unfathomable,
it seems like the ancestral lord of all things.

*Dull its sharpness* until *profoundly, like existence*—
if one can use the Dao to blunt the edge of emotions and desires,
to unravel the chaos of affairs,
to refine the heart like a mirror without flashing its brilliance,
to blend with the dust of the world without staining its truth,
then the Dao is always *profoundly, like existence*—
sometimes appearing as if present.

I do not know whose child it is,
nor does it resemble the Sovereign’s creation.

Zhuangzi says:
*It exists before the Sovereign’s creation*—
whose child is this thing?

Xiu Xiu’an states:
*The Dao is boundless yet its function sometimes seems not to overflow*—
its function is poured into yet never full,
measured yet never exhausted.
*Profoundly, like the root of all things*—
the Dao’s essence is profound and still,
though it is the root of all things,
all things do not know how they are rooted in it,
hence *like the root*.

*Dull its sharpness* until *equalize its dust*—
those who embody the Dao blunt their sharp edges,
unravel their chaos,
harmonize their light without dazzling,
equalize their dust without obscuring.
*Profoundly, like existence*—
profoundly existing beyond all things yet not flowing,
as Zhuangzi says: *It nourishes things yet is not ensnared by them.*

I do not know whose child it is,
nor does it resemble the Sovereign’s creation.

Before the Five *Taos* (*wǔ tài*), whose child was it?
The Sovereign’s lord?

Chu Berniu’s *Bìxiū* states:
*The Dao is boundless yet its function sometimes seems not to overflow*—
the Dao gives birth to gods and spirits,
to the Sovereign and Heaven,
to Earth and all things,
yet it cannot be sought through form or named through words.
Empty yet moving,
it is nowhere absent,
thus it can govern all under Heaven,
respond to all sensations,
seemingly filling Heaven and Earth yet never truly full.

The Dao contains the *Original Qi* (*yuán qì*) yet is unseen,
yet its signs already exist within it—
the principles of giving birth to Heaven and Earth
originate from the utmost emptiness.

Its use depends on humanity—
it weaves through all transformations,
and only when one attains the realm of utter emptiness
can they employ this Dao.
With no fixed form or measure,
how could it ever overflow?

*Profoundly* (*yuān*), deep and still,
its divine brilliance emerges,
all transformations arise.
Things are born from existence (*yǒu*),
existence from non-existence (*wú*),
and its root is non-existence.

Once it emerges to become things,
it is only seemingly distinct from non-existence.

Ordinary people cling to traces of existence,
encountering obstacles at every turn.
Teaching them to blunt their sharpness prevents harm to things,
to unravel chaos preserves their selfhood,
to harmonize light without standing out,
to equalize dust without being swept away—
then *profoundly, like existence* can be seen.

Though seen clearly and believed firmly,
one does not know whence this thing was born,
nor whose child it is.

The Sovereign’s ruler is called *Heaven* (*dì*).
This thing seems to dwell even before the Sovereign,
exalted yet beyond exaltation—
nothing further to exalt.

In this chapter, there are ten sentences,
yet five use ambiguous words.
Some debate whether the Sage, upon seeing the Dao,
could penetrate its principles so clearly—
why speak of the Dao with so many ambiguities?

Fixed form means fixed name,
words have definite referents when examined thoroughly.
Once the Dao is named and called *Great*,
it cannot be commanded,
nor can it be pointed to and defined.
This is why it is said to be beyond naming.」

「If one clings rigidly to things in a single corner without allowing for transformation and flow,
then, as Zhuangzi says, it is *awakened yet as if lost and existing*—
*unformed yet spiritually manifest*, all things gathered yet unknown whence.

The Sage and Worthies speak of the Dao in this manner,
not from reluctance to speak, but because at this point words are insufficient.

Let the scholar delve deeply to grasp its clarity,
as one awakens from drunkenness—
the Sage’s teachings, earnest and unhidden, reveal themselves to you.

The *Mysteries of the Cow* say:
*The Dao is vast yet in use seems not to overflow.*

*Vast* means *central*—
the Dao’s essence contains all creation,
nurturing and giving birth to Heaven and Earth,
generating the Four Great Elements to precede them,
encompassing all dharmas yet standing alone supreme.

The Dao’s application is indeed great,
yet it is called *vast* because it does not indulge in self-satisfaction.
Thus, when we consider the meaning of *not overflowing*,
is it not fitting?

The *Taoist Sovereign* speaks of this to encourage humility and centrality,
and there is also the principle that *non-satisfaction naturally leads to overflowing.*

In the time of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors,
there was a vessel called the *Yòu Zhī* (Graceful Cup)
used for admonition.
When Confucius saw it, he instructed his disciples to fill it with water—
when upright, it held; when full, it tipped over.

Confucius sighed and said:
*"Good! This is the way of those who hold fullness."*

The ancients, wise and clear-sighted, took this as the highest warning,
often placing it beside their seats.

Does this not illustrate the Dao’s application in *centrality*?
*Profound yet like the ancestral source of all things.*

The ancestral source of all things is the Dao—
for the Dao gives birth to Heaven,
Heaven to Earth,
and Earth to all things,
thus it is called the ancestral source.

The Dao is the progenitor and ancestor of all things,
truly the most exalted.

Yet it is called *like* the ancestral source,
because it does not claim self-exaltation—
this is the language of humility.

This lesson teaches the world:
if one always practices humility and centrality,
then one naturally avoids *highness leading to peril.*

The *Book of Changes* says:
*"He who has greatness yet knows how to be humble will surely have good fortune."*
This is the case.

Thus the virtuous person, hearing much,
*restrains himself yet holds fast to it*;
with many aspirations,
*refines his nature yet conceals it*;
with profound understanding,
*simplifies his actions yet executes them with precision*.
Hence, when he stands above others, all revere him;
when he leads, none dare to harm him.

Therefore, the world willingly follows him without tiring—
why is this so?

It is because of his *humility and centrality.*

**Dulling the sharp.**
*Dulling* means *restraining*.
*Sharp* refers to *the cutting edges of speech and action*—
when a person’s *qi* is sharp,
sometimes it erupts from within,
manifesting in words—
the world calls this *lip-spears and tongue-swords*,
and at times it wounds others more than actual blades.

Thus the good and virtuous person,
how could he not tolerate all?
If he constantly reflects inward,
dulling his sharpness and restraining his *qi*,
then he will not recklessly harm others.

This is the meaning of *dulling the sharp.*

**Untangling the tumult.**
*Tumult* refers to *the clashing of conflicting emotions*.
*Untangling* means *self-discipline*.
When two joys arise, there will be many exaggerated praises;
when two angers arise, there will be many exaggerated reproaches.
If the *qi* of discontent surges within,
then exaggerated reproaches will burst forth,
and the two clash in resistance—
this is called *tumult and competition*.

Thus the great and virtuous person,
constantly restraining his discontent and checking his desires,
does not fall into contention and rivalry.

**Harmonizing his brilliance.**
*Brilliance* refers to *cleverness and innate talent*.
*Harmonizing* means *concealing and dimming*.
To *conceal* is to prevent cleverness from being displayed;
to *dull* is to prevent innate talent from being revealed.
Confucius, the greatest Sage,
in his native village appeared as if *without words*—
Yanzi, the greatest Worthies,
throughout the day spoke not, as if foolish.

These are all examples of *harmonizing his brilliance*.

I have heard from the ancients:
*"I am clever—what does cleverness avail me?"*
*"I am virtuous and capable—what do virtue and capability avail me?"*
If one boasts and relies upon them,
then one has already become small.

I only lower my *qi* to humility and harmony,
align my heart with uprightness and restraint,
submit my spirit to solemnity and reverence,
so that even the common folk can consult me,
and the ministers and great officials are all those I honor.
Yet I do not know that I am exalted,
and they do not know that they are low.

The *Book of Changes* says:
*"The virtuous person, when he presides over the people,
conceals his brilliance yet makes it clear—*
this is the case."

**Equalizing the dust.**
*Dust* refers to *obscurity and vulgarity*.
*Equalizing* means *treating all with equal benevolence*—
to *equalize benevolence* is to have no division between *darkness in others* and *clarity in oneself*;
to *view uniformly* is to have no distinction between *foolishness here* and *virtue there*.

In general, the Way of being a person
values *lowliness as the foundation*,
*humility as the base*—
thus the great and virtuous person,
constantly concealing his brilliance and yielding to the vulgar,
dulling his traces and blending with the dust,
knows that the world cannot be elevated,
so he descends;
knows that the people cannot be surpassed,
so he follows behind.
With warmth, respect, and careful virtue,
he makes others admire him;
by adopting the receptive and holding low,
none can surpass him.
Internally, he hides his wisdom and does not display his skills—
though I am exalted and high,
others do not harm me.
Though the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers flow to the left,
they are longer than all other streams,
because they can humble themselves.

The *Book of Changes* says:
*"By lowering the noble and elevating the humble,
one gains the people’s loyalty."*
Is this not the meaning of *harmonizing his brilliance* and *equalizing the dust*?

**Profound yet like existence.**
*Profound*—
this speaks of *non-existence* and *existence*,
of *having* and *being*—
the Dao’s essence seems *non-existent* yet *existing*,
*present* yet *as if lost*,
thus it is said: *profound yet like existence.*

This is why the ancients, wise and clear-sighted,
understood the Dao’s *having* and *non-having*—
constantly *dulling the sharp*, *untangling the tumult*,
*harmonizing their brilliance*, and *equalizing the dust*.

Then, what is the meaning of *embodying the Dao*?
The Dao’s teachings—
its essence is boundless,
its application infinite,
its nature inherent in all things,
neither lacking nor deficient.
It is obtained in human life at the beginning of *stillness*,
manifested in response at the moment of *natural flow*,
nurtured in the *unaroused emotions* of joy, anger, sorrow, and delight,
and realized when *intent and form* are both *non-existent*—
*serene yet correct*,
*profound yet clear*,
*dim yet vast as the Great Emptiness without dust*,
*flickering yet ordered as the four seasons*—
*non-action yet all things are done.*」

This is the teaching of *serene yet seemingly existent*—
I do not know whose child the Dao is, before the Emperor’s reign.

*"I"*—this is Laozi’s self-designation.
*"Whose"*—no name can be ascribed.
*"Child"*—refers to the Dao.
*"Like"*—as in *resembling*.
*"Emperor"*—human sovereign.

Just as the forms of Heaven, Earth, and myriad things,
their coming into being has its own origin—
when one speaks of mother and child,
only the single character *Dao* is naturally void and boundless,
its birth having no source—
thus, the Sage of Highest Clarity rightly says,
*"I do not know whose child the Dao is."*

For the Dao’s meaning,
when pushed to the limits of the unheard and unseen,
its subtlest aspect is difficult to name;
when concealed in the scentless, soundless Heaven,
its utmost essence is difficult to know.
Trace it forward—no beginning is seen to converge,
draw it backward—no end is seen to depart.
Who could know whose child the Dao is?

*"Like the Emperor before his reign"*—
Laozi once served as the Emperor’s teacher;
ancient Emperors once asked Laozi:
*"Of whom is the Dao the child?"*
The Sage of Highest Clarity thus said,
*"Like the Emperor before his sovereignty—*
what form, what appearance was it?"

Yang Zhiren says:
*"The Dao’s subtlety in its application is like the Emperor before his reign."*
The Dao’s subtlety in its application—
vigorous yet pure, empty yet not filled—
is thus the abyss of all things.
Humans may walk it:
dulling the sharp, untangling the tangled,
harmonizing within and yielding without,
aligning with waves and flowing with currents,
concentrating the mind internally,
letting the primordial *qi* surge and harmonize above and below,
subduing the restless monkey-mind from straying,
embodying nature’s serene stillness,
true and constant, unmoved—
having yet not having, real yet seemingly void,
illuminating inside and out,
revealing its own luminous clarity.

I do not know whose child the Dao is,
before the Emperor’s reign.
The ancients say: *"Do you still recognize this?"*

The Dao’s essence, neither lost through time nor ancient,
is plainly visible before one’s eyes.

Yu Qingzhong says:
*"The Dao’s subtlety in its application is like the Emperor before his reign."*

The Dao is like the sea—
for the Dao alone is void and thus receptive,
while the sea alone is vast and thus capacious.
The Dao’s essence is inherently void,
yet its application never strays beyond the subtlety of this emptiness.

The phrase *"never filled"*—
only when examined in the context of the following passage does its meaning become clear.

Among the things between heaven and earth,
none is as great as the sea—
the Dao is truly like it:
profound and deep, wondrous in its capacity.
Rivers and streams pour into it,
day and night without ceasing,
yet it never appears to be filled.
Some say *"never filled"*—
people often doubt its lack of fullness.
Yet where is its use concealed?
Does it not blunt the sharp within the unseen heavens?
Is this not the dulling of the keen?

Does it not transcend mundane entanglements
beyond the realm of right and wrong?
Is this not the untangling of the tangled?

*"Harmonizing its light"*—
it does not flaunt its brilliance to dazzle itself;
*"aligning with dust"*—
it does not compete in purity to turn away from filth.

「湛然」之二字，Yōngzhāi Lín Zhī [1]认为是微茫而不可见的状态，道本无形，在恍惚之间，指真空为实有，故曰似若存。

道超越于器物形象之外。我不知是哪位圣哲之子，却能精妙地体现它。Qīngyuán Liú Jì说：象是有形的开端，帝是生物的本源。有子之字，正下得象字。象，即肖也 [2]。犹如继世象贤之意。

Xū Liùxū说：道冲虚，而为月之至万物之宗。冲，即虚也；宗，即本也。夫至道冲虚，人皆具有，用之则弥满天地，乃至饮食起居，莫不显见。而曰*"或不盈"*者，谓其无形状可言而见，用言其动也。渊乎，言其静也，若水之停流，谓其静也。渊深明静，鉴照无穷，为万物之宗本，人乃万物之一也。

经曰*"似"*而不曰*"为"*，似即为也，且不欲直言之矣。挫其锐至似或存。这一段语盖以丁祝知道者，便不可止乎知而已。又须摧挫其锐利，追图之志，解释其纷乱之情，和融炫耀之光，混同尘世之俗，四者皆为知道者之病，须力去之，方除得浄，始可言冲虚至道，湛然常存矣。

似或，即常也。我不知其谁之子，象帝之先。象，即似也。老君谓冲虚至道，我不知其所由生，然究其极，似未天帝以先，卓然独立矣。

Lǐ Shì从说：道冲而用之至象帝之先。夫道者冲深潜行，而为用之*"或不盈"*者，无出其外也。渊乎似万物之宗者，心清若渊，观照万物，往来形影映现，业识所生，由此宗有也。挫其锐解其纷者，挫折其萌动之尖锐，解开其怨结之纷乱也。和其光同其尘者，和顺时俗所见之光，同其时俗所欲之尘也。湛然似若存者，返心内照，澄湛清平，见其真性，似若不离，常存定也。

Chái Yuángāo说：道太极冲中，虚而用之*"或不盈"*。体虚则用不竭，比如井虚不曾满，终日取用不竭，何况道乎？渊乎似万物之宗。如万水朝东，量不可测。挫其锐，解其纷。道体道用如此冲妙，则自己底刚锐纷争，外来底刚锐纷争，皆能挫解矣。和其光，同其尘。身中既冲虚，则外貌必和同顺境矣。湛然似若存。体虚则用处常不昧。我不知是哪位圣哲之子。不昧底是谁应用。象帝之先。太极以前那个。

Sū Jìngjìng说：道冲而用之至象帝之先。道在天地间，无一不有，无一不在，本为盈满，然道有理而无形，人以冲虚而用之，则有时疑其不盈。或云者，疑之也。冲虚用之，即后章*"知雄守雌"*之意。庄子曰*"雕琢复朴，无为名尸，无为谋府，无为事任，无为知主"*，此道盈而用之以冲虚也。万物之宗。宗，祖也。万物自无而生。渊，深也，其渊深不可测，为万物之祖。不盈则未能遽及乎，亦似之而已。既曰*"或"*，又曰*"似"*，正以道非不盈，用之以虚，则虚非真虚，故曰*"或"*曰*"似"*。

锐，才之露圭角者，挫之使无。纷，争之处缪扰者，解之使散。和其光，明之硼中彪外也，和之而不使露。同其尘，土之浮游污杂也，同之而不欲异。湛，清也。若存若士#3，而似乎清不清也，此皆冲虚用道。我不知此为谁之子。象，肖也。帝，天也。其肖象实居天帝之先，乃太极也。太极，虚无也。道本大极，生天地然后生万物，万物自无而生，即用之以冲虚，亦当然而然也。

首章以有无二名，总道之要。此章冲盈对立，总道之用。则由无而玄，由玄而又玄，妙不可及矣。

*《拾遗》* Yuántīshī说：在光同光，在尘同尘。秉文此章首尾，言道挫锐解纷，和光同尘。

「The inferior knowers do not speak of *chapters* [of the Dao]. Those who speak of humans embodying the Dao and achieving absolute dependence on and alignment with its mysterious depths are not merely conforming to the ways of the world.

*The Commentary on the Various Schools* states: *"The Dao has sentiment and trustworthiness, yet it acts without form or design. It can be transmitted but not clung to*#2*, obtained but not seen. From its own root and origin, before heaven and earth existed, it has endured from antiquity. It encompasses gods and spirits, emperors and lords, giving rise to heaven and earth—yet it does not claim precedence over the Supreme Ultimate (太极), nor does it dwell beneath the Six Extremes (六极) as something profound. It precedes the birth of heaven and earth yet is not deemed ancient, and it surpasses the Upper Antiquity (上古) yet is not considered aged.*

The Stone Cavern Master (石潭) remarks: *"The Dao is vast yet when applied may seem insufficient, deep as if it were the ancestral source of all things.*"

冲 means *emptiness/void*. Emptiness prevents fullness; emptiness without fullness means no manifestation, and no manifestation means profound depth. Hence, it is called *vast and deep*. Though it is said to be unmanifest, it is indeed the ancestral source of all things. The word *seem* (似) implies that the Dao cannot be definitively named.

*Ancestral source* (宗) refers to the primordial origin from which all things arise, affirming that all things emerge from the Dao.

To *blunt its sharpness* (挫其锐) means to remove its exposed facets; to *dissolve its turbulence* (解其纷) means to disperse external disturbances. To *harmonize its radiance* (和其光) means to conceal its brilliance so it is not seen externally. To *align with the dust* (同其尘) means to blend with the world’s impurities without standing apart. *Luminous yet seemingly present* (湛兮似若存) conveys the Dao’s clarity and enduring presence, though it appears as if it were not always there.

I do not know whose offspring this is—it precedes the Heavenly Sovereign (天帝).

The Dao is the origin and ancestral source of all things. I do not know whose offspring this Dao itself is, for even the term *ancestral source* (宗) suggests the Dao has its own origin. Yet it is further described as *preceding the Heavenly Sovereign*—where *sovereign* (帝) means the Heavenly Emperor, and *seeming* (象) implies its presence before him. Though named as the mother of all things, it is truly the beginning of heaven and earth. Heaven and earth arise from it, so the Dao precedes the Heavenly Sovereign. This shows that the Dao is not only the ancestral source of all things but also the ancestral source of heaven and earth itself.

This entire passage speaks of the Dao’s essence, not of those who embody the Dao.

**Volume Ten of *The Collected Meanings of the True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* – Observations on the Profound and Distant Dao by Master Constant Virtue (凝远大师常德路)**

**Chapter on "Heaven and Earth Lack Virtue" (天地不仁章)**

*Variants in Transmission:*
The *River Above Master* (河上公) titled this *"Chapter on Empty Use"* (虚用章),
while *Master Zhao Shi’an* (赵实庵) called it *"Chapter on the Just Conduct of Great Transformation"* (大化公行义章).

*Emperor Xuanzong of Tang’s Commentary:*
The preceding chapter expounds the ineffable Dao in its spontaneous, non-acting state—
existing in use yet without deliberate action.

This chapter reveals how partial favor breeds selfishness,
and selfishness makes universal benevolence difficult.
It first likens all things to fodder and dogs,
showing how heaven and earth equally forget them.
Next, it compares the space between heaven and earth to a *tuóqiào* (橐钥, bellows),
demonstrating how the Dao’s emptiness yields boundless function.
It concludes with the warning that excessive speech and action exhaust one’s essence,
urging adherence to the central harmony of *zhōnghé* (中和).

*Master Du Guangting’s (杜光庭) Observation:*
If one clings to "virtue" as virtue, then there is attachment;
if one does not regard transformation as virtue, then there is no selfishness.

The sovereign’s gaze upon all living beings
is like heaven and earth’s regard for all things.
All things arise and transform of their own accord—
heaven and earth do not claim credit for their work.
The myriad folk dwell and thrive as they will—
the sovereign does not take merit for their sustenance.
He relies on the wondrous *qi* to animate and shape,
and on the mysterious transformation to bring forth life—
this is the ultimate transformation.

If one speaks of their virtue and kindness,
logic will itself reach exhaustion.
Why?
The virtue of heaven and earth is vast—
yet grasses and trees flourish in summer and wither in winter.
The virtue of the sovereign is vast—
yet laws decree exile and execution.
Such virtue is not as great as that which does not cling to virtue as virtue,
but instead follows the natural flow and preserves the tranquil stillness—
the essential secret for nurturing one’s body.

*Master Zhang Chongying’s (张冲应) Response:*
"Emptiness" means "voidness."
The boundless void contains no forms,
yet between heaven and earth it moves and functions—
without sound or scent,
yet all things arise from it, endlessly.
If humans attune to this emptiness and employ it,
then the Dao will achieve nothing it cannot perfect.

Heaven and earth lack virtue,
treating all things as fodder and dogs.
The sage lacks virtue,
treating the people as fodder and dogs.
Between heaven and earth,
is it not like the bellows?

The bellows is empty within,
yet produces sound and breath.
Empty yet unexhausted,
moving yet ever more abundant.
Excessive speech and action lead to depletion—
better to guard the central harmony.

*Variant in Transmission:*
"Empty yet ever more abundant" (虚而愈出) is also rendered as "empty yet abundantly yields" (虚而俞出).

*River Above Master’s (河上公) Explanation:*
Heaven and earth lack virtue—
they bestow life and transformation without sentiment,
acting purely by nature’s course.
They treat all things as fodder and dogs—
for though heaven and earth produce all beings,
humans are the most precious.
Yet they regard them as mere grasses and beasts,
demanding no repayment in return.

The sage lacks virtue—
the sage nourishes the people without sentiment,
following heaven and earth’s example,
acting by nature’s course.
He treats the people as fodder and dogs—
the sage regards them like grasses and beasts,
demanding no gratitude or reverence.

Between heaven and earth—
the space between heaven and earth is empty and tranquil,
and harmonious *qi* flows through it,
so all things arise spontaneously.
If humans eliminate desires and emotions,
moderate tastes and pleasures,
purify the five viscera,
then the spirit will dwell within them.

Like the bellows—
the bellows is hollow within,
yet produces sound and breath when moved.
Empty yet unexhausted,
moving yet ever more abundant—
it speaks of an emptiness that cannot be depleted,
and movement that never ceases to yield sound and breath.

Excessive speech leads to depletion—
excessive action harms the spirit,
excessive speech harms the body.
When the tongue moves and words multiply,
disaster and calamity follow.
Better to guard the central harmony—
better to cultivate virtue within,
nourishing the spirit,
treating *qi* as precious,
and speaking sparingly.

*Master Wang Fusi’s (王辅嗣) Interpretation:*
Heaven and earth lack virtue,
treating all things as fodder and dogs—
for they act by nature alone,
without contrivance or design.
All things regulate themselves naturally,
so heaven and earth do not interfere.

If one clings to virtue, they must contrive and impose transformations,
entertaining thoughts and actions.
Contrived transformations cause things to lose their authenticity,
and deliberate actions prevent their natural completion.
If things cannot complete naturally,
then they cannot fully sustain life.

The earth does not cultivate fodder for beasts,
yet beasts eat fodder;
the earth does not breed dogs for humans,
yet humans eat dogs.
Without action toward all things,
yet all things find their proper place,
and their use is never wanting.

If kindness stems from one’s own contrivance,
it is insufficient and unreliable.

The sage lacks virtue,
treating the people as fodder and dogs—
for the sage aligns with heaven and earth’s virtue,
comparing the people to fodder and dogs.

Between heaven and earth,
the movement is boundless yet ever more abundant.
Within the bellows,
the emptiness is void of desires and actions,
so it cannot be exhausted or depleted,
and its movement is never spent.

Between heaven and earth,
the natural flow is boundless,
just as the bellows—
excessive speech leads to depletion,
yet guarding the central harmony prevents exhaustion.
The more one acts,
the more one loses.
To establish harm in things,
and to misplace words in actions,
is to invite inevitable depletion.
If one guards the bellows’ central harmony,
then there is no exhaustion,
and if one abandons self to follow things,
then all will be in order.

If the bellows had intent to produce sound,
it would fail to meet the demands of those who blow it.

*Emperor Xuanzong’s (唐明皇) Commentary:*
From "Heaven and earth lack virtue" to "the people as fodder and dogs"—
"lacking virtue" means they do not perform acts of virtue and kindness.
"Fodder and dogs" refers to the ritual practice of binding straw into dog shapes for sacrifice.

Dogs are kept for guarding and defense,
so their owners expect loyalty and vigilance in return.
But the sacrificial dogs are mere forms,
without the capacity to bark or protect—
so their virtue is not as profound as that of the living.

It is said that heaven and earth regard humans
as humans regard sacrificial dogs—
without expectation or demand.

I have examined this further:
The ultimate virtue knows no partiality—
who then embodies universal love?
If love is partial,
it is not ultimate—
it is merely selfish favor.

If one does not love only their own kin,
then all under heaven are kin.
If one does not treat only their own children as children,
then all under heaven are children.

Thus, ultimate virtue is not partial—
it is the most inclusive.
How could it be universal love?

*Commentary:*
"Virtue" here is the natural expression of universal love.
"Fodder and dogs" refers to the ritual practice of binding straw into dog shapes for sacrifice.

Today, heaven and earth’s ultimate virtue
manifests in the creation and sustenance of all beings—
like humans binding straw into dog shapes,
they do not expect the dogs to bark or guard,
nor do they regard their creation as an act of virtue or kindness.
Hence, it is said they lack virtue.

The Sage abides in *yòu* (indulgence/forgiveness),
and thus views all under heaven’s people likewise.

*Commentary:*
The "priceless favor of a worn mat" (*bìgài zhī ēn*)—
Confucius said in the *Records of Rites*:
*"A worn mat is not discarded—it is for burying a dog."*

*"Not only loving one’s own kin"*—
this is the text of *The Rites of Zhou*.

Between heaven and earth,
it is like the *tuó* and *yuè*—
*Tuó* is the *tāo* (leather bag),
*Yuè* is the *dí* (reed pipe).
When the bag is struck to fan the wind,
and the pipe is played to direct the breath,
both rely on emptiness and no-mind,
thus they move and yet have response.

Therefore, the utmost things between heaven and earth,
being without private favor,
are also because of emptiness and no-mind.

Empty yet unyielding,
moved yet ever more forth.
The *tuó* and *yuè* are empty yet unyielding—
when plucked, they emit sound and breath ever more,
illustrating how the Sage’s heart, without partial love,
has no time of yielding or obstruction,
its applications endless—
truly moved yet ever more forth.

*Commentary:*
*Tuó* is *tāo*—a leather bag used to fan wind to kindle fire.
*Yuè* is the *dí* (reed pipe).
It says that heaven and earth create all beings like straw dogs,
for their space is empty,
thus they generate without private favor and without expectation,
just as the *tuó* fans wind and the *dí* directs breath.
Those who constantly seek response
find no emotion in me.

Thus, when emptied, there is no yielding or obstruction,
when moved, sound and breath emerge ever more—
illustrating how a ruler, with an empty and silent heart,
purely harmonizing and uniformly transforming,
has no yielding or obstruction,
ever in daily use, yet unknown—
moved yet ever more forth.

Many words lead to exhaustion;
better to hold the Center.
Many words do not bear fruit,
thus they exhaust and bend,
while universal love is hard to extend,
leading to resentment and hatred—
thus it is better to embrace and guard the Middle Way,
and all will naturally suffice.

*Commentary:*
"Many words" refers to excessive talk of universal love.
Excessive talk of universal love,
yet in practice it cannot be fully extended,
thus it exhausts and bends without fulfillment—
this shows why it is better to forget concerns and respond emptily,
embracing and guarding the Middle Way,
so that all will naturally align.

"Not bearing fruit" means
*chóu* (answer)—
speaking without action in return.

Du Guangting said:
*"Heaven and earth’s lack of virtue makes all under heaven like straw dogs."*

Ancient sacrificial rites included figures for use,
modeled after their forms,
placed among the ritual vessels—
thus the setting of straw dogs.
Dogs bark and guard,
yet straw dogs serve no such purpose.
Heaven and earth’s view of all things,
the Sage’s view of the people,
is like that of straw dogs—
they do not demand barking or guarding,
nor do they regard creation as virtue or kindness,
nor do they expect repayment.
If their virtue is not displayed,
then it is said they lack virtue.

Humans toward dogs have the favor of a worn mat and burial,
yet toward straw dogs, there is no such favor—
this clearly shows the Sage does not consider universal love as virtue.

*"Worn mat"*—
the *Records of Rites* [missing character] *Tán Gōng* says:
When Confucius’ dog died,
he had Zigong bury it.
The Master said:
*"I have heard—
a worn mat is not discarded—
it is for burying a horse.
A prince’s carriage horse, when dead, is buried with a mat,
and a worn mat is not discarded—
it is for burying a dog.
I am poor, with no mat,
so at its burial, I gave it a mat instead,
so its head would not sink into the earth.
I feared its head would lie straight in the soil."*

*"Not only loving one’s own kin"*—
the text of *The Rites of Zhou* says:
*"When the Great Dao prevails,
all under heaven is public—
not only loving one’s own kin,
not only regarding one’s own children as children.
It is universal love for all things,
pushing toward the public and acting impartially,
not indulging in partial love."*

Between heaven and earth,
the utmost movement is ever more forth.

「The *tú* is a leather bag that beats the wind,
the *yuè* is a bamboo pipe that guides the *qi*.
The *tú* beats the wind without the *yuè* to guide it—
the *yuè* guides the *qi* without the *tú* to beat it.
Both must rely on each other in their operation,
as heaven and earth rely on the *tú*,
and the five *qi* on the *yuè*.
They hold emptiness and movement within themselves
to give birth to all the myriad transformations,
yet never falter or exhaust themselves.

A sovereign empties his heart and follows the Dao,
his ministers embody his virtue and enact his transformations,
just as heaven and earth move the five *qi* without exhaustion—
then governance knows no obstruction,
and the four seas enjoy peace.
The more it moves, the more its sound and *qi* emerge,
its words endless.

When the *qi* are pure and transformations uniform,
the virtue of purity and harmony pervades all things.
If one does not know of its daily use—
*The Book of Changes* [□ *Xì* *Yǐnyǔ*] says:
*"The myriad regions and common folk,
rely on the use of this Dao to obtain life,
yet do not know of the Dao’s functional power,
so they do not regard function as function—
the common folk use it without knowing."*

*Qū* is exhaustion,
*náo* is disorder.
Excessive words lead to depletion,
excessive affairs lead to harm—
excessive words, when they fail to respond,
bring exhaustion and obstruction.
Governance through excessive words means
frequent issuance of decrees,
morning orders and evening reversals—
this is called depletion.

Excessive words in governing oneself—
its faults are clear.
Thus, one lost word cannot be recalled,
let alone many lost words—
