how could there be no disgrace?

The spoken word departs from the firm and clings to the disparate,
turning white into black.
To guard against words is as crucial as to guard against rivers—
one must be cautious indeed.

Better to remain silent and guard the central harmony—
for the state, this does not exhaust its governance,
for oneself, this does not invite disgrace.
Loving the *qi* and sparing words,
holding virtue within,
practicing instruction without speech—
this is true excellence.

The *Sòng Dàojūn* said:
*"Heaven and earth do not transform until the common folk become fodder and dogs.*
Favor arises from harm,
harm arises from favor.
If one calls benevolence ‘favor,’
then harm follows inevitably.
Heaven and earth’s regard for all things,
the sage’s regard for the common folk—
they assist in their natural course,
without the heart of partial love or gain.
Benevolence cannot be named in this way.

Binding fodder to make a dog,
used in sacrifices,
once its purpose is fulfilled, it is discarded—
passersby trample its head and body,
woodcutters burn its limbs.
Heaven and earth’s regard for all things,
when spring brings birth and summer growth—
if they have benevolence and love,
it extends to autumn and winter,
when all things wither and fall—
this is not heaven and earth’s lack of love,
but the natural order of things.
The sage does not act with partial benevolence,
treating the common folk as fodder and dogs.
Indeed, the sage extends righteousness and benevolence to all under heaven—
if his benevolence reaches the affairs of men,
there are sequences of beginning and end,
changes of life and death—
this too is the natural order of things.
This is not loving first and enduring later,
but the natural unfolding of principle.
Thus, it is said:
‘Not benevolent’—
yet this is the ultimate benevolence.

*Zhuāngzi* said:
*"The Perfect Man has no kin,
the Great Man is not benevolent."*
This aligns with the above.

Between heaven and earth,
the utmost movement is ever more forth.
The Dao has no form,
no fixed direction—
with the *qi* of boundless harmony,
it beats and moves between heaven and earth,
nurturing all things,
like the *tú* and *yuè* being empty yet unobstructed,
moving yet ever more forth.
Excessive words lead to depletion—
better to guard the central harmony.

When words are spoken, they have form and direction—
grand speech is how the Dao is clarified.
Words imply intent,
intent cannot avoid error—
thus, excessive words lead to depletion,
and it is better to guard the central harmony
to respond to all changes.

*Sū Yǐngbīn* said:
*"Heaven and earth are not benevolent until the common folk become fodder and dogs.*
Heaven and earth have no partiality,
but listen to all things’ natural course—
thus, all things arise and perish of their own accord.
Death is not my doing to harm them,
life is not my doing to bestow benevolence.
Like binding fodder into a dog for sacrifice,
once the ritual is complete, it is cast aside—
passersby trample it—
is this hatred?
It is merely the natural unfolding of time.
After the sacrifice, it is discarded,
trampled upon—
is this not love?
It is also the natural unfolding of time.
The sage’s regard for the people is the same.
If he does not harm them,
the people preserve their nature,
life and death, gain and loss—
I have no part in it.
Though I have not acted with benevolence,
my benevolence is grand indeed.

Between heaven and earth,
the utmost movement is ever more forth.»

The bellows and the key—
when their movement reaches,
nothing resists its sway.
The unknowing praise their craft as supreme,
yet what purpose do bellows and keys serve?
They are empty yet unyielding,
thus their motion ever overflows.

Between heaven and earth,
their birth and death of all things,
their carving of myriad punishments—
such is their way alone.

Much speech exhausts itself,
yet nothing surpasses abiding in the Center.

Seeing motion overflow,
they fail to grasp it as the response of the Void-Center.

Thus I tell them:
Much speech exhausts itself,
yet nothing surpasses abiding in the Center’s boundlessness.

Lü Jiufu said:
Heaven and earth are not benevolent,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.
The Dao of Heaven is obscure before the Formless Sovereign,
yet who knows its origin?
Then how can one who embodies this Dao be called benevolent?

The heart—
merely human heart—
yet heaven and earth embody this Dao,
needing no benevolence,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.

The full meaning of "sacrificial dog":
its purpose in ritual.
Received, it serves without use,
yet cannot be omitted.

Like heaven and earth toward things—
no intent toward them,
yet seemingly no love,
yet in spring’s birth and summer’s growth,
it seems there is love.

The sage toward the people—
thus it is also.

The sage is not benevolent,
treating the people as sacrificial dogs.
The sage embodies this Dao,
needing no contention over benevolence,
treating the people as sacrificial dogs.

The sacrificial dog—
a thing contended over for no benevolence,
yet kept.

All things share substance with heaven and earth,
the people share substance with the sage.
Heaven and earth, the sage—
viewing themselves as sacrificial dogs,
thus their regard for all things and the people is so.

Between heaven and earth,
motion ever overflows.
Yet in nurturing, raising, growing, and fostering—
what need for benevolence?

Only the not-benevolent
is called great benevolence.

Thus between heaven and earth,
its principle of bellows and keys
is clearly seen.

The bellows and the key—
only because they are empty yet unyielding,
their motion ever overflows.

Much speech exhausts itself,
yet nothing surpasses abiding in the Center.

Thus the person who embodies this Dao—
speech arises from non-speech,
speech without speech,
knowing how speech speaks.

Thus much speech exhausts itself,
yet abiding in the Center is the true endeavor.

Lü Nóngshī said:
Heaven and earth are not benevolent,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.
Heaven and earth toward all things,
the sage toward the people—
calm and unattached,
yet not clinging to benevolence,
using them as fitting,
discarding them when past—
thus it is said:
The sacrificial dog—
before its use, adorned in wicker baskets,
covered in embroidered cloth;
after its use,
passersby trample its head,
woodcutters burn its body.
This is what is meant by:
using them as fitting,
discarding them when past.

Between heaven and earth,
motion ever overflows.
Heaven and earth are not benevolent,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.
The sage is not benevolent,
treating the people as sacrificial dogs.
Moving with the world,
drifting with the times,
yet not bound to past traces,
nor entangled in what has been trodden—
thus able to sound when entered,
fall silent when not,
and know the bellows and keys.

Thus it is said:
Between heaven and earth,
is it not like the bellows and keys?
Empty yet unyielding,
moving yet ever overflowing,
much speech exhausts itself,
yet nothing surpasses abiding in the Center.

Empty yet without yielding—
no place to yield.
Moving yet ever overflowing—
something to demonstrate.
Without yielding yet with demonstration—
this is the numinous.

Empty, without yielding,
moving yet with demonstration—
thus able to respond to things’ impulses,
speaking as such,
yet never exhausted.

As for reciting ancient soil-mounds,
discussing the former kings’ sacrificial dogs,
yielding to past traces,
clinging to what has been trodden—
seeking to act in the age of decline,
this is why much speech exhausts itself,
yet abiding in the Center is ever more so.

This entire passage
aligns broadly with Zhuangzi’s intent on sacrificial dogs.

Wang Yuanzé said:
Heaven and earth are not sevenfold,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.
The sacrificial dog—
used in ritual,
when in use, solemn rites and respect are paid.
When the ritual ends,
it is cast aside and trampled,
equal to filth—
yet in the time of solemn rites and respect,
it was not without sincerity.
Yet it was merely bound fodder shaped as a dog—
what was there truly to revere?

Though unworthy of reverence yet revered—
this was not falsehood.
All things each attain their due,
life and death returning to the soil,
nature’s course is as it must be.
Yet heaven and earth alone are their parents,
so they cannot but love.
Yet probing heaven and earth’s intent—
what attachments remain?

Thus in their time of love,
though with utmost sincerity,
all things proceed naturally,
truly nothing to love.
Yet at their end,
all return to the same dust—
where is the lingering affection?

The sage is not sevenfold,
treating the people as sacrificial dogs.
Benevolence—
human benevolence.
To love things with human virtue is benevolence,
yet those who bear human form yet are of Heaven—
how can they be named so?

Thus the sage loves the near and benevolences the people,
hence speaks only of the people—
yet their Dao is one with heaven and earth.
Yet bearing human form,
their responsibilities differ.

Between heaven and earth,
motion ever overflows.
The bellows and keys—
empty, responding to things,
impulsed, then responding,
responding yet not hoarding.

Heaven and earth toward all things,
the sage toward the people—
responding as it must,
yet no attachment to the moment,
no lingering on the past,
thus the bellows and keys’ boundlessness.

Empty yet unyielding—
emptiness of substance.
Moving yet ever overflowing—
movement of function.

Excessive speech often leads to exhaustion—
better to hold fast to the Center.

Without speech, one is exhausted;
with speech, one becomes known.
Yet the sage’s work is to speak yet not act.

Holding fast to the Center
is how one responds to all transformations.

Liu Zhongping said:
*"Heaven and Earth are not benevolent,
they treat all things as straw dogs.*

*Sevenfold compassion—
this is how love is brought to fruition.*
*As for straw dogs—
if one shows compassion to govern love, it is acceptable,
but if one shows no compassion yet still brings love to fruition, it is also acceptable.*

*When they are at their height,
woven in baskets, adorned with silk embroidery,
the priests and attendants observe strict rites,
then carry them forth—
as if showing compassion to govern love.
But when their backs are trampled by passersby,
when they are burned by woodcutters,
and they are discarded, scattered, and reduced to dust—
then there is no longer compassion to govern love.*

*Heaven and Earth are thus as well.*
*When thunder and wind stir,
when dew and rain nourish,
covering, embracing, nurturing,
giving life to those who would live,
fulfilling those who would grow,
so that all with form stand firm,
all with nature are completed—
as if showing compassion to bring love to fruition.*

*But when frost and hail, ice and snow descend,
cruel and merciless,
breaking, bending, destroying,
so that the sun dares not advance,
the light dares not shine,
the great are ruined, the small perish,
the strong are shattered, the weak annihilated—
then there is no compassion to bring love to fruition.*

*Thus it is said:
Heaven and Earth are not benevolent,
they treat all things as straw dogs.*

*The sage is not benevolent,
he treats the people as straw dogs.*
*It is not only that Heaven and Earth treat all things thus,
the sage treats the people likewise.*

*When he moves them with grace,
disturbs them with teaching,
when grace overflows and kindness flows,
when the people respond with warmth and labor,
with sighs and murmurs—
as if nurturing an infant,
as if showing compassion to bring love to fruition.*

*But when crimes are great, they are killed;
when crimes are small, they are punished—
limbs severed, bodies torn,
dragged, stoned, burned, abandoned,
left sprawled in the marketplace,
scattered across the wilderness,
while walled cities weep with severed ears,
and the capital flows with blood—
then there is no compassion to govern love.*

*Thus it is said:
The sage is not benevolent,
he treats the people as straw dogs.*

*Between heaven and earth,
motion ever overflows.*
*Because they hold no attachment to love or its absence,
this is how Heaven and Earth attain their numinous power.*

*The numinous has what it demonstrates,
yet nothing to constrain it—
because it is unconstrained,
it is like the bellows and keys:
empty yet unyielding.*
*Because it has what it perceives,
its non-action becomes clear.*

*Manifested in the body as speech,
seen in affairs as principle—
sometimes spoken, sometimes acted,
yet in essence, one and the same.*

*Why so?*
*Speech is its substance—
nothing more.*
*To fail to know this*
*is to let speech not emerge from non-speech.*
*If speech does not emerge from non-speech,*
*it diverges from the bellows and keys’ empty motion.*

*Thus its excess leads to exhaustion—
how could it be otherwise?*

*Confucius said:*
*"Who now sings these songs?*
*To know this is to know speech emerges from non-speech."*

*Speech emerges from non-speech—
no one escapes this.*
*Yet those who cannot*
*are those whose hearts cling to having rather than non-having,*
*to taking rather than letting go,*
*and thus fail to align with the Dao.*

*Neither having nor non-having,*
*neither taking nor letting go—*
*yet aligning with the Dao—*
*this is called holding fast to the Center.*

*Holding fast to the Center without ceasing,*
*it moves like the bellows and keys, ever overflowing.*
*Thus it is said:*
*Between heaven and earth,*
*is it not like the bellows and keys?*

*Empty yet unyielding,*
*moving yet ever overflowing—*
*this is how the sage models Heaven and Earth.*

*Excessive speech often leads to exhaustion—*
*better to hold fast to the Center.*

*Speech is how one responds to things.*
*Indeed, modeling Heaven and Earth,*
*the sage emerges—*
*inevitably responding to things with speech.*
*Yet if speech is excessive,*
*it fails to conform to principle and stop.*
*If it fails to conform to principle and stop,*
*it cannot be extended and put into practice.*

*Only by holding fast to the Center*
*does one’s speech neither multiply nor diminish,*
*always conforming to principle and stopping.*
*Thus it can be extended and put into practice,*
*and exhaustion will not often befall it.*

*Hence it is said:*
*Excessive speech often leads to exhaustion—*
*better to hold fast to the Center.*

*Those who hold fast to the Center*
*speak neither excessively nor sparingly.*
*Yet why does Laozi so vehemently oppose excessive speech?*

*He clarifies the Dao—*
*The Dao is ever without speech,*
*yet ever with speech,*
*for the Dao cannot help itself.*
*Thus it can be spoken of,*
*because it is ever without speech.*
*The fewer the words,*
*the closer one is to the Dao.*
*The more the words,*
*the farther one strays from the Dao.*
*Hence his vehement opposition to excessive speech.*

*Liu Jujie said:*
*"The sage is not benevolent,*
*he treats the people as straw dogs.*
*Nothing is more cruel than war and punishment,*
*yet even the most virtuous cannot abolish them—*
*only follow their logic.*

*Sometimes speaking of all things,*
*sometimes of the people—*
*each has its proper order.*

*Between heaven and earth,*
*motion ever overflows.*
*This further explains Heaven and Earth.*

*The two intervals of Heaven and Earth*
*can be empty,*
*thus they find their stopping point.*
*Empty—*
*this is the substance of the bellows and keys,*
*unyielding because of its emptiness.*

*The bellows and keys’ function—*
*the bellows moves with wind,*
*the keys move with qi,*
*moving only to respond,*
*thus their resonance grows.*

*Excessive speech often leads to exhaustion—*
*better to hold fast to the Center.*

*Heaven and Earth respond to all things with emptiness,*
*yet speak not at all.*
*The sage also responds to the people with emptiness,*
*yet when waves of disturbance arise,*
*it is not speech that sustains them—*
*only that excess is avoided.*

*The Classic of Changes says:*
*"Excessive speech leads to exhaustion."*
*The Center’s substance is one—*
*worthy of being held fast to.*
*The Center’s function is empty—*
*capable of response,*
*just as Heaven and Earth are called intervals.*

The *New Sayings of the Chancellor* states:
The sage is not virtuous/ren,
yet treats the people as grass-dogs.*

The stillness is unsoiled,
the purity is unstained,
yet their sacrifices suffice to honor ritual.
Yet the reverence of the grass-dog—
at its beginning, when it is to be used,
it is adorned with embroidered patterns,
stored in ornate cases.
Once used, the travelers tread upon its head,
the woodcutters cook its body,
yet it does not cling to what it loves,
nor does it adhere to what it possesses.
When appropriate, it is employed;
when fitting, it is released—
when excessive, it is discarded,
when seasonable, it is followed.
Yet the sage’s virtue/ren,
how could it be far from this?

The Dao of Heaven cannot generate life,
yet life’s generation belongs to the True Lord,
and the True Lord never generates.
The Dao of Earth cannot transform,
yet transformation belongs to the True Sovereign,
and the True Sovereign never transforms—
thus virtue/ren manifests in all things.
Therefore, all things within Heaven and Earth,
in form and sound, color and essence,
are governed by me,
yet things cannot be distant.
When life is generated and transformation complete,
they enter and are concealed in use—
thus things have their kinds and groups,
each clinging or departing as naturally fits,
yet forgetting their origin in me,
yet things cannot be close.

Though so, Heaven generates but cannot complete,
Earth completes but cannot govern—
the sage emerges to govern it.
Thus, virtue/ren is displayed in form,
and when it emerges,
it shares in the calamities of joy and sorrow,
so all things’ births are aided and sustained,
their proper order never lost—
virtue/ren concealed in use.
When it retreats,
even the sage does not share its cares,
thus its traces vanish, its heart grows dark,
and it views things as strange.

Ah! The sage’s relation to Heaven and Earth—
how could it be weighed down by virtue/ren toward the people and all things?
Thus, when things emerge,
the sage emerges with them, unhesitant—
when things retreat,
the sage retreats with them, undeterred.
It gives birth without possession,
acts without reliance,
nurtures without control,
completes without taking credit—
all things find their due,
yet some also find regret.
And yet, what Laozi says—
*"Heaven and Earth are not virtuous/ren,
treating all things as grass-dogs."*
*"The sage is not virtuous/ren,
treating the people as grass-dogs."*
How could his words be far from this?

Later students cling to narrow virtue/ren,
forgetting the ancients’ grand Dao—
thus, in serving others, they fail at universal love,
in cultivating themselves, they fail at selflessness—
how could they know the sage neither loses himself nor others?

Shifting with the times,
turning with all things—
within Heaven and Earth, is it not like the bellows and keys?
Thus, the more it moves, the more it emerges—
the upright self, without ego,
is how the sage responds to things,
not by opposing them.
The empty, unyielding—
the selfless, who lose themselves,
are how they sever things,
not how they perfect them.

Alas! The sage’s Dao of Heaven and Earth,
of treating the people and all things as grass-dogs,
can be exhausted in one phrase.

Liu Ji said:
*"Heaven and Earth’s lack of virtue/ren is no greater than holding fast to the Center."*
Heaven and Earth, in their relation to all things,
the sage, in his relation to the people,
follow their natural course,
entrust them to their own fate—
without love or gain,
thus called not virtuous/ren.
It is like binding grass to make a dog,
used in sacrifice—
when fit, it is employed;
when past, it is cast aside—
no lingering attachment.
The empty, awaiting things.

The Great Emptiness moves with one *qi*,
making Heaven and Earth like the bellows and keys.
The bellows—*wǔ* (a leather bag),
beaten to kindle fire.
The keys—*diào* (a reed pipe),
blown to produce sound.
Their substance is empty yet unyielding,
their function moves yet emerges evermore.
What difference is there from
Heaven’s motion as yang,
Earth’s stillness as yin,
the ceaseless striking of yin and yang,
while creation unfolds between?

Man’s form follows Heaven and Earth’s symbols,
his transformations align with yin and yang—
like the bellows and keys as instruments.
This speaks of Heaven and Earth,
yet man is within them.
Heaven and Earth grasp the marvel of one *qi*,
and move without ceasing.
The sage grasps the marvel of one *qi*,
and ascends and descends without end.
Its Dao is vast and distant,
hard to speak of.
If one seeks it in excessive words,
then it is mired in ancient dross,
and spirit is wasted in shallow depths—
not merely unprofitable.
Thus, excessive speech leads to exhaustion,
better to hold fast to the Center.
Holding fast to the Center—
within, it preserves;
without, it does not sway.
Without thought, without action,
serene and unmoving,
yet it guards the Center,
like Heaven and Earth’s bellows and keys—
without heart,
naturally moving and functioning,
for the True Lord abides within.
The True Lord—
Heaven’s grain, the original spirit.
Thus, it is followed by the spirit of the grain.
Zhao Shi’an said:
*"The two precedents—
First, Heaven’s utmost fairness."*

Heaven and Earth are not kind,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.
Blending the singular nature into the Great Unity,
who is kind and who is not?
With private affection toward things,
there arises righteousness and unrighteousness.
Kindness gives birth to righteousness,
while ruthlessness brings death—
rooted in the natural course of Heaven’s operation.
When favor is bestowed, harm follows,
seen in the reversals of human affairs.
The Classics speak of "not-kindness,"
yet this is the greatest kindness.
Great kindness knows no private gain,
reaching only the utmost fairness.

When it is time to give life, life begins—
the Yang warmth that first animates things.
When it is time to take life, death comes—
the Metal *qi* stern and unyielding.
To say that the appointed time for death cannot be delayed
is to acknowledge the fixed fate of life and death.
When shaken, all things awaken;
when met with harmony, their uses decay—
though life is granted, decay soon follows,
though death is decreed, life’s intent persists.
This is Heaven’s fairness—
no more, no less.

But if one kills when it is time to give life,
or spares when it is time to take it—
this is not the public operation of Heaven’s Way,
but the private affection of human contrivance.
To harm the public with private gain is the upright order of Heaven and Earth;
to damage the public for private ends is the way of depravity and excess.
The Dao acts with fairness,
hence the saying that Heaven and Earth are not kind,
yet are likened to sacrificial dogs—
and thus Heaven’s intent is revealed.

Therefore, the sage’s governance
embodies Heaven and follows the Dao,
severing private kindness and righteousness,
upholding just rewards and punishments,
establishing what is proper—
what need for personal inclination?
The commentary states:
*"Favor arises from harm, harm from favor.
Kindness as favor—harm follows.
All this is to sever private affection."*

Thus, the sage is not kind,
treating the people as sacrificial dogs.
So that later sages may align with the Dao,
responding to change without obstruction.
Zhuangzi said, *"Constant kindness never succeeds,"*
and again, *"Do not heap up favors."*
Laozi equated Heaven and Earth’s kindness with the Dao—
the Dao is vast, so it knows no private gain,
and thus transcends the limited kindness of the Five Constants.
This intent points to the world’s petty kindness and righteousness.
Otherwise, why say that excessive speech leads to exhaustion,
better to hold fast to the Center?

Thus, the likeness of sacrificial dogs
illustrates how the sage’s use of "not-kindness" is true kindness.
To embody the kindness of "not-kindness"
is to embody Heaven and align with the Dao.

**Second Precept:**
The sage embodies Heaven.
The sage is not kind,
treating the people as sacrificial dogs.
The sage’s governance of the people
is without private intent,
in harmony with Heaven and Earth.

**Second Analogy:**
One, drawing from the essence of embodiment.

The space between Heaven and Earth—
it is like the *tǔnuò* [leather bellows].*
The *Gùzhù* [Commentary] says:
The *tǔnuò* receives through its emptiness,
and responds through its emptiness.

Indeed, the Dao is empty in its essence,
and void in its function.
When viewed through the Dao’s essence,
emptiness allows for boundless response;
when viewed through *lǐ* [principle/pattern],
voidness enables the measureless flow of *qi*.

The Dao responds through supreme voidness—
its origins are unknown;
The sage acts without contrivance—
who can fathom its purpose?

Between Heaven and Earth,
neither above nor below,
it employs *qi* within,
like the *tǔnuò*’s movement.

**Second Analogy:**
The function of the *tǔnuò*—
empty yet unyielding,
moving yet ever issuing forth.

The *Lǐzǐ* [Analects of Master Li] says:
"Why do you esteem emptiness?"

Emptiness has no worth in itself,
yet if emptiness is esteemed,
it becomes obstructed within.
If emptiness is merely emptiness,
it is not a worth to be esteemed.

Yet emptiness’s worth lies
in its ceaseless response—
viewed through the *tǔnuò*,
emptiness is thus esteemed.

Though viewed through the *tǔnuò*,
emptiness is not worth itself.

The sage acts without contrivance—
when things arise, he responds,
responding yet never exhausted.

All that is fitting yet unerring,
we call it *guījǔ* [rule/criterion],
and thus accord with it as *guījǔ*.
We call it *quánhéng* [balance/weights],
and thus accord with it as *quánhéng*.

Who can name its self-possession?
Even so,
when governing emperors and kings,
embodying the Dao is his mind—
in affairs, he is called "without contrivance";
in things, he is called "without possession."
How does this differ from *lǐ* [rites] and *yì* [justice], laws and measures?

Yet those who cling to *lǐ* and *yì*, laws and measures,
do I not also name them?
They name themselves in their own accord—
I do not bend to such naming.

What issues forth yet ever issues more,
what responds yet ever multiplies—
this is the supreme principle preserved.

Excessive speech leads to exhaustion,
better to hold fast to the Center.

This passage, from the Dao’s emptiness as function,
to the *tǔnuò*’s void response,
ends again with "Excessive speech leads to exhaustion,
better to hold fast to the Center"—
compared to the previous chapter,
it still regards speech as the Center.

Laozi likens the *tǔnuò* to the sage’s silence—
when speech is pressed, it moves;
when stirred, it responds—
because he acts without contrivance.

The *Yì* [Book of Changes] says:
"Speech and action are the pivot and hinge of the *jūnzǐ* [noble/gentleman]."
The pivot and hinge’s operation
determines honor and shame.
Yet it is merely fitting and appropriate.

The Center’s adherence is without fault—
not merely without fault but with method.
Confucius said:
"Moderation as *virtue/power* is indeed so—
thus speech must not be reckless."

Jūn Píng said:
"When words are spoken, calamity enters;
when words are lost, the body perishes."
Hán Zǐ said:
"Be cautious with water and fire as well."
The Dao is originally without speech—
when speech is unavoidable,
response must be measured.

If one desires speech,
how can it be avoided?
Thus, thrice he seals his mouth.
The sage thus demonstrates his form—
students seek the sage’s intent.

Shào Ruòyú said:
"Heaven and Earth’s *not-kindness* is supreme,
yet still not as good as adhering to the Center."

Heaven and Earth follow the Dao’s natural course—
this is called supreme *kindness*.
If not supreme *kindness*,
then there is partiality—
spring’s birth is not *kindness*,
autumn’s killing is not *not-kindness*.

The *tǐ* [sacrificial vessels] are discarded when their use is done,
treating all things as sacrificial dogs.

The sage holds *one mind* as *virtue/power*—
thus he takes the people’s mind as his own.
Rewarding the good is not *kindness*,
punishing the evil is not *not-kindness*.

Following the people’s needs,
rewarding and punishing according to the times—
thus the analogy of treating the people as sacrificial dogs.

Zhuāngzi said:
"Supreme *kindness* knows no partiality,
great *kindness* is *not-kindness*."

Only *not-kindness* is called great *kindness*.

Between Heaven and Earth—
meaning the four directions and above and below—
it is like the *tǔnuò*.

The *tǔnuò* is hollow within,
its function lies in the void,
yet it does not bend.

Discarding it to inflate the wind,
using the *nuò* [valve] to direct the breath—
moving yet ever issuing forth,
like the opening and closing of *Qiánkūn* [Heaven and Earth].

Laozi prefers "Excessive speech leads to exhaustion,
better to hold fast to the Center."
The Center is voidness—
dwelling in the mind within voidness,
its function is endless.

Wáng Zhìrán said:
"Heaven and Earth’s *not-kindness* is supreme,
yet still not as good as adhering to the Center."

The Great Dao acts without contrivance in Heaven and Earth,
yet Heaven and Earth depend upon it before they arise.
Heaven and Earth act without contrivance toward all things,
yet all things also depend upon it before they stir.
Only after Heaven and Earth arise
do all things exist—
and among all things,
humans are the most refined,
yet none fail to receive their natural endowment.
Initially, there is no mind of love or gain—
if *kindness* is considered favor,
is it not too small?

Heaven and Earth have no *emotion*—
they regard all things as sacrificial dogs.
Yet Heaven and Earth never demand repayment from all things,
nor do all things know
the favor of Heaven and Earth’s ceaseless generation—
great favor arises naturally.

The sage has no *emotion*,
yet he never demands repayment from the people,
nor do the people know
the power of the sovereign’s influence—
great transformation is thus accomplished.

Heaven and Earth toward all things,
the sage toward the people—
yet their natural order is self-formed,
where is room for contrivance?

Pursuing without end,
everyday use unknown—
where is the place for *kindness*?

Moreover, sacrificial dogs,
though pure and unsoiled,
are used in sacrifices—
when their use is at its height,
they are like the *táixì* [victim] in the grand temple,
adorned with embroidered robes,
treated with reverence as if divine,
yet without private favor or demand.
Once their use is done,
they are equal to dung and soil—
yet this is not from neglect or abandonment.
The haste between use and discarding—
is this not the sage’s contrivance?

Thus, Heaven, Earth, and the sage
regard themselves as sacrificial dogs—
then their view of all things and the people
is likewise without distinction.

Inflating the primordial *qi*,
stirring all existence—
like the *tǔnuò*, like the *nuò*—
pressed, then it moves;
stirred, then it responds.
Empty yet unyielding,
moving yet ever issuing forth—
the analogy is as the Dao’s response to things,
endless variations without end.

The interplay of transformations—
also like humans’ *emotions*.

The person expands the Dao/Way,
not the Dao/Way expanding the person.
The sage’s words are not confined by rhetoric—
when words suffice, the Dao/Way is exhausted in a day;
when words do not suffice, one may speak all day yet exhaust only things.
Eloquent discourse may pierce through,
silence embraces supreme truths—
yet if insight is shallow,
words fail to illuminate the Dao/Way,
the more one speaks, the further one strays from it.

Must there be a tongue of benevolent grace,
a mouth that pours forth rivers of speech,
when examined by great principle—
what true merit is there?
Better to remain silent yet deeply comprehend,
constructing wisdom in stillness.

Thus it is said:
Nine truths in ten words,
are not as good as one silence;
many words often fail,
better to uphold the central truth.

Huang Maozai remarked:
Heaven and Earth lack virtue/power until they treat the people as sacrificial dogs.
Heaven and Earth, toward all things,
do no harm—only let them follow their nature.
The sage, toward the people,
does no disturbance—only lets them flourish naturally.
Letting them flourish naturally,
so the people have no failing to thrive;
letting them follow their nature,
so things have no failing to fulfill.
This is their virtue/power most profound.

When they let things be as they are,
as if without concern or affection,
thus Heaven and Earth and the sage are said to lack virtue/power.
Like the sacrificial dogs—
using straw as dogs,
offered in sacrifice,
discarded once spent—
what concern or affection remains?
The doctrines of Shen Buhai and Han Fei
thus stole this to become the *criminal nomenclature*[*xíngmíng*], most cruel in their severity.

When questioned,
they say: "The sage’s governance of the world
has no concern or affection."
Their reasoning stems from this.

Has this not strayed from Laozi’s intent?

Between Heaven and Earth, nothing surpasses the virtue/power of *guard-the-center*[*shǒuzhōng*].

Heaven occupies the upper position, Earth the lower—this all people know.
The secret interplay of yin and yang, the hidden shifts of creation—this no one can know.

Now, let us liken it to the *bellies*[*tuó*] and *tubes*[*yuè*]: the Dao of Heaven and Earth is nearly contained in *wuwei*[*non-action*].

Empty and void in essence, thus it does not bend;
Ever-moving without cessation, thus it ever emerges anew.

Laozi’s Dao has no inner or outer—
to awaken to the *sacrificial-dog* teaching, one may forget the form and body;
to grasp the principle of *bellies* and *tubes*, one may refine *jing* and *qi*.

This should be self-evident without words—
speak of it, and one will exhaust its meaning.
Only *guard-the-center* attains it.

Program Tai said: Heaven and Earth are without virtue/power, treating all things as *sacrificial dogs*.
Binding straw into a dog’s shape—
when used in sacrifice, it is honored; once the rite is done, it is cast aside.
This is how things may be noble or base at different times.

Heaven and Earth generate and transform all things,
yet they cyclically replace one another—
truly like the *sacrificial dog*.

When rice ripens, wheat withers;
when melons grow, the *qí* plant dies;
when deer shed their antlers, spring and winter reverse.
Geese and swallows depart as guests—
south and north, they avoid one another.

Among all creatures, their inherent natures differ vastly—
thus what suits one may not suit another.
If one governs universally,
and yet harbors a heart of *virtue/power*,
then whom shall one favor?

To benefit one is to harm another,
to profit one is to neglect a hundred—
such *virtue/power* is laborious and petty.

If one aligns with the *qi* of things,
and acts when their roots and natures align,
then they arise and transform themselves,
take form and color themselves,
consume and rest themselves—
while Heaven and Earth seem to take no part in it.

This is *virtue/power* without *virtue/power*.
The sage is without *virtue/power*,
treating the people as *sacrificial dogs*.
The sage acts without intent,
yet employs the *Great Rectification* to model Heaven and Earth.

Thus, though never curving to love one person,
no one fails to receive their virtue/power.

Zhuangzi extended this, saying:
*"The most virtuous has no favorites—*
*let me forget the world,*
*and the world will forget me.*
This is the *true non-seven*[*zhēngbùqī*] virtue/power."

Though its blessings cover all,
the world does not know its virtue/power—
this is not true forgetting.

He also said:
*"The sage’s love for people—*
*if you name it for them,*
*they will not know it as love unless told."*

This too spreads blessings across ages,
yet the sage does not know it as *virtue/power*.
This is called *virtue/power* without *virtue/power*.

If one selects things to love,
and extends kindness only to those within one’s favor—
this is like a tiger or wolf
that does not devour its own young.

*Virtue/power* without *virtue/power*
is not its true essence.

Mencius said:
*"Kill them, and they bear no grudge;
benefit them, and they do not repay.*
The people daily improve and distance themselves from fault,
yet do not know who acts for them—
this is the method of their governance.
To say that plowing, digging, play, and leisure
are not the Emperor’s doing—
this is how their effects manifest."*

Between Heaven and Earth, movement is endless and ever emerges anew.

*Tuó* means to regulate *yuè*[*leather bellows*];
*yuè* is its tube.
In music, it is the *羽钥*[*yǔyuè*];
in locks, it is the *管钥*[*guǎnyuè*];
in foundry tools, it is the *橐钥*[*tuóyuè*];
yet in essence, it is but one.

*Tuó* is the belly that draws in breath and fills it,
then disperses it into the furnace.
*Yuè* is the tube that receives this breath
and exhales it to disperse it.

The pattern of one exhale and one inhale
is the alternating movement of yin and yang as the four seasons.

Thus, between Heaven and Earth,
cold and heat succeed one another as the four seasons,
life and death replace each other as the ages pass—
just as the *tuóyuè* exhales and inhales.

Jia Yi matched the creation of yin, yang, and all things
to the casting of metal—
his meaning stems from this.

The alternating exhale and inhale
are the mutual urging of *action* and *return*.
The wondrous must decay into rot,
and rot must return to the wondrous—
this is how things may be noble or base at different times.

To say that between Heaven and Earth is like the *tuóyuè*
means that all things shaped between the two
are formed by its inhaling and exhaling,
its expansion and contraction.

Zhuangzi’s discourse on things begins:
*"Yin and yang intermingle to form harmony, and thus things arise.
Ebb and flow, fullness and emptiness—
one dark, one bright—
daily changing, monthly transforming,
ever acting yet unseen in its function,
beginning and ending in life and death,
contrasting yet endless, unknown in its extremity."*

Yin and yang intermingle, and all things draw life from it—
this is the origin of things.
*Action* and *return* are the progression of generation and transformation.
Ebb and flow, full and empty—
yin and yang in motion, governing the inhale and exhale of the *tuóyuè*.
Change and transformation, life and death—
things alternately becoming *sacrificial dogs*.

Laozi borrowed the *tuóyuè* and *sacrificial dog* to speak of his principles;
Zhuangzi directly transmitted them in affairs.

Many words exhaust meaning—
better to *guard-the-center*.

All schools say this *center* is the *middle* of *Zhōngyōng*[*The Doctrine of the Mean*],
but Su Huangmen [*Su Xun*] disagrees:
*"This is the void of the *tuóyuè* dwelling in the center—*
his explanation is correct."*

Laozi sought to establish a singular doctrine,
and thus altered or replaced all the *Six Classics*’ terms for the Dao.

The *Six Classics* speak of *middle*—
Laozi called this *good*.
Yet he never spoke of *middle* in his own book.

Then what is this *middle*?
Like the *center* of a *domain*, an *archer’s bow*, or a *ring*—
naming a place within things,
not like the *middle* of *Zhōngyōng*,
which reaches the utmost and names its principle.

Thus, *guard-the-center*
refers specifically to the *center* of the *tuóyuè*,
to be held as its pivot—
like the *shū* [*pivot*] attaining the *center* of the *ring*,
to respond to the boundless.

Speakers first act and then name what they describe—
saying, *"This deed’s virtue/power is all my doing."*
Yet when applied to the world,
it may or may not be fitting,
may or may not align—
this cannot be certain.

「If one does not wait for the fitting moment but first gives form to words,
then those who conjecture and guess may occasionally hit upon the truth—
but those who conjecture and guess without hitting the mark are far more numerous,
and their efforts inevitably lead to exhaustion.

If one instead *guards-the-center*,
the response to sensation at first seems sluggish and dull,
yet in the end, it never falters or reaches exhaustion.
Thus it is said: *"It is better to guard-the-center."*

Discussing the space between heaven and earth is like speaking of *tuóyuè*—
its rise and fall all depend on the *succession* of the *Daode*’s *forging*.

The *Daode* is the one who wields *transformations*.
To allow oneself to be emptied and thus yield to the *Daode*’s manipulation,
one becomes the source of the ebb and flow of *yin* and *yang*—
for all things with form, emptiness brings fluidity,
fluidity allows for *inducing change*;
solidity brings stagnation,
stagnation leads only to inertness.

The *tuó*’s capacity to *absorb*,
the *yuè*’s capacity to *exhale*,
both arise from their emptiness.
Without the *tuó*’s emptiness, there would be no way to contain its *absorbing*;
without the *yuè*’s emptiness, there would be no way to effect its *exhaling*.
If the *tuóyuè* remains ever-empty,
it can receive the *eternal generation* of the *Daode* as its *rise*,
and receive the *transformations* of the *Daode* as its *fall*—
this is like borrowing the hollow space within the *tuóyuè*
to illustrate that what is not stagnant can still receive.

Only because it is not stagnant
does the *spreading qi* find a way to enter it.
The *Daode*’s *mechanism* is triggered by movement,
and it is *stirred* to *rise*—
this is its ability to manipulate *generation* and *transformation*.
Because it remains empty yet unyielding,
it can receive what is present
and manifest it in the world.

The *yin* and *yang qi* hides within the *Great Emptiness*,
yet takes form in sensation.
When sensation responds,
it can bring forth the *non-existent* as the *existent*.

The *tuóyuè* is not the *Great Emptiness*—
its emptiness allows for reception,
its reception does not cling—
it mirrors the *symbol* of all things entering and exiting the *mechanism*,
so this *mechanism* never ceases,
and *rise* and *fall* are endless.

Thus, the one who remains *still* and *unmoving*
is able to respond to sensation and thereby attain fluidity.

Discussing the marvel of the *tuóyuè*
is nearly akin to the *Gu shén*—
yet it cannot be fully aligned with it.
The *Gu shén* can *self-regulate* existence and non-existence,
while the *tuóyuè*’s *exhaling* and *absorbing*
still depend on the *Daode*’s *transformation*.
When *stirred* to *exhale*,
it differs from *self-receiving* and *self-responding*—
thus this chapter speaks of the *tuóyuè*,
and the next chapter turns to the *Gu shén*.

**Zhān Qiūpǔ** said:
*"Heaven and earth’s lack of virtue/power is as extreme as guarding-the-center.*
The *Daode*’s *non-attachment* chapter states that heaven and earth do not act from partiality or favor as virtue/power,
but treat all things as *fuel-for-sacrifice*—
the wise do not act from partiality or favor as virtue/power,
but treat the people as *fuel-for-sacrifice*.

*Fuel-for-sacrifice* is sufficient to feed horses and cattle,
and dogs are sufficient to guard homes—
these are all useful things,
relied upon by people for their needs.
The space between heaven and earth is like the *tuóyuè*—
its hollow center can *fan* and stir to generate *wind*,
yet though it is hollow, it does not bend or break.
This is the marvel of *non-attachment*—
when *fanning wind*, the more one moves, the more it exhales,
its marvel is beyond naming—
yet it is not as profound as steadfastly *guarding-the-center*,
which allows for boundless use.

**Zhāng Chōngyìng** replied:
*"Heaven and earth’s lack of virtue/power is as extreme as guarding-the-center.*
The virtue/power of the *Dao* is vast and boundless,
beyond any form or description—
thus Confucius rarely spoke of it,
and Laozi did not claim it as his own.
Rarely speaking means that it cannot be described in words,
and not claiming it means that it cannot be described yet he does not dwell on it either.
Heaven and earth do not claim virtue/power as their own,
thus they can *cover* and *encompass*—
all things generate and grow within them,
yet they do not know how they come to be.
The sage does not claim virtue/power as their own,
thus they can *include* and *contain*—
the people thrive and rest within them,
yet they do not know how they come to thrive.
All is seen as *fuel-for-sacrifice*—
loved and nurtured,
yet never cherished or held dear,
for fear of harm or decay—
the heart remains unperturbed, without attachment.

The reason heaven and earth lack virtue/power,
the reason the sage lacks virtue/power,
is that they follow the *single principle* of *qi* as it flows endlessly above and below—
like the *tuóyuè*’s capacity to *enclose*,
or the *yuè*’s capacity to *blow*—
circulating without end,
encompassing without limit—
though empty, it is never exhausted when *blown*,
though vast, it is never diminished when *stirred*—
the virtue/power of the *Dao* is boundless like this.
Thus Confucius said:
*"What words does heaven have?*
The *Four Seasons* move in their course."
Then the heart of heaven and earth, of all things,
has no voice within it.

If one desires to learn the *Dao*,
to embody the *transformations* of heaven and earth,
and yet still clings to words,
their tongue will tire,
their spirit will be disordered,
their essence will be depleted,
and their *qi* will falter—
all will reach exhaustion.

Thus it is said: *"It is better to guard-the-center."*
One should *guard* this *square-inch* [of the heart],
and *spread virtue/power* among things,
yet not reveal its traces.

**Bái Yùchán** said:
*"Heaven and earth lack virtue/power—*
they have no *heart* and treat all things as *fuel-for-sacrifice*,
letting them be as they are.
The sage lacks virtue/power—
they take heaven and earth’s *heart* as their own,
and treat the people as *fuel-for-sacrifice*,
yet still *forget-the-self*—
what else could there be?

The space between heaven and earth is the *heart*—
is it like the *tuóyuè*?
It flows without ceasing,
empty yet unyielding,
its use is endless.
When *stirred*, it exhales ever more,
pure and unchanging.
How can it be spoken of?
It is better to *guard-the-center*,
to exhaust what lies within us.

**Liào Cuìrán** said:
*"Heaven and earth lack virtue/power—*
they originate from humanity,
yet if one *returns* to their *root*,
treating all things as *fuel-for-sacrifice*,
then one should regard all things as *unconscious objects*—
in humanity, one must also *overcome-the-self* in this way.
The sage lacks virtue/power—
humanity’s ruler is also rooted in virtue/power,
yet by *returning* to their *root* and *restoring* to the *origin*,
treating the people as *fuel-for-sacrifice*—
one should abandon all the people as *useless objects*,
as in humanity, one must also *revert to ritual*."」

The space between Heaven and Earth,
within its embrace—
like the bellows and flute, is it not?

To Heaven and Earth, it is vast emptiness.
To my body, it is a stinking sack.
Empty yet unyielding,
when released, it fills the six directions,
when gathered, it does not overflow a single fistful.
Stirred, it exhales ever more—
*original qi* surging forth,
endless and unceasing.

Too much speech leads to exhaustion,
better to align with silence,
to seal the lips like a bottle.
It is better to *guard-the-center*,
to embrace the *original* and uphold the *One*,
endless and boundless.

If humanity acts thus,
the *Dao-qi* will be preserved.

**Chén Bìxū** said:
*"Heaven and Earth lack virtue/power*
until they treat the people as *fuel-for-sacrifice*—
*Sū* (草), the grass.
To bind the grass as a dog,
ancient rites used it for sacrifice,
to dispel omens of ill fortune,
and cast it aside once used—
in ordinary times, they did not cherish it,
yet when cast aside, they did not hate it either.
Thus, *fuel-for-sacrifice* is formed by divine intelligence,
yet divine intelligence has no use for it.

Without use, there is no partiality;
without partiality, there is no favor.
Therefore, Heaven and Earth, though lacking in favor,
generate great favor;
the sage, though not virtuous,
achieves great virtue.

To lack virtue/power—
it means no attachment to love,
not that they scorn what is evil.

Thus, Heaven and Earth, without attachment,
regard all things as *fuel-for-sacrifice*,
demanding no return from the myriad creatures.
The sage, without attachment,
regards the people as *fuel-for-sacrifice*,
demanding no return from the people.
This is the natural way of Heaven and Earth.

**Yán Jūnping** said:
*"Heaven is high and clear,
Earth is thick and tranquil.
Yin and Yang intermingle,
harmonious *qi* flows unceasing,
yet effortlessly, all things arise naturally.
Heaven and Earth do not strain their hearts,
move their intentions,
exhaust their spirits,
or labor over affairs—
no anxious care,
no lavish love,
no spreading of favor,
no granting of benefits—
yet all things are fulfilled.
This is what is meant by
*Heaven and Earth lack virtue/power,
treating all things as fuel-for-sacrifice*.

The enlightened king and sage
uphold the *Dao-qi* in harmony,
clear and unchanging,
transforming through the *One*,
divine intelligence silently guiding,
conforming to the *Dao*'s rites,
the world responding,
all things transforming naturally.
The sage does not exhaust wisdom,
deplete ability,
disturb the heart,
or strain the mind—
no ceasing of thought,
no restless wandering,
no grasping of human affairs,
no leading of the people—
yet all is fulfilled.
This is what is meant by
*the sage lacks virtue/power,
treating the people as fuel-for-sacrifice*.

The space between Heaven and Earth is stirred yet ever more exhales—
The bellows (*tuó*) holds the wind,
flute (*yuè*) emits the sound.
Like the bellows blowing wind to kindle fire,
or the flute releasing notes to tune the music,
its application is endless,
yet it can never be bent.
Thus, the sage—
without partiality, without attachment—
does not engage in love or gain.

**Yán Jūnping** further said:
*"If Heaven and Earth abandon emptiness
and engage in love and gain,
then transformation will falter,
and things will not fully arise.
If the sage abandons emptiness
and engages in love and gain,
then virtue and grace will not be universal,
the realm will not be at peace,
favor will not reach the depths,
and affairs will not be fully accomplished.
Why so?
For the art of love demands measure,
yet the myriad things aspire to boundless transformation.
To wield measured gain
and bestow it upon boundless potential—
its failure is as certain as a dried riverbed,
and to aid it is to weep in vain.

Again he said:
Lice and fleas move upon the hair,
yet sleep is disturbed by them;
mosquitoes and flies settle on the skin,
yet the spirit is agitated,
thoughts stifled.
External harm from wasp and scorpion venom
poisons the core within,
while unseen damage to ears and eyes
leaves all limbs paralyzed.
This shows that love and gain,
when harbored in the chest,
cannot but yield to strain,
impurity, and depletion of blood and *qi*.

Too much speech leads to exhaustion,
better to align with silence.
Too much speech—
it means excessive words of universal love.
Excessive words make biased action difficult,
and thus exhaustion comes,
bending yet never succeeding.
If one follows Heaven and Earth’s emptiness and tranquility,
and the bellows and flute’s heartlessness,
embracing and upholding the *center’s harmony*,
then its natural sufficiency will be enough.
It also lies in the teaching of *non-speech*.
*The Honglie Jie* says:
*Wáng Shòu* carried books as he walked,
and met *Xú Féng* in Zhou.
*Xú Féng* said:
*‘Affairs arise from responding to change,
and change is born of time,
so one who knows time has no fixed action.
Books are the source of speech,
and speech comes from knowledge.
Knowledge keeps the books hidden.’*
Thus, *Wáng Shòu* burned his books
and danced, saying:
*‘Too much speech leads to exhaustion,
better to align with silence.’*

**Xiè Túnán** said:
*"Heaven and Earth lack virtue/power*
until they treat the people as *fuel-for-sacrifice*.
All things receive Heaven and Earth’s *qi* to arise,
the people receive the sage’s grace to flourish—
to say they lack virtue/power is impossible.
Yet rise and fall, success and failure,
are entrusted to natural forces,
and life and death, calamity and fortune,
are summoned by humanity alone.
Heaven and Earth, the sage—
in this, they have no attachment at all.
To say they lack virtue/power
is not to say they lack it.
It is that they cannot wield their virtue/power in action.
*Fuel-for-sacrifice*—
it is the remnant after sacrifice,
left to its own formation and decay,
with no further thought given to it.
The space between Heaven and Earth—
its principle for all things is natural and effortless,
thus the two *qi* of Yin and Yang
flow through the void without obstruction,
like the bellows and flute.
The bellows has no bottom,
the flute has holes.
The bellows’ emptiness allows *qi* to circulate,
unbending, unbroken;
the flute’s holes let sound resonate,
ever more exhale, never cease.
All this is natural and effortless.
Things and humanity within Heaven and Earth—
their beginning and end, their transformation—
are also natural and effortless.
Thus, too much speech leads to repeated exhaustion,
and cannot be fully accomplished,
better to uphold the *One*’s central principle."*

The principle reaches its apex in *zhōng* and stops there.
Heaven and Earth, sages, common folk, all things under Heaven—
none exist beyond this *zhōng*.

Now let us examine this:
All things and all people share this same *qi*.
All beings between Heaven and Earth share this same mind.

What is Heaven’s mind?
To nurture life is its mind.
What is the sage’s mind?
To love the people is its mind.

Yet at the beginning, when life first arises,
it cannot but change by its end.
At the start, when love is given,
it cannot but differ later.

Why?
Heaven’s way establishes Yin and Yang,
humanity’s way establishes *rén* and *yì*.
Life emerges—this is Yang—
yet it cannot lack the solemn and killing Yin.
Nurturing is *rén*—
yet it cannot lack the cutting and restraining *yì*.
This is the natural course of things.

Even a humble *chúgǒu*—a minor thing—
yet when it is nurtured for sacrifice,
one fears its integrity may be incomplete.
But once the sacrifice is done,
it is cast aside as useless,
crushed and broken—
none can escape this fate.

All beings in Heaven and Earth
share the same original endowment,
and all life is worthy of love.
Yet once formed, they scatter and differ—
some are cultivated, some are toppled,
some are blessed, some are doomed,
each following its own portion.

At this time,
Heaven and Earth’s nurturing virtue,
the sage’s loving care—
there are aspects that cannot be fully preserved.
To call this *not-rén* is to say
one cannot exhaust one’s *rén*.

Heaven and Earth use the *zhōng*’s emptiness—
like the bellows and flute—to nurture all things.
The sage uses the *zhōng*’s path
to respond and reciprocate with the people.

Thus, in one word, it is said:
*"Better to uphold the *zhōng*."*

What is this *zhōng*?
Is it the utmost impartiality, without favor?
Is it the avoidance of excess or deficiency?

Lin Yōngzhāi said:
*"Heaven and Earth’s lack of *rén* is why one must uphold the *zhōng*."*

Nurturing life—this is *rén*.
Yet Heaven and Earth, though they nurture life,
do not claim it as merit,
forgetting themselves with all things.

Nurturing the people—this is *rén*.
Yet the sage, though nurturing the people,
does not claim it as favor,
forgetting themselves with the people.

*Not-rén* means not possessing one’s own *rén*.
The *chúgǒu*, once used and discarded,
is an illustration of mutual forgetting.

Chapter Thirty-Eight says:
*"The sage’s highest virtue is without virtue,
thus it has virtue."*

*Not-rén* is like *not-de*.
In *Zhuangzi’s* *"Qíwù"*:
*"Great *rén* is not *rén*."*
In *"Tiāndì"*:
*"In the age of perfect virtue,
they love one another without knowing it as *rén*."*

This is the same meaning.

The *chúgǒu*—
when used in sacrifice, it is honored;
once the sacrifice is done, it is cast aside—
an illustration of not dwelling on it,
of mutual forgetting.

Speaking precisely,
this implies the intent to transform what is excessive.
But if one takes this to mean
treating the people as grass and chaff,
that is mistaken.

The teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi delight in shocking the world and defying convention, hence their language often contains flaws.

This chapter’s core meaning is simply:
The Dao of Heaven and Earth does not harbor intent in nurturing life,
The sage does not harbor intent in nourishing the people.
Yet it speaks thus in strange metaphors,
and readers who lack precision fall into deep error.

Thus it is said that the harshness of Shen Buhai and Han Feizi
originates from the intent of treating the people as *chúgǒu*.
Even Laozi cannot evade blame for this.

The *kǒu* (口) is the tube of the *tuó* (橐).
When the *tuó* and *kǒu* are used, wind arises.
Though its body is hollow,
when applied, it does not bend—
movement generates wind,
the more it operates, the more it produces.

Between Heaven and Earth,
its nurturing of myriad things is likewise so.
The *tuó* and *kǒu* do not harbor intent in generating wind—
Heaven and Earth do not harbor intent in nurturing life.
Thus, this metaphor is used.
Moreover, when used, wind arises;
when unused, it ceases—
this too implies the intent of transforming excess.

*Shù* (数) means "repeatedly."
*Shǒu zhōng* (守中) means silently closing one’s mouth.
It means:
The Dao of Heaven and Earth cannot be fully expressed in words;
excessive speech repeatedly leads to exhaustion—
better to remain silent and forget words.

The Master said:
*"I wish to speak not at all."*
What speech can Heaven have?
The four seasons move within it,
myriad things are born within it.
This is the same meaning.

Yet the sage’s words are pure and easily understood,
while this text oscillates wildly, making it difficult to grasp.
Some may say it warns against excessive speech,
but this contradicts the chapter’s intent.

If one sees through this,
not only does the beginning and end cohere,
the meaning becomes clear,
but its language is also concise, profound, and ancient—
how could this be easily attained?

Fan Yingyuan said:
*"Heaven and Earth are without virtue, treating myriad things as *chúgǒu*.*
*Virtue* is the principle of love.
It is said that Heaven and Earth’s nurturing is vast,
yet they do not speak of virtue—
toward myriad things, it is like binding straw into a dog for sacrifice.
Before it is presented, it is carried in a wicker basket,
covered with embroidered cloth—
not out of love, but because of the occasion.
Once the sacrifice is complete,
passersby trample its head and back,
firewood gatherers take it for fuel—
not that they do not love it,
but because of the occasion.
Spring and summer nurture growth,
like the *chúgǏu* before presentation;
autumn and winter wither and fall,
like the *chúgǒu* after discard—
all is the work of the seasons.
How could it be that they love in spring and summer
but do not love in autumn and winter?
When *qi* arrives, myriad things act without knowing why—
the sage is without virtue, treating the people as *chúgǒu*.
The sage embodies this Dao to universally love,
his virtue is thus supreme.
Yet he does not speak of virtue—
toward the people, it is like Heaven and Earth toward myriad things:
aiding their natural unfolding without harm,
ensuring life and death proceed without regret,
so they do not know the Emperor’s power over them.

Between Heaven and Earth, the more it moves, the more it produces.
The bag is called *tuó*, the bamboo tube is called *kǒu*.
In smelting, the *kǒu* connects the *tuó* to channel *qi* and blow the furnace fire.
*Qū* (屈) means "bent."
*The Yīn Biàn* says: *"Yú"* (俞) is pronounced as *"yáng zhū"* (羊朱).
Fù Yì cites *Guang Yǎ*: *"Yú"* means "benefit."
The *Han Shǐ* records the people’s suffering and hardship as *"yú"* (俞).

Between Heaven and Earth, it is only empty and flowing—
like the bamboo tube channeling *qi*,
empty yet unbent—
when *qi* comes, it passes through;
when *qi* departs, it does not accumulate.
It is like the *tuó* wind:
the more it moves, the more it produces.
Once the furnace’s materials are refined into forms,
the *tuó* and *kǒu* never speak of virtue or love.

Excessive speech leads to exhaustion—
better to uphold the central emptiness of Heaven and Earth,
without deviation, so that myriad things naturally find their place.
How could there be exhaustion?

Xué Yǒngzhāi said:
*"Heaven and Earth are without virtue, treating the people as *chúgǒu*.*
Heaven and Earth nurture myriad things
yet harbor no intent toward them.
The sage nourishes the people
yet harbors no intent toward them.
Between Heaven and Earth, the more it moves, the more it produces.
The *tuó* and *kǒu* remain unobstructed in their emptiness,
thus the more they move, the more sound they produce.
Heaven and Earth’s ability to transform and nurture myriad things without exhaustion
lies in their emptiness and their ability to move.
Excessive speech leads to exhaustion—
better to uphold the central emptiness."

Huì Shī’s eloquence
is not as good as Yán Zhī’s silent cultivation.

Xiū Xiū’ān said:
*"Heaven and Earth are without virtue, treating the people as *chúgǒu*—*
*until it is better to uphold central emptiness.*
The *chúgǒu* is a straw dragon bound for sacrifice,
enclosed in a red lacquered case,
covered with embroidered cloth—
once the sacrifice ends, it is discarded.
Heaven and Earth, the sage—
they embody the marvel of *wuwei*,
nurturing myriad things without expecting gratitude,
not claiming ownership,
allowing things to transform naturally,
like the *chúgǒu*—
thus it seems as though they are without virtue.
Between Heaven and Earth, it is empty like a *tuó* bag,
*qi* flows and runs, nurturing myriad things.
A clear and empty mind is likewise so.
A spontaneous spark of insight,
endless wondrous application—
this is called empty yet unbending,
moving yet ever producing.
The *tuó* is the *tuó* bag,
the *kǒu* is the tube—
instruments for stirring wind and movement.
Though this metaphor illustrates the marvel of transformation,
excessive speech only distances one from the Dao.
Even with great eloquence and repeated analogies,
metaphors are limited in number,
while this Dao is beyond all metaphor—
better to remain silent.
The subtlety of upholding central emptiness
can reveal the penetration of transformation.

Chǔ Bóxiù said:
*"Heaven and Earth are without virtue, treating the people as *chúgǒu*—*
*until it is better to uphold central emptiness.*
*Virtue* is the concrete manifestation of the numinous Dao,
establishing the heart of Heaven and Earth,
continuing the mandate of the people—
like *yuan* (元) to *qián* (乾),
gathering all virtues and achieving completeness,
molding myriad kinds without omission.
In humans, this means perfecting oneself and others,
universal love and benevolent rescue—
all are its applications."*

Heaven and Earth possess natural virtue beyond speech and symbols.
The Sage embodies Heaven’s virtue and extends benevolence,
thus expanding the Imperial Dao and achieving governance.
Yet the text speaks of "not-ren" (不仁)—why?
It means their virtue is not displayed,
like *upper virtue* not being called virtue—
a paradoxical statement.
Using the analogy of bound straw shaped as a dog for sacrifice,
before sacrifice it is adorned with love and respect,
afterward discarded and trampled—
its creation and destruction are mere transformations,
not rooted in affection or aversion.
This reveals the true nature beneath illusion,
and the logic of things becomes clear.

All moving, growing, flying, and swimming beings,
their birth, flourishing, decline, and return,
are but the circulation of one *qi*,
flowing endlessly—
like bound straw becoming a dog,
then the dog returning to straw.
How could there be any intentionality here?

The Sage, regarding the people,
lets them pursue their affairs,
while the Dao naturally unfolds.
This is what Zhuangzi meant by *"great virtue is not-ren."*

Between Heaven and Earth, it is like the bellows and windbox.
This also speaks of its lack of intention.
The bellows and windbox, when activated,
blow air through the pipes—
like the circulation of *qi* in yin and yang,
breathing without pause.
All beings and things are cast in its molding.
Only when it remains centrally empty and unobstructed
does its movement of *qi* flow ever outward.
This principle harmonizes perfectly with the transformations of creation—
why speak further, only to exhaust oneself?
Better to uphold the bellows and windbox within oneself,
to explore the Heaven and Earth within,
for where is the logic of generating all things?

Some interpret the excessive words of the restless as an explanation,
but this does not align with the context above and below.
The core meaning of this passage lies in *"upholding centrality."*
The profound truth is so subtle and mysterious
that only scholars who practice diligently
can verify within themselves the presence of a Heaven and Earth—
for it exists within the human body alone.

**Niu Miaozhuan said:**
Heaven and Earth are not-ren,
treating all things as bound straw-dogs.
Yet the great virtue of Heaven and Earth is *generation*—
unceasing generation is called *ren*.
*Ren* is the virtue of Heaven and Earth’s creation.
Yet it says "not-ren"—
meaning Heaven and Earth do not possess virtue for themselves.
All things are the myriad kinds filling Heaven and Earth.
The bound straw-dog refers to ancient sage-kings’ sacrifices,
where straw was bound into dog-shaped offerings—
*Shu* (刍) being reeds or thatch.
Though reeds are humble, their use is weighty;
the dog, a domesticated beast,
holds the *xu* (戌) position and corresponds to *Qian* (乾).
Thus, ancient people shaped reeds into dogs for sacrifice,
symbolizing their reverence.
If Heaven and Earth treat all things as bound straw-dogs,
it is not that they hold them lightly.
Some argue that Heaven and Earth regard all things
as mindless straw and beasts,
expecting no reciprocation—
this reasoning is flawed.
All things share *qi* with Heaven and Earth in their origin,
only differing in the smallness of their form.
If Heaven and Earth truly viewed all things
as mere straw and beasts,
then they would be selfishly hoarding their own greatness—
would that not be *not-ren*?
This is my shallow understanding.
The enlightened will discern it.

The Sage is not-ren,
treating the people as bound straw-dogs.
The Sage is the complete embodiment of utility,
a teacher for all ages.
Thus, the people revere them like the sun and moon,
look up to them like parents.
Yet it is called "not-ren"—
not claiming virtue for oneself,
a humble and exalted stance,
as Confucius himself did not dwell on it.
The people are the common folk.
Though the Sage and the people share the same *qi*,
their noble or humble, prosperous or destitute fates differ.
If the Sage treats the people as bound straw-dogs,
it is not that they are held lightly.
Some say the Sage views the people
as mindless straw and beasts,
expecting no reciprocation—
this interpretation is likely mistaken.
Humans stand alongside Heaven and Earth,
the Three Powers in equilibrium—
how could they be compared to straw and beasts?
Mencius said:
*"If a ruler treats his ministers as hands and feet,
the ministers will treat the ruler as their heart.
If a ruler treats his ministers as dogs and horses,
the ministers will treat the ruler as a commoner.
If a ruler treats his ministers as dust and weeds,
the ministers will treat the ruler as an enemy."*
If the Sage truly regarded the people
as mere straw and beasts,
then the Sage would indeed be not-ren.
My fellow seekers,
I earnestly hope you will discern this truth.

Between Heaven and Earth,
the more movement, the more it emerges.

The bellows belong to the drum family.
The *piào* (笛) is a flute, of the pipe family.
*"Yóu"* (犹) means *"like."*

Movement means *use*.
Between Heaven and Earth, the void is empty,
yet it employs the Four Seasons and Five Phases.
The bellows and *piào* are instruments—
their emptiness is void,
employing the Five Tones and Six Pitches.
Thus it is said:
*"Between Heaven and Earth, it is like the bellows and *piào*."*

The Old Master (老君) said:
*"The bellows and *piào* are instruments,
their value lies in their use.
Empty yet full, present yet absent,
round yet square, vast yet minute,
long yet short, broad yet narrow—
they follow the player’s will,
yet do not compete for mastery.
Humans in the world—
are they not like the bellows and *piào*?
They do not contend with all things,
yet their virtue naturally returns.
This is because they are humble, empty, and without striving.
This truly speaks of Heaven and Earth’s virtue:
to receive all things in their void,
to let nature take its course,
to follow the people’s desires,
not to contend with things,
just as the bellows and *piào*
follow the player’s breath and notes."*

Too much speech leads to regret.
Speech is the voice of the heart.
In the heart, it is *intent* (志);
when expressed, it is speech.
*"Shù"* (数) means *frequent*;
*"qióng"* (穷) means *regret and loss*.
Too much speech means too many faults—
thus it is said: *"Too much speech leads to regret."*

The ancients said:
*"A single word can ruin a state—
this is the speech of the highest kind of fool.
A single word can bring disaster—
this is the speech of the middling fool.
A single word can bring shame—
this is the speech of the lowest fool."*

Thus Heaven has the *rolling-tongue star* (卷舌之星),
and humans have the *sealed-mouth inscription* (缄口之铭).
Speech cannot be taken lightly.
It is said:
*"The gentleman desires to be slow in speech yet quick in action."*
This is indeed correct.

In ancient times, Confucius observed the Zhou,
and entered the Temple of Houji (后稷).
On the right step stood a golden man,
his mouth sealed three times,
with an inscription on his back:
*"A man of caution in speech in ancient times.
Beware of excessive speech!"*
Avoid too much speech—
too much speech leads to failure.
Avoid too much action—
too much action leads to calamity.

The *Book of Poetry* (《诗》) says:
*"Revere your bearing,
be cautious in your words."*
This is what it means.

Better still is to *guard the Middle* (守中).
The *Middle* is the *pivot and mechanism* (枢机).
To *guard* means to be *vigilant* (谨).
Moreover, the sun and moon—
they are Heaven’s *ornaments* (文).
Mountains and rivers—
they are Earth’s *ornaments*.
Speech and language—
they are humanity’s *ornaments*.
Yet speech issues from the mouth,
like a blade held in check—
do not move it lightly.
It is like a drawn bowstring,
which may still be stopped,
but once the arrow leaves the string,
even if you wish to recall it,
you cannot.

The *Appendices to the Changes* (《系辞》) say:
*"Words issue from the self and affect the people;
actions arise nearby and are seen afar.
Speech and action—
the pivot and mechanism of the gentleman.
When the pivot and mechanism are set in motion,
honor and disgrace are determined.
Speech and action—
by which the gentleman moves Heaven and Earth.
Can they not be taken with caution?
This is the meaning of *better still is to guard the Middle*."*

The *Book of Changes* (《易》) says:
*"To bind the bag without blame or praise—
this is indeed caution, is it not?"*

Yang Zhìrén (杨智仁) said:
*"Heaven and Earth’s lack of virtue is the ultimate *guard the Middle* (守中).*
Heaven and Earth do not act with virtue,
yet they regard all things as *straw-dogs* (刍狗).
They bestow transformation without virtue or favor—
nature takes its course,
and they do not expect reciprocation.
The Sage is the same.
For those who study the Dao/Way,
do not cling to even a single hair of material desire.
If the Great Void (太虚) is calm and ever still,
and the *Three Powers* (三才) operate within it,
the *bellows and *piào* (橐钥) sound through the cosmos,
the Original Qi (元炁) ascends and descends in the Yellow Court (黄庭),
the *Kàn* (坎) and *Lí* (离) transform in their cycles,
the *Sè* (塞) and *Duì* (兑) hang their veils,
the *Hán* (含) and *Guāng* (光) remain silent—
empty yet never yielding,
guarding with *chōnghé* (冲和),
unmoved by trifles,
yet ever more active when moved—
this is the ancient saying:
*'Preserve the body, let go of all,
and not a single thought arises.'*
If one speaks too much and regrets it,
there is loss without gain—
far better is to *guard the Middle* for ages.
Refined and natural,
it blends into one piece.

The Confucianists say:
*'The Sage’s Dao/Way is nothing but virtue and righteousness, moderation and correctness.'*
Heaven, Earth, and the Sage regard all things as straw-dogs—
they do not cling to anything.
The gentleman is matched to Heaven and Earth—
is he not like the bellows and *piào*?
Empty yet never yielding,
active yet ever more so.
Most simple, most easy—
how difficult is it to know?
Thus, too much speech leads to regret,
and better is to *guard the Middle*."

The gentleman is *yellow-centered and harmonious* (黄中通理),
never losing his *correctness* (正).

In further analogy:
*"Heaven and Earth’s lack of virtue is the ultimate *guard the Middle*."*
What does Heaven speak?
The Four Seasons move,
and all things are born.
Heaven and Earth give birth to things
yet do not claim virtue for themselves—
they forget about things.
Unknowing yet unknowing,
they follow the *imperial norm* (帝则),
and the *imperial force* (帝力) has no hold on them.

The Sage nourishes the people
yet does not claim virtue for himself—
he forgets about the people.
*"Straw-dog"* (刍) is *straw*;
it symbolizes *bundled straw shaped like a dog*.
The *Zhuangzi* (《庄子》□*Tiān Rùn* [天运]篇) says:
*"Before the straw-dog is offered in sacrifice,
it is adorned with embroidered bags,
wrapped in silk and brocade.
After the sacrifice is complete,
passersby trample its head and back,
and woodcutters take it to fuel their fires.
It is honored before the sacrifice,
yet despised after the rites are done.
This is the analogy—
it embodies the intent of *transcending form and passing beyond transformation*."*

I have read Liu Zizhu’s (柳子) *Biography of Guo Tuótuo* (《郭橐驼传》),
and from cultivating trees,
I have learned the art of nurturing people.
Guo Tuótuo’s method of planting trees—
do not disturb it, do not fret over it;
once planted, leave it be.
When tending, treat it like a child;
when setting it down, treat it like discarding.
A father toward his child—
how often does he claim credit for his kindness?
His poetry is like a child:
born and raised,
yet he does not claim virtue for himself—
it is simply what he possesses.
If he errs and forgets his possession,
if he transforms and discards what he has placed,
it is like abandoning the straw-dog after sacrifice.
Between Heaven and Earth,
the bellows are struck, the *piào* is played—
one instrument alone.

*"Tuó"* (橐) means *leather bag*;
*"qiào"* (钥) means *pipe*—
the tool by which wind is drawn.
Empty within yet never yielding in use,
the more it is moved, the more it emerges;
the more it emerges, the more it has.
Its origin is boundless,
its issue endless.

The **virtue/power** of the **Dao/Way** of Heaven and Earth and the Sage is also like this.

The **Dao/Way** of Heaven and Earth cannot be fully expressed in words,
yet its transformation through sound and color is the most trivial of human affairs.
Hence it is said:
*"Many words exhaust the limitless"*—
better to uphold the **center** (中).

Upholding the **center** (中),
silently yet naturally preserving itself.

The *Xū Liù Xū* (胥六虚) says:
*"Heaven and Earth’s lack of virtue/power is no greater than upholding the **center** (中)."*

The greatest **virtue/power** of Heaven and Earth is **generation** (生),
yet it treats all things as straw-dogs.
It covers and carries them,
but lets those that thrive grow of their own accord,
while those that wither perish on their own—
Heaven and Earth take no part in this.
This is how Heaven and Earth do not possess their **virtue/power** (仁),
yet treat all things as straw-dogs—
**virtue/power** (仁) is vast indeed.

The straw-dog’s purpose:
before sacrifice, it is honored and revered;
after sacrifice, it is cast aside—
not from a fickle heart,
but simply the nature of the moment.

Thus, the Sage uses it as an analogy.

The Sage embodies the **Dao/Way** of Heaven and Earth,
nurtures the people,
broadens and forgives them,
letting those who flourish do so naturally,
those who grow do so of their own accord.
With tilling and weaving,
their families prosper and the nation is at peace,
yet the Sage takes no credit—
this too is how the Sage does not claim his **virtue/power** (仁),
yet treats the people as straw-dogs.

Between Heaven and Earth,
a single *qi* steams and molds,
all things **generate** and **transform** (生化),
unceasing from ancient times to the present.

It is like the bellows and pipe—
empty within yet boundless in use.
When struck and moved,
sound and *qi* flow forth ever more.
This praises the Sage’s **virtue/power** (德),
vast and limitless—
his **virtue/power** (仁) nourishes the people yet is not his own.

How so?
It is simply **emptiness** (虚).

Thus, in response to the movements of the world,
there is no end to his power.

If one does not grasp the **Dao/Way** (實) of Heaven and Earth’s **non-virtue/power** (不仁), but instead **discerningly** (察然) **seeks** (自好) what is pleasing,
hanging laws and enacting punishments,
adorned with elaborate words and phrases,
to guide the people toward **transformation** (從化),
he violates Heaven and contradicts **principle** (理),
invoking the wrath of the spirits and the resentment of the people.
Thus he hastens toward the **Dao/Way** of **exhaustion** (穷极),
and so I urge him: *"Excessive speech leads to **exhaustion** (穷),
better to hold fast to the **central** (中)."*

*"Excessive speech"* means to adorn with elaborate words and phrases—
many words, few principles—
better to grasp my **central** (中) and **silently** (默) **know** (識) and **practice** (行) it,
**conscientiously** (謹) **guarding** (守) it without loss,
so that the world observes the **wind** (風) and **transforms** (化).

Is there any **exhaustion** (穷) in **teaching without words** (不言之教)?
**Cultivating oneself** (修身) also follows this **Dao/Way** (法).

**Gai Yuan Gao** (柴元皋) said: *"Heaven and Earth are **non-virtue/power** (不仁)."*
They **benefit** (以美利) the world with their **virtue/power** (利) yet do not speak of their own **virtue/power** (利).
They treat all things as **straw-dogs** (刍狗).
**Straw** (刍), **reed** (茅) bound like dogs for sacrifice.
At first, when bound, it is **sincere and pure** (誠洁), **strict and solemn** (甚嚴),
but once the sacrifice is complete, it is cast aside without regard.

The **heart of creation** (造物之心) is likewise as the **straw-dog’s beginning and end** (刍狗之始終):
it follows **nature** (自然).

The **Sage is **non-virtue/power** (不仁)**.
The Sage **embodies** (體) Heaven and Earth,
yet does not speak of his own **virtue/power** (利).
He treats the people as **straw-dogs** (刍狗).
Only he fears that a single person might be **neglected in nourishment** (失養),
just as **strict** (謹) as the first binding of the **reed** (茅),
not daring to **overlook** (忽) even a **thread** (毫).

Between Heaven and Earth lies the **Dao/Way** of the **bellows and pipe** (橐鉤).
**Bellows** (橐), the **leather bag** (冶韛) for smithing.
**Pipe** (鉤), the **three-holed flute** (三孔笛).
Both are **empty within** (虚其中),
their **breath** (氣) **inhaled and exhaled** (一阖一辟).
The same applies to the human body’s **breathing** (呼吸).

The **nourishment of the people** (養民) occurs within a single **breath** (呼吸),
not like Heaven and Earth,
which might cause the people to **lose their place** (失所).
**Cultivating the body and its functions** (修體用) is likewise.
**Empty yet unyielding** (虚而不屈),
its **embodiment** (體) is **unobstructed** (無礙).
**Moved, yet ever more** (動而愈出),
its **function** (用) is **inexhaustible** (不穷).

Excessive speech leads to **exhaustion** (穷),
better to hold fast to the **central** (中).
If one **boasts of his own virtue** (矜其仁) and **prizes speech** (尚口),
