The *Spirit of Grain* [谷神] is the *divine essence within the void* [虚中之神者也]. It is said that *human spirit emerges from the void* [人之神自虚中而出], hence it *endures perpetually without perishing* [故常存而不死].

*Mysterious* [玄] is that which is *remote and boundless* [远而无极者也]. *Feminine* [牝] is that which is *void and unsubstantial* [虚而不实者也]. These two characters merely describe the *void* [虚].

*Heaven and Earth* [天地] arise from this, hence it is called the *root* [根]. *Continuous* [绵绵] conveys the meaning of *unceasing, unbroken* [不已、不绝]. *As if existing* [若存] means *as if present, as if absent* [若有若无]. When applied within the *void and nothingness* [虚无之中], it *endures without labor* [不劳而常存], thus it is said: *void yet unyielding, in motion yet ever emerging* [虚而不屈，动而愈出].

*Master Huì* [晦翁] says: *The most wondrous principle* [至妙之理] contains the *intent of eternal generation* [有生生之意存焉]. This passage is well-phrased, though its meaning leans toward *theories of nourishing life* [养生之论]. Though this chapter may be applied to *cultivation and nourishment* [修养], its original intent was not *exclusively for this purpose* [实不专主是].

*Master Fàn Yīngyuán* [范应元] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is called *the Mysterious Feminine* [是谓玄牝]. *The Spirit of Grain* [谷神] is akin to *void luminosity* [犹言虚灵也]. *Not perishing* [不死] is akin to *boundlessness* [犹言无极也]. *The Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] speaks of *that which generates all things yet remains unseen in its generation* [言其生物而不见其所以生也]. It is said: *void luminosity, boundlessness*—this is the *feminine principle of generation* [虚灵无极], which is unseen in its generation, hence it is called *mysterious* [玄]. *The Spirit of Grain* [谷神]—*Fù Yì* [傅奕] says it is *profound yet penetrating* [幽而通也].

*Sīmǎ Wēngōng* [司马温公] says: *It is called Grain because it is centrally void* [中虚故曰谷], *it is called Spirit because it is unfathomable* [不测故曰神]. *Sū* [苏] says: *Grain is supremely void yet still retains form* [谷至虚而犹有形], *but the Spirit of Grain is void and formless* [谷神则虚而无形也]. If it is *void and formless*, how could there be *anything to die* [虚而无形尚无有生，安有死邪]? Calling it *the Spirit of Grain* [谷神] speaks of its *virtue* [言其德也]; calling it *the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] speaks of its *function* [言其功也]. The *Mysterious Feminine* generates all things yet *remains unseen in its generation* [牝生万物而谓之玄], how could one see its generation without seeing *how it generates* [焉见其生之而不见其所以生也]?

*The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝之门] is called *the root of Heaven and Earth* [是谓天地根]. *Gate* [门] refers to *yin and yang* [指阴阳也]. It is said that *one opening, one closing*—*endless coming and going* [以其一辟一阖，往来不穷而言也]. *Yin and yang* [阴阳者] are spoken of in terms of *the Dao’s motion and stillness* [以道之动静而言也]. When in motion, it is called *yang* [动而曰阳]; when motion reaches its extreme and stillness ensues, it is called *yin* [动极而静曰阴]. Motion reaching its extreme turns to stillness, stillness reaching its extreme turns back to motion—*opening and closing without error* [动极而静，静极复动，开阖不忒], *generation and nurture without end* [生育无穷]. *Root* [根] means *Heaven and Earth originate from this* [谓天地本於此也].

If a person *first attains this in their heart* [人能於此心之初得之], they will know that *the root of Heaven and Earth is a root without root* [天地之根，无根之根也]; *the Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is a gate without gate* [玄牝之门，无门之门也]; *the Spirit of Grain is a spirit without spirit* [谷神，不神之神也]. How could it ever be exhausted?

*Continuous, as if existing* [绵绵若存], *used without exertion* [用之不勤]. It is said that *the Spirit of Grain in Heaven and Earth is continuous and boundless* [谓谷神之在天地，绵绵密密而无极也]. Yet *it cannot be seen when viewed* [然视之不可见], *cannot be heard when listened to* [听之不得闻], *cannot be exhausted when used* [用之不可既], hence it is said: *as if existing*—*Heaven and Earth use it, and the four seasons proceed, all things flourish, yet they never labor* [故曰若存，天地用之而四时行、百物生，未尝劳也]. The *Spirit of Grain in humans* [谷神在人] is likewise.

*Continuous and boundless* [绵绵密密], *eternally generating* [生生无穷], *as its origin*—who could claim dominion over this body? *As its origin*—where could it ultimately reside? Hence it is said: *as if existing* [故曰若存]. Those who *skillfully use it* [善用之者] *never labor* [未尝劳也], how could it ever be exhausted? This chapter should be *profoundly understood* [宜深体之]. Some may interpret it *exclusively for cultivation and nourishment* [或有专就修养上解者], yet one must *first recognize the Spirit of Grain* [然必须认得谷神方可].

*Xuē Yōngzhāi* [薛庸斋] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is called *the root of Heaven and Earth* [至是谓天地根]. *Grain* [谷] is where *the spirit resides* [神所居]. *Spirit* [神] is what *the form carries* [形所载]. *Nourishing the form to vitalize the qi, containing the qi to harbor the spirit*—this is the *Way of non-perishing* [以形养气，以气含神，不死之道也]. *Spirit inherently does not perish* [神本无死], yet when *assigned to form, it has death* [赋于形而有死], though even in death it *has not truly died* [虽死而未尝死也]. The *Spirit of Grain* [谷神] *does not perish because of the Mysterious Feminine* [因玄牝不死], and *Heaven and Earth take the Mysterious Feminine as their root* [天地以玄牝为根].

*The Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] is *internal* [内焉], yet *harbors essence externally* [而藏精外焉], *adjusting breath*—*one opening, one closing* [而调息一开一阖], *one exhalation, one inhalation* [一呼一吸]. Exhaling reaches *the deep root* [呼则至於深根], inhaling reaches *the firm base* [吸则至於固蒂]. Thus *the spirit enters* [于是有神入焉], *revolving through the Dipper* [离斗辗历天廷], *riding the sun and moon, parting clouds and mists* [骑日月披云雾], *soaring and returning to the Hall of Great Possession* [腾腾乎会归于大有之室], much like the *divine beings dwelling on Mount Gūshè* [亦犹姑射山有神人居焉].

*Continuous, as if existing* [绵绵若存], *used without exertion* [用之不勤]. *Continuous* [绵绵] means *adjusting breath as if present, as if absent* [调息似有若无], *its use requires no labor* [用之要不至勤劳尔].

*Xiū Xiū’ān* [休休庵] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—*used without exertion* [至用之不勤]. *Void and luminous* [虚明] is called *Grain* [谓之谷], *subtle and wondrous* [灵妙] is called *Spirit* [谓之神]. *Void, luminous, subtle, and wondrous without end* [虚明灵妙无穷] is called *not perishing* [谓之不死], which is the *Mysterious Feminine* [即玄牝也]. *Mysterious* [玄] is the *Great Dao* [大道也]. *Feminine* [牝] is the *Mother* [母也]. *One vital breath* [一气] *generates within the void and luminosity* [生於虚明之中], then *clears and turbid divide to establish Heaven and Earth* [然后分清浊立天地], hence it is said: *The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is the root of Heaven and Earth* [故云玄牝之门，是谓天地根].

*The wondrous Dao acts without action* [妙道无为], *one vital breath runs unceasingly* [一气运行不绝], hence it is called *continuous, as if existing* [是谓绵绵若存]. *Responding to the times, adapting to circumstances* [应时应机], *benefiting life and aiding all things* [利生济物], *accomplished without labor* [不劳而办], hence it is said: *not exerting* [故云不劝].

*Void, luminous, subtle, and wondrous* [虚明灵妙] in humans is called *heart* [在人曰心]. The *heart is sovereign over all phenomena* [心为万法王], capable of *generating Heaven and Earth, running the sun and moon* [能生育天地，运行日月], *wondrous mechanisms and marvelous functions* [玄机妙用], *effortlessly boundless* [任运无穷], *responding to circumstances and sensations* [随缘应感], *accomplished without labor* [不劳而办]. Those who *awaken and clarify* [悟明者] *understand without being told* [不言而知已].

*Zhù Bóxìu* [褚伯秀] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—*used without exertion* [谷神不死至用之不勤]. *Grain is void yet responsive* [谷虚而善应], *Spirit is luminous yet boundless* [神灵而无方]. If a person *harbors the most luminous essence within the most void place* [人能以至灵之物藏至虚之所], then *they respond to sensations without trace* [则随感而应]. *Response leaves no mark* [应已无迹], *life does not even know its own generation* [生尚不知], *how could death exist* [死乎何有]?

*Mysterious* [玄] refers to *the Dao’s profound, unfathomable nature* [道妙难测], *Feminine* [牝] is *the realm of transformation and nurturing* [化育之地]. Its *function* [其为用也] *is wondrous in generating all things yet eternally generates* [妙万物而能生生], hence it is called *not perishing* [是之谓不死].

This elucidates *the Way of void-hearted spirit-nourishment* [此发明虚心养神之道], borrowing *Heaven and Earth’s creative transformation* [借天地造化为言], beginning with *void-heartedness and yielding to transformation* [始於虚心而任化], ending with *effortless self-transformation* [终於无心而化自己出]. All things’ generation *originates from this* [凡物之生，本莫不由斯], hence it is called *Gate* [故称门焉].

*Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子] says: *The Heavenly Gate* [天门者]—*there is no such thing* [无有也]—*all things emerge from non-being* [二万物出於无有]. In terms of the *Yì* [《易》], this is the *Tàijí* [太极]; in terms of humans, this is *nature* [以人言即性].

The beginning is the *one source* [一化] *awaiting transformation*, the *gathering place of myriad principles and myriad things* [万理众甫之都会].

If each person possesses it fully yet ignores its pursuit, then *the Valley* [谷] *is not truly the Valley*, *the Spirit* [神] *does not manifest itself as Spirit*—how can one relate to Heaven and Earth, to all things?

The *form* [形] *nourishes life*, *the contained qi* [含气] *nourishes life*, and *the primordial spirit* [元神] *nourishes life*.
When these three are regulated and abide, the *Dao flourishes* [生道昌].
Within the body, the *Void-hearted Mother* [身中玄牝] is seen.

Continuously guarding it without loss,
like preserving something in the realm of *faint and elusive* [恍惚],
then what movement could there be?

This chapter’s words are *concise yet profound* [语简意深],
akin to *Mencius* [孟子] discussing the *浩然* [浩然] *qi of righteousness*—
it manifests only after cultivation within the person,
permeating the body as the *Dao itself*.
Those who awaken grasp it naturally;
it cannot be fully exhausted by mere words.

Earlier masters, discussing *Dao* from beyond the orthodox [方外],
often elaborated its *refined essence* [精] yet neglected its *coarse manifestations* [粗],
achieving *transcendence* [上达] but lacking *foundational study* [下学].

*Huǐnyuán* [混元] placed this chapter after *Beauty and Evil, Virtue and Wealth, and the Keys to the Mysteries* [美恶贤货橐钥],
unifying them without separation,
but its language is *profoundly abstruse* [玄奥],
so scholars fear its *height and distance* [高远] and dare not approach it directly.

Now, without heeding my own *shallow inadequacy* [浅陋],
I presume to sketch beyond the shadow—
*the Valley-Spirit* [谷神] *is akin to the Non-ultimate* [无极],
the *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] *is akin to the Tàijí* [太极].
The *continuous method* [绵绵] *mirrors the Tàijí’s* [太极] *pervasive diffusion* [氤氲布化],
giving rise to an unceasing *Dao* [生道不息].

*The Valley* [谷] refers to its *substance* [体],
the *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] to its *transformation* [化],
and *continuous* [绵绵] to its *application* [用].
If one can *inwardly seek it within oneself* [反求诸身],
then self-transformation is achieved.

The *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之根] is *implied without words* [不言而喻].
In the present age, those who practice *life-nourishment* [养生家],
their teachings also center on *Valley-Spirit and Void-hearted Mother* [谷神玄牝],
yet they fixate on *physical form and material essence* [形质],
extracting it from the *kidneys and heart* [心肾], or from *breathing through mouth and nose* [口鼻呼吸].
These are but *later Heaven’s crude residues* [土苴] after all.

As for the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之根] and the *origin of myriad things* [万物宗],
they are abandoned and not explored—
how can they illuminate the *wondrous essence of Valley-Spirit* [谷神之妙]?

According to *The Liezi* [《列子》], it cites *The Yellow Emperor’s Book* [《黄帝书》],
which preserves this chapter entirely.
Evidently, these words existed in antiquity,
and *Huǐnyuán* [混元] merely *recounted them without original composition* [述而不作].

*Niú Miào* [牛妙]’s transmission states:
*The Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死], hence it is called *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝].
*The Valley* [谷] is *nourishment* [养].
*Spirit* [神] is one of the *three highest elixirs* [上药三品] in the *Daoist canon*.
*The Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] refers to the *two nostrils* [鼻之左右孔].

Thus, *great cultivators* [大修行人] practice the *method of fetal breathing* [胎息法],
from *external Void-hearted Mother* [外玄牝] to *internal Void-hearted Mother* [内玄牝],
guiding and drawing the *true qi of Supreme Harmony* [太和真气],
focusing intent on the *elixir field* [丹田].
With prolonged practice,
their bodies endure eternally—
hence it is said, *the Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死].

*The Jade Purity Fetal Essence Inner Nourishment Classic* [《玉清胎元内养经》] states:
*The wondrous Dao of the Fetal Essence* [胎元妙道],
uniting *external Void-hearted Mother* [外玄牝] with *internal Void-hearted Mother* [内玄牝],
supplementing *external true spirit* [外真神] with *internal true qi* [内真气],
gathering *Heaven’s myriad treasures* [天之万宝] and *my own fetal essence* [我胎之元精],
so that *spirit is born from the fetus* [神生於胎],
*qi clings to the spirit* [气恋於神],
the *heart-sovereign* [心君] *governs in concealment* [潜御],
*breathing is smooth and even* [气息调匀],
*continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing* [绵绵若存而不息],
*endless in its application yet manifesting its efficacy* [用之不穷而见功].
*The Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死] is the *union with my true origin* [合我真宗].
This is the meaning.

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Now, the discourse on the Mysterious Female has **inner and outer** aspects. The **outer** has already been explained above; the **inner** is a **mouth-to-mouth transmitted** secret, not recorded in texts. Thus, Zhang Pingzhong’s *Awakening to the True* [《悟真篇》] states:

*The Mysterious Female*—
not the heart, not the kidneys,
not the liver, not the lungs,
not the spleen, not the Triple Burner,
not the bladder, not the elixir field [丹田].

Then what is it?
It is further said:
*The True Mysterious Female, the Mysterious True Female*—
all converge at a single orifice.

Yet this profound principle,
without an enlightened teacher, is difficult to know.

I once read the *Daoist Canon on Cultivation* [《道藏修行论》], which states:
*The Mysterious Female resides between the two kidneys,*
called the **Divine Chamber**—
the **Palace where the Spirit-Sovereigns assemble**,
the **Region where essence and qi intermingle**,
the **Gate of Life**—
thus called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

For the human body is a **miniature Heaven and Earth**.

Continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing—
this speaks of the **Fetal Breath cultivation method**:
neither strained nor slack,
as if present yet as if absent,
letting the nasal breath flow gently in and out,
without forcing it.
Thus it is said: *its use requires no effort* [用之不勤].

The *Jade Emperor’s Heart-Seal Scripture* [《玉帝心印经》] states:
*The three supreme elixirs*—
**Spirit, Qi, and Essence**.
Vague and indistinct,
dim and obscure,
preserved yet not held,
instantly perfected.

The **cyclic winds merge**—
in a hundred days, the **Spirit becomes luminous**.
Entering and exiting the **Mysterious Female**,
as if absent yet as if present,
endlessly unbroken,
firmly rooted—
each person has their **essence**,
and when essence is perfected, **spirit is born**.

When spirit unites with **qi**, and **qi unites with the body’s true nature**,
spirit depends on qi to manifest,
essence depends on qi to flourish.
When gathered, it exists;
when scattered, it dissipates.

The three elixirs share one principle—
wondrous beyond words.
Obtain it once, and it is eternal—
naturally, the body becomes light.
The **Great Harmony** overflows,
bones transmute into **frosted jade**.

This is the meaning.

Yang Zhiren says:
*From "Valley-Spirit does not perish" to "its use requires no effort."*
The **Valley-Spirit**—
this is the **Heavenly Primordial Spirit** [天谷元神].
At the **Hun-Dong’s** [鸿蒙] initial division,
this spirit existed first.
It shares substance with the **Great Void**,
and is born with Heaven and Earth.
When the spirit arrives, life begins;
when the spirit departs, death comes.
Yet life is never truly born,
and death is never truly death.

It is the **Sovereign of Yin and Yang**,
the **Exalted Lord of all Spirits**.
Profound and vast—
without it, the sun and moon cannot shine,
without it, the Five Phases cannot flourish,
without it, all things cannot grow.
Its immortality lies in the **Mysterious Female**.

*Mysterious* is **True Yang**,
*Female* is **True Yin**.
Above, it connects to Heaven;
below, it coils within Earth,
circulating through the **Six Voids**,
without fixed abode above or below.

In the elixir, it is **True Lead and Mercury** [真铅汞];
in the *I Ching*, it is **Kan and Li** [坎离];
in the symbols, it is **Dragon and Tiger**.
When a person cultivates it,
Kan and Li wax and wane within the body,
winds and clouds surge through the **Seven Orifices**,
true *qi* steams and warms without cold or heat,
pure Yang flows and nourishes without birth or death—
this is the **function of the Mysterious Female**.

Moreover, the **Gate**—
this is the **portal of the sun and moon**.
Not the heart or kidneys,
not the mouth or nose,
not the **Cinnabar Field** [泥丸],
not the **elixir field below the navel**,
not the **one-inch circular orifice within the navel**,
not the **double gate between the shoulder blades**,
not the **orifice above the heart**,
nor is it a matter of **closing the breath and forcing it**—
to fixate on these is utterly mistaken.
Why not return to the **Root of Heaven and Earth**?

The *I Ching* says:
*The still and unmoving is sincerity* [诚],
*responding and thus communicating is spirit*—
this is the **Gate of the Mysterious Female**.
*The movement before form takes shape is the subtle*—
this is the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Sincerity is refined, thus clear;
spirit responds, thus wondrous;
the subtle is profound, thus mysterious.
Sincerity and subtlety—this is **sagacity**.

Continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing—
its use requires no effort.

Jù Qīngzhōng says:
*From "Valley-Spirit does not perish" to "its use requires no effort."*

The *Book of Laozi* treats **governance and benevolence**,
**cultivating the heart and nurturing nature**,
**breath-work and spirit-refining**—
both coarse and subtle, beginning and end,
all encompassed.
This chapter primarily concerns **cultivation and nourishment**,
and should be harmonized with **Confucian and Daoist texts** for mutual elucidation.

From the **Confucian perspective**:
*Valley* means **emptiness**;
*Spirit* means **the spirit within emptiness**.

From the **Daoist perspective**:
*Valley* is the **Heavenly Valley**;
*Spirit* is the **Primordial Spirit of the body**.
The **Palace where the Primordial Spirit resides**—
its emptiness is like a valley, yet the spirit dwells within—
thus it is called **Valley-Spirit**, the **Cinnabar Field Palace** [泥丸宫].
When the spirit is preserved, life continues;
when the spirit departs, death comes.
The reason the **Valley-Spirit does not perish**
lies in the **Mysterious Female**.

The **Yang Spirit** is *Mysterious*,
the **Yin Breath** is *Female*—
when spirit and breath intermingle,
true essence naturally forms.
Uniting with the **Way**, it enters **neither death nor birth**—
thus: *Valley-Spirit does not perish*—
this is the **Mysterious Female**.

The *Yellow Emperor’s Secret of Yin* [《黄帝阴符经》] states:
*The mouth connects to the five viscera*—
the exhaled breath is **heavy and turbid**, belonging to **Yin**—
called the **Earthly Root**.
*The nose connects to the six bowels*—
the exhaled breath is **light and pure**, belonging to **Yang**—
called the **Heavenly Root**.
The mouth and nose—
the **Yang Spirit and Yin Breath**—
are the **passageways of their coming and going**,
thus called the **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

The Sage **directs this breath** during **ascent and descent**,
**preserves and refines it** within **inhalation and exhalation**,
continuously, without interruption.
Preserve it by following its natural course—
over time, the spirit naturally settles,
the breath naturally steadies.
It is never forced or hastened.
Thus it is said: *its use requires no effort*.

The **Confucian and Daoist texts** converge in principle.
Liezi fully cites this chapter, attributing it to the Yellow Emperor,
suggesting Laozi’s words may have had an origin.

Some say the human body contains **one orifice**—
not the mouth or nose,
not the heart or kidneys,
not the **Valley Passage** [谷道]—
yet its essence is difficult to articulate.
Let those who discuss the **Mysterious** deliberate further.

Xū Liùxū says:
*Valley-Spirit does not perish*—
this is the **Mysterious Female**.

The **Valley** takes its emptiness—
the **Spirit’s** words are unfathomable.
*"Not dying"* means it abides eternally.

Speaking of the emptiness within the **Valley**,
within it resides the **Spirit**—
unfathomable in yin and yang,
eternal from ancient times to now.
Thus it is said: *"The Valley-Spirit does not die."*

Because it does not die,
it is called the **Mysterious Female**.
*"Mysterious"* means distant.
*"Female"* means birth.
It speaks of the countless eons since antiquity,
profound and unfathomable,
its principle of generation endless—
thus it is called the **Mysterious Female**.

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.
*"Gate"* means passage and foundation.
The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
from it Heaven and Earth emerge,
from it all things are born—
the very foundation of Heaven and Earth.

Continuous as if preserved,
its use requires no effort.
*"Continuous"* means subtle yet unbroken—
the very body of the **Mysterious Female**.
*"No effort"* is its function—
the **Gate of the Mysterious Female**,
from antiquity to now,
subtle yet unbroken,
though unseen in sight,
its wondrous generative power
manifests as if present—
how could it ever be said to labor?

This chapter, from beginning to end,
speaks only of the **Valley-Spirit**—
the Sage unfolds it thus, how marvelous!
Ah! This **Valley-Spirit**,
from birth to old age,
never for a moment departs from man—
its form, function,
differ not in the slightest.

Those who believe need no further force;
those who grasp it will depart.
If one speculates while alive,
the falcon has already passed beyond Silla.

Li Shifu says:
From *"The Valley-Spirit does not die"* to *"its use requires no effort"*—
*"The Valley-Spirit does not die"* is called the **Mysterious Female**,
for the **Valley** is emptiness—
the great **Valley** of Heaven and Earth,
the small **Valleys** of mountains and marshes.
The **Spirit** is the numinous essence—
the **Spirit** abides in emptiness,
borrowing *qi* to resonate.
Mountains and marshes, though lifeless,
when called, respond with echoes.
My **Spirit** is formless,
relying on *qi* to sound—
undying, eternally preserved.

*"Mysterious"* is the subtle heart.
*"Female"* is the intent of *qi*.
Before the heart’s use manifests,
men do not perceive it—*"Mysterious."*
Before *qi* transforms,
the deed remains unseen—*"Female."*

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**—
the passage of giving and receiving,
of release and return.
From this single *qi*, the Dao is born;
from this single heart, Heaven, Earth, and all things emerge—
the foundation of all affairs’ mechanisms.

Continuous as if preserved,
its use requires no effort—
unbroken and eternal,
unwaning.
Apply it gently, never forcing,
lest the **Spirit** and *qi* be injured.

Chai Yuangao says:
*"The Valley-Spirit does not die"*—
this is called the **Mysterious Female**.
The **Valley** is emptiness,
*"not dying"* is perpetual wakefulness.
When the myriad thoughts stir,
the root is revealed—
when emptiness prevails, it revives.

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.
The opening and closing of *Kàn* and *Hūn*.
Continuous as if preserved,
its use requires no effort.
The **True Person’s** breath—
resting on the heels, effortless.
The common man’s breath—
through the throat, labored.
There must be action, yet
the mind must not be fixed,
forget not,
nor force growth—
this is the effortless use.

Is it not the Gate of *Kàn* and *Hūn*?

Su Jingjing says:
From *"The Valley-Spirit does not die"* to *"its use requires no effort"*—
this chapter speaks of nurturing *qi*.
The Master of the Yellow River and Zhang Chong
both took the **Mysterious Female** as the nose and mouth—
the passage for inhaling and exhaling.
*"Root"* means origin.
The nose and mouth are the passageways
through which Heaven and Earth’s primal *qi* circulates.
Continuous and unbroken,
its subtlety is as if nonexistent yet present—
when *qi* is nourished,
its use requires no extra force,
naturally extending life and vision.

Even the Tang Emperor Minghuang,
when the **Valley** responded to sound,
knew not how—
when stimulated, it responded,
as if divine.
In Laozi’s text, the **Valley** is used as metaphor repeatedly:
*"Vast, like the **Valley**,"*
*"The **Valley** that holds One is full,"*
*"Be the **Valley** of the world,"*
*"The rivers and seas can be kings of the **Valleys**,"*
all because of their ability to descend.
Yet here it uniquely says:
*"The Valley-Spirit does not die,"*
*"Continuous as if preserved."*
If one seeks it from its undying, as-if-preserved nature,
descending alone cannot exhaust it.
Only as the Emperor’s responsive echo
can the meaning of *"not dying yet as-if-preserved"* be fully grasped.

Echo and shadow are one—
shadows trace form,
from the sun, moon, water, fire.
But sound’s resonance:
when uttered in the wild, it scatters;
when striking mountains, it is stifled.
Only when sound emerges from an empty **Valley**
does it resonate as if from nothing—
divinely so.
Then one knows that *"not dying yet as-if-preserved"*
is truly without deceit.

The Yellow Emperor said:
When form moves, it does not generate form—
it generates shadow.
When sound moves, it does not generate sound—
it generates resonance.
When the void moves, it does not generate the void—
it generates the existent.

Thus the **Valley’s** ability to manifest as **Spirit** is indeed verifiable.
When it is empty, it is void;
when sound strikes it, it responds—
sensing, it manifests.
This sensing-response is its undying, as-if-preserved **Spirit**.

*"Mysterious"* is subtlety.
*"Female"* is responding without initiating.
The **Valley’s** storing of resonance awaiting sound—
this is *"not initiating."*
If sound does not strike,
the resonance’s response never emerges;
when sound strikes, the resonance responds.
So subtle is its **Spirit**—
thus it is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Heaven and Earth are born from the **Supreme Polarity**,
the **Supreme Polarity** originates from the void,
the void can generate the existent,
the existent is born from the void.
Resonance responds to sound—
the void generating the existent—
if not called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**, why?

The previous chapter speaks of the *Nameless*,
the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
This speaks of the **Root of Heaven and Earth**—
root and beginning are one.

*"Continuous"*—
when the prior resonance fades,
the next sound strikes,
its response remains unchanged.
Thus it is said to *"as-if-preserve"*—
the **Valley-Spirit** does not perish.
If used, the more it is applied,
it seems labored yet truly requires no effort—
move with its emptiness,
with its void.
The void generates the real,
the nonexistent generates the existent—
what else could it be but **Spirit**?

The cultivation of *qi* is but another extension by humans of their own reasoning.

Wu Huanzhong said: *"The Valley-Spirit does not die—its use requires no effort."*

Wu Huanzhong’s disciple, Wu Zhen, remarked: *"The *Laozi* contains hidden Daoist intent—when the spirit is ever-nourished, the *po* does not dissipate, and water and fire harmonize. His words are most unusual."*

I once heard my teacher say: *"The Valley-Spirit is the primordial *qi* of Heaven-before-Heaven. Spirit-*qi* returns to the Mysterious Feminine, and wherever the mind moves, it borrows spirit to act—not through mouth or nose. Mysterious, it is Yang; Feminine, it is Yin—true Yin, true Yang."*

As *Zhuangzi* says: *"All things are born, yet none know their root; they emerge, yet none know their gate. But the source from which Heaven and Earth arise is the Mysterious Feminine."*

The essence of the Great Elixir lies not beyond the spirit, soul, *po*, and intent. Spirit is fire; essence is water—true unity’s essence. The soul is wood; the *po* is metal; intent is earth. The Five Phases cannot be pure without earth, and intent nourishes *qi*. Nourishing *qi* condenses essence; condensing essence awakens spirit. When the Four Symbols harmonize into one, refined practice makes *qi* soft and enduring—unbroken, like thread. Its use requires no effort; day and night, it flows naturally.

Ancient immortals, whether hidden or revealed, spoke of *yin-yang* as substance, likened it to lead and mercury, compared it to sun and moon, modeled it on male and female, likened it to dragon and tiger—*Zhen* and *Dui*, *Kan* and *Li*, gold and cinnabar, *Jia* and *Geng*, *Bing* and *Ren*, *Wu* and *Ji*, water and fire, sovereign and minister, child and mother, infant and maiden, knife and scale, metal and wood, warmth and cold, host and guest, floating and sinking, bathing and rinsing, birth and death, punishment and virtue, battle and retreat, waxing and waning, addition and subtraction, *wen* and *wu*, hot and cold—all these are matters of the Mysterious Feminine. Thus, they established symbols in metaphor, urging one to self-realization: seek it within, not without. Have you not heard the saying: *"The Master of Emptiness and Stillness governs spirit, spirit retains *qi*—no need for external arts to attain longevity?"*

Today’s seekers of the Dao may recognize medicinal herbs but lack the means to apply them. Even if they know where to begin, they fail to grasp the method, wandering lost in the Mysterious Feminine’s domain. Spirit is the root of life; form is the vessel of spirit. When spirit is whole, *qi* is whole; when *qi* is whole, essence is whole; when essence is whole, form is whole; when form is whole, spirit thrives; when spirit thrives, *qi* is refined; when *qi* is refined, spirit transcends. At first, it aligns with the Dao as one. But when spirit is diminished, essence cannot recover; when essence is depleted, the *po* is restless.

You study texts—do you not understand the interplay of things? Yet in waking and sleeping, in seeing, hearing, speaking, and moving, your mind wanders beyond the reach of ears, eyes, heart, and thought. This is what ancient immortals, having cast aside desires and transcended the mundane, achieved only through unyielding resolve. If spirit cannot govern *qi*, and *qi* cannot solidify form, how can one dwell in peace, much less preserve their dwelling? To seek enduring attainment is difficult indeed.

You heard my words, and with a smile of sudden understanding, said nothing.

The teacher then poured wine and sang a chapter from *The Songs of Chu*:

*"The Dao can be received but not transmitted,
Its smallness has no bounds within,
Its greatness knows no limits without.
Without deceit, the spirit is pure—
Then it follows its natural course.
How could it be that *qi* is so refined,
That at midnight, in emptiness, it waits—
Before action, in non-doing’s embrace?"*

With a bow, he departed. On a leisurely day, I composed three stanzas to caution myself:

*"Not all demons are heavy burdens,
Coming forward to speak of foolish dreams.
Xie the Immortal lights the fire with shared intent,
Yangzi’s riverbank watches one *liang* of gold.
When alone, the work is just right—
Concealed, concealed, concealed, yet not difficult.
There are hundreds of green-copper vessels,
Often poured with kind words to quench my thirst.
Rain or no rain, wind or no wind,
Without doubt, without worry, laughter rings warm.
Clustered joy on cinnabar’s earth,
Sealed alone, opened alone."*

And another poem:

*"Do not delay in beginning—
What doubt remains of the Golden Elixir?
A single ball of harmonized *qi*—
Mind the fire’s precision.
When the Four Symbols unite,
Divine insight naturally appears.
To grasp its true mystery,
Observe the lone moon over the pool."*

*—Moon House carving on Stone Pool’s annotation of the* Dao De Jing*, appended by Zhen to this chapter on the Valley-Spirit. Master Wu Zhen’s poem reads:*

*"Do not blame Heaven’s secrets for leaking—
It is because seekers are too bewildered.
Hahaha."*

Master Benyuan said: *"The Valley-Spirit does not die—its use requires no effort. The Valley is empty yet formed; the spirit within it is formless yet present. Mysterious, it is deep yet intangible; as the Feminine, it is void yet substantial. Formless yet present—thus it does not die; void yet substantial—thus it can generate. This too is the body of the Dao.*

*Its emergence is called the Gate; its sustaining root is called the Root. The first chapter speaks of Heaven, Earth, and all things. But here, it does not mention all things—for where there are Heaven and Earth, there are all things. The Root is that which endlessly generates, and thus all things are within it. If one embodies the Dao in the body, unbroken as thread, then the Valley-Spirit and the Mysterious Feminine will reside within you, and the Dao’s use will know no end.*

*Unbroken—neither void nor not-void.
As-if-preserved—neither present nor not-present.
Without effort—without toil.
If one says it is taken from left or right,
It is but returning to its origin.
The *Laozi*’s intent is, broadly, to trace the Dao’s mystery back to Heaven—Heaven and Earth’s beginning—and then reflect it within the self, embodying and preserving it. Mencius’ *xiao-hua cun-shen* is akin to the Valley-Spirit. The Buddhist *zhēnkōng miǎoyǒu* aligns with the Mysterious Feminine."*
