「Comparative Analysis: Master He Shang composed *The Chapter of the Wandering Yi* (《运夷章》), while Zhao Shixian wrote *The Chapter of Observing Retreat as Advancement* (《观退为进义章》).

Emperor Xuanzong of Tang explained: The previous chapter elucidates the virtuous conduct of the sage—gentle and yielding, hence free from blame. This chapter clarifies how the common folk, drowned in desires and arrogant with excess, inevitably incur fault.

It begins with the admonition **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已。 揣而锐之, 不可长保), showing how such states are hard to preserve. Next, it warns of gold and jade, wealth and honor, cautioning against greed. It concludes with **"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw"** (功成名遂身退), urging one to forget merit and avoid harm.

Master Du Guangting remarked: The previous chapter used water as an analogy to illustrate the Way of cultivation. Here, with **"Hold and it will overflow"**** as its opening, it further reveals the folly of greed and stagnation, urging one to forget merit and retreat, thus aligning with the sage’s perfection.

Zhang Chongying stated: *Yi* refers to the boundless void of the cosmos—clear and luminous yet without form or color—unfathomable by humans. Though human affairs may flow like that void, if one prevents others from perceiving them, it is akin to concealing one’s spirit and avoiding self-harm.

**"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已。 揣而锐之, 不可长保).
**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).

Comparative Analysis: Yan Zun, Yang Fu, and Wang Bi all concurred with the ancient text.

Master He Shang said: **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已).
*Sweng*, meaning "full," *ji*, meaning "stop."
To hold what is full is to risk collapse—better to stop.

**"Grasp and it will blunt"** (揣而锐之, 不可长保).
*Chuai*, meaning "to refine."
After refinement, it must be discarded—its sharpness cannot endure.

**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
Lustful desires harm the spirit, riches burden the body.

**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
If one is wealthy, they should relieve the poor; if noble, they should pity the lowly. Yet if they instead grow arrogant, calamity will surely befall them.

**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).
It means that when a person’s deeds are accomplished and their reputation secured, if they do not retreat and relinquish their prominence, they will meet misfortune. This is Heaven’s constant Way.

As the sun reaches its zenith and begins to decline, the moon wanes after fullness, things flourish only to decay, and joy reaches its peak before sorrow follows.

Wang Fu’s commentary: **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已).
*Chi* means "to hold without losing virtue," but if one holds virtue while also filling oneself with excess, collapse is inevitable. Thus, it is better to stop—meaning to be even worse than having no virtue or merit at all.

**"Grasp and it will blunt"** (揣而锐之, 不可长保).
If one refines and sharpens it further after already making it sharp, its force will only be exhausted and ruined—thus it cannot be long preserved.

**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
It is better to stop.

**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
It cannot be long preserved.

**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).
The seasons cycle in turn, and when merit is fulfilled, one must withdraw.

Emperor Xuanzong remarked: **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已).
To grasp and fill with excess, lest it topple—if one accumulates, it becomes a burden, and regret will arise. Hence, it is better to stop.
*Ji*, meaning "to stop."

Explanation: *Chi* means "to grasp," *sweng* means "full," *ji* means "to stop."
It speaks of how human hearts, greedy and insatiable, grasp and hoard, filling themselves with wealth. Accumulation brings burdens, and regret will inevitably follow. Thus, the sage warns: It is better to cease.

**"Grasp and it will blunt"** (揣而锐之, 不可长保).
*Chuai* means "to measure or refine," *rui* means "sharp and keen."
To refine and sharpen desires for fame and honor, to cling to power and rely on wealth—if one accumulates to fullness, arrogance will arise, and ruin will follow. Thus, it cannot be long preserved.

Explanation: *Chuai* means "to measure or assess," *rui* means "sharp and keen."
All who are mired in desires, greedy for fame and gain, assess past deeds and sharpen their ambition, provoking resentment and inviting ruin. Hence, it cannot be long preserved.

**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
This illustrates how excess is difficult to sustain.

Explanation: Suppose one’s greed knows no bounds, filling their halls with gold and jade. Even elephants are tamed by fire, and roosters mutilated for ritual propriety. Yet, by losing the treasure of non-greed, one invites the anxiety of bandits. With such harm, how can they be guarded? This reverses the meaning of **"Hold and it will overflow."**

**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
This reveals how sharpness cannot be grasped—arrogance stems from the heart, so blame is not from another.

Explanation: Wealth attracts envy, so one easily oppresses others. Honor demands deference, so one readily domineers over others. Arrogance and excess arise without warning; calamity follows without cause. Regret comes from arrogance itself, born of the heart. Hence, it is said: one invites blame upon themselves. This reverses the meaning of **"Grasp and it will blunt."**

**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).
Those whose achievements are complete and reputation secured should retreat and avoid excess—just as Heaven’s Way follows the cycles of fullness and emptiness. Thus, there will be no misfortune.

Explanation: This is an admonition. Fullness invites loss, while humility brings benefit. Even Heaven does not remain perpetually full, so those who achieve will be humbled, and those who gain fame will suffer decline. To seek long preservation is unheard of. One must instead forget merit and fame, retreat, and relinquish excess—like Heaven’s Way. Only by not defying the cycles of fullness and emptiness can one avoid calamity and censure.

Master Du Guangting said: The analogy of **"Hold and it will overflow"**** encompasses four meanings.
One: Clinging to desires until they reach fullness.
Two: Hoarding worldly wealth until it overflows.
Three: Persisting in evil deeds until they swell.
Four: Grasping authority and relying on office until they become excessive.

In general, those who know only advancement and forget retreat, who do not reflect on the Dao of virtue, who cling stubbornly without turning back—all such as reach fullness will meet retribution. Those whose desires overflow will suffer from feebleness and illness, harming their lives. Those whose worldly wealth overflows will face plunder and loss.

The evil deeds that reach fullness will meet retribution through punishment, calamity, and harm.
Those whose power and emoluments overflow will face ruin and annihilation.
Thus, the Venerable Lord Lao admonishes: *"It is better to cease than to persist in holding fullness.*
If one neither ceases nor stops, retribution will surely manifest.
To sharpen and press forward is not something that can be long preserved.

When a ruler sharpens his ambition to expand territory and seize land, the people will resent it and the state will perish.
When a minister sharpens his greed for profit and fame, his own life will be endangered and disaster will follow.
Even if he temporarily gains what he desires, how can it last?
Moreover, advancement brings no benefit, while retreat brings only worry and misfortune.
Hence, it is said: *"It cannot be long preserved.*

Gold and jade filling the halls cannot be guarded forever.
Even if one could measure and discern, and sharply curb avarice, filling the halls with treasures and ornaments—
there will still be plunder and attack, how could one preserve and guard them?
Much less can one, with a limited lifespan and insatiable desires, hope to preserve gold and jade when death cannot be averted.

There is the parable of the elephant burning itself with its own tusks:
In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Shànggōng Year 24, when the Jin minister Fán Xuānzǐ governed, the burdens on the allied states grew heavy, and the people of Zheng lamented.
In the second month, the Duke of Zheng visited Jin.
Zǐchǎn entrusted a letter to Zǐxī to convey to Xuānzǐ:
*"You govern Jin, yet the neighboring states hear only of heavy burdens, not of virtuous governance. I am perplexed by this.
I have heard that those who govern states must fear not the lack of wealth, but the difficulty of earning a virtuous name.
When wealth accumulates in the lord’s halls, the states grow disloyal.
If you rely on it, Jin will become disloyal.
When the states are disloyal, Jin will collapse; when Jin collapses, your house will fall.
Why would you court such ruin?
Wealth is but a vehicle for virtue, and virtue is the foundation of a state.
With a foundation, there is no collapse—why not strive for this?
Virtue brings joy, and joy ensures longevity. The *Odes* say:
‘Joy belongs to the virtuous; it is the foundation of the state.’
Thus, it is the virtuous name that matters.
Reflect deeply to cultivate virtue, let your virtuous name spread far and near, and all will be at peace.
Would you rather have people say, ‘You gave life to us,’ or ‘You drained us to death?’
The elephant burns itself with its own tusks—wealth is like that.
Xuānzǐ was pleased and lightened the burdens.
This was the reason the Duke of Zheng visited Jin—because of the heavy burdens.

The rooster that cuts off its own tail:
In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ transmission of Zǐzhāo, son of King Jìng of Zhou, Mèng Shì went to the suburbs and saw a rooster cut off its own tail, sighing:
‘The use of sacrificial animals depends on their completeness and fatness.
Now it cuts off its own tail, making itself incomplete, hoping to avoid being used as a sacrifice.
Thus does the rooster preserve its life—how much more so for humans?
To covet gain and forget oneself is even worse than the rooster’s folly.

The treasure of non-covetousness:
A man of Zheng found a jade piece and offered it to Zǐhǎn, saying:
‘This is a treasure. I would present it to you.’
Zǐhǎn replied:
‘You consider jade a treasure, but I consider non-covetousness a treasure.
If I take the jade, we both lose our treasures.
It is better to preserve both.’
Thus, he did not accept the jade.

The thief who invites plunder:
The *Yì* explains the third line of the *Guà* hexagram:
‘*Bearing and mounting, bringing thieves upon oneself.*’
Bearing refers to the petty man’s burden—carrying burdens for others.
Mounting refers to the noble’s carriage.
Now the petty man abandons his burden and takes the noble’s carriage—
this is the petty man riding in the noble’s instrument.
Thus, thieves will think to seize it.
Arrogance in wealth and rank invites one’s own downfall.
Abundance is called wealth, so people seek it.
High position is called rank, so people submit to it.
If one is full without overflowing, this is how one long preserves wealth.
If one is high without peril, this is how one long preserves rank.
The saying goes: *"Wealth and rank do not last for the arrogant and extravagant—
arrogance and extravagance bring their own ruin.
If one does not guard against them, contempt and insults will follow,
and disaster will surely come.
‘Hereditary’ means ‘given by oneself.’
Blame does not come from outside—it arises from one’s own arrogance and negligence.
Hence, it is said: *"Arrogance comes from the heart.
If one can be high in rank without peril, wealthy without overflowing,
free from grievances, and disaster-free,
then governing the state and cultivating oneself is perfect.

Arrogance is pride.
When achievement is complete and fame is fulfilled, one should retreat—this is the Way of Heaven.
To avert disaster and eliminate misfortune is called *achievement*,
wealth, rank, honor, and glory are called *fame*.
If achievement is complete and fame is fulfilled, yet one does not know when to retreat,
few escape calamity.
Why is this?
Favor invites disgrace, fullness invites decline, and extremism invites regret.
When fine birds are exhausted, the good bow is hidden;
when the hare is killed, the hunting dogs are boiled—
this is the inevitable course of things.
Fàn Lì escaped disaster in a small boat, while Dàfū Zhōu lost his life clinging to his position—
this is the lesson.

The sun reaches its zenith and then declines,
the moon is full and then wanes,
heat gives way to cold,
spring’s flourishing turns to autumn’s fall—
this is the Way of Heaven.
If one aligns with the cycles of fullness and emptiness in Heaven’s Way,
forgets the pursuit of achievement and fame,
and like Zǐfáng abstains from food to wander freely,
or like Cú Guāng resigns his seal to live in refinement,
then there will be no regret like that of Cāi Huàtíng or Huàtíng’s pursuit.
How much more so for one who holds the *jiǔwǔ* position and governs the myriad people,
illuminating the four quarters and regulating the seas,
yet does not heed the warning against holding fullness to excess?

The Lord of Song’s Way says:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Fullness leads to overflow, sharpness leads to blunting.
The principle of all things is that fullness must have its deficiency.
If one does not know to hold emptiness in readiness for fullness,
or to grasp emptiness to govern fullness,
and instead indulges in the desires of overflow and sharpness,
one only increases the calamity of ruin.
The changes of things are boundless, but human wisdom is limited.
Preemptive knowledge is the flower of the Way, the beginning of folly.
If one measures things by their nature yet sharpens his pursuit of immediate gain,
his wisdom will falter at times—
how can such a state be long preserved?*

The Lord of Song’s Way says:
*"Gold and jade filling the halls—this is how one invites his own calamity.
Wealth and noble rank are not the Dao of life and nature.
External things cannot be relied upon as one’s own.
Treasure gold and jade, and you are burdened by things;
burdened by things, how can you avoid loss?
None can guard them.
Rich and noble yet proud, you harm your virtue.
He who harms his virtue—how can he escape misfortune?
Thus it is said: *‘He invites his own calamity.’*

The Sage does not cling to the gains of a single age as his private possession,
nor does he take ruling the world as his own display of honor.
What need has he for gold and jade as treasures,
or for wealth and rank as burdens?
Thus, when wealth is supreme, the state’s resources are exhausted alongside it;
when rank is supreme, the state’s honors are depleted alongside it.
His nobility is unmatched, his wealth unparalleled,
yet the Way remains unshaken.
When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
When achievement is complete, it collapses;
when name is fulfilled, it falters.
At high noon, the sun declines;
when the moon is full, it wanes—
this is the nature of things.
The Sage perceives the signs of rise and decay,
discerns the inevitable cycles of fullness and deficiency,
and stands apart, unburdened, free from the calamity of pride and excess.
Who but one who knows Heaven could attain this?
Thus it is said: *‘When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.’*

The revolutions of the four seasons—
when achievement is complete, it departs—
this is the Way of Heaven.
To know advancement but not retreat,
to know preservation but not ruin,
to know gain but not loss—
how can one avoid regret?

Yi Yin said:
*The minister does not dwell on success through favor and gain.*
Wang Anshi said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.*

He who clings to his vessel’s fullness
will easily overturn it.
He who sharpens his grasp
cannot long preserve it.
He who sharpens his grasp
cannot long preserve it.
Gold and jade filling the halls—
none can guard them.
The halls are empty receptacles for things.
When gold and jade fill them, they are full—
thus they cannot be guarded.
Rich and noble yet proud—
he invites his own calamity.
Great wealth and rank do not seek pride,
yet pride arrives naturally—
this is how calamity is invited.

When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
For the Sage, when achievement is complete and name is fulfilled,
he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.

The Way of Heaven:
The high are humbled, the low are raised.
It is also said: *‘Heaven diminishes fullness and benefits the modest.’*
The *Book of Documents* says: *‘The modest receive benefit; the proud invite loss.’*

Su Yingbin said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Knowing fullness must overflow yet clinging to it—
it is better not to fill at all.
Knowing sharpness must blunt yet sharpening it—
it is better not to sharpen at all.
As for the Sage, possessing yet not possessing,
how could there be fullness?
Following principle before acting,
how could there be sharpness?
Without fullness, there is no need to cling;
without excess, there is no need to guard.
Without excess, there is no need to sharpen.

Gold and jade filling the halls—
this is the Way of Heaven when he withdraws.
The sun at its zenith declines,
the moon at its full wanes.
The revolutions of the four seasons—
when achievement is complete, it departs.
Even Heaven and Earth follow this—
how much more so for humans?

Lu Jifu said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Clinging to prevent overflow yet filling—
this only invites greater overflow.
If one wishes to avoid overflow,
it is better not to fill at all.
Sharpening to prevent loss yet sharpening—
this cannot be long preserved.
Sharpening to anticipate loss—
this only invites greater loss.
If one wishes to avoid loss,
it is better not to sharpen at all.

Gold and jade filling the halls—
none can guard them.
To remain full without overflowing—
this is how wealth is long preserved.
Holding fullness to excess—
then gold and jade fill the halls,
and none can guard them.
Rich and noble yet proud—
he invites his own calamity.
To be high yet not perilous—
this is how nobility is long preserved.
Sharpening to excess—
then wealth and rank bring pride,
and he invites his own calamity.

When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
Then how does one avoid this calamity?
Only by conforming to the Way of Heaven.
For when achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven,
the means by which the private is accomplished without selfishness.
The *Book of Documents* says: *‘The Sage withdrew himself.’*
This is to follow the Way of Heaven.

Wang Yuanzai said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Clinging to fullness with intent—
this is how one loses it.
Only by forgetting the act of possessing as possession itself,
and holding through non-possession,
can one avoid loss and overflow.
Sharpening to excess cannot be long preserved.
The cunning measure emotions,
the sharp exploit things,
yet affairs are boundless,
and one holds a single life to meet their changes—
then the skill of clinging and sharpening will falter at times.
How can it be long preserved?
Thus the Sage follows the times, rides the principle,
and meets them with non-self—
his actions are boundless,
his responses inexhaustible.

Gold and jade filling the halls—
none can guard them.
Treasuring external things and guarding them—
what is guarded is not truly possessed.
How could it be guarded?
Rich and noble yet proud—
he invites his own calamity.
Pride arises from reliance on externals—
what use are those who rely on externals?
The four [wealth, rank, clinging, sharpening]—
all stem from having things—
what difference is there between them and pride?
Yet clinging to fullness only leads downward,
each loss growing worse.

When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
Cold and heat succeed one another,
things at their extreme reverse,
yin and yang alternate—
the Way of Heaven is thus.
Yet the foolish of the world,
once encountering change,
once transgressing its name,
cling to it for life,
taking it as their own,
unaware of the subtle shifts of creation,
the hidden patterns of fortune and misfortune—
thus they inevitably invite calamity,
unable to preserve themselves.

The Sage is not thus.
He hides gold and jade yet does not treasure them,
dwells in wealth and rank yet does not glory in them.
All things that come as guests
are like shadows gathering at his feet—
vague, unknown whether they belong to him or to another.
Then how could he cling to fullness as a burden,
or sharpen his grasp as a skill?"

「If not for the peerless marvel of selflessness,
how could he partake in this?

The Dao of Heaven is vast indeed,
yet nothing surpasses this principle.

Liu Jujie said:
*"To grasp and fill is not as good as to let go."*
He meant that one who clings to fullness,
seeking wealth and riches,
is a fool.

When full yet able to remain empty,
what need is there for such exertion?

To grasp what cannot be held—
to grasp is to invite ruin.
Thus it is said: *"Not as good as to let go."*
To let go is to cease.

To probe and sharpen is not long-lasting.
He meant that to measure and intrude,
seeking absolute certainty,
is a delusion.

When sharp yet able to remain blunt,
what need is there for such craft?

If the measure fails,
then the measure itself is flawed.
It cannot be long preserved,
not because it can be luckily preserved,
but because having obtained it,
one is bound to lose it.

Gold and jade fill the halls,
yet none can keep them.
This further illustrates the meaning of *"Not as good as to let go."*
The halls and chambers,
though vast enough to store gold and jade,
are doomed by their fullness—
unless it be Heaven’s retribution,
then there will surely be human calamity.

Wealth and honor yet pride,
one invites his own misfortune.
This further explains *"It cannot be long preserved."*
Wealth and honor breed arrogance,
arrogance breeds transgression,
and by taking pride against others,
one seals his own fate with reputation.

When the work is done and the name is earned,
he withdraws—
this is the Dao of Heaven.
To benefit others is the work,
to be praised and then renounce the self is the name.
Work is the substance of wealth and honor,
while fame and praise are its superficial adornments.

Work must be completed,
name must be fulfilled—
wealth and honor, fame and power,
are inevitable even for the Sage and the Worthies.
Yet they do not topple and fall.
If they are full,
it is not because they seized the moment,
if they benefit others,
it is not because they schemed to gain it—
yet they can empty themselves and guard against pride,
withdrawing in due time.

For those who stand on the foundation of completed work and earned name,
while common folk advance,
the Sage and Worthies retreat—
could one who does not embody the Dao of Heaven
achieve such mastery?

The sun and moon alternate in their brightness,
the four seasons follow in succession—
this is the Dao of Heaven.

The previous chapter spoke of the highest virtue,
like water, allowing one to dwell in wealth and honor.
Thus this passage follows.

Liu Ji said:
*"To grasp and fill, until withdrawing—
this is the Dao of Heaven.
The Great Dao is clear and bright,
yet the people love shortcuts.
Because of their thick attachment to life,
they are bewildered by the realm of action,
seeking swift success,
unaware of the wondrous workings of Nature.
They cling and grasp to achieve fullness,
yet fullness only leads to loss—
thus it is not as good as to let go.
To probe and sharpen to attain sharpness,
yet sharpness only leads to blunting—
thus gold and jade cannot be long preserved,
as they are burdens of things.
Things become burdens,
and those who desire them multiply—
thus none can keep them.
Wealth and honor yet pride,
harm one’s virtue.
Harming virtue,
those who attack multiply—
thus one invites his own misfortune.

The Sage dwells at the peak of wealth and honor,
yet without the burden of fullness,
for his work is done and his name is earned,
and he withdraws in time.
Would he cling to fullness
or probe for sharpness?

The sun and moon alternate in their brightness,
the four seasons follow in succession—
those who complete their work withdraw,
this is the Dao of Heaven.

The Sage follows the Dao of Heaven,
thus it is hard to advance yet easy to retreat,
abandoning the ways of others
and seeking within himself—
hence the next passage speaks of nurturing the spirit and body."*

Zhao Shixian said:
*"The first four lines speak of not dwelling:
First, not the Dao of utmost emptiness.
*'To grasp and fill is not as good as to let go.'*
One’s body is not hard to govern,
the Great Dao is not hard to exhaust.
What is not difficult lies in recognizing the heart.

The heart is originally nonexistent.
At first, it arises from love,
where the four great elements gather,
and the five aggregates converge.
Blood and qi rely upon each other,
a hundred limbs interdependently form—
all these arise from deluded thoughts.

Now that the heart is recognized,
the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera
exist within it—
to whom else shall I be close?
To grasp yet possess—
all are delusions.

By the heart clinging to delusion,
bewilderment arises.
By the heart recognizing emptiness,
delusion is self-destroyed.

The Sage knows this,
thus he says: *"I have a body,
yet the body is delusion.
If external things come,
I forget external things.
The body and external things—
both forgotten in truth,
within the forgetfulness,
Heaven’s light shines forth.
I do not know if things forget me,
or if I forget things—
in the empty chamber, whiteness is born,
the Dao comes naturally.
Where is the so-called ‘grasping fullness’?

To grasp fullness is to have things,
having things distances one from the Dao.
The text says: *‘To grasp and fill,’*
meaning the vessel is full.
To grasp is to use one’s hands—
taking what is nonexistent to fill emptiness,
reluctant to pour it out,
unwilling to forget it.
In his actions,
he cannot even lift his feet without stirring dust,
in his sitting,
he dares not turn his gaze.
He exhausts his spirit and torments his heart,
all for one vessel.
Before things are harmed,
his body is already frazzled and weary.
Deluded calculations and stubborn attachments—
such is his plight,
for he does not view it from the perspective of the body.
The body is originally no body—
where then do things reside?
I forget myself,
what concern are things to me?
The closest things are known,
the distant ones can be understood.

To let go is to attain liberation.
Second, self-inflicted injury from sharpness.
*'To probe and sharpen is not long-lasting.'*
By nature, one desires stillness,
yet without stillness, fortune and misfortune, regret and remorse arise.
By nature, one’s qi seeks balance,
yet without balance, resentment and anger, love and desire arise.

The heart that opposes things must seek victory,
yet without movement, it gains nothing.
Desiring gain,
the stillness stirs and becomes contention.
What is not beneficial does not enter,
desiring benefit,
the balanced becomes sharp and leads to injury.

To harm integrity yet gain—
how could one preserve it?

For one who knows stillness,
contention ceases,
and without contention,
harm with things does not arise.
Harmony and peace bring self-serenity,
self-serenity guards the spirit—
not burdening the form with gain,
not injuring the body with nourishment,
aligning with the great and turning away from the great orifices,
thus attaining the midst of indifference—
this is the ancient virtue of preserving life.
How could one covet small gains,
be like a greedy wolf,
seeing benefit yet forgetting the self,
seeking power yet exhausting it,
and invite the Dao of peril and annihilation?"」

「Those who do not understand this are like that of **Zhao Tuo** [晁错], who was ordered to reduce the lands of the feudal lords—his state was not yet prosperous when he met his death; or **Deng Ai** [邓艾], who led the campaign against Eastern Wu—his plans were not yet fulfilled when he died prematurely. All were harmed by their sharpness—how could one not take heed?

**Three: What is not innate cannot be firmly held.**
Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can guard them.
Those skilled in seeking the Dao seek within themselves; those skilled in preserving virtue secure what they attain.
Without seeking the Dao, there is no foundation for virtue; without establishing virtue, there is no way to manifest the Dao.
If one is unsettled here, if one is hasty here, then external things cannot be allowed to enter.
Once virtue and the Dao are lost, what one preserves lies outside—grand halls with carved beams and ornate walls, towering eaves and sculpted partitions—unless filled with gold and jade, they cannot be said to be truly refined.
Gold and jade are the essence of pure yang, treasured by the world.
Those who gain these and consider themselves rich do not follow a lasting path.
They can only moisten their homes but not nourish their bodies; they can invite thieves but cannot ensure blessings. Thus, greed for gain becomes a fatal malady, and the pursuit of wealth leads to reckless excess.
What need is there for such transient fortune?

**Four: The virtuous person guards against arrogance.**
Rich and noble yet proud, one invites disaster upon oneself.
The *Hong Fan* [《洪范》] lists five blessings: first, longevity; second, wealth—but it never mentions nobility.
For wealth can bring nobility, yet nobility does not necessarily bring wealth.
Zhuangzi said: *"Great wealth brings the nation’s treasures; great nobility brings the nation’s honors."*
If one can attain wealth, nobility will follow.
Yet even a son of a thousand pieces of gold sits without arrogance—though one may wish not to be proud, how can it be avoided?
Power compels it thus.
But if one, in wealth and nobility, precedes it with propriety, applies it with benevolence, and acts with righteousness, then even wealth and nobility cannot burden virtue.
There are those of noble character who surpass this—arrogance harms virtue.
Those who harm virtue, can they escape misfortune?
Zigong asked: *"Poor yet without flattery, rich yet without arrogance—how is that?"*
The Master replied: *"That is acceptable.
But it is not as good as being poor yet joyful, or rich yet fond of ritual."*

Those like the **Fan family**, who suffered humiliation at the hands of **Qiu Kai** [丘开], yet ultimately brought ruin upon themselves, or the **Yu family**, who were injured by a crossbow bolt meant for an assassin because of a rotting rat—these were all those who bore the look of arrogance.
Thus, the later generations withdrew their caution:
**One: Great names do not endure.**
When achievement is complete and reputation is fulfilled,
the Sage, in all matters, thinks deeply.
When holding great things and fearing excess, one fears them as if they were nothing—yet still does not guard against them.
Thus, holding to excess is not as good as ceasing.
Ease is simple; action is difficult.
Action cannot avoid premeditation, and where premeditation arises, how can one remain unchallenged?
If challenged, one seeks victory; if victorious, the other is defeated.
To measure and sharpen—is this not a strategy for long preservation?
To hold gold and jade without burdening the heart, to dwell in wealth and nobility without arrogance toward others—these are what people find difficult.
To have is not as good as to not have; to act is not as good as to cease.

**Two: Align with Heaven and act accordingly.**
Retreat is the Way of Heaven.
At the decline of the sun, without drumming or singing, the aged sigh at misfortune—those who follow Heaven’s path, having achieved their purpose and fulfilled their name, withdraw in retreat.
They say, *"How could this burden me?"*
**Shao Ruo** [邵若愚] said: *"Holding to excess until one retreats is the Way of Heaven.*
To dwell in high status and thick profit is like holding a vessel full to the brim—always fearing it will topple, it is better to cease before it overflows.
Thus, the unfilled is easier to hold.
To measure and sharpen is to invite ruin.
Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can guard them.
Wealth and nobility breed arrogance; arrogance and negligence lead to excess—this is not Heaven’s punishment, but self-inflicted ruin.
Yet how does one avoid this calamity?
Thus, the Sage observes the cycles of the four seasons: like spring’s transformation, when achievement is complete and reputation fulfilled, by summer one retreats and does not remain—this is the Way of Heaven.
**Wang Zhi Ran** [王志然] said: *"Holding to excess until one retreats is the Way of Heaven.*
What is beyond form is called the Dao; what is within form is called the vessel.
Within the realm of vessels, if there is fullness, there must be emptiness; if there is abundance, there must be decline.
To hold and guard, one must always fear self-excess—self-excess inevitably brings the disaster of collapse.
Thus, the ancients acted before harm arose and governed before disorder set in, vigilant and cautious, fearing only the loss of the means to reflect and amend.
The four cardinal virtues—ritual, righteousness, propriety, and shame—are the constants.
They dwell in substance, not in ornament; they always occupy the thick, never the thin.
The *Yijing* says:
*The Dao of Heaven diminishes excess and benefits humility;
The Dao of Earth transforms excess and flows toward humility;
Ghosts and spirits harm excess and bless humility;
Human nature abhors excess and loves humility.*
How perfect is humility as virtue!
Its root lies here; its branches lie there.
Holding to ancient ways, the Sage has never failed to value humility.
Its ultimate principle warns against overflow—
what is called *holding to excess is not as good as ceasing.*
Thus, holding excess is not as good as preserving humility;
measuring and sharpening is not as good as blunting sharpness.
To measure is to gauge others’ intentions;
to sharpen is to exploit others’ weaknesses.
Sharpness cannot be beneficial; benefit does not harm others.
As Mencius said: *"The archer fears injuring others; the crossbowman fears not injuring others."*
This is what should be blunted, not sharpened.
If one advances with sharpness, one’s retreat will be swift—
how could this endure?
This is its meaning.
External things cannot be relied upon—
people may claim them as their own, yet the Sage withdraws and avoids them.
Moreover, wealth and nobility are what people desire,
gold and jade are what people value—
if one knows how to accumulate but not how to disperse,
knows how to take but not how to give,
then one is no different from a great thief hoarding treasures."*

「Thus there are those who cling to their selfish private gains, insatiable even unto death, neglecting the cultivation of the fundamental Dao of life and death, and instead harming themselves—many perish without realizing it. How utterly foolish they are.

Laozi specifically warns: *"The more one loves, the greater the cost; the more one hoards, the heavier the loss."* Hence, those who understand the Dao recognize that wealth and nobility are ultimately insufficient to preserve one’s life. They do not cling to the transient advantages of a single lifetime for their own private gain, nor do they seek to dominate the world for the sake of display. When wealth accumulates to the point of overflowing the nation’s treasury, when nobility reaches the stage where titles and honors are bestowed upon all, when the distinctions between heaven and earth are blurred and great and small alike are governed by this principle—yet their own person remains untainted by wealth or nobility, their heart tranquil, never slighting even a single thing in their breast, though gold and jade fill their halls, they never grow arrogant or stingy. Their actions align with auspicious fortune, so what blame could there be?

The affliction of possessing a body is indeed grave. Yet, if one examines and reflects with care, what is truly valued is the absence of blame. When blame is absent, then where do misfortune, regret, and stinginess arise from?

To know how to advance yet not know how to retreat, to know how to preserve yet not know how to lose, to know how to gain yet not know how to suffer—how could one avoid regret?

If one achieves fame and success, yet grows proud and self-satisfied, boasting and flaunting, who in the world would not vie to contest their achievements?

The *Yijing* states: *"To know how to advance and retreat, preserve and lose, without losing one’s true course—is this not the unique attribute of the Sage?"*

The august Heaven has no partiality, only virtue does it assist. The yin and yang of heaven and earth create and transform all things; the four seasons proceed in their order, and the year’s harvest is fulfilled. When the harvest is complete, the season departs—Heaven says nothing of it.

If humans can embody this, they will harmonize with Heaven and Earth in virtue, with the sun and moon in luminosity, with the four seasons in order, and with the spirits and gods in fortune and misfortune. Heaven will not oppose them, and what of humans?

Thus the classics say: *"When achievements are complete, fame is secured, and one withdraws—this is the Dao of Heaven."* Students of the Way, how could they dare not strive to emulate this?

Huang Maocai remarks: *"To cling and fill to the utmost is impossible to sustain long."* The Dao is without attachment, yet one seeks to make it void. To cling and fill, is this possible? The Dao is without fixed form, yet one seeks to make it rigid. To measure and sharpen, is this possible? All these are rooted in *non*-Dao. Non-Dao is early decay; how could it endure?

Even when gold and jade fill one’s halls, it leads to self-inflicted blame. Gold and jade, as in the saying *"clad in coarse hemp yet holding jade in one’s bosom,"* are not of this world’s material wealth. Wealth and nobility, as in the saying *"those who know me are few, hence I am noble,"* are not of this world’s transient riches. The ancients had inner attainments; worldly affairs could not perturb their hearts. They valued the inner over the outer, prized themselves above external things.

Yet when it comes to arrogance, the disciples of Jian Kang in the Jin Dynasty indulged in lofty discourse, extolling profound mysteries, not without some grasp of the Dao. But by trampling others and scornful of the world, they ultimately met disaster. It is fitting that Laozi warned against this.

*"When achievements are complete, fame is secured, and one withdraws—this is the Dao of Heaven."* Achievement here means *"achievement without attachment,"* not the world’s so-called achievements. Fame here means *"fame without self-aggrandizement,"* not the world’s so-called fame. When achievements are complete and fame is secured, yet one withdraws—observing the sequence of the four seasons reveals the Dao of Heaven.

Laozi, Zhuangzi, Liezi, Fan Li, the Four Worthies, Anqi Sheng, and Dongfang Shuo were Sages of the ancient times. Yet the histories do not record their final fate—is this not because the Dao was fulfilled and they withdrew, leaving no trace for mortals to know?

Cheng Tai remarked: *"It is better not to cling and fill at all."* Fame, success, wealth, and nobility—when one reaches their utmost measure, this is called *"filling."* Above the point of filling, there is only collapse and overflow. Why strain anxiously to cling and hold, pushing toward the extreme, when it would be better to extinguish such thoughts and leave room for natural overflow? Hence the saying: *"It is better not to cling and fill at all."*

To measure and sharpen cannot be sustained long. If one fixates on the idea that *"offices and emoluments are insufficient to fill,"* then in one’s pursuits, the fear is of ever becoming dull. Thus, one preemptively gauges and calculates; when opportunity is seen, one acts with sharp precision. Those who follow such schemes may indeed succeed. Yet the measuring is in oneself, while the opportunity lies with others; guessing and often hitting the mark is mere luck. Even if one often succeeds by luck, there remain instances where luck fails, and this is the rigid insistence on what cannot be guaranteed. How could one expect such fleeting luck to become a constant? Hence, *"it cannot be sustained long."*

When gold and jade fill one’s halls, yet one withdraws—this is the Dao of Heaven. If wealth is gathered yet cannot be preserved, those who possess it grow proud with their abundance, and pride leads to ruin. Recognizing the cycle of filling and emptying, abandoning fame and success without clinging to them, this is to walk with Heaven. Without pride, one cannot speak of it.

Discussing the movement of the four seasons, the accomplished withdraw. This is precisely what Laozi meant by the Dao of Heaven. Yet the world hears it as if not hearing. They see the possibility of dwelling in success, yet fail to grasp the true principle of void and fullness.

Qijingshuai, the Duke of Qi, lamented the wealth of his state, considering death a tragedy. Yanzi laughed at him: *"If the ancients never died, then Taigong and Wenzi would always guard it. Would you, my lord, wear a patched robe and till the fields, with no time to ponder death?"* For they take turns in their roles, take turns in departing, and yet return to the lord. Yet you alone weep—is this not unkind?

In saying this, he was pointing out the alternating cycles of the four seasons, the successive phases of filling and emptying, and their relation to life and death, gain and loss. Hence, Liezi expounded on the mutual urging of life and transformation, saying: *"The living cannot avoid living; the transforming cannot avoid transforming."* He also spoke of the opposing balance of excess and deficiency: *"What is lost to one is gained by another; what is gained here is lost there."*

The transforming cannot avoid transforming, for it is the condition of the living’s inability to remain unborn. If this fullness and completion were not drawn from the other, yet the other must inevitably suffer loss and decay—how then could this fullness and completion be sustained without the other’s loss?

「From this perspective, the alternating cycles of departure and return are precisely the teachings of the Old Master [Laozi]. He spoke of those whose accomplishments are complete and whose reputation is fulfilled, yet whose fate demands they must withdraw.

Indeed, accomplishments and fame are the fruits of a profession brought to fruition. Wealth and honor are the gatherings of rank and emolument. Examining the affairs of the world, the number of ranks and emoluments in one age is fixed. Therefore, those who entrust their profession to others must also remain within this same age. If talented and wise individuals were to constantly monopolize these gains, then those who teach and guide with humility would have no place to welcome them.

Thus, when new arrivals come, the already accomplished must retreat—this is the inevitable succession of the four seasons. Hence, the Daoists, regarding the world, initially refuse to lightly accept responsibility for others, and ultimately do not wish to long remain in positions of success.

Like the disciples of Zhang Liang [in his retreat to the Garden of Fine Brocade], they could look down upon the calamities and humiliations of Xiao He and Han Xin with a smile, all having perceived this truth.

But for those who ascend to become sages, the matter is grander still. They say: *"To harmonize with the virtue/power of Heaven and Earth, to align with the sequence of the four seasons, advancement and retreat, life and death—all proceed without deviation."* This is far beyond those who fear fullness and seek safety, for they cannot be compared.

Zhan Qiu Pu said: *"The Dao of holding while full is to withdraw when Heaven demands."* The passage of *Yun Yi Zhang* [《运夷章》] elaborates: *"Yun"* means "use," *"Yi"* means "balance."* To hold until fullness overflows, to grasp until sharpness is extreme—when gold and jade accumulate to fill the hall, when wealth and honor lead to extravagance and arrogance, these are not the paths of balance. They are the roots of calamity and ruin.

True balance lies in the passage of *Yun* alone. Therefore, when accomplishments are fulfilled and reputation is complete, one must courageously withdraw. This is in accordance with Heaven’s Dao, which is as such. One cannot know advancement without knowing retreat.

Zhang Chong replied: *"The Dao of holding while full is to withdraw when Heaven demands."* Just as the sun reaches its zenith and then declines, the moon attains fullness and then wanes, and torrential rain cannot last an entire day—Heaven’s Dao operates thus, and how much more so for humanity?

Humans understand that Heaven’s Dao abhors excess and advocates humility, tempering sharpness and avoiding overreach. Thus, when fullness accumulates within oneself, one must swiftly consider self-restraint. Yet, if one persists in greed for wealth and position, they will invite harm to their spirit and body, bringing ruin upon themselves.

When sharpness is directed toward others, one must quickly reflect on tempering it. If they continue to nurture malevolence and harm others, they will provoke retaliation and endanger themselves. To forget fullness and not know restraint is to let gold and jade fill the halls, only to attract disaster—none can guard against it.

Wealth and honor leading to arrogance, while harboring sharpness, will only bring self-inflicted blame. If one remains still and unmoving, what blame could there be?

When accomplishments are complete and reputation is fulfilled, it is like the moon reaching the center of the sky—then comes the time of cooling winds and rippling waters. The Dao of withdrawing when Heaven demands leaves room for retreat.

Liao Cui Ran said: *"The Dao of holding while full is to never be self-satisfied. The best course is to let go when it is already complete, to guard oneself with enduring strategy."*

*"The Dao of tempering sharpness is to not indulge in reckless thoughts—one must cut decisively."* *"To not long preserve is to avoid future calamities."*

Gold and jade fill the hall—
yet one does not prize external wealth,
only cherishing what is self-nourished.

None can guard it.
If one could preserve it,
would it not be wondrous?

Wealth and honor bring arrogance—
yet one should not covet extravagance,
for splendor comes naturally.

Self-inflicted blame arises.
If I act without contrivance,
what blame could there be?

When accomplishments are complete and reputation fulfilled,
one guards oneself with the Dao—
water flows to its course naturally,
yet one must not cling.

Withdrawing in retreat,
hidden like water in the depths—
this aligns with Heaven’s Way.
Effortlessly, from beginning to end,
one’s household moves without a single step.

Chen Bi Xu said:
*"To hold while full is not as good as stopping.
Fullness means excess;
stopping means restraint.
He who clutches at what is already overflowing,
yet knows not humility and self-effacement,
will surely see its collapse.
To guard against ruin,
it is better to plan for early cessation.
This is a solemn warning."*

Strictly speaking, *zhí ér yíng zhī* (积而盈之) refers to hoarding wealth and treasures.
*"To temper sharpness is to not long preserve.
*Describe* (揣) means to measure, also to refine;
*say* (说) means keen sharpness.
Men know only the sharpness of greedy desires,
pursuing wealth and honor,
yet recklessly indulge their passions,
unmindful of restraint—
disaster comes, and it cannot be long sustained."*

Strictly speaking, *yán jūn píng* said:
*"Wealth and honor to me are like ascending a mountain to gaze afar;
name and power to me are like a fleeting lightning bolt.
This is to say they cannot be long preserved."*

*The Hong Lie Explanation* says:
White Gong won Jing State,
yet could not distribute its treasuries to the people.
Seven days later, Shi Qi entered and said:
*"An unjust gain, yet unable to give—
calamity will surely come.
If unable to share with others,
it is better to burn it,
so none may harm it."*
White Gong did not heed this.
On the ninth day, Ye Gong entered
and opened the treasury’s wealth to give to the people,
drew arms from the high storehouse to tax the citizens,
and thus attacked him.
Nineteen days later,
White Gong was captured.
The state was not his to possess,
yet he sought to possess it—
this was extreme greed.
Unable to benefit others,
yet unable to benefit himself—
this was extreme folly.
What difference is there
between White Gong’s stinginess
and the owl’s love for its young?
Thus it is said:
*"To hold while full is not as good as stopping;
to temper sharpness cannot be long preserved."*

Gold and jade fill the hall—
none can guard it.
This proves that excess cannot be reversed;
it is the inevitable logic of holding fast.

Gold and jade fill the hall,
yet only moisten the house—
when great thieves arrive,
they bear away baskets and cases,
shoulders laden with sacks.
Even the wise cannot guard them.
Thus, the elephant has tusks yet burns its body,
the rooster fears the sacrificial knife and loses its tail.
Even beasts know this—
why do not men reflect?

Wealth and honor bring arrogance,
self-inflicted blame arises.
*Her* (遗) means to bestow.
Riches attract seekers,
so one easily deceives others.
Honor makes others submit,
so one easily oppresses others.
Deception and oppression grow unchecked—
calamity and blame must come.
Who else could bring it?

Strictly speaking, *yán jūn píng* said:
*"Gold and jade to the body,
name and power to the spirit—
like ice and fire,
they cannot coexist.
Thus, name is the defilement of the spirit,
profit is the harm to the body.
Nurturing the defilement of the spirit,
accumulating harm to the body—
it damages what I have achieved,
yet benefits what I should destroy.
Gaining it is called profit,
losing it is called harm—
then their thoughts are confused,
and their inclinations perverse."*

Again he said:
*"What benefits my wealth harms my spirit,
what brings me fame destroys my body.
Misfortune arises from within, not from others;
blessing arises from within, not from Heaven."*

Lu Xi Sheng said:
*"To hold a great vessel while full—
though one fears it, it is better to stop early.
To occupy a high position with arrogance—
though one worries, it is better to retreat early.
To grasp at advantage with sharp intent—
though one gains it, it cannot be long preserved.
To hoard gold and jade in the hall—
though one possesses it, one cannot long guard it.
Noble while arrogant brings its own ruin,
rich while arrogant increases its faults.
Arrogance springs from the heart,
blame arises from oneself.
How can one blame Heaven or reproach others?"*

When accomplishments are complete and reputation fulfilled,
retreat is Heaven’s Way.
This concludes the meaning.

Who, when great deeds are done and fame is achieved,
yet does not know to rest and withdraw?
Moreover, when fine birds are exhausted,
the good bow is hidden;
when the cunning hare is slain,
the hunting dog is boiled.
This is the way of things.
Only those who understand
Heaven’s Way of fullness and emptiness,
knowing advance and retreat, survival and ruin—
these are the Perfect Ones.

Xie Tu Nan said:
*"To hold while full cannot be long preserved.
How extreme is the thought of fullness—
not even a hair’s breadth should take root!
The *Yijing* says:
‘One fullness brings four losses,
one humility brings four gains.’
The hearts of Heaven, Earth, man, and ghost
are thus revealed.*

*Holding* refers to guarding what is within;
*describing* refers to measuring what is without.
If within there is a mind of excess,
one easily becomes arrogant toward others—
excess will surely fail,
so it is better to stop.
If without there remains unrefined sharpness,
one easily harms others—
sharpness will surely break,
so it cannot long endure.
This is why the Sage does not seek greatness,
does not seek height."*

Gold and jade fill the hall—
self-inflicted blame arises.
Gold and jade are precious treasures—
who does not love them?
Yet if accumulated without dispersal,
what is lost will be much.
Riches and honor—
who does not desire them?
Yet arrogance and contempt for others
will make enemies many.
Who bears the blame?

When accomplishments are complete and reputation fulfilled,
retreat is Heaven’s Way.
In this life, to labor without achieving results—
the gentleman finds this shameful.
To die without a worthy name—
the gentleman finds this shameful.
When deeds are done and fame is achieved,
then all that can be done is complete.
To preserve oneself in retreat,
knowing when to stop brings no peril—
Heaven’s Way of transformation unfolds naturally.

The discussion has been examined: Heaven has the four seasons, and when accomplishments are fulfilled, retreat is called for.

Reputation is like the Creator’s stingy bestowal—once achieved and perfected, if one cannot preserve oneself and avoid harm by retiring to leisure, if one is greedy for honor and risks favor, calamity will soon follow.

This is because one does not understand the principle of *consumption and replenishment*, the Dao of advance and retreat, of flourishing and decline. When *yang* is excessive, regret follows; when *yin* is exhausted, struggle ensues—even the *Heavenly Stem* and *Earthly Branch* cannot escape. How much more so for humanity?

Thus, the Yellow Emperor humbled himself before Broad Success’s inquiry, and Zi Zhang followed the wanderings of Chi Song—these are but one Dao.

Lin Yongzhai said: *"To hold and fill to excess until retreat is Heaven’s Way."* This chapter speaks only of how advance is not as good as retreat, thus using the metaphor of *holding fullness* and *sharpening to a point*.

A vessel filled to its brim will surely overflow; to hold it is difficult, yet it is easier not to fill it at all. *Already* means "do not fill to excess."

*Describe* (治) means *to govern*; *point* (锐) means *sharpness*. To govern a vessel until it reaches extreme sharpness—nothing can endure without breaking. It is better not to sharpen at all, for then it may endure long.

To amass wealth until gold and jade fill the hall—one cannot long preserve it. To occupy the rank of a prince and grow arrogant—one will surely invite blame.

Thus, those who wish to preserve their accomplishments and safeguard their reputation must know when to retreat, for this is Heaven’s Way. When accomplishments are fulfilled and reputation is achieved, it is a matter of their scale—those who can preserve themselves.

Hence it is said: *"fulfilled"* and *"achieved."* If one does not know when to stop, when is it fulfilled? When is it achieved?

Fan Yingyuan said: *"To hold and fill to excess cannot be long preserved. Fullness leads to overflow; to hold and fortify it is better than not stopping at all. Sharpness leads to fracture; to govern and sharpen it—how can it be long preserved? Gold and jade fill the hall, yet one invites blame by oneself. Greedy for wealth and reckless with life—one loses all while the treasures remain. Rich and noble yet arrogant and extravagant—one loses oneself and brings ruin to one’s descendants."*

The Master of the Riverbank said: *"When rich, one should rescue the poor; when noble, one should pity the lowly. If instead one grows arrogant and unrestrained, then calamity will follow."*

When accomplishments are fulfilled and reputation is achieved, retreat is Heaven’s Way. The movement of *yin* and *yang* runs its course—when accomplishments are fulfilled, retreat is Heaven’s Way. Humanity should emulate Heaven, so from ancient times to today, those who achieve accomplishments and reputation yet do not retreat are often met with disaster.

The words of Laozi are a mirror for ten thousand generations. Those like Zi Zhang alone align with Heaven’s Way.

Xue Yongzhai said: *"To hold and fill to excess is not as good as stopping."* A vessel filled to its brim will overturn—even if held, it is of no use. It is better to cease what is held and keep it balanced and upright.

To govern and sharpen to a point cannot be long preserved. A person’s sharp edges, even without grinding, will surely be injured in motion—though governed, they cannot be preserved.

Gold and jade fill the hall—none can guard them. Shi Chong, standing in the marketplace, said: *"My slaves profit from my wealth alone; none can guard it."*

Rich and noble yet arrogant—one invites blame by oneself. Han Xin, though wise in his many warnings, still demonstrated his power to King Qi, thus inviting the calamity of Yunmeng.

Guo Zhen, after twenty-four promotions to Chancellor, enjoyed wealth, nobility, longevity, and honor from beginning to end—what more could a subject achieve? What blame could there be?

When accomplishments are fulfilled and reputation is achieved, retreat is Heaven’s Way. Fan Li and Zi Zhang certainly knew this Dao. Did the Grandee Zhen and Li Si understand it?

Xiu Xiu An said: *"To hold and fill to excess until retreat is Heaven’s Way."* The wise do not govern fullness or sharpen to a point. Those who guard and wait for satisfaction should know that fullness brings loss—it is better to stop early. Those who govern and sharpen to a point know that sharpness brings fracture—it cannot be long preserved.

Gold and jade fill the hall—none can guard them. Time is limited, fleeting and swift; human wealth and nobility are but dreams. Some, when in wealth and nobility, should deeply reflect and awaken, seizing the time to cultivate the Dao and virtue, entering sainthood and transcending humanity. If one is ignorant, indulgent, and extravagant, blind to the Way, one invites blame by oneself.

Those who achieve accomplishments and reputation should early preserve themselves and retreat, gathering results from causes, thus aligning with Heaven’s Way. Those who followed Chi Song’s wanderings—like Zhang Liang.

Zhu Bo Xiu said: *"To hold and fill to excess until retreat is Heaven’s Way."* To hold things until they are full is to metaphorically speak of insatiable ambition, thus warning against not stopping. And not to govern and sharpen to a point—to avoid competing for gain and risking harm—thus declaring it cannot be long preserved.

Those who rush in pursuit of gain, reckless in their ambitions, until gold and jade fill the hall—will they not tread the path of *"wealth without virtue"*? Those who long dwell in wealth and nobility, without restraint, will grow arrogant and extravagant, corrupting their hearts and ruining their nature. Human and ghostly censure will have no escape—all this begins with excess, with not knowing when to stop.

Accumulating evil and inviting disaster, they end in self-destruction. The affairs of Yi Bu and Jin Gu can serve as a warning. Thus, those who hold should not let things fill to excess—if not filled, there is no need to hold.

The foolish know this yet take no heed, sweetly stepping into disaster. The gentleman, in this regard, weighs the heavy and light, acting with advance and retreat—not abandoning accomplishments and reputation, but clearly discerning Heaven’s principles of rise and fall, examining human affairs for what is permissible and what is not. Knowing that fulfilled accomplishments and achieved reputation have things to fear, they retreat and conceal themselves to nurture their virtue.

Thus, they see the honor of Heaven’s bestowal. Looking back on worldly gains and offices, they find them unworthy of pursuit.

The cycles of the four seasons run their course—when accomplishments are fulfilled, retreat is called for. If one defies this principle, one disrupts Heaven’s order—how much more so for human affairs?

Observing the ancient and modern heroes, few preserve their later years—worthy of sighs. Only those who perceive omens and know contentment can avoid misfortune in life and leave a fragrant name behind.

The sages have said: *"Without the strength to lift mountains or move tides, how could one turn back to see the cold place?"*

「Truly so. The *Niu Miao* transmission states: *"To hold and fill is not as good as to know when to stop."* By *hold*, it means *admonition*—when what one holds becomes full, it must overflow. Thus, it is seen that it is better to stop before reaching fullness than to hold until overflowing.

To dwell in *zhongyong* (the balanced middle) is to naturally avoid overflowing. Hence it is said: *"To know when to stop is better than to hold until full."*

In ancient times, Confucius observed in the temple of Duke Huan of Lu a tilted vessel, and asked its keeper: *"What is this vessel?"* The keeper replied: *"It is called the *yòu* (tolerant) seat vessel."* Confucius said: *"I have heard that the *yòu* seat vessel—when empty, it commands respect; when half-full, it stands upright; when full, it overturns. The ancient wise rulers considered this the ultimate admonition—is this not the meaning of 'to know when to stop is better than to hold until full'?"*

To probe and sharpen is not long-lasting. By *probe*, it means *test*; by *sharpen*, it means *unyielding strength*. When one is tested and found to be unyielding, it is certain that they lack *ren* (benevolence). Confucius declared: *"The unbenevolent cannot long endure adversity, nor can they long dwell in pleasure."* This is the same principle.

The ancients said: *"To associate with a virtuous person is like walking through mist and dew—though one may not be drenched, there is constant refreshment;
To dwell among the wicked is like standing between blades—though one may not be harmed, there is constant peril.*
Moreover, if one’s attire and bearing are not proper, others may already be inclined to dismiss them—how much more so for the unyielding, whose association cannot be long preserved?

Mencius said: *"When Shun ruled the world, he selected from the masses and raised Gao Yao—then the unbenevolent were distant indeed.
When Tang ruled the world, he selected from the masses and raised Yi Yin—then the unbenevolent were distant indeed.*
It is because the unbenevolent know they cannot long endure association. Hence it is said: *"To probe and sharpen is not long-lasting."*

Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can guard them. Gold and jade are the world’s most precious treasures—though they fill the chamber, they are inherently valued by others, and what benefit do they bring to one’s *shìgōng* (worldly accomplishments)? This is the meaning of *"none can guard them."*

The *Tàishàng* (Supreme Sage) said: *"Wealth and honor cannot accompany one at death—when the Five Heavenly Messengers (*Wúcháng Shǐzhě*, the agents of fate) strike without warning, seizing the soul, the grand halls and lofty chambers are no longer inhabited, nor can one follow the swift chariots and fine steeds into the afterlife. Gold and jade, jewels and treasures, are but playthings for others—this is the meaning of 'none can guard them.'*
Wealth and honor bring arrogance, which invites one’s own downfall. Wealth and honor are *zūnróng* (eminence and grace); arrogance is *àomàn* (haughtiness and insolence). *Héi* (to invite) means self-inflicted; *jiù* (blame) means regret and remorse. The ancients said: *"Does wealth and honor make one arrogant, or does poverty make one arrogant?"*
The proverb states: *"Wealth and honor do not make one arrogant—if they do, the arrogance comes from within."*
Confucius said: *"The noble one maintains composure without arrogance; the petty one arrogantly lacks composure.*
To fail in dwelling in composure is to invite regret. The *Shū* (Book of Documents) says: *"Revelry and arrogance lead to ruin—this is to invite disaster oneself."*
Disaster and fortune come from no other source than one’s own actions—this is the meaning of *"to invite one’s own downfall."*

When accomplishments are fulfilled and reputation achieved, one must retreat—this is the *Dao* of Heaven. If one stands in the halls of power, their name inscribed on bamboo and silk, they may be said to have fulfilled accomplishments and achieved reputation. Yet if they know to seek retreat, hanging their official cap and refusing further office, this is called *shēntuì* (retiring oneself). Those who retire without overflowing are in accord with Heaven’s *Dao*.

For instance, Zhang Liang served Emperor Gaozu of Han, ranked among the feudal lords, yet he did not dare accept three thousand households—only saying: *"A seal and a title are enough."* Later, he left office and wandered with the *Chìsōng Zǐ* (Red Pine Immortal). Was this not retiring oneself?
Fan Li served King Goujian of Yue and achieved hegemony, then said: *"Under a great name, one cannot long remain."* He removed his official seal, set sail across the sea, and departed. These two men—fulfilling accomplishments without claiming them, achieving reputation and retiring—embodied the *Dao* of Heaven’s non-overflowing principle, were they not virtuous?

Yang Zhiren said: *"From 'to hold and fill' to 'retiring oneself' is the *Dao* of Heaven. To hold and fill means the sun reaches its peak at nine in the third month, while the moon wanes at two in the eighth month. In *xiūzhēn xuédào* (cultivating true *Dao*), lead and mercury transform into the most precious elixir—when the fire’s *huò* (alchemical potency) is complete and the *qi* is sufficient, one must retreat and not act further. If they fail to know when to stop, great disgrace will follow. Hence, 'to know when to stop is better than to hold until full.'*
It is because holding until full leads to overflowing—better to stop before that. Yet if one has not yet reached fullness, there must be greed. To probe and sharpen—how can this be long preserved?
Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can guard them. Wealth and honor bring one to retire and conceal—this is to harmonize with Heaven’s *Dao*.

Shu Guang said to his son: *"I have heard that knowing contentment brings no disgrace, knowing when to stop avoids peril. When accomplishments are fulfilled and reputation achieved, this is the way—if one does not leave, fear will come with regret. Yet arrogance and indulgence in desires will surely harm one’s *shénqì* (spirit and *qi*), inviting one’s own downfall."*

When accomplishments are fulfilled without boasting, and reputation achieved without flaunting, the *Dao* is complete.

Qing Zhong said: *"From 'to hold and fill' to 'retiring oneself' is the *Dao* of Heaven. Fullness invites loss; modesty invites benefit. This is the *Dao* of Heaven, the essence of this chapter’s teaching.*
A vessel full to the brim will overturn—none hold it better than knowing when to stop.
A blade too sharp will break—if one further probes and grinds it, it cannot be long preserved.
Using objects as metaphors, it is to teach people to know when to advance and when to retreat.
Gold and jade fill the hall—one should stop there. Yet if they greedily seek more, though they possess this gold and jade, none can guard it.
Wealth and honor that permeate the heavens should prompt one to know when to stop. Yet if they further indulge in arrogance and self-indulgence, this is to invite one’s own downfall.»

The sun at its zenith must decline,
the moon at full must wane—
Heaven and Earth in fullness and emptiness
follow the ebb and flow of time.
When merit is complete and name is fulfilled,
one who knows to retreat—
is this not in accord with the natural *Dao* of Heaven?

Fan Li conquered Yue yet sailed away in a humble boat upon the Five Lakes,
Lu Zhonglian declined the thousand-gold reward at Liaocheng,
rejected the emperor’s title and fled the noble seals of Qin.
Zhang Zifang, though he humbled the tyrant Xiang Yu,
then drifted away to wander with the immortal Zhongshan.
All surpassed the figures of Qin and Han in grandeur—
these were those whose merit was complete yet who did not cling to it.

The *Yijing* says:
*"The virtuous one perceives the signs and acts—
waiting until the day is done is too late."*

The *Shiliu Xu* says:
*"To hold and fill is not as good as stopping.
All things under Heaven, when grasped and pushed to their fullest,
will inevitably invite ruin—
thus it is urged: ‘Better to stop early.’
‘Stop’ means ‘halt.’
It means: better to halt in good time."*

Power and influence are even more so.
To sharpen and probe it—
it cannot be long preserved.

The *Dao* is sought and found,
abandoned and lost—
this seeking is beneficial to what is obtained,
for the seeking lies within oneself.
Yet now, when one’s mind schemes and sharpens ambition,
even if one gains what is desired,
it is far removed from the virtue of *Dao*, *de*, and *renyi*.
How could it be long preserved? Is this not fitting?

Gold and jade fill the hall—
none can guard it.
Gold and jade are the supreme treasures of Heaven and Earth,
loved by all under Heaven—
though piled high in a grand hall,
those whose greedy hearts are never satisfied
truly cannot guard them.
Is this not the way of great thieves accumulating wealth?

Riches and honor bring arrogance—
one invites one’s own ruin.
The lords and kings, the most exalted in wealth and honor,
if they govern themselves with humility,
shall long enjoy Heaven’s blessings.
But if they lord it over the world with pride,
they bring ruin upon themselves—
who else is to blame?

When merit is complete and name is fulfilled,
one retreats—
this is the *Dao* of Heaven.
Merit and fame are the weightiest concerns of sages past and present.
Only when they are complete and fulfilled does one know to retreat,
thus preserving them—
this is the duty of those with great virtue.
How could it be the concern of petty wisdom?

Thus it is said: *"To hold and fill is the *Dao* of Heaven."*
The cycles of the four seasons,
the completion of merit—
this is the *Dao* of Heaven.
It is because the four seasons cannot but succeed one another.
This chapter’s true intent in *Laozi* is:
when merit is complete and fame is fulfilled,
to retreat early—
emphasizing that fullness must overflow,
sharpness must break.

A vessel full yet grasped—
better to halt and not cling.
A blade sharpened and probed—
it cannot be preserved long unbroken.
*"Probe"* means to sharpen it further.

Gold and jade fill the hall—
they invite robbers and cannot be guarded.
Riches and honor bring arrogance—
ruin and blame inevitably follow—
this is the natural order.

*Laozi* spoke thus,
desiring that people know contentment to avoid disgrace,
knowing when to stop to avoid peril.

In this world, people seek nothing but merit and fame.
When merit is achieved and name is fulfilled,
one should retreat—
for Heaven abhors fullness and favors humility.
Otherwise, clinging to fullness, sharpening ambition,
arrogance in riches and honor,
unknowing of contentment—
disgrace and peril will surely follow.

The *Yuan’an Resident* says:
*"To hold and fill is the *Dao* of Heaven."*
Fullness must overflow,
sharpness must break.
To fear overflow and forcefully grasp it—
better not to be full in the first place,
so there is no need to grasp.
To fear breaking and probe it with one’s hands—
better not to be sharp in the first place,
so there is no need to probe.

‘Fullness’ refers to power and status,
‘sharpness’ to talent and wisdom.
Gold and jade fill the hall—
this refers to talent and wisdom.
Riches and honor bring arrogance—
this refers to power and status.
Merit complete—power and status.
Fame fulfilled—talent and wisdom.

Gold and jade are objects of joy and admiration—
even storing them in a room is hard to guard,
let alone in a hall?
Even the hall is unsafe—
how much more so when it is full?
Thus, though one might watch with the keen eyes of Li Zhu
and defend with the strength of Bi Yu,
thieves would still seize them.
This illustrates how those who boast of talent and wisdom,
flaunting their fullness,
will inevitably be undone by external forces.
This is why great fame is hard to sustain.

Riches and honor are easy to lose and hard to secure—
even humility and retreat cannot guarantee safety,
let alone adding arrogance and excess?
This ruin is not wrought by Heaven,
nor does misfortune come from without—
all is self-inflicted.

This is why great merit is hard to preserve.
Only the wise, when merit is complete and fame is fulfilled,
retreat—
thus aligning with the *Dao* of Heaven.

"Retreat" carries two meanings:
in terms of power and status, it is *guitian* (withdrawal);
in terms of talent and wisdom, it is *qianxu* (humble retreat).
The *Dao* of Heaven is as the *Yijing* speaks of *xu-ying-yi-qian*,
and the commentaries say of the four seasons’ cycles—
those who achieve merit must retreat.

The people of Jin said of Lin Gong:
*"He can be said to have gold and jade filling his hall,"*
also referring to talent and wisdom.
The world interprets this as guarding wealth—
how shallow!

The Sage of Later Chapters, clad in coarse hemp yet harboring jade within—
could this truly be jade?

*《Zhuzizi Pangzheng》* records:
*《Wenzi》* states: "The Master Lao said:
If acquired through unrighteousness,
and not shared through generosity,
then calamity will befall oneself,
and one cannot be called a true person.
Nor can one differ from the owl that loves its young.
Thus, to hold and hoard it,
is not as good as letting it go.
To clutch and sharpen it,
cannot be long preserved.

Shi Tan said:
To hold and fill oneself with it,
is not as good as letting it go.
To clutch and sharpen it,
cannot be long preserved.
Gold and jade filling one’s hall,
none can guard it.
Rich and noble yet arrogant,
one invites one’s own ruin.

When merit is complete and fame is fulfilled,
retreat while still alive—
this is the Dao of Heaven.
To cling and be self-satisfied,
is not as good as stopping.
To clutch and polish with sharp edges,
cannot be long preserved.
Gold and jade filling one’s hall,
may depart at its appointed time,
and cannot be considered as something to be long guarded.
Rich and noble yet arrogant,
one invites one’s own ruin.

High position brings slander,
wealth invites thieves’ eyes.
Thus, when merit is complete and fame is fulfilled,
one must first retreat in person,
then can avoid ruin.
For the full will surely be diminished,
the spent will surely be exhausted—
this is the Dao of Heaven.

The *《Yijing》*’s *《Qian》* (Modesty) says:
The Dao of Heaven diminishes the full and benefits the modest,
the Dao of Earth transforms the full and flows into modesty,
the Dao of spirits harms the full and blesses the modest,
the Dao of humanity abhors the full and favors modesty.
*《Shu》* (Book of Documents) says:
‘The full invites loss, the modest invites benefit—
this is the Dao of Heaven and time.’

This aligns with the meaning of this chapter.
The earlier scholars said:
‘The Master Lao truly grasped the *《Yijing》*’s Modesty—
this is certain.’

*《Daode Zhengjing Jiyi》* Volume Fourteen concludes.

**《Daode Zhengjing Jiyi》** Volume Fifteen:
**《Ningyuan Dashijuan’s Exalted Observations on the Chapter of *Changde* (Constant Virtue) and *Lu Xuanmiao Guan* (Mysterious and Profound Observations)**»

**Chapter on *Yingpo* (Nurturing the Vital Essence):**
*Considerations of Variations:*
The *Laozi* of the *Riverbank Master* (河上公) is titled *Chapter of What Can Be Done* (《能为章》),
while the *Laozi* of Zhao Shizhan (赵实庵) is titled *Chapter of the Profound True Meaning of Ebb and Flow* (《消息至真义章》).

*Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang* (唐明皇) expounds:
In the previous chapter, it is made clear that unrestrained indulgence and drowning in emotions,
or arrogance and excess, will bring misfortune.
This chapter illustrates that when one nourishes the spirit and cherishes *qi* without distraction,
there will be no blemish.

From *Yingpo* (Nurturing the Vital Essence) down to *Dixie* (Purifying Elimination):*
These teachings caution against bodily cultivation to preserve one’s *virtue/power* (德).
From *Airen* (Loving Others) down to *Mingbai* (Clarity):*
They demonstrate that perfecting *virtue/power* (德) can enable one to rule as a sovereign.

The conclusion with *Shengzhu* (Generating and Nurturing) signifies
the Dao’s mysterious function manifesting in all things.

Du Guangting (杜光庭) states:
This chapter clarifies the benefits of *Embracing the One* (抱一),
contrasting it with the folly of *Probing the Sharp* (揣锐) from earlier.
*Embracing the One* ensures the spirit is whole and the vital essence secure,
while *Probing the Sharp* leads to excess and inevitable ruin.

As for the subtleties of *attaining softness* (致柔) and *mysterious observation* (玄览),
the principles of *loving others* (爱人) and *governing the realm* (理国),
and the harmony of the Dao’s *generating and nurturing* (生畜),
it reveals the profound and mysterious *virtue/power* (德) of the *Commentary* (注).

Zhang Chongying (张冲应) responds:
The fifth chapter already expounds on the gate of *vital essence* (精气) entering and exiting.
This chapter further elucidates how *vital essence* (精) transforms into *qi* (气).
Thus, *What Can Be Done* refers to *vital essence* (精),
which can be refined into *qi* (气).

*Nurturing the Vital Essence and Embracing the One* (载营魄抱一):
One can remain steadfast without separation.
*Concentrating Qi to Attain Softness* (专气致柔):
The body can be as supple as an infant.
*Purifying Elimination and Mysterious Observation* (涤除玄览):
One can be without blemish.
*Loving Others and Governing the Realm* (爱民治国):
One can act without interference.
*The Celestial Gate Opens and Shuts* (天门开阖):
One can transcend duality.
*Clarity and Fourfold Reach* (明白四达):
One can be without knowing.
*Generating and Nurturing* (生之畜之):
The Dao generates without possession,
acts without reliance,
and nurtures without domination—
this is called *Mysterious Virtue/Power* (玄德).

*Considerations of Variations:*
One version reads:
*Nurturing the Vital Essence and Embracing the One*—
can one remain steadfast without separation?
*Concentrating Qi to Attain Softness*—
can one be as pure as an infant?
*Purifying Elimination and Mysterious Observation*—
can one be without blemish?
*Loving Others and Governing the Realm*—
can one act without interference?
*The Celestial Gate Opens and Shuts*—
can one transcend duality?
*Clarity and Fourfold Reach*—
can one be without knowing?
*Generating and Nurturing*—
The Dao generates without possession,
acts without reliance,
and nurtures without domination—
this is called *Mysterious Virtue/Power* (玄德).

*Nurturing the Vital Essence* (载营魄):
One alternate reading is *Zai* (哉), as seen in the *Zhu* (注) version,
which has been clarified below.

*Can one transcend duality?* (能无雌乎):
One version reads *Can one transcend the feminine?* (能无雌),
though this may not align with the original meaning.
In the *Commentary*, it states: *"Knowing its masculine, one can act without interference"* (知其雄能无为乎).
One version reads: *"Can one act without interference?"* (能无为乎).
Another version states: *"Loving others and governing the realm—*
*can one be without knowing?"* (爱民理国，能无知乎).
