In *wuwei*, one governs the world with abundance;
in *youwei*, one serves the world yet lacks sufficiency.
Thus, to love the people and govern the state—
how could one not practice *wuwei*?

*Wuwei* means *wuwei*—yet nothing remains undone.
The Heavenly Gate opens of its own accord,
the Earthly Gate closes itself.
The Heavenly Gate is where spirit enters and departs.
When the Heavenly Gate opens and shuts,
the spirit can move freely,
sitting in one place yet wandering boundless realms.

Yet if the spirit wanders without restraint,
there are places it cannot reach—
thus, it must be still,
and align with *yin*’s virtue.

When the primal spirit is still,
true nature shines forth,
capable of mirroring Heaven and Earth,
illuminating the ten thousand things.

Yet if wisdom is overused,
it will falter at times.
Thus, clarity and openness—
how could one not embrace *wu*?

What is called "clever, enlightened, and wise"
is guarded by *yū* (primordial stupor).

Wisdom unused is true—
stillness and tranquility nourish each other,
knowing and serenity cultivate one another,
aligning with Heaven and Earth in essence,
matching Creation in function—
its *Dao* can generate the ten thousand things,
its *virtue* can nourish the world.

Thus it is said: *"To generate and to nourish."*
To generate without claiming the deed,
to act without relying on action,
to foster without ruling—
this is the *Classic*’s teaching:
*"Its achievements cover the world yet seem not its own,
its transformations benefit all things yet the people do not depend on them."*

Zhao Shizhan says:
At the outset, the root principle:
*"Gold and Fire seize the form."*
Then comes *"loading the *hun* and *po*."*
Recognizing the limits of Heaven’s timing,
knowing the impermanence of external things—
discarding the former, taking the latter—
thus lies the *Dao* of longevity.

Hence, it continues with *"loading the *hun* and *po*."*

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Establish Heaven’s *Dao*—*yin* and *yang*.*
*Yin* and *yang* are things that seek each other."

The spirit of one’s body is called *hun* and *po*;
*hun* and *po* are the *Dao* of mutual exchange.
*Hun* is *yang*, *po* is *yin*;
*po* draws from *yang* to manifest,
*hun* depends on *po* to stand.
When *hun* is full, *po* is born;
when *hun* fades, *po* retreats.
This is the rhythm of the sun and moon’s passage,
the ebb and flow of *yin* and *yang*—
Heaven’s eternal order.

The *Book of Documents* says: *"Zāi, the birth of *po*—*
this is the moon.
It shines bright in the east,
and *zāi* (wanes) in the west—
meaning a month of thirty days,
the numbers five and six.

**Chapter on Nourishing the Vital Essence**

Master Yinyuan, whose profound virtue traverses the Mysterious Path, oversees the compilation of affairs.
Sifu Liu Weiyong assembles the text.
Formerly honored official Ding Yidong, Director of the Imperial Treasury and Compiler of the Secretariat, verifies the text.

**On Nourishing the Vital Essence:**

Huang Maocai says:
*"Can one who nourishes the vital essence and embraces unity ever separate?"*
**Vital essence**—this is motion.
**Spirit**—this is yin.
Yin belongs to form; form, by nature, cannot move. Yet **qi** bears it and sets it in motion.
When a person cultivates and directs **qi** so it never departs from form, this is called *embracing unity*.
It is not spoken of as **qi** because only this can sustain life—there is no second way.

**Concentrating qi to achieve softness—can one be like an infant?**
Having embraced unity, over time one naturally forgets form and focuses solely on nurturing **qi**, hence form is not mentioned. What ordinary people contend for is the burden of form.
To forget one’s form and return to the state of an infant means no breath of strife remains—thus it is called *achieving softness*.
Softness is the companion of life.

**Purifying and gazing into the Mysterious—can one be without blemish?**
By this stage, both form and **qi** are forgotten.
Washing the heart clean, exhausting all filth, equal to the boundless void—how could there still be blemish?

**Loving the people and governing the state—can one act without doing?**
To study the Dao and reach *wuwei* is not the work of a single day.
Only after embracing unity, achieving softness, and gazing into the Mysterious without blemish can one attain *wuwei*.
If one has not yet reached this and yet forces oneself to *wuwei*, this is called *riding at a gallop*—ever more distant from the Dao.
The state is like the body; the people are like the spirit. Loving the people and governing the state is the same as tending to oneself.

**The Heavenly Gate opening and closing—can one avoid the feminine?**
The Heavenly Gate is the **fontanel**.
Now, the infant’s fontanel opens and closes uncontrollably. When cultivation reaches this stage, one can ascend to communicate with Heavenly Dao—thus it is called the Heavenly Gate.
**Feminine** is the same as **yin**.

**Clarity and openness in all directions—can one avoid knowing?**
To be without knowing is to know all things, like a person opening their eyes to see—nothing is unseen.
How could one say, *"I have perception"*? To have perception and lack perception is called *eye disease*.
To have knowing and not knowing is called *heart disease*.
From embracing unity, six stages progress until one reaches *wuwei*—thus, Kexue questioned Wangni four times, and four times Wangni answered, *"I do not know."* Kexue then leapt for joy—there was good reason.

**To nurture life to this point is called Mysterious Virtue.**
The Classic speaks of this twice.
The first mention refers to the **Dao**; this refers to **virtue**.
The **Dao** descends as **virtue**; the subtlest **virtue** merges once more with the **Dao**—thus it is called *Mysterious Virtue*.

Program Tai said:
*"Can one who nourishes the vital essence and embraces unity ever separate?"*
Unity is the name that encompasses all things.
When joy, anger, sorrow, and delight are about to emerge but have not yet formed,
When wisdom and insight are about to manifest but have not yet taken shape—
All these are unified into One, refined and without separation, returning to the origin where the **Dao** first emerges as One.
The **Dao** is One alone.
To ground the **Dao** in affairs and name what can be called **virtue** is already distinct from the **Dao**.
From the **virtue** one attains, one divides it into *ren, yi, li, zhi, xin* to name it—
The source grows distant, and the branches multiply beyond count.
Earlier, it was spoken of as a unified whole; now it is divided into five, and their offspring are innumerable.
Thus, Laozi thins it out, saying:
*"When the **Dao** is lost, **virtue** arises; when **virtue** is lost, *ren, yi, li* arise."*
When he says *"lost,"* he does not mean *gone*—
Rather, moving away from the root, the commandments multiply, ever more contrary to Unity.
Thus, what Laozi most treasures is the subtle, indistinct, and undifferentiated origin.
Yet Yi Yin, speaking of his attainment, places it in the realm of **virtue**, harmony, and accord.
Examining beginning and end, all conform to Unity as their standard.

Liezi’s theory is like a lost sheep with many paths:
*"Only by returning to Unity and merging can one avoid gain or loss."*
Zhuangzi says, *"**Virtue** is the totality of what the **Dao** encompasses."*
Unity is called *totality*; merging is called *returning*.
Both stem from the restoration of the Mandate—
Thus, cultivating the **Dao** must begin with embracing Unity.

The human spirit and **qi** are called *hun* and *po*.
The moon’s substance, which does not receive sunlight, is also called *po*.
This **vital essence** and **spirit** are the *young hun* and *po* paired in opposition from the *Yijing*.
The *young hun* can ascend and descend lightly, entering and exiting freely.
But the *po*’s **vital essence** is like encampment, gathering, and clustering—
Yet it is bound and constrained, unable to govern its own movement.
Thus, the ascent or descent of spirit and form is the most critical mechanism of the body.
If the spirit governs the form, all actions follow its will—
If the spirit does not reign, it is instead bent by the form, and decay follows.
Now, let the spirit be the chariot, the form the load—
The chariot moves, and the load is borne upon it—
This is the spirit already governing the form.
If a person achieves this, their will directs the form like a chariot moving its load—
Desire east, and it goes east; desire west, and it goes west—
Whatever is willed, there is compliance, no resistance.
To embrace Unity from here is not difficult.
It is only that one does not know whether, in governing the form and embracing Unity, one can persist without abandoning it.

Thus, the hesitant tone—this is doubt.
Using doubtful language to examine the superficial—
It is to make one reflect upon themselves.
Hence, Zhuangzi’s discussion of the *Yashengjing* says:
*"Can one embrace Unity? Can one avoid loss?"*
This is the very meaning.

All this chapter speaks to those who have glimpsed the **Dao** but whose guardianship is not yet firm.
If one embraces Unity and does not separate,
Achieves softness and is like an infant—
Then one is already One with the **Dao**.
If Laozi were to speak from this ground,
The doubtful language would become decisive.

「凡此章下文设疑以示者，其义皆类此也。
To embrace Unity and achieve softness—can one persist like a newborn babe? The *Liezi* describes the infant thus: *"Qi is focused and harmonized to its utmost."*
Nothing harms it, no virtue can surpass it—this speaks of its innate thickness, untainted by external things.
Mencius says: *"The noble person is one who does not lose the heart of their infant self."*
This means though they engage with the world, they do not forget their original nature.

Combining both, only those whose virtue remains unseparated can truly return to the state of the infant.
When one is about to act, their *qi* carries out their intentions as if wind conveys the chill and heat of seasons.
If one’s *qi* is not diverted elsewhere, and they focus solely on achieving softness,
Then when this softness is attained, the harmonized state that harms nothing returns once more.
It is only that one does not know whether they can reach this state.

To purify and perceive the profound—can one remain without flaw?
The profound is that which is deep and unfathomable.
*Xuànpín* (玄牝), *Xuàndé* (玄德), *Xuàntóng* (玄同), and *Xuànguān* (玄览) all describe this unfathomable realm.

This kind of perception, all have it—yet if the heart’s source is unclean,

Then the senses are obscured, and how can the luminous be seen?

Nánróng Zī asked Laozi: *"What is the difference between the eye and its form?

Laozi briefly illuminated the nature of innate disposition and emotions to awaken him,
And Zī thus retreated to his dwelling, called forth what he loved,
And banished what he hated—
After ten days, he returned to see Laozi.
Laozi praised his ability to purify himself.

Zī’s question concerned vision, yet what Laozi taught was about innate disposition and emotions.
If Zī could purify his disposition and emotions,
Then the obscurations would vanish on their own, and he would recover his original nature.
Thus, to purify and perceive the profound is not to exert oneself upon the eyes.
To investigate why obscurations arise and then purify them,
Then all that can be seen and known will return to its original state.
Returning to the original, one’s perception of the profound will be restored.

To love the people and govern the state—can one act without doing?
Loving the people and governing the state must involve means to execute,
And only then can intentions bear fruit—
Yet all establishing laws and affairs are but these means.
If one has means yet still warns against deliberate action,
Zhuangzi has already made this clear.
He said: *"I have heard of nurturing the world, but never of governing it."*
In the way of nurturing, one discards cleverness,
Sets aside rewards and punishments,
Follows the natural flow of life and disposition,
And finds ease in effortless harmony—
Thus, all things are not burdened.

There is one who transcends the rules and measures of law and order.
This is what is called *wuwei* (无为).

Thus, those who strive to follow the established ways cannot,
And those who seek governance through deliberate action often fail in many matters.
Hence, the warning here is like asking: *"Who can love the people and govern the state
Without resorting to contrived schemes and actions?"*
To act in accordance with nature, without deliberate intervention,
Is the very essence of the next chapter’s governance—
As vast as simmering fresh meat.

The opening and closing of the Heavenly Gate—can one avoid bias?
Zhuangzi once pointed to the realm of birth and death, existence and nonexistence,
As the Heavenly Gate—
This is the Heavenly Gate of Heaven.
He also discussed the Dao that cannot be spoken or transmitted:
*"If one’s heart rejects it, the Heavenly Gate will not open."*
This also speaks of the human heart as the Heavenly Gate.

Since the Heavenly Gate of Heaven is the realm of birth and transformation,
Then the human Heavenly Gate is also the passage of their innate vitality.
The Creator’s contraction and expansion of yin and yang,
Their successive nurturing of birth and transformation,
Is the ability to regulate the opening and closing of the Heavenly Gate.
If one’s engagement with the world is cautious,
Preserving life and death through moderation,
Judging what is appropriate and welcoming or rejecting accordingly,
Then the Heavenly Gate of one’s self
Can also regulate its opening and closing.

Cultivating to this degree is already to surpass the world and reveal its essence—
Yet to act only when appropriate, never leading the way of things,
Is not this even more excellent?

Clarity and openness in all directions—can one avoid knowing?
Clarity means no obstruction, whiteness means no darkness.
To be open in all directions is to have no closed doors or blind spots—
All four ways are thoroughly illuminated.
The distant lies beyond the eight extremes,
The near is within the space between one’s eyebrows—
If there is a distinct sound that comes to disturb me,
I must know it—
This is the clarity and openness that reaches in all directions.

When one attains this state, the danger lies in being too sharp in applying wisdom.
Without affairs, one becomes overly observant;
Encountering affairs, one becomes too probing.
Yet if one has attained the Dao, this is not so.
They have never deliberately sought to see—
Yet seeing arises from the things themselves.
The wisdom of divining from tortoise shells,
The clarity of the water mirror,
Are all its manifestations.

If one’s cultivation has not yet reached this state,
Then even with keen intelligence and sharp insight,
They may guard it with foolishness—
Could one not expose their own nature?

To nurture and accumulate life.
Originally, there is nothing—yet through creation, something arises—
Thus, it can be called *shēng* (生).
Like the Dao giving rise to Unity, and Unity to Duality.
To take what has already been born and solidify it,
Is to *chù* (畜) it.
As when one cultivates their virtue.

Nearly all the teachings in this chapter,
From embracing Unity and achieving softness onward,
Are about holding fast to virtue and seeking to return to the Dao.
The pursuit of Unity, softness, and elemental clarity is through virtue—
To hope for no separation and no flaw is to seek return to the Dao.
The methods of focusing *qi* and purifying obscurations,
Are all ways to attain virtue.
If one attains virtue, one can nurture life—
Unity, softness, and elemental clarity—
Do they come to me?
If they dwell, then I am the one who can accumulate them.»

「Ren arises from filial piety and fraternal respect,
Trust arises from what is desirable—
Both are what is called *shēng* (生).

Ren has already arisen,
Yet there is a way to delight in it,
So that it does not abandon virtue.
Trust has already been established,
Yet there is a way to fulfill it,
And when it reaches reality, it is *shēng* (生),
And then to *chù* (畜) it—
That is what is meant.

To *shēng* (生) without possession,
Is the original *wú* (無).
Yet I am the one who brings forth *shēng* (生),
And yet I do not stir to claim it as my own—
This is the lofty aspiration of those who embody the Dao.

What was spoken of before as *shēng* (生) and *chù* (畜) to attain virtue,
Is now spoken of as *bù-yǒu* (不有)—
To possess yet appear as though not possessing,
To be real yet appear as though empty,
To not dwell upon what has been attained.

To act yet not rely upon it.
As Zhuangzi said: *"When one is in harmony yet does not claim self-possession, one does not rely upon it."*

To grow yet not dominate.
To rise above and yet silently guide,
To not reveal the means of one's governance.
If one truly entrusts without dominating,
Then who shall wield its reins?
This is called *Xuán Dé* (玄德).

What was spoken of before as the eight *shēng* (生) and eight *yí* (疑),
