chunks.original_text: 夫真心本来虚静，元无生灭，因真心动而为有，其名曰欲念也、智也、几也、识也。 缘心起欲，故随欲受生，既生之后，受纳好恶，攀缘不息，着五色殢五音，恃强梁居宠辱，迷妄为心，因执妄心，盖覆一心，不明一气之道。 若人舍妄去欲，便是一心，此心持之则为正，得之则为灵。 为万物之母，乃生死之根缘，其存欲盖覆真心，所以有生有死。 人能无欲，无欲则虚静，乃同无名之始，便能出离死生。 故老子云：常无欲以观其天地之始。 此乃出离生死之妙。 又云：常有欲以观其一气之道。 故为徼边也。 浅之意不可将心求心，为有欲； 不可将心灭心，为无欲。 此有无两者同摄为一缘，出言为教，而分有无之异名。 有无混同，谓之玄。 释氏谓之不二法门，又谓之中道。 玄之门以中为法，设喻如荃，然法从心起，既起於心，系着在中，则非虚静。 老子恐中道法缚，不能舍筌，故将又玄以释之，学人但不着有无，亦不居玄之中道，实际理地不受一尘，则心虚静，乃是无为，故不须推照。 以无所得故始是无欲，所以纤尘不立，故名清静； 都无作用，故名无为； 无修无证，故名自然； 都无一物，故名虚静； 自在无碍，故名逍遥； 一味平常，故名恬淡。 是故心无欲则离诸分别，离分别故无烦恼，心无欲则触事无我，无我则无争，故无咎。 心无欲则离诸善恶，离善恶故不拘因果。 心无欲则不着万物，故无生，无生故无死。 夫心常无欲者，乃众妙之门。 王志然：道可道至众妙之门。 道不可言，言而非也。 道不可名，名而非也。 谓之曰道，可得无言乎？ 可道之道，非常道之自然。 可名之名，非常名之自出。 常道常名，如环之无端，如四时之行焉，未始有极，未始有始，而乍起乍灭，代废代兴，非吾所谓真常者也。 常无欲以观其妙者，道之体。 常有欲以观其徼者，道之用。 而体用每寓之於恍惚。 有无精粗微妙之间，固不可以智知，不可以识识，以至视听迎随皆不可得。 云何得之，有学而知之者，未有不学而知之者也。 《易》曰：无思也，无为也，寂然不动，感而遂通天下之故。 杨子曰：耕道而得道，猎德而得德。 孟子曰：自得之。 自得之则左右逢其原，为学至於左右逢原之后，则何所往而不将。 而所谓得之者，得此者也。 於戏，道之妙足以尽万物之性，道之缴足以穷万物之理。 理性玄同，而所谓有无者，果可并观而双泯之。 或谓有有无有、无无有无者何也，此言有无相代之如此，无即真有，有即真无，有无相因，未始有异。 经曰此两者同出而异名，同谓之玄者，玄之为色幽而眇、赤而黑，阴阳混蒸，同乎一也。 《易》曰：一阴一阳之谓道，阴阳不测之谓神。 而阴与阳、有与无同乎一也。 同乎一矣，未妙乎一也； 妙乎一矣，未妙乎多也； 妙乎多矣，未妙乎我与物也。 故曰神也者，妙万物以为言者是也。 玄之又玄，则一之与多，我之与物，莫不皆妙者也。 此其所谓众妙之门。 故老子以此首篇，重玄之义，至至之理深矣远矣，不可以有加矣。 学者所宜尽心者焉。 程泰之：道可道至非常名。 无彼此今昔之间，以莫不然，则其能常者也。 能乎此不能乎彼，昔尝如是今不如是，则不得谓之常矣。 道之未为德也，混然茫然，函万有而一之，其中所蕴能刚能柔，能实能虚，能短能长，随所感以出，有万不同之应而非因所应，以附丽於一事一物也，则亦何所感而不能，何所施而不遂也？
chunks.translated_text:
The true heart is originally empty and tranquil, without birth or annihilation. When the true heart moves, it becomes manifest, and its names are desire-thought, wisdom, intuition, and cognition. Because the heart gives rise to desire, one follows desire and receives birth. After birth, one accepts and rejects pleasures and evils, clings endlessly to the five colors and five sounds, relies on strength and arrogance to dwell in honor or humiliation, and is deluded by false thoughts. Clinging to this false heart, one covers the true heart, failing to comprehend the Dao/Way of **one qi**.

If one abandons falsehood and desire, then one attains **oneness**. This heart, when held, is upright; when obtained, it is luminous. As the mother of ten thousand things, it is also the root of birth and death. Desire covers the true heart, hence there is birth and death.

If one can be without desire, then being without desire is empty and tranquil, returning to the formless beginning. Thus, one can transcend birth and death.

Hence, Laozi says: *"Constantly without desire, one observes the beginning of Heaven and Earth."* This is the subtle mystery of transcending birth and death. Again, he says: *"Constantly with desire, one observes the Dao/Way of one qi."* This is the perilous edge.

Shallow understanding cannot seek the heart with the heart—this is having desire. It cannot annihilate the heart with the heart—this is being without desire. These two—having and not having—are both encompassed as one principle. When spoken of as teaching, they are distinguished by the names "having" and "not having."

When having and not having merge, it is called **Xuan** (the Mysterious). The Buddhist School calls it the **"Non-dual Dharma Gate"** or the **"Middle Way."** The gate of **Xuan** takes the Middle as its law, like a net analogy. Yet since the law arises from the heart, and once it arises in the heart, it clings to the Middle—this is not empty and tranquil.

Laozi feared the Middle Way’s law would bind, preventing one from abandoning the net. Thus, he further explained with **Xuan**, teaching that the student should neither cling to having or not having nor dwell in the Middle Way of **Xuan**. In actual practice, the ground of reality is untouched by even a speck of dust, and the heart becomes empty and tranquil—this is **wuwei** (non-action), so no need for contemplation.

Because there is no attainment, this is being without desire. Hence, no dust arises, and it is called **clearing and tranquility**; there is no action, so it is called **wuwei**; there is no cultivation or realization, so it is called **natural**; there is nothing at all, so it is called **empty and tranquil**; it is unrestrained and free, so it is called **soaring**; it is uniformly ordinary, so it is called **serene and simple**.

Thus, when the heart is without desire, it departs from all distinctions. Departing from distinctions, there is no affliction. When the heart is without desire, encountering things there is no self. Without self, there is no conflict, hence no blame.

When the heart is without desire, it departs from all good and evil. Departing from good and evil, it is not bound by cause and effect. When the heart is without desire, it does not cling to all things, hence there is no birth, and without birth, there is no death.

The heart that is constantly without desire is the gate of all mysteries. King Zhi-ran says: *"The Dao that can be spoken of reaches the gate of all mysteries."* The Dao that cannot be spoken of—when spoken of, it is not so. The Dao that cannot be named—when named, it is not so. Calling it the Dao, can it not be spoken of? The Dao that can be spoken of is not the naturally constant Dao. The name that can be named is not the naturally arising name.

The constantly constant Dao and constantly constant name, like a ring without end, like the four seasons in their course—never beginning, never ending, yet arising and vanishing in turn, decaying and reviving, are not what I call the truly constant.

Constantly without desire, one observes its mystery—this is the substance of the Dao. Constantly with desire, one observes its perilous edge—this is the function of the Dao. Yet substance and function are always concealed in **huanghu** (obscurity and confusion). Between the subtle and coarse, the profound and the obscure, it cannot be known by wisdom, cannot be perceived by cognition, nor can it be attained through sight, hearing, or response.

How then does one attain it? There are those who learn and know it; there are none who know it without learning.

The *Yijing* says: *"Without thought, without action, silently unmoving, yet responding and thus communicating with all under Heaven."*

Yangzi says: *"Plow the Dao and obtain the Dao; hunt virtue and obtain virtue."*

Mencius says: *"Self-obtained."*

When self-obtained, one encounters the source on all sides. When study reaches the point of encountering the source on all sides, then where does one go without carrying it?

The so-called "obtaining" refers to obtaining this.

Ah! The mystery of the Dao suffices to exhaust the nature of all things. The subtlety of the Dao suffices to fathom the principles of all things. Nature and mystery are one in profundity, and the so-called having and not having—can they not be observed together and dualistically extinguished?

Some say: *"Having having, not having not having—what does this mean?"* This speaks of how having and not having alternate thus: not having is true having, having is true not having. Having and not having interdependently arise, never differing.

The Classic says: *"These two emerge together but have different names. They are called **Xuan** because its color is dark and faint, red and black, yin and yang mingling in steam—all unified."*

The *Yijing* says: *"One yin and one yang is called the Dao; the unfathomable yin and yang is called the Spirit."* Yin and yang, having and not having, are all unified.

Unified in one, yet not yet mysterious in one; mysterious in one, yet not yet mysterious in multiplicity; mysterious in multiplicity, yet not yet mysterious in self and things. Hence, it is said: *"Spirit is the mysterious speech of all things."*

**Xuan** beyond **Xuan**, then one and multiplicity, self and things—all are mysteriously unified. This is the so-called gate of all mysteries.

Thus, Laozi begins his first chapter with the profound meaning of **repeated Xuan**, reaching the most profound and distant principles, which cannot be exceeded. This is what students should devote their hearts to.

Program Tai-zhi says: *"The Dao that can be spoken of reaches the unnameable."* Without distinctions of self/other, past/future, always thus—this is its constancy. If it can do this but not that, if it was once thus but is not now, then it cannot be called constant.

Before the Dao becomes virtue, it is indistinct and boundless, encompassing all things in one. Within it, it can be firm or yielding, real or empty, short or long, responding to all stimuli with countless differences, yet not adhering to any particular thing or event—so what can it not respond to, what can it not accomplish?

---
*(Note: "重玄" [chóng xuán] is rendered as "repeated Xuan" to preserve the layered profundity, though "double mystery" or "ultimate mystery" could also serve. "恍惚" [huanghu] is "obscurity and confusion," a Daoist term for the ineffable state beyond duality.)*

chunks.original_text: 故无彼此今昔之异也。 知道者得其以而明言之，故遂指其无或不然者，而命以为常也。 及夫道出而为德，德着而为令，曰仁曰义，曰礼曰智，固皆道之所寓，而进传於事，事立之名，於是有所丽而有所局矣。 此之德既不可以通诸他德，而此之名又不可命为他名也。 故凡道之可道者，已不得谓之常道，则名之可名者，自应不得谓为常名也。 无名，天地之始。 天地也者，总司造化，开阖作复，在域中既极其大矣，而老氏又即天地之上，别立一目，而名之曰无。 且曰此之无者，可以名为天地之始也。 诸如此类，皆儒流疑以为虚夸无实者也。 然而《易》之两仪即天地也，而生两仪者实为太极。 太极也者，非天非地，而能该天地以立於总。 於是时也，无仪可放，无数可数，故老氏易其名而命以为无也。 凡老之谓无约其等级，则与太极正相应也。 极之言至也。 太极者，能极天地之所不至者也。 无之立名，则以未兆为义也，未有天地故也。 名虽异而理正同也。 其徒亦知后世必疑乎此矣，故列子自作之问而自为之答。 其言曰：有形生於无形，则天地安从生？ 然则谓无之能始天地也。 虽列子亦知夫人之必疑矣。 而自释其以则曰：天地未生之前，其於无中有象凡四也：太易、太初、太始、太素，是其序也。 是皆气形质具而未离者，第可目为浑沦而已也。 又动又变而后轻清者乃始为天，重浊者乃始为地，则夫太极也者，正其居虚而包清浊、以自立於无为无匹之地，夫非浑沦而无者耶？ 则老氏立名为无，而先乎天地者，正应易理也。 有名，万物之母。 后章曰天下之物生於有，有生於无。 当其无也，则直空然窅然而已。 而凡有由之以生，则谓无之能始天地者，尚其可明也。 及其既入於有，则与物何异，而反能生物也？ 曰：此盖无之已动而未成其为物者也。 揆其分际，正浑沦者，欲动而未及於出者也。 方欲名以为无，则既异於无矣。 方欲谓之为物，则又未着形质也。 故参研其衷，而名以为有也。 至号物之盈而名为万物者，则皆形象已凝，体质已具者也。 天地、日月、雨露、山川、草木、人禽、器物，皆其明有形质，不止仅可名有而已也。 老氏之形容此有，则凡三易其名，而实同一理也。 借数言之，则为一。 一者，谓其可以生万而未至为万也。 仿形而言，则为象； 对器而言，则为朴。 曰象曰朴，又皆可以为形为器，而其形器未及凝结者也。 是故上之已不为无，而下之未至为物，则此之谓有者，无古今彼此之问，而常为物生之祖也。 故后章又曰天下有始以为天下母也。 庄子物初之论，盖亦由此而立矣。 老子亦自知此理之难遽解也，又尝由总及散，而槩申之曰：有物混成，先天地生，寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不贻，可以为天下母。 吾不知其名，字之曰道，强名之曰大。 夫混成也者，浑沦不分之谓也。 即有无两者，方同而未出之初也。 先天地生，则天地固尝於此受始矣。 独立周行而槩为天下之母，则信乎无物，而不为其子也。 此三者极天下之事事物物所从生起，皆总是也。 凡老氏之书，於六经之所以言者，则略之而不竟； 至六经之所未究者，则必曲致其详也。 六经言治至於道则极矣，而老氏自道母天地之上更有数级，则无也、玄也、又玄也，皆其地也。
chunks.translated_text:
The absence of distinctions between self and other, past and future—this is its constancy. Those who grasp the Dao understand its boundless essence and thus speak clearly of its unchanging nature, calling it *constant*.

When the Dao manifests as virtue, virtue solidifies into principles—*ren* (benevolence), *yi* (righteousness), *li* (ritual), *zhi* (wisdom)—all dwelling within the Dao yet unfolding into specific deeds. Once named and defined, they adhere to particular forms and limits. Thus, this virtue cannot encompass other virtues, nor can its name serve as another’s. Therefore, what can be spoken of as the Dao is no longer the *constant Dao*, and what can be named is not the *constant Name*.

The unnamed is the origin of heaven and earth.
Heaven and earth—governing all creation, opening and closing, generating and transforming—are already vast within their domain. Yet Laozi further ascends beyond them, establishing another category and naming it *Wu* (the Non-being). He declares that this *Wu* is what can be called the origin of heaven and earth. Such claims, the Confucian scholars doubt as empty boasts.

Yet the *Yijing*’s two principles (*yin* and *yang*) are heaven and earth, but what gives rise to them is truly the *Taiji* (Supreme Ultimate). The *Taiji* is neither heaven nor earth, yet it encompasses both, standing supreme. At that stage, no forms exist to be cast aside, no numbers to be counted—thus Laozi renames it *Wu*. Though their names differ, their essence is the same. His disciples knew later ages would doubt this, so Zhuangzi framed a question and answered it himself:

*"If form arises from the formless, how did heaven and earth come to be?"*
Thus, it is said that *Wu* gives rise to heaven and earth.
Even Zhuangzi knew people would doubt, so he clarified: Before heaven and earth formed, within the formless there were four stages: *Taiyi* (Great Unity), *Taichu* (Great Commencement), *Taishi* (Great Beginning), *Taosu* (Great Primordial)—this is their order. Though their *qi*, form, and substance were present yet undivided, they could only be called *hunlun* (indistinct chaos).

Only when movement and transformation occurred did the light and clear rise as heaven, the heavy and turbid settle as earth. Thus, the *Taiji* is precisely that which dwells in emptiness, embracing both purity and turbidity, establishing itself in an unmatched state of non-action. Is this not the indistinct yet formless?

Laozi names it *Wu*, preceding heaven and earth—this aligns with the *Yijing*’s logic.

The named is the mother of all things.
A later passage states: *"All things under heaven arise from the having; having arises from the non-being."* When it is *Wu*, it is simply vast and boundless. Yet all things emerge from it, so calling *Wu* the origin of heaven and earth is still plausible. But once it enters *You* (the having), how does it differ from other things, yet still generate them?

It is the *Wu* that has stirred yet not yet solidified into things. Examining its boundaries, it is the *hunlun*—about to move but not yet manifest. On the verge of being named *Wu*, it already differs from *Wu*; on the verge of being called *wu* (thing), it lacks defined form. Thus, studying its core, it is named *You*.

When it fully takes shape and is called *wanwu* (ten thousand things), they are all fixed in form and substance: heaven and earth, sun and moon, rain and dew, mountains and rivers, grasses and trees, humans and beasts, tools and vessels—all clearly defined, not merely *You*.

Laozi describes this *You* in three shifting names, yet they share one essence. Numerically, it is *One*—capable of generating all yet not yet all. Figuratively, it is *Xiang* (image); practically, it is *Pu* (uncarved block). *Xiang* and *Pu* can both become form and vessel, yet their form and vessel remain uncoagulated. Thus, above it is not yet *Wu*, below it is not yet *wu*—this *You* transcends past and future, self and other, as the eternal progenitor of all things. Hence, a later passage declares: *"All things under heaven have a beginning, which is the mother of all things under heaven."* Zhuangzi’s theory of origins stems from this.

Laozi himself knew this truth would be hard to grasp at once, so he further explained, moving from the whole to the particular: *"There is a thing, indistinctly formed, existing before heaven and earth. Silent and boundless, it stands alone yet never changes, revolves eternally yet leaves no trace—it can be the mother of all things under heaven. I do not know its name; I call it the Dao, forcefully name it the Great."*

*Mixing and forming*—this is the undivided state. It is the indistinct unity of *Wu* and *You* before differentiation. Existing before heaven and earth, it is where they truly originate. Standing alone, revolving eternally, it is the mother of all things under heaven—truly without a child, yet the source of all.

These three aspects encompass the origin of all things and phenomena under heaven. Laozi’s text omits what the *Six Classics* already elaborate, yet delves deeply into what they leave unexplored. The *Six Classics* exhaust the discussion of governance when reaching the Dao, but Laozi ascends beyond the Dao’s mother—heaven and earth—to higher realms: *Wu*, *Xuan*, and *repeated Xuan*—these are its domains.

chunks.original_text: 而分际在此三者已上，则皆不可得而道，亦不可得而名者也。 夫既无名可称，而欲从此地立言，以启未悟，则将何所寄语也哉？ 於是超乎可道可名者，而创立有无二目，以寓其指也。 此其立教之总也。 此二者既立名义，而其话言所及，人人悉可循想矣。 言及乎无，则知其所指必在天地之先也。 言及乎有，则又知其所指必在万物之表也。 故其书之纵横曲折，条目不胜其多，而皆不出乎有无二义也。 然而有也无也，六经实已言之，而其与老语不同者，六经未尝单言有无也。 《易》之无思无为、无方无体之类，固尝言无矣，而思为方体仅相缀属，未尝捐弃所附，而单立一无也。 老氏之创此模也，正从造化未有形着之时言之，则并与夫思为方体者皆未着兆朕也。 此其意指，殆将自居於无，而处六经於既已为物之地也。 要求其归则诚高矣远矣，疑世无其事而寓其言矣。 然其分际甚明，前后具有义例，悉可稽覆。 而儒流语脉亦相灌注，非如世之训释其书者，不分道器，取甚浅之理驾而入之高妙，其实荒忽无见也。 则其尊而抗之，乃所以汨而乱之也。 且彼何不浅而验之以事也，张良之恬澹、曹参之清静、文帝之元默，是老教之不行乎周而肇效乎汉者也。 其於用老，则万世之称首矣。 然此一君二臣者，岂其於世事而尝少少去心也哉？ 特不肯以人欲自累，故其贵无之力，虽未尽道，亦足以集虚镇扰，而不入於名事也矣。 至於西晋之世，遗弃礼乐刑政，专为无有，而纪纲法度荡然不存，晋室因以大乱，故读老者，必知夫无为之中有无不为者在焉，而后可以知汉晋之治同所出而异所效也。 若夫妄言无行之徒，以道流自名，而依并虚无以文荒诞，伪为飞升祸福之说，则皆老语之所无也。 推原其所始，则神仙之说起於战国，祷祠报应盛於两汉，而八十一章未始有此也。 世之学老者，其当以八十一章本语为是乎，抑以末世增饰诞语为是也？ 凡君若臣，其常以张良曹参文帝为准乎，抑以西晋之放荡与夫末流之怪传为可准也？ 此其当鉴当戒，昭着而易见者也。 常无欲至观其徼。
chunks.translated_text:
Yet once the distinctions lie beyond these three aspects, they become beyond what can be spoken of as the Dao or named at all.

Since there is no name to invoke, yet one must speak from this realm to awaken the unenlightened—where then shall words be anchored?

Thus, transcending what can be spoken of or named, he establishes the dual categories of *You* and *Wu*, to convey his intent.

This is the overarching principle of his teaching.

Once these two categories are named, the scope of his discourse becomes accessible to all, allowing each to follow and infer its meaning.

When speaking of *Wu*, one knows his intent must lie before heaven and earth.
When speaking of *You*, one knows his intent must lie beyond all things.

Thus, though his text meanders in intricate ways, its myriad passages never stray from the dual principles of *You* and *Wu*.

Yet *You* and *Wu* were already discussed in the *Six Classics*, differing only in that the *Six Classics* never spoke of them in isolation.

The *Yijing*’s references to "without thought, without action, without form, without substance" indeed speak of *Wu*, yet thought, action, form, and substance are merely adjuncts—never wholly abandoned to stand alone as *Wu*.

Laozi’s innovation here lies in addressing the moment before creation had any manifestation, where even thought, action, form, and substance had not yet taken shape.

His intent, it seems, is to position himself within *Wu*, placing the *Six Classics* in the realm of already-formed things.

His aspirations are indeed lofty and distant, yet his words imply what may not exist.

Yet his distinctions are clear, his principles consistent throughout, and all may be examined and verified.

Confucian scholars also draw from this lineage, though many misinterpret his text by conflating *Dao* and *qi*, forcing shallow reasoning into profound mysteries—thus distorting and confusing it.

Why not test his teachings with concrete examples? Zhang Liang’s tranquility, Cao Parameter’s serenity, and Emperor Wen’s silent governance—these are instances where Laozi’s teachings, though not fully implemented in the Zhou, bore fruit in the Han.

In applying Laozi’s principles, they stand as the foremost models across the ages.

Yet did these rulers ever truly withdraw from worldly affairs? They simply refused to burden themselves with personal desires, so their reverence for *Wu*’s power—though not fully realizing the Dao—sufficed to cultivate emptiness and still chaos, never entangling themselves in worldly matters.

By the time of the Western Jin, however, rituals, music, laws, and governance were abandoned in favor of absolute *Wu*, leaving no structure or order, and the Jin dynasty collapsed in chaos. Thus, those who study Laozi must recognize that within *wuwei* lies *wu buwei*—what is not done—and only then can they understand how Han and Jin governance, though rooted in the same source, produced such divergent outcomes.

As for those who falsely claim *wuwei* as their practice, naming themselves Daoists while fabricating absurd tales of transcendence, fortune, and misfortune, these are not Laozi’s words.

Tracing their origins, tales of immortality arose in the Warring States, while prayers for retribution and responses flourished in the Han—yet none of this appears in the *Eighty-One Chapters*.

Should students of Laozi adhere to the original eighty-one chapters, or to the later embellishments of fantastical speech?

Should rulers and ministers emulate Zhang Liang, Cao Parameter, and Emperor Wen, or the reckless excesses of the Jin and the bizarre later traditions?

These are clear lessons—easy to discern, yet essential to heed.

Ever without desire, one may observe its boundaries.

These three aspects encompass the origin of all things and phenomena under heaven. Laozi’s text omits what the *Six Classics* already elaborate, yet delves deeply into what they leave unexplored. The *Six Classics* exhaust the discussion of governance when reaching the Dao, but Laozi ascends beyond the Dao’s mother—heaven and earth—to higher realms: *Wu*, *Xuan*, and *repeated Xuan*—these are its domains.

chunks.original_text: 无之能生有，而不自为有者，乃能常其无也。 有之能生物，而不自为物者，乃能常其有也。 何者？ 未着形体，中无间断，故可常也。 若夫因造化而得形质，出大道而为德仁义礼，则皆物也。 此之为物，常凝不散，则可名。 以有散之，则无矣。 故自有已为物之后，则凡其尝着形体者，则皆不能自主其有也。 万物之并作而芸芸也，其归根而枯秃者，可立待也。 此其已有者，既不可留，则复命，而静者一旦土膏春溢，凡其芸芸而出，亦不能自遏，而藏处於无也。 凡道学之失得，与夫辐毂户牖之具否，皆一理也。 则合世间之有无，皆不足以循求大道之表里也。 若夫常无也者，道之蕴而未出者也。 常有也者，道之已动而向乎出者也。 是皆物物而不物於物，故能总生化而不入於生化也。 以其居总而体该，故大道之本末可以即是而求也。 其曰妙者，居造化之奥，而万有之所自出也。 是常无所总之地也。 其曰徼者，边际也，如边境处中国之四隅也，盖无之已出为有，而有又将出而为物者也。 故不得为奥而遂常为际也。 二义立而道之表里有稽矣。 得常无而即之，则可以究万有所出而见其里； 得常有而即之，则又可以穷万物之所生而见其表。 故老子所以贵夫常无常有者，道之表里於此乎可想也。 庄子曰：睹有者，昔之君子； 睹无者，天地之友。 即是理也。 《易》曰：形而上者谓之道，形而下者谓之器。 道即器也，器即道也。 特所形有上下，而非判然二物也。 此之妙徼，即《易》之上下矣。 其舍上下而名妙徼者，正欲自成一家，而其指归未尝少有不同也。 天下之物，安有下无载承而能空立其上者耶，亦安有里而无其表者也？ 此道器有无之相须，而明白易晓者也。 故借之以喻，使人知其谈妙之中，未尝遗徼也。 此两者同出而异名。 常有於常无为徼，而常无於常有为妙。 当其已出也，则有之与无，固可分矣。 而其未出则混合无间也，故曰此两者同也。 同即一也，一即未为一，三可以生万，而未至为万者也。 《易》暨五经《论》、《孟》皆尝言一，而未尝言其何以为一也。 老氏之师弟子，则於此特详矣。 曰混成，曰浑沦，曰浑沌，皆言其未分为二也。 从其未出而命之以同，从其无与匹对而命之以独，自其无或不然者而命以为常，则皆主其总而明其以也。 及其无已出有而未至为物，则又立为名称，以明示人曰一、曰朴、曰象，又皆取其函万为一者，随所寓而名之故也。 故老氏言道，於此特为详委，是以枝叶虽甚戾儒，而儒者不能不资其妙也。 故夫知道者尚能即异以资其同； 而浅於道者，至谓孔者不为一家，则是过其门，而不知其中有堂有室者也。 同谓之玄。 五色以黑为玄，天之色以无所政极为玄，太玄指罔之直，冬物皆归根复命，而不见畦畛者，名之以玄。 则玄云者，窈然深远之谓也。 列子之谓易无形终，正训此也。 同谓之玄，则有与无合，浑沦未相判别，是可谓窈然深远也矣。 若其朕兆微见，则无者真隐於无，有者实形於有。 分际既萌，不得复谓之玄矣。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 万有之冥於无，则既极矣。 今也进而上之，更有玄焉，无进而玄，则益深矣。 而玄之上更有又玄焉，其理何也？ 曰：列庄固尝有所发明矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The capacity to generate the **Having** from the **Non-Having**, yet not claiming itself as the **Having**, is how one may perpetually abide in the **Non-Having**.

The capacity to generate **Things** from the **Having**, yet not claiming itself as **Things**, is how one may perpetually abide in the **Having**.

How so? Before form and substance take root, within there is no separation or interruption, hence it may be perpetuated. But when one derives form and substance from **Creation-Transformation** (造化), and emerges from the **Dao/Way** to manifest as **virtue/power** (德), **benevolence**, **righteousness**, **propriety**, and **ritual**, these are all **Things**.

When these **Things** are perpetually congealed without dispersion, they may be named. If the **Having** is dispersed, then there is **Non-Having**. Thus, once the **Having** has become **Things**, all that has ever taken form cannot master its own **Having**.

When myriad **Things** arise together in their **keynote** (芸芸) state, and those that return to their root and wither become **bare** (枯秃), they may be awaited. For those who already possess the **Having**, since it cannot be retained, they revert to **command** (复命), and when the **stillness** (静) of the **Non-Having** once more overflows like spring’s nourishment, all that emerges in **keynote** cannot restrain itself, and thus retreats into the **Non-Having**.

The **Dao/Way’s** attainment or loss, along with the **spokes-and-hub** (辐毂) and **door-and-window** (户牖) of its implements—all are governed by a single principle. Thus, the **Having** and **Non-Having** of the world are insufficient to trace the **outer and inner** (表里) of the **Great Dao/Way**.

Those who perpetually abide in **Non-Having** are the **Dao/Way’s** essence yet to emerge. Those who perpetually abide in the **Having** are the **Dao/Way’s** movement already tending toward emergence.

These are all **Things** yet not ensnared by **Things**, hence they may encompass all **Creation-Transformation** without being consumed by it. With their dwelling in totality and their substance embracing all, the beginning and end of the **Great Dao/Way** may be sought within them.

That which is called **Mysterious** (妙) dwells in the depths of **Creation-Transformation**, where all **Having** originates. This is the **Non-Having** yet to be encompassed by totality.

That which is called **Boundary** (徼) is the **edge**, like the four corners of a frontier marking the boundaries of a central kingdom. It is the **Non-Having** that has emerged as **Having**, yet has not yet fully become **Things**. Hence it cannot be called **Mysterious** and is perpetually the **Boundary**.

With these two distinctions established, the **outer and inner** (表里) of the **Dao/Way** may be measured. To attain **Non-Having** and dwell within it is to explore the origin of all **Having** and perceive its **inner**; to attain the **Having** and dwell within it is to exhaust the production of all **Things** and perceive their **outer**.

Thus, Laozi esteems the perpetuation of **Non-Having** and **Having**, for within them the **outer and inner** of the **Dao/Way** may be imagined.

Zhuangzi said: *"Those who perceive the **Having** are the virtuous gentlemen of old; those who perceive the **Non-Having** are the friends of Heaven and Earth."* This aligns with the principle.

The *Book of Changes* (《易》) states: *"That which is above form is called the **Dao/Way**; that which is below form is called the **instrument** (器)."* The **Dao/Way** is the **instrument**, and the **instrument** is the **Dao/Way**. It is merely that their forms are above or below, not that they are two distinct entities.

This **Mysterious** and **Boundary** are the *Book of Changes*’s **above** and **below**. Those who abandon the **above** and **below** yet name it **Mysterious** and **Boundary** seek only to establish their own school, though their ultimate intent is not fundamentally different.

In the world, how could there be anything below that lacks support and yet stands empty above? Or anything **inner** without its **outer**?

This is the mutual reliance of **Dao/Way** and **instrument**, **Having** and **Non-Having**, clearly evident and easily understood. Hence, they are borrowed to illustrate that within the discourse on **Mysterious**, **Boundary** is never neglected.

These two are of the same origin yet bear different names. The **Having** is **Boundary** to the **Non-Having**, while the **Non-Having** is **Mysterious** to the **Having**. When they have already emerged, the **Having** and **Non-Having** may indeed be divided. But before emergence, they are indistinguishably merged, hence it is said they are the same.

The same is **One**. **One** is not yet **One**, for from it the **Three** may generate the **Myriad**, yet it has not yet reached the **Myriad**.

The *Book of Changes* and the Five Classics, as well as the *Discourses* (《论》) and *Mencius* (《孟》), have all spoken of **One**, yet none have explained how it is **One**.

Laozi’s disciples, however, have elaborately expounded upon this. They speak of **"indistinct unity"** (混成), **"indistinctly merged"** (浑沦), and **"indistinct chaos"** (浑沌)—all describing its undivided state.

From its emergence before division, it is named **"same"** (同); from its **Non-Having** and **matching"** (匹) not yet being so, it is named **"alone"** (独); and from its **Non-Having** not being otherwise, it is named **"perpetual"** (常). All these terms emphasize its totality and clarify its essence.

When the **Non-Having** has emerged as **Having** yet not fully become **Things**, it is again given distinctions—named **"One"** (一), **"Uncarved"** (朴), or **"Form"** (象)—all taken from its capacity to encompass the **Myriad** in unity, for the names arise from what it contains.

Thus, Laozi’s discourse on the **Dao/Way** is particularly detailed here. Though its branches and leaves may greatly diverge from Confucian teachings, even Confucians cannot help but draw upon its **Mysterious** insights.

Hence, the profound in **Dao/Way** can still align the disparate to serve the unified; while the shallow in **Dao/Way**, to the point of declaring that Confucius does not belong to a single school, are like those who pass through a doorway yet fail to recognize the halls and chambers within.

The unified is called **Dark** (玄). Five colors find **black** as their **Dark**, Heaven’s color is **Dark** in its boundless expanse, the **Great Dark** (太玄) of the **Vague** (罔) is direct, and in winter, all **Things** return to their root, **revert to command** (复命), without visible boundaries—this is named **Dark**.

Thus, **Dark** refers to the **profound and distant**. The *Liezi*’s statement that *"the **Dao/Way** is formless and ends in the **Dark**"* is precisely this teaching.

The unified is called **Dark**, for **Having** and **Non-Having** merge, indistinctly merged without separation, hence it may be called **profound and distant**.

If their traces are faintly discernible, then the **Non-Having** is truly hidden within the **Non-Having**, while the **Having** is truly formed within the **Having**. Once distinctions begin to emerge, it cannot again be called **Dark**.

The **Dark** beyond **Dark**, is the gateway to myriad **Mysterious** insights. When all **Having** is indistinctly merged into **Non-Having**, it has reached its extreme.

Now, advancing further upward, there is yet another **Dark**. The **Non-Having** advancing into **Dark** becomes ever more profound. And beyond the **Dark**, there is yet another **Dark**, its principle being what?

Zhuangzi and Liezi have indeed illuminated this.

chunks.original_text: 其在列子，则曰有太易者、有太初者、有太始者、有太素者，皆气形质之所资始也。 凡四降其序，而始及夫轻清之天、重浊之地，则循其序而观之，有之进也为无，无之又进也为玄，玄之又进而加玄也，其次第可想也。 庄子曰有有也者有无也者，是老氏之常无常有也。 又曰有未始有夫有无也者，是老氏之玄也。 又曰有未始有夫未始有无也者，是玄之又玄者也。 皆心见其理而世无其名，出意想而强言之也。 老之言曰寂寥窈冥，则实形容夫玄及又玄之状者也，而庄子益复广之以为昏默淇津也。 夫惟常无，既可以总会万有之妙，则玄之又玄固其当为众妙之所出也。 后章之众甫也，庄子之百昌也，众美也，又皆仿此之妙，而与之为明也。 论自有书契以来，圣智仁义之机，发於《易》而孚乎五三《六经》之治。 自始及今，天下赖以为命，如五谷布帛，得之则生，不得则死，次无可以易而他之之理。 老氏则设一教，必欲绝弃圣智仁义，而复诸结绳之始。 世之以六经为业者，相与协合排摈，至指其书以为异教，然而五千言者常与六经并行，终不可废，是独何也？ 六经明礼法，故其所书皆器也。 而於道则略，老氏穷道未故常#1，遗器不言。 二者详略虽异，而器实载道，道实生器，不可折而二之也。 世之求道者，必皆自下学以求上达，而上达六经不肯究言也。 老氏则尝罄底蕴而畅达之矣。 故凡学道而微有所见，其在六经无语可为质验，则皆并老语以德发其理。 故其立教，若甚相悖而道常并行，盖有以也。 呜呼，此理微矣，难猝以一语会而通之也。 大昌今取古今日用最浅而最切者明之，则人人可解矣。 农者天下大本，而其业至粗也。 六经之教则与之言耕耘收敛之候，未耜鏄铚之具，其可谓形而愈下者矣。 然而四时之化於此器乎托体焉，百谷之种於此器乎成实焉，则虽天地元气其妙入於不可名者，亦皆托此以着其用，岂容以其具在器而云道不在是也。 若夫老氏之於道也，穷极要妙，则有之矣。 东作西成之政，老氏固已绝口不道矣。 及其着诸书也，虽万物作复芸芸归根者，不胜其变也，种获养伐悉有其具，而老氏曾无一语以及也。 至於谈微阐妙，则天地生化之枢，道德蕴藏之始，尚犹指以为浅，直欲究天地之何以得为天地，玄无之何以能为玄无，乃为称惬其意，则此一教似不与六经相丽矣。 然大昌尝由其言以探其所不言，由其不肯明言以求其所不容不言，则德仁义礼未尝不存，赋税兵刑鸡犬舟车未尝不具，则其言虽尝贵无，而未尝遗有也。 此之首章极於玄之又玄，则又超众妙而司其出矣。 而有之观徼也，亟与妙且无者对出而偶立，则是有也，器也，何尝相二也。 圣智仁义亦何尝可弃也。 用此而读老语，则至无之中，实常该有造妙之初必由践迹，不可诬也。 黄茂材曰：道可道至非常名。 常之为言，长也，久也。 道与天地相终始，其为长久，岂人所能言哉？ 若使可得而道，可得而名，则是世人之见，何足以为常。 经曰：吾不知其名，字之曰道。 道惟有一而已，何以与名对？ 老子之意，欲详以长久之道示人者耶？ 无名至万物之母。 天地之始，其果无乎？ 若其果无，孰从而始。 无名非名，无非无也，不可得而名，故尔。

「In Liezi’s discourse, there are **Too-Easy** (*Tà Yì*), **Too-Primordial** (*Tà Chū*), **Too-Beginning** (*Tà Shǐ*), and **Too-Substantial** (*Tà Sù*), all of which are the **Qi** (*Qi*) and form’s foundation for the myriad.

When descending through these four stages in sequence, and reaching the **Light and Pure** Heaven (*Qīng Qīng zhī Tiān*) and the **Heavy and Impure** Earth (*Zhòng Zhuó zhī Dì*), one may observe their order: **Having** advances to **Non-Having**, **Non-Having** further advances to **Dark**, and **Dark** advances yet again to **Darkness**—their successive ranks are clearly discernible.

Liezi says: *“There is **Having**, and there is **Non-Having**,”*—this aligns with Laozi’s **constant Non-constant Having** (*Cháng Wúcháng Yǒu*).

Again, *“There is **Having** before **Having** and **Non-Having**,”*—this is Laozi’s **Dark**.

Again, *“There is **Having** before **Having** and **Non-Having**, before **Having** and **Non-Having**,”*—this is the **Dark** beyond **Dark**.

All are insights perceived by the mind yet unnamed by the world, expressed through thought and forced into speech.

Laozi’s words—**“stillness, emptiness, profound and distant”** (*Jìliáo Yǎomiǎo*)—truly describe the state of **Dark** and **Dark** beyond **Dark**, while Zhuangzi further expands them as **“dim and silent, murky and obscure”** (*Hūn Mò Qí Jīn*).

Only **constant Non-Having** (*Cháng Wú*), which can encompass the **Mysterious** essence of all **Having**, is the true source from which the **Dark** beyond **Dark** emerges.

In later chapters, the **multitude of myriad** (*Zhòng Fǔ*) and **Zhuangzi’s hundred transformations** (*Bǎi Chāng*), along with the myriad beauties, all follow this same **Mysterious** principle, yet are clarified in their own terms.

Since the advent of written records, the **Dao/Way** of sages’ wisdom, virtue, and righteousness has been revealed in the *Yì* and confirmed by the governance of the **Five Three** (*Wǔ Sān*)—the **Six Classics**. From ancient times to the present, the world relies on them for sustenance, like the **Five Grains** and **Cloth of Raw Silk** (*Bùmáo*), without which life cannot thrive, and with which it flourishes. None can replace them, nor is there another principle as profound.

Yet Laozi establishes a teaching that seeks to utterly abandon sages’ wisdom, virtue, and righteousness, and revert to the **beginning of knotted cords** (*Jiégǒu*).

Those who take the **Six Classics** as their profession collectively uphold and reject this teaching, even labeling his work as a **heretical doctrine**. Yet the **Ten Thousand Words** (*Wàn Yī Yán*) persist alongside the **Six Classics**, never truly discarded—why is this?

The **Six Classics** elucidate **rites and laws**, so their texts are all about **instruments** (*Qì*). Yet regarding the **Dao/Way**, they offer only a brief outline.

Laozi exhausts the **Dao/Way** in its **constant Non-Having** (*Cháng Wú*), yet omits mention of **instruments** (*Qì*).

Though their focus differs—one detailed, the other sparse—**instruments** (*Qì*) bear the **Dao/Way**, and the **Dao/Way** generates **instruments** (*Qì*). They cannot be separated into two distinct paths.

Seeking the **Dao/Way**, one must ascend from lower learning to higher attainment, yet the **Six Classics** do not fully explore its depths.

Laozi, however, has fully expounded its profound essence.

Thus, those who study the **Dao/Way** and glimpse its truth find no language in the **Six Classics** to verify it, and so they align with Laozi’s words to elucidate its **virtue/power** (*Dé*).

Hence, though his teaching appears contradictory to theirs, the **Dao/Way** remains concurrent—there is good reason for this.

Ah! This principle is subtle indeed, too profound to be grasped in a single utterance.

Now, let me take the most accessible yet closest examples from ancient times to clarify it, so all may understand.

**Agriculture** is the foundation of civilization, yet its practice is the most coarse.

The teachings of the **Six Classics** speak of the timing for plowing, sowing, harvesting, and storing—of the tools before the **plow** (*Sì*), **hoe** (*Chuán*), **weeder** (*Zhì*), and **reaper** (*Zhì*). These are the most **concrete** (*Xíng*) and **lowly** (*Yuè*) of all **instruments** (*Qì*).

Yet the transformations of the four seasons depend on these **instruments** for their manifestation, and the seeds of a hundred grains achieve their fullness through them.

Even if the **original Qi** of Heaven and Earth is beyond naming, it still relies on these **instruments** to manifest its functions—how can one claim the **Dao/Way** is absent simply because its tools are present?

As for Laozi’s **Dao/Way**, he exhausts its utmost **Mysterious** essence.

He rejects the governance of **eastern labor and western harvest** (*Dōng Zuò Xī Chéng*), yet even in his texts, though he speaks of all things arising and returning to their roots—too numerous to enumerate—he still provides tools for **planting** (*Zhòng*), **harvesting** (*Shuō*), **nurturing** (*Yǎng*), and **pruning** (*Fá*).

Yet Laozi never utters a word on these matters.

When discussing the **subtle** and **Mysterious**, he still considers the **hinge of Heaven and Earth’s transformations** (*Tiān Dì Shēnghuà zhī Shuā*) and the **beginning of virtue and Dao** (*Dé Dào Yǔncáng zhī Shǐ*) as shallow, directly probing the origins of Heaven and Earth—**“how did Heaven and Earth come to be Heaven and Earth?”**—and the **Dark Non-Having**—**“how could the **Dark Non-Having** be **Dark Non-Having**?”**—only to name them in accordance with his intent.

Thus, his teaching seems entirely distinct from the **Six Classics**.

Yet, by examining his spoken words to infer what he does not say, and by seeking what he cannot help but imply despite his reluctance to speak openly, one finds that **virtue** (*Dé*), **righteousness** (*Rén*), and **rites** (*Yì*) are never truly absent, nor are **taxes** (*Shuì*), **punishments** (*Xíng*), **military force** (*Bīng*), **criminal law** (*Xíng*), and the **practical tools of daily life**—**chickens, dogs, boats, and carts** (*Jī Quǎn Zhōuchē*).

Though his words often exalt **Non-Having**, they never truly abandon **Having**.

In the first chapter, he reaches the extreme of **Dark** beyond **Dark**, yet he transcends the myriad **Mysterious** and governs their emergence.

When observing **Having**, it frequently appears in contrast with the **Mysterious** and **Non-Having**, standing parallel yet distinct—this **Having** and these **instruments** (*Qì*) are never truly separate.

Sages’ wisdom, virtue, and righteousness are never truly discarded.

Thus, when reading Laozi’s words, within the utmost **Non-Having**, one finds the **virtue/power** (*Dé*) of all **Having** and **Mysterious**—it must originate from **tracing** (*Jiànjì*).

Huang Maocai says: *“The **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of is not the **constant Non-Having**.”*

**Constant** (*Cháng*) here means **enduring** and **permanent**.

The **Dao/Way** begins and ends with Heaven and Earth—how could it be anything but enduring and permanent? Who could truly speak of it?

If the **Dao/Way** could be spoken of and named, then the world’s understanding would suffice as **constant**.

The Classics say: *“I do not know its name, so I call it **Dao/Way**.”*

The **Dao/Way** is singular and absolute—why then does it oppose **name** (*Míng*)?

Laozi’s intent is to reveal the **enduring and permanent** **Dao/Way** to people, is it not?

**Non-Having** is the **mother of myriad things**.

At the **beginning of Heaven and Earth**, was there truly **Non-Having**?

If there was indeed **Non-Having**, who then gave rise to it?

**Non-Having** is **Non-Naming**—**Non-Naming** is **Non-Having**—it cannot be named, so it is called thus.»

chunks.original_text: 及其既有，其果有乎，示强为之名尔。 经曰：惚兮恍其中有象，恍兮惚其中有物。 又曰有物混成。 皆强名也。 母者，谓其能生物也。 有天地然后有万物，故先天地后及万物，其言次序如是。 常无欲至同谓之玄。 经言不欲、寡欲、可欲多矣，今若曰无欲有欲，则与经之言相符。 然无欲谓之常可也，有欲谓之常可乎？ 曰：自有物以来，九窍者胎生，八窍者卵生，皆因为欲，生复生生，宁有尽时，故有欲亦谓之常。 人知无之出於道，而不知有之亦出於道。 夫岂知有无同出於玄者哉？ 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 南伯子葵谓女偊曰：子独恶乎闻之？ 曰：闻诸副墨之子，副墨之子闻之洛诵之孙，洛诵之孙闻之瞻明，瞻明闻之聂许，聂许闻之需役，需役闻之於诅，於电闻之玄冥，玄冥闻之参寥，参寥闻之疑始。 夫道愈微而愈有，愈穷而不可尽。 女偶闻而至疑始，玄之又玄，可见於此。 所以为众妙之门也欤。 道德真经集义卷之二竟 ＃1 老氏穷道未故常：『未』疑当作『末』。 道德真经集义卷之三 凝远大师常德路玄妙观

「When it has already come into existence, does it truly have something? It is only named thus to emphasize its power.

The Classics say: *“Vague and indistinct, yet within it there is form; indistinct and vague, yet within it there are things.”*
And again: *“Things are formed in a chaotic unity.”*
All these are forced names.

The term **"Non-Having"** (母) refers to its capacity to generate things.
Only after Heaven and Earth came into being did myriad things arise—thus, the sequence is first Heaven and Earth, then myriad things. His words follow this order.

**"Non-Having"** (无) and **"Non-Wanting"** (无欲) are said to reach the same state, called **"Mysterious"** (玄).
The Classics speak of **"Not Wanting"** (不欲), **"Few Wants"** (寡欲), and **"Desires Abundant"** (可欲多矣). Now, if one says **"Non-Wanting"** (无欲) and **"Having Wants"** (有欲), then it aligns with the Classics’ words.

Yet, **"Non-Wanting"** (无欲) may be called **"constant"** (常), but can **"Having Wants"** (有欲) also be called **"constant"** (常)?
One replies: Since things came into existence, those with **nine orifices** (*jiǔqiào*) are born from the womb, and those with **eight orifices** (*bāqiào*) are born from eggs—all due to desire. Desire begets life, which begets more life, and this cycle has no end. Thus, even **"Having Wants"** (有欲) may be called **"constant"** (常).

People know that **"Non-Having"** (无) arises from the **Dao/Way** (*Dào*), but they do not know that **"Having"** (有) also arises from the **Dao/Way** (*Dào*).
How could they know that both **"Having"** and **"Non-Having"** emerge from the **"Mysterious"** (玄)?

The **"Mysterious"** (玄) deepens into **"Mysterious Again"** (玄之又玄), the gateway to all wonders.

**Nánbó Zǐ Kuài** said to **Rǔ Jiǎo**:
“Where did you hear this from?”
She replied: *“I heard it from **Fù Mò’s son**, **Fù Mò’s son** heard it from **Luò Sòng’s grandson**, **Luò Sòng’s grandson** heard it from **Zhān Míng**, **Zhān Míng** heard it from **Niè Xǔ**, **Niè Xǔ** heard it from **Xū Yì**, **Xū Yì** heard it from **Yú Diàn**, **Yú Diàn** heard it from **Xuán Míng**, and **Xuán Míng** heard it from **Cān Liáo**, **Cān Liáo** heard it from **Yí Shǐ**.”

The **Dao/Way** grows ever more subtle yet ever more present; it becomes ever more refined yet cannot be exhausted.
Even **Rǔ Jiǎo** heard it and reached **Yí Shǐ**—**"Mysterious Again"** (玄之又玄)—this is evident in her words.
Thus, it is the gateway to all wonders.

chunks.original_text: 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易束校正 道可道章 詹秋圃曰：道可道至之门。 道可得而名言其道，此非常久自然之道。 名可得而定名，此非常久可贵之名。 道不可以抑扬立论，於是上言无能名者，天地混沌之始，有可名者，万物生育之母。 故常无欲而动心於内，自足以观其要妙； 常有欲而动情於外，但足以观其趣徼。 此两者同出於道，而微显异名，故同谓之玄。 玄之又玄而无不通，是可以造其众妙之门户矣。 道妙难名，故此章内则以有名而为生物之母，以常有欲而为观妙之徼，以同出谓玄，玄之又玄而为造妙之门。 夫曰母曰徼曰门，岂非由精达粗，由体道而达妙用也欤。 张冲应曰：道可道至之门。 大道无形，生育天地。 大道无名，长养万物。 人不能体此自然之道。 而尚经术政教之道，以希荣显利达之名。 所谓道者，世所可得而道，非长久不可磨灭之道也。 所谓名者，世所可得而名，非远久不可形容之名也。 体其不可名之道，则为无名； 体其可名之道，则为有名。 无名则其道大，犹天覆地载，混然其初而人不知其覆载之原。 有名则道小，犹万物萌拆，善善恶恶而各有所名。 其善恶之根，是谓无名，天地之始，有名，万物之母也。 人生天地间，以血肉为躯，心统五官，运乎此体，体道之际，有能即我无欲而静之中，以观不可道、不可名之妙，即有人欲而动之外，以观可道可名之徼，则我得其要而知夫人之所趣徼者矣。 此人我有无之欲，同出於此心而异其名，同谓之玄也。 我视无欲贵之为玄，人视有欲亦贵之为玄。 观人有欲之玄，反观我无欲之玄，是为进修大道之要地，斯曰众妙之门。 张灵应曰：无名，天地之始。 有名，万物之母。 道本无名，以炁化而得名。 炁出於无则无所可名，天清地宁，道从此始。 炁结为有，则有所可名。 枝叶种类，各宗其母。 炁以化物，物以寓道，人也只是一物，原其始，守其母，这便是入道处。 白玉蟾曰：道。 如此而已。 可道，非常道。 可说，即不如此。 名，强名曰道。 可名，非常名。 谓之道，已非也。 无。 此即道。 已名天地之始，道生一，即是天地之初，有一生二，二生三，三生万物，故有名万物之母。 一无生万有，万有归一无，故常无虚心无念，欲以观其妙，见物知道，知道见心，常有守中抱一，欲以观其徼。 身有生死，心无生死，此两者，万有一无。 一无亦无，无中不无，同出而异名，万法归一，一心本空，同谓之玄。 道非欲虚，虚自归，人能虚心，道自归一。 玄之又玄，虚里藏真，无中生有，众妙之门。 悟由此入，用之无穷。 廖粹然曰：道。 元始可道，字之曰道，非常道，不是寻常所言道者。 名，太上可名，强名曰道，非常名，不是泛泛所称名者。 无。 无极名天地之始，太初肇生，有太极名万物之母。 动静互根，常无这柱杖子时时提挈，欲以观其妙。 黄中通理，正位居体，美在其中，畅於四肢，常有只这眦子多守成，欲以观其徼。 隳肢体黜聪明，离形去智，同於大道，此两者同一气所生，出而异名，前三三后三三，同谓之玄，其归一揆。 玄之又玄。 如是如是，众妙之门。 散一成万、聚万归一，生生不穷之妙。 陈碧虚曰：道可道，非常道。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of is the gateway to the **Dao/Way**.

When the **Dao/Way** can be named, it is the **Dao/Way** of transient convention, not the **Dao/Way** of eternal, indestructible nature.
When a **name** can be fixed, it is the **name** of transient value, not the **name** of enduring, indescribable worth.

The **Dao/Way** cannot be confined by elevation or suppression in argument.
Thus, it is said above: "That which cannot be named," the origin of the chaotic **Heaven** and **Earth**,
and "That which can be named," the mother of all things born.

Hence, when one remains without **desire** yet stirs within the mind,
it suffices to observe the **Dao/Way**’s profound subtlety;
when one abides with **desire** yet moves in outward **emotion**,
it suffices to observe the **Dao/Way**’s shifting manifestations.

These two arise from the same **Dao/Way**, yet differ in subtle and manifest forms—
thus they are both called **"Mysterious"** (玄).

**"Mysterious Again"** (玄之又玄), yet all-pervasive,
this is the gateway to all wonders.

The **Dao/Way**’s subtlety defies naming,
so this chapter first names it as the mother of all things born,
then as the shifting manifestations of **desire**,
and as the **"Mysterious"** origin.
**"Mysterious Again"** is the gateway to all wonders.

To say "mother," "manifestations," "gateway"—
is this not the progression from essence to form,
from embodying the **Dao/Way** to attaining its wondrous applications?

**Zhāng Chōng Yìng** replied: The **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of is the gateway to the **Dao/Way**.

The **Great Dao/Way** is formless, giving birth to **Heaven** and **Earth**.
The **Great Dao/Way** is nameless, nurturing all things.
Humans cannot embody this natural **Dao/Way**,
yet they cling to the **Dao/Way** of scriptures and governance,
seeking fame, display, and the attainment of transient **names**.

The **Dao/Way** they speak of is the **Dao/Way** that can be attained by the world,
not the **Dao/Way** of eternal, unerodible nature.
The **name** they speak of is the **name** that can be attained by the world,
not the **name** of far-reaching, indescribable worth.

To embody the **Dao/Way** that cannot be named is to be nameless;
to embody the **Dao/Way** that can be named is to have a **name**.
Nameless, the **Dao/Way** is vast—
like **Heaven** covering and **Earth** bearing,
chaotic in its origin, yet unknown to humans as the source of covering and bearing.
Named, the **Dao/Way** is small—
like all things sprouting and branching,
distinguishing good and evil, each having its **name**.

The root of their good and evil is called the nameless **Dao/Way**,
the beginning of **Heaven** and **Earth**.
The named is the mother of all things.

Between **Heaven** and **Earth**, humans live with flesh and blood as their body,
the mind governing the five senses.
When embodying the **Dao/Way**, there is the ability to rest within my **desire**-less stillness,
to observe the **Dao/Way** that cannot be spoken of or named;
and to move in outward **desire**,
to observe the **Dao/Way**’s shifting manifestations.
Thus, I attain its essence and know the world’s shifting inclinations.

This **desire** of mine and the world’s, both arising from the same mind yet differing in **name**,
is called **"Mysterious"**.
I esteem the **"Mysterious"** of **desire**-lessness,
while the world esteems the **"Mysterious"** of **desire** as equally noble.
Observing the world’s **"Mysterious"** of **desire**,
then reflecting upon my own **"Mysterious"** of **desire**-lessness,
this is the crucial ground for advancing and refining the **Great Dao/Way**—
this is called the gateway to all wonders.

**Zhāng Líng Yìng** said: Nameless, it is the beginning of **Heaven** and **Earth**.
Named, it is the mother of all things.

The **Dao/Way** is originally nameless,
but through **qi** transformation it gains **name**.
**Qi** emerging from the nameless has no **name** to be fixed—
**Heaven** clears, **Earth** settles, and the **Dao/Way** begins from here.
**Qi** coalescing into form has **names** to be fixed—
branches, leaves, and kinds all trace back to their mother.
**Qi** transforms into things,
things contain the **Dao/Way**—
humans are but one thing among them.
To trace its origin and guard its mother,
this is the path to entering the **Dao/Way**.

**Bái Yù Chán** said:
The **Dao/Way**—
nothing more than this.
That which can be spoken of is not the **Dao/Way**.
That which can be said is not as it is.
The **name** is a forced designation of the **Dao/Way**.
That which can be named is not the true **name**.
To call it the **Dao/Way** is already to misname it.
The **Dao/Way** is **emptiness**.

This is the **Dao/Way**.
The beginning of **Heaven** and **Earth** is called **"Unnamed"** (无).
The **Dao/Way** generates **"One"** (一), which is the initial chaos of **Heaven** and **Earth**—
**"One"** generates **"Two"** (二), **"Two"** generates **"Three"** (三),
**"Three"** generates all things.
Thus, **"One"** is named the mother of all things.

**"One"** without form generates all **"Ten Thousand Things"** (万有),
all **"Ten Thousand Things"** return to **"One"** without form—
hence, one must always remain with an **emptiness**-filled mind,
without thought,
to observe its subtlety.
When one sees things, one knows the **Dao/Way**;
when one knows the **Dao/Way**, one sees the mind.
One must always guard the central **emptiness** and embrace **"One"**,
to observe its shifting manifestations.

The body has birth and death,
the mind has none—
these two are the **"Ten Thousand"** (万) and the **"One"** (一).
**"One"** without form is also without form—
within the **emptiness** there is no **emptiness**,
same origin yet different **names**—
all **dharma/laws** return to **"One"**,
the mind is fundamentally **emptiness**—
thus they are both called **"Mysterious"**.

The **Dao/Way** is not **emptiness**-seeking **desire**;
**emptiness** naturally returns.
Humans, when they achieve **emptiness**-filled minds,
the **Dao/Way** naturally returns to **"One"**.

**"Mysterious Again"**—
within **emptiness**, the true is hidden;
from **emptiness**, form arises—
the gateway to all wonders.
Awakening enters from here,
its application is endless.

**Liào Cuì Rán** said:
The **Dao/Way**—
the **Dao/Way** of **Primordial Beginning** (元始) can be spoken of,
and is called the **Dao/Way**, yet it is not the **Dao/Way**,
nor the ordinary **Dao/Way** spoken of by the world.
The **name**—
the **name** of the **Supreme Primordial** (太上) can be fixed,
and is called the **Dao/Way**, yet it is not the true **name**,
nor the common **name** invoked by all.

**"Unnamed"** (无)—
**"Unnamed"** (无极) is named the beginning of **Heaven** and **Earth**,
the **Supreme Primordial** (太初) initiating birth.
The **"Great Polarity"** (太极) is named the mother of all things.

**Movement** and **stillness** are mutually rooted—
always relying on this pillar and guide,
using **desire** to observe its subtlety.
The **yellow middle** (黄中) harmonizes principles,
correctly positioned within the body,
its beauty contained within,
flowing through the four limbs—
always abiding with **desire** is like this **eye** (眦),
often guarding the **form**,
using **desire** to observe its shifting manifestations.

To sever limbs and discard wisdom,
to abandon form and discard intellect,
to align with the **Great Dao/Way**—
these two arise from the same **qi**,
yet differ in **name**,
the first three three, the latter three three—
both are called **"Mysterious"**, yet they converge in **"One"**.

**"Mysterious Again"**—
as it is, as it is—
the gateway to all wonders.
The wondrous mystery of gathering **"One"** into **"Ten Thousand"**

chunks.original_text: 夫道者杳然难言，非神口所能辨，故心困焉不能知，口辟焉不能议，在人灵府之自悟尔。 谓之无为，自然也。 今标道者，已是强名，便属可道。 既云可道，有变有迁，有言有说，是曰教典何异糟粕。 尝试举扬不可沈默，且从训释曰：道，通也，言万物得之无所不通，无所不达。 亦曰道，蹈也。 取道路以为称也。 《说文》曰所行道也。 一达谓之道。 先贤今人体而行之，故曰道也。 至于仁义礼智信五常，皆道之用也。 用则谓之可道，可道既彰，即非常道。 常道者，自然而然，随感应变，拟物不穷者也。 不可以言传，不可以智索，但体冥造化，含光藏晖，无为而无不为，默通其极。 其严君平曰：可道之道，道德彰而非自然也。 又曰：今之持者画不操烛者＃1，为曰明也。 夫曰明者，不道之道，常道也。 操烛，可道之道彰也。 夫着於竹帛，镂於金石，可传於人者，可道之道也。 若乃可传而不可受，可得而不可见，自本自根，未有天地，自古以固存，神鬼神帝生天生地者，常道之道也。 五千文之蕴发挥自此数言，实谓渊之又渊，神之又神也。 名可名，非常名。 夫道者体也，名者用也。 用因体生，名自道出。 既标其名，即可称用。 称用既立，故曰可名。 可名既着，即非常名。 常名者，谓其应用无方，支离其德也。 严君平曰：可名之名，功名显而非素真也。 夫列子居郑圃四十年，人无识者，国君卿大夫视之犹众庶，此真守常名者也。 故道常无名，此之谓也。 无名，天地之始。 无名者，指其道而言之也。 夫万化未作，无其强名，但妙本之始既降，浑沦之朴将离，则易之太极生两仪也。 严君平曰：无名无朕，与神合体，天下恃之，莫知所以变於虚无，为天地始，此体道者也。 有名，万物之母。 有名者，指天地而言之也。 天施地化，茂养万物，亭之毒之，如母养子，故曰有名，万物之母也。 夫大道杳冥，岂系於有名无名哉？ 且圣人约用立教，以明本迹之同异尔，几日新之道，皆曰无名，是故始万物者为无名，成万物者为有名也。 严君平曰：有名者之为化也，尊道德，贵神明，师太和，则天地，故为万物母。 此用道者也。 常无欲以观其妙，常有欲以观其徼。 欲者，逐境生心也。 妙者，要也，又微之极也。 徼者，边隅也。 大道边有小路曰徼，又归也。 夫虚无之道寂然不动，则曰无欲； 感孕万物，则曰有欲。 无欲观妙，守虚无也； 有欲观徼，谓存思也。 常谓真常，即大道也。 无欲、有欲，即道之应用也。 夫道本无物，物感道生，且形而上者谓之道，形而下者谓之器，夫上士知微知彰，睹其未然已尽其妙，故曰常无欲以观其妙。 中士因循任物，见其群材乃得其用，故有万不同，真理难测，但觇其边徼耳。 又解曰：夫人常体大道之微，守清静之要，复性命之极，不为外物所诱，则志意虚憺，可以观道之要妙，造微之至极。 严君平曰：心如金石形如枯木，默默隅隅志如驹犊者，谓无欲之人，复其性命之本也。 且有欲之人贪逐境物，亡其坦夷之道，但见边小之徼，迷而不反，丧失真元。 先贤或以谓无欲者，体道内观，化及群品，无所思存，忘其本进也； 谓有欲者从本起用，施于可道，立教应物，成济众务，见物所终，了知归趣。

The **Dao/Way** is vast and difficult to speak of—
not something the divine mouth can discern.
Thus the mind is perplexed and cannot know,
the tongue falters and cannot discuss it—
it lies within the human **spiritual treasury** (*lingfu*), to be self-awakened alone.

It is called **"Non-Action"**—
for it is **naturally** so.

Now, to label the **Dao/Way** is already to impose a name,
and thus it belongs to the **"speakable"** realm.
Once it is said to be **"speakable"**, then there are changes and shifts,
words and explanations—
this is no different from teachings and doctrines, mere dregs of wisdom.

Let us attempt to raise what should be kept silent,
and from instruction explain:
**"Dao"** means **"pervasive"**—
speaking of how all things, obtaining it, find no obstruction,
no boundary.

It is also called **"Dao"**—**"to tread"**—
taking the path as its metaphor.
*The Classic of Graphs* says: **"Dao"** is **"the way one walks."**
One path leads—this is called **"Dao."**

Ancient sages and modern scholars embody and practice it,
thus it is called **"Dao."**

As for **benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust**—
the five **constants**—
these are all the **applications** of **Dao**.

When applied, it is called **"speakable."**
Once **"speakable"** is made clear,
then it is no longer the **"unspeakable."**

The **"unspeakable Dao"** is **naturally** so,
responding to stimuli, adapting without end.
It cannot be transmitted by words,
cannot be sought by intellect—
only by embodying the **mysteries of transformation**,
containing light, hiding radiance,
doing **Non-Action** yet accomplishing all—
silently attaining its utmost.

**Yán Jūn Píng** said:
The **"speakable Dao"**—
when **virtue/power** and **Dao** are made manifest,
they are no longer **natural**.

He also said:
Those who now hold **Dao** but do not wield it like a torch—
they claim to be **"enlightened."**
But **"enlightened"** is the **Dao** that is **not the Dao**—
the **"unspeakable."**
To wield a torch is to make the **"speakable Dao"** manifest.

What is inscribed on bamboo and silk,
carved into metal and stone,
what can be passed to others—
this is the **"speakable Dao."**

But what can be transmitted yet not received,
what can be obtained yet not seen—
its roots and origins,
before heaven and earth existed,
from ancient times onward, eternally abiding—
the **spirits, gods, and divine emperors** who gave birth to heaven and earth—
this is the **"unspeakable Dao."**

The **Five Thousand Characters** unfold from these few words,
truly the **"profound yet deeper"**,
the **"divine yet more divine."**

What can be named is not the **true name**.
The **Dao** is **embodiment**,
**name** is its **application**.
Application arises from embodiment,
names emerge from the **Dao**.
Once a name is given,
it can be invoked in use.
When use is established,
it is called **"nameable."**
Once **"nameable"** is fixed,
it is no longer the **"true name."**

The **"true name"** refers to its boundless applications,
fragmenting its **virtue/power**.
**Yán Jūn Píng** said:
The **"nameable name"**—
when **achievement and reputation** are displayed,
they are not the **original truth**.

**Lǐ Zǐ**, dwelling in the **Jīng Garden** for forty years,
no one recognized him—
the king and ministers treated him like commoners.
This was truly one who guarded the **"true name."**

Thus, the **Dao** is always **nameless**—
this is what is meant.

**"Nameless"** is the beginning of heaven and earth.
**"Nameless"** refers to the **Dao** itself.
Before the ten thousand transformations took form,
there was no imposed name—
only the **mystery of origins** descending,
the **primordial simplicity** about to disperse—
then the **Great Polarity** of the *Yì Jīng* emerged.

**Yán Jūn Píng** said:
**"Nameless"** and **"no trace"**—
uniting with the **Divine**,
the world relies upon it,
yet none know how it transforms from **emptiness**—
the beginning of heaven and earth.
This is the **embodiment of Dao**.

**"Named"** is the **mother of all things**.
**"Named"** refers to heaven and earth.
Heaven nurtures, earth transforms—
nourishing all things,
protecting and harming them like a mother to her child.
Thus it is called **"Named,"** the **mother of all things**.

The **Great Dao** is vast and obscure—
how could it be bound by **"Named"** or **"Nameless"**?
Moreover, the sage adapts use to establish teachings,
to clarify the **principles and traces** of **Dao**—
the **new teachings** of each age
are all called **"Nameless."**
Thus, what **begins** all things is **"Nameless,"**
what **completes** all things is **"Named."**

**Yán Jūn Píng** said:
The **"Named"** in its **transformations**—
honors **virtue/power and Dao**,
values **divine clarity**,
follows the **Great Harmony**,
aligns with heaven and earth—
thus it is the **mother of all things**.
This is the **application of Dao**.

Always **without desire**, observe its **mystery**;
always **with desire**, observe its **boundaries**.

**"Desire"** is the mind chasing after phenomena.
**"Mystery"** is the **essence**, the utmost subtlety.
**"Boundary"** is the **edge**, the **corner**—
the **Dao** has small paths at its edges,
also its **return**.

The **Dao of emptiness** is **silent and unmoving**—
this is **"without desire."**
When it **responds and gives birth** to all things—
this is **"with desire."**
**"Without desire"** observes **mystery**—
guarding **emptiness**.
**"With desire"** observes **boundaries**—
this is **contemplation**.

**"Constant"** refers to the **true and enduring**—
the **Great Dao** itself.
**"Without desire"** and **"with desire"**—
these are the **applications of Dao**.

The **Dao** originally has no form;
things **stimulate** the **Dao** to manifest.
What is **"above form"** is called **"Dao,"**
what is **"below form"** is called **"instrument."**
The **superior person** knows the subtle and the manifest,
perceiving what has not yet come and exhausting its **mystery**—
thus it is said: **"Always without desire, observe its mystery."**

The **middle person** follows along, yielding to things,
seeing their **material forms** before grasping their use—
thus there are **ten thousand differences**,
true principles are hard to fathom—
only glimpsing their **edges**.

Another explanation:
The **constant person** embodies the **Dao’s** subtlety,
guards the **essence of stillness**,
restores the **extremes of nature and life**,
not seduced by external things—
then the will and intentions are **empty and vast**,
able to observe the **Dao’s** **essence**,
reaching the **utmost of subtlety**.

**Yán Jūn Píng** said:
The heart like **metal and stone**, the form like **dry wood**,
silent and secluded, the will like a **foal or calf**—
these are the **"without desire,"** restoring the **roots of nature and life**.

Moreover, the **"with desire"** clings to phenomena,
losing the **broad path**—
only seeing the **small edges**,
lost and not returning,
losing the **true essence**.

Some ancient sages said:
The **"without desire"**—
embodies **Dao** through inner observation,
transforming all beings,
with no thoughts or storage,
forgetting their **original progress**.

The **"with desire"**—
from the **root**, applies **Dao**,
establishes teachings to respond to things,
accomplishes **benefiting all**,
sees the **end of things**,
fully knows their **return**.

chunks.original_text: 斯乃前以约身为说，后以化民为言，修身治国，理无不备也。 此两者同，此者指上事也，两者谓可道可名、无名有名、无欲有欲也。 俱蕴于寂然不动，湛尔之源，体用未彰，善恶都泯，故云同也。 出而异者，出谓从本降迹，可道渐分，虽起自一人之心，而五常之用殊别，贤愚有隔，迁变万端，寿夭存亡，其名各异，故曰出而异名。 同谓之玄，玄之又玄。 渊者，深妙也，冥也，天也。 所谓天者，自然也。 言此无名有名、无欲有欲，皆受气於天，禀性於自然，中和浊辱，形类万状，盖由渊之又渊、神之又神，所谓自然而然也。 若乃通悟深妙、洞达冥默者，是谓有渊德者也。 故严君平曰：玄之又玄，此之谓欤。 众妙之门，谓道域也。 夫大道旷荡，无所制围，无门无旁，四达之皇皇也。 约身而论，出则同众人，入则为妙本。 举教言则众真讲妙而出，群圣蕴妙而归，化导无方，湛然惟一，独立不改，是曰知常。 既有出入之由，故曰门耳。 庄子曰：有乎生，有乎死，有乎入，入出而无见其形，是谓天门。 天门者，无有也。 万物出乎无有，斯亦谓众妙之门也。 谢图南曰：道可道至常名。 何谓道？ 经曰道法自然，则道者，自然而然，非可以使然者也。 道本无名，名之曰道者，以其四通八辟，可以共行，如道路然。 孟子曰：道若大路。 正谓此尔。 可道者，犹曰可行也。 可名者，犹曰可称也。 天下何莫由斯道，而百姓日用而不知，则可道可名之中，又有非常之妙存焉。 《中庸》曰：夫妇之愚可以与知，及其至也，圣人有所不知； 夫妇之不肖可以与行，及其至也，圣人有所不能。 此曰非常者，其亦不可知、不可能者欤。 无名至之母。 未有天地，先有此道，而道之名未立，太极既分，天地万物自道而生，有母之义，而道之也名始显。 夫物之生，虽有万不同，而为母一也。 盖尝论之，有形者，有形形者，有化者，有化化者。 形者，形矣； 而形形者，未尝形。 化者，化矣； 而化化者，未尝化。 道之名乎后天，即先天之未名者也。 古往今来，形生气化，无有纪极，是孰使之然哉？ 惚兮恍兮，其中有象，寂兮寥兮，独立不改，无为而无不为，无在而无不在，岂非所谓无名者乎，岂非所谓非常者乎？ 吾故曰形形者未尝形，化化者未尝化。 故常无至之门。 道母万物，而人亦天地之一物也。 人本道以生，则道在吾身矣。 故以有欲无欲，反观乎吾身之道，老子此言修身之本也。 妙者在内也、本也。 徼者在外也、末也。 人之一身所恃以立者，惟精与神。 经曰窈窈冥冥，其中有精，其精甚真，其中有信。 方其无欲，则寂然不动，精神混合，故可观其妙。 及其有欲，则感而遂通，精神相离，故可观其徼。 精生於玄，玄者天也，天一生水，水性润下，自乾为首，而至於坎为肾，此玄实相流通也。 故曰同出异名，由徼入妙，则玄之下者复返乎上，可与入众妙之门矣。 桓凯曰：道妙之门，实昆仑之上。 然则当於乾为首者求之。 盖尝论之，一阴一阳之谓道，自然而然者也。 人禀阴阳之气以生，有欲无欲，亦其自然者也。 精神同出，本乎一天，自妙而徼，天者人矣。 譬之於水，天一所生，其源本同，自源祖流，同者始异，故徼者其流也，妙者其源也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus, the former speaks of **restraining the self**, the latter of **transforming the people**—
to cultivate the self and govern the realm,
the **Dao/Way** is never left incomplete.

These two are the same in essence,
but the latter refers to **higher matters**—
the two being the **namable and unnamable**,
the **desiring and without desire**.

Both are contained within the **stillness and immobility** of **emptiness (寂然)**,
the **profound source (湛尔之源)**,
where **substance and function** remain indistinct,
and **good and evil** are indistinct as well—
thus they are called the same.

Yet when they manifest differently,
it means **descending from the root** to **traceable forms**,
the **Dao/Way** gradually becoming **distinct**,
though originating from the mind of one individual,
the **Five Constants (五常)** apply in varied ways—
the **virtue/power** of the wise and foolish differ,
their **transformations** are countless,
and their **lifespans and fates** diverge—
thus, when they emerge, their names differ.

The same is called **profound (玄)**,
**profound beyond profound**.

**Depth (渊)** is profound subtlety,
**obscurity (冥)**,
**heavenly (天)**.
What is called **heavenly** is **natural (自然)**.

This **namable and unnamable**,
**desiring and without desire**—
all receive **qi** from **heaven**,
and inherit their **nature** from **naturalness (自然)**,
harmonizing within and without,
assuming countless forms—
arising from **profound beyond profound**,
**spiritual beyond spiritual**,
what is called **self-so (自然而然)**.

Those who **penetrate and comprehend** this profound subtlety,
**piercing the obscurity (冥默)**—
these are called those with **profound virtue (有渊德)**.

Thus **Yán Jūn Píng** said:
**"Profound beyond profound"**—
this is what he meant, is it not?

The **gateway to all marvels (众妙之门)****
is called the **domain of the Dao/Way (道域)**.

The **Great Dao/Way** is vast and unbounded,
with no limits or confines,
no gates or byways—
it is the **august sovereign (皇皇)** of fourfold passage.

When discussed in terms of **restraining the self**,
it emerges as common to all people,
but when withdrawn, it becomes the **marvelous root**.

When taught to the masses,
the **truths (众真)** expound the marvelous and emerge,
while the **sages (群圣)** contain the marvelous and return—
their **transformation and guidance** are boundless,
yet **stillness (湛然)** remains singular,
**independent and unchanging**—
this is called **knowing the Constant (知常)**.

Since there is **entry and emergence (出入)**,
it is thus called a **gateway**.

**Zhuangzi** said:
There is the **gateway of life**,
there is the **gateway of death**,
there is the **gateway of return**—
**entry and emergence**, yet no form is seen—
this is called the **Heavenly Gateway (天门)**.

The **Heavenly Gateway** is **the Unmanifest (无有)**.
All things emerge from **the Unmanifest**,
and thus it is also called the **gateway to all marvels**.

**Xie Tu'nan** said:
**"The Dao/Way that can be named"** is the **Constant Name (至常名)**.

What is called the **Dao/Way**?
The **Classics (经)** say: **"The Dao/Way follows naturalness (自然)"**,
so the **Dao/Way** is **self-so (自然而然)**,
not something that can be **made so (使然)**.

The **Dao/Way** originally has no name;
it is called the **Dao/Way** because its **fourfold passage and eightfold reach (四通八辟)****
can be **shared and followed (共行)**,
like roads and paths.
**Mencius** said: **"The Dao/Way is like a great road."**
This is exactly what he meant.

The **"namable Dao/Way"** is like saying **"followable"**,
the **"nameable"** is like saying **"worthy of mention."**

Why does the world not follow this **Dao/Way**,
while the people use it daily without knowing?
Within the **"namable and unnamable" Dao/Way**,
there exists an **extraordinary marvel (非常之妙)**.

The **Zhōng Yōng (《中庸》)** says:
Even the **foolish commoners (夫妇之愚)** can share in **knowing**,
but when it reaches its **ultimate (至)**,
even the **sages** have things they do not know.

Even the **unworthy commoners (夫妇之不肖)** can share in **following**,
but when it reaches its **ultimate**,
even the **sages** have things they cannot do.

This is called the **"extraordinary"**—
that which is **unknowable and unattainable**, is it not?

The **Unmanifest Mother (无名至之母)** of the **ultimate**.
Before **heaven and earth** existed,
this **Dao/Way** was already present,
yet its name had not yet been established.
When the **Great Ultimate (太极)** was divided,
**heaven and earth and all things** arose from the **Dao/Way**,
holding the meaning of a **mother**,
while the **Dao/Way** itself was only later named.

Though all things arise with **ten thousand differences (万不同)**,
they share the same **mother**.

Having examined this thoroughly,
there are **forms (形)**,
there are **forms of forms (形形)***,
there are **transformations (化)**,
there are **transformations of transformations (化化)***.

**Forms** are forms indeed,
yet **forms of forms** have never truly been forms.
**Transformations** are transformations indeed,
yet **transformations of transformations** have never truly been transformations.

The **Dao/Way** is named **post-heaven**,
yet it is the **pre-heaven** that is **unnamed**.

From ancient times to the present,
**forms** arise from **qi** and **transformations**—
without beginning or end—
who is it that makes this so?

**Vague and indistinct (惚兮恍兮)**,
yet within there are **images (象)**;
**still and empty (寂兮寥兮)**,
yet **independent and unchanging**—
**effortless yet nothing is left undone (无为而无不为)***,
**nowhere yet everywhere present (无在而无不在)***—
is this not what is called the **Unnamed**?
Is this not what is called the **Extraordinary**?

Thus I say:
**Forms of forms** have never truly been forms,
**transformations of transformations** have never truly been transformations.
Hence, there is no **gateway to the Ultimate (常无至之门)**.

The **Dao/Way** is the **mother of all things**,
and **humans** are but one thing among **heaven and earth**.
Since **humans** arise from the **Dao/Way**,
then the **Dao/Way** is within **my own body**.

Thus, **desiring and without desire**—
**returning inward** to observe the **Dao/Way** within **my own self**—
this is the **foundation of cultivation (修身)** spoken of by **Lǎozǐ**.

The **marvelous (妙)** lies within—
in the **root (本)**.
The **small edges (徼)** lie without—
in the **end (末)**.

What **humans** rely upon to stand firm
is only **essence (精)** and **spirit (神)**.

The **Classics (经)** say:
**"Deep and mysterious (窈窈冥冥)"**,
within it there is **essence**—
its **essence** is most **true (甚真)**,
and within it there is **faith (信)**.

When one is **without desire**,
then **still and unmoving (寂然不动)**,
**essence and spirit** blend harmoniously—
thus one can observe its **marvelousness**.

When one is **with desire**,
then **sensations arise and pass (感而遂通)***,
**essence and spirit** separate—
thus one can observe its **small edges**.

**Essence** arises from **profound (玄)**,
**profound** being **heaven (天)**—
**heaven** first generates **water (水)**,
water’s nature is **moist and descending (润下)**,
from **Qián (乾, Heaven)** to **Kǎn (坎, Water)** as the **kidneys (肾)**—
this is the **profound** truly flowing through.

Thus it is said:
**"Same origin, different names (同出异名)"**,
**from the small edges into marvelousness (由徼入妙)**—
then the **profound** of the lower returns to the **upper**,
and one can enter the **gateway to all marvels**.

**Huán Kǎi** said:
The **gateway to the Dao’s marvels (道妙之门)***
is indeed **above Kunlun (昆仑)**.
Then one should seek it at **Qián (乾, Heaven)** as the **beginning**.

Having examined this thoroughly,
**one yin and one yang** is called the **Dao/Way**—
**self-so (自然而然)**.

**Humans** inherit **yin and yang qi** to arise,
and **desire and without desire** are also their **naturalness**.
**Essence and spirit** have the same origin,
rooted in **one heaven (一天)**—
from **marvelousness to small edges (自妙而徼)**,
**heaven** is **human**.

It is like **water**—
**one heaven** generates it,
its **source** is originally the same,
from **source to tributary to river (源祖流)***,
the same begins to differ—
thus, the **small edges** are its **river**,
the **marvelous** is its **source**.」

chunks.original_text: 玄之又玄，则沿流以遡源，而与吾之天者一矣。 昔黄帝西游，归而失其玄珠，使明目人离娄求之，不得，使罔象求而得之。 知黄帝之玄珠，则知老氏之玄玄矣。 林鬳斋曰：道可道至之门。 此章居一书之首，一书之大旨，皆具於此。 其意盖以为道本不容言。 才涉有言，皆是第二义。 常者，不变不易之谓也。 可道可名，则有变有易； 不可道不可名，则无变无易。 有仁义礼智之名，则仁者不可以为义，礼者不可以为智。 有春夏秋冬之名，则春者不可以为夏，秋者不可以为冬。 是则非常道非常名矣。 天地之始，太极未分之时也。 其在人心，则寂然不动之地。 太极未分，则安有春夏秋冬之名； 寂然不动，则安有仁义礼智之名？ 故曰无名，天地之始。 其谓之天地者，非专言天地也。 所以为此心之喻也。 既有阴阳之名，则千变万化皆由此而出。 既有仁义之名，则千条万端皆自此而始。 故曰有名，万物之母。 母者，言自此而生也。 常无常有两句，此老子教人究竟处，处人世之间，件件是有，谁知此有自无而始。 若以为无则又有，所谓莽莽荡荡，招殃祸之事。 故学道者常於无时就无上究竟，则见其所以生有者之妙； 常於有时就有上究竟，则见其自无而来之徼。 徼即《礼记》所谓窍於山川之窍也，言所自出也。 此两欲字有深意。 欲者要也，要如此究竟也。 有与无虽为两者，虽有异名，其实同出，能常无常有以观之，则皆谓之玄。 玄者，造化之妙也。 以此而观，则老子之学何尝专尚虚无？ 若专主於无，则不可两者同出矣，不曰同谓之玄矣。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 此即庄子所谓有始也者、有未始有始也者、有未始有夫未始有始也者，但赞言其妙而已，初无别义。 若曰一层上又有一层，则非其本旨。 众妙即《易》所谓妙万物者也。 门言其所自出也。 此章人多只就天地上说，不知老子之意正要就心上理会，如此兼看，方得此书之全意。 范应元曰：道可道，非常道。 道者，自然之理，万物之所由也。 可道者，谓可言也。 常者，久也。 道一而已，有体用焉，未有不得其体而知其用者也。 先体立，然后用有以行。 老氏说经，先明其体，常者言其体也，可道者言其用也。 体用一源，非有二道也。 今夫仁义礼智，可言者也，皆道之用也。 人徒知恻隐之心，仁之端也，羞恶之心，义之端也，辞让之心，礼之端也，是非之心，智之端也，而不知其体之一则是道也。 分裂四出，末流不胜其弊也。 惟先知其体之一，则日用常行随事着见，无有不当，皆自然之理也。 如是则久而无弊矣。 故凡道之可以言者，非常久自然之道也。 夫常久自然之道，有而无形，无而有精，其大无外，故大无不包； 其小无内，故细无不入，无不通。 求之於吾心之初，则得之矣。 人物莫不由此而生，圣贤莫不体此而立。 然此道虽周行乎事物之际，相传乎典籍之中，而其妙处，事物莫能杂，言辩莫能及，故人鲜造诣於是。 老子应运垂教，不得已而发明之，岂容离乎言哉？ 故首曰道可道非常道，意欲使人知常久自然之道，不在言辞，当反求诸己，而自得之於吾心之初也。 名可名，非常名。 名者，犹人之有名也。 凡名之可以名字者，皆其可道者，非常久自然之道也。

「The **Dao/Way** beyond the **Dao/Way**—
then one follows the **river** to trace its **source**,
and thus unites with **my heaven** in **one**.

In ancient times, **Emperor Yellow (黄帝)** ventured westward,
returning without his **marvelous pearl (玄珠)**.
He sent the **clear-eyed man (明目人)** **Lí Lóu (离娄)** to seek it,
who failed.
Then he sent **Wàng Xiàng (罔象)**, who found it.

To know **Emperor Yellow’s marvelous pearl**—
then one knows **Laozi’s** **most marvelous Dao/Way (玄玄)**.

**Lín Chǐng (林鬳斋)** said:
**"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of"**—
this passage stands at the **beginning of the book**,
and the **great essence of the entire book** is all contained here.
Its meaning is that **the Dao/Way** originally **does not admit of speech**.
Once speech is introduced, it is all **second-order meaning (第二义)**.

**"Constant"** refers to **unchangeable, immutable**—
**what can be spoken of and named** is changeable and mutable;
**what cannot be spoken of or named** is unchangeable and immutable.
With **names like benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom (仁义礼智)**,
the benevolent cannot be said to be righteousness,
the proper cannot be said to be wisdom.
With **names like spring, summer, autumn, and winter (春夏秋冬)**,
spring cannot be said to be summer,
autumn cannot be said to be winter.
Thus, **the constant Dao/Way is not the spoken Dao/Way**.

At the **beginning of heaven and earth (天地之始)**,
it was the time before **the Great Polarity (太极)*** was divided.
In **human mind**, it is the **still, unmoving state (寂然不动)**.
Before **the Great Polarity** was divided,
how could there be names like spring, summer, autumn, and winter?
In the **still, unmoving state**,
how could there be names like benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom?
Thus, it is said: **"The nameless"** is the **beginning of heaven and earth**.

When it speaks of **"heaven and earth" (天地)***,
it does not refer solely to heaven and earth.
It is a metaphor for **this mind (此心)**.

Once **yin and yang (阴阳)** are named,
then **ten thousand changes and myriad transformations (千变万化)** all arise from them.
Once **benevolence and righteousness (仁义)** are named,
then **ten thousand branches and myriad threads (千条万端)** all begin from them.
Thus, it is said: **"The named"** is the **mother of all things (万物之母)**.
**Mother** means **from this they are generated**.

The two phrases **"constant" and "non-constant"**—
this is where **Laozi** teaches people the **ultimate truth**.
In the **worldly realm (人世之间)**,
each thing is **non-constant (有)**,
yet who knows that this **non-constant** originates from **the constant**?
If one insists on **the constant** alone,
then **non-constant** will again arise—
the **reckless, chaotic acts (莽莽荡荡)** that invite **calamity and disaster (招殃祸)**.

Thus, those who study the **Dao/Way** must, in the **constant state (无时)***,
seek the **ultimate truth (无上究竟)** of the **constant**,
and see the **marvelousness (妙)** of how **non-constant** arises.
Or, in the **non-constant state (有时)***,
seek the **ultimate truth (有上究竟)** of the **non-constant**,
and see its **source (徼)** from **the constant**.

**"Source"** is what **The Book of Rites (礼记)*** calls
**the hidden depths of mountains and rivers (窍於山川之窍)***—
speaking of **its origin (所自出)**.

The two **"desire" (欲)** characters here have deep meaning.
**"Desire"** means **to seek earnestly**—
to seek earnestly this **ultimate truth**.
Though **constant** and **non-constant** appear as two,
though they bear different names,
their origin is the same.
If one can observe **constant** and **non-constant** with **the constant** in mind,
then both are called **Dao/Way**.

**"Dao/Way"** is the **marvelousness of transformation (造化之妙)***.
Observing it thus,
how could **Laozi’s teachings** be said to **exclusively uphold emptiness and nothingness (虚无)**?
If one **exclusively adheres to the constant**,
then one cannot acknowledge that both **constant** and **non-constant** share the same origin—
that is not called **"Dao/Way"** as **Dao/Way**.

**"Dao/Way beyond the Dao/Way"**—
the **gateway to all marvels**.
This is what **Zhuangzi (庄子)*** praises as:
**"What has a beginning"**—
**"what has no beginning yet has a beginning"**—
**"what has no beginning yet has no beginning"**—
but only **extols its marvelousness**, with no other meaning.
If one says **"there is another layer above this layer"**, then it is not his **original intent**.

**"All marvels"** are what **The Book of Changes (易)*** calls:
**"the marvelousness of all things"**.
**"Gateway"** refers to **its origin**.

Many people discuss this passage only in terms of **heaven and earth**,
yet they fail to grasp **Laozi’s true intent**—
to **examine it within the mind**.
Only by **viewing it together** can one attain the **full meaning of this book**.

**Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元)** said:
**"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of"**—
**not the constant Dao/Way**.

**Dao/Way** is the **principle of nature (自然之理)**,
the **origin of all things (万物之所由)**.
**What can be spoken of** means **what can be expressed in words**.
**"Constant"** means **enduring**.

**Dao/Way** is **one**,
yet it has **substance and function (体用)***.
No one has ever **known its function without first grasping its substance**.
**Substance** must be established first,
then **function** can be put into practice.

**Laozi’s** teaching begins by **clarifying its substance**—
**"constant"** refers to **its substance**,
**"what can be spoken of"** refers to **its function**.
**Substance and function** share a **single source**,
not two separate **Dao/Way**.

Now, **benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom**—
these are **what can be spoken of**,
all **functions of the Dao/Way**.

People merely know:
**the heart of compassion (恻隐之心)** as the **beginning of benevolence (仁之端)***,
**the heart of shame and dislike (羞恶之心)** as the **beginning of righteousness (义之端)***,
**the heart of decorum and yielding (辞让之心)** as the **beginning of propriety (礼之端)***,
**the heart of distinction and judgment (是非之心)** as the **beginning of wisdom (智之端)***,
yet they fail to recognize
that **the Dao/Way’s single substance (体之一)** is **the Dao/Way itself**.

**Divided and scattered** in four directions,
the **endless branches (末流)*** bring **no small harm (不胜其弊)***.

Only if one **first knows its single substance**,
then **daily life and constant practice** will naturally reveal itself in **each affair**,
without fail—
all **the principle of nature (自然之理)**.

Thus, it will endure **without harm** for long.
Therefore, whatever **Dao/Way** can be spoken of,
it is **not the constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way**.

The **constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way**—
**has form yet is formless (有形)***,
**is formless yet has essence (无形)***,
its **greatness knows no outer limit (大无外)**,
so it **embodies all without exclusion (无不包)**;
its **smallness knows no inner limit (小无内)**,
so it **penetrates all without omission (细无不入)**,
**all-pervasive (无不通)**.

Seeking it in **the initial state of my mind (吾心之初)***,
one will attain it.

**All people** are born from this,
**sages and worthies** stand by embodying this.
Yet though this **Dao/Way** **pervades all affairs (周行乎事物之际)***,
**is transmitted through scriptures (相传乎典籍之中)***,
its **marvelous depths**—
**affairs cannot mingle with them (事物莫能杂)***,
**words cannot reach them (言辩莫能及)***—
so few people **attain mastery (鲜造诣)***.

**Laozi** **responded to the times (应运)** and **delivered his teachings (垂教)***,
**revealing the Dao/Way out of necessity (不得已而发明)***,
how could it be **separated from words (离乎言)**?
Thus, he begins with:
**"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of"**—
**not the constant Dao/Way**,
intending to make people **know the constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way**,
**not in words (不在言哉)**,
but to **seek it within themselves (反求诸己)***,
and **attain it in the initial state of my mind (自得之於吾心之初)***.

**"The name that can be named"**—
**not the constant name**.

**Name** is like **a person’s given name**.
All **names that can be named** are **what can be spoken of**,
**not the constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way**.

chunks.original_text: 且如万物生来未常有名，亦只是昔人与之名以分别之尔。 万物有形，固可以道、可以名，惟常久自然之道，为万物之母，而无形，故不可道，不可名也。 无名，天地之始。 天地之先，元有此道，浑沦未判，孰得而名？ 有名，万物之母。 浑沦既判，天地人物从此而生，圣人见是万物之母而无形，故强字之曰道，强为之名曰大。 因其无名强为之名，俾一切人假此有名，探其无名，以复其初也。 故常无欲以观其妙。 常无绝句，观去声，谛视也。 妙，徼妙也，常久自然之道。 自古固存，然而无形无声，微妙难穷，故谓之常无，则欲要使人以观其微妙也。 惟人也由此道而生，为万物之最灵，诚能回光反视於吾身之中，悟一真体，虽至虚而物无不备，则道之微妙可得而观矣。 如是乃知一理包乎万殊，凡物凡事不可违，自然之理也。 常有欲以观其徼。 常有绝句，观平声，徼，循也，境也，归也。 大道自然，化生万物，在天则成日月星汉等之象，在地则成山川草木等之形，在人则成身体发肤等之质，故谓之常有，则欲要使人以观其境也。 惟人也中天地而立为三才之一，果能仰观俯察於两仪之内，悟万物形虽不同，而理无不在，则道之境致可得而观矣。 夫如是乃知万殊归於一理，凡物凡事，固当循自然之理也。 此两者至谓之玄，两者，常无与常有也。 玄者，深远而不可分别之义，盖非无不能显有，非有不能显无，无与有同出而异名也。 以道为无，则万化由之而出； 以道为有，则无形无声，常常不变。 故曰常无常有也。 无有之上，俱着一常字，乃指其本，则无有不二，深远难穷，故同谓之玄也。 窃尝谓有无固不足以论道，然自其微妙而言，不可不谓之常无； 自其着见而言，不可不谓之常有。 分而言之，妙是微、徼是显； 合而言之，无与有同出而异名，妙徼皆一道也。 此老氏所以兼有无、贯显微、合同异而为言也。 人能如是观之，则妙与徼相通、物与我浑融，表里洞然，本无留碍，亦无差别也。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 常久自然之道，亦不可以名言。 今既强字之曰道矣，且自其微妙，而谓之常无。 又自其着见，而谓之常有。 复自其本之有无不二，深远难穷，而同谓之玄，是皆不免乎言焉。 玄之又玄，则犹云深之又深、远之又远。 非无非有，非异非同，不知所以然而然，终不可得而名言，分别之也。 然万化由斯而出，各各具妙，故曰众妙之门。 老氏悯夫世人逐末忘本，寖复失真源，不得已而应机垂训，又恐人溺於言辞，弗能内观，故复示人以深意，必使反求诸己，欲其自得之，而入众妙之门，以复其初，又能体是而行，以辅万物之自然，而同归于一也。 唯人为万物之最灵，诚能反观，则是道也，湛然常存，夫何远之有。 此章直指此心之初，自然之理，使不惑於有无同异，得意忘言，升玄及妙，乃入道之门。 立德之基，实一经之总也，宜深味之。 徐君约曰：道可道至之门。 首四句言道不可以言语道说，不可以名字题号。 但古之知道者，欲因言语以示人，则不得不立为名字，非其本来固有也。 故次四句承上而言，曰无者所以名天地之始，曰有者所以名万物之母。 始者，谓未有天地之先，专言形而上之道。 道不可谓之无，然无声臭无形状借此而强名之耳。
