「Moreover, take the case of all things: when they first arise, they do not yet have names—only the names given by past sages to distinguish them. All things with form can indeed be spoken of and named, but the constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way is the origin of all things, yet **without form (无形)**, so it cannot be spoken of or named.

**"The Unnamed (无名)"** is the beginning of heaven and earth.
Before heaven and earth existed, this Dao/Way was already present, **indistinct and undifferentiated (浑沦未判)**, who could name it?
**"The Named (有名)"** is the mother of all things.
Once **indistinct and undifferentiated (浑沦)** was clarified, heaven, earth, and all beings came into existence. The sage saw that this was the mother of all things yet **without form (无形)**, so he **forced a term upon it (强字)**, calling it Dao/Way, and **assigned a name to it (强为之名)**, calling it *Great (大)*. Because it was originally unnamed yet forced to be named, he did so that all people might **borrow this name (假此有名)** and **investigate its unnameable essence (探其无名)**, thereby **restoring its original state (以复其初)**.

Thus, **one must habitually lack desire (常无欲)** to perceive its subtlety (妙).
**"Habitually lacking desire (常无欲)"**—**habitually without fixed speech (常无绝句)**, observing the *departing voice (去声)*, scrutinizing it closely (谛视).
**"Subtlety (妙)"**—**the ultimate subtlety (徼妙)**, the constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way.
From ancient times, it has always existed, yet **without form or sound (无形无声)**, so **exquisitely subtle (微妙)** that it cannot be fully exhausted. Hence, it is called *constant unnameable (常无)*, intending to **urge people to observe its subtlety (以观其微妙)**.

Only humans, born from this Dao/Way, are the most **responsive (灵)** of all things. If they truly **retrace the light and reflect inward (回光反视)** within themselves, **awakening to the single true essence (悟一真体)**, though it be **utterly void (至虚)**, yet **nothing is lacking (物无不备)**, then the Dao’s subtlety can be **perceived and observed (可得而观)**.

Thus, one comes to know that **one principle encompasses all particulars (一理包乎万殊)**, and all things and affairs **cannot defy (不可违)** the natural principle.

**One must habitually have desire (常有欲)** to perceive its **manifestation (徼)**.
**"Habitually having desire (常有欲)"**—**habitually with fixed speech (常有绝句)**, observing the *level voice (平声)*, **manifestation (徼)**, which is **to follow (循)**, **the realm (境)**, **or return (归)**.
The Great Dao/Way is natural and spontaneous, transforming and giving rise to all things. In heaven, it manifests as the forms of sun, moon, stars, and galaxies (星汉); on earth, as mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees; in humans, as the substance of **body, hair, and skin (身体发肤)**. Hence, it is called *constant having (常有)*, intending to **urge people to observe its manifestations (以观其境)**.

Only humans, **standing between heaven and earth (中天地)** as one of the *Three Powers (三才)*, if they **contemplate above and examine below (仰观俯察)** within the *Two Principles (两仪)*, realize that though all things have different forms, the principle is **never absent (无不在)**. Then, the Dao’s **manifestations and subtleties (境致)** can be **perceived and observed (可得而观)**.

Thus, one comes to know that **all particulars return to one principle (万殊归於一理)**, and all things and affairs **must follow (固当)** the natural principle.

These two—**constant unnameable (常无)** and **constant having (常有)**—are called *Dao (道)*.
*"Dao (道)"* refers to **that which is profound and distant (深远)**, yet **cannot be distinguished (不可分别)**.
It is **neither non-existence (无)** without the ability to reveal existence (有),
nor existence (有)** without the ability to reveal non-existence (无)**.
Existence and non-existence **emerge together yet bear different names (同出而异名)**.

If one considers the Dao/Way as **non-existence (无)**, then all transformations arise from it.
If one considers the Dao/Way as **existence (有)**, then it is **formless and soundless (无形无声)**, ever **unchanging (常常不变)**.
Hence, it is said: **constant unnameable, constant having (常无常有)**.

Above the **non-existent and existent (无有)**, both are **marked with the character *constant (常)***, pointing to its **root (本)**.
Since it is **neither existent nor non-existent (无有不二)**, yet **profound and distant (深远)**, it is exhaustively called *Dao (道)*.

I have often thought that **existence and non-existence (有无)** alone are **insufficient to discuss the Dao/Way (论道)**.
Yet, from its **subtlety (微妙)**, one cannot avoid calling it *constant unnameable (常无)*;
from its **manifestation (着见)**, one cannot avoid calling it *constant having (常有)*.

When **divided (分而言之)**, subtlety is **refined (微)**, manifestation is **explicit (显)**;
when **unified (合而言之)**, non-existence and existence **emerge together yet bear different names (同出而异名)**,
and both **refined and explicit (妙徼)** are **one Dao/Way (一道)**.
This is how **Laozi** **combines non-existence and existence (兼有无)**, **penetrates explicit and refined (贯显微)**, **unifies same and different (合同异)** in his discourse.

If people can **observe in this manner (如是观之)**, then **refined and explicit (妙与徼)** will **communicate (相通)**, and **things and self (物与我)** will **merge indistinctly (浑融)**.
Inside and outside will be **clearly revealed (表里洞然)**,
with **no obstruction to its root (本无留碍)** nor **any distinction (无差别)**.

*"Dao that is again Dao (玄之又玄)"*—
the **gateway to all subtleties (众妙之门)**.
The constant, enduring, natural Dao/Way **cannot be fully expressed by names or words (不可以名言)**.
Now, since it is **forced to be termed (强字)** as Dao/Way,
and from its **subtlety (微妙)**, it is called *constant unnameable (常无)*,
and from its **manifestation (着见)**, it is called *constant having (常有)*.
Again, from its **root’s unity of existence and non-existence (本之有无不二)**,
profound and distant, yet **inexhaustible (难穷)**, it is **equally called *Dao (玄)***.
All these are **inevitably bound by words (不免乎言焉)**.

*"Dao that is again Dao (玄之又玄)"*—
this is **like saying *profound that is again profound (深之又深)*, distant that is again distant (远之又远)***.
It is **neither non-existence nor existence (非无非有)**,
**neither different nor the same (非异非同)**,
**unknown in its *so-and-so-yet-so (所以然)***,
yet **cannot be fully named or spoken of (终不可得而名言)**,
for it is **beyond distinction (分别)**.

Yet, all transformations arise from it, each **possessing its own subtlety (各各具妙)**,
hence it is called **the gateway to all subtleties (众妙之门)**.

Laozi **pities (悯)** that **people of the world chase superficiality (逐末)** while **forgetting the root (忘本)**,
and **lose the true source (失真源)**.
Unable to help but **respond to the times (应运)** and **deliver his teachings (垂训)**,
he also **fears that people will drown in words (溺於言辞)**,
and **cannot reflect inward (弗能内观)**.
Thus, he **further instructs (示人以深意)**,
**compelling them to seek within themselves (必使反求诸己)**,
**desiring they attain it themselves (欲其自得之)**,
and **enter the gateway to all subtleties (以入众妙之门)**,
**restoring its original state (以复其初)**.
They can also **embody and act upon it (体是而行)**,
**assisting the natural transformation of all things (以辅万物之自然)**,
and **returning to unity (而同归于一)**.

Only humans are the most **responsive (灵)** of all things.
If they truly **reflect inward (反观)**, this Dao/Way **will remain luminously present (湛然常存)**—
how could it be **distant (远)**?

This chapter **directly points to the initial state of this mind (直指此心之初)**,
the natural principle,
**preventing confusion over existence and non-existence, same and different (不惑於有无同异)**,
**realizing the intent beyond words (得意忘言)**,
**ascending to the profound and attaining subtlety (升玄及妙)**,
and **entering the Dao’s gateway (乃入道之门)**.

**Establishing the foundation of virtue (立德之基)**,
this is **the essence of the entire teaching (实一经之总)**.
It should be **deeply savored (宜深味之)**.

Xu Jun Yue said:
*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is the gateway to the Dao/Way."*
The first four sentences state that the Dao/Way **cannot be conveyed through speech (不可以言语道说)**,
nor **labeled with names (不可以名字题号)**.

Yet, **ancient sages who understood the Dao/Way (古之知道者)**,
**wishing to guide people through words (欲因言语以示人)**,
**could not help but assign names to it (则不得不立为名字)**,
though these were **not its originally inherent nature (非其本来固有)**.

Hence, the next four sentences **follow the previous (承上而言)**:
*"The Unnamed (无)"* is what names **the beginning of heaven and earth (天地之始)**,
*"The Named (有)"* is what names **the mother of all things (万物之母)**.
**"The beginning (始)"** refers to **the Dao/Way beyond form (形而上之道)** before heaven and earth existed.
The Dao/Way **cannot be called non-existence (无)**, yet it is **formless, soundless, and without attributes (无声臭无形状)**—
only **forced to be named (借此而强名之耳)**.

chunks.original_text: 夫既名之曰道矣，又曰无名可乎万物之母。 谓既有天地、之后，兼言形而下之器，道非至此而后有。 但既丽於器，则有实迹，有定位，对无而为言耳。 若指此为有名，何者为无名乎？ 以名字绝句，义理不通。 又次四句，则言体道之人反求诸己，先以故字发之，常无欲则纯是道理，生而静者也，於此而观其妙。 妙者，微妙而不可见，然谓之观，则必有昭然而不昧人所不知而已。 独知者常有欲，则是人心感物而动者也。 人自禀生赋形，而后耳目口鼻四肢之欲皆有所当，然而不能无，於此而观其徼。 徼者循也，亦谓边境尽处，循其心之所欲而极其所至之境，有以观之而不至於沦陷也。 是道与器不相离，人所以异於物处。 在天地间则谓之无、谓之有，在人之身则谓之无欲、谓之有欲。 若并以无有字绝句，却亦未当。 此两者同出而异名，同谓之玄。 其名虽异，其出则同也。 玄者，深远之义，而又结之曰玄之又玄，众妙之门者，若曰是道也，冲漠无朕，至深至远，而动静阴阳之机，万事万物之变所从出也。 老子言道，先於此章，亦莫要於此章。 但吾圣贤语道，曰无声无臭无体，而不直谓之无耳。 若以下章有物混成者推之，彼岂直以道为无哉？ 言无言有，意不相害。 知道者默而识之，然后知无极而太极之言，至为精当，百世以俟圣人而不惑也。 薛庸斋曰：道可道，非常道。 寂然不动，常道也。 感而遂通，可道也。 喜怒哀乐未发谓之中，常道也。 发而皆中节谓之和，可道也。 常道体也，可道用也，自诚而明，体之於用也，自明而诚，用之於体也。 文玄先生曰：读《老子》不知体用，难与入矣。 名可名，非常名。 无名之名，常名也。 有名之名，可名也。 无名至万物之母。 道本无名，失天地，故云始。 道既有名，生万物，故云母。 常无欲至观其徼。 无名有名，言其道； 无欲有欲，言乎人。 无欲观其妙，静而观其体也。 有欲观其徼，动而观其用也。 不知体用，则徼妙皆一偏也。 此两者至同谓之玄。 自其异者视之，肝胆楚越也。 自其同者视之，万物皆一也。 若使异同一致，徼妙两忘，可以谓之玄矣。 玄也者，道之本理之极也。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 玄固难知，知则犹有所待，故以又玄捐去之。 若夫玄而不玄，物我融然，大同万化，皆由此而出矣。 休休庵曰：道可道至非常名。 虚明湛寂，无相无名，空而有灵，是谓真空； 有而无相，是谓妙有。 真空妙有，灵妙无穷，大达者尊而称之曰道，道本无言，因言显道，可以说也，非寻常之道，妙道也，大道也。 妙也者，大包无外，细入无内，无为而普应，无私无始，而灵妙无竭，无相而现一切相，无名而立一切名。 大也者，无极无上，至尊至贵，为一气之母，是三才之祖。 故无名也。 虚明无相，故无名也。 一气动而清浊判，二仪位而阴阳显，三才立焉，万物生焉，可得而名矣。 非常名者，妙道也，大道也，三才之大本也。 何谓大本？ 灵妙气清者刚，在上成象曰天； 灵妙气浊者柔，居下成形曰地； 得灵明至真中和之气，其刚柔者人也。 虚明灵妙，在人曰心，为一身之主，为万法之王，亦曰性，即命也。 天命之谓性者，久也。 无名至之母。 无相而极虚明，有灵而无声色，一气於其中发现，是谓天地之元始，三才由是而立，三生万物，故有名，万物之母，世界成矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Now that the Dao/Way has been named, how can it also be called "the Nameless" as the mother of all things?

This refers to the period **after** heaven and earth came into being—speaking of the **manifested forms** beneath the Dao/Way. The Dao/Way does not arise only at this stage. Yet once it **adheres to these forms**, it takes on **concrete traces** and a **fixed position**, standing in contrast to the Nameless when spoken of.

If one points to this as "the Named," what then is the "Nameless"? To sever the discussion with the terms "Named" and "Nameless" alone is to disrupt the logic.

The next four sentences then speak of those who embody the Dao/Way and turn inward to examine themselves. They first use the term *"without desire"* to express it—those who are perpetually without desire are **pure in Dao/Way and nature**, born in stillness. Here, one observes its **subtlety**.

*"Subtlety"* means **so refined as to be invisible**, yet when one speaks of observing it, it must be **manifest yet not obscure**, revealing what others do not know.

Those who truly understand it **always have desire**, for this is the human heart responding to external stimuli.

From birth, humans are endowed with form, and the desires of the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, and limbs all have their objects—yet they cannot be entirely absent. Here, one observes its **boundaries**.

*"Boundaries"* means **to follow through**, or the **extreme limits** of the heart’s desires, tracing where they lead without falling into ruin.

Thus, the Dao/Way and its manifestations are inseparable—what distinguishes humans from other beings.

In the realm of heaven and earth, it is called **"the Nameless"** and **"the Named."**
In the human body, it is called **"without desire"** and **"with desire."**
If one rigidly separates the terms "Named" and "Nameless," the meaning still falls short.

These two aspects, though differently named, share the same origin and are both called **"the Mysterious."**
Though their names differ, their source is one.

*"The Mysterious"* carries the meaning of **profound and distant**, and when it is said *"the Mysterious beyond the Mysterious,"* it is the **portal to all subtleties**—if one says this is the Dao/Way, it is **empty and boundless**, the most profound and distant, yet the source of all movement, stillness, yin, yang, and the transformations of all things.

When Laozi speaks of the Dao/Way, he precedes this chapter and nowhere is it more crucial than here. Yet when our sages speak of the Dao/Way, they say it is **"without sound, without scent, without form,"** yet they do not call it simply **"non-existence."**
If one follows the next chapter—*"There is something formless and complete"*—how could it be said the Dao/Way is merely non-existence?

The terms "Named" and "Nameless" do not contradict each other. Those who understand the Dao/Way **silently recognize it**, and only then do they grasp the meaning of **"the Boundless"** and **"the Supreme Polarity,"** a truth that will never confuse the ages to come.

Xue Yongzhai says:
*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the Eternal Dao/Way.
Silent and unmoving, this is the Eternal Dao/Way.
Responding and thus harmonizing, this is the Dao/Way that can be spoken of.
Before joy, anger, sorrow, and delight arise, this is the Middle—**the Eternal Dao/Way**.
When they arise yet remain measured, this is Harmony—**the Dao/Way that can be spoken of**.
The Eternal Dao/Way is its **essence**; the Dao/Way that can be spoken of is its **function**.
From sincerity comes clarity—**applying essence to function**.
From clarity comes sincerity—**applying function to essence**."*

Wen Xuanxian says:
*"To read Laozi without understanding essence and function is to make entry difficult.
The Name that can be named is not the Eternal Name.
The Nameless Name is the Eternal Name.
The Named Name is the Name that can be named.
The Nameless is the mother of all things.
The Dao/Way originally had no name; it lost heaven and earth, hence 'the beginning.'
The Dao/Way, once named, gives birth to all things, hence 'the mother.'
The Eternal 'without desire' leads to observing its subtlety.
The Nameless and Named speak of the Dao/Way;
The without desire and with desire speak of humanity.
Observing subtlety while without desire is to observe its essence in stillness.
Observing boundaries while with desire is to observe its function in action.
To fail to know essence and function is to grasp only one side—either subtlety or boundaries.
These two aspects, when seen as identical, are called 'the Mysterious.'
When viewed from their differences, they are like the liver and gallbladder, Chu and Yue.
When viewed from their unity, all things are one.
If difference and unity align, and subtlety and boundaries are both forgotten, this can be called 'the Mysterious.'
'The Mysterious' is the fundamental principle of the Dao/Way.
'The Mysterious beyond the Mysterious' is the gateway to all subtleties.
The Mysterious is difficult to know; even when known, it still depends on something, hence 'beyond the Mysterious' is discarded.
If one attains 'the Mysterious yet not the Mysterious,' subject and object merge, and the Great Harmony of all transformations emerges from this."*

Xiu Xiu An says:
*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the Eternal Name.
Empty yet luminous, tranquil yet profound—without form, without name, yet alive—this is called **True Emptiness**.
Existing yet without form—this is called **Wondrous Being**.
True Emptiness and Wondrous Being are boundlessly wondrous and profound.
Those who attain the utmost honor it as the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way originally has no words; through words, it is revealed—this can be spoken of, yet it is not the common Dao/Way. It is the **Wondrous Dao/Way**, the **Great Dao/Way**.

*'Wondrous'* means **encompassing all without exclusion**, penetrating all without omission, acting without action yet universally responsive, without selfishness or origin, yet endlessly wondrous and inexhaustible—without form yet manifesting all forms, without name yet establishing all names.

*'Great'* means **without limit, without surpassing**, the most exalted and noble—it is the mother of **One Qi** and the ancestor of the **Three Powers**.
Thus, it is **Nameless**.
It is empty and luminous, without form—thus, it is **Nameless**.
When One Qi moves, clarity and turbidity separate; when the Two Principles are positioned, yin and yang become evident; when the Three Powers are established, all things are born—now it can be named.
The Dao/Way that can be named is the **Wondrous Dao/Way**, the **Great Dao/Way**, the **Great Root** of the Three Powers.

What is the **Great Root**?
The **clear and wondrous qi** is firm—above, it forms the image of **Heaven**.
The **wondrous yet turbid qi** is yielding—below, it takes form as **Earth**.
Those who receive the **pure, true, and harmonious qi of luminous clarity** are **humanity**, where firmness and yielding balance.
Empty, luminous, and wondrous, in humans it is called **the Heart**, the sovereign of the body, the king of all things—also called **Nature**, which is **Life**.
'Nature' is what is called **Heaven’s Command**.
The Nameless is the mother of all things.
Without form yet supremely empty and luminous, alive yet without sound or color—
within it, One Qi emerges—this is called **the Primordial Origin of Heaven and Earth**.
From this, the Three Powers are established, and the Three Generations give birth to all things—
thus it is named, the **mother of all things**, and the world is complete."*

chunks.original_text: 万物虽殊，承恩一也。 大道无为，至德显矣。 道体也，德用也，用无体不生，体无用不妙，无为而有妙用者，道也。 常无至之门。 老子以自利之，皆普利世人，曰常舍诸缘，一念不生，绝无所欲以观其妙。 自妙至玄，廓达大道。 儒以大道曰大本，指其要曰喜怒哀乐未发谓之中，中字是寄宣此道也。 不可以字义伦如标月指也。 向一念未萌时，着眼乃可悟达。 释以大道曰实相、曰真如、曰如来地、曰无生法忍，指其要曰不思善不思恶，回光自看，忽然悟明。 三教之旨，见道一也。 常有欲以观其徼者，举念之际，机将发时，见闻觉知中动静施为处，返观灵变亦可悟达。 所谓常无欲，是无念，从理入； 常有欲，是有念，从事入。 有念无念，同出於心，而名异矣。 同谓之玄。 真心无相，视之不见，听之不闻。 玄之又玄者，极虚明而不可以智知，不可以识识，绝思议无譬喻，真空妙有，阴阳妙此发现，三才自此而立，万物自此而生，三纲五常、法度刑政、治世语言、工巧伎艺、资生之业、种种德行、出世经书、力量神通、光明寿量、智慧辩才、玄机妙用、清浄世界、浊恶世界，总由是而出现。 故曰众妙之门。 褚伯秀曰：道可道至之门。 道本至无，不容称道。 所可道者，御世之迹。 道本至寂，无以命之，所可名者，强为之辞。 人非生知，理籍言教，因迹明心，从权显实，使之进道复常，而阶乎玄妙也。 夫道寓於物，混成无间，此常道也。 道散为物，辩物制名，非常道也。 常道如日昱乎？ 昼光出自然而无限量。 可道如烛炳乎？ 夜光出人为而有尽也。 可名常名，其义亦然。 世以不变曰常，不知能变亦其常。 无有常而不变，无有变而不常。 究极而言之，谓大常无名，即常道常名，不涉形气，虚极神生，是为天地始。 有名即可道可名，兆萌理具，气见象陈，是为万物母。 天地始即道，万物母即天地也。 人能反观身中天地之始，而得其生生化化之主，诸幻既灭，真常犹存，则无欲、有欲皆不离道。 有欲谓最初一念善之始萌、万事万理所从出也。 无欲则真性湛然，天理冲彻、一尘不立、鬼神莫窥者也。 道之精妙，舍此何观。 徼犹边际，指成心之初，将与物接，便当反照以遏其源，善念亦不欲，况非善乎？ 无欲则寂然不动，有欲则感而遂通，体用一源，机在动静。 动静多寡，凡圣分焉。 夫妙为道本，徼为物初，生化所资不离日用，妙非绝无而旷荡也，从虚化气，有一未形者是已。 徼非实有而充塞，由静而动几微可测者是已。 细论此理，有如空虚而忽见鸢飞，水静而忽闻鱼跃，顿发深省，开天之天，飞往跃余，见闻何有。 声迹虽泯，而见见闻闻者未尝泯。 此吾之先天太极混元祖师密传心印也。 人存常心，初於此观照世念无间，可入离徼而纯归乎妙，则所谓欲者，龟毛兔角耳。 徼妙同出乎道，而理有精粗，譬夫源泉出山，润涤灌溉，善利非一，清泠澄湛，其本性也。 风日有捐，恃源无穷，常观二途，源可复矣。 玄者，道之至理，幽眇精徼。 若存此见，犹被法缚，法尚应舍，始契又玄众妙之理。 悉从此出，故谓之门。 此门无关无楗，惟知道者能入焉。 妙虽众，而皆出於玄，则众妙一妙也，一妙众妙也。 造玄者知之。
chunks.translated_text:
「Though all things differ in form, they all receive the same **Heaven’s Grace** in their origin.

The **Dao/Way** is without action, yet its **virtue/power** shines forth.
The **Dao/Way** is the **substance**; **virtue/power** is its **function**.
Without **substance**, **function** cannot arise;
without **function**, **substance** lacks **wondrous efficacy**.
To act without action yet possess **wondrous efficacy**—this is the **Dao/Way**.

The **Primordial Origin of Heaven and Earth** is the **Gate of the Nameless**.

The **Laozi** taught that even self-benefit is universal benefit for all beings,
saying: *"Always abandon all causes and conditions,
and let no thought arise—
cutting off all desires to perceive its **wondrous efficacy**.*
From **wondrous efficacy** to **the Mysterious**,
one attains the **unobstructed Dao/Way**."

The **Confucian** school calls the **Dao/Way** the **Great Origin**,
and its essence, *"**joy, anger, sorrow, and delight** yet unmanifested,"* is called **the Middle**.
The character **中 (Middle)** is but a symbol to convey this **Dao/Way**.
It cannot be understood by mere linguistic reasoning—
like pointing at the moon with a finger.

When the first thought has yet to sprout,
one must fix the gaze to suddenly awaken and comprehend.

The **Buddhist** school calls the **Dao/Way** the **Real Suchness**,
the **True Thusness**,
the **Thusness of the Tathāgata**,
and the **Dharma of Non-Birth**,
and its essence, *"**not thinking of good, not thinking of evil**,
returning the light to self-examine—
suddenly awakening to clarity."*
The principles of the **Three Teachings** converge in the **Dao/Way**.

Those who observe **wondrous efficacy** with **desire**—
at the moment when thought arises and the **mechanism** is about to unfold—
within perception, hearing, awareness, and action,
when **dynamic** and **static** interplay,
one may return to perceive the **spontaneous transformation** and thus awaken and comprehend.

**"Always without desire"** means **"without thought"**—entering through **principle**;
**"always with desire"** means **"with thought"**—entering through **affairs**.
Both **"with thought"** and **"without thought"** emerge from the **Heart**,
yet their names differ.

Both are called **the Mysterious**.
The **True Heart** is formless—
to gaze upon it, one sees nothing;
to listen to it, one hears no sound.
**The Mysterious beyond the Mysterious**—
utterly empty and luminous, beyond all **intellect** and **discernment**,
cutting off all **conceptualization** and **reasoning**, with no analogy—
**True Void, Wondrous Existence**,
where **yin** and **yang** reveal their **wondrous efficacy**,
and the **Three Powers** are established,
while all things are born.
The **Three Bonds** and **Five Constants**,
legal codes and governance,
the language of civilization,
artisan skills and crafts,
means of livelihood,
all virtues and conducts,
transcendent scriptures,
supernatural powers and **spiritual penetrations**,
radiant longevity and **life-force**,
**wisdom** and eloquence,
**wondrous mechanisms** and **functions**,
pure and luminous worlds,
and turbid and evil worlds—
all arise from this.

Thus it is called the **Gate of All Wonders**.

Zhū Bófǔxiù said:
*"The **Gate of the Dao/Way**—the **Primordial Origin**."*

The **Dao/Way** itself is **Primordial** and **Nameless**,
not to be spoken of.
What may be spoken of is but its **manifestation in the world**.
The **Dao/Way** itself is **Ultimate** and **Silent**,
beyond all naming.
What may be named is but forced words.

Humans are not born with innate knowledge—
**principle** must be conveyed through words and teachings.
Through **manifestation**, one perceives the **Heart**,
and through **convenient expedients**, one reveals the **Real**.
Thus, one advances along the **Dao/Way** and returns to its **constancy**,
ascending to **wondrous efficacy**.

The **Dao/Way** resides within all things,
intermingling without separation—
this is **the constant Dao/Way**.
The **Dao/Way** disperses as all things,
and through discriminating all things, names are established—
this is **the Dao/Way of differentiation**.

Is **the constant Dao/Way** like the sun’s brilliance at midday?
The daylight arises naturally and is boundless.

Or is it like the candle’s radiance?
The nightlight is created by humans and is limited.

Similarly, what may be spoken of or named—
its meaning is the same.

The world calls that which does not change **"the constant"**,
yet it does not know that **the ability to change** is also its **constancy**.

There is no **constancy** without change,
and no change without **constancy**.

Pushing this reasoning to its utmost:
**"Great Constancy"** is **Nameless**—
the **constancy of the Dao/Way**, the **constancy of names**,
not entangled in **form** or **qi**.
When emptiness reaches its extreme, **spiritual vitality** is born—
this is the **beginning of Heaven and Earth**.

With **name**, it may be spoken of and named—
when **principles** first emerge and **qi** reveals its **manifestations**,
this is the **origin of all things**.

The **beginning of Heaven and Earth** is the **Dao/Way**,
and the **origin of all things** is **Heaven and Earth** itself.

If humans can return to perceive within their own bodies
the **beginning of Heaven and Earth**,
and grasp the **principle of birth and transformation**—
when all illusions are extinguished,
the **True Constancy** remains—
then both **"with desire"** and **"without desire"** do not depart from the **Dao/Way**.

**"With desire"** refers to the initial sprout of a good thought,
the origin of all **affairs** and **principles**.
**"Without desire"** is when the **True Nature** is serene and undisturbed,
**Heaven’s Principle** surges through unobstructed,
not a speck of dust stands—
**ghosts and spirits** cannot even pry into it.

The **Dao/Way’s** most refined subtleties—
what else is there to observe?

**"Manifestation"** is like an **edge or boundary**,
pointing to the **initial state of the Heart**,
when it is about to interact with all things.
One must then return to perceive it
to **block its source**—
even good thoughts should not be indulged,
much less those that are not good.

**"Without desire"** is **silent** and unmoving,
**"with desire"** is responsive and thus harmonized.
**Substance** and **function** share one source,
and the **mechanism** lies in **dynamic** and **static** interplay.

The **degree** of **dynamic** and **static**—
this distinguishes **commoners** from **sages**.

**"Wondrous efficacy"** is the **essence of the Dao/Way**,
**"manifestation"** is the **initial state of all things**—
the **resources** for **birth and transformation** never stray from daily life.
**"Wondrous efficacy"** is not **utterly absent** yet **vast and empty**;
from **emptiness**, **qi** is transformed—
when there is yet **no form**, it is already present.

**"Manifestation"** is not **concrete and pervasive**;
from **stillness**, it moves—
even the slightest **impulse** can be measured.
To delve deeply into this **principle**,
one perceives as if **void** yet suddenly sees a **crow soaring**,
or **water still** yet suddenly hears a **fish leaping**—
suddenly awakening to profound insight,
one opens the **Heaven of the Heart**—
the **crow** flies beyond, the **fish** leaps away—
what is seen or heard?

Though **traces** and **sounds** may vanish,
the **perceiver** of seeing and hearing never truly vanishes.
This is the **secret transmission of the Heart-Seal** from my **Primordial Ancestor of the Supreme Ultimate and Mixed Element**.

If humans maintain **the constant Heart**,
initially observing all worldly thoughts without interruption,
they may enter the realm of **"beyond manifestation"** and return purely to **"wondrous efficacy"**,
then what is called **"desire"** is but **tortoise hair** and **rabbit horn**.

**"Manifestation"** and **"wondrous efficacy"** both emerge from the **Dao/Way**,
yet **principles** have degrees of refinement—
like a **spring** issuing from the mountains,
nourishing and irrigating all—
its benefits are countless.
Clear and pure, its **True Nature** remains.
Though **wind** and **sun** may wither it,
it relies on the **inexhaustible source**.
Always observing these two paths,
the **source** may be restored.

**"The Mysterious"** is the **ultimate principle of the Dao/Way**,
profound and subtle, refined and **manifested**.

If one holds this **perception**,
one is still bound by **dharma**.
Even **dharma** must be abandoned,
to truly grasp the **principles of the Mysterious beyond the Mysterious**.

All arise from this—
thus it is called the **Gate**.

This **Gate** has no barriers or locks,
only those who understand the **Dao/Way** may enter.

Though **wonders** are manifold,
they all emerge from **the Mysterious**—
thus **all wonders are one wonder**,
and **one wonder encompasses all wonders**.

Those who **create the Mysterious** know this.»

chunks.original_text: 牛妙传曰：道、可道至非常名。 道者，视之不见，听之不闻，虚无自然者也。 出於五太之先，鸿蒙未始，惟溟涬大梵，辽廓无光，莫可测也，当此始云太易。 太易者，谓未有气也。 渐而云太初。 太初者，谓气之兆生也。 渐而云太始。 太始者，谓有气而未成质也。 渐而云太素。 太素者，谓有质而未成形也。 渐而云太极。 太极者，谓形质已具。 既极则判，轻清之气上升为天，重浊之气下凝为地，中和之气为人，绪余土直，散而为万物。 其神功妙用，广大恢洪，莫可纪极。 太上说经，无言而言，故强为之名曰道也。 夫道者，虽有情而有性，然无思而无为，可传而不可受，可得而不可见，自本自根，未有天地，自古以固存。 神鬼神帝生天生地，在太极之先，而不为高； 在六极之下，而不为深。 然其用也，大得之而成大，小得之而成小，以言乎迩，则周流秋毫而有余焉； 以言乎远，则弥纶太虚而不足焉。 为声之声，为响之响，为形之形，为影之影，方者得而静，圆者得而动，无适而不通，无可无不可，故云可道也。 非者，无也。 常者，定也。 盖道之为用，应化多端，无有常定，在天为天，在地为地，在四序为四序，在五行为五行，太空不可言其无，品汇不可称为有，方而不规，圆而不矩，来者莫见，往焉莫追。 乾以之高，坤以之卑，云以之行，雨以之施，千变万化，无适而不有也。 老君曰：道非在我，万物皆有之。 昔东郭子问於庄子曰：道恶乎在？ 庄子曰：无往而不在。 东郭子曰：期而后可。 曰：在蝼蚁。 曰：何其下耶？ 曰：在稊稗。 曰：何其愈下耶？ 曰：在瓦甓。 曰：何其愈甚耶？ 曰：在屎溺。 盖道之为用，无乎不在，初无常定。 故非常道也。 名者道也。 或曰道本无形，何名之有？ 然以此而言之，则固有是说也。 以愚之所见，岂得无名乎？ 盖太上说经，以明夫道，着书立言，以启迪后人，不假其名，将何以言之？ 盖名不正则言不顺，是以名之耳。 《清静经》云：大道无形，生育天地； 大道无名，长养万物。 吾不知其名，强名曰道。 此庸之所以云名者道也，盖本此耳。 可名者，亦道也。 盖道之用覆天载地，高不可际，深不可测，植之则塞乎天地，横之而弥於四海，卷之而不盈一握，舒之而幎於六合，约而能张，幽而能明，柔而能刚，弱而能强，大包无外，细入毫芒，可久可大，随圆随方，万物以之各得其宜，取之无禁，用之不竭，此大道之用也。 盖道之为物，无往而不在，无适而不可，以道名之，不亦可乎？ 故云可名者亦道也，非常名者亦道也。 盖道之在天地间，万於事物无有定名，在四序则名春夏秋冬，在四大则名火风地水，於五行则名金木水火土，在五常则名仁义礼智信，在天文则名日月星辰，在地理则名山川河海，在日则名为昼夜晦明，在人则名为视听言动，在万物则名荣枯消长，在一气则名动静刚柔，名有不可胜数，多皆道之发施，初无定名，故曰非常名也。 无名，天地之始。 无者，道之体也。 盖道之为体，出於太空之先，隐乎空洞之中，无光无象，无色无名，无形无绪，无音无声，玄黄未朕，太朴未浑，但寂兮寥兮，惟恍惟惚耳。 所以经称视之不见，听之不闻。 既云不可见闻於视听，顾非无而何耶？

「The *Cow Miao* transmission states:
The **Dao/Way**, though it may be spoken of, is beyond naming as **the Unnameable**.

The **Dao/Way** is that which, when observed, is unseen,
when listened to, is unheard—
**the void** yet **naturally** existing.

Before the **Five Great**,
before **Hongmeng** (the primordial chaos) emerged,
only **Mingdang** (the boundless void) and **Daofan** (the great primal),
**vast and luminousless**,
**unfathomable**—
this is what is called **Taiyi** (the Supreme Unity).

**Taiyi** refers to **the state before qi** existed.
Gradually, it is called **Taichu** (the Primordial Origin).
**Taichu** refers to the **first stirrings of qi**.

Gradually, it is called **Taishi** (the Primordial Beginning).
**Taishi** refers to **qi** existing yet **unformed** in substance.

Gradually, it is called **Taixu** (the Primordial Purity).
**Taixu** refers to **substance** existing yet **unshaped** in form.

Gradually, it is called **Taiji** (the Primordial Polarity).
**Taiji** refers to **form and substance** already complete.

Once polarity is complete, it divides—
**light and clear qi** ascends to become **Heaven**,
**heavy and turbid qi** condenses below to become **Earth**,
**harmonious central qi** becomes **Humanity**,
and the **remaining essence** disperses,
giving rise to **all things**.

Its **divine functions and wondrous operations** are **boundless and vast**,
**inexhaustible**—
**no measure or limit**.

The **Supreme Sage** expounds the scriptures,
**speaking without words**,
thus forcibly naming it the **Dao/Way**.

The **Dao/Way**, though possessing **emotion** and **nature**,
**lacks thought** and **action**—
**transmissible yet unreceived**,
**obtainable yet invisible**,
**self-originating and self-rooted**,
existing **before Heaven and Earth**,
**since ancient times** unchanging.

**Gods and spirits, divine emperors**—
those who **generate Heaven and Earth**,
exist **before Taiji** yet are **not exalted**;
they exist **beneath the Six Extremes** yet are **not profound**.
Yet in their **operations**,
**greatly** receiving it yields **greatness**,
**slightly** receiving it yields **smallness**—
when spoken of in **proximity**,
it **pervades autumnal hairs** with abundance;
when spoken of in **distance**,
it **encompasses the great void** yet is **insufficient**.

It is **the sound of sound**,
**the echo of echoes**,
**the form of forms**,
**the shadow of shadows**—
the **square** receives it and becomes **still**,
the **round** receives it and becomes **active**.
**Without bias**, yet **omnipresent**,
**without constraint**, yet **unrestricted**—
thus it is called **the Speakable**.

The **Unnameable** is **the Nonexistent**.
The **Constant** is **the Unchanging**.

The **Dao/Way’s operations** are **multifarious and adaptive**,
**without fixed constancy**—
in **Heaven**, it is **Heaven**,
in **Earth**, it is **Earth**,
in the **Four Seasons**, it is the **Four Seasons**,
in the **Four Great Elements**, it is **Fire, Wind, Earth, Water**,
in the **Five Phases**, it is **Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth**,
in the **Five Constants**, it is **Benevolence, Righteousness, Propriety, Wisdom, Trust**,
in **celestial phenomena**, it is the **Sun, Moon, Stars, and Constellations**,
in **terrestrial geography**, it is the **Mountains, Rivers, and Seas**,
in the **day**, it is **day and night, obscurity and clarity**,
in **humanity**, it is **seeing, hearing, speaking, and acting**,
in **all things**, it is **flourishing and withering, decay and growth**,
in **one breath of qi**, it is **movement and stillness, hardness and softness**.
Names are **innumerable**—
most are **emanations of the Dao/Way**,
**without fixed designation**,
thus it is called **the Unnameable**.

**The Unnameable** is the **beginning of Heaven and Earth**.
**The Nonexistent** is the **substance of the Dao/Way**.

The **Dao/Way’s substance** emerges **before Taiyi**,
**hidden within the void**,
**without light or image**,
**without color or name**,
**without form or trace**,
**without tone or sound**—
before **Minghuang** (the indistinct) and **Taipu** (the undifferentiated) arose,
before **the great simplicity** became **mixed**,
it is but **silent and desolate**,
**only hazy and indistinct**.

Thus the scriptures say:
*"Observed, it is unseen;
listened to, it is unheard."*

If it is **unseen and unheard** by **sight and sound**,
then what else is it but **the Nonexistent**?»

chunks.original_text: 老君曰：道象无形端，恍惚亡若存。 譬如种木，未生时不见枝叶根，此皆无之为说也。 始者亦道也。 当其太易太始之时，天地未根，日月未光，幽幽冥冥，无祖无宗，三色混沌，乍存乍亡，迨至运推数极，三气开光，气清高澄，积阳成天，气结凝渍，积滞成地，九气列正，日月星宿，阴阳五行，人民品物，并受生成，此庸之所以谓天地之始乃道也，本此说耳。 有名，万物之母。 有者，道之用也。 盖道之为用，从不有中有。 夫不有者，无也，无则必有有者，太极是也。 太极判而然后有天地，有天地然后有万物，有万物然后有男女，有男女然后有夫妇，有夫妇然后有君臣，有君臣然后有上下，悉自无而方有。 自无而有也，非道而何耶？ 故云有者道之用也。 母者道也，何以言之？ 《易系》曰盈天地之间者万物。 且如根荄而植，柯叶而茂，芽而萌，穗而实，翼而飞，足而走，鳞而跃，喙而鸣且啄，息而食且啮，千态万状，皆自道而生。 夫谚称生我者父母。 今既云万物之母，非道而何。 《内观经》云：有以无为母，无以虚为母，虚以道为母。 道者，万物之母也。 是非之谓欤。 常无欲以观其妙。 常无者，道之体也。 盖大道之体，故常於无，当其混沌太无之时，在上则无高天，无日月，无星辰，无云霞，无雾露，无雷霆，无风雨，无霜雪，不过杳杳而冥冥，在下则无厚地，无山川，无河海，无溪谷，无草木，无兽无禽，无人无邦国，不过默默而昏昏。 乃大道之体，故云常无也。 妙者，道之体也。 前所谓常无之说是也。 常无者，谓其寂然不动也。 然其寂然不动之体，渊微莫测，蕴奥难见，此其所以云常无耳。 然夫此理人皆有之，但於妄念顿除之顷，默然静坐之时，心若太虚，一毫无翳，当此之际，道即我矣，我即道也。 岂不妙欤。 欲观者，谓探索其蕴奥也。 常有欲以观其徼。 常有者，道之用也。 谓混茫分判，天地裁形，三光棋布於上穹，五纬经躔於分度，阴阳升降，寒暑往来，雨露沾濡，风雷号令，五行生克，四序推迁，至如九州八纮，五湖四海，国王侯伯，乡社人民，草木山川，群类万物，常盈於天地之间，皆道气周流不息，方能常有，故云常有者，道之用也。 徼者，道之用也。 前所谓常有之说是也。 然则何谓常有哉？ 如天长地久，四时行，百物生，未尝有一息愆期，故云常有也。 且人身者，号小天地也，头圆象天，足方象地，目号日月，发为星辰，四时五行、阴阳升降、卉木丛林，万物皆备，人能观夫道之体、道之用而行之，则此身即道也，道即此身矣。 此两者至之玄。 两者，谓徼妙二字，本同一个道字上流出，故立异名以彰其体用，故云同谓之玄也。 然道之为体，虽杳冥无形，然有体则必有用也，如无极者乃其体也，太极乃其用也。 体者静也，用者动也。 何以言之？ 濂汉曰：无极而太极，太极动而生阳，动极而静，静而生阴，静极复动，动极复静，一动一静，互为其根。 合而言之，乃道也。 故曰同谓之玄也。 玄之至之门。 此太上赞道之辞也。 玄者，谓道之为物，微妙难思，心困焉不能知，口辟焉莫能辩，竭西江之水不足以书其善，穷宇宙之口不足以称其玄。 难议难思，至玄至妙，一言以蔽，故云玄之又玄也。
chunks.translated_text:
「The Venerable Lord Lao said: The **Dao/Way’s** manifestation is **formless and subtle**,
**hazy and indistinct yet somehow present**.

Like planting a tree,
when it has not yet sprouted, one does not see branches, leaves, or roots—
these are all examples of **the Nonexistent**.

**The Beginning** is also the **Dao/Way**.
In the time of **Taiyi** and **Tai Shi** (the Great Beginning),
**Heaven and Earth** lacked roots,
**the sun and moon** lacked light,
**dark and obscure**, **without origin or lineage**,
the **Three Colors** (三色 *sān sè*) in **chaotic mixture**,
now appearing, now vanishing—
until the **cosmic cycles** (*yùn tuī shù jí*) reached their utmost,
when the **Three Qi** (三气 *sān qì*) illuminated,
**clear and high**,
**accumulated yang** formed **Heaven**,
**congealed and settled qi** formed **Earth**,
the **Nine Qi** aligned in order,
**the sun, moon, and stars**,
**yin and yang, the Five Phases**,
**people and things**—
all received their birth and formation,
thus the common saying that **Heaven and Earth’s beginning** is **the Dao/Way**,
originating from this very explanation.

**The Named** is the **mother of all things**.
**The Existent** is the **function/operation** of the **Dao/Way**.

For the **Dao/Way’s function/operation** arises from **the Nonexistent**.
The **Nonexistent** is **the Nonexistent**,
but from **the Nonexistent** must come **the Existent**—
**Tai Ji** (the Supreme Polarity) is this.

**Tai Ji** divides,
and then **Heaven and Earth** exist;
**Heaven and Earth** exist,
and then **all things** exist;
**All things** exist,
and then **male and female** exist;
**Male and female** exist,
and then **husband and wife** exist;
**Husband and wife** exist,
and then **lords and ministers** exist;
**Lords and ministers** exist,
and then **high and low** exist—
all derive from **the Nonexistent** before they come into being.
If they derive from **the Nonexistent** before they come into being,
what else is it but **the Dao/Way**?
Thus it is said that **the Existent** is the **function/operation** of the **Dao/Way**.

**Mother** is the **Dao/Way**—
how so?

*The **Yijing System** says:
*"All things under Heaven and Earth are full of it."*

Take, for instance, the **roots and stems** that grow and **branches and leaves** that flourish,
**buds that sprout** and **ears that bear fruit**,
**wings that fly** and **feet that walk**,
**scales that leap** and **beaks that peck and cry**,
**breath that nourishes** and **teeth that bite**—
in **thousands of forms and ten thousand states**,
all arise from **the Dao/Way**.

The common saying goes:
*"That which gives birth to me is my parents."*
Now, since it is said that **the Dao/Way** is the **mother of all things**,
what else could it be but **the Dao/Way**?

*The **Scripture of Inner Observation** says:
*"The Nonexistent is the mother of the Existent,
the Nonexistent is the mother of the Void,
the Void is the mother of the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way is the mother of all things."*

Thus, **the Dao/Way** is **the mother of all things**—
is this not so?

**The Way’s substance** is **always the Nonexistent** to observe its **miraculous subtlety**.
**The Always-Nonexistent** is the **Dao/Way’s substance**.

For the **Great Dao’s substance** is always in **the Nonexistent**,
when in **utterly chaotic void**,
above, there is **no high Heaven**,
no **sun and moon**,
no **stars, clouds, or mists**,
no **dew, thunder, or lightning**,
no **wind or rain**,
no **frost or snow**—
only **dim and boundless**,
**dark and obscure**.

Below, there is **no thick Earth**,
no **mountains or rivers**,
no **lakes or seas**,
no **streams or valleys**,
no **grasses or trees**,
no **beasts or birds**,
no **people or nations**—
only **silent and murky**,
**deep and indistinct**.

Thus, the **Great Dao’s substance** is **always the Nonexistent**,
and this is why it is said.

**Miraculous subtlety** is the **Dao/Way’s substance**—
this is the explanation given earlier.

**The Always-Nonexistent** means **its still and unmoving nature**.
Yet its **still and unmoving substance** is **profound and unfathomable**,
**concealed and difficult to perceive**—
this is why it is called **the Always-Nonexistent**.

But this principle is **inherent in all people**,
only when **delusive thoughts are suddenly eradicated**,
and one **sits in silent repose**,
the **mind like the Great Void**,
**without the slightest obstruction**—
at this moment,
**the Dao/Way is I**,
**I am the Dao/Way**.
Is this not **miraculous subtlety**?

To observe it means **to probe its concealed depths**.

**The Existent** is **always present** to observe its **boundless operation**.
**The Always-Existent** is the **function/operation** of the **Dao/Way**—
it refers to the **mixed and divided**,
**Heaven and Earth** taking form,
the **Three Lights** (*Sān Guāng*) arrayed in the **upper vault**,
the **Five Venerable Stars** (*Wǔ Wéi*) traversing their **degrees**,
**yin and yang** ascending and descending,
**cold and heat** passing in turn,
**rain and dew** nourishing,
**wind and thunder** commanding—
the **Five Phases** generating and overcoming,
the **Four Seasons** shifting in succession—
even the **Nine Regions and Eight Directions**,
the **Five Lakes and Four Seas**,
**kings, lords, and vassals**,
**villages and communities**,
**grasses, trees, mountains, and rivers**,
**all classes and myriad things**—
**constantly filling Heaven and Earth**,
all arising from the **Dao/Way’s qi** flowing ceaselessly,
thus it is said that **the Always-Existent** is the **function/operation** of the **Dao/Way**.

**Boundless operation** is the **function/operation** of the **Dao/Way**—
this is the explanation given earlier.

Then what is **the Always-Existent**?
Like **Heaven’s longevity and Earth’s duration**,
the **Four Seasons** proceeding,
**hundreds of things** flourishing—
**never once failing to fulfill its appointed time**,
thus it is called **the Always-Existent**.

Moreover, the **human body** is called **a lesser Heaven and Earth**,
the **head round** like **Heaven**,
the **feet square** like **Earth**,
the **eyes** named **sun and moon**,
the **hair** as **stars and constellations**,
the **Four Seasons and Five Phases**,
**yin and yang** ascending and descending,
**plants and forests**—
all things are complete.
If one can observe **the Dao/Way’s substance and function** and act accordingly,
then **this body is the Dao/Way**,
**the Dao/Way is this body**.

This is the **uttermost profundity of the two** (*liǎng zhě*).
The **two**—meaning **boundless operation and miraculous subtlety**—
both flow from the **same single Dao/Way**,
thus distinct names are established to **illustrate its substance and function**,
and it is said that **they are both called the Profound**.

Yet **the Dao/Way’s substance**, though **dim and obscure without form**,
must necessarily have **function/operation**—
**the Nonexistent** is its **substance**,
**Tai Ji** is its **function/operation**.

**Substance** is **stillness**,
**function/operation** is **movement**—
how so?

**Meng Han** said:
*"From the Nonexistent comes Tai Ji,
Tai Ji moves and generates yang,
movement reaches its limit and becomes still,
stillness and it generates yin,
stillness reaches its limit and moves again,
movement reaches its limit and becomes still again—
each movement and each stillness
mutually serve as their roots.
Together, they are called the Dao/Way."*
Thus it is said that **they are both called the Profound**.

The **gateway to the Profound**—
this is the **Supreme Lord’s** praise of the **Dao/Way**.

**The Profound** refers to **the Dao/Way** as an entity,
**so subtle and miraculous it defies thought**,
the **mind is confounded** and cannot know it,
the **mouth is stilled** and cannot speak of it—
exhausting the **waters of the Western River** would not suffice to write its **virtue/power**,
and **all mouths in the universe** would not suffice to articulate its **profound subtlety**.

**Difficult to discuss and difficult to think**,
**utterly profound and utterly miraculous**—
in a single word,
thus it is called **the Profound of the Profound** (*xuán zhī yòu xuán*).」

before **Minghuang** (the indistinct) and **Taipu** (the undifferentiated) arose,

chunks.original_text: 众妙者，万物也； 门者，理也； 理者，道也。 且夫天地之间，凡一物各有一理，凡一理各有一门，门者出入之户也。 孔子曰：谁能出不由户？ 何莫由斯道也。 世称八万四千门，门各有其理，独此一门，万理兼该，无物不备，称众妙之门也。 杨智仁曰：道可道至之门。 道者本无名字，始先天而不为始，终后天而不为终。 可道则非也。 常道者，日用常行皆道也，饮食衣服、卧具医药皆道也。 名者，天地未始无名可称。 古云唤作一物即不中，若可名即非谓道也。 名者，曰天地、曰日月、曰阴阳、曰万物、曰人、曰鬼，皆谓之常名也。 无名天地之始者，乃无极也。 无极动而生阳，静而生阴，故谓之无极，谓之始也。 有者，太极也。 形象备见，是太极判而一生二，二生三，三生万物也。 天无欲而四炁朗清，人无欲而湛然常寂，此乃返观之妙也。 人若有欲者，於应机接物之间，无忘回光返照，此两者同出而异名者也。 乃曰用发生动静之间，玄妙备於斯矣。 庄子曰：夫道者，有情有性，无为无形，可传而不可受，可得而不可见。 自本自根，未有天地，自古以固存。 神鬼神帝生天生地，在太极之先而不为高，在六极之下而不为深。 先天地而不为久，长於上古而不为老，天地虽大，其化均也。 万物虽多，其治一也。 人卒虽众，其主君也。 君厚於德而成於天，故曰玄古之君，天下无为也。 天德而已矣。 以道观言而天下之君正，以道观分而君臣之义明，以道观能而天下之君治，以道泛观而万物之应备。 故通於天地者，德也，行於万物者，道也。 道德真经集义卷之三竟 ＃1 今之持者画不操烛者：『画』疑当作『昼』。 道德真经集义卷之四 凝远大师常德路玄妙观
chunks.translated_text:
「All the myriad wonders—
these are the **ten thousand things** (*wànwù*); the **gateway**—
this is **principle** (*lǐ*).

**Principle** is the **Dao/Way**.

Now, between heaven and earth,
every single thing has its **principle**,
every single **principle** has its **gateway**,
and the **gateway** is the **portal** for entry and exit.

Confucius said:
*"Who can exit without passing through the door?"*
Thus, **what could be more fitting than this Dao/Way**?

The world speaks of **eighty-four thousand gateways** (*bā wàn sì qiān mén*),
each with its own **principle**,
yet this single **gateway** alone
encompasses all **principles**,
nothing is omitted—
thus it is called the **gateway to all wonders**.

Yang Zhìrén said:
*"This is the **gateway to the Profound of the Dao/Way**."*

The **Dao/Way** is originally nameless,
beginning before heaven and earth yet not being their **origin**,
ending after heaven and earth yet not being their **termination**.
If it can be named, then it is not the **Dao/Way**.

The **constant Dao/Way**—
daily life and habitual practice are all the **Dao/Way**,
drinking and eating, clothing and shelter,
sleeping, medicine, and all else—
these are all the **Dao/Way**.

**Names**—
heaven and earth were not originally without names to be called.
The ancients said:
*"If you name it, it is no longer the **Dao/Way**;
if it can be named, then it is not the **Dao/Way** itself."*

**Names**—
such as **heaven and earth**,
**sun and moon**,
**yin and yang**,
**ten thousand things**,
**human**,
**spirit**—
these are all called **common names**.

The **Dao/Way** without name at the **beginning** of heaven and earth—
this is the **Non-Extreme** (*Wújí*).
The **Non-Extreme** moves and gives rise to **yang**,
is still and gives rise to **yin**,
thus it is called the **Non-Extreme**,
thus it is called the **beginning**.

The **Extreme**—
this is the **Supreme Lord** (*Tàijí*).
Its **forms and manifestations** are fully visible;
this is the **Supreme Lord** dividing into **one**,
**one** generating **two**,
**two** generating **three**,
and **three** generating the **ten thousand things**.

Heaven, without **desire** (*yù*), has the **Four Qi** (*sìqì*) clear and bright,
Humans, without **desire**, are serene and ever at peace—
this is the **miracle of returning light** (*fǎn guāng fǎn zhào*) to observe.

If humans have **desire**,
then in their **interactions with circumstances** and **engagements with things**,
they must never forget the **returning light** to illuminate—
these two are **same in origin yet different in name**.

Thus it is said:
*"Within the arising of movement and stillness,*
the **profound subtlety** is fully manifested here."

Zhuangzi said:
*"The **Dao/Way**—
it has **sentience** and **character**,
yet does nothing and takes no form.
It can be **transmitted** yet cannot be **received**,
can be **obtained** yet cannot be **seen**.
From its **root and origin**,
before heaven and earth existed,
since ancient times it has always been so.

**Spirits and deities**, **divine lords and sovereigns**,
give birth to heaven and earth,
existing before the **Supreme Lord** yet not being **high**,
existing beneath the **Six Extremes** yet not being **deep**.

Existing before heaven and earth yet not being **eternal**,
enduring beyond the **upper antiquity** yet not being **ancient**—
though heaven and earth are vast,
their **transformations** are **uniform**;
though the **ten thousand things** are many,
their **governance** is **one**;
though humans are numerous,
their **master** is the **sovereign** (*jūn*).

The **sovereign** is **thick with virtue** and **complete in heaven**,
thus it is called the **profound ancient sovereign** (*Xuángǔ zhī jūn*).
Under the **Dao/Way**, the **sovereign** is **without action**—
this is the **virtue/power of heaven** alone.

Observing the **Dao/Way** in **governance** clarifies the **sovereign’s rectitude**,
observing the **Dao/Way** in **division** makes the **duties of lord and subject** clear,
observing the **Dao/Way** in **capacity** brings the **sovereign’s governance** to completion,
observing the **Dao/Way** broadly reveals the **response of all things** fully.

Thus, what **permeates heaven and earth**—
this is **virtue/power** (*dé*).
What **operates among the ten thousand things**—
this is the **Dao/Way** (*dào*).

The *Zhāngyǒng* (*True Scripture of Dao and Virtue*) *Collection of Meanings*—
**Volume Three** ends.
**Volume Four**—
**Master Yōngyuǎn**’s *Observation of the Profound Subtlety of the Constant Dao/Way*.

chunks.original_text: 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易东校正 道可道章 喻清中曰：道可道至之门。 道者，太极之全体，万理之总名。 鸿蒙肇判，鳌极既奠，强而名之曰道。 其所谓道，未尝不可道也，而道之精微、道之玄妙，则非常人之所能道。 天地亦道中之一物，有一物必具一名。 轻清而上浮者则谓之天，重浊而下载者则谓之地，昭乎可睹者为日月，灿然有象者为星辰，人皆得而名之，而其所以轻清、所以重浊、所以久照而不息，其理安在，常人孰得而名之？ 夫子言性与天道，以子贡之闻一知二，且不可得而闻，况不如子贡者乎？ 闻且不可，况得而拟议之乎？ 呜呼，夫子圣人也，子贡其常常者耳，程伊川尝指食卓问邵康节曰：此卓安在地上？ 不知天地，安在何处？ 康节为之极论其理，以至六合之外。 伊川叹曰：平生唯见周茂叔论至此。 康节之子伯温记之，但云极论而不言所论云何，使后之学者竟莫得闻其梗栗，此岂常人之所能道、常人之所能名耶？ 太极未分，冲漠未朕，其名未立，故曰无名，天地之始。 始者，指其初而言也。 名既立矣，阴阳有阴阳之名，万物有万物之名，则千变万化皆自此而出，千条万端皆自此而生，故曰有名，万物之母。 母者，生之所自出也。 犹坤称母，万物资生之谓也。 常无常有，是句读。 道之为物静无而动有，不於无处，不足以见其妙，不於有处，不足以见其徼。 妙，玄也，要也，又微之极也。 徼，边隅也，大道边有小路曰徼。 徼，归也。 欲者，要如此也。 善学道者，常於无时就无上究竟者，盖欲观其极致之妙； 常於有时就有上究竟者，盖欲观其旁出之徼。 有无对待，同出异名，皆谓之玄。 玄者，妙之极，不可以言语形容也，不特谓之玄，而曰玄之又玄。 亘古今，穷天地，妙有万不同，出而有出，此门也，入而无入，此门也。 庸斋林氏释此章，谓道本不容言，才涉有言，皆是第二义。 常者，不变不易之谓也。 可道可名，则有变有易； 不可道不可名，则无变无易。 其说高矣。 子细玩味，谓可道者非常久之道，则可谓可名者非常久之名，则未可盍於下文有名万物之母一句，微有窒碍故也。 大槩道字静而重，可道常道二道字动而轻，名字亦然。 此章居一经之首，老子示人之大旨，学者造道之极功，皆基於此，谈经者宜紬绎之。 胥六虚曰：道可道，非常道。 道开仰触讳了也，如未解且听为蛇画足矣。 原夫混混沌沌，无形无名，开辟以来，自古固存，大智不能测，神口莫能言，圣人默而知之，不忍后世无闻，强以道字为无形无名者之寓，使得有可称，而通达於后学也，故曰道。 取其通达之义。 虽然，此既其文，而未既其实耳。 实之一字，须要各人自诚自悟自证其於道也，方有实用。 若然者，可与天地并久，可与日月并明。 否则，惟事文理言论为至，犹寒者说衣绞锦，饥者言饱珍羞，是则美人听闻，全无实济其於道也，岂能常存乎？ 故经曰道可道，非常道。 可道既非常道，则道之一字分晓，要人自得之耳。 名可名，非常名。 夫道之一字，亦是无形无名者之名也，如不造其实，惟徇其名可名之名飘风然骤雨然，焉能久而不已哉？ 无名，天地之始。 言天地之始，始於无名者也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter: "The Dao/Way That Can Be Spoken Of"**

Master Liu Weiyong, appointed to oversee and compile,
Formerly honored as *Grand Secretary* and *Clerk of the Treasury*,
Concurrently *Editor of the Secretariat*,
Ding Yidong, *Inspector of the Imperial Academy*, verified the text.

*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of"*—
Master Yucheng said: *"The gateway to the Dao/Way that can be spoken of."*

The Dao/Way—
the complete essence of the *Supreme Ultimate*,
the all-encompassing name of ten thousand principles.
From *Hun-Meng*’s primordial division,
to the settled *Aoxi*’s foundation,
it was named *Dao/Way* for its strength.
What is called the Dao/Way
has never been beyond speech—
yet its profound subtlety, its ineffable mystery,
are beyond what ordinary mortals can articulate.

Heaven and earth are but one thing within the Dao/Way;
where there is a thing, there must be a name.
That which is light and clear, ascending—
this is called *Heaven*;
that which is heavy and turbid, descending—
this is called *Earth*.
What is manifest and visible—
the sun and moon;
what is radiant and patterned—
the stars and constellations.
All may name them—
yet why they are light and clear,
why they are heavy and turbid,
why they endure in luminosity without ceasing—
what principle underlies this?
Who among ordinary folk can name it?

The Master spoke of *human nature* and the *Dao/Way of Heaven*;
even Zigong, with his *hearing one thing and knowing two*,
could not grasp it—
how much less those who fall short of Zigong?
If even *hearing* it is impossible,
how could one presume to discuss it?

Ah! The Master was a Sage—
Zigong merely a common scholar.
Program Yi-chuan once pointed to a table and asked Shao Kangzhe:
*"Where is this table located?"*
*"Where is Heaven and Earth?"*
Kangzhe expounded its principle to the utmost,
even beyond the six directions.
Yi-chuan sighed:
*"All my life, only Zhou Moshu has spoken thus."*
Kangzhe’s son, Bo-wen, recorded it—
yet only said *"he expounded to the utmost"* without detailing what was said,
so later scholars could never grasp its essence.
Could this be what ordinary mortals can speak of,
what ordinary mortals can name?

Before the *Supreme Ultimate* divided,
before *Yin-Yang*’s indistinctness took form,
no name had yet been established—
thus it was called *the Nameless*,
the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
*Beginning*—
speaking of its first emergence.

Once names were established,
Yin and Yang had the names *Yin* and *Yang*,
the ten thousand things had their respective names—
thus all transformations and changes arose from this,
all myriad branches and tendrils sprang from this.
Hence it was called *the Named*,
the *Mother of the Ten Thousand Things*.
*Mother*—
that from which all things derive their birth.
Just as *Kun* is called *Mother*,
for it is the source from which all things draw sustenance.

*"Constantly without, yet constantly with"*—
this is the punctuation.

The Dao/Way as a thing is still yet dynamic,
not to be found in mere *nothingness*—
for then its wonder would not be seen;
not to be found in mere *somethingness*—
for then its periphery would not be glimpsed.
*Wonder*—
the utmost *profound*, the utmost *essential*,
the extreme of subtlety.
*Periphery*—
the borderlands, where the Great Dao’s edge meets lesser paths, called *jiao*.
*Jiao*—
also *return*.
To *seek*—
this is to *aspire*.

Those who study the Dao/Way well
constantly, in *timelessness*, pursue the *supreme ultimate*—
for they seek to observe its utmost wonder;
constantly, in *timeliness*, pursue the *supreme ultimate*—
for they seek to observe its peripheral paths.

*Nothingness* and *somethingness* oppose yet arise together,
same source, different names—
both are called *profound*.
*Profound*—
the extreme of wonder,
beyond speech or description,
not merely *profound*, but *profound yet more profound*.

Spanning antiquity and eternity,
exhausting Heaven and Earth,
wonderfully manifold yet differing—
emerging, it emerges;
entering, it does not enter—
this is the *gateway*.

Master Lin of Yongzhai interpreted this chapter:
*"The Dao/Way is originally beyond speech;
once speech is applied, all is secondary meaning."*

*Constant*—
unchanging, unalterable.
What can be spoken of, what can be named—
this is change, this is alteration;
what cannot be spoken of, what cannot be named—
this is no change, no alteration.
His reasoning is lofty—
yet upon close reflection,
if *"what can be spoken of"* is not the *eternal Dao/Way*,
then *"what can be named"* is not the *eternal Name*—
this may conflict with the later phrase *"the Named, Mother of the Ten Thousand Things."*

The character *Dao* in *"The Dao/Way"* is static and weighty;
the *Dao/Way* in *"can be spoken of"* and *"constant Dao/Way"* is dynamic and light—
the same for *name*.
This chapter opens the *Scripture*—
Laozi’s grand intent for all who study.
Those who seek the Dao/Way’s utmost foundation
must begin here.
Scholars of the *Scripture* should ponder it deeply.

Xu Liu said:
*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of—
this is not the eternal Dao/Way."*
The Dao/Way opens to reverence, touching the taboo—
like one who does not yet understand
but merely hears and draws a snake’s foot.

Originally, *Hun-Meng* was formless, nameless—
since the opening of creation,
anciently enduring,
beyond the grasp of great wisdom,
beyond the speech of divine mouths.
The Sage knew it in silence,
yet could not bear for later ages to remain ignorant—
thus, he named it *Dao/Way* as a metaphor for the formless, the nameless,
so that it might be accessible,
transmitted to later learners.
Hence it was called *Dao/Way*.
Taking its meaning of *transmission*.

Yet even so,
this is but its *form*—
not yet its *reality*.
The *reality* of a single character
must be personally verified in sincerity, enlightenment, and self-attainment.
Only then does it have true application.
If so,
one may endure alongside Heaven and Earth,
shine alongside the sun and moon.
Otherwise,
merely discussing texts, theories, and words—
like the cold speaking of silk brocade,
the hungry speaking of feasts—
this pleases the ears of the beautiful,
yet offers no real benefit to the Dao/Way.
How could it endure?

Thus the *Scripture* says:
*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of—
this is not the eternal Dao/Way."*
Since what can be spoken of is not the eternal Dao/Way,
then the character *Dao* is clarified—
it is for the seeker to attain it themselves.

*"The Name that can be named—
this is not the eternal Name."*
The character *Dao* itself
is but the name for the formless, the nameless.
If one does not attain its reality,
merely clinging to the *name* that can be named—
like the wind, like a sudden rain—
how could it endure without ceasing?

*"The Nameless—
the beginning of Heaven and Earth."*
Speaking of Heaven and Earth’s origin—
their origin lies in the *Nameless*.

chunks.original_text: 有名，万物之母。 言自有天地之名，事事物物皆由斯道而生。 母，生也。 此两则语，乃圣人勉人穷理尽性之大旨。 吁，人生与天地一也。 如母之理奚殊焉，胡为不究哉？ 故常无欲至观其徼。 此二句，圣人为后世开示悟入之门，俾学者於此探索，必有所造。 何哉？ 常乃常道也。 无欲有欲，常道之动静也。 观，察也。 妙，微妙也。 徼，归也。 晏子曰：徼也者，德之归也。 夫寂然闲居，无思无虑，常道之静也。 於此可以察见常道微妙之本体，故曰常无欲以观其妙。 有感即通，应事接物，常道之动也。 於此可以察见常道应变功用之所归，故曰常有欲以观其徼。 明其体，达其用，知其归，圣人之学备矣。 苟不知其归，流而忘返，众人也。 知体而不知其用，一偏之士也。 未悟其体而能饰其用者，理学也。 体用两明，千转万变，道无不在者，至学也。 此两者同出而异名。 此两者，乃指前有无，妙徼也。 同者，同於常道也。 异名，则两者之名也。 常道未发，无有无妙徼之分，是所同也。 发出则有无妙徼之名列矣，是所异也。 故曰出而异名。 同谓之玄。 人能知是两者未发之同，可谓学造深远矣。 玄，深远也，故曰同谓之玄。 夫行远者必有所至，今所造虽远，然未有至处，则所造未至乎极。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 又玄则所造之至极矣，至极则谓之众妙之门也。 众妙之门，五千至言无量妙义，悉由是出。 圣人开是门者，意其后学有进入之望，过门而不入者，固不在言。 倚门而议者，常有之也。 言至于此，呵呵踊跃，不知手之舞之，足之蹈之矣。 李是从曰：道可道至之门。 道存心中，日用平常，随机应变，无处不在，安静无为，是真常之道也。 可以别外妄求有为，动乱其心，执着他事者，非其平常之道也。 道本无名，从此一气生出天地万物。 有名，为万物之母也。 人心未兆，无知巧拙，造出万般器物立名，是心生为万物之母也。 常无欲以观其妙，常有欲以观其徼者，常无爱欲，回光返照，以观其本性，真妙也； 常有欲以观其求生行径，循徼也。 此两者同出而异名者，无欲入於静，有欲出於动，动静机同其本原，故有异名也。 同谓之玄者，同其本心，未发彰时，难料也。 玄之又玄者，常人之心难测，况圣人之心乎？ 机怀深奥，探赜不得也。 众妙之门者，应变万事从此出，妙用则无穷也。 苏敬静曰：道可道至非常名。 道，天之道也； 名，道之名也。 天之道如可指为世人之道，则非吾常行之道也； 道之名如可指为世人之名，则非吾常用之名也。 天道一自然，而世人之道则有帝道、王道、霸道之殊； 道之名一清静，而世人之名则有仁义礼智信之异。 老氏道为自然，名为清静，固与世人之所谓道，所谓名不同也。 老氏生於衰周，盖见当时王道已衰，霸道将起，思以天道自然为治，见当时礼为忠信之薄，而乱之首，若仁若义，若智若信，壹是纷纷，思以清静无为为化，故有非常道、非常名之言。 其学至汉文、曹参用之，能致安静之效、宁一之歌。 西晋不善用之，而稔成清谈之祸，亦各随其所用之何如耳。 无名至万物之母。 太极、浑沦、天地且无名，非天地之始乎？ 虽未有天地，而天地已具於太极之内，故曰天地之始。
chunks.translated_text:
「Having a name, the mother of all things.
Speaking of the origin of Heaven and Earth’s names,
all things and events arise from this Dao/Way.
Mother—this is the act of giving birth.
These two lines express the sage’s great intent
to urge people to exhaust principles and perfect their nature.
Ah, human life is one with Heaven and Earth.
What difference is there in the principle of the mother?
Why do they not investigate it?

Thus it is said:
*"Always without desire, observe its subtlety.*
These two sentences, the sage opens
the gate of awakening for later generations,
so that students may explore here
and surely attain some realization.
Why so?
Constant—this is the eternal Dao/Way.
Without desire and with desire,
the stillness and motion of the eternal Dao/Way.
Observe—this is to scrutinize.
Mysterious—this is the profound subtlety.
Subtlety—this is the return.
Yan Zi said:
*"Subtlety is the return of virtue/power.*
In tranquil repose, without thought or care,
this is the stillness of the eternal Dao/Way.
Here one can discern the eternal Dao/Way’s
profound subtlety in its original essence,
thus it is said: *‘Always without desire, observe its subtlety.’*
With sensation comes understanding;
responding to affairs and engaging with things—
this is the motion of the eternal Dao/Way.
Here one can perceive the eternal Dao/Way’s
adaptive functions and their ultimate return,
thus it is said: *‘Always with desire, observe its subtlety.’*
Clarifying its essence, comprehending its functions,
knowing its return—
the sage’s learning is complete.
If one does not know its return,
wandering and forgetting the way back—
this is the common folk.
Knowing the essence but not its functions,
this is a one-sided scholar.
Not yet awakened to its essence
yet able to adorn its functions—
this is scholasticism.
When essence and function are both illuminated,
through myriad transformations and changes,
the Dao/Way is nowhere absent—
this is the highest learning.
These two share a common origin yet differ in name.
These two, pointing to the prior *having* and *not having*,
profound subtlety and return—
their commonality lies in the eternal Dao/Way.
Differing in name, yet these two names arise,
thus it is said: *‘They share an origin yet differ in name.’*
The eternal Dao/Way, before its manifestation,
has no distinction of *having* or *not having*,
profound subtlety or return—
this is their commonality.
Once manifested, it has the names of *not having* and *profound subtlety/return*—
this is their difference.
Thus it is said: *‘They share an origin yet differ in name.’*
That which is called *profound* is named so for its depth and distance.
If one can know the two’s unmanifested commonality,
then their learning is profound and far-reaching indeed.
Profound—this is depth and distance,
thus it is said: *‘That which is called profound is named so for its depth and distance.’*
He who travels far must reach some destination;
though their attainment may be distant,
if they have not yet reached the ultimate,
then their attainment is not yet at its peak.
The *profound* again *profound*—
the gate of all mysteries.
Again *profound*, then their attainment reaches the ultimate,
and the ultimate is called the *gate of all mysteries*.
The *gate of all mysteries*—
five thousand profound teachings and boundless subtle meanings,
all arise from this.
The sage opened this gate,
hoping later students might enter;
those who pass through the gate yet do not enter—
this is not the intent of the words.
Those who lean against the gate and debate—
this is a common occurrence.
When words reach this point,
one cannot help but laugh and leap,
unaware of hands dancing, feet stamping.

Li Shifu said:
*"The gate of the Dao/Way that can be spoken of—*
The Dao/Way exists within the mind,
everyday and ordinary,
responding flexibly to circumstances,
nowhere absent, at ease and without action—
this is the true eternal Dao/Way.
Those who can separate external false pursuits,
calm their minds, and cling to other affairs—
this is not the Dao/Way of their ordinary practice.
The Dao/Way originally has no name,
yet from this single *qi* arise Heaven and Earth and all things.
Having a name—this is the mother of all things.
Before the mind’s inclination arises,
there is no knowledge of cleverness or clumsiness,
yet it produces myriad instruments and assigns them names—
this is the mind giving birth to the mother of all things.
*‘Always without desire, observe its subtlety’*—
this is to always have no attachment to desires,
returning the light to observe its original nature,
the true subtlety.
*‘Always with desire, observe its return’*—
this is to always have desires,
observing the paths of seeking life and following return—
this is the way of subtlety.
These two share an origin yet differ in name—
without desire, entering stillness;
with desire, emerging into motion—
motion and stillness share the same original source,
thus they have differing names.
That which is called *profound* is named so—
it is the same as the original mind,
before its manifestation, difficult to measure.
The *profound* again *profound*—
the minds of common people are unfathomable,
what of the sage’s mind?
Deep and mysterious in intent,
even the profound cannot be fully explored.
The *gate of all mysteries*—
all adaptive responses arise from this,
and its mysteries are boundless.

Su Jingjing said:
*"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the eternal Dao/Way.*
The Dao/Way—this is the Dao/Way of Heaven;
the name—this is the name of the Dao/Way.
If the Dao/Way of Heaven can be pointed to as the Dao/Way of the world,
then it is not the eternal Dao/Way of my ordinary practice;
if the name of the Dao/Way can be pointed to as the name of the world,
then it is not the eternal name of my ordinary usage.
The Dao/Way of Heaven is one with nature,
yet the Dao/Way of the world has distinctions:
the Dao/Way of the sovereign, the Dao/Way of the king, the Dao/Way of the tyrant.
The name of the Dao/Way is one with clarity and tranquility,
yet the names of the world have differences:
benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trustworthiness.
The Dao/Way of Laozi is natural,
and its name is clarity and tranquility—
this is indeed different from the Dao/Way and name
of what the world calls Dao/Way and name.
Laozi was born in the declining Zhou dynasty,
witnessing the Dao/Way of the king already in decline
and the Dao/Way of the tyrant about to rise.
He thought to govern with the natural Dao/Way of Heaven,
and saw that propriety was the root of thin trustworthiness,
the beginning of chaos.
Whether benevolence or righteousness,
whether wisdom or trustworthiness,
all were in tumultuous confusion.
He sought to transform with clarity and tranquility, without action,
thus there arose the words: *‘The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the eternal Dao/Way.’*
His learning was applied by Han Wen and Cao Can,
achieving the effects of tranquility and the songs of unity.
The Western Jin did not apply it well,
and it led to the calamity of empty debate—
each follows their own use, that is all.
The *Nameless* is the mother of all things.
The *Great Polarity* (太极), the *Chaotic Undivided* (浑沦),
Heaven and Earth—even these have no name,
is this not the beginning of Heaven and Earth?
Though Heaven and Earth have not yet come into being,
they are already contained within the *Great Polarity*,
thus it is said: *‘The beginning of Heaven and Earth.’*」

chunks.translated_text:
When Heaven and Earth first began to differentiate,
and all things then took on names,
is this not the mother of all things?
Once Heaven and Earth existed,
all things were born within their embrace—
thus it is said: *the mother of all things.*

To observe its subtlety through eternal non-desire.

The *Great Polarity* spans ancient and modern times,
with principle yet no form—
without form, it is the subtle.

Thus, one must observe its subtlety through non-being.

Heaven and Earth give birth to all things,
eternally present from ancient to modern times—
with being, it is the manifest.

Thus, one must observe its manifest through being.
*Manifest* refers to boundaries.

When all things come into being,
one must exhaust their four edges
to observe their all-encompassing generation.

Being arises from non-being,
yet non-being cannot generate being.
Laozi wrote his book,
establishing speech on the two characters *being* and *non-being*,
for he saw that the *Yijing*, *Shujing*, *Shijing*, and *Chunqiu*
all spoke of *being*—
yet I say *being arises from non-being*,
and non-being cannot generate being—
this is indeed lofty and profound,
yet it falls into emptiness and nothingness.

Yet, when viewed through Laozi’s teachings,
it is not entirely empty and nothingness.

As when one does not see what is desired,
the heart remains undisturbed;
as when one rejects cleverness and profit,
thieves and robbers cease to exist;
as when one assists the sovereign with the Dao/Way,
rather than using force to dominate the world;
as when fine weapons are deemed inauspicious instruments,
and governance is conducted with rectitude,
while warfare employs stratagem—
the more taboos a land has, the poorer its people grow;
the more tools of profit proliferate, the more the state grows dim;
the more ingenious devices and strange things arise,
the more laws are enacted, the more thieves appear;
as when one acts before things exist,
and governs before chaos arises;
as when the people’s hunger stems from excessive taxation by their rulers,
and their unruliness arises from the rulers’ excessive actions.

chunks.original_text: 言皆中理。 盖老氏言无而不道於有，《易》、《诗》、《书》、《春秋》言有而或遗於无，岂可槩以清静无为言之哉？ 此两者至谓之玄。 两者，有与无也。 同出於道，而有无之名各异，同谓之玄。 玄者，玄妙也。 二者名虽不同，皆极其妙，无能生有，无之妙也。 有生於无，有之妙也。 其理玄妙，同谓之玄，则不可以有无论矣。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 泯有无而谓之玄，则又不可谓之玄矣，谓之玄之又玄可也。 无能生有，有生於无，天下万善，众妙集焉，皆从此而出，非玄之又玄乎？ 吴环中曰：道可道章。 道果有物乎？ 吾不得而知之也。 道果无物乎？ 吾亦不得而知之也。 然则道果何物乎？ 盖道之大原出於天，天即道也。 天地间惟道为大，实在人物未生之前，及其生也，於是道之名生焉。 吁，道易言乎哉。 周至昭王时，老子着道德五千文，伤周之衰，人物滋伪，世道险巘，欲一挽回为粹古之风，故於第一章首论道枢，有常道常名，有无徼妙，玄之又玄，众妙之门等语，其旨隐而不露，其言近而弘深。 自汉迄今，解者不止百家，各出己见，均不敢妄为异说，亦不敢以经子史为证，秪就老子书中寻究，庶不差误。 仁义礼乐、政刑兵法、财货求贤、治国安民之理，诸家解已详悉。 大槩《老子》一书，教人於无形无影处，加存养体察之功，於念头动处，乃生死之机才着念，却又不是欲毋意毋我，两至其极，此其所以异於吾儒之所谓道也。 善乎文公朱紫阳之语曰：《老子》一书中涵仙意，祇是自家占便宜，清静无为而已。 斯言尽老氏之旨矣。 老子之所谓道，非世上寻常之道也。
chunks.translated_text:
All words conform to principle.
Indeed, the Master Lao speaks of *wu* (無) yet does not neglect *you* (有), while the *Yijing*, *Shijing*, *Shujing*, and *Chunqiu* speak of *you* yet sometimes overlook *wu*—how can one simply reduce this to the doctrine of *qingjing wuwei*?

These two are called *xuan* (玄). The two—*you* and *wu*—
though they arise from the Dao/Way, bear different names, yet are both called *xuan*.
*Xuan* is *xuanmiao* (玄妙).
Though their names differ, both reach the utmost subtlety:
*Wu* generating *you*—the subtlety of *wu*;
*You* arising from *wu*—the subtlety of *you*.
Their principle is *xuanmiao*, yet both are called *xuan*—
thus one cannot dismiss *you* entirely.
*Xuan* again *xuan*, the gateway to all subtleties.
To obliterate *you* and *wu* and call it *xuan*—
that is not *xuan* at all; it may be called *xuan* again *xuan*.

*Wu* generates *you*, *you* arises from *wu*—
all virtues under heaven, all subtleties gathered here,
all spring from this—is it not *xuan* again *xuan*?

Wu Huanzhong said:
*"The chapter 'The Dao that can be spoken of...'*
Is the Dao truly a thing?
I cannot know it.
Is the Dao truly not a thing?
I cannot know that either.
Then what is the Dao?
Its great origin lies in Heaven—
Heaven is the Dao itself.
Between Heaven and Earth, only the Dao is supreme,
existing before all things were born.
When they came to be, then the name *Dao* arose.
Ah, how easily spoken is the Dao!

In the time of King Zhao of Zhou,
Laozi composed the *Five Thousand Words on the Dao and Virtue*,
grieved by Zhou’s decline, the proliferation of deceit among people,
and the treacherous paths of the age.
He sought to restore the pure ancient ways,
thus in the first chapter, he first expounded on the pivot of the Dao—
eternal Dao, eternal name,
the boundless subtlety of *you* and *wu*,
*xuan* again *xuan*, the gateway to all subtleties—
his meaning hidden yet not revealed,
his words seemingly simple yet profound.

From the Han to now,
commentators number in the hundreds,
each offering their own views,
daring neither to fabricate divergent interpretations
nor to cite the Classics, histories, or commentaries as proof.
They merely delve into Laozi’s text itself,
lest they err.

The principles of *renyi* (仁義), *lili* (禮樂), governance, law, warfare,
finance, seeking talent, ruling the state, and pacifying the people—
these have been thoroughly explained by other schools.

In broad strokes, *Laozi* teaches one to cultivate and observe
in the formless and shadowless,
to act at the moment life and death’s mechanism first stirs—
yet it is not the same as the Confucian *Dao* of "no scheming, no self."
Pushing both extremes to their limits—
this is how it differs from the *Dao* of our scholars.

Truly, as Wen Gong Zhu Ziyang said:
*"Within Laozi’s text lies the intent of transcendence—
merely seizing one’s own advantage,
practicing *qingjing wuwei* alone."*
These words exhaust the meaning of Laozi.

The Dao that Laozi speaks of
is not the common Dao of the world.

chunks.original_text: 其言曰有物混成，先天地生； 又曰迎之而不见其首，随之而不见其后。 此老子所谓道可道非寻常之道也。 老子之所谓名，非世上寻常之名也，故其言曰吾不知其名，强为之名； 又曰视之不见，名曰夷，听之不闻，名曰希。 此老子所谓名也可名寻常之名也。 故继之曰：无名，天地之始； 有名，万物之母。 既非常道，又非常名，若有若无，有无互用，有者不滞於有，无者不泥於无，无不在先，有不在后，生而不有，为道之母。 故於无上观道之妙，於有上观道之徼。 妙与徼，有与无，同出而异名，同谓之玄。 玄者，幽深之义，非取乎色。 玄之又玄，幽深而不可究诘，众妙之所由出。 门者有无出入之门，得其门者寡矣。 其大无外，其小无内，惚兮恍兮，其中有象； 恍兮惚兮，其中有物。 道为万物之奥，无有入乎无间，岂不为众妙之门乎？ 《老子》首章首论道枢，以有无二字贯常道常名，为一书之旨，独於道字上不十分说破，一书间见迭出。 均反覆况潜，至天得一以清，地得一以宁，神得一以灵，谷得一以盈。 喟然叹曰：一乎一乎，其为道之根柢乎。 是一也，敛之则无，散之则有。 庄周曰：人得一，万事毕。 信斯言也，道果生於一矣，果能此道矣。 致虚极，守静笃，知雄守雌，知白守黑，专气致柔，能如婴儿，出入生死，入水火，贯金石，乘虚御风。 此天下皆谓我道大似不肖，此下士闻之大笑也。 吴筠称深於道者，无如五千文。 岂欺我哉？ 柴元皋曰：道无极而太极，体虚用实，内约外博。 可道非常道，万古不变，一真悠久，曰常道。 常道，无可言者也，非无可言也，不言之言也。 不言是体四时，行百物，生是用，这生底行底，便是不言之言。 要知此理，须向静中默会个活泼泼地底是谁，方会得不言之主宰。 修道以性为体，以命为用，养神则性灵，养气则命固。 神是默言于中，而不能言于外者，必假气以发言也。 气是声言于外，而亦密言于中者，必忘言以养神也。 此是虚处做实用，口说不成，故曰可道非常道。 若工夫成了时，道出来底真是常道。 名体虚难，名可名，非常名。 只唤做道已是强名，才有可名，便非妙道。 无名，天地之始。 混沌以前。 有名，万物之母。 用从体出，母乃用名，其用无穷。 故常无欲以观其妙。 至神难名曰妙，反观乎内而无可欲者，潜其神也。 常有欲以观其缴。 循小道曰徼，动观乎外而欲有为者，施诸用也。 此两者至玄之又玄。 同出体也，异名用也，体既玄妙，用又玄妙。 众妙之门。 此门乾坤阖辟处，体用出入处，惟无欲而静观者，方会此门。 本一庵居士曰：道可道至众妙之门。 道无在而无不在，以为无耶，天地万物出焉； 以为有耶，无方无体之可言。 所可见者，常而已常者，无始终，无今古，非有非无而该乎有无，非阖辟往来而行乎阖辟往来者也。 以可道为道，以可名为名，何足以尽此常哉？ 既曰道，又曰名者，道其隐而名其着也。 又名者，所以形此道也。 谓之无，非无其实也，无其名而已。 谓之有，非有其实也，有其名而已。 故曰无名，天地之始； 有名，万物之母。 人之生也，资始於父而成形於母，故天地万物，亦父於无而母於有。 妙犹妙有之妙，徼，归也。
chunks.translated_text:
The words say: *"There is a thing that blends into unity,
born before Heaven and Earth;
It is also said: 'Go to meet it and you do not see its head,
follow it and you do not see its back.
This is the Dao of Laozi—
the Dao that can be spoken of is not the common Dao of the world.
The names that Laozi speaks of
are not the common names of the world,
thus his words: 'I do not know its name,
yet I forcefully name it';
It is also said: *'See it and you do not perceive,
call it *yi* (夷);
Listen to it and you do not hear,
call it *xi* (希).
This is the naming of Laozi—
yet it is not the naming of common names.
Thus it continues: 'The Nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth;
The Named is the mother of all things.
Neither the common Dao nor the common name,
being and non-being interweaving—
the being does not cling to being,
the non-being does not fixate on non-being.
Non-being precedes, being follows not;
Born yet not possessed—
this is the mother of the Dao.
Thus, from the formless observe the Dao’s subtlety,
from the formed observe the Dao’s limits.
Subtlety and limits, being and non-being,
emerge from the same source yet bear different names,
both called *xuan* (玄).
*Xuan* means profound and deep—
not derived from color.
Profound beyond profound,
deep beyond measure,
the origin of all subtleties.
The gate of entry and exit for being and non-being—
few attain this gate.
Its greatness knows no outer bounds,
its smallness knows no inner void—
dim and vague within it,
yet there is an image;
vague and dim within it,
yet there is a thing.
The Dao is the hidden mystery of all things—
none can enter its boundless void,
how could it not be the gate of all subtleties?
In the first chapter of *Laozi*,
the Dao’s pivotal principle is discussed,
using the terms *you* (有) and *wu* (无) to penetrate both the common Dao and common names,
as the essence of the entire book—
yet it does not fully reveal the Dao,
only glimpses appear throughout.
It repeatedly reflects and conceals itself,
until Heaven attains *yī* (一) to become clear,
Earth attains *yī* to become tranquil,
Spirits attain *yī* to become luminous,
and the Valley attains *yī* to become full.
Ah! he sighs: *'Yī! Yī!
Is this not the root and foundation of the Dao?*
This *yī*—
when gathered, it is non-being;
when dispersed, it is being.
Zhuang Zhou said: *'When a man attains *yī*, all things are complete.'*
Indeed, these words are true—
the Dao is born from *yī*,
and one can truly attain this Dao.
By perfecting emptiness and steadfastly preserving stillness,
knowing the strong yet holding to the weak,
knowing the bright yet holding to the dark,
focusing *qi* to attain softness—
one can be like an infant,
entering and exiting life and death,
passing through water and fire,
penetrating metal and stone,
riding the void and mastering the wind.
This is what the world calls *my Dao* as if it were not so,
and common men hearing it laugh in scorn.
Wu Jun praised: *'None are deeper in the Dao than the Five Thousand Words.'*
Does he deceive me?
Chai Yuan Gao said: *'The Dao is without extremity yet is the Great Extremity,
its essence is void yet its manifestation is real,
its inner is constrained while its outer is vast.
The Dao that can be spoken of is not the common Dao—
eternal and unchanging,
one true and enduring—
this is the constant Dao.
The constant Dao is beyond words,
yet it is not without words—
it is the speech of the unspeakable.
The unspeakable is the essence of the four seasons,
the manifestation in all things—
its essence is birth, its use is action,
the birth and action of this very thing
are the speech of the unspeakable.
To truly grasp this principle,
one must quietly contemplate within stillness
the lively, unrestrained one—
only then will one know the unspeakable sovereign.
Cultivating the Dao,
one takes nature as the body,
life as the use—
nurturing the spirit makes nature luminous,
nurturing *qi* strengthens life.
The spirit is the silent speech within,
yet cannot speak outwardly—
it must rely on *qi* to express itself.
*Qi* is the outward utterance,
yet it also silently speaks within—
one must forget speech to nurture the spirit.
This is the real use of the formless—
words cannot convey it,
thus it is called the Dao that can be spoken of yet is not the common Dao.
When the practice is complete,
the Dao that emerges is truly the constant Dao.

The essence is difficult to name, thus called *miao* (妙).
The limits are difficult to name, thus called *jiao* (徼).
*Jiao* means "return" (归).
The subtlety of being and non-being—
both emerge from the same essence,
yet their names differ in use.
The essence is profound and subtle,
the use is also profound and subtle.
The gate of all subtleties—
this gate is where the *bu* (阖) and *kai* (辟) of Heaven and Earth unfold,
where essence and use intermingle.
Only those who observe with no desires
can truly grasp this gate.
The Master of One-ness said:
*'The Dao that can be spoken of is the gate of all subtleties.
The Dao has no place yet is everywhere—
if one says it is non-being,
Heaven, Earth, and all things emerge from it;
if one says it is being,
its form and substance cannot be named.
What can be seen is only the constant—
the constant has no beginning or end,
no past or future,
neither being nor non-being yet encompassing both,
neither opening nor closing yet moving through all openings and closings.
To name the Dao as the Dao that can be spoken of,
to name the names as the names that can be named—
how can this exhaust the constant?
When it is called Dao and also called name,
the Dao is hidden while the name is manifest.
Again, the name—
this is to shape the Dao.
To say it is non-being,
it is not truly non-being—
only its name is non-being.
To say it is being,
it is not truly being—
only its name is being.
Thus it is said: 'The Nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth;
The Named is the mother of all things.
Man’s birth,
drawing its beginning from the father and its form from the mother—
thus Heaven, Earth, and all things
are fathered by the non-being and mothered by the being.
*Miao* is the subtlety of the being and non-being;
*Jiao* is return (归).'*
