chunks.original_text: 《列子》死者德之徼。 张湛注谓徼者归也，是也。 盖方其未有一物之先，森罗万象之理已具，及万物散殊之异，未有不归於一本者。 故体道者常无欲以观其妙，所以存其神而感通天下之故，已会於寂然不动之中。 常有欲以观其徼，所以观其复，而归根复命之常，已见於芸芸并作之际。 是以知微知显，反约於博，执要以御物，而道在我矣。 体用一源，显微无间，故曰此两者同出而异名。 玄者，深远之义，同谓之玄，言圣人与道为一贯精粗，兼动静超於两，而有无不足以名之，故寄之玄，若曰深矣远矣而无能名耳。 此大而化之之事，玄之又玄，则圣不可知之神矣，出入往来，奚适而不妙，故曰众妙之门。 常在释氏为真常，妙在释氏为妙有，常无常有即空色，色空之意。 同谓之玄，则所谓不属有无者也。 《拾遗》：严君平曰：有名，非道也。 无名，非道也。 有为，非道也。 无为，非道也。 无名而无所不名，无为而无所不为。 太平光师曰：有对则客异，绝待则玄同，忘玄之玄则曰玄玄。 秉文曰：此章明重玄之极致，非但可道非道，不可道亦非道。 《庄子》语默皆不足以尽道。 非但道常无名，有名无名亦不足以尽道。 无令者，道之似也。 有无皆不足以尽道，故又寄之重玄。 《诸子旁证》、《关尹子》曰：非有道不可言，不可言即道； 非有道不可思，不可思即道。 天物怒流，人事错错然，’若若乎回也，戛戛乎国也，勿勿乎似而非也，而争之、而介之、而哯之、而啧之、而去之、而要之，言之如吹影、思之如镂尘，圣智造迷，鬼神不识，惟不可为，不可致、不可测，不可分，故曰天、曰命、曰神、曰玄，合曰道。 无一物非天，无一物非命，无一物非神，无一物非玄。 物既如此，人岂不然。 人皆可曰天，人皆可曰神，人皆可致命通玄，不可彼天此非天，彼神此非神，彼命此非命，彼玄此非玄。 是以善吾道者，即一物中知天尽神、致命造玄。 学之循异名，析同实，得之契同，实忘异名。 陈抱一解曰：道可道非常道，名可名非常名。 世之学者罕见关尹子书，而多以百家之言及臆说解之，愈不能明老子之旨。 关尹谓； 使有道不可言，则道与言为二。 惟不可言即道，则言与道为一。 学者骤观非有道不可言，多误认为有道可言，若有道可道，则当云有道非不可言，不曰非有道不可言也。 今曰非有道不可言，不可言即道，是则翻老子之言，以明老子言外之旨也。 此言翻之则曰：非有道不可道，不可道即道。 既翻出不可道即道，则翻出道可道非道矣。 道可道非道，即是老子道可道非常道也。 或者犹疑可道为口道之道，愚又翻经言以晓之曰：如曰空可空非真空，使其可空，即是有物。 窒而不空之处，岂谓之真空乎？ 知空可空，非真空，则知道可道，非常道矣。 或者喻曰：如心心如性，性皆可用功。 以人为而道，独不可以人为，故不可以道道也。 向非翻言外之言，吾终世不能明老子之经旨矣。 世人又多被常字转了，将谓老子有非常之道，然老子立此常字者，政恐世人疑吾所谓道有异乎人也，殊不知此乃通天下之常道尔。 犹强名曰道者，通天下之常名尔。 是道也，通天彻地，亘古亘今，无往而不在，才开口言则去道远矣，故曰二也。

「The *Liezi* states: The dead are the Dao’s return (归). Zhang Huan’s annotation says that *miao* (徼) is return (归), which is correct. Indeed, before there was any single thing, the principles of all phenomena were already complete. When the myriad things dispersed and took on distinct forms, none failed to return to their original source. Thus, those who embody the Dao must always be without desire to observe its subtlety (妙), and thereby preserve their spirit (神) to resonate and connect with all under Heaven. This understanding is already realized in the stillness of unchanging repose.

They must also have desire to observe its return (徼), and thereby perceive its cycles, as the constant return to the root and the restoration of vital essence (命) are already evident in the ceaseless interplay of all things. Hence, knowing the subtle and the manifest, one reflects on the vast, grasps the essential to govern all things, and thus the Dao resides within them.

The Dao’s essence and function are one source, with its subtle and manifest aspects inseparable, so it is said: *“These two [subtlety and return] share a common origin but differ in name.”*

*Xuān* (玄) signifies profound and distant meaning. When called *xuān*, it is said that the Sage and the Dao are as one, encompassing both the refined and the coarse, motion and stillness, transcending being and non-being—so that neither being nor non-being can truly name it. Thus, it is entrusted to *xuān*, as if to say: *“Deep and distant, yet no name can suffice.”*

This is the great and transforming work of the Dao—*xuān* beyond *xuān*—the unknowable essence of the Sage. In its entering and exiting, its coming and going, what is its proper abode yet remains ineffable? Hence, it is called *“the gateway to all subtleties.”*

In the Buddhist tradition, the *constant* (常) is called *true constant* (真常), and *subtlety* (妙) is called *wondrous being* (妙有). The interplay of constant, non-constant, and being is the meaning of *emptiness-form* (空色).

When called *xuān*, it is that which transcends being and non-being.

The *Collected Remnants* (*Shíyí*) records: Yan Junping said: *“The Named is not the Dao. The Nameless is not the Dao. The Constructed is not the Dao. The Unconstructed is not the Dao. That which is Nameless yet names all things, that which is Unconstructed yet constructs all things—*
this is the Dao. The Sage of the Great Peace (太平光师) said: *“When there is opposition, it is duality (客异); when all distinctions are severed, it is the profound unity (玄同). To forget the profound unity itself is to call it *profound-profound* (玄玄).”*
Bing Wen states: *“This chapter illuminates the ultimate essence of the *Double Profound* (重玄), not merely that the Dao which can be spoken of is not the Dao, nor that the Dao which cannot be spoken of is not the Dao. In the *Zhuangzi*, both speech and silence are insufficient to exhaust the Dao. Not only is the Dao always nameless, but even the interplay of named and nameless cannot exhaust the Dao.*

*The Unnamed is the semblance of the Dao. Since both having and non-being cannot exhaust the Dao, it is again entrusted to the *Double Profound* (重玄).”*

The *Cross-Referencing of the Masters* and *Guan Yinzi* state:
*“There is no Dao that can be spoken of; what cannot be spoken of is the Dao.
There is no Dao that can be thought of; what cannot be thought of is the Dao.
Heaven’s flow is unrestrained (怒流), human affairs are intricate (错错然)—*
like the flickering of shadows (若若乎回), like the clashing of nations (戛戛乎国), like the fleeting of semblances (勿勿乎似而非), yet people debate it, cling to it, reject it, praise it, abandon it, or grasp at it. To speak of it is like chasing after a shadow; to think of it is like probing dust. The Sage’s wisdom creates confusion, and even spirits do not recognize it. Only that which cannot be done, cannot be attained, cannot be measured, and cannot be divided is called Heaven, called Vital Essence (命), called Spirit (神), called Profound (玄), and collectively called the Dao.

There is not a single thing that is not Heaven, not a single thing that is not Vital Essence (命), not a single thing that is not Spirit (神), not a single thing that is not Profound (玄). If things are such, how can humans be otherwise? Everyone can be called Heaven, everyone can be called Spirit (神), everyone can be said to attain Vital Essence (命) and penetrate the Profound (玄). Yet one cannot say this thing is Heaven and that is not, this is Spirit and that is not, this is Vital Essence and that is not, this is Profound and that is not.

Thus, those who excel in the Dao understand that within a single thing, Heaven is complete, Spirit is exhausted, Vital Essence is attained, and the Profound is realized. In studying it, one follows the varied names, analyzing them to find their shared reality. In attaining it, one aligns with the unity, forgetting the varied names.”*

Chen Baoyi’s interpretation states:
*“The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao; the name that can be named is not the constant name. Scholars of the world rarely see the *Guan Yinzi*, yet they often interpret the Dao through the words of a hundred schools and their own conjectures, making them ever more unable to clarify Laozi’s intent.*

*The *Guan Yinzi* says:
If there were a Dao that could not be spoken of, then the Dao and speech would be two. Only when what cannot be spoken of is the Dao do speech and the Dao become one. Yet scholars, upon seeing ‘there is no Dao that can be spoken of,’ often mistakenly believe there is a Dao that *can* be spoken of. If there were a Dao that could be spoken of, it should be said ‘there is a Dao that is not unspeakable,’ not ‘there is no Dao that can be spoken of.’

Now, when it is said: ‘There is no Dao that can be spoken of; what cannot be spoken of is the Dao,’ it is reversing Laozi’s words to clarify his deeper meaning. When reversed, it reads: ‘There is no Dao that cannot be spoken of; what cannot be spoken of is the Dao.’ Once it is reversed to say ‘what cannot be spoken of is the Dao,’ then it is reversed again to say ‘the Dao that can be spoken of is not the Dao.’ This is Laozi’s statement that the Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.

Some still doubt whether ‘can be spoken of’ refers to the Dao of speech. I further reverse the scripture’s words to enlighten them, saying: As when one says ‘emptiness can be emptied, yet it is not true emptiness’—if it can be emptied, then there are things. Where it is blocked yet not emptied, how can it be called true emptiness? Knowing that emptiness can be emptied is not true emptiness, then one knows that the Dao which can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.

Others may illustrate it thus: ‘Like the heart, the heart is like nature (性); nature can all be cultivated through effort.’ If the Dao were something humans could construct, why then cannot the Dao be spoken of as the Dao? Without reversing the meaning beyond words, I would never have been able to clarify Laozi’s scriptural intent in my lifetime.

People of the world are also often misled by the word *constant* (常), thinking Laozi speaks of a Dao beyond the constant. Yet Laozi established this word *constant* precisely to prevent such doubt—that my Dao differs from that of others. They do not realize that this is the universal Dao of all under Heaven. Even the Dao named as Dao is the universal name of all under Heaven.

This Dao penetrates Heaven and Earth, spans the ancient and the present, without a place it does not inhabit. The moment one opens their mouth to speak of it, they are far removed from the Dao. Hence, it is said to be *two* (二).」

chunks.original_text: 才指此强名之名为可名，则非名矣。 惟不可名，故假常名强名之，犹曰非有名不可名，不可名即名也。 是则不可言即道，不可名即名，即老子可道则非常道，可名则非常名之意也。 然则老子大圣人也，其言如天之不言之言，非有大圣人如关尹子者畴，能复以不言之言发明其言外之旨哉？ 然关尹子既发明不可名言之旨矣，又恐世人谓道不可名言，则可以思而得之，故又曰非有道不可思，不可思即道，与上意同。 噫，可言可思皆人也，不可言不可思皆天也。 然则人与天果何以异观乎？ 曰人皆可曰天。 然则人与天果可以同观乎？ 曰天物怒流，人事错错然，有相若而回者，有相戛而斗者，有相勿而似而非者，或争而日以心斗，或介而不交於物，或哯而呵叱之，或啧而呼唤之，或去而离之，或要而合之，天物人事不齐如此，岂可以同观哉？ 今欲以人之言思及之，譬如吹影镂尘，徒劳心耳。 是道也，圣智造之犹迷，鬼神测之不识，惟其不可为，故曰天； 不可致，故曰命； 不可测，故曰神； 不可分，故曰玄。 合是四者，强名曰道。 老子言道，继之以常无欲以观其妙，常有欲以观其徼，同谓之玄，玄之又玄，众妙之门。 关尹子恐学者徇异名，析同实，而并以天命神玄四者异观之，故於此章重言，即一物中可以知天、尽神、致命、造玄。 物物皆然，人人本具，不可彼天此非天，彼神此非神，彼命此非命，彼玄此非玄也。 是则或曰妙，或曰徼，或曰玄，亦物物皆然，人人本具，惟得之者契其同，有之实忘其异，谓之名。 至於玄之又玄，可以入道矣。 庄子曰：有始也者，有未始有始也者，有未始有夫未始有始也者，有有也者，有无也者，有未始有无也者，有未始有夫未始有无也者，俄而有无矣。 而未知有无之果孰有孰无也？ 今我则已有谓矣，而未知吾所谓之其果有谓乎？ 其果无谓乎？ 以本为精，以物为粗，以有积为不足，澹然独与神明居。 古之道术有在於是者，关尹老聃闻其风而悦之见，建之以常无有，主之以大一，以濡弱谦下为表，以空虚不毁万物为实。 文子曰：夫事生者，应变而动，变主於时，无常之行。 故道可道非常道也，名可名非常名也。 书者，言之所生也，言出於智者不知，非常道也； 名可名，非藏书者也。 古者被发而无卷领，以王天下，其德生而不杀，与而不夺，天下非其空同怀其德。 当此之时，阴阳和平，万物蕃息，飞鸟之巢可俯而探也，走兽可系而从也。 及其衰也，鸟兽虫蛇皆为人害，故铸铁锻刃以御其难。 故民迫其难则求其便，因其患则操其备，各以其智，去其可害，就其所利。 常故不可循，器械不可因，故先王之法度有变易者也。 故曰名可名，非常名也。 五常异道而覆天下，三王殊事而名立后世。 因时而变者也。 譬师旷之调五音也，推移上下，无常尺寸以度，而靡不中者。 故通於乐之情者，能作音有本，主於中。 而知规矩钩绳之所用者能治人，故先王之别不宜即废，末世之事善者即之，故圣人之制礼乐者，而不制於法。 故曰道可道非常道。 振穷补急则名生利起害，除积功成。 世无灾害，虽圣无所施其德，上下和睦，虽贤无所立其功。 故至人之治，含德抱道推诚，施无穷之智，寝说而不言，天下莫知，贵其不言者，故道可道非常道也，名可名非常名也。

The moment one declares this arbitrarily named *name* as a name that can be named, then it is no longer a name. Only because it cannot be named does one use the conventional name to name it arbitrarily—just as one says, "It is not a name that can be named, yet the inability to name it *is* the name."

Thus, what cannot be spoken of *is* the Dao; what cannot be named *is* the name. This is Laozi’s meaning: that which can be spoken of is not the constant Dao, and that which can be named is not the constant name.

Yet Laozi was a great sage—his words like Heaven’s unspeakable speech. Were it not for a sage like Guan Yinzi, who could have further illuminated the meaning beyond the words through unspeakable speech?

But Guan Yinzi, having already illuminated the meaning of what cannot be named or spoken, feared that people might think: if the Dao cannot be named or spoken, then it can be attained through thought. Hence, he further said: "It is not that the Dao cannot be thought, but that which cannot be thought *is* the Dao"—the same intent as before.

Ah! What can be spoken of and thought about are human affairs; what cannot be spoken of or thought about are Heavenly matters. Then how do people and Heaven truly differ in appearance?

One might say: all people can be called Heaven.

Yet can people and Heaven truly be observed as the same?

One might say: Heaven’s phenomena rage like flowing waters, while human affairs are tangled and chaotic—some resemble each other yet turn away, some clash and contend, some seem alike yet are not. Some contend daily with their minds, some remain aloof without engaging, some scold and shout, some murmur and call, some depart and separate, some seek and unite. Heaven’s phenomena and human affairs differ thus—how can they be observed as the same?

Now if one attempts to grasp the Dao through human speech and thought, it is like blowing at shadows or carving dust—only exhausting the mind in vain.

This Dao: even sages and wise ones, when crafting it, remain bewildered; even spirits and gods, when probing it, do not recognize it. Only because it cannot be made, it is called *Heaven*; because it cannot be attained, it is called *Fate*; because it cannot be measured, it is called *Spirit*; because it cannot be divided, it is called *Mysterious*.

Combining these four, one arbitrarily names it *Dao*.

Laozi spoke of the Dao, following it with *constant* and *without desire* to observe its subtlety, *constant* and *with desire* to observe its peril—both called *Mysterious*. Mysterious beyond mysterious, the gateway to all subtleties.

Guan Yinzi feared that scholars would cling to differing names, dissecting the same reality, and thus observe Heaven, Fate, Spirit, and the Mysterious as separate. Hence, in this passage, he reiterates: within a single thing, one can know Heaven, exhaust Spirit, attain Fate, and craft the Mysterious.

All things are thus; all people inherently possess this. It cannot be that this is Heaven and that is not, this is Spirit and that is not, this is Fate and that is not, this is Mysterious and that is not.

Thus, some call it *subtle*, some call it *perilous*, some call it *Mysterious*—yet all things are thus, and all people inherently possess it. Only those who grasp it recognize its unity, forgetting its differences, and call it by name.

As for *Mysterious beyond mysterious*, one may enter the Dao.

Zhuangzi said:
*"There is a beginning, there is what has no beginning yet has a beginning, there is what has no beginning to what has no beginning yet has a beginning, there is what has existence, there is what has non-existence, there is what has no beginning to non-existence, there is what has no beginning to what has no beginning to non-existence. Suddenly, there is non-existence. Yet who knows whether this non-existence is truly non-existent or truly existent?"*

Now, I have already spoken of it, yet I do not know whether my words truly have meaning or truly lack meaning.

With the original as refined, with things as coarse, with accumulation as insufficiency, serene and alone, dwelling with Spirit and Clarity.

In ancient Daoist arts, there was one such as this. Guan Yinzi and Lao Dan heard of its essence and took delight in it, establishing it with *constant non-being*, governing it with *Great Unity*, using *softness, weakness, humility, and lowliness* as its outward form, and *emptiness, voidness, and non-destruction of all things* as its substance.

Wenzi said:
*"What gives rise to affairs responds to changes and moves accordingly. Change is governed by time, and its actions are without constancy."*

Thus, the Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao, and the name that can be named is not the constant name.

Books are born from speech. Speech arises from the wise who do not know—this is the non-constant Dao. What can be named is not the act of preserving books.

In ancient times, those with unbound hair and no collar ruled under Heaven. Their virtue was born without killing, gave without taking, and all under Heaven, though empty, cherished their virtue.

At that time, yin and yang were harmonious, and all things flourished. Birds’ nests could be reached by leaning down, and wild beasts could be tethered and followed.

When it declined, birds, beasts, insects, and serpents all became human hazards. Thus, iron was cast and blades were forged to defend against them.

When people were pressed by these hazards, they sought convenience; when plagued by troubles, they prepared defenses. Each used their wisdom to avoid what harmed them and pursue what benefited them.

Since constancy cannot be followed, and tools cannot be relied upon, the laws of the ancient kings had variations.

Thus, it is said: what can be named is not the constant name.

The Five Constants differ in Dao yet cover all under Heaven; the Three Kings varied in affairs yet their names endure in posterity.

They adapted to the times and changed accordingly.

For instance, the music master’s tuning of the five tones shifts up and down without fixed measurements, yet never misses the mark.

Thus, those attuned to the emotions of music can compose sounds with roots, centered in harmony. Those who understand the uses of compasses, squares, hooks, and cords can govern people. Hence, the ancient kings’ distinctions, though not rigidly enforced, were followed in the later ages. Thus, sages established rites and music without being bound by law.

Hence, it is said: the Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.

To alleviate poverty and relieve urgency brings forth names of profit and harm, removes accumulated ills, and achieves success. When the world has no disasters, even sages have no virtue to apply, and when all are harmonious, even the virtuous have no deeds to establish.

Thus, the governance of the perfected sage embraces virtue, holds to the Dao, extends sincerity, and applies boundless wisdom—resting in speechlessness, unknown to the world. Their speechlessness is honored, hence the Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao, and the name that can be named is not the constant name.

chunks.translated_text:
What is inscribed upon bamboo and silk, carved upon metal and stone, and thus transmitted to humanity—these are but its superficial traces.

The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, the Three Kings, though their deeds differed, shared a singular intent; though their paths diverged, their ultimate aim was one.

Scholars of the later ages, failing to grasp the essence of the Dao or the unity of virtue, seek only to advance their own achievements. Kneeling or seated, they speak of it, though their vast learning and wide hearing only lead them further into confusion.

Stone Tan said: *"The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao."* This passage has two divergent interpretations.

Some take the opening *"The Dao that can be spoken of"* as the Dao that can be attained through speech, while *"the constant Dao"* refers to that which cannot be spoken. Others interpret *"The Dao that can be spoken of"* as the Dao spoken of by Laozi, and *"the constant Dao"* as the Dao spoken of by ordinary people.

Yet if the first *"Dao"* is taken as the Dao that can be spoken of, then Laozi would invert the world’s conception of Dao by placing it at the beginning of his text, making this *"Dao"* not his own. Would Laozi name his work *"Dao"* only to immediately speak of the world’s Dao?

If instead the first *"Dao"* is Laozi’s own Dao—meaning *"My Dao is not the Dao of the common people"*—this also holds some plausibility. Yet then *"the constant Dao"* would refer to the Dao of the common people, as in Confucius An Guo’s *"Book Sequence"* where *"the constant Dao"* is mentioned.

But the next chapter speaks of *"knowing the constant as clarity,"* and this chapter itself contains *"constantly without desire to observe its subtlety, constantly with desire to observe its peril."* Would *"constant"* here mean merely the ordinary?

Both interpretations seem flawed. After careful reconsideration, it appears that both the opening *"Dao"* and the subsequent *"constant Dao"* refer to the essence of the Dao itself. The *"Dao that can be spoken of"* is the Dao as commonly understood by people. If one says, *"My Dao is not the Dao that can be pointed to by the world,"* then the Dao that can be named is not the Dao of natural constancy that I speak of.

The *"constant"* refers to that which is ever-present in all things, unchanging through time, eternally enduring from antiquity to the present. The Dao as commonly spoken of—what Confucius called *"the lesser Dao"* and Mencius *"the divided Dao"*—is the Dao of daily practice and common conduct. But Laozi’s Dao is the singular, void, and natural principle itself.

*"The name that can be named is not the constant name."* This passage also has two interpretations.

Some take the opening *"name"* as the name of the common world, while others take it as the name of the Dao. The distinction in meaning mirrors that of the previous passage.

Following the earlier pattern, the opening *"name"* and the subsequent *"constant name"* both refer to the naming of the Dao. The Dao itself cannot truly be named, yet we designate it as *"Dao"* by force of convention. If it could be named, then its names would be relative—such as the *"beautiful and ugly, difficult and easy, long and short, high and low"* mentioned in the next chapter—which cannot be considered the *"constant name."* Thus, these two sentences serve only to elucidate the previous two, explaining the later chapter’s assertion that the Dao is forcibly named.

*"Nameless, the origin of heaven and earth. Named, the mother of ten thousand things."* This passage also has two interpretations.

Some punctuate it as *"Nameless, named,"* while others as *"Without, with."* The latter seems more elevated. Yet the next chapter speaks of *"the Dao constantly without name at its origin, then named in its manifestation,"* so perhaps this too could be punctuated thus.

Those who punctuate *"Nameless, named"* are correct. The essence of the Great Dao is boundless and formless, yet all phenomena are already manifest within it. Because it is boundless and formless, it cannot be named, hence *"Nameless."* Though nameless, it is the origin of heaven and earth. Because all phenomena are already present, their principles can be named, hence *"Named."* Once named, it becomes the mother of all things.

*"Origin"* refers to its source—being generated from the void, hence *"origin."* *"Mother"* refers to its latent presence, like an embryo already formed, hence *"mother."* This *"origin"* is akin to the *"Great Origin"* in the *Yijing*, and *"mother"* is akin to the *"completion of things."* But the *Yijing* speaks primarily of Heaven and Earth, while this text focuses solely on the Dao.

*"Constantly without desire, one observes its subtlety; constantly with desire, one observes its peril."* This passage also has two interpretations.

Some punctuate it at *"without"* and *"with,"* following Zhuangzi. Indeed, the *"Heaven and Earth"* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* speaks of *"establishing it with constant non-being,"* directly echoing this passage’s *"constant without, constant with."* Yet the later chapter of the *Laozi* itself contains the phrase *"constant without desire,"* making it unlikely to punctuate at *"without."*

Punctuating at *"desire"* conflicts with the *Zhuangzi*, while punctuating at *"without"* conflicts with the later chapter. Yet the *Zhuangzi* most faithfully captures the *Laozi’s* essence—could the *"without desire"* in the later chapter be a mere coincidence, not to be taken as precedent?

Since both interpretations have merit, neither should be discarded. Punctuating at *"without"* and *"with"* speaks to the nature of the Dao itself; speaking of *"constant without desire"* and *"constant with desire"* addresses how humanity embodies the Dao.

The constant Dao is hidden in the void, hence its subtlety can be observed there; the constant Dao manifests in the having, hence its perils can be observed there.

chunks.original_text: 妙者，言其不可名者也。 徼者，言其有可名者也。 若欲字断句，则人常能无欲可以见其常无之妙，此犹《大易》所谓寂然不动者也。 常於有欲处则可以见其常有之徼，此犹《大易》所谓感而遂通者也。 於无欲而见其寂然不动之妙，於有欲而见其感而遂通之徼，则道之体用得矣。 此两者同出而异名，同谓之玄。 此即儒者所谓体用一源，显微无间之说也。 两者，有与无也。 道以无为体，以有为用。 两者皆出於道，所谓一源也。 而有无异名，无即微也，有即显也，惟一源故无间也。 伺谓之玄者，谓之有不可谓之无，亦不可以为有耶？ 则其体似无； 以为无耶？ 则其用似有。 故谓之玄。 玄者，有无不可分之谓也。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 庄子曰：有有也者，有无也者，有未始有无也者，有未始有夫未始有无也者。 有名者即庄子所谓有有者也，无名者即庄子所谓有无者也，玄者有则不可谓之有，无亦不可谓之无。 既不可谓之无，则未始有无者也。 既玄矣，又玄焉，则庄子所谓未始有夫未始有无者也。 玄者不可以有无言，玄之又玄则又不可以玄言焉，虽玄之又玄矣，然一理之中万理寓焉，众理之妙无不由兹而出，故谓之门。 夫以一理而出万理，此似与儒者之道同矣。 而与儒者之道卒不同者，盖儒者以事物为主，而道寓於器，此则以虚无为主，专以道为精，而超乎事物之粗故也。 道德真经集义卷之四竟 道德真经集义卷之五

The subtlety refers to that which cannot be named; the perils refer to that which has names.

If one punctuates at *"desire"*, then humanity’s ability to remain without desire reveals the Dao’s constant subtlety—this is akin to what the *Great Classic of Change* calls *"tranquil and motionless"*. The Dao’s constant perils appear where desire exists—this is akin to what the *Great Classic of Change* calls *"stirred and thus responsive"*.

To perceive the Dao’s constant subtlety in the absence of desire and its constant perils in the presence of desire is to grasp the Dao’s essence and function.

These two are of the same origin yet bear different names, both called *Xuan* (玄).
This is the Confucian teaching of *"essence and function are one source, manifest and subtle without separation"*.

The two—having and non-having—
the Dao takes non-having as its essence, having as its function.
Both arise from the Dao, hence called *"one source"*.
Yet having and non-having are distinct names:
non-having is the subtle,
having is the manifest,
and only because of their shared source are they without separation.

Now, what is called *Xuan* (玄)?
It is neither having nor non-having,
yet it is not as if one can say it is non-having—
then its function would seem to be having.
Hence it is called *Xuan*.
*Xuan* means that having and non-having cannot be divided.

*Xuan* beyond *Xuan*—
the gate through which all subtleties pass.
Zhuangzi said:
*"There are those who speak of having-having,
those who speak of having-non-having,
those who speak of neither having nor non-having,
and those who speak of neither having nor non-having yet also not of having that which is neither having nor non-having."*

That which can be named is Zhuangzi’s *"having-having"*;
that which cannot be named is Zhuangzi’s *"having-non-having"*,
while *Xuan* is neither having nor non-having—
yet if one says it is non-having,
then it is *"neither having nor non-having"*,
and if it is *Xuan* beyond *Xuan*,
then it is *"neither having nor non-having yet also not of having that which is neither having nor non-having"*.

*Xuan* cannot be spoken of as having or non-having,
and *Xuan* beyond *Xuan* cannot be spoken of even as *Xuan*—
though *Xuan* beyond *Xuan* it is,
within the single principle are myriad principles contained,
and the subtleties of all principles emerge from this,
hence it is called the *gate*.

Now, to have one principle give rise to myriad principles—
this seems akin to the Confucian Dao.
Yet it ultimately differs from the Confucian Dao,
for the Confucian school takes concrete things as primary,
and the Dao is found within them,
while this takes emptiness and non-being as primary,
and focuses solely on the Dao’s essence,
transcending the coarse nature of concrete things.

chunks.original_text: 凝远大师常德路玄妙观 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易东校正 天下皆知章 考异：河上公作《养身章》，赵实庵作《真常融摄义章》。 唐明皇疏：前章明妙本生化，入两观之不同。 此章明朴散异名，因万殊而逐境，逐境则流浪，善化则归根。 故首标美善妄情，次示有无倾夺，结以圣人之理，冀速还淳之由。 杜光庭曰：夫悠悠众趣，蠢蠢群生，涉境起情，去道逾远，圣人悯其忘返，启此妙门。 前明两观之殊，自无而入有。 此标六者之惑，因事以相倾，能知逐境之非，不随流浪之变，则可以言虚心实腹之渐矣。 张冲应曰：道先乎身而包乎天地也。 人体此自然之道而行之，则神存精固，勿与物逐，不逞其才，不食其名，畏益就损，因近惧远，则万祸潜消而身得其养矣。 故养身所以次于体道之章。 此河上公之释也。 天下皆知美之为美，斯恶已。 皆知善之为善，斯不善已。 故有无相生，难易相成，长短相形，高下相倾，音声相和，前后相随。 是以圣人处无为之事，行不言之教，万物作焉而不辞，生而不有，为而不恃，功成而不居。 夫惟弗居，是以不去。 考异：故有无至相随。 一作有无之相生，难易之相成，长短之相形，高下之相倾，音声之相和，前后之相随。 万物作焉而不辞，一无焉字，一作万物作焉而不为始。 功成而弗居，夫惟弗居，弗，一作不，一无而字。 是以不去，一作不处。 河上公曰：天下皆知美之为美，自扬己美便显彰也。 斯恶已，有危亡也。 皆知善之为善，有功名也。 斯不善已，人所争也。 故有无相生，见有而为无也。 难易相成，见难而为易也。 长短相形，见短而为长也。 高下相倾，见高而为下也。 音声相和，上唱下必和也。 前后相随，上行下必倾也。 是以圣人处无为之事，以道治也。 行不言之教，以身师导之也。 万物作焉，各自动也。 而不辞，不辞谢而逆止。 生而不有，元气生万物而不有。 为而不恃，道所施为，不恃望其报也。 功成而弗居，功成事就，退避不居其位。 夫惟弗居，夫惟功成不居其位。 是以不去，福德常在，不去其身也。 此言不行不可随，不言不可知矣。 上六句有高下长短，君开一源，下生百端。 百端之变，无不动乱。 王辅嗣曰：天下皆知至前后相随。 美者，人心之所进乐也。 恶者，人心之所恶疾也。 美恶犹喜怒也，善不善犹是非也，喜怒同根，是非同门，故不可得偏废也。 此六者皆陈自然不可徧举之明数也。 是以至之事。 自然已足，为则败也。 行不言之教至为而不恃。 智慧自备，为则伪也。 功成而弗居。 因物而用，功自彼成，故不居也。 夫惟至不去。 使功在己，则功不可久也。 唐明皇曰：天下皆知至不善已。 美善者生於欲心，心苟所欲，虽恶而美善矣。 故云皆知己之所美为美，所善为善，美善无主，但是忘情，皆由对执有无，分别难易，神奇臭腐，以相倾夺，大圣较量，深知虚妄，故云恶已。 疏：天下者，举大凡，言凡在天覆之下也。 美者，心所甘美也。 善者，身所履行也。 言天下之人皆知己心所甘美者为美，己身所履行者为善，故论甘则忌辛，好丹则非素，共相倾夺，竟起是非，皆由兴动於欲心，所以递成乎美恶，圣人知美恶无主，但是妄情，妄则不常，故云恶已。
chunks.translated_text:
**Volume Five of *Collected Meanings of the True Classic of the Dao and Virtue***

Master Yǒngyuǎn’s profound and subtle exposition of the Dao’s vast virtue,
with Sī Wéiyǒng’s compilation of observations,
and Dīng Yìdōng’s annotations—
a former imperial scholar and editor of the Secretariat Bureau,
with variant readings noted.

**Chapter: "All Under Heaven Know" (天下皆知章)**

**Variant Readings:**
- *Héshànggōng* composed *The Chapter on Nourishing the Body* (《养身章》),
- Zhào Shí’ān composed *The Chapter on the True and Eternal Integration of Principles* (《真常融摄义章》).

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Commentary:**
The preceding chapter illuminated the wondrous origin of transformation,
distinguishing the twofold observation [of Dao].
This chapter elucidates the undifferentiated and scattered names of *Pu* (the Uncarved),
arising from myriad distinctions—
as distinctions arise, so does wandering,
but virtuous transformation returns to the root.

Thus, it first marks the entanglement of beauty, goodness, and delusion,
then demonstrates the interplay of presence and absence,
and concludes with the Sage’s principle,
hoping to swiftly restore the pure and unadulterated.

**Dù Guāngtíng’s Explanation:**
The vast and boundless currents of existence,
the sluggish multitude of living beings—
entering realms, emotions stir;
the farther from the Dao, the more distant they stray.
The Sage pities their forgetfulness and opens this wondrous gate.

The twofold observation of the previous chapter
entered from non-being into being.
This chapter marks the sixfold delusions,
whereby affairs sway the mind.
If one knows the error of following realms
and does not succumb to wandering transformations,
then one may speak of the gradual cultivation of an empty heart and full belly.

**Zhāng Chōngyìng’s Interpretation:**
The Dao precedes the body yet encompasses heaven and earth.
If one aligns with this natural Dao in action,
the spirit is preserved, the essence fortified—
do not chase after things,
do not flaunt one’s talents,
do not crave fame;
fear gain as one seeks loss,
approach the near while dreading the far—
then all calamities fade unseen,
and the body finds its nourishment.
Thus, *Nourishing the Body* follows the chapter on embodying the Dao—
this is *Héshànggōng*’s exposition.

---
**All under heaven know beauty as beauty—**
then ugliness arises.
All under heaven know goodness as goodness—
then wickedness arises.
Thus, presence and absence give rise to each other,
difficulty and ease complete one another,
length and shortness define each other,
high and low contrast each other,
sounds harmonize with each other,
before and after follow each other.

Therefore, the Sage acts in non-action,
teaches without speech—
all things arise yet he does not claim them,
gives birth yet does not possess,
acts yet does not rely upon it,
and when the deed is done, does not dwell upon it.
**Only by not dwelling does it not depart.**

**Variant Readings:**
- "Presence and absence follow each other closely" (有无至相随) alternates with:
  *"Presence and absence give rise to each other, difficulty and ease complete each other..."*
- "All things arise yet he does not claim them" (万物作焉而不辞) alternates with:
  *"All things arise yet he does not initiate"* (万物作焉而不为始).
- "Does not dwell upon it" (弗居) alternates with:
  *"Does not"* (不) or omits the *"while"* (而) entirely.
- "Thus it does not depart" (是以不去) alternates with *"Thus it does not abide"* (不处).

**Héshànggōng’s Explanation:**
All under heaven know beauty as beauty—
this is to boast of one’s own excellence.
Then ugliness arises—
there is peril and ruin.
All under heaven know goodness as goodness—
this is to seek fame and merit.
Then wickedness arises—
it becomes what others contend for.

Thus, presence and absence give rise to each other—
seeing presence as absence.
Difficulty and ease complete each other—
seeing difficulty as ease.
Length and shortness define each other—
seeing shortness as length.
High and low contrast each other—
seeing height as low.
Sounds harmonize—
when one sings, the other must respond.
Before and after follow—
when one advances, the other must incline.

Therefore, the Sage acts in non-action—
governing through the Dao.
Teaches without speech—
leading by personal example.
All things arise—
each moves spontaneously.
Yet he does not refuse—
he does not reject or obstruct.
Gives birth yet does not possess—
the Original Qi generates all things yet does not claim them.
Acts yet does not rely upon it—
the Dao’s work is done without expectation of reward.
When the deed is complete, he does not dwell upon it—
when the work is done, he withdraws, not claiming the position.
**Only by not dwelling does it not depart—**
only by not claiming the deed does the blessing remain,
and it does not abandon the body.

This shows that what is not done cannot be followed,
and what is not spoken cannot be known.

The first six lines speak of high and low, long and short—
the Sage opens one source,
from which a hundred branches arise.
The transformations of these branches
are without fail in motion and disorder.

**Wáng Fǔsì’s Commentary:**
All under heaven know beauty as beauty—
beauty is what the heart delights in.
Ugliness is what the heart abhors.
Beauty and ugliness are like joy and anger,
goodness and wickedness are like right and wrong—
joy and anger share the same root,
right and wrong share the same gate.
Thus, they cannot be partially discarded.

These six are all natural, self-evident truths—
therefore, the Sage’s affairs are complete in their naturalness;
if forced, they fail.
From *"teaches without speech"* to *"does not rely upon it"*—
wisdom is inherently complete;
if forced, it becomes false.
*"When the deed is complete, he does not dwell upon it"*—
acting in accordance with things,
the deed completes itself;
thus, he does not dwell upon it.
**Only by not dwelling does it not depart—**
if the deed is attributed to oneself,
the deed cannot endure.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Commentary:**
All under heaven know beauty as beauty—
beauty and goodness arise from desire.
Where the heart desires,
even ugliness becomes beautiful and good.
Thus, it is said:
*"All under heaven know what they themselves deem beautiful as beauty,
and what they themselves deem good as good."*
Beauty and goodness have no inherent master—
they are merely deluded emotions.
This arises from clinging to presence or absence,
distinguishing difficulty and ease,
discerning the marvelous from the vile—
all swaying and contending.
The great Sage weighs these carefully,
knowing their emptiness and delusion,
thus declaring: *"Then ugliness arises."*

**Commentary:**
*"All under heaven"*—
speaking of the general populace beneath heaven’s canopy.
*"Beauty"*—what the heart finds pleasing.
*"Goodness"*—what the body practices.
It is said that all under heaven know what their own hearts find pleasing as beauty,
and what their own bodies practice as goodness.
Thus, in matters of taste, they shun the bitter,
preferring the red;
in matters of virtue, they reject the plain,
favoring the ornate—
mutually swaying, they inevitably stir contention,
all arising from the stirring of desire.
Thus, beauty and ugliness emerge in succession.
The Sage knows beauty and ugliness have no inherent nature—
they are merely deluded emotions.
Delusion is not constant,
hence it is said: *"Then ugliness arises."*

chunks.original_text: 已，语助也。 注云神奇臭腐，庄子云所美为神奇所恶为臭腐是也。 故有无相生。 疏：此明有无性空也。 夫有不自有，因无而有。 凡俗则以无生有。 无不自无，自有而无，凡俗则以有生无。 故云相生，而有无对法，本不相生，相生之名由妄执起，亦如美恶非自性生，是皆空。 故圣人将欲究其迷滞，是以历言六者之惑。 难易相成。 疏：此明难易法空也。 此以难故彼成易，此以易故彼成难。 亦如工者易於本而难於陶，甄匠易於坛而难於木，故云难易相成。 若同其所难，则无易； 同其所易，则无难。 难易无实，妄生名称，是法空。 故能了之者巧拙两忘，则难易名息。 亦如美恶无定故也。 长短相形。 疏：此明长短相空也。 以长故形短，以短故形长，故云长短相形。 亦如凫胫非短，以鹤之长，故续之则忧。 鹤胫非长，因凫之短，故断之则悲。 见长短相形，犹如美恶，既无定体，是皆妄生。 形相既空名亦空，故特未定也。 高下相倾。 疏：此名高下名空也。 高下两名，互相倾夺，故称高必因於下。 又有高之者称下，必因於高，又有下之者，又高则所高非高，又下则所下非下，如彼代间凡诸名位，递为臣妾，亦复无常，是皆空故，故无定位。 音声相和。 疏：此名和合空也。 五音相和成曲者，谁总众声，则能度曲，如代间法皆和合成，即体非真是皆空，故将欲定其美恶，岂云达观之谈。 前后相随。 疏：此明三时空也。 日夜相代，代故以新，如彼投足，孰为前后，则前后之称由相随立名。 名由妄立，诈识其神，过去，未来及以见在三时空，故旋旋迁改，亦美恶无定名也。 六者相违，递为名称，亦如美恶，非自性生，是由妄情，有此多故。 是以圣人至之教。 无为之事，无事也。 寄以事名。 故云处不言之教，忘言也。 寄以教名，故云行也。 疏：是以者，说下明上也。 夫饰智诈者，虽拱默非无为也，任真素者虽终日指挥，而未始不晏然矣。 故圣人知诸法性空，自无矜执，则理天下者当绝浮伪，任用纯德，百姓化之，各安其分，安分则不扰，岂非无为之事乎？ 言出於己，皆因天下之心，则终日言未尝言，岂非不言之教耶？ 万物作焉而不辞。 令万物各自得其动作，而不辞谢於圣人。 疏：作犹动作也，辞谓辞谢也。 言圣人善化，无事无为，百姓不知，爰游爰豫，各自得其动作，而不辞谢於圣人。 故击壤鼓腹而忘帝力，人忘圣功也。 生而不有至不居。 令物各遂其性，不为己有，各得所为而不负慎。 如此，太平之功成矣。 犹当日慎一日，不敢宁居。 疏：今物各得成全其生理，圣人不以为己有。 令物各得其营为，圣人不恃为己功。 如此，太平之功弘济日远，犹宜慎终如始，不敢宁居，此圣人自忘其功也。 云日慎一日，《尚书》文也。 夫惟不居，是以不去。 夫惟不敢宁居，而增修其德者，则忘功而功存，故勿居而不去。 疏：彼圣人者，稠直如发，慎终如始，本末不衰，未尝宁居而逸豫，是以日新其盛德，忘功而功不去，光宅而天下安。 故云夫惟弗居，是以不去。 杜光庭曰：天下皆知美之为美至斯不善已。 天下之人知道者稀，常俗者众。 知修身者寡，徇物者多。 皆知美善为是而莫能为，皆知不善与恶为非而莫能革。 故圣人叹之，故云恶已、不善已。

「已， merely a verbal particle for emphasis.

注云 *"Godly wonders and putrid decay"*—
Zhuangzi states: *"What is deemed beautiful is godly wonders, what is deemed ugly is putrid decay"*—this is precisely it.
Thus, the arising of being and non-being is relative.

**Commentary:**
This elucidates the emptiness of being and non-being’s inherent nature.
Non-being does not exist inherently—it arises from being.
The common folk thus assert that being generates non-being.
Being does not exist inherently—it arises from non-being.
The common folk thus assert that non-being generates being.
Hence, it is said *"they arise in relation"*—
though being and non-being are not inherently dependent,
the names of *"relative generation"* stem from deluded perception,
just as beauty and ugliness are not inherently produced—
all are empty.
Thus, the Sage seeks to investigate this deluded entanglement,
and so proceeds to enumerate the sixfold illusions:
Difficulty and ease arise in relation.

**Commentary:**
This elucidates the emptiness of difficulty and ease’s inherent nature.
Because of difficulty, ease arises;
because of ease, difficulty arises.
It is like the artisan who finds his craft easy in shaping but difficult in firing,
or the potter who finds his kiln easy to manage but wood difficult to work.
Hence, it is said *"difficulty and ease arise in relation."*
If one aligns with what is difficult, then ease does not exist;
if one aligns with what is easy, then difficulty does not exist.
Difficulty and ease are without substance—
their names arise from false perception.
Thus, those who comprehend them abandon both skill and clumsiness,
and the names of difficulty and ease cease.
Similarly, beauty and ugliness are without fixed nature.

Length and shortness arise in contrast.

**Commentary:**
This elucidates the emptiness of length and shortness’s inherent nature.
Because of length, shortness appears;
because of shortness, length appears—
hence *"length and shortness arise in contrast."*
The duck’s legs are not short,
yet when compared to the crane’s length, they seem so—
thus, to extend them causes sorrow.
The crane’s legs are not long,
yet when compared to the duck’s shortness, they seem so—
thus, to shorten them causes grief.
Seeing length and shortness arise in contrast,
it is like beauty and ugliness—
without fixed substance,
all are falsely perceived.
Since their forms are empty, their names are also empty—
hence, they are left undefined.

High and low arise in mutual dependence.

**Commentary:**
This elucidates the emptiness of the names *"high"* and *"low."*
The names *"high"* and *"low"* mutually depend,
hence one speaks of *"high"* only in relation to *"low,"*
and one speaks of *"low"* only in relation to *"high."*
Again, when one deems something *"high,"*
it is not truly high—
when one deems something *"low,"*
it is not truly low.
Like the ministers and subjects of past dynasties,
who constantly shift in status,
these names are also without fixed nature—
hence, no fixed position.

Sounds and voices arise in harmony.

**Commentary:**
This elucidates the emptiness of *"harmony"* and *"union."*
When the five tones harmonize to form a melody,
who unifies all the voices?
Then one can measure the song—
as with the laws of past dynasties,
all harmonize and unite,
yet their essence is not truly real—
all are empty.
Thus, when the Sage seeks to establish beauty and ugliness,
how could he speak of such profound observation?

Past and future arise in succession.

**Commentary:**
This elucidates the emptiness of the three times.
Day and night succeed each other—
the new arises from the old.
Who, when casting a footstep, determines *"past"* and *"future"*?
The names *"past"* and *"future"* arise from their succession.
Since names arise from false perception,
and one deceives oneself in recognizing their essence,
the three times—past, present, and future—are empty.
Thus, they constantly change and transform,
just as beauty and ugliness have no fixed names.

The six arise in opposition,
sequentially generating names—
just as beauty and ugliness,
which are not inherently produced,
stem from deluded emotions,
leading to such manifold confusions.
Thus, the Sage’s ultimate teaching.

*"Non-action"*—
this is the teaching of non-action.
It is metaphorically called *"action"*—
hence, *"abiding in the teaching of non-speech"*—
this is the forgetting of speech.
It is metaphorically called *"teaching"*—
hence, *"practicing"*—

**Commentary:**
*"Thus"*—
this explains the lower to clarify the upper.
Though the adorned and deceitful may remain silent,
they are not practicing non-action;
though the natural and simple may give constant orders,
they remain unperturbed.
Thus, the Sage knows all dharmas are of empty nature—
without arrogance or attachment,
one governs the world by rejecting pretenses,
employing pure virtue.
The people transform accordingly,
each content in their allotted place.
Contentment in one’s place brings no disturbance—
is this not the matter of non-action?
Words issue from oneself,
all based on the world’s hearts—
thus, though speaking all day, one has never truly spoken—
is this not the teaching of non-speech?
All things act naturally without complaint.
The Sage allows all things to follow their own movements,
yet they do not thank or reproach the Sage.

**Commentary:**
*"Act"* means movement—
*"complaint"* means gratitude or reproach.
The Sage’s good governance is without action or effort,
yet the people, unaware, rejoice and are content,
each following their own movements,
without thanking or reproaching the Sage.
Thus, they strike the earth and drum their bellies,
forgetting the Emperor’s power—
the people forget the Sage’s deeds.

*"To give birth without possession,
to act without dwelling"*—
allowing things to fulfill their nature,
not claiming them as one’s own,
each attaining their proper course without neglecting caution.
Thus, the great peace’s function is achieved.
It is still necessary to be cautious each day as one was at the beginning—
not daring to rest complacently.

**Commentary:**
Now, all things attain fulfillment in their natural course,
yet the Sage does not possess them.
The Sage allows all things to follow their own cultivation,
yet does not rely upon them as his own merit.
Thus, the great peace’s function is ever more expansive and distant,
yet it is still fitting to remain cautious as at the outset—
not daring to rest complacently—
this is the Sage’s self-forgetting of his merit.
*"It is still necessary to be cautious each day as one was at the beginning"*—
this is the wording of the *Shan Shu*.
The Sage who does not dwell in merit,
thus does not lose it.
The Sage who does not dare rest complacently,
yet constantly refines his virtue,
forgets his merit while it remains—
thus, he does not dwell in it and yet does not lose it.

**Commentary:**
The Sage is upright like a hair,
cautious to the end as at the beginning,
his beginning and end never decaying.
He never rests complacently or indulges in ease,
thus daily renewing his great virtue,
forgetting his merit while it remains,
illuminating his dwelling as the world finds peace.
Hence, it is said: *"The Sage who does not dwell in merit, thus does not lose it."*
Du Guangting states:
*"All under heaven know beauty as beauty,
yet this does not make them virtuous."*
Under heaven, those who know the Dao are few,
the common are many.
Those who cultivate their bodies are few,
those who follow material desires are many.
All know beauty and virtue as correct,
yet few can practice them;
all know ugliness and evil as incorrect,
yet few can abandon them.
Thus, the Sage laments them—
hence *"ugliness has already arisen,"*
*"evil has already arisen."*

chunks.original_text: 夫戴仁仗义、抱道守谦、忠孝君亲、友悌骨肉，非美善之行也，皆知之矣而不能为。 反於此者乃不善之行也，皆知之矣而不能革，况於修无为之道乎？ 故可欺也。 妄者，非真实之义也，因境起念，随物生情，不守道循常即为妄矣。 神奇臭腐者，《庄子□知北游篇》黄帝谓知曰万物一也。 是其所美者为神奇，所恶者为臭腐，臭腐复化为神奇，神奇复化为臭腐，故曰通天地一气耳。 圣人贵一也。 此明神奇臭腐，物之偏性，百氏殊学，九流异门，递执是非，互生臧否，理身理国，能无为任物，一以贯之，臭腐神奇自然无二矣。 故有无相生，老君叹彼常，徒迷正道，妄生对执，滞此幻情，故明此义以松其执。 执者，着也。 执有即斥无，执无则斥有，执难则斥易，执易则斥难，执短即斥长，执长即斥短，执高即斥下，执下即斥高，执后即斥前，执前即斥后，有此执故皆非究竟。 故经云执者失之，但无偏执，自契中道，便入玄妙正观之门。 难易相成。 夫难因於易，非易无以知其难。 夫易因於难，非难无以彰其易。 循环倚伏，递为之用，审而明之，於难无滞，於易无执，即可以语其齐物，通乎中道矣。 工者巧技之称也，陶者和土为器也。 各擅其侠则为易，更而使之则为难也。 长短相形。 夫物之形也，有短长之相； 夫事之兴也，有难易之法； 化之起也，有有无之变； 俱自然也。 若拘常俗之见，则长者不得不长，短者不得不短。 有无难易在兹乎，滞之则为执，通之则为道。 惟有道者能无滞尔。 凫鹤之喻亦《庄子□骈拇篇》之辞也。 谓各自有正，不可以此正彼，而损益也。 此斥世人不任自然之旨也。

To wear virtue and uphold righteousness,
embrace the Dao while maintaining humility,
serve with loyalty and filial piety toward sovereign and kin,
and cherish brotherly harmony among relatives—
these are not merely acts of beauty and goodness,
yet all know them while few can practice them.
To act contrary to these is evil,
yet all know them while few can abandon them—
how much less can they cultivate the Way of *wuwei*?
Thus, they are deceptive.

Delusion (*mang*) is not true principle.
When mind arises from conditions,
emotions stir with things,
and failing to uphold the Dao or follow constancy—
this is delusion indeed.

The wondrous and the foul, the divine and the rotten—
as in the *Zhuangzi*’s *"Know North Game"* chapter,
the Yellow Emperor told Know:
*"All things are one."*
What they deem wondrous becomes divine,
what they abhor becomes foul,
yet foul transforms into divine,
and divine into foul—
thus it is said: *"It permeates Heaven and Earth as one qi."*

The Sage values unity.
This reveals that divine and foul are but the partial nature of things.
A hundred schools and nine currents,
each clinging to their *shi* and *fei*,
mutually passing judgment—
whether governing the body or the realm,
if one acts without doing and trusts in spontaneity,
unifying all with one thread,
then foul and divine naturally become undivided.

Thus, being and non-being generate each other.
Laozi lamented those who cling to constancy,
lost in the true path,
delusively opposing each other,
entangled in illusory emotions—
hence, this principle is taught to loosen their grasp.

*Existence* (*zhu*) is attachment.
To cling to existence is to reject non-being,
to cling to non-being is to reject existence.
To cling to difficulty is to reject ease,
to cling to ease is to reject difficulty.
To cling to short is to reject long,
to cling to long is to reject short.
To cling to high is to reject low,
to cling to low is to reject high.
To cling to later is to reject earlier,
to cling to earlier is to reject later.
Because of this clinging, none reach ultimate truth.

Thus the scripture says: *"The clinging one loses it."*
But without partial attachment,
one naturally aligns with the Middle Way,
entering the gate of profound and true observation.

Difficulty and ease complement each other.
Difficulty arises from ease—
without ease, one cannot know difficulty.
Ease arises from difficulty—
without difficulty, one cannot recognize ease.
In cyclic dependence, each serves its turn.
Examining and clarifying them,
in difficulty there is no obstruction,
in ease there is no attachment—
then one may speak of harmonizing all things,
penetrating the Middle Way.

*A gōng* is a term for skilled craftsmanship,
while *táo* refers to shaping clay into vessels.
Each excels in their own art—this is ease,
but to force them into another’s method—this is difficulty.

Long and short contrast each other.
Things have forms of short and long,
affairs unfold with laws of difficulty and ease,
transformation arises with changes of being and non-being—
all this is natural.
If one clings to common perceptions,
then long must remain long,
short must remain short.
Do difficulty, ease, being, and non-being lie within this?
To be obstructed is attachment;
to be fluid is the Dao.
Only those who follow the Dao can avoid obstruction.

The metaphor of the duck and crane
also comes from the *Zhuangzi*’s *"Interlocking Thumbs"* chapter,
meaning each has its own proper form—
one cannot impose this standard on that,
nor alter it through gain or loss.
This rejects the world’s failure to trust in spontaneity.

chunks.original_text: 高下相倾。 夫高下之设，名形势位，性智才业，万殊之中皆有高下，则不独拘於名位也。 但高忘其高，下忘其下，各安其分，守以天常，则无倾夺之事矣。 臣者，男子之卑称。 妾者，女子之卑称。 卑伏於人，故称臣妾。 疏：指名位之说。 盖以广戒群情也。 言尊卑之道各安其分，不相倾夺，则保其始终。 若弃卑而慕其尊名。 厌下而图其高位，不安素分，祸败随之。 故经曰知足不辱，知止不殆。 可以长久。 可不戒哉？ 音声相和。 夫天地噫气而众籁作焉，律吕和合而众乐生焉。 声之作也，美恶随之。 故有安乐怨怒、哀思惉懘之别也。 然此别者，人事强而随之，政化因而应之，於达观之士忘其善恶矣。 随变责实，谓之妄情。 美恶都忘，方为达道。 达道之士，虽天地之大，万物之殷，犹无有也。 《乐记》曰：凡音之起，由人心生，心感於物而形於声，声相应故成变，变成方谓之音。 比音而乐之，及干戚羽旎谓之乐。 故哀心感者其声□以杀，乐心感者其声啴以缓，喜心感者其声发以散，怒心感者其声粗以厉，敬心感者其声直以廉，爱心感者其声和以柔。 是以先王慎其所以感，故礼以导其志，乐以和其心，政以一其行，刑以防其奸。 礼乐刑政，其极一也。 音声之道与政通矣。 宫为君，商为臣，角为民，征为事，羽为物。 五者不乱，则无懘之音也。 理世之音安以乐，其政和； 乱世之音怨以怒，其政乖； 亡国之音哀以思，其民困。 宫乱则荒，其君骄； 商乱则陂，其官坏； 角乱则忧，其民怨； 征乱则哀，其事勤； 羽乱则危，其财匮。 五者皆乱，递相凌谓之慢。 郑卫者，乱世之音，比於慢。 桑间濮上者，亡国之音，其政散，其民流。 夫知声而不知音者，禽兽也； 知音不知乐者，众庶也。 唯君子能知乐，审声以知音，审音以知乐，审乐以知政。 不知声者不可以言音，不知音者不可与言乐，知乐者几於礼矣。 子夏对魏文侯曰：郑音好滥淫志，宋音无女溺志，卫音趣数烦志，齐音傲僻骄志。 四者害於德，非正声也。 《春秋》晏子对齐景公曰：先王之济五味以和五声，以平其心，以成其政，声亦如味矣。 一曰气，须气以动也，二曰体，舞象文武也，三曰类，风雅颂也，四曰物，以四方之物成器也。 五声者，宫商角征羽也。 六律者，黄锺、大簇、姑洗、蕤宾、夷则、无射也。 六吕者，夹锺、林锺、仲吕、应锺、南吕、大吕也。 律主於阳，吕主於阴也。 七音，武王伐纣所制也。 自午及子，制七日为七音。 八风，八方之风也。 东方曰明庶，东南曰清明，南曰景风，西南曰凉风，西方曰阎阖，北方曰广莫，西北曰不周，东北曰融风也。 九歌者，六府三事，九功之歌也。 清浊小大、短长疾徐、哀乐刚柔、迟速高下、出入周流，以相成也，以相济也。 君子听之以平其心，心平德和而后几於道矣。 舜作五弦之琴，以歌《南风》； 夔始制乐，以赐诸侯。 理国之道，以音而知理乱，故吴公子季札历听三代古今之乐，而知其兴废也。 修身之士闲视返听，以听无声，然后可与言道矣。 前后相随。 前后之别，生於变动也。 不变不动，谁后谁先？ 既有相随，乃分前后。 达观之士，泯尔都忘，世间之法彰其别耳。 投足者，举步之谓也。 步之举也，孰后孰初？
chunks.translated_text:
High and low incline toward each other.
The establishment of high and low
names forms, status, and positions,
talents, wisdom, and achievements—
within all their diversity, high and low exist.
Thus, it is not merely constrained by titles and rank.

But when the high forget their elevation,
and the low forget their subordination,
each abides in its proper place,
guarding the natural order,
then there will be no usurpation or encroachment.

A subject is the humble designation for a man,
a concubine is the humble designation for a woman.
They are humble and subservient to others,
thus called *chen* and *qie*.
*Cushu*: refers to the doctrine of names and ranks.
This is to broadly warn against the world’s inclinations.

Speaking of the Dao of high and low,
each abides in its proper place,
without encroachment or usurpation,
then it preserves its beginning and end.

If one abandons humility and covets high rank,
or despises lowliness and schemes for exalted position,
failing to accept one’s natural station,
disaster will follow.
Thus the *Classic* says:
*"Knowing contentment brings no disgrace,
knowing restraint brings no peril.
This ensures longevity—
how can one not be warned?"*

Sounds harmonize with one another.
When Heaven and Earth exhale *qi*, all tones arise;
when the *Lü* and *Yue* harmonize, all music is born.
The origin of sound carries beauty or vice with it.
Thus there are distinctions between
serene joy, resentment, anger,
grief, melancholy, and sorrowful lament.

Yet these distinctions,
though imposed by human affairs and followed by governance,
are forgotten by those of penetrating insight.
To follow change while ignoring reality is called *mangqing* (erroneous emotion).
Only when beauty and vice are both forgotten
does one attain the Dao.

Those who grasp the Dao,
though vast as Heaven and Earth,
though teeming as all things,
remain unaffected.

The *Record of Music* states:
*"All sounds arise from the human heart.
The heart, moved by things, manifests in sound.
Sounds resonate and thus create variation—
variation realized is called music.
Comparing sounds to create music,
and using *gan* and *qi* (weapons and feathers) to complete it,
is called *yue* (ritual music).
Thus, when the heart is moved by sorrow,
its sound is sharp and restrained;
when moved by joy,
its sound is bright and slow;
when moved by happiness,
its sound is unrestrained and dispersed;
when moved by anger,
its sound is coarse and fierce;
when moved by reverence,
its sound is upright and austere;
when moved by love,
its sound is harmonious and gentle.
Therefore, the ancient kings were cautious in what moved them,
using ritual to guide their intentions,
music to harmonize their hearts,
governance to unify their actions,
and law to prevent deceit.
Ritual, music, law, and governance—
their ultimate aim is one."*

The Dao of sound and music aligns with governance.
*Gong* is the sovereign,
*Shang* is the minister,
*Jiao* is the people,
*Zheng* is affairs,
*Yu* is things.
If these five remain unconfused,
there will be no discordant tones.

In a well-ordered age, music is serene and joyful—
its governance is harmonious;
in a chaotic age, music is resentful and angry—
its governance is misaligned;
in a doomed state, music is mournful and reflective—
its people are suffering.

If *Gong* is disordered, the land becomes barren,
and its ruler grows arrogant;
if *Shang* is disordered, the officials are corrupt;
if *Jiao* is disordered, the people are anxious;
if *Zheng* is disordered, affairs are laborious;
if *Yu* is disordered, resources are depleted.
When all five are disordered,
they successively oppress one another—this is called *màn* (decadence).

The music of Zheng and Wei
is the music of chaotic times,
comparable to *màn*.
The songs of Sangjian and Puxia
are the music of a dying state—
its governance is scattered,
its people drift away.

Those who know sound but not music
are like beasts;
those who know music but not *yue* (ritual music)
are the common folk.
Only the noble can know *yue*,
discerning sound to know music,
discerning music to know governance,
discerning governance to approach ritual.

Zi Xia replied to Duke Wen of Wei:
*"The music of Zheng seduces and indulges the mind,
the music of Song lacks restraint and drowns the mind,
the music of Wei is repetitive and vexes the mind,
the music of Qi is arrogant and defiant.
These four harm virtue—
they are not proper music."*

In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*,
Yan Zi replied to Duke Jing of Qi:
*"The ancient kings blended the five flavors to harmonize the five tones,
to calm the heart,
to complete governance.
Music is like flavor."*

One: *qi* (breath), which stirs movement;
Two: *ti* (form), which embodies the dances of Wen and Wu;
Three: *lei* (category), which encompasses *feng*, *ya*, and *song*;
Four: *wu* (things), which uses the materials of the four directions to craft instruments.

The five tones: *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zheng*, *yu*.
The six *lü*: *Huangzhong*, *Dadu*, *Guxi*, *Ruibin*, *Yizhi*, *Wushè*.
The six *lü*: *Jiangzhong*, *Linzhong*, *Zhonglü*, *Yingzhong*, *Nanlü*, *Dalu*.
*Lü* governs the yang,
*lü* governs the yin.

The seven tones were established by King Wu
when he conquered Zhou—
from *wu* (noon) to *zi* (midnight),
seven days were measured as seven tones.

The eight winds are the winds of the eight directions:
East: *Ming Shu*,
Southeast: *Qing Ming*,
South: *Ying Feng*,
Southwest: *Liang Feng*,
West: *Yanhé*,
North: *Guang Mo*,
Northwest: *Buzhou*,
Northeast: *Rong Feng*.

*Jiugong* is the song of the six ministries and three affairs,
the nine functions in song.
Clear and turbid, small and great,
short and long, swift and slow,
grief and joy, firm and yielding,
fast and slow, high and low,
entering and exiting, circulating—
these complement and assist one another.
The noble listens to them to calm the heart;
when the heart is calm, virtue harmonizes,
and only then does one approach the Dao.

Shun created the five-stringed *qin*,
and sang *"The South Wind"*;
Qiu first instituted music,
and bestowed it upon the feudal lords.

The method of governing the state
lies in knowing order and disorder through music,
thus the son of Duke Wu of Wu, Ji Zha,
listened to the ancient and modern music of the Three Dynasties,
and knew their rise and fall.

Those who cultivate themselves
observe in stillness and listen in silence,
listening to the unsounded—
only then can they speak of the Dao.

Before and after follow one another.
The distinction between before and after
arises from change and movement.
Without change or motion,
who comes first, who follows?
Once there is succession,
then before and after are divided.

Those of penetrating insight
erase and forget all distinctions—
the world’s laws only emphasize their differences.

*Touzu* refers to taking a step.
When a step is taken,
which comes first, which follows?

chunks.original_text: 明於此者乃绝前后之竟矣。 老君伤悯世俗流荡不还，争起妄情，忘其中道，历指六事以化愚迷耳。 夫中道者，非阴非阳，无偏名也。 处天地之间，傲然自放，所遇而安，了无功名，而反乎道本，虽尧桀之殊，生死之变，是非之别，寿夭之异，荣贱之隔，哀乐之感动，古今之递代，皆忘之也。 不知尧桀之殊，忘美恶也。 不知死生之变，忘有无也。 不知是非之别，忘难易也。 不知寿夭之异，忘长短也。 不知荣贱之隔，忘高下也。 不知哀乐之感动，忘音声也。 不知古今之递代，忘前后也。 处乎无是之乡，立乎不疾之途，遭之而不违，过之而不守，调而应之以德，偶而应之以道也。 益之而不加益，损之而不加损，此了乎中道之士，忘前后之别，忘变动之机矣。 是以圣人至之教。 夫圣人者，与天地合其德，日月合其明，四时合其序，鬼神合其吉凶，谓之圣人也。 略而言之，凡有五种。 第一得道之圣，太上老君、诸天大圣是也。 第二有天下之位，兼得神仙之圣，伏羲、黄帝、颛顼、少昊、尧舜是也。 第三有天下之位，而无得仙之圣。 殷汤文武是也。 皆廓清六合，不言升天矣。 第四博赡之圣无天下之位者，周公孔子制作礼乐，垂范百王，而无九五之位，而皆具天地合德之美也。 第五有独长之圣，而无博赡之名，亦不具上众美者，谓伯牙师文为鼓琴之圣，子卿绥明能棋之圣，锺期延州知音之圣，韩娥秦清讴歌之圣，龚叔文挚智洞之圣，离朱师旷视听之圣，张芝锺县草书之圣。 今经中明者，指言理天下之圣也。 理天下之圣，垂衣裳恭己南面而已矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who are enlightened in this
are thus freed from the bounds of before and after.

Laozi, moved by pity for the common folk
wandering in confusion without return,
quarrelling over false passions,
forgetting the central Dao,
pointed out the Six Matters
to awaken the ignorant and the deluded.

For the central Dao is neither yin nor yang,
having no partial name.
It dwells between Heaven and Earth,
proud and unrestrained in its self-sojourning,
content with whatever it encounters—
free from all striving for gain or fame,
yet returning to the root of the Dao.
Even the differences between Yao and Jie,
the shifts of life and death,
the distinctions of right and wrong,
the disparities of long and short-lived,
the gulf between honor and disgrace,
the stirrings of sorrow and joy,
the succession of ancient and modern times—
all are forgotten by it.

To not know the differences between Yao and Jie
is to forget the distinction between good and evil.
To not know the shifts of life and death
is to forget the existence of anything.
To not know the distinctions of right and wrong
is to forget the difficulty of what is easy.
To not know the disparities of long and short-lived
is to forget the length and brevity of things.
To not know the gulf between honor and disgrace
is to forget high and low.
To not know the stirrings of sorrow and joy
is to forget sound and voice.
To not know the succession of ancient and modern times
is to forget before and after.

Dwelling in the realm of no "rightness,"
standing on the path of no "hurry,"
encountering it without resistance,
passing it without clinging,
adjusting to it with virtue,
aligning with it through the Dao—

Adding to it without conferring benefit,
subtracting from it without conferring harm—
these are the ones who have fully grasped the central Dao,
forgetting the distinctions of before and after,
forgetting the mechanisms of change.

Thus, the Sage attains the highest teaching.
For the Sage is one who aligns with Heaven and Earth in virtue,
with the sun and moon in luminosity,
with the Four Seasons in order,
with the spirits and gods in auspicious and inauspicious omens—
such is called the Sage.

Briefly speaking, there are five categories.
First, the Sage who attains the Dao: the Supreme Sage Laozi, the Great Sages of the heavens.
Second, the Sage who holds the position under Heaven and attains the virtue of immortality: Fu Xi, the Yellow Emperor, Zhuānxū, Shàohào, Yao, and Shun.
Third, the Sage who holds the position under Heaven but lacks the virtue of immortality: the Sages of the Shang and Zhou dynasties, Tang, and Wen and Wu of the Zhou.
All of them cleared the Six Extremes, yet they did not speak of ascending to Heaven.

Fourth, the Sage of broad and comprehensive virtue without the position under Heaven:
Zhougong and Confucius established rituals and music,
set examples for a hundred kings,
yet did not hold the Nine Five position,
yet all possessed the beauty of aligning with Heaven and Earth’s virtue.

Fifth, the Sage with singular excellence,
without the name of broad and comprehensive virtue,
nor possessing the virtues of the above categories:
the Sage of the *qín* (琴) is Boya and Shifu;
the Sage of chess is Ziqing and Suiming;
the Sage of discerning sound is Zhongqi and Yanzhou;
the Sage of singing is Han Ao and Qin Qing;
the Sage of wisdom is Gong Sun and Wen Zhi;
the Sage of vision and hearing is Lizhu and Shigong;
the Sage of calligraphy is Zhang Xu and Zhong Xuan.

In the scriptures, the "enlightened" refers to those who govern the world through principles.
The Sage who governs the world through principles
need only wear formal robes, maintain a respectful demeanor,
and face south—
that is all.

chunks.original_text: 何为哉？ 所谓处无为之事也。 原天地之美，达万物之理，顺四时之行，君无为於上，物自化於下，可谓行不言之教也。 理国如此，则人安其居，乐其俗，与道合矣。 万物作焉而不辞。 圣人之於万物也，万物自古而固存，岂待为之而后存哉？ 物自得其生，盲动作也。 爰游爰豫，《太玄经》之词。 言上既无为，其下自遂，故闲暇也。 击壤者，壤，土也。 《庄子□马蹄篇》云：赫胥氏之时，民含哺而嬉，鼓腹而游也。 不知帝力者，王充《论衡》曰：尧之为君荡荡乎，人无得而名，有年五十者，击壤於路，鼓腹而歌曰：凿井而饮，耕田而食，日出而作，日入而息，帝何力於我？ 此众庶之忘圣功也。 生而至不居。
chunks.translated_text:
What then is this?
It is called dwelling in affairs of *wuwei* (無為).

To observe the beauty of Heaven and Earth,
to comprehend the principles of all things,
to follow the course of the Four Seasons—
when the ruler does *wuwei* above,
things transform spontaneously below.
This may be called practicing the teaching of *non-speech* (不言).

To govern the realm thus,
then the people find contentment in their dwellings,
joy in their customs,
and align with the Dao.

All things arise and act without complaint.
The Sage, regarding all things,
has them exist naturally since antiquity—
why should they await his doing before existing?
Things find their own way to life,
moving spontaneously, as in the words of the *Taixuan Jing* (《太玄经》):
*"Free to wander, free to delight."*

When the ruler above does *wuwei*,
those below naturally thrive,
thus there is leisure.

The "striking the earth" (擊壤) refers to earth, the soil.
As in the *Zhuangzi* (《庄子》□馬蹄篇):
*"In the time of Huixu, the people carried food in their mouths and played,
drummed their bellies and wandered."*

Those unaware of the Sovereign’s power—
as Wang Chong (*Lunheng* 《论衡》) says:
*"Emperor Yao ruled with boundless ease,
so nameless to the people.
An old man of fifty struck the earth by the roadside,
drummed his belly, and sang:
'We dig wells to drink,
till fields to eat,
rise with the sun, rest with the moon—
what power does the Sovereign hold over me?'
This is the common folk forgetting the Sage’s deeds."*

Born and yet not dwelling—
*not residing* (不居).

chunks.original_text: 夫圣人处物不伤於物，物遂其生； 物遂其生，圣人不有之而恃其功，任自然也，处至顺也。 夫功者，王功曰勋，辅成王业若周公也； 国功曰功，保全国家若伊尹也； 民功曰庸，施法於民若后稷也； 事功曰劳，以劳定国若夏禹也； 理功曰绩，制法成理若咎孙也； 战功曰多，克敌出奇若韩信也。 生成万物者玄功也，其功深远曰玄也。 功成而不居所以全无为之功也。 日慎一日，巳具疏解，言圣人有及物之功，不自伐自恃，惟恐失其所，以隳其功，故曰加慎，不敢宁息尔。 宁，安也，慎谨也。 圣人无为，其功广大，物遂其性，不失其宜，天清於上，地宁於下四海平一，泰然而宁，是太平之谓也。 夫惟至不去。 夫惟者，发句之语也。 谓上不有不居之事也，夫圣人威加四海而不为有，泽被万物而不为惠，功格天下而不为己，德冠四时而不为主，忘怀於至道，合志於虚无，处上而人不重，处前而人不害，天下乐推而人不厌，故其志不去矣。 王者不妄於喜怒，则刑赏不滥，金革不起矣。 不妄於求取，则赋敛不厚供亿不繁矣。 不妄於爱恶，则用舍必当，贤不肖别矣。 不妄於近侍，则左右前后皆正人矣。 不妄於土地，则兵革不出，士卒不劳矣。 不妄於万姓，则天下安矣。 物得其分，不恃其功，无为，不恃之利，信哉博矣。 稠直如发，《诗□小雅□都人士篇》之词也。 言情性密致，操行正直，如发之本末，无隆杀也。 道君曰：天下皆知至斯不善已。 道无异相，孰为美恶。 性本一致，孰为善否。 有美也，恶为之对。 故曰天下皆知美之为美，斯恶已。 有善也，不善为之对。 故曰皆知善之为善，斯不善已。 世之所美者为神奇，所恶者为臭腐，神奇复化为臭腐，臭腐复化为神奇，则美与恶奚辨？ 昔之所是，今或非之。 今之所弃，后或用之。
chunks.translated_text:
The Sage, in dwelling among things, is not harmed by them;
things fulfill their own nature.
When things fulfill their own nature,
the Sage does not claim their fruits but relies on their virtue—
trusting in Nature, abiding in perfect harmony.

Now, *function* (功) has different names:
The ruler’s *function* is called *merit* (勋),
as when the Duke of Zhou aided the King’s work.
The state’s *function* is called *achievement* (功),
as when Yi Yin preserved the nation.
The people’s *function* is called *service* (庸),
as when Hou Ji taught the laws of cultivation.
The laborer’s *function* is called *toil* (劳),
as when Yu of Xia stabilized the realm through exertion.
The administrator’s *function* is called *accomplishment* (绩),
as when Gou Sun established just ordinances.
The warrior’s *function* is called *victory* (多),
as when Han Xin triumphed with unconventional strategy.

Yet the *mysterious function* (玄功) is that which brings forth all things—
its depth and reach are profound, hence called *mysterious*.
When function is complete yet not claimed,
the Sage preserves the virtue of *wuwei*.

Day by day, he grows more cautious—
already explained in detail—
for the Sage’s deeds reach outward,
yet he does not boast, only fears failing his purpose,
lest his function collapse.
Thus he is ever vigilant, never at rest.

*Ning* (宁) means both *tranquility* and *diligence*.
The Sage’s *wuwei* is vast in its function,
things fulfill their nature without loss,
the heavens clear above, the earth settled below,
the Four Seas unified in peace—
serene and at rest—
this is called *Great Peace*.

Now, *only* (夫惟) is the opening phrase—
meaning the Sage does not depart from non-possession.
The Sage’s influence extends to the Four Seas, yet he does not claim it;
his benevolence covers all things, yet he does not call it favor;
his function shapes the world, yet he does not take it as his own;
his virtue surpasses the Four Seasons, yet he does not rule as master.
He forgets himself in the Dao,
harmonizes his will with the Void,
dwelling above yet not making others feel his weight,
dwelling before yet not harming them,
the world willingly follows, yet none grow weary—
thus his resolve does not waver.

The ruler who does not err in joy or anger
avoids excessive punishments and rewards,
and war does not arise.

Who does not err in seeking and taking
avoids heavy taxation and burdensome provisions.

Who does not err in love or hatred
ensures proper appointments and distinguishes the worthy from the unworthy.

Who does not err in choosing attendants
makes all around him upright.

Who does not err in governing lands
keeps arms idle and soldiers unlabored.

Who does not err in treating the people
brings peace to the world.

Things find their proper place,
not relying on function,
*wuwei* without seeking its benefits—
truly vast and profound!

*"Thick and straight as hair"*—words from the *Shijing* (《诗□小雅□都人士篇》),
speaking of emotions sincere and conduct upright,
like the root and tip of a hair—
no excess, no deficiency.

The Dao of the ruler says:
*"When all know beauty as beauty, then ugliness arises.
The Dao has no differing forms—who decides what is good or evil?
Nature is inherently unified—who judges right or wrong?
Where there is beauty, there is its opposite, ugliness.
Thus, when all know beauty as beauty, ugliness arises.
Where there is goodness, there is its opposite, ungoodness.
Thus, when all know goodness as goodness, ungoodness arises.
What the world now admires as divine and strange,
it once despised as foul and rotten.
Divine and strange may transform into foul and rotten,
foul and rotten may transform into divine and strange—
then how can beauty and ugliness be distinguished?
What was once right may later be wrong.
What is now discarded may later be used."*

Those unaware of the Sovereign’s power—
as Wang Chong (*Lunheng* 《论衡》) says:
*"Emperor Yao ruled with boundless ease,
so nameless to the people.
An old man of fifty struck the earth by the roadside,
drummed his belly, and sang:

chunks.original_text: 则善与不善奚择？ 圣人体真无而常有，即妙用而常无，美恶善否，盖将简之而不得，尚何恶与不善之能累哉？ 故有无相生至前后相随。 太易未判，万象同体，两仪既生，物物为对。 此六对者，群变所交，百虑所生，殊涂所起，世之人所以陷溺而不能出者也。 无动而生有，有复归无，故曰有无之相生，有涉险之难，则知行地之易，故曰难易之相成，长短之相形，若尺寸是也。 高下之相形倾，若山泽是也。 声举而响应，故曰声音之相和。 形动而影从，故曰前后之相随。 阴阳之运，四时之行，万物之理，俄造而有，倏化而无。 其难也，若有为以经世。 其易也，若无为以适己。 性长非所断，性短非所续，天之自高，地之自下，鼓宫而宫动，鼓角而角应，春先而夏从，长先而少从。 对待之境虽皆道所寓，而去道也远矣。 是以圣人至之教。 处无为之事，《庄子》所谓无为而用天下也。 行不言之教，《易》所谓以神道设教而天下服也。 为则有成亏，言则有当愆，曾未免乎累，岂圣人所以独立乎万物之上，化万物而物之所不能累欤？ 万物作焉而不辞至不去。 万物并作，随感而应，若鉴对形，妍丑毕现； 若谷应声，美恶皆赴； 无所辞也。 故曰万物作而不辞，自生自化，自形自色，各极其高大而遂其性，孰有之哉？ 故曰生而不有。 整万物而不为利，泽及万世而不为化，覆载天地，雕刻众形而不为巧，故曰为而不恃。 四时之运，功成者去，天之道也。 圣人体之，故功盖天下而似不自己，认而有之亦己惑矣。 故曰功成不居，有居则有去，古今是也。 在己无居，物莫能迁，适来时也，适去顺也，何加损焉？ 故曰夫惟不居，是以不去。 王介甫曰：天下皆知至不善已。 夫美者恶之对，善者不善之反。 此物理之常，惟圣人乃无对於万物，自非圣人之所为，皆有对矣。 故有无相生至相随。 有之与无，难之与易，高之与下，音之与声，前之与后，是皆不免有所对，唯能兼忘此六者，则可以入神，入神则无对於天地之间矣。 《字说》：无从大，霖从亡，盖大霖者有之极也，有极则复此於无者矣。 老子曰：有无之相生。 是以圣人至之教。 圣人观有之有对，於是处无为之事，行不言之教。 圣人未尝不为也，盖为出於不为； 圣人未尝不言也，盖言出於不言。 生而不有至功成不居。 生之而不有其生，为之而不恃其为，功成而不居其功，此三者皆出於无我。 惟其无我，然后不失己。 非惟不失己，而又不失人。 不知无我而常至於有我，则不惟失己。 非惟不失己，而又不失人。 功成则居，居则与去为对。 圣人不居上之三者，然后道之常在於我，而不去也。 苏颍滨曰：天下皆知至前后相随。 天下以形名言美恶。 其所谓美且善者，岂信美且善哉？ 彼不知有无难易、长短高下、声音前后之相生相夺，皆非其正也。 方且自以为长而有长於我者临之，斯则短矣。 方且自以为前而有前於我者先之，斯则后矣。 苟从其所美而信之，则失之远矣。 是以圣人至之教。 当事而为无为之之心者，当教而言无言之之意者，夫是以出於长短之度，离於先后之数，非美非恶，非善非不善，而天下何足以知之？ 万物作焉至不居。 万物为我作而我无所辞，我生之为之而未尝有未尝恃，至於成功亦未尝以自居也，此则无为不言之教，其为美且善也。
chunks.translated_text:
Then how can goodness and ungoodness be chosen?

The Sage embodies the True One—ever present yet ever absent,
manifesting wondrous use yet ever without—
beauty and ugliness, goodness and ungoodness,
are all but simplified away—
how then could evil and ungoodness ever burden?

Thus, the interplay of *having* and *non-having* unfolds,
forever preceding and following.
Before the *Tàiyī* was differentiated, all phenomena shared one body.
Once the Two Forces emerged, each thing found its opposite.

These six pairs—
where myriad transformations intersect,
where myriad thoughts arise,
where divergent paths begin—
are the snares by which the world is ensnared, unable to escape.

Without motion, there is *having*;
*having* returns to *non-having*—
thus, the interplay of *having* and *non-having*.
Where there is peril in crossing,
one knows the ease of traversing—
thus, the interplay of difficulty and ease,
of length and shortness—
as with inches and spans.
High and low take form in contrast—
as with mountains and marshes.
Sound rises, echo responds—
thus, the harmony of sound and voice.
Form moves, shadow follows—
thus, the succession of before and after.

The movement of yin and yang,
the progression of the four seasons,
the principles of all things—
suddenly formed, then suddenly vanished.
Its difficulty is like deliberate action governing the world;
its ease is like effortless alignment with nature.

What is long is not to be severed,
what is short is not to be extended—
heaven naturally ascends, earth naturally descends.
Strike the *gōng* and the *gōng* resonates;
strike the *jué* and the *jué* responds.
Spring comes first, summer follows;
the elder precedes, the younger follows.

Though these paired realms all rest within the Dao,
they are far from the Dao itself.

Thus, the Sage’s supreme teaching:
to act in *wuwei*, as *Zhuangzi* said—
*"to govern the world without action."*
To practice speechless instruction, as the *Yijing* taught—
*"to set the divine Way as teaching, and the world submits."*

To act is to risk failure;
to speak is to risk error—
how could this ever be free from entanglement?
How could this be the Sage’s way of standing above all things,
transforming all things without being burdened by them?

All things arise, yet the Sage does not decline or withdraw.
All things act in concert, responding as sensed—
like a mirror reflecting form, revealing beauty and ugliness alike;
like a valley echoing sound, revealing goodness and evil alike—
without refusal.

Thus, *"all things arise, yet the Sage does not decline."*
They self-generate, self-transform,
self-form, self-color,
each reaching their utmost height and fulfilling their nature—
who could claim ownership?
Thus, *"to give birth yet not possess."*

To harmonize all things yet seek no gain,
to benefit ten thousand generations yet claim no transformation,
to encompass heaven and earth, to carve all forms yet claim no craft—
thus, *"to act yet not rely."*

The seasons turn, and the effective departs—
this is the Way of Heaven.
The Sage embodies it,
so achievements cover the world yet seem not of oneself—
to claim them would only be self-deception.
Thus, *"when success is achieved, do not dwell upon it."*
Dwelling invites departure—
as past and present attest.
To dwell within oneself is to remain unshaken;
to follow the coming is natural,
to follow the going is natural—
what harm or gain is there?
Thus, *"only by not dwelling does one not depart."*

Wang Anshi said:
*"When all know beauty as beauty, then ugliness arises."*
Beauty is the opposite of ugliness,
goodness the opposite of ungoodness—
this is the constant principle of things.
Only the Sage stands without opposition to all things.
What is not the Sage’s doing all has opposites.
Thus, the interplay of *having* and *non-having* unfolds,
forever preceding and following.

*Having* and *non-having*,
difficulty and ease,
length and shortness,
high and low,
sound and voice,
before and after—
all inevitably have their opposites.
Only by transcending these six pairs
can one enter the divine—
and entering the divine, one stands without opposition between heaven and earth.

*The Zìshuō* says:
*"Wu* from *dà*, *lín* from *wáng*—
the ultimate of *having* is to return to *non-having*.*
Laozi said:
*"The interplay of having and non-having."*

Thus, the Sage’s supreme teaching:
The Sage, observing that *having* has opposites,
therefore acts in *wuwei* and teaches without speech.
The Sage never fails to act—
yet action arises from *wuwei*.
The Sage never fails to speak—
yet speech arises from *non-speech*.

From *"giving birth yet not possessing"* to *"achieving success yet not dwelling"*—
to give birth yet not claim its birth,
to act yet not rely on the act,
to achieve success yet not dwell upon it—
these three arise from *wu-wǒ* (no-self).

Only by *wu-wǒ* does one not lose oneself.
Not only does one not lose oneself,
but one also does not lose others.
To fail to know *wu-wǒ* and instead dwell in *yǒu-wǒ* (self),
is not only to lose oneself—
but also to lose others.

To dwell upon success is to invite departure;
dwelling and departure are opposites.
The Sage’s three non-dwellings—
only then does the Dao abide within oneself,
and not depart.

Su Yán said:
*"When all know beauty as beauty, then ugliness arises."*
The world judges beauty and ugliness by form and name.
What they call beautiful and good—
is it truly beautiful and good?
They do not know the interplay of *having* and *non-having*,
difficulty and ease, length and shortness, high and low,
sound and voice, before and after—
all these are not their true nature.

Just as one assumes length, yet a longer one surpasses—
then one is short.
Just as one assumes precedence, yet a prior one comes—
then one is last.
If one follows what is deemed beautiful and believes it,
one strays far from the truth.

Thus, the Sage’s supreme teaching:
When acting, hold the heart of *wuwei*;
when teaching, hold the intent of *non-speech*—
thus, transcending measures of length and shortness,
free from ranks of before and after,
neither beautiful nor ugly,
neither good nor ungood—
how could the world ever comprehend?

From *"all things arise"* to *"not dwelling"*—
all things act for me, yet I decline none;
I give birth to them, yet never claim or rely—
even in success, I never dwell upon it—
this is the teaching of *wuwei* and *non-speech*,
its beauty and goodness beyond measure.
