chunks.original_text: 岂复有恶与不善继之哉？ 夫惟至不去。 圣人居於贫贱，而无贫贱之忧； 居於富贵，而无富贵之累。 此所谓不居也。 我且不居，彼尚何从去哉？ 此则居之至也。 吕吉甫曰：天下皆知至斯不善已。 天下皆知美之为美，善之为善，而欲之知恶与不善而恶之，然自道言之，则虽美与善皆离乎道矣。 自出於道言之，则虽恶与不善皆非道之外也。 由是观之，则美斯恶，善斯不善，岂虚言哉？ 故有无相生至相随。 天下之物生於有，有生於无，是之谓有无之相生。 难事作於易，而易亦由难之故无难，是之谓难易之相成。 有鹤经之长，而后知有兔经之短； 有凫胫之短，而后知有鹤胫之长。 是之谓长短之相形。 以高为是，则百谷为川渎之源，则高有以倾乎下； 以下为是，则川渎为百谷之归，则下有以倾乎高。 是之谓高下之相倾。 黄锺为君，则余律和之； 余律为君，则黄锺和之。 是之谓音声之相和。 自秋冬而望春夏，则春夏前而秋冬后； 自春夏而望秋冬，则秋冬前而春夏后。 是之谓前后之相随。 是以圣人至之教。 圣人处无为之事，无为也，无事则无心，圣人无心，以百姓心为心。 行不言之教，无言也。 无言则言出於不言，虽事不涉为之之迹，虽教不发言之之意，故事济而教行。 万物作焉而不辞至不居。 功名虽高，岂有无满之累乎？ 将使人反常复朴，与天地为徒，与造化为友也。 夫惟至不去。 不居则去为对，此道之常在我，岂有迁去哉？ 陆农师曰：天下皆知至不善已。 美至於无美者，天下之真美也。 善至於无善者，天下之真善也。 真美斯离，天下窗知美之为美。 真善斯散，天下皆知善之为善。 故有无相生至相随。 有无者以言乎其道，难易者以言乎其德，长短者以言乎其体，高下者以言乎其位，声音者以言乎其交感，前后者以言乎其始终，此势之然也。 是以圣人至之教。 夫圣人处无为之事，行不言之教者，将以使人冥於真善，混於真美，复归于朴，而与天地，与造化为友者矣。 万物作焉而不辞至不去。 万物之息，与之入而不逆； 万物之作，与之出而不辞。 王元泽曰：天下皆知至不善已。 道本无物，物有妄情，自相分别，此溺於转徙之流而不能自出故耳。 然溺而不出者，不由厌离而乐着，所以恶不善也。 故恶与不善，美善之随也。 当其美善之时，盖已恶且不善矣。 俟其随而后悟，则亦悟之晚也。 虽然，至人所谓美善未离乎恶与不善，而恶与不善未尝离乎美善也。 天下之愚不足与此。 故所谓美善，常恶与不善也。 《新说》：此言美恶善不善相逐而妄者，溺於美善，不如有恶与不善也。 唯圣人超然远览，知美之有恶，善之有不善，未尝有所溺也。 故有无相生至相随。 离道而我，我则有彼。 彼我既分，触类为二矣。 此六对者，物之所以不齐，而喜怒哀乐、生死之变、更出迭入而不能自止者也。 凡此皆不冥夫阴阳之本，而随其末流自性分别，执一废百，以妄为常故耳。 此篇第二与《庄子□齐物论》相似，篇有叙篇，可以理推。 是以圣人至之教。 圣人无心，以百姓心为心，虽事而未尝涉为之之进，虽教而未尝发言之之意，故事以之济，教以之行。 而吾寂然，未始有言为之累，而天下亦因得以反常而复朴也。 夫惟无累，故虽寄形阴阳之间，而造化不能移。
chunks.translated_text:
No evil or ungoodness could follow it—
for the Sage’s ultimate teaching is *not departing*.

The Sage dwells in poverty and lowliness yet knows no worry of poverty or lowliness;
dwells in wealth and honor yet bears no burden of wealth and honor—
this is called *not dwelling*.

If I do not dwell, how could others depart?
This is the ultimate of *dwelling*.

Lu Jiufu said:
All under heaven know that the ultimate is not ungood.
All under heaven know beauty as beauty, goodness as goodness,
yet desire to know evil and ungoodness to hate them—
yet when speaking of the Dao itself,
even beauty and goodness depart from the Dao.
When speaking of the Dao’s emergence,
even evil and ungoodness are not outside it.
Thus observed, beauty becomes evil, goodness becomes ungood—
is this not true?

Hence, *having* and *non-having* generate and follow one another.
Things under heaven arise from *having*, *having* from *non-having*—
this is called the generation of *having* and *non-having*.
Difficult things arise from ease, yet ease arises from difficulty—
without difficulty, there would be no ease—
this is called the completion of difficult and easy.
The crane’s long legs reveal the hare’s short;
the duck’s short legs reveal the crane’s long—
this is called the contrast of long and short.
If high is taken as true, then all valleys are the source of rivers—
then high would tilt toward the low.
If low is taken as true, then rivers are the confluence of valleys—
then low would tilt toward the high.
This is called the mutual incline of high and low.
If the yellow bell is master, the other bells harmonize;
if the other bells are master, the yellow bell harmonizes—
this is called the mutual resonance of sounds.
From autumn and winter, spring and summer appear prior;
from spring and summer, autumn and winter appear prior—
this is called the succession of before and after.
Thus, the Sage’s ultimate teaching:
The Sage acts in *wuwei*, yet *wuwei* means no action—
no action, no mind; the Sage’s mind is the people’s mind.
He teaches through *non-speech*, yet *non-speech* means no words—
no words, yet words emerge from *non-speech*.
Though deeds leave no trace of doing,
though teaching reveals no intent of speech,
yet affairs are accomplished, and teaching takes root.
All things act, yet he declines none—
his virtue is ultimate, without the burden of success.
He would make people return to simplicity, become companions of Heaven and Earth,
friends of Creation and Transformation.
For the ultimate is *not departing*.

*Not departing* is the opposite of departing—
this Dao abides within me, how could it ever shift?

Lu Nongshi said:
All under heaven know that the ultimate is not ungood.
When beauty reaches *non-beauty*, that is true beauty under heaven.
When goodness reaches *non-goodness*, that is true goodness under heaven.
True beauty departs, yet all under heaven know beauty as beauty.
True goodness disperses, yet all under heaven know goodness as goodness.
Hence, *having* and *non-having* generate and follow one another.
*Having* and *non-having* speak of the Dao’s essence,
difficult and easy speak of its virtue,
long and short speak of its form,
high and low speak of its position,
sounds speak of mutual resonance,
before and after speak of beginning and end—
this is the natural order.
Thus, the Sage’s ultimate teaching:
The Sage acts in *wuwei*, teaches through *non-speech*,
to make people merge with true goodness, blend with true beauty,
return to simplicity, and become companions of Heaven and Earth,
friends of Creation and Transformation.
All things act, yet he declines none—
he does not depart.
All things exhale, and he follows them inward without resistance;
all things arise, and he follows them outward without refusal.

Wang Yuanzai said:
All under heaven know that the ultimate is not ungood.
The Dao is originally without things;
things have delusive emotions, self-differentiating—
this is drowning in the flow of transformation, unable to emerge.
Yet those who drown do not emerge because they do not weary of attachment
but instead cling to delight—
thus they hate ungoodness.
Hence, evil and ungoodness follow beauty and goodness.
When beauty and goodness arise, they are already evil and ungood.
Waiting for their reversal to awaken is already late.
Still, the Perfect One says beauty and goodness have not departed from evil and ungoodness,
nor have evil and ungoodness departed from beauty and goodness.
The foolish under heaven cannot comprehend this.
Thus, beauty and goodness are always evil and ungood.

*The New Saying* states:
This speaks of those who blindly follow beauty and goodness,
preferring evil and ungoodness to beauty and goodness.
Only the Sage, detached and far-seeing, knows
that beauty contains evil, goodness contains ungoodness—
never drowning in them.

Hence, *having* and *non-having* generate and follow one another.
To separate from the Dao is to create *self*—
*self* creates *other*.
Once *self* and *other* divide, duality arises in all things.
This is why emotions, life and death, and transformations
emerge and recede without end—
all failing to grasp the root of yin and yang,
instead following superficial distinctions,
fixating on one while abandoning the rest,
taking delusion as truth.

This second section resembles *Zhuangzi’s "Equating Things"* in structure,
with a sequential argument that can be logically traced.
Thus, the Sage’s ultimate teaching:
The Sage’s mind is the people’s mind—
though he acts, he never advances his own doing;
though he teaches, he never reveals his intent of speech.
Yet affairs are accomplished, teaching takes root,
while I remain still, never burdened by words,
and all under heaven thus return to simplicity.

Only without burden could one,
though lodged between yin and yang,
resist the sway of Creation and Transformation.

chunks.original_text: 彼六对者，恶能扰之哉？ 万物作而不辞。 万物并作，圣人各尽其性而无所辞，以吾心寂然，无去取故也。 苟怀去取之虑，则物之万态美恶多矣。 乌能不辞哉？ 生而至不居。 有我则居，居则迁矣。 夫惟至不去。 形名已降，莫不代谢，惟道无体，物莫能迁，圣人体道，故充塞无外，而未尝有物，应接万变，而未尝有心。 如是，则岂以适然之事搅以为功，而固有之哉？ 夫然后离六对之境，绝美恶之名，越生死流处常住法也，持此心以涉世，则功名虽高，岂有亢满之累乎？ 刘仲平曰：天下皆知至不善已。 天下皆知吾美之为美，则美不足其终也，反谓恶．而已矣。 天下皆知吾善之为善，则善不足其终也，反谓不善而已矣。 是以圣人至之教。 惟单人处无为之事，行不言之教，使天下不知吾有善与美，之所以然者，此其道教人而不去也。 夫惟至不去。 夫惟不居，是以不去者，言与为成，故此举断以不居也。 不去谓处六对之间，为独立也哉。 民冥无知，既以流於六对，而於六者又绝而去之，不以事教为应，则民何赖乎？ 唯不居功，则虽不去之，其善救大矣。 庄子曰：因万物而不去。 刘巨济曰：天下皆知至不善已。 妙名立则美善生矣，徼名立则恶不善生矣，美名立则恶生矣，善名立则不善生矣，皆道之失也。 善恶之性虽立而名名字字，未始有极也，俗学不能知然，而知所好，方以为美也，而恶因之； 以为善也，而不善因之。 圣人虽不能绝於善恶，亦不能离善恶而独立，然能以美为恶，以善为不善，亦能以恶为美，以不善为善。 庄子曰：所美者为神奇，所恶者为臭腐，臭腐复为神奇，神奇复为臭腐。 故有无相生至相随。 得鹿者俄失之，失马者俄得之，得失无端，相生之类也。 水者不车，陆者不舟，巧拙无端，相成之端，相成之类也。 冥灵朝菌，寿夭无端，相形之类也。 王公乞人，贵贱无端，相倾之类也。 梦饮酒者，旦而哭泣，哀乐无端，相和之类也。 婴孩、少壮、老耄，死亡无端，相随之类也。 此六对者，皆因於善恶为名字，言未知有极者也。 惟见晓於冥冥之中，则能知之，知之则齐之。 是以圣人至之教。 善恶既分，则有六对。 为民宜无知，则其为贵大矣。 同民患者，於是有事。 又有教焉，远为之而事成者，无为之事也。 近言之而教行者，不善之教也。 有事有教，特以救俗而已，反与之同流，将为六对者之所浮沉，尚何以为贵乎？ 庄子曰：至言去言，至为去为。 万物作而不辞。 此申不言之义，委万物於自造，而不能说，故曰作而不辞。 既作则生，既生则教行焉，为举之以无我，故曰生而不有。 以辞属言者，盖令万物则口不能无费者也。 夫惟至不去。 为而不恃，功成不居者，此申不为之有为则事成，有事则功成，侍为於前，则功居於后矣。 刘骥曰：天下皆知美之为美至是以不去。 混沌未判，万象同体。 二气既分，物物为对。 既谓之美，则纯朴已残，必有恶为之对。 既谓之善，则性情已离，必有不善为之对。 美或为恶，善或为不善。 是犹有无之相生，难易之相成，长短之相形，高下之相倾，声音之相和，前后之相随，此六对者可否相因，终始反覆，非天下之至正也。 昔之所是，今或非之，今之所弃，后或用之。
chunks.translated_text:
The six pairs—how could they disturb him?
Ten thousand things arise without refusal.
When all things arise together,
the Sage exhausts their nature without hesitation,
for my mind is still—
without grasping or rejecting.

If one harbors thoughts of grasping or rejecting,
then the myriad forms of things—beautiful or ugly—are endless.
How could one refuse them?

Born yet never dwelling.
To dwell is to perish.
Only the utterly non-dwelling endures.
Once form and name descend,
all undergo transformation and decay—
yet the Dao has no substance,
and nothing can displace it.
The Sage embodies the Dao,
thus filling all without boundary,
yet never possessing anything;
responding to ten thousand changes,
yet never harboring intent.

Then how could one cling to transient affairs,
fixating on them as achievement?
Only then does one transcend the realm of the six pairs,
sever the names of beauty and ugliness,
and dwell in the eternal law beyond birth and death.

Holding this mind to traverse the world,
even if fame and achievement are lofty,
how could there be the burden of arrogance?

Liu Zhongping said:
When all under heaven know that the utmost ugliness is ugliness,
then ugliness cannot persist—
it becomes beauty instead.
When all under heaven know that the utmost goodness is goodness,
then goodness cannot persist—
it becomes non-goodness instead.

Thus, the Sage’s ultimate teaching:
Only the solitary one dwells in the affairs of non-action,
practicing the teaching of non-speech,
so that all under heaven do not know of my goodness or beauty.
This is how the Dao teaches without departing—
for it is utterly non-departing.
For it is utterly non-dwelling,
thus non-departing is achieved—
this is why it is called non-dwelling.
Non-dwelling means standing independently
amidst the six pairs.

The people are in ignorance,
already swept along by the six pairs.
If one cuts off and departs from these six,
and does not respond with deeds or teachings,
then what reliance do the people have?
Only by not dwelling on achievement
does one, though not departing,
save them greatly.

Zhuangzi said: *"Follow ten thousand things without departing."*

Liu Jujie said:
When all under heaven know that the utmost ugliness is ugliness,
then wondrous names arise, and beauty and goodness emerge.
When false names arise, ugliness and non-goodness emerge.
When the name of beauty arises, ugliness emerges.
When the name of goodness arises, non-goodness emerges—
all are deviations from the Dao.
Though the natures of good and evil may arise,
their names and words have no end.
The vulgar cannot know this,
yet they know what they favor,
and call it beautiful—
while ugliness follows.
They call it good—
while non-goodness follows.

The Sage, though unable to sever good and evil,
cannot stand apart from them either.
Yet he can turn beauty into ugliness,
and goodness into non-goodness,
or turn ugliness into beauty,
and non-goodness into goodness.

Zhuangzi said:
*"What is deemed wondrous becomes foul decay,
what is deemed foul decay becomes wondrous—
foul decay and wondrousness cyclically transform."*

Thus, being and non-being generate and follow one another.
He who gains a deer may lose it immediately;
he who loses a horse may gain it again.
Gain and loss have no fixed end—
this is the pattern of generation.
Water cannot be a carriage,
land cannot be a boat—
skill and clumsiness have no fixed end—
this is the pattern of mutual completion.
The mycelium and the morning mushroom—
longevity and early death have no fixed end—
this is the pattern of contrast.
Kings and beggars—
nobility and lowliness have no fixed end—
this is the pattern of inversion.
One dreams of drinking wine,
then wakes to weeping—
sorrow and joy have no fixed end—
this is the pattern of harmony.
Infancy, youth, old age, and death—
life and death have no fixed end—
this is the pattern of succession.

These six pairs,
all arise from the naming of good and evil—
speaking of what has no ultimate end.

Only when one awakens in the depths of obscurity
can one know this,
and knowing it, harmonize with it.

Thus, the Sage’s ultimate teaching:
Once good and evil are distinguished,
the six pairs emerge.
For the people, it is better to remain ignorant—
then their nobility is profound.
Those who share the people’s afflictions
thus engage in affairs.
And there are teachings—
those far away are served without action,
which is the affair of non-action.
Those nearby are taught with speech,
which is the teaching of non-goodness.
Affairs and teachings exist
only to rescue the vulgar,
yet they return to the same flow,
and are swept along by the six pairs—
how then can they be considered noble?

Zhuangzi said:
*"The utmost speech is beyond speech,
the utmost action is beyond action.*
Ten thousand things arise without refusal—
this expounds the meaning of non-speech,
committing ten thousand things to self-creation,
yet unable to explain them,
hence ‘arise without refusal.’
Once they arise, they are born;
once born, teaching takes root—
this is why it is called ‘born yet not possessed.’
Those who attribute speech to words
are those who cannot help but exhaust their mouths.

Only the utterly non-departing—
acting yet not relying,
achieving yet not dwelling—
this expounds how non-action leads to accomplishment.
When there is action, achievement follows;
when there is achievement, dwelling follows.
If one attends to action beforehand,
then dwelling comes afterward."

Liu Ji said:
When all under heaven know that beauty is beauty,
then non-departing is achieved.
Before differentiation, all things were one body.
Once the two *qi* divide,
things form opposing pairs.
Once called beautiful,
then purity is lost—
evil must oppose it.
Once called good,
then nature is severed—
non-goodness must oppose it.
Beauty may become ugliness,
goodness may become non-goodness—
just as being and non-being generate,
difficulty and ease complete,
long and short contrast,
high and low invert,
sounds harmonize,
before and after succeed—
these six pairs may affirm or negate,
reverse or persist,
and are not the ultimate rectitude of all under heaven.

What was once right may later be wrong,
what was once discarded may later be used.

chunks.original_text: 是犹美之为美，善之为善，特未定也。 经所谓正或为奇，善或为妖是矣。 且天下之理，有为则有成亏，有言则有当愆，皆未免乎累。 是以圣人处无为之事，行不言之教。 所以能遗物离人，而独立乎万物之上，不与物为对，而物无能偶之者，列子所谓疑独，庄子所谓独有者是矣。 无为之事，则至为去为，而冥冥之中独见晓焉； 不言之教，则至言去言，而无声之中独闻和焉。 圣人体道在己，其用心不劳，其应物无方，万物皆往资焉缅不匮，故万物并作，随感而应，则与之作而不辞，任万物之自生而不有其生，任万物之自为而不恃其为，功盖天下而似不自己，化贷万物而民不恃。 故功成不居，有居则有去。 故夫惟弗居，是以不去。 功成而不居其功，其不欲见贤耶。 故次之以不尚贤。 赵实庵曰：初序六对之缘。 一、谓非正性。 天下皆知至斯不善已。 老子之言道德，妙在首篇。 自常无以至於常有，则恍惚之中有象，与物一以贯之，又自玄之又玄，分顿渐之义，要妙尽乎此矣。 然八十一篇义理相贯，其义皆有攸绪。 自物离妙门则常道常名者，交融於美恶之地，故继以天下皆知章。 夫道降而为物，常即道之体，体者所以备众用，用之岂能一於常，故逐物之性则有迁，在物之情必有变，常者不可以自常，美者不可以常美，情变不一，而善恶相反矣。 《诗》云：习习谷风，以阴以雨。 采葑采菲，无以下体。 言天地之情不能常和，万物之性不能常善。 美恶者，非道也，亦非性也，是情立知见也。 凡立知见，无非是欲，欲之心只知美之为美，不知美者返而为恶矣，知善之为善，不知善者返而为不善矣。 此见乎常道常名者流而为事物，故曰事以继道。 是章自善恶相返，至于六对不齐，先引事而显理，次去累而返真。 所谓以事显理者，谓美恶善否六对不齐无非事者，至於圣人处无为之事，则因事而见理，由尘而入觉，是理者非圣人其能乎？ 圣人以独智照明，超然於万形之上，去彼流动之域，自处无为之地，凡天下之有是者，岂能累我哉？ 此去累而返真。 夫无则无为，无为而已，有则兴事，事从有兴，圣人岂恐然自立於无事之地哉？ 随变所适治之而已。 经义至此，渐云治道。 凡言治道，必该方内之教，然后明治之之理。 故平有纳无，虽儒者之讥议室斯通矣，属圣人之独，知经所以先言善恶显之事相，次举六对以明因缘。 二、对待之境。 故有无相生，难易相成。 故之字牒前文，美善相返，叹其美恶善否如此后，正标六者对待有无理也。 难易事也，长短才也，高下势也，声音律吕也，前后新故也。 夫万物出於机而入於机，百昌生於土返於土。 出机入机者，自至无之中受命而来，及其返也，返入於无。 此以性言也。 百昌生於土，自有形而逮夫无形，既生於物，又化为土，未离有有也。 此以形言也。 盖有无同出於道之一性，出则为有，入则为无。 若春夏之居先，秋冬之蹑后，成始成终，互隐互显，对待境中第一义也。 故曰有无之相生，此理也。 难易之相成，事无易也，积难成易； 事无难也，积易成难。 夫创业难也，守成易也，以创业比守成，创业虽难，因而返易，何以明之？ 以有道伐无道，所谓饥者易为食，渴者易为饮，如汤武吊民伐罪是也。
chunks.translated_text:
Is this not like beauty being called beauty, goodness being called good—
yet their nature remains undetermined?

The *Classics* say:
*"The right may become the strange,
the good may become the ominous."*
This is indeed so.

Moreover, the principles of all under heaven:
Where there is action, there is gain and loss;
where there is speech, there is right and error—
none are free from entanglement.

Thus, the Sage engages in *wuwei* (non-action),
conducts *buyan* (non-teaching).
Through this, he transcends things and people,
standing alone above all things,
not opposing things—
and thus nothing can pair with him.
This is what *Liezi* called *"doubtful solitude,"*
what *Zhuangzi* called *"the singular possession."*

In *wuwei*, the utmost is to abandon action,
yet in the silent depths, clarity is alone revealed;
in *buyan*, the utmost is to abandon speech,
yet in the soundless void, harmony is alone heard.

The Sage embodies the Dao within himself—
his mind labors not,
his response to things is without measure.
All things come to him endlessly, never exhausted,
so when all things act in concert,
responding as they are sensed,
he acts with them without reluctance,
allows all things to generate themselves without claiming their generation,
allows all things to be themselves without relying on their being.
His achievements cover all under heaven,
yet it seems not his own doing;
his transformation benefits all things,
yet the people do not depend on him.

Thus, when achievements are complete, he does not dwell upon them—
if he dwells, then he must depart.
Therefore, only by not dwelling does he not depart.
When achievements are complete yet he does not claim them,
is this not because he does not wish to be seen as virtuous?
Thus, he follows this with *"not extolling the virtuous."*

Zhao Shiyuan remarked:
*"The opening sequence explains the six pairs.*
*First, it declares the non-essential nature of the right.*
*When all under heaven know this, they recognize that evil has already arisen.*

*The Dao De Jing’s discourse on virtue and power*
*is most profound in its opening chapter.*
*From the ever-non-existent to the ever-existent,*
*within the vague and indistinct, form emerges,*
*unifying all things in one thread.*
*Again, from the mysterious to the yet more mysterious,*
*the meaning of gradual and sudden transformation is fully exhausted here.*

*Yet the eighty-one chapters’ principles are interconnected,*
*their meanings all having their threads.*
*Once things depart from the subtle gate,*
*the ever-Dao and ever-name merge*
*in the realm of beauty and evil.*
*Thus, it follows with the passage:*
*'When all under heaven know...'*

*The Dao descending as things,*
*the ever-present is the body of the Dao.*
*The body is what fulfills all uses—*
*how could its use remain fixed in the ever-present?*
*Thus, following the nature of things, there must be change,*
*and within things, there must be variation.*
*The ever-present cannot remain ever-present,*
*beauty cannot remain ever-beautiful—*
*as emotions shift and do not align,*
*good and evil become opposites.*

*The *Shijing* says:*
*'The gentle autumn wind blows,
bringing shade and rain.
Plucking *bo* and *fei*,*
*do not harm their roots.'*
*It speaks of how*
*the emotions of heaven and earth cannot always be harmonious,*
*the natures of all things cannot always be good.*

*Beauty and evil are neither the Dao nor nature—*
*they arise from established perceptions.*
*All established perceptions stem from desire;*
*the heart of desire knows only that beauty is beauty,*
*yet does not know that beauty may reverse into evil,*
*that goodness may reverse into non-goodness.*

*This is how the ever-Dao and ever-name*
*flow into affairs—*
*thus, it is said: "Affairs follow the Dao."*

*From this chapter,*
*beginning with the reversal of good and evil,*
*to the six pairs not being uniform,*
*first citing affairs to reveal principles,*
*then abandoning entanglements to return to truth.*

*The saying "revealing principles through affairs"*
*refers to how the six pairs—*
*beauty, evil, goodness, non-goodness—*
*not being uniform are all matters of affairs.*
*When the Sage engages in *wuwei*,*
*he perceives principles through affairs,*
*enters awareness through dust—*
*who but the Sage could grasp this principle?*

*The Sage, with singular insight, illuminates all,*
*transcending all forms above,*
*leaving the realm of flux,*
*dwelling in the domain of *wuwei*.*
*What things of all under heaven could entangle him?*
*This is abandoning entanglements to return to truth.*

*If there is nothing, then there is *wuwei*—*
*only *wuwei* exists.*
*If there is something, then affairs arise,*
*affairs arise from the something.*
*The Sage would not fearfully establish himself*
*in the realm of non-affairs.*
*He simply adapts to changes and governs accordingly.*

*At this point in the text, the discussion shifts to governance.*
*All discourse on governance*
*must encompass internal teachings,*
*then clarify the principles of governance.*
*Thus, though Confucian scholars may criticize*
*"Nashisutong"* (the room’s teachings),
*it belongs uniquely to the Sage.*
*The text first displays the affairs of beauty and evil,*
*then cites the six pairs to clarify their causes.*

*Second, the realm of opposition.*
*Thus, the non-existent and existent generate each other,*
*difficulty and ease complete each other.*
*The word *zhe* (this) echoes the earlier text,*
*after lamenting the reversals of beauty, evil, goodness, and non-goodness,*
*it now marks the six as opposites in the logic of non-existence and existence.*

*Difficulty and ease are matters of affairs,*
*long and short are matters of talent,*
*high and low are matters of position,*
*sounds are matters of pitch and harmony,*
*before and after are matters of new and old.*

*All things emerge from the mechanism and return to the mechanism,*
*a hundred transformations arise from soil and return to soil.*
*Emerging from the mechanism and returning to it—*
*from the ultimate non-existent, they receive their mandate,*
*and when they return, they return to the non-existent.*
*This is speaking of nature.*

*A hundred transformations arise from soil,*
*from the formed to the formless,*
*born of things, yet transforming back into soil—*
*they never depart from the existent.*
*This is speaking of form.*

*Truly, the existent and non-existent share the same origin in the Dao’s nature—*
*emerging, they become existent;*
*returning, they become non-existent.*
*Just as spring and summer come first,*
*autumn and winter follow—*
*beginning and ending complete each other,*
*alternately hidden, alternately revealed,*
*the primary meaning within the realm of opposition.*

*Thus, it is said:*
*"The non-existent and existent generate each other—*
*this is principle.*
*Difficulty and ease complete each other—*
*affairs have no ease; accumulated difficulty becomes ease.*
*Affairs have no difficulty; accumulated ease becomes difficulty.*

*Founding a venture is difficult,*
*preserving it is easy.*
*Comparing founding to preserving,*
*though founding is difficult,*
*its reversal becomes easy—*
*how is this made clear?*
*By the righteous overthrowing the unrighteous,*
*as the hungry are easily fed,*
*the thirsty are easily quenched—*
*like Tang and Wu consoling the people and punishing crimes."*

chunks.original_text: 以守成比创业，守成则易，因而返难，何以明之？ 守成之君如执满器，使心定志平，不可以不静而镇之，动即倾覆，谓不知定心平志，返为难矣。 故守成之君无如成王也。 若夫易知则有亲，易从则有功，特言易而不言难，而能易者，难在其中矣。 天下之势，其孰不然。 盖易其难则致难，难其易则有易。 故曰难易之相成。 兹事也。 长短之相形。 物生於天地之间，同禀乎一气，得其气之全者，形之长，得其气之弱者，形之短。 故古之人多长七尺，今之人不过五尺。 古之人长而魁伟者，一气之降也； 今之人短小而削弱者，一气之浸微也。 岂徒事之变耶？ 人亦然尔。 虽间复不齐，盖不能纯如此也。 故天人之形有定数也，相形者用之有宜也。 材用适於大匠之手，各当其宜； 人才置诸圣人之选，各称其德。 性长非所断，鹤经是也； 性短非所续，凫膝是也。 故长者不可短，短之则悲； 短者不可续，续之则忧。 自然之理也。 独性之在人，无长无短，平等而已。 若物之在人，固不一矣。 《传》曰龟长於蛇，不以形言而以理言。 阴亏於阳，不以气言而以德言。 有若防风之骨以专车，□侥之民长尺五，何其不齐也？ 夫寸短而尺长，非寸不能致尺； 栋修而拱短，非栱不能以安栋。 相形之谓也，此固以材言。 高下之相倾。 天高而地下，阳上而阴下，山高而泽下，上下者，势也，位也。 位之高，其势不得不高； 位之下，其势不得不下。 然天覆下，地仰上，二者无相倾； 阳在上，阴在下，二者无相倾。 惟山高泽下有相倾也，山高而泽下，有从水而言者，曰百谷为川渎之源，则高以倾乎下。 以下为是，则川渎为百谷之归。 又以相倾之势言之，高岸为谷，深谷为陵，亦相倾之理也。 何以言之？ 岸，高也。 岸穴而为谷，谷，洼也。 洼者陷而复平，平者崇而为陵，千年之后安知陵不为岸乎？ 岸不为洼乎？ 相倾者，凡以势而言。 声音之相和，言乐也。 礼以导中，乐以导和，朴散之后，民失性情。 非礼以节之则乱，非乐以和之则伤，故乐之兴，音声之作也。 《乐记》曰：凡音之起，由人心生也。 人心之动，物使之然也。 感於物而动，故形於声，声相应故生变，变成方谓之音。 比音而乐之，及干戚羽旄谓之乐。 乐者，音之所由生也，其本人心之感於物也。 是故哀心感者其声瞧以杀，其乐心感者其声哔以缓，其喜心感者其声发以散，其怒心感者其声粗以厉，其敬心感者其声直以廉，其忧心感者其声和以柔。 六者非性也，感於物而后动，是故先王慎所以感之者，故礼以导其志，乐以和其声，政以一其行，刑以防其奸。 礼乐刑政，其政一也。 所以同民心而出治道也。 凡音者，生人心者也，情动于中，故形於声，声成文，谓之音。 是故治世之音安以乐，其政和。 乱世之音怨以怒，其政乖。 亡国之音哀以思，其民困。 声音之道，与政通矣。 宫为君，商为臣，角为民，征为事，羽为物。 五者不乱，则无惉懘之音矣。 律吕者，配於十二月矣。 夫五音起於五行，五行配於五脏。 肝主怒，肺主悲，脾主思，心主喜，肾主恐。 五脏所主不同，五声相感亦异。 以喜召喜，其声亦喜。 以悲召悲，其声亦悲。 内有所感，外有所应，情志之所感也，故有声音相和焉。
chunks.translated_text:
The Way’s nature—when manifest, it is existence;
when withdrawn, it is non-existence.
As spring and summer precede,
autumn and winter follow—
beginning and ending complete each other,
alternately hidden, alternately revealed,
the primary meaning within the realm of opposition.

Thus, it is said:
*"The non-existent and existent generate each other—*
*this is principle.*
*Difficulty and ease complete each other—*
*affairs have no ease; accumulated difficulty becomes ease.*
*Affairs have no difficulty; accumulated ease becomes difficulty.*

*Founding a venture is difficult,*
*preserving it is easy.*
*Comparing founding to preserving,*
*though founding is difficult,*
*its reversal becomes easy—*
*how is this made clear?*
*By the righteous overthrowing the unrighteous,*
*as the hungry are easily fed,*
*the thirsty are easily quenched—*
*like Tang and Wu consoling the people and punishing crimes."*

Now, comparing preserving to founding,
preserving is easy,
yet its reversal becomes difficult—
how is this made clear?
A ruler who preserves like one holding a full vessel
must keep his heart settled and his will balanced,
lest he not remain still and composed—
movement brings collapse.
This is called failing to settle the heart and balance the will,
and thus it becomes difficult.

Therefore, no ruler who preserves compares to King Cheng.
If knowledge is easy, there is affection;
if obedience is easy, there is merit.
Though only ease is spoken of and not difficulty,
those who can achieve ease hold difficulty within.
The world’s affairs—who does not follow this?
To make difficult what is easy brings ease,
to make easy what is difficult brings difficulty.
Thus it is said: *"Difficulty and ease complete each other."*

This matter also concerns
the contrast of long and short.
All things born between heaven and earth
share the same vital *qi*.
Those who receive the fullness of *qi* grow long,
those who receive its weakness grow short.
Thus ancient people often reached seven *chi* in height,
while today’s people rarely exceed five.
Ancient people were tall and majestic—
the full descent of *qi*;
today’s people are short and frail—
the gradual weakening of *qi*.
Is this merely the change of affairs?
Humans are the same.
Though some vary, none can remain entirely pure.
Thus, the forms of heaven and humanity have fixed measures,
and their contrasts serve appropriate uses.
Materials fit the hands of a master craftsman,
each suited to its purpose;
talents are placed under the selection of the Sage,
each fulfilling its virtue.

What is naturally long cannot be shortened—
the crane’s legs are proof;
what is naturally short cannot be extended—
the duck’s legs are proof.
Thus, the long cannot be shortened—
to do so brings sorrow;
the short cannot be lengthened—
to do so brings worry.
This is the natural order.
Yet in human nature, there is neither long nor short—
only equality.
But in the things of humanity,
they are certainly not uniform.
The *Transmission* says: *"The tortoise is longer than the snake,"*
not speaking of form but of principle.
*"Yin is deficient to yang,"*
not speaking of *qi* but of virtue.
There are those like the bones of the *Fangfeng* people,
who could span a chariot,
and the people of *Xingyuan*, who were only a *chi* and a half tall—
how unequal they are!
Though an inch is short and a *chi* is long,
without the inch, the *chi* cannot be complete;
though a beam is tall and a rafter is short,
without the rafter, the beam cannot stand firm.
This is the meaning of contrast—
this is certainly speaking of materials.

The contrast of high and low:
Heaven is high, earth is low,
yang ascends, yin descends,
mountains rise, marshes sink—
high and low are matters of position and force.
The higher the position, the higher the force must be;
the lower the position, the lower the force must be.
Yet heaven covers below, earth supports above—
the two do not topple each other.
Yang is above, yin is below—
the two do not topple each other.
Only mountains rising and marshes sinking create a contrast—
mountains rise, marshes sink,
and if we speak of water, we say:
*"A hundred valleys are the source of rivers and streams,"*
then high things descend to the low.
If we take this as true,
then rivers and streams are the gathering of the valleys.
Again, speaking of the contrast of forces,
high banks become valleys,
deep valleys become hills—
this is the principle of contrast.
How so?
Banks are high.
When banks are hollowed, they become valleys;
valleys are depressions.
Depressions sink and then level out,
level ground rises and becomes hills.
Who knows that after a thousand years,
hills will not become banks,
or banks will not become depressions?
Contrast is always a matter of force.

The harmony of sounds—this is music.
Ritual guides the mind,
music guides harmony.
After the simplicity of antiquity dispersed,
people lost their natural emotions.
Without ritual to regulate them, they become disordered;
without music to harmonize them, they are injured.
Thus, the rise of music is the creation of sounds.
The *Record of Music* says:
*"All sounds arise from the human heart.
The heart’s movement is caused by things.
When moved by things, it manifests in sound.
Sounds respond to each other and thus create variation;
when variation is complete, it is called music.
Comparing sounds to create music,
and using drums, spears, feathers, and flags—this is music.
Music is the origin of sound,
its root in the heart’s response to things.
Thus, when the sorrowful heart is moved,
its sound is sharp and severe;
when the joyful heart is moved,
its sound is slow and relaxed;
when the joyful heart is moved,
its sound bursts forth and scatters;
when the angry heart is moved,
its sound is coarse and fierce;
when the respectful heart is moved,
its sound is straight and restrained;
when the worried heart is moved,
its sound is harmonious and gentle.
These six are not innate;
they arise only when moved by things.
Thus, the ancient kings were cautious about what moved them,
so they used ritual to guide their wills,
music to harmonize their sounds,
government to unify their actions,
and law to prevent their deceit.
Ritual, music, law, and governance—
these are one in purpose.
They serve to unify the people’s hearts
and establish the path of governance.

All sounds arise from the human heart.
Emotions move within,
and thus manifest in sound.
When sound forms patterns, it is called music.
Thus, in a well-ordered age, music is peaceful and joyful,
and its governance is harmonious.
In a chaotic age, music is resentful and angry,
and its governance is misaligned.
In a fallen kingdom, music is sorrowful and reflective,
and its people are suffering.
The way of sound is linked to governance.

*Gong* is the ruler,
*Shang* is the minister,
*Jiao* is the people,
*Zheng* is affairs,
*Yu* is things.
If these five are not disordered,
there will be no discordant sounds.
The *Lü* and *Yu* correspond to the twelve months.
The five tones arise from the five phases,
the five phases correspond to the five viscera.
The liver governs anger,
the lungs govern sorrow,
the spleen governs thought,
the heart governs joy,
the kidneys govern fear.
Since the five viscera govern differently,
the five tones, when resonating, also differ.
To summon joy with joy,
its sound is also joyful.
To summon sorrow with sorrow,
its sound is also sorrowful.
Inner responses meet outer echoes—
this is the harmony of emotions and sounds.

chunks.original_text: 故音声以律吕言也。 前后之相随。 日之徂也，不复有一日，月之所系焉。 年之徂也，不复有一年，岁之所统焉。 幻之迁也，不复有诸幻，身之所纪焉。 今之往也，不复有于今，时之所递焉。 回首视之，立致今古。 春夏先而秋冬后，四时之运未尝暂止，新者复故，故者复新，循环无端，前后相逐，祸福相倚而不忒，形影相吊而不离，兹前后之理，以新故而言之。 观夫有无之相生，事物之变也。 若同乃虚，虚乃大，复何出没焉。 难易相成也。 持而盈之，不如其已，复何忧患焉。 长短之相形。 形之不齐也，无形者数之所不能穷，孰齐孰不齐焉。 高下之相倾。 上为皇，下为王，得吾道之所，一也，物莫能迁，孰倾孰不倾焉。 为声音之相和，宁如大音希声者听之所不能入乎？ 前后之相随，宁如处阴休影者进之所不能辨乎？ 兹非体道而立乎万物之上者，孰能与於斯。 则知圣人者，有物安足以系之。 次离患守真。 一、以常反照。 是以圣人处无为之事。 是以字牒前起后。 前言六对不齐，於此义中略分二门。 一者谓物之不齐，六对相仍。 二者物之相待有和合，相以不齐而齐之，是有为也。 以对待而和合之，是胶固也。 於对待不齐之中独超然自得，即圣人也。 圣人则尽其性者也。 尽其性，则才与道并。 不能尽其性，则有圣人之才而无圣人之道。 有其才而无其道财巧，巧则人为。 有其道而无其才则质，质则不化。 惟才与道并，是谓全德。 适时应变，变而不穷，然后能明无为之道。 能明无为之道，善处无为之事； 善处无为之事，能行不言之教。 凡寓形於宇内者，不能逃乎事，处位乎至贵者，不可劳乎心。 盖心与事并，则失无为之理。 身与事远，则失善处之能。 圣人者处乎一堂之上，而供万事之求，岂可以身远乎事哉，必曰虚心应变而已。 彼六对者虽自外来，以理观之，定自心至。 且以心起情，事与情合； 事与情合，则对待之境纷纷错错，无时而已。 是未知因其固焉，付之自尔。 彼物有自然之性，吾则因而治之。 彼物有不说之理，吾则默而相之，乃所谓不行而知，不见而明者也。 若夫天无为以之清，而福善祸淫之理明矣。 地无为以之宁，而承天效法之情着矣。 由是观之，天地岂无事耶？ 处之无为而已。 二、以诚化物。 行不言之教。 夫不言之教者，圣人以诚化天下也。 以诚化物，则观而化也。 上之化下，如风行地上，岂俟言哉？ 庄子谓两无为相合是也。 《易》曰圣人以神道设教。 化至於神，则不疾而速，不行而至，若孟子所谓圣而不可知之谓神。 又正者一而止之也，凡我之正物莫不正，故曰其身正不令而行，其身不正虽令不从。 此皆不言之教也。 虽然以诚化物，以身率人，皆治天下者之事也。 若夫不吉而谓之教者，尚有谆谆之意，殆夫若不知其所以然而然者，得其自然也。 非圣人孰可语於斯乎？ 故观不及豫，终南戒裹公之诗曰：锦衣狐裘，颜如渥丹。 其君也哉。 三、运量不匮。 万物作焉而不辞。 前言六对不齐，圣人以独智见觉，破幻归真，自处无为之地，坐制纷华。 次云万物作而不辞，显道之用。 何谓显用？ 无为即不动也。 今也万物有作，物自何来，还从无出，虽云生者自生，化者自化，道未尝主之又何以言不辞？
chunks.translated_text:
The sounds and tones are spoken through *lǚ* and *lǘ*.
The past and future follow one another.
The sun’s passage does not return to a former day—
the moon’s course governs it.
The year’s passage does not return to a former year—
the seasons govern it.
The shifting of illusions does not return to former illusions—
the body marks it.
The present’s departure does not return to former presents—
time transmits it.

Turning back to view it,
ancient and present stand revealed.
Spring and summer precede autumn and winter—
the four seasons flow without pause,
new replacing old, old returning as new,
cycling endlessly, past and future chasing,
fortune and calamity leaning upon each other without error,
form and shadow consoling each other without separation.
This is the principle of past and future,
spoken of in terms of new and old.

Observe how existence and nonexistence generate each other—
the transformation of things.
If identical, it is emptiness;
emptiness, then, is vast—
what more is there to appear or vanish?

Difficulty and ease complement each other.
To grasp and fill is not as good as leaving it be—
what more is there to fear or grieve?

Length and shortness define each other.
Their forms are not uniform—
the formless cannot be exhausted by numbers.
Which is uniform, which is not?

High and low incline toward each other.
The exalted is *Huang*, the lowly is *Wang*—
both attain the Dao’s place,
one and undivided—
no thing can displace it.
Which inclines, which does not?

For the harmony of sounds and tones,
is it not like the great sound that lacks voice,
which hearing cannot penetrate?
For the past and future following one another,
is it not like resting in shadow while the light advances,
which progress cannot distinguish?

If not one who embodies the Dao and stands above all things,
who can partake in this?

Thus, the sage knows:
no thing can truly bind the *Wuji*.
Next, depart from suffering and uphold the True.

**First, reflect with constancy.**
Therefore, the sage dwells in non-action.
Thus, the written characters arise in sequence—
earlier words spoke of the six opposing pairs being unaligned,
here dividing the meaning into two gates.

One: things are unaligned, the six pairs persist.
Two: things in mutual dependence find harmony,
yet through their unalignment, they achieve alignment—
this is *having-for* (action).
To harmonize through mutual dependence is rigidity.
Amid unaligned dependence, to stand alone and self-possessed—
this is the sage.
The sage is one who fulfills their nature.
To fulfill one’s nature,
talent and Dao merge.
Unable to fulfill one’s nature,
one may have the sage’s talent but lack the sage’s Dao.
With talent but no Dao, one is clever—
cleverness is artificial.
With Dao but no talent, one is plain—
plainness does not transform.
Only when talent and Dao merge is it called *complete virtue*.
To adapt to time and respond to change,
to change without exhaustion,
then one can illuminate the Dao of non-action.
To illuminate the Dao of non-action,
to skillfully dwell in non-action;
to skillfully dwell in non-action,
to practice the teaching of *wu yan* (non-speech).

All who dwell within the cosmos
cannot escape affairs,
those in the highest positions
cannot avoid exertion of the mind.
For if mind and affairs run parallel,
the principle of non-action is lost.
If body and affairs are distant,
the ability to dwell well is lost.
The sage, seated in one hall,
supplies all demands—
how could the body be distant from affairs?
It must be: *empty the mind and respond to change*.

Though the six pairs come from without,
by principle, they are fixed within the heart.
For the heart gives rise to emotions,
affairs align with emotions;
when affairs align with emotions,
the realm of mutual dependence becomes tangled and confused,
without pause.
This is not knowing their fixed nature,
leaving it to unfold naturally.
Things have their inherent nature—
we follow and govern accordingly.
Things have their unspoken principles—
we remain silent and respond in kind,
this is what is called *knowing without action, seeing without clarity*.

Heaven, through non-action, attains clarity—
the principle of rewarding virtue and punishing licentiousness is manifest.
Earth, through non-action, attains tranquility—
the sentiment of following Heaven’s law is established.
Thus observed,
Heaven and Earth—do they have no affairs?
To dwell in non-action is all.

**Second, transform things with sincerity.**
Practice the teaching of *wu yan*.
The teaching of *wu yan* is how the sage transforms the world with sincerity.
To transform things with sincerity is to observe and transform.
The superior transforms the inferior,
like wind passing over the earth—
what need for speech?
Zhuangzi said: *Two non-actions merge*—this is it.
*The Classic of Changes* says: *The sage teaches through the divine method.*
When transformation reaches the divine,
it is swift without haste, effective without action—
as Mencius said: *Sagehood beyond knowing is called divine.*
Moreover, correctness is singular and stops there—
all my correct things are corrected.
Thus it is said: *When the self is correct, orders need not be given for them to be followed;
when the self is incorrect, even orders will not be obeyed.*
These are all teachings of *wu yan*.

Yet even so, to transform things with sincerity,
to lead by example—
these are the affairs of governing the world.
As for those who call it teaching without virtue,
they still bear the intent of earnest instruction—
perhaps those who do not know *why it is so* are simply following nature.
Who but the sage can speak of this?

Thus, foresight cannot be observed—
the poem warning the Duke of Nan warns *Guo Gong*:
*"Silk robes and fox-fur garments,
complexion like polished cinnabar—
this is your lord!"*

**Third, the flow of measure is inexhaustible.**
All things act yet do not decline.
Earlier words spoke of the six opposing pairs being unaligned—
the sage, with singular insight, awakens,
shatters illusion, and returns to the True,
dwelling in the realm of non-action,
seated amidst the bustle of the world.
Next, it is said: *All things act yet do not decline*—
this reveals the Dao’s function.

What is this revealed function?
Non-action is non-movement.
Now, all things act—
from where do they come?
Still, they arise from the non.
Though it is said that what is born is born of itself,
what transforms transforms of itself—
the Dao never takes charge—
how then can it be said *not to decline*?

**Yet it is said that there is no refusal—**
then the coming is never rejected.

Thus, it must be that all things are truly born from the Dao,
and the sage governs them—
does this not mean they come to him?

What concerns me, I must know.
In the discussion of *quan* (权) and *shi* (实)—
all things are *quan* (transient/phenomenal),
the sage is *shi* (substantial/true).
The true does not shift,
the transient reveals it—
so then, the world belongs to the sage.

The sage has never possessed the world,
yet his vast heart accommodates it all,
content and at ease.
Empty yet illuminating,
ever-responsive yet ever-serene—
how then can there be refusal?

**Fourth, transformation arises from nature.**
Born yet not possessed.
Earlier words spoke of action without refusal—
this follows the natural order of things,
letting them arise and transform as they will.

Next, it is said: *born yet not possessed*—
the sage empties his heart to respond to things,
how could he claim what is born as his own?

The *I Ching* says: *"Qián (乾) is stillness, its essence is singular."*
The heavens and earth contain *yin* and *yang*,
and *yin* and *yang* give birth to all things.
The Dao never takes charge—
does the sage then merely *shī* (尸) it?

Then one knows that the sage governs the Dao yet not things;
to govern things would only muddle his heart.

Zhuangzi says: *"The Dao does not desire mixing, mixing brings multiplicity."*
Is this not what is meant?

chunks.original_text: 五、不任智力。 为而不恃。 前二句言无为，此言有为，无为即有为之本也。 经曰为无为则无不治，今此明为而不恃者，言不矜伐也。 向所谓作而不辞者，物在范围之内，故作者不可辞。 次言生而不有者，致物於空虚之地，故生而不有。 此显圣人处无为之中，而未尝不为也。 自有为而至无为，则天下既以治矣，百官既以职矣，君臣父子既以序矣，朋友既以信矣，礼义既以明矣，刑罚既以清矣，百工既以具矣，四夷既以服矣，百姓既以定矣。 圣人於此不归其功，然则归之谁耶？ 圣人作之初无心，成之亦无心。 盖一切尘缘本无自性，圣人之心亦虚而已。 此言大圣之道也。 若夫为一事曰仁，行一事曰义，从以矜，伐於人，不过霸者之事而已。 又岂与隆古比治哉？ 六、神化不留。 功成不居，道无定体，因物以为体； 常无一心，因心而为心。 响之发也，其在声物之生也，其在色，至于手执足行，梦思觉想，前念未灭，后念复兴，是心本无绿尘而作，圣人觉此，其谁居乎？ 然则功成者居其位也，居其位而不去者，是泥迹於有为也。 泥迹於有为，宜其胶固而不解，若是则岂有道者之心哉？ 语曰：既得之，患失之。 苟患失之，无所不至矣。 又况出治之圣人乎？ 圣人则不然。 体天而行也，比夫四时之运，功成者去，去则无系矣。 《易》曰：乘木舟虚。 不特去者而然，其在位之心亦若是而已。 苟为不然，则道有去留矣。 今所谓功成不居者，进退有道也。 《易》曰：知进退存亡而不失其正者，其唯圣人乎？ 夫乾之亢阳用九之义是也。 居天下之广居，孟子之言是也。 大名之下难可久居，鸱夷子之言是也。 二边俱不立，中道不须安。 释氏之言是也。 内观起火，十月脱胎。 真人之言是也。 知此者，非圣人而畴克焉哉？
chunks.translated_text:
Five, **Not relying on cleverness**.
Doing yet not claiming credit.

The first two lines speak of *wuwei*—this speaks of *youwei*, for *wuwei* is the root of *youwei*.
The Classic says: *"Do *wuwei* and nothing remains untamed."* Now it clarifies *doing yet not claiming*—meaning one does not boast or take pride.
What was earlier called *"acting yet not refusing"*—when things are within proper bounds, the actor cannot refuse.
Next, *"born yet not possessed"*—bringing things to a state of emptiness, hence not claiming what is born as one’s own.
This reveals how the sage operates within *wuwei* yet never ceases to act.

From *youwei* to *wuwei*, the world is already governed, officials fulfill their duties, ruler and subject, father and son follow their order, friends keep their trust, rites and virtue shine forth, punishments are clear, artisans are complete, the four barbarian lands submit, and the people are settled.
The sage, in this, does not claim the merit—then to whom does it belong?
The sage acts at first with no intention, completes it with no intention.
For all dusty causes are inherently empty, the sage’s heart is but emptiness itself.
This is the Dao of the Great Sage.

If one merely does one thing and calls it *ren*, performs one act and calls it *yi*, then boasts and takes pride before others, this is but the deed of a petty conqueror—how could it compare to the ancient rectification of the world?

Six, **Spiritual transformation leaves no trace**.
Merit completed, no dwelling upon it—the Dao has no fixed form; it adapts to things as its form.
Always without a fixed mind, yet the mind adapts as it acts.
The echo arises—whether in sound, in things born, in color, or in holding with hands and walking with feet, in dreams, thoughts, and waking awareness—before one thought fades, another arises. The mind, originally empty of defilements, acts thus. The sage, aware of this, claims nothing.

Thus, one who completes merit occupies their station, yet if they do not depart, they cling to the traces of *youwei*.
Clinging to *youwei* leads only to rigidity and stagnation—how could this be the mind of the Daoist?
It is said: *"Once obtained, fear losing it."* If one fears losing it, they will stoop to anything.
How much more so for the sage who has achieved governance?
The sage is not thus.
They embody Heaven’s movement, like the four seasons’ cycles—merit completed, they depart, and departing, they leave no attachment.
The *I Ching* says: *"Riding a hollow wooden boat."*
Not only does the departing one act thus, but even while in station, their heart is the same.
If it were otherwise, the Dao would have attachment and departure.
What is now called *"completing merit yet not dwelling"* is the proper way of advance and retreat.
The *I Ching* says: *"Knowing advance and retreat, survival and perishing, yet not losing one’s proper course—is this not the sage alone?"*
This is the meaning of *Qián’s* (乾) extreme *yang* using the trigrams of Nine.
*"Dwelling in the broadest realm of the world"*—Mencius’ words are true.
*"Under a great name, it is hard to remain long"*—the words of the *Yīyī* (鸱夷子) are true.
*"Neither extreme can stand; the middle path requires no fixing"*—the words of the *Release School* are true.
*"Inner observation ignites fire; in the tenth month, the embryo sheds its shell"*—the words of the True Person are true.
To know this—who but the sage could attain it?

chunks.original_text: 三牒前显常。 夫惟弗居，是以不去。 所言去者，名与位也。 所不可去者，独立而不改也。 道德真经集义卷之五竟 道德真经集义卷之六 凝远大师常德路玄妙观 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易东校正 天下皆知章 邵若愚曰：天下皆知至不去。 天下皆知美之者，己亦效之为美，斯恶己。 皆知善之者，己亦效为善，斯不善己。 夫何故？ 观有无互换之相生，难易事之相成，长短理之相形，高下势之相倾，声音是非之相和，前后瓞瓞之相随，世人因着美善事障，本心逐境，以为遂生八万四千烦恼，是以处之无心，为之无事，所以能齐万物，行之治世，可不言而教天下，且万物并作，而圣人不以言辞分别者，恐民生好恶之情，於己无所与，於民无事取，缘以无事安民，故生民不知有君之化，虽为君父而不恃，功业成而不居。 夫惟不居於迹，是以德存而不去。 王志然曰：天下皆知至不去。 夫美恶善否，古今对治之术，通天下皆知之矣。 而美者有恶为之对，而善者有不善为之对。 知美恶善否之所在，则美者自美，吾不知其美也； 恶者自恶，吾不知其恶也； 况善否云乎哉？ 善善恶恶，非肆情纵欲之妄有而何？ 且善之不善，安有美之不美者焉？ 美之为美，安有善之不善者焉？ 鉴明则尘垢不止，心明则善恶自彰，而愚者反是。 庄子曰是非吾谓情者是也。 吾所谓无情者，言人不以好恶内伤其身，常因自然而不益生者也。 夫何世人每陷於对待之境，不能自出其所囿，不偏诸有则偏诸无，不滞诸形则滞诸数，故曰有无也，难易也，长短也，高下也，音声也，前后也。 原其所起，不谓之无端由也已，其必有旨焉。 不立一物，兹谓常无； 不废一物，兹谓常有。 故曰有无之相生。 严君平曰：无难无以知其易，无易无以知其难。 古谓先难而后获，经谓多易又多难。 故曰难易之相成。 无长无以知其短，无短无以知其长。 御解曰若尺寸是已。 无高无以知其下，无下无以知其高。 御解曰若山泽是已。 无声无以知其音，无音无以知其声，六律既协，八音既谐，所谓音声之相和者必矣。 无前无以知其后，无后无以知其前，春先而夏从，长先而少从，所谓前后之相随者必矣。 之六者固不出其所位，以迹观之，未始不异； 以道观之，未始不同。 曾不若圣人治天下，槩以无为之道而处之，则无不治矣。 故曰我无为而民自化，用不言之教教之天下，使民不欲，以静默而成之。 天下口耳之教，学譊譊之说将无所开其喙。 故曰我好静而民自正。 圣人无作，作则万物睹有所作则有所治焉。 生而或有则未能忘我者也，为而或恃则有所托焉者也，功成或居则有所系焉者也。 惟其不自作、不自有、不自恃、不自居，所以与道翱翔於万物之上，而常自若未始或去者矣。 黄茂材曰：天下皆知至斯不善已。 目美於色，耳美於声，口美於味，天下之谓美也。 以此为美，岂不至於恶乎？ 行一善行亦可谓之善矣，言一善言亦可谓之善矣，虽不足以进为道，然未至於为恶。 故曰斯不善已。 天下之所谓美者不足以为美，天下之所谓善者不足以为善。 然则何以为美且善乎？ 曰：淡乎无味，斯吾所谓美也。 处人所恶，斯吾所谓善也。 知乎此者，然后可与入道。

「The essence of the heart is no more than this.
If it is not so, then the Dao will have attachment and departure.

What is called *"not dwelling"* is why it does not depart.
What is called *departure*—that is name and position.
What cannot depart—is the independent and unchanging self.

Master *Ning Yuan*’s *Chang De Lu* presents the profound and mysterious observation of virtue.

*Observing Affairs* by *Liu Wei Yong* was compiled and edited,
*Ding Yi Dong*, a former *Feng Da Fu* (奉大夫), *Tai Fu Si* (太府寺) registrar, and concurrent editor at the *Gong Mi Yuan* (枢密院), verified the text.

**Chapter: The World All Knows**

*Shào Ruò Yú* (邵若愚) said:
*"The world all knows, yet the Dao does not depart."*

Those who know what the world calls *beauty* and follow it—this is to love what is evil.
Those who know what the world calls *good* and follow it—this is to do what is not good.

Why is this?
To observe the mutual generation of *having* and *not having*,
the interplay of *difficulty* and *ease*,
the manifestation of *long* and *short*,
the inclination of *high* and *low*,
the harmony of *sound* and *voice*,
the succession of *before* and *after*—
these are the six pairs.

Worldly beings, clinging to beauty and goodness, obstruct themselves with worldly affairs,
their true nature follows external conditions,
thus generating *eight thousand and four thousand afflictions* (八万四千烦恼).
Hence, they act without intent,
do without attachment,
and thus can align with all things,
govern the world,
and instruct without words.

Though all things arise together,
the sage does not distinguish them with speech,
fearing that the people would develop likes and dislikes.
The sage takes no action for himself,
demands nothing from the people,
and relies on *non-action* (無為) to settle them.
Thus, the people do not know the sage’s transformation,
though he is their ruler and father,
he does not depend on it.
His deeds complete, yet he does not dwell upon them.

It is because he does not dwell in outward traces
that his *virtue/power* (德) remains and does not depart.

*Wáng Zhì Rán* (王志然) said:
*"The world all knows, yet the Dao does not depart."*

Good and evil, right and wrong—
these are the ancient and modern methods of *opposing treatment* (對治).
The world has universally known them.

Yet those who love beauty have evil as their opposite,
and those who love goodness have ungoodness as their opposite.

If one knows where beauty, evil, goodness, and ungoodness lie,
then the beautiful will reveal itself as beautiful—*I do not know its beauty*;
the evil will reveal itself as evil—*I do not know its evil*;
how much more so with goodness and ungoodness?

Goodness that is not good,
beauty that is not beautiful—
what else could this be but reckless indulgence?

Yet goodness that is not good—
how could beauty not be beautiful?
Beauty that is beautiful—
how could goodness not be good?

Clarity reveals dust and filth,
mindful clarity distinguishes good and evil—
yet fools do the opposite.

As *Zhuāngzi* said: *"Good and evil, I call them emotions."* (是非吾謂之情者)

What I call *without emotion*—
that the person does not internally harm themselves with likes and dislikes,
always following nature without adding to it.

Why do worldly beings always fall into the realm of opposites,
unable to escape their confines?
They do not lean toward *having*, yet they lean toward *not having*;
they do not cling to *form*, yet they cling to *numbers*.

Thus, it is said: *having* and *not having*,
*difficulty* and *ease*,
*long* and *short*,
*high* and *low*,
*sound* and *voice*,
*before* and *after*.

Examining their origins,
they are not without cause—
there must be intent behind them.

Not favoring any single thing—this is called *constant not-having*;
not neglecting any single thing—this is called *constant having*.
Hence, *having* and *not having* mutually generate.

*Yán Jūn Píng* (嚴君平) said:
*"Without ease, one cannot know difficulty;
without difficulty, one cannot know ease."*

The ancients said: *"First difficulty, then ease"* (先難而後獲),
the *Classics* say: *"Many easings, many difficulties"* (多易又多難).
Hence, *difficulty* and *ease* mutually complete.

Without *short*, one cannot know *long*;
without *long*, one cannot know *short*—
as the *Commentary* says: *"Like the measure of a cubit."* (若尺寸是已)

Without *low*, one cannot know *high*;
without *high*, one cannot know *low*—
as the *Commentary* says: *"Like mountains and marshes."* (若山泽是已)

Without *voice*, one cannot know *sound*;
without *sound*, one cannot know *voice*.
The *Six Pitches* (六律) harmonize,
the *Eight Sounds* (八音) accord—
this is the *sound* and *voice* that must harmonize.

Without *after*, one cannot know *before*;
without *before*, one cannot know *after*.
Spring comes first, followed by summer,
the long precedes the short—
this is the *before* and *after* that must succeed.

The six pairs do not depart from their positions,
yet when viewed by outward traces,
they are never the same;
when viewed by the Dao,
they are never different.

Not even like the sage governing the world,
using the *Way of non-action* (無為之道) to manage it,
then nothing remains ungoverned.

Hence, *"I use non-action, yet the people transform themselves"* (我無為而民自化),
*"I instruct with speechless teaching"* (以不言之教教之天下),
making the people not desire,
achieving harmony through stillness and silence.

The world’s spoken and heard teachings,
its learned and verbose doctrines—
where would they open their mouths?

Hence, *"I love stillness, yet the people align themselves"* (我好靜而民自正).

The sage does nothing.
If he acts, then all things see what he has done—
this is to have something to govern.

If one is born and yet has something—
they have not forgotten themselves.
If one acts and yet depends on it—
they have something to rely upon.
If one’s deeds complete and yet they dwell upon them—
they have something to bind themselves to.

Only by not acting for oneself,
not having anything for oneself,
not relying upon anything for oneself,
not dwelling upon anything for oneself—
can one soar with the Dao above all things,
and remain ever constant, never departing.

*Huáng Mào Cái* (黃茂材) said:
*"The world all knows, yet this does not make one good."*

The eyes find beauty in colors,
the ears find beauty in sounds,
the mouth finds beauty in flavors—
this is what the world calls *beauty*.

If one takes this as beauty,
would it not lead to evil?

To perform one good act is to be good,
to speak one good word is to be good—
though it may not suffice to advance toward the Dao,
it does not yet reach the level of evil.

Hence, *"This does not make one good."* (斯不善已)

What the world calls *beauty* is not sufficient to be beauty,
what the world calls *good* is not sufficient to be good.

Then what is truly *beauty* and *good*?

It is said:
*"Without taste, this is what I call beauty."*
*"To dwell where others find evil, this is what I call good."* (處人所惡，斯吾謂之善也)

Only when one knows this
can they then enter the Dao.»

chunks.original_text: 故有无相生至行不言之教。 有与无对，故能相生； 难与易对，故能相成； 长与短对，故能相形； 高与下对，故能相倾； 声与音对，故能相和； 前与后对，故能相随。 天下事物莫不皆然，圣人与人混处其中，亦岂能舍是哉？ 然观此理，其处事也无为，而为其行教也。 不言而言，故能不累於物。 万物作而不辞至是以不去。 夫盈於天地之间者，无非无也。 其作之者谁乎、其生之者谁乎、其为之者谁乎？ 是必有主宰默运於其间。 道虽无名不可得而辞其名，道虽无迹不可得而辞其迹。 故曰作而不辞，若夫生而有其生之功，为而恃其为之力，其为道也浅矣。 圣有体此不有不恃，何功之不可成？ 功成不居者，生而不有、为而不恃之谓。 夫如是则与道合而为一，无适不可，何用远去於人哉。 程泰之曰：天下皆知至斯不善矣。 众所嘉尚则命以为美，事为曲当则名以为善，美之与善固可贵矣，而不可使人得而明知也。 我之示彼之见也，我固尚之，彼必效之。 羊质虎皮，反以乱真。 故天下知此之为善为美，则遂入於不善不美也。 世或贵逊，则必有阴请而阳辞者，反假之以济其食也； 世方尚俭，则又有羸服弊车、自挈壶飱者，是又故自菲陋以中上欲非其中心实然也。 若夫体道之人，藏其用而不示，使人由而不知，则夫至德之世，相爱而不知以为仁，端正而不知以为义者，是其效也。 正如婴儿之慕驹犊之从，不知慕从之为孝，而自与孝合者，乃其孝之真者欤。 老氏上乎道而言自然者，皆此类也。 故有无至相成。 诚有是美，诚有是善，是之谓有。 诈焉而为，则直无耳。 积思累行以及美善，是之谓难。 摸其似而放为之，则易也。 夫真美不生美而生恶，真善不生善而生不善。 何也？ 积思累善者难，而售伪假真者易也。 故表示美善以观，欲天下人从其易者，为之以益其己之所无，而街世人之所不知，其理固相因仍也。 长短至相倾。 好胜自衒之心，人皆有之。 上之人昭昭乎揭美善以诏天下，彼愧其无有，知其难，及是从其易者，为之以求益其所无，於是耻其短之见形於长也，则扶跂其卑以倾人之高，此皆善否美恶，转易之本也。 声音之相随。 声，人声也，音乐之成文者也。 登歌在上，而匏竹受之以为乐，均是其所以为相和也。 谓其相和之先后，则又常相追逐也。 庄子曰：我固卖之，彼固鬻之。 以此理达诸治道，则不止音之和声而已也。 一以传十，十以传百，前后之相随者未已也。 故上之所向，不可使人人知之也。 是以至之事。 凡老氏之言无为，所包甚广，而随事指者不一其地也。 此之无为，主动化以言也。 胸中实分当否，而外貌全泯。 形述美者心固美之，而不露其美之之意，善者心亦善之，而不示其善善之边，此其於作为之地，默行其意而不着其状，是谓无为之事也。 夫其为此者何也？ 正虑夫意向外着，而人得习其好以雠其伪也。 其曰处者，立抚於此，安而居之，不复杂以他事也。 行不言之教。 通彼我必以言，既曰教矣，而无言以喻，则人将何所循以为趋耶？ 此章之指正恶夫好尚外形，而人得放而为伪也。 名此事之为美，表此人之为善，形诸褒借，播诸号令，人从其所美所善，而摹拟其似，则向之真美真善，皆将转为假托矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao arises from the interplay of *having* and *having-not*, manifesting in effortless action through silent teaching.

Having and having-not oppose each other, thus giving rise to one another;
Difficulty and ease oppose each other, thus completing one another;
Length and shortness oppose each other, thus defining one another;
Height and lowliness oppose each other, thus inclining one another;
Sound and music oppose each other, thus harmonizing one another;
Before and after oppose each other, thus following one another.

All things under heaven follow this pattern—
the Sage blends with humanity amidst them,
how could they abandon this principle?

Yet observing this truth,
their conduct is *wuwei*, yet their teaching is action.
They speak without speaking,
thus avoiding entanglement with things.
All things act without complaint,
thus they do not depart from this.

What fills the space between heaven and earth
is nothing but *having-not*.
Who is it that acts? Who is it that gives life? Who is it that does?
There must be a silent sovereign guiding this.

The Dao, though nameless, cannot be named;
the Dao, though without trace, cannot be traced.
Thus it is said: *"Act without complaint."*
But if one claims to have given life and takes credit for its function,
or acts and relies on its force,
then their understanding of the Dao is shallow.

The Sage embodies this—
not possessing, not relying—
what deeds cannot be accomplished?
To complete deeds without claiming them
is to *"give birth without possessing, act without relying."*
Thus, they align with the Dao and become one,
omitting nothing, needing no distance from others.

Program Tai said:
*"All under heaven know this, yet it is not good."*
What is praised and esteemed is called *beauty*,
what is fitting is called *good*—
though *beauty* and *good* are indeed precious,
they cannot be made known to all.

I reveal to them what they see,
yet I hold it in high regard—
they will surely imitate it.
Like a lamb in tiger’s skin,
it only serves to confuse the truth.

Thus, when all under heaven know this as *good* and *beauty*,
they fall into what is *not good* and *not beautiful*.

When the world values humility,
there will be those who secretly seek while publicly declining,
pretending to refuse to fulfill their desires.
When frugality is esteemed,
there will be those in tattered robes and broken carriages,
carrying their own food in a basket—
these are those who deliberately degrade themselves
to satisfy others’ desires, though not truly so.

But those who embody the Dao
conceal their actions without display,
letting people follow without knowing.
In the age of supreme virtue,
people love one another without calling it *ren*,
they are upright without calling it *yi*—
this is its effect.

Just as infants follow calves,
unaware that following is *filial piety*,
yet truly merging with it—
this is the genuine *filial piety*.

The Master Lao spoke of the Dao’s naturalness,
all of this kind.

Thus, *having* and *having-not* reach perfect complementarity.
True *beauty* and true *good* exist—
this is what is called *having*.
If done deceptively, then it is merely *having-not*.

Accumulating thought and action to achieve *beauty* and *good* is difficult,
but mimicking their semblance is easy.
True *beauty* does not generate *beauty* but *evil*,
true *good* does not generate *good* but *not-good*.
Why?
Because accumulating thought and *good* is difficult,
while selling falsehood as truth is easy.

Thus, displaying *beauty* and *good* to observe,
desiring all under heaven to follow the easy path—
they act to supplement what they lack,
while deceiving those who do not know.
This principle naturally follows in sequence.

Length and shortness incline toward one another.
The heart of vanity and self-aggrandizement is universal.
The rulers openly proclaim *beauty* and *good* to the world,
yet those who lack them feel shame,
knowing the difficulty—
when they follow the easy path,
acting to gain what they lack,
their perceived shortcomings become exposed in their striving for superiority,
thus they prop up their lowliness to topple others’ heights—
this is the root of transforming *good* into *evil*, *beauty* into *ugliness*.

Sound and music follow one another.
Sound is human voice,
the structured form of music.
When the song ascends above,
the *pao* and bamboo respond to create harmony—
this is how they harmonize.
As for their sequence of harmony,
they constantly pursue one another.

Zhuangzi said:
*"I sell it, and they buy it."*
Applying this principle to governance,
it extends beyond mere harmony of sound and voice.

One transmits to ten, ten to a hundred—
the following of before and after never ceases.
Thus, what the rulers intend
cannot be made known to all.

This is the essence of supreme action.

The Master Lao’s teaching of *wuwei* is vast in scope,
yet his guidance varies with each matter.
This *wuwei* speaks of guiding transformation through action.
Though the heart discerns right and wrong,
the outward appearance remains entirely erased.

Those who describe *beauty* truly hold it in their hearts,
yet do not reveal their admiration for it;
those who are *good* truly hold it in their hearts,
yet do not display their approval of it.
In their actions,
they silently act without leaving traces—
this is the affair of *wuwei*.

Why do they do this?
For fear that outward intentions,
once exposed, will let people habituate to their virtues
and counterfeit their sincerity.

As for *"dwelling"*—
they stand firm here, settled and at ease,
unburdened by other concerns.

To teach through silent action:
Communication between self and others must rely on speech,
yet if teaching is proclaimed without explanation,
how will people know what to follow?

This passage warns against the love of outward forms,
where people abandon themselves to falsehood.

To name this deed as *beauty*,
to display this person as *good*,
to manifest in praise and borrowings,
to spread through decrees—
when people follow what is called *beauty* and *good*,
and imitate their semblance,
then the original *true beauty* and *true good*
will all turn into mere pretense.

chunks.original_text: 老子於是究其伪之所起，而反之矣。 其中未尝不存动化之机，而外焉不示抑扬之则，使夫游泳其间者，莫知夫何者之可以中上欲也； 则谓道非明民，将以愚之。 此正教焉而不言者也。 若夫立师资之等列，分亲生之先后，则夫不言之教虽其默如渊，而其声如雷矣。 万物作焉至功成不居。 作者，兴起而承其教也。 生如动而徐，生之生也，教孚於人，而善心有萌者，是其所以生之也。 为者，其作为之地也，功者以天下之自化自宾者，而归其效於己也。 夫无为之事，不言之教，其事其言，非家至户到各立一则也，放天地不仁之大槩，四海而用一抚焉。 凡能兴起而应其所教者归，斯受之未尝有所却谢也。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之，是之谓不辞也。 善心有萌，其教已效，而犹不肯自以为当也，是不有且不恃也。 及其作也生也为也，三者皆底于成，则功且遂矣，乃又弃而不居，则若己未尝有预也。 呜呼，其已大矣。 事之未济也，以为己任； 及其已济也，不为己功。 此大道之所以不肯为德也。 夫惟至不去。 有形必终於坏，有数必终於尽，是凡有必趋於无也，则其去安可得留也。 若夫功成而不居，则直付之无有，是在我者无盈可亏，无成可坏，则安得而去也。 春之华物，是明以发生之德自居也，故其华可代。 秋而成实，是明以击敛之事自任也，故其实可落。 若元气行乎四时之表，生生而不自生，化化而不自化，则亘万古而常然。 此既无所於留彼，亦无所於往也，是谓自古及今，其名不去，以阅众甫也。 论儒者恨民之难觉，而老氏恨其不愚，故其言曰民之难治，以其智多； 又曰民多利器，国家滋昏。 至其自言待之之道，则曰道非明民，将以愚之； 又曰鱼不可脱於渊，国之利器不可以示於人。 推此言也，则夫力诋圣智仁义，而欲弃绝其具者，意不专在乎圣智七义也。 其曰智慧出有大伪者，是其所从立矫之本也。 盖礼法之立，自羲尧始。 其立也，以补结绳之简也。 既病其简，故从而祖习者，其势不容不趋於繁。 及其繁也，制度机括布满暴白，民之巧者既有所见，亦有所放。 是上能出智以防民，而民亦能放智以乱法也。 此老氏所为追咎智慧之多事，而欲矫之以无为也。 惩明民之启伪，而欲矫之以无迹也。 夫川实而谷虚，丘夷而渊实，一彼一此，既已对立，则势不两大。 故圣智仁义，不容不在弃绝之域也。 然而圣智仁义，老氏终不免取之以寓此道，则其所欲弃绝者，岂其实理也哉？ 究终观敝，而咎其播宣利器以明示民焉耳。 即此两章而详味之，岂不灼其可见也哉。 其曰不尚贤也者，非贤不肖一律也，特不肯表而出之，始季彻之谓危其楼观以招致投迹者耳。 日天下皆知美善之为美善，斯入於不美不善，正亦默运其迹，而不使至於奔趋假托焉耳。 至其师资兼用，而高下有分，动静两立，而情生有机，则虽外示兼容，而中实有别也。 既以兼容之公来天下，又以甄别之机动人心。 此其法出於《易》之藏用，而非老氏之意创也。 特其施置有浅深焉耳。 《易》之言曰：显诸仁，藏诸用。 显者，有具可示之谓也； 藏者，致用之本深密难测之谓也。 礼乐刑政既已裁为治具，而犹病夫可使之由，而不能使之知也，则夫据总体道，以制为此具者，虽欲示之亦无由可示也。
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi thus examined the origins of this falsity and reversed it. Within, the mechanism of spontaneous transformation never ceases, yet outwardly, no signs of suppression or elevation are shown. Thus, those who drift between these states cannot know what to follow to ascend. Therefore, he says, *"The Dao does not enlighten the people; it seeks to make them simple."*

This is the essence of teaching without words.

But when distinctions of rank are established between teachers and disciples, and precedence is drawn between those born first and last, then even the silent teaching—though profound as the abyss—resounds like thunder.

All things arise and achieve great deeds without claiming them.
*"Arising"* means to stir and uphold the teaching.
*"Generating"* is like gentle movement, nurturing life—teaching takes root in people, and goodwill begins to sprout, for this is how it gives birth.
*"Doing"* refers to the realm of action, while *"achievement"* belongs to those who transform the world through self-so and self-receiving, returning its effects to the Dao.

The affairs of *wuwei* and the teaching of *non-speech* are not private rules set in every household. Instead, they embrace the vast indifference of Heaven and Earth, governing the four seas with a single touch.

All who can arise and respond to the teaching are welcomed—none are ever rejected or declined.
*"To the good, I am good; to the ungood, I am also good"*—this is called *not declining*.

When goodwill begins to sprout and the teaching takes effect, yet one still refuses to claim credit, this is *not possessing and not relying*.

When action, generation, and doing all reach completion, the deed is fulfilled—yet it is abandoned without attachment, as if one had never been involved. Ah! How vast this is.

Before completion, it is taken as one’s responsibility; when completed, it is not claimed as one’s achievement. This is why the Great Dao does not seek to establish virtue.

Only what is utterly unceasing endures. All that is formed must eventually decay, all that is numbered must eventually exhaust—thus, all that exists tends toward nonexistence. How then can departure be retained?

But if achievement is completed without claiming it, it is as if it never existed. What belongs to the Dao cannot be depleted or destroyed—how then can it depart?

The flowers of spring declare their own virtue in blooming, so their splendor can be replaced. The fruits of autumn take responsibility for gathering and refining, so their harvest can fall. But the Original Qi moves beyond the four seasons, generating without being generated, transforming without being transformed—thus enduring eternally through the ages. This, having neither attachment nor departure, is called *"from ancient times to the present, its name does not fade, as it oversees all things."*

Confucian scholars lament that the people are difficult to awaken, while Laozi laments that they are not simple enough. Hence, he says, *"The people are difficult to govern because they are too clever,"* and *"When the people have many sharp tools, the state grows confused."* Yet when speaking of his own approach, he says, *"The Dao does not enlighten the people; it seeks to make them simple,"* and *"Fish cannot be lifted from the depths, nor can the state’s sharp tools be displayed before the people."*

Pursuing this logic, those who fiercely condemn sagely wisdom, benevolence, and righteousness, desiring to abandon their implements, do not truly oppose these virtues themselves. For he says, *"Wisdom and insight, when overdeveloped, breed great falsity,"*—this is the root of his corrective intent.

Indeed, the establishment of rites and laws began with Xuanyu and Yao. Their creation was meant to supplement the simplicity of knotted cords. But once their simplicity was seen as deficient, those who followed inevitably leaned toward excess. When excess grew, institutions and mechanisms spread until they became overt and exposed—then the clever among the people, seeing them, also began to manipulate them. Thus, the sage could use wisdom to restrain the people, while the people could use their cleverness to disrupt the laws.

This is why Laozi blamed the proliferation of wisdom and sought to correct it with *wuwei*. He feared that enlightening the people would spawn falsity and sought to correct it with *wuji* (non-tracing).

For rivers fill while valleys empty, hills level while depths fill—once opposites arise, neither can dominate. Thus, sagely wisdom, benevolence, and righteousness must inevitably fall into the realm of abandonment.

Yet Laozi, though he ultimately rejects them, still employs them to embody the Dao—so what he truly condemns is not their essence, but the propagation of sharp tools to enlighten the people.

Examining these two passages closely, is it not clear?

When he says *"do not exalt the worthy,"* he does not mean all are equal in merit—only that he refuses to display them openly. He warns against the danger of erecting grand structures to attract those who seek fame.

When the world knows beauty and goodness as beauty and goodness, then entering the realm of *not-beauty* and *not-goodness* is also a silent operation, preventing people from rushing into pretense and false imitation.

Yet when teachers and disciples are both employed, with distinctions of high and low, and when movement and stillness are both established, with emotions stirring naturally—though outwardly appearing inclusive, inwardly there remains discrimination.

He governs the world with an all-encompassing public stance, yet within, he employs subtle mechanisms to move the hearts of people. This method stems from the *Yijing*’s principle of *"manifesting in virtue, concealing in use."* The manifest refers to what can be demonstrated; the concealed refers to the profound, inscrutable source of transformation.

Though rites, music, punishments, and governance have been established as tools of governance, the concern remains that people can be made to follow without truly understanding. Thus, those who grasp the totality of the Dao to craft these tools—even if they wished to reveal it—could find no way to do so.

chunks.original_text: 故《易》之藏用，其极致遂至於入神也。 神云者，不疾而速，不行而至。 老氏模之以谓无为而无不为者是也。 特变其语，度以自立己则焉耳。 学者不敢以此议《易》，而皆用此为老氏讥病，则是否何其无定也。 然其施置不免小异於《易》者，则亦不可掩盖矣。 《易》求显於用而不可，故常恨百姓之愚，而不能自同乎仁智之有见也者。 老氏则直欲从而愚之，必待其无知无欲，然后与取歙张一出於我也。 此其异也。 詹秋圃曰：天下皆知至不去。 养身一章始欲相忘於不识不知之表，终欲相反相成，而不自大其大，以居天下之大也。 故曰天下皆知美之为美，善之为善，适恐好慕乖张，至於为恶为不善已。 善事为字偶对待，自相生而极於相随，其反复各以类从为消长，是以圣人处无为之事，行不言之教，付万物於此作彼应，而不辞让，生而不自有，为而不自恃，虽及功成而弗居，必且推之而不去矣。 盖善养吾身者，能以功成身退自处，则居安资深，又宁失其肩背乎？ 张冲应曰：天下皆知至不去。 大道恶盈而持谦也。 才美矣，而众美之终为起妬。 名善矣，而众善之，终为起争。 妬固害身，争亦害身。 故庞涓逞其才而中树下之失，韩信贪其名而遭云梦之诛。 是皆不足以语玄道者也。 圣人者出，不恃其才之所独有，而常怀见有为无之心，不惜其功之所难成，而常有见难为易之念。 彼短我兮我推之以长，而短为长所覆，故曰相形。 彼高我兮我居之以下，而高为下所抑，故曰相倾。 彼感此应，而声音相和，前行后效，上下自顺，处之以无为之事，行之以不言之教，以道律身，以身阐道，真心固矣。 万物作而心不乱，贪心绝矣。 万物生而心不有，志可为而不逞所为，功已成而不居其位，子房所以赤松之游速，锺离权所以玉洞之去忙，皆此养也。 夫有此养则精长固，气长存，神长清，而身长生，福德在我而不去。 白玉蟾曰：天下皆知美之、为，求为美名，美斯恶已，不得美名。 皆知善之为，求为善人，善斯不善已，反为恶人。 故有无相生，无必生有，有必生无。 难易相成。 先难后易，先易复难。 长短相形。 道本无形，自相长短，高下相倾。 天旋地转，本无高卑。 音声相和。 一风所鸣，万籁皆应。 前后相随。 往古即今，来今即古。 是以圣人处无为之事。 贵乎自然。 行不言之教。 道寓於物。 万物作焉而不辞。 无必生有，安得不生？ 傥若不生，安见长存？ 生而不有。 无非妄幻。 为而不恃。 今日今日而已。 功成而弗居。 岂可与梦为实。 夫惟弗居。 忘外而不忘其内也。 是以不去。 一我自存也。 廖粹然曰：天下皆知美之为美，人皆以色声香味触法，喜怒爱恶哀乐欲为强美，吾知则不然。 夫何故哉？ 斯恶已。 故好事多魔，七情内攻，六贼外寇，一切贪欲又为身害，吾恒恬憺无为，以学道得道为强，岂不美欤。 皆知善之为善，亦以为善最乐，或作善功，济人利物，皆是善事。 吾见未然。 何故？
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus, the *Yijing*’s principle of *concealing in use* reaches its ultimate expression in *entering the divine* (入神). *Entering the divine* means moving without haste yet swiftly, acting without effort yet arriving with perfect effect. This is precisely what the Old Master (老氏) imitated when he spoke of *"non-action yet nothing left undone"* (无为而无不为).

Yet, he altered the phrasing, merely applying it as a means to establish his own doctrine. Scholars dare not use this to critique the *Yijing*, but instead all employ it as a basis to condemn the Old Master, which is a matter of unclear judgment indeed.

However, his methods of implementation do not entirely diverge from the *Yijing*, and this cannot be concealed. The *Yijing* seeks to *manifest in virtue* (显诸仁) yet fails, thus lamenting the common folk’s ignorance, unable to align them with the *virtue of the wise and the enlightened* (仁智之有见).

The Old Master, however, directly aims to deceive them, waiting until they are *without knowledge and without desire* (无知无欲), before he then *takes and seizes* (取歙张) them, emerging from within. Here lies their difference.

Zhan Qiupu (詹秋圃) said: *"All under Heaven know ‘the utmost’ yet do not attain it."* In the chapter on *Nurturing the Body* (养身), he first seeks to *forget oneself in the realm of unknowing and unrecognizing* (不识不知之表), yet ultimately desires *contraries giving rise to each other* (相反相成), without magnifying his own greatness to dwell in the greatness of all under Heaven.

Hence, it is said: *"All under Heaven know beauty as beauty, goodness as goodness; yet this very pursuit of beauty and goodness may lead to perversion and distortion, resulting in evil and wickedness."* The pairing of *"good deeds"* (善事) and *"action"* (为) reflects how opposites generate each other and reach their extreme in mutual dependence. The rise and fall of each arise from their kind, thus the Sage acts in *non-action* (无为), teaches through *non-speech* (不言), entrusting all things to *this generates that* (此作彼应) without complaint. He gives life yet does not possess it, acts yet does not claim it—though his deeds are accomplished, he does not dwell upon them, but rather *pushes them away* (推之) and they do not depart.

Indeed, those who excel in *nurturing the body* (养身) can *retire after success* (功成身退), thereby *dwelling in security and deepening their roots* (居安资深), and would never lose their *shoulders and backs* (肩背) for the sake of it.

Zhang Chongying (张冲应) replied: *"All under Heaven know ‘the utmost’ yet do not attain it."* The Dao abhors excess and upholds humility (谦).

Though talent is beautiful, those who are praised for their beauty will ultimately *arouse envy* (起妬). Though virtue is good, those who are praised for their virtue will ultimately *spark contention* (起争). Envy harms the body, contention harms the body as well. Thus, Pang Juan (庞涓) flaunted his talent and fell into the *tree’s shadow disaster* (树下之失), while Han Xin (韩信) coveted his name and met his end in the *Cloud Dream purge* (云梦之诛). These are matters unworthy of discussion with the *mysterious Dao* (玄道).

The Sage, when he emerges, does not rely upon his unique talents, but instead harbors the mind of *seeing action in non-action* (见有为无). He does not grudge the difficulty of his accomplishments, but rather holds the thought of *seeing difficulty as ease* (见难为易).

When others are short and I extend them, their shortness is covered by my length—thus it is said, *contraries form each other* (相形). When others are high and I humble myself beneath them, their height is suppressed by my lowliness—thus it is said, *contraries topple each other* (相倾).

When one responds and the other resonates, their voices harmonize; when one leads and the other follows, above and below align naturally. The Sage governs through *non-action* and teaches through *non-speech*, using the Dao to regulate his body and his body to elucidate the Dao. His true heart is steadfast.

All things arise, yet his mind remains unperturbed—*desires are extinguished* (贪心绝矣). All things are born, yet he does not possess them—*his will can act yet does not indulge in its own doing* (志可为而不逞所为). Though his deeds are accomplished, he does not dwell in their position—thus Zhang Liang (子房) attained swiftness in *Red Pine’s wandering* (赤松之游速), and Zhongli Quan (锺离权) achieved leisure in *Jade Cavern’s departure* (玉洞之去忙), all through this cultivation.

With this cultivation, *vital essence endures* (精长固), *qi remains stored* (气长存), *spirit stays clear* (神长清), and thus the body *long-lives* (身长生). *Blessings and virtue* (福德) reside within yet do not depart.

Bai Yu Chan (白玉蟾) said: *"All under Heaven know beauty as beauty, goodness as goodness; those who seek fame in beauty and goodness, though they attain beauty and goodness, cannot escape the rise of evil. Those who seek to be called ‘good,’ though they perform good deeds and benefit others, ultimately become wicked."*

Hence, *having and non-having generate each other*—non-having must generate having, having must generate non-having. *Difficulty and ease complete each other*—first difficult, then easy; first easy, then difficult again. *Length and shortness form each other*—the Dao itself is formless, yet through self-extension, length and shortness arise. *High and low topple each other*—Heaven revolves, Earth turns; originally there is no high or low.

*Voices harmonize*—when one wind sounds, all ten thousand echoes respond. *Front and back follow each other*—the past is the present, the present is the past.

Thus, the Sage governs through *non-action* and values *naturalness* (自然). He teaches through *non-speech* and the Dao is embodied in things. All things arise from this, yet he does not refuse it.

Non-having must generate having—how could it not generate? If it did not generate, how could it endure long? He gives life yet does not possess it—non-having is merely false illusion. He acts yet does not claim it—*today is today alone* (今日今日而已). Though his deeds are accomplished, he does not dwell upon them—*how could it compare with reality, to dream of it?*

Only in *not dwelling* (弗居) does he *forget the external yet not forget the internal*—thus it is said, *it does not depart* (不去). *One self remains stored* (一我自存).

Liao Cuiran (廖粹然) said: *"All under Heaven know goodness as goodness; people take color, sound, fragrance, flavor, and physical form (触法) as their objects of attachment, indulging in joy, anger, love, hatred, sorrow, delight, and desires to make them their ‘strong goods’ (强美). I know this is not so.*

Why is this not so? Because *this very attachment is the root of evil* (斯恶已). Thus, those who love affairs are plagued by *demons* (魔), the *Seven Emotions* (七情) assault from within, the *Six Bandits* (六贼) invade from without, and all desires ultimately harm the body. I habitually remain *serene and indifferent* (恬憺无为), considering *learning the Dao and attaining the Dao* (学道得道) as the true ‘strong goods’—is this not beautiful?

All under Heaven know goodness as goodness, yet they also believe that goodness is the most joyous. Some perform good deeds, aid others, and benefit all things—these are all considered good actions. *I see otherwise*—why is this so?
chunks.overlap_context:
Yijing*’s principle of *"manifesting in virtue, concealing in use."* The manifest refers to what can be demonstrated; the concealed refers to the profound, inscrutable source of transformation.

Though rites, music, punishments, and governance have been established as tools of governance, the concern remains that people can be made to follow without truly understanding. Thus, those who grasp the totality of the Dao to craft these tools—even if they wished to reveal it—could find no way to do so.
