chunks.original_text: 是以骨强则有立，弱以守之，正以行之者也。 如有所立卓尔，则异乎根也欲矣。 观夫天下学道之士多矣，有知之者，知之而不能守，守之而不能行。 无他焉，是欲利之心胜而清虚之道难反。 强其志而弱其骨也，譬如多积货财，阖户守之，不能贸迁，何由富矣。 御注曰：骨强则行流散徙，言无中下矣。 惟自强不息者，为能体此。 三政化所及。 常使民无知无欲。 此一句总结前义，下一句示以法也。 常使民无知无欲，则是重明向上不尚贤、不贵货、不见可欲，以至虚心实腹、弱志强骨，言圣人出治天下有此七者，诚无他焉，使民无知无欲是也。 尚贤则多知，至於天下大骇，儒墨毕起。 责货则多欲，至於决性命之情以争之，攘夺诞谩，无所不至。 见名之可欲，见利之可尚，皆失道者也。 惟圣人为能去此三者，民自无知也，亦无欲也。 惟民生厚，因物有迁。 盖以上之人作聪明，务机巧而为之诲也，及其已甚，刑法不足以齐之。 董子曰：法出而奸生，令下而诈起。 此昔之在位者教之不善，风俗渐染之深，未可一日而化也。 今虽欲以法而禁之，令而申之，彼其奸恶之心尚在，当以道化之则可也。 法始乎伏羲而成乎尧，大备乎成周，而智巧尽矣。 故曰周衰而道微可知也。 老子作经，意在乎此。 虽然，岂止为当时而作，将以为万世之蓍龟。 及其乱也，何异乎战国，是尚贤贵货多欲之过。 孔子曰：民可使由之，不可使知之。 尧闻童谣曰：不识不知，顺帝之则。 苟在上之人多知多欲，而欲其无知无欲，是不可也。 犹之恶醉而强酒，诚不若以至诚而化之，纯朴以守之，在上者如愚，在下者无知，即庄子谓上如标枝民如野鹿，何威福之用哉？ 刻意尚行，离世异俗，民始疑矣。 二、牒前智巧无施。 使夫知者不敢为也。 经曰将以愚之，民之难治，以其智多。 庄子曰：天下有道，圣人成焉； 天下无道，圣人生焉。 多知多欲，爚乱天下，至於民失常性又欲以刑威而禁之，兹又大乱之本也。 秦之毒天下，智巧胜矣，不能用仁义而以刑威，欲治天下，恩不及民，故其忘速矣。 然民岂无知也，可使藏之而不用，惟上之人不启其端，则下之人有知而不敢为也。 《阴符经》曰：绝利一原，用师十倍。 其此之谓也。 若使夫知之者敢为，则纷拏不足而禁矣。 一至于此，虽欲诛之，有不胜诛者矣。 故曰我无为而民自化。 四显无为之功。 一、化行无彰二。 为无为，此一句总结一篇之义，以明圣人出治，虽无为而未尝不为。 无为则绝物，有为则近事，所谓事非道也，而事实出於道矣。 使为之而不见为之之迹，治之而不显治之之功，斯善矣。 且如之何使为而不见为之之迹、治之而不显治之之功乎？ 《易》曰寂然不动，感而遂通。 夫不动者性也，感而遂通者情也。 性本无为，道之体也。 道之为性，其实无形，有极而作，则天地至於万物，无不由兹而出焉。 《传》曰万物职职，皆从无为殖是道也。 出於圣人之心，而应次二之神，潜天而天，潜地而地，无非精神之运动者也。 夫见於精神之运动者，则有为也。 运而不见其进者，本无为也。 且不为也，天下一日二日，而万机其可置而勿论乎。 勿论则不治。 若事事而治之，物物而察之，则又劳矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The bones grow strong to stand firm,
Yet weakness guards them,
And uprightness guides their movement.

If one stands outstandingly erect,
Then it differs from the roots of desire.

Observe how many scholars of the Dao there are in the world—
Some know it, yet cannot guard it;
Guard it, yet cannot act upon it.
There is no other reason—
For the heart’s desire for gain overpowers,
And the Way of clarity and emptiness becomes difficult to return to.

Strengthen the will yet weaken the bones—
Like hoarding wealth without trade,
Shutting doors to guard it,
Yet unable to exchange it—
How then could one grow rich?

**Commentary:** *"The bones grow strong, yet their movement scatters and shifts—*
*This is to say there is no steadiness below."*

Only those who persist in self-strengthening
Can truly embody this.

The Three Governments’ teachings reach far—
Ever making the people without knowledge, without desire.
This sentence summarizes the preceding meaning,
While the next demonstrates the method.

Ever make the people without knowledge, without desire—
This is to emphasize:
*"Do not value the worthy,
Do not prize wealth,
Do not show what is desirable,"*
Thus achieving a hollow heart and full belly,
A weak will and strong bones.
The Sage, governing the world, relies on these seven principles—
Nothing else is needed—
Making the people without knowledge, without desire.

To value the worthy brings excessive knowledge,
Until the world is in uproar—
Confucians and Mohists arise in chaos.
To prize wealth brings excessive desire,
Until one risks life and nature for gain,
Seizing and deceiving without restraint.
To see names and profits as desirable—
All are deviations from the Dao.

Only the Sage can abandon these three,
And thus the people naturally have no knowledge,
Nor any desire.

Yet human nature is thick,
And circumstances shift with things.
For those above, cleverness and artifice
Are taught and refined—
But when carried to excess,
Laws and punishments cannot correct them.

**Master Dong said:**
*"When laws are issued, deceit arises;
When orders are given, fraud follows."*
This stems from past rulers’ poor instruction,
And the deep corruption of customs—
Not something that can be changed in a day.

Now, even if one tries to suppress it with laws,
Or reinforces it with decrees,
Their deceitful hearts remain—
Only the Dao can transform them.

Laws began with Fu Xi and were perfected by Yao,
Fully developed in the Zhou—
Yet cleverness reached its peak.
Thus it is known that when the Zhou declined,
The Dao faded.

Laozi composed the *Classic*,
Its intent here.
Yet it was not merely for his time—
It was meant as an oracle for all ages.

When chaos arose, it was no different from the Warring States—
The excess of valuing the worthy, prizing wealth, and excessive desire.

**Confucius said:**
*"The people can be made to follow, but not to understand."*

**Emperor Yao heard a child’s song:**
*"Unknowing, unknowing,
Following Heaven’s patterns."*

If those above are knowledgeable and desiring,
Yet wish the people to be without knowledge or desire—
This is impossible.
It is like hating drunkenness yet forcing wine—
Truly, nothing is better than
Using utmost sincerity to transform them,
Purity and simplicity to guard them.
If those above act as if foolish,
The people below remain unknowing—
As Zhuangzi said:
*"The ruler like a tree branch,
The people like wild deer—
What use is there for rewards and punishments?"*

Forced effort and rigid conduct,
Separating from the world and customs—
The people begin to doubt.

**Second Point: Restraining cleverness and artifice.**
Make the knowledgeable dare not act.

The *Classic* says:
*"I will deceive them with simplicity—*
*The people are hard to govern because their cleverness is excessive."*

**Zhuangzi said:**
*"When the Dao prevails in the world, the Sage completes it;
When the Dao does not prevail, the Sage arises."*

Excessive knowledge and desire
Throw the world into chaos—
Until the people lose their natural nature,
And punishment is used to suppress them—
This is the root of greater disorder.

The Qin poisoned the world—
Their cleverness was supreme,
Yet they could not use benevolence and righteousness,
Only punishment and coercion,
To govern the world—
Their kindness did not reach the people,
So their downfall came swiftly.

Yet the people were not without knowledge—
It could be hidden and unused.
Only if those above do not provoke it,
Then those below, though knowing, dare not act.

*The Yinxu Classic* says:
*"Cut off the root of gain,
And ten armies will be useless."*
This is what is meant.

If those who know dare to act,
Then even strict prohibitions are insufficient.
To this point, even if one wishes to punish them,
There are those punishment cannot reach.

Thus it is said:
*"I take no action, yet the people transform themselves."*

**Fourth: Displaying the function of *wuwei*.**

1. *Transformation proceeds without display.*

*Wuwei* yet action—
This sentence summarizes the entire meaning,
To show that the Sage, though governing through *wuwei*,
Is never without action.

*Wuwei* cuts off external interference,
Action aligns with affairs—
What is not the Dao becomes the Dao in practice.

To act without showing traces of action,
To govern without displaying governance—
This is the pinnacle.

How then does one act without showing traces,
Or govern without displaying function?

*The Book of Changes* says:
*"Motionless yet responsive,
Stirred and thus in harmony."*

The unmoving is nature,
The responsive is emotion.
Nature is originally *wuwei*—
The essence of the Dao.

The Dao as nature
Is formless in reality,
Yet at its extreme, it manifests—
From Heaven and Earth to all things,
None arise without this.

*The Commentary* says:
*"All things flourish,
Yet they all stem from *wuwei*—this is the Dao."*

Emerging from the Sage’s heart,
Responding to the divine in sequence—
Penetrating Heaven, Heaven responds;
Penetrating Earth, Earth responds—
Nothing but the movement of spirit.

What is seen in the movement of spirit—
This is action.
What moves yet shows no progress—
This is originally *wuwei*.

Moreover, if one does not act,
Could the world’s affairs be neglected for a day or two?
Neglect leads to disorder.
If one governs each matter,
Inspects each thing—
Then labor is endless.

chunks.original_text: 劳则堕，堕则不治矣。 凡为之之道，岂免仁以仁之，义以宜之，礼以体之，信以质之，恩以爱之，刑以威之哉？ 若出治而略此数者，且欲求治，又不可得也。 上古不用礼法，羲皇已用结绳，大率上古之时，民纯事简，无为之功易可见也。 若谓后世只可有为，不可无为，则是道不可行也。 惟体道之圣人能通乎此。 《易》曰其道甚大，百物不废。 惟不废一物也，道实有为之。 及乎求道也，道本无为矣。 兹所谓为无为者是也。 尝试论之，无为者内圣也，有为者外王也。 内圣则渊乎其虚，外王则兴事造业。 以渊虚之心而为事业，则事出於道，道本於虚，有为无为混而无迹，岂俟他哉？ 是篇归之不尚贤，欲圣人之独化也。 独化则神矣。 有能不亲贤道，而致无为自然者，大圣之治也。 若需贤佐者则逃也，请以神观大圣之教人也。 摇荡人心，使之成教易俗，其朴徐徐，其觉于于，无事而万物化，无为而百姓定，此神也。 请以迹观尧禅舜，舜命九官，皋陶曰：知在知人，知人则哲，能官人安民则惠。 又曰：百工惟时，庶续其凝。 则朝廷既治，可以率天下矣。 至於《仲虺》之称汤用人惟己，皆须贤以为辅佐也。 又曰：旁求俊乂而共成天下之治，则智者为之谋，能者为之使，君逸臣劳。 此见乎迹，是君能任人，以成无为之治也。 彼无所待，圣之无为也。 此有所待，因贤而致无为也。 盖得贤则治，失贤则亡，不尚者存於大圣人也。 世尝谓老子之道，语类鸿荒，非用中之道，其何以云有为？ 为则是不废中庸也。 二、道契自然。 则无不治矣。 如上则见无为之功矣。 至於无为，则与道为一。 道德真经集义卷之七竟 ＃1 主以不贿闻千诸侯者：『千』据《左传》当作『于』。 道德真经集义卷之八 凝远大师常德路玄妙观

Exhaustion leads to decline,
Decline leads to disorder.

Now, the Way of action—
How could it avoid
Ren with its benevolence,
Righteousness with its fittingness,
Ritual with its form,
Trust with its sincerity,
Grace with its love,
Law with its authority?

If one governs without these,
Yet still seeks order—
It cannot be attained.

In the Age of the Yellow Emperor,
Gifts were exchanged without written laws,
But by the time of the Three Sovereigns,
Knots on cords were already used.
Generally, in ancient times,
The people were pure and simple,
And the efficacy of *wuwei* was easily seen.

If one claims that later ages
Must only act and cannot practice *wuwei*,
Then the Dao cannot be followed.

Only the Sage who embodies the Dao
Can harmonize these truths.

The *Yijing* says:
*"Its Way is vast—
No thing is neglected."*

To neglect nothing is truly *wuwei*.
Yet when seeking the Dao,
The Dao itself is *wuwei*.

This is what is meant by
*"Doing without doing."*

Consider this:
*Wuwei* is the Sage within,
Action is the Sovereign without.
The Sage within is profound in emptiness,
The Sovereign without creates deeds and enterprises.

With a heart of profound emptiness
To undertake affairs,
Then actions arise from the Dao,
The Dao roots in emptiness—
*Wuwei* and action blend without trace.
What more is there to seek?

This treatise concludes
By not valuing the worthy,
Desiring the Sage’s solitary transformation.

Solitary transformation is divine.
If one does not personally embody the Dao,
Yet achieves *wuwei* naturally—
This is the governance of the Great Sage.

If one relies on worthy ministers,
That is retreat.
Now, let us observe the Sage’s divine teaching:

Shaking the hearts of people,
Guiding them toward virtue and custom—
Their simplicity grows gradually,
Their awakening comes softly.
Without action, all things transform;
Without *wuwei*, the people are settled—
This is divine.

Now, observe the succession of Yao to Shun:
Shun appointed the Nine Ministers,
And Gao Yao said:
*"Knowledge lies in knowing people,
Knowing people makes one wise,
Able to govern officials and settle the people—this is benevolence."*

Again he said:
*"All craftsmen follow their seasons,
The common people continue their labors."*

Thus, when the court was orderly,
It could lead all under Heaven.

As for *Zhonghu*’s praise of Tang,
*"He used people only as he himself would,"*
Yet he still required worthy ministers as assistants.

Again it says:
*"Seek the talented and capable
To jointly achieve the governance of all under Heaven—
The wise plan for it,
The capable execute it,
The ruler rests while ministers labor."*

This, seen in practice,
Shows the ruler’s ability to entrust others,
Thus achieving *wuwei* governance.

The one who depends on nothing
Is the Sage’s *wuwei*.
The one who depends on the worthy
Achieves *wuwei* through them.

Generally, having worthy ministers brings order,
Losing them brings ruin.
Not valuing them is the way of the Great Sage.

The world often says
That Laozi’s teachings
Resemble the chaos of the primordial age,
Not the Way of governance—
How then can it be called *wuwei*?

*Wuwei* is not neglecting the Middle Way.
The Dao aligns with nature—
Then nothing remains untended.

Thus, *wuwei* is seen in its efficacy.
When it comes to *wuwei*,
It merges with the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易东校正 不尚贤章 邵若愚曰：不尚贤使民不争至为无为则无不治矣。 夫不尚贤能者，恐人矜智。 王所好者谓之风，民乐随之谓之俗，上矜贤智，下心竞趣。 不尚贤，使民不争其名故也。 食之为货，务资赡养，岂贵珍其难得。 贵乎难得，民必深藏。 凡人之情，与之则不受，藏之必窃夺。 治世非不用货，不贵珍奇难得之货者，使民不为盗故也。 下民不见名利，可使欲心不乱，其民自治。 是以圣人之治，不尚贤，使民无知，无知则自虚其心，心虚则能容万物。 故云实其腹。 不贵货，使民无欲，无欲则自弱其志，志弱则不随境转。 故云强其骨。 常使民无知则虚心，无欲则忘境，心境两忘，无所攀缘，万事俱息，使夫有智者而不敢为，圣人为无心之为，则天下无不治矣。 王志然曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 夫语道而非其序，非道也，语道而非其道，安取道。 庄子九变之序五变，刑名可举舍，是若倒道而行，逢道而说者，人之所治安能治人，骤而语刑名者，由未知所以为学为治之本意欤。 且名者实之宾，名实既定乎内外之分，天下之人爵因任而已，岂有贤者弃之野而不用者哉？ 而老子谓不可尚之之意，其有深旨焉。 故庄子曰举贤则名相轧。 尚贤则起争之一端，以至天下大骇，智诈是非，颉滑解垢，儒墨毕起，其不可尚者如此。 聚天下之货财，养天下之民人，而民熙熙然，击壤而歌，鼓腹而游，物物而不物於物，乌可窃窃然而贵之哉？ 老子谓不可贵之之意，其亦有谓。 以天下之万物职职芸芸，各有所系焉。 既有时而成，必有时而毁，既有时而贵，必有时而贱，付之自尔，讵可容心哉？ 人欲贵之者，唯必得是求，求之不得，将决性命之情以争之。 以至攘夺觊觎，靡所不至，岂只为盗而已？ 此盖上有所好，下有必甚者焉。 经曰不见可欲使心不乱，孔子云富贵是人之所欲。 至如目击耳闻，鼻嗅舌尝，侈情动心，皆谓之可欲。 苟欲之无餍者，虽天地之大，万物之多，不足以供其求。 君子之所欲者名也，小人之所欲者利也，举天下贤不肖皆不见可欲之欲，则心常寂然，何乱之有？ 所以圣人常虚其心，不为一物之所囿，常实其腹，不为一物之所礩。 内观其心，廓然无有，外观其形，与物委蛇而同其波； 远观其物，物无其物。 故志弱而有用，骨强而有立，志之所之有所操，则有所守焉。 肾主藏志，而骨者肾之余，弱其志则精不摇，而骨强矣。 心主藏神，而腹者心之宅，虚其心则神不亏，而腹实矣。 由是万化生乎身，精神生乎道，以此治人事天。 常使民无知无欲，使夫知者不敢为也。 唯其如此，则无不治矣。 庄子曰：同乎无知，其德不离； 同乎无欲，是谓素朴。 素朴则民性得矣。 若然者，天下焉知贤之可尚不可尚，货之可贵不可贵者。 黄茂材曰：不尚贤至使心不乱。 方且和其光，惟恐人之知，何贤之可尚，故民不争。 不争者，各安其性之自然。 方且窒其欲，惟恐物之扰，何货之可贵，故民不为盗。 不为盗者，取足於身而有余。 不见可欲，非闭其目，而不之见也。 物之交於吾前，而动於吾心者甚多，将不知见其可得乎，惟能见其无有可欲之处，然后不足以乱吾心。

**The Moral and Virtue Classic: Collected Meanings**

**On the Chapter "Not Valuing the Worthy"**

Sūshì Liú Wéiyǒng compiled, with annotations by the former Court Attendant and Treasury Bureau Clerk, former *Jùnmì Yuàn* Editor Dīng Yìdōng.

**Shào Ruòyú** said:
*"Not valuing the worthy"* makes the people not contend—thus achieving *wuwei*, and nothing remains untended.

He who does not value the worthy and able fears that men will boast of their wisdom.
What the king favors becomes the *wind*; what the people delight in becomes the *custom*.
When the ruler prizes the wise and clever, the common folk’s hearts turn to rivalry and striving.

*"Not valuing the worthy"* prevents the people from contending over reputation—that is all.

Food is but a commodity; its purpose is to sustain life—why then prize what is rare?
If rarity is prized, the people will surely hoard it.
By human nature, if given, they will not accept it; if hoarded, they will steal and plunder.

In governing, one does not refrain from using wealth—yet one does not prize rare and difficult-to-obtain goods, lest the people become thieves.

When the common folk see no allure in fame or gain, their desires grow orderly, and the people govern themselves.

Thus, the Sage’s governance:
*"Not valuing the worthy"* makes the people ignorant—ignorance empties the mind, and an empty mind can embrace all things.
Hence, *"fill their bellies."*
*"Not prizing wealth"* makes the people desireless—desirelessness weakens the will, and a weak will does not bend to circumstance.
Hence, *"strengthen their bones."*

Ever keep the people ignorant, so their minds remain empty;
Ever keep them desireless, so they forget the world.
When mind and world are both forgotten, no attachments remain—all affairs cease.
Thus, even the wise dare not act.
The Sage acts with no intention—then nothing in the world remains untended.

**Wáng Zhìrán** said:
*"Not valuing the worthy"* makes the people not contend—thus nothing remains untended.

To speak of the Dao yet disregard its order is not the Dao.
To speak of the Dao yet misunderstand it—how can one claim to have found it?

Zhuangzi’s *"Nine Transformations"* and *"Five Changes"*—discarding or upholding *xíngmíng* (names and forms)—is like walking the Dao backward.
Those who encounter the Dao and praise it—how can they govern others?
Those who suddenly speak of *xíngmíng*—have they not yet grasped the fundamental intent of learning and governance?

Names are the guests of reality.
Once names and reality are fixed in their internal and external distinctions, all under Heaven’s ranks follow their duties—why would the worthy be abandoned in the wild, unused?

Yet Laozi’s intent in saying *"do not value them"* holds profound meaning.
Thus Zhuangzi says: *"To promote the worthy is to invite contention over titles."*

Valuing the worthy sparks contention—leading to chaos under Heaven, where cunning deceit, disputes over right and wrong, and the dissolution of morals arise.
Confucians and Mohists all emerge—such is the danger of valuing the worthy.

Gathering all under Heaven’s wealth to nourish its people, yet the people are content, striking the earth and singing, drumming their bellies and wandering—each thing serves its purpose without being enslaved by things.
How could one secretly prize such a state?

Laozi’s intent in saying *"do not prize them"* is also profound.

All things under Heaven flourish in their appointed roles—each has its place.
When their time to flourish comes, so too comes their time to decay.
When their time to be prized comes, so too comes their time to be despised.
This is their natural course—how can one’s heart interfere?

Those who seek to prize them must obtain them at all costs.
If they cannot, they will risk life and limb to seize them—
leading to robbery, covetousness, and every vice.
Is theft the only sin?

This stems from the ruler’s preferences—when the ruler favors something, the people will pursue it excessively.

The *Classic* says: *"Do not let the desirable be seen, lest the heart be disturbed."*
Confucius said: *"Wealth and honor are what people desire."*
Even what is seen and heard—scented, tasted, or felt—stirs the emotions and disturbs the mind, all called *"desirable."*

If desire is insatiable, even Heaven and Earth’s vastness and all things’ abundance cannot satisfy it.

The gentleman desires *name*; the commoner desires *gain*.
If all under Heaven—worthy or unworthy—see no desirable desires, their hearts remain still—what disturbance could there be?

Thus the Sage ever empties the mind, unfettered by any thing;
Ever fills the belly, unobstructed by any thing.
Within, observing the mind—vast and empty;
Without, observing the form—yielding with things like flowing water.
From afar, observing things—things have no hold on him.

Thus, a weak will is useful; strong bones stand firm.
Where the will directs, there it guards.
The kidneys store the will, and bones are the kidneys’ remnant—
Weakening the will steadies the essence, and the bones grow strong.
The heart stores the spirit, and the belly is the heart’s dwelling—
Emptying the mind preserves the spirit, and the belly is filled.

From this, all transformations arise in the body;
Spirit and essence arise from the Dao—
With this, one governs humanity and harmonizes with Heaven.

Ever keep the people ignorant and desireless,
So even the wise dare not act.
Only thus does nothing remain untended.

Zhuangzi said:
*"In harmony with ignorance, virtue does not depart;
In harmony with desirelessness, this is called *sūpǔ* (primordial simplicity)."*
Primordial simplicity restores human nature.

If so, how could the world know whether the worthy should be valued or not,
Whether wealth should be prized or not?

**Huáng Màocái** said:
*"Not valuing the worthy"* reaches the point where the heart is undisturbed.
Just as one harmonizes one’s radiance, fearing others’ knowledge—
Why value the worthy? Thus, the people do not contend.
The non-contending each find contentment in their nature’s spontaneity.

Just as one restrains desire, fearing things’ disturbances—
Why prize wealth? Thus, the people do not steal.
The non-stealing take sufficiency in themselves and have abundance.

*"Not seeing the desirable"* is not closing one’s eyes to it.
Many things pass before us, stirring the heart—
One may not know what can be obtained,
But if one sees only that nothing is truly desirable,
Then nothing can disturb the heart.

chunks.original_text: 何者？ 毛嫱丽姬，天下之美也，人莫不欲之，而鱼见之深入，鸟见之高飞，麋鹿见之决骤，推此以言，诚无见其有可欲者，则心不乱矣。 是以圣人之治至实其腹。 南郭子泰隐几而坐，仰天而嘘，嗒然自丧其偶，能养其心至此，则可谓之虚矣。 一饱之外，虽有珍羞百味列於其前，惟恐其不亟彻而去，此腹所以欲其实也。 经曰圣人为腹不为目。 弱其志。 自强者有志。 今乃弱其志，何也？ 自强则可以进乎道，弱则可以到於日损之地矣。 强其骨，老子之道深乎强强，故曰强梁者，不得其死。 今强其骨何也？ 戒乎强者，恶其与物争也； 强其骨者，自强也。 夫道独立不改，非自强者安能政乎。 常使民无知无欲。 老子以治国治民况於其身，所谓使民即是其身，无知无欲，非顽然如木石之无所欲也。 其始也，不能无知，去其知至於无知； 其始也，不能无欲，去其欲至於无欲。 则自非有道君子，其积所至，其孰能之？ 使夫知者至则无不治矣。 夫道自然，岂可以智为之？ 惟能为无於无所为，斯可矣。 程泰之曰：不尚贤使民不争至使心不乱。 其人贤矣，表而出之，以暴耀天下，则必有耻其不若而强与之争，故庄子曰举贤则民相轧也。 贵难得之货，则必有弃业趋利，而不惜为盗者。 故曰货财聚然后睹所争也。 争且盗皆其睹可欲，而生心者也。 若上之人藏好恶而不示，下之人无所趋以为利，则凡其可欲者不复见前，心自不乱而争盗自息。 此老氏正本澄源之道也。 蒋闾勉之言治曰：必拔公忠之属，而无可私，民孰敢不辑？ 勉之此言，盖尧舜以来举善而教不能，凡致治者之所共也。 而季辙讥之曰：若子之言，则其自为处也。 危其观台多物，将往投迹者众。 盖讥其表而出之，则昭昭乎如观台之招物也，则见可欲而往焉，以争者多也。 然则见贤而不尚，岂其无别哉？ 泯迹以息争忌焉耳矣。 凡老氏之教所欲藏用自晦者，其意皆类此也。 见之读如现，上之人出而示之之谓也。 是以圣人之治至强其骨。 常时存想者，为心临事欲为者为志，腹所以饮食也，骨所以负任也。 老氏书有寓言，有实言，此之腹也，骨也，诚即其实而命之也。 后章曰：民之饥，以其上食税之多。 是其当实而虚之者也。 又曰：民之难治，以其智多。 此恶其强，而求以弱之者也。 庚桑子之居畏垒也，其臣之画然知者去之，其妾之挈然仁者远之，不使其心得有仁知焉，是求以虚也。 拥肿之与居，鞅掌之为使，拥肿鞅掌非骨强而耐负荷者，不在数也，此其立庚桑之则，而讥尧舜之举贤任知者然也。 常使民无知无欲。 民之有知则智多，而难治者是也。 其有欲则睹可欲，而争且盗者是也。 老氏之贵无为也，欲以无事处天下，而使天下亦安於无事也。 庄子之言治效，曰同乎无知，其德不离，同乎无欲，是谓素朴。 素朴而天下之性得矣。 使夫知者不敢为也。 使民无知无欲，将以愚之也。 而其中有桀黠不受愚者，是所谓智也。 智则不复可愚矣。 於是举天下皆顺吾教，则皆无知无欲矣。 无知无欲则安土乐业，不可诱之为乱矣。 虽有智者，知其无与附和，则亦意消而不敢复为。 故曰使民重死而不远徙，虽有甲兵无所陈之。 正其自谓可复结绳者，由此其致也。 庄子取是语而托之上古，曰古之人在混茫之中，与一世而得澹漠焉。
chunks.translated_text:
「What then? The beauty of Máoqiáng and Lìjì is renowned throughout the land—
no one fails to covet it.
Yet fish seeing them dive deep, birds seeing them soar high,
and deer seeing them flee swiftly—
by this reasoning, indeed, if one truly sees nothing as desirable,
then the heart remains undisturbed.

Thus, the Sage’s governance reaches the point of filling one’s belly.
Nánguō Zǐtài reclined behind his screen, gazing heavenward and sighing,
lost in his own emptiness—
to cultivate the heart to this extent is what may be called *emptiness* (虚).

Beyond mere satiation, though rare delicacies and sumptuous flavors
be displayed before him,
he fears only that they may not be swiftly cleared away—
this is why his belly craves only the real.

The *Classic* states: *"The Sage governs for the belly, not for the eyes."*

Weaken one’s resolve.
Those who strengthen themselves have resolve.
Now, why weaken it?
Strengthening oneself may advance one toward the Dao,
but weakening it may lead one to the state of daily diminishment.

Strengthen one’s bones.
The Dao of Lǎozǐ runs deep in the principle of *strong strength* (强强).
Thus it is said: *"The overbearing shall not meet their natural end."*
Now, why strengthen one’s bones?
It is a warning against the strong—
lest they contend with things.
Strengthening one’s bones is self-strengthening.
The Dao stands firm and unchanging—
how could the weak govern it?
Always keep the people without knowledge and without desire.

Lǎozǐ likened governing the state and the people
to cultivating oneself,
saying *"to make the people"* is to make oneself—
without knowledge and without desire,
not like the dullness of wood or stone that lacks all desire.
At first, one cannot lack knowledge entirely—
to remove knowledge until it is utterly gone;
at first, one cannot lack desire entirely—
to remove desire until it is utterly gone.
Then, who but a Daoist gentleman,
with his accumulated virtue,
could achieve this?

If the wise are allowed to appear,
then nothing shall remain ungoverned.
The Dao is natural—
how could it be shaped by intelligence?
Only by acting without action in non-action
may it be attained.

Chéng Tài’s words on governance say:
*"Not valuing the worthy brings the people to non-contention,
until the heart is undisturbed."*
If such a person is worthy,
yet he hides his excellence and does not display it,
flashing his brilliance before the world,
then surely there will be those who shame themselves
for not being equal to him
and who strive to contend with him.
Thus Zhuāngzǐ said: *"To elevate the worthy is to invite the people to jostle."*

To prize hard-to-obtain wealth
is to invite those who abandon their livelihoods
to chase profit,
and who do not hesitate to become thieves.
Thus it is said: *"Wealth accumulates, then contention arises."*
Contention and theft all stem from seeing what is desirable
and thus stirring the heart.
If the ruler conceals his likes and dislikes,
and does not reveal them,
then the people below have no direction for profit,
and all that is desirable no longer appears before them.
The heart remains undisturbed,
and contention and theft naturally cease.
This is the Dao of Lǎozǐ—
rectifying the root and clarifying the source.

Jiāng Yǔ’s exhortation on governance says:
*"Necessarily elevate those of public loyalty,
and let there be nothing private,
then who among the people would dare not to be orderly?"*
Jiāng Yǔ’s words,
though common among those who seek governance since Yáo and Shùn,
were criticized by Jìzhé, who said:
*"If you speak thus, it is only your own way of acting."*
The dangers of the high platform are many,
and those who would cast their lot there are numerous—
a criticism of displaying excellence openly,
as clear as the platform’s invitation to all,
so that they see what is desirable and flock to it,
and contention grows.

Yet, if the worthy are seen but not valued,
is this not a distinction?
It is only to obliterate traces
and thus extinguish contention.
All that Lǎozǐ’s teaching seeks to conceal and use subtly
holds this same intent.
*See* (见) is read as *manifest* (现)—
when the ruler steps forth and reveals himself.

Thus, the Sage’s governance reaches the point of strengthening one’s bones.
The mind is always present in thought,
and resolve is present when action is desired.
The belly is for nourishment,
and the bones are for bearing burdens.
Lǎozǐ’s text contains metaphor and direct speech—
here, the belly and bones
are indeed their true names.

In a later passage, it is said:
*"The people’s hunger comes from their rulers’ excessive taxation."*
This is the case where one should fill what is real
and dispel what is false.

Again it is said:
*"The people are difficult to govern because their cleverness is excessive."*
This is the warning against the strong
and the search for means to weaken them.

Gēngsāng’s dwelling feared collapse—
his clever ministers left him,
his compassionate concubines withdrew—
not allowing his heart to harbor cleverness or compassion,
this is the pursuit of emptiness.

To dwell with those who are bloated
and to appoint those who are clumsy—
bloated and clumsy are not those whose bones are strong
and can endure burdens,
yet they are not counted among the few.
This is why he established Gēngsāng’s principles,
mocking Yáo and Shùn’s elevation of the worthy
and appointment of the clever.

Always keep the people without knowledge and without desire.
If the people have knowledge, then their cleverness is excessive,
and this is why they are difficult to govern.
If they have desire, then they see what is desirable,
and this is why contention and theft arise.
Lǎozǐ values *non-action* (无为),
wishing to place the world in a state of *non-affairs* (无事),
and to make the world also content with *non-affairs*.
Zhuāngzǐ’s words on governance effects say:
*"To align with the lack of knowledge—
its virtue does not depart.
To align with the lack of desire—
this is called *primordial simplicity* (素朴)."*
In primordial simplicity, the nature of the world is attained.

If the wise are not allowed to act,
then they do not dare to act.
To make the people without knowledge and without desire
is to make them dull.
Yet among them are those who are obstinate and clever,
unreceptive to dullness—
these are the ones called *clever*.
The clever cannot be made dull again.

Thus, if all under heaven follow my teaching,
then they shall all be without knowledge and without desire.
Without knowledge and without desire,
they shall love their native soil and find joy in their work,
and cannot be lured into chaos.
Even if there are the clever,
knowing they have no one to join them,
they shall lose resolve and no longer dare to act.
Hence it is said:
*"Make the people value death over migration,
then even with armies and weapons,
there shall be no place to deploy them."*
The Sage who claims he can again bind the people with knots
achieves this through these very means.

Zhuāngzǐ took this language and entrusted it to antiquity,
saying:
*"The ancient people dwelled in the *chaotic undifferentiation* (混茫),
and with the world attained *tranquility* (澹漠)."*»

chunks.original_text: 当是时也，万物不伤，群生不夭，人虽有智，无所用之，正明此也。 为无为则无不治矣。 既曰无为矣，而又有夫为无为者焉，则岂委事功而不作也哉？ 以无为为居，而以无事行之，是之谓为无为也。 我以无为镇之，而下以无知无欲应之，所谓无为而民自化，无事而民自富者也，则安有不入於治也？ 詹秋圃曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 安民章所言，不欲尊尚贤人，使民不狂僭而争名。 不贵珍货奇宝，使民不为盗窃，不见可欲纷华盛丽，使心不生妄乱。 是以圣人治民，久欲与之相安，在我必虚其心，而去嗜欲，常使斯民无知无欲。 虽知亦不敢为，则为无为而无不治安矣。 张冲应曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 老子出乎上古，其风淳俗厚，人皆质朴，日以无为，名利俱忘，声色不作，五神不乱。 盖自上古降民改而皇，皇改而帝，帝改而王，官以鸟名，继以龙名，又继以王侯卿大夫，以美名之，则虚名日盛。 而世所尚者行权之贤，是以比干争而死，夷齐不能争而隐。 ，以激纷纭征战之苦，又自凿山耕海，钻石淘沙，良金美玉，惑之未已，奇珍怪宝，惑世愈甚。 世所贵者罕获难得之货，是以虞氏怀玉而丧国，石氏藏宝而丧家，以成灭身倾德之祸。 又自笙簧之淫声逆耳，子女之淫色迷目，异味逆口，异香逆鼻，异服逆身，神昏精乱，而以所欲之形状毕露。 是以商亡以长夜之饮，陈破以后庭之曲，以起弒逆暴乱之阶，皆此三者之故也。 故上古圣人所以治乎人者无他，不尚行权之贤，不贵难得之货，不纵可欲之惑，则上行之而下效之，斯无以动人心之争、之盗、之乱者矣。 故虚心下而不为，三者之所拘。 实腹运道而不为，三者之所耗。 弱其志而不尚、不贵、不欲，强其骨而常健常康常宁，人有以观我之无为，则自然无知无欲矣。 或有知者欲尚其贤、欲贵其货、欲华其五鬼心鼻口耳身欲，亦不敢为也。 故人皆为其所无为，而人无不治者矣。 张灵应曰：心不虚明，如何得其炁冲和以实其脏腹； 志不卑弱，如何得其精胶固以强其筋骨。 心常虚而炁不亏，志常弱而精不耗，这腹便充实，骨便坚强，更有何趋蹶梦遗之患。 大凡人一时趋蹶，皆炁不冲和中来； 寝梦遗失，皆精不胶固中出。 要皆炁不冲和，只是心不虚，精不胶固，只是志不弱。 白玉蟾曰：不尚贤，为子当孝，为臣当忠，使民不争，饱不思食。 不贵难得之货，黄金与土同价，使民不为盗，如意无他。 不见可欲，耳目之间，心实在焉，使心不乱，去即唤回。 是以圣人之治，虚其心。 实其腹。 弱其志。 强其骨。 常使民无知无欲。 使夫知者，不敢为也。 为无为。 则无不治矣。
chunks.translated_text:
At this very time, all things remain unharmed, all living beings do not perish young, and though people may have wisdom, they have no use for it—this is the very proof of it. To act through *non-action* (*wuwei*) is to ensure nothing remains untended.

Though it is said to act through *non-action*, this does not mean abandoning deeds entirely. Rather, to dwell in *non-action* and govern through *non-interference*, this is what is meant by *wuwei*. I govern through *non-action*, and the people respond with their own *wuwei*—this is what is called *"govern through non-action, and the people transform themselves; govern through non-interference, and the people prosper on their own."* How then could there be any failure to achieve order?

Zhān Qiúbù said: *"If one does not exalt the virtuous, the people will not contend for them, and thus nothing remains ungoverned."* The chapter *"Nurturing the People"* speaks of not desiring to honor the virtuous, so that the people do not grow reckless and contend for fame. Not valuing rare treasures and strange jewels, so that the people do not turn to theft. Not displaying alluring luxuries and dazzling beauties, so that the heart does not generate chaotic desires. Thus, the Sage who governs the people, wishing to dwell in harmony with them for long, must first empty his own heart and abandon his cravings, always keeping the people in a state of *wu zhi wu yu* [without knowledge, without desire]. Even if they are wise, they dare not act. Thus, through *non-action*, governance becomes effortless and stable.

Zhang Chong replied: *"If one does not exalt the virtuous, the people will not contend for them, and thus nothing remains ungoverned."* Laozi emerged from the ancient past, when customs were pure and people were simple. They lived daily in *wuwei*, forgetting fame and gain, abstaining from music and color, their five spirits unperturbed. From the ancient times onward, the people changed from *Huang* [Yellow Emperor], to *Shi* [Emperor], to *Di* [Emperor], to *Wang* [King], with officials named after birds, then dragons, then kings, nobles, ministers, and great officers—all adorned with grand titles. Thus, empty names flourished, and the world came to revere those who wielded power through cleverness. Hence, Bi Gan contended and died, while Yi and Qi could not contend and so withdrew. The suffering of endless wars and strife arose, and yet they dug mountains and plundered the sea, mined gold and sifted sand, seeking fine jade and precious stones—never satisfied. Strange treasures and marvelous jewels only deepened their delusion. The world treasured rare and difficult-to-obtain goods, so Yu’s clan perished for hoarding jade, and Shi’s family was ruined for hiding treasure—thus bringing ruin to themselves and their virtue.

Again, the licentious sounds of pipes and bells assailed the ears, the wanton allure of women dazzled the eyes, strange flavors offended the palate, strange scents assailed the nose, and strange garments offended the body—clouding the mind and scattering the spirit—while alluring forms were laid bare. Thus, Shang fell to its debauchery of nightlong drinking, and Chen was destroyed by its decadence in the rear chambers, giving rise to regicide, rebellion, and chaos—all from these three evils.

Thus, the Sages of antiquity governed the people with no other means: they did not exalt those who wielded power through cleverness, did not treasure rare and difficult-to-obtain goods, nor indulged the allurements of desire. When the ruler acted thus, the people followed suit, and there was nothing to stir the hearts of contention, theft, or rebellion.

Thus, when the heart is emptied and no action is taken, the three evils [contention, theft, rebellion] are restrained. When the belly is filled and the Dao is cultivated without action, the three evils are exhausted. When the will is weakened—neither exalting, nor treasuring, nor desiring—while the bones are strengthened to remain ever healthy, strong, and at peace, if people observe my *non-action*, they will naturally be without knowledge and without desire.

Should any wise person wish to exalt the virtuous, to treasure rare goods, or to indulge the five senses—eyes, ears, nose, mouth, and body—even they dare not act. Thus, all people act as if in *non-action*, and there is none who remains ungoverned.

Zhang Lingying said: If the heart is not emptied and clarified, how can the *qi* be harmonized and the organs filled? If the will is not humble and weak, how can the essence be solidified to strengthen the sinews and bones? When the heart is always empty, the *qi* is not depleted; when the will is always weak, the essence is not wasted. Then the belly is full, the bones are strong—what more could ail one with fears of *trendency* (*quju*) or *nocturnal emissions* (*mengyi*)?

Generally, when a man suffers from *trendency*, it arises from *qi* that is not harmonized; when he loses semen in dreams, it comes from essence that is not solidified. Both stem from *qi* not harmonized—because the heart is not emptied—and essence not solidified—because the will is not weakened.

Bái Yùqiān said: *"Not exalting the virtuous"* means that as a son, one must be filial; as a subject, one must be loyal—thus the people do not contend, and when full, they do not crave more food. *"Not treasuring rare goods"* means gold is valued no more than soil—thus the people do not steal, for there is nothing to desire. *"Not displaying alluring luxuries"* means the heart remains steadfast between the ears—thus the heart does not stray; when it does, it is called back. Therefore, the Sage’s governance lies in emptying the heart, filling the belly, weakening the will, and strengthening the bones—always keeping the people without knowledge and without desire. Even the wise dare not act. Thus, through *non-action*, nothing remains ungoverned.

chunks.original_text: 廖粹然曰：不尚贤，有道之士不务荣华。 使民不争，默识如愚，无争三昧。 不贵难得之货，观世财如灰尘，不贪而不欲，以内丹为至宝，自爱而不自贵，使民不为盗。 知是不欲不见可欲，外不着物，内不自见，使心不乱，同太虚空如如不动。 是以圣人之治，主上以道治国，吾亦以此修身。 虚其心，以虚为身，以无为心。 实其腹，神炁冲然，清浄自守，要将坎位中央画，点化离宫腹里阴。 弱其志，专炁至柔，顽然不动，强兵战胜，功成后霹雳，俄然出地雷。 强其骨，潜形於身而不出，藏神於心而不见，水火抽添丹就日，金筋玉骨自坚强。 常使民无知无欲，国安民富更无他，吾之子孙亦无事。 使夫知者。 省得此理，不敢为也。

Lào Cùirán said: *"Not exalting the virtuous"* means the Daoist scholar does not seek honor and wealth.

*"Make the people not contend"* means they remain silent and simple like the foolish, attaining the *Three Mysteries of Non-Contention*.*

*"Not treasuring rare goods"* means viewing worldly riches as mere dust, neither greedy nor desiring—treasuring the *Inner Elixir* as the supreme treasure, cherishing oneself without arrogance—thus the people do not steal.

*"Knowing this, yet not desiring what is not desired"* means the external self does not cling to things, while the internal self remains unseen, keeping the heart unmoved, like the *Great Void*—as still as the immovable.

Therefore, the Sage’s governance: the ruler governs the land with the Dao, and I cultivate my body with this principle.

*Empty the heart*—let emptiness be the body, let non-action be the heart.

*Fill the belly*—let the divine *qi* surge vigorously, guarding purity within, refining the *Kàn* position at the center, and alchemizing the *Lí* Palace’s inner yin.

*Weaken the will*—concentrate the *qi* to its utmost softness, motionless and tranquil, yet fierce in battle, victorious—then suddenly strike like thunder, erupting as the earth’s lightning.

*Strengthen the bones*—hide the form within the body, conceal the spirit within the heart; draw water and fire to nourish the elixir daily, so that *golden sinews* and *jade bones* grow naturally firm.

Always let the people be without knowledge and without desire—then the land is secure, the people prosper, and there is no other way. My descendants will also face no troubles.

Even the wise, *when they understand this truth*, dare not act.

Thus, through *non-action*, all is governed.

chunks.original_text: 何尝妄作为无为？ 道常自然，则无不治矣。 子能知一，万事毕也。 则岂不快哉？ 陈碧虚曰：不尚贤，使民不争。 夫人君之谦下雌静，不矜尚己之贤能，则民之从化如风靡草，柔逊是守，何有争乎？ 经曰：我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正。 又解曰：人君静，大臣明，刑不避贵，泽不隔下，贤不肖各当其分，则士无争矣。 若人君依违，大臣回佞，虽尚贤求士，则外忠内僻，情毒言和之才至，至则奸伪生而交争起。 严君平曰：盛德者为主，微劣者为臣。 贤者不万一，圣人不世出，夫天生之贤，匪由尚出也。 又曰：譬如使驽马驿骝并驰於夷道，鸿鹄鹑鴳双翼於青云，则贤不肖可知矣。 此乃自然，非由尚也。 故曰不尚贤，使民不争； 不贵难得之货，使民不为盗。 难得之货，谓金玉珠犀也。 言上化清静，民务耕织，藏金於山，捐珠於渊，不利货财，不近贵富，则民无贪盗之心矣。 又解曰：骊龙夜光之珠，金玉锦绣之玩，君王不贵，臣民无贪，盗贼於何而有？ 语曰：苟子之不欲，虽赏之不窃也。 《鸿烈解》引神农之法曰：丈夫力壮而不耕，天下有受其饥者； 妇人当年而不织，天下有受其寒者。 故身自耕妻自织，以为天下先。 其导民也，不贵难得之货矣，不见可欲使心不乱，可欲者，谓外物或情令人生可尚爱欲之心也。 而曰不见者，非远绝不见也，谓不以见为见，而为无为也。 若乃人君见外物而无可尚爱欲之心者，是不为色尘所染乱，则性原清静恬澹而复其真一矣。 人君能守乎真一，则使民心不乱，而淳朴之风可致矣。 严君平曰：世不尚贤则民不趋，不趋则不争，不争则不为乱。 世不贵货则民不欲，不欲则不求，不求则不为盗。 世绝三五则民无喜，无喜则无乐，无乐则不淫乱。 此自然之数也。 《鸿烈解》曰：令君子佩请饮楚庄王，庄王许之，子佩疏揖，北面立於殿下，曰：昔者君王许之，今不果往，意者臣有罪乎？ 庄王曰：吾闻子具於疆台。 疆台者，南望料山以临方皇，左江而右淮，其乐忘死。 若吾薄德之人，不可以当此乐也。 恐留而不能反，故曰不见可欲，使心不乱。 傅奕《音义》曰：古本作使民心不乱。 河上公、开元御本作使心不乱，亦通。 是以圣人之治虚其心。 大圣人之治，先治其身，然后及于家国也。 虚其心者，谓无邪思也，不役心逐境，泊然内寂，嗜欲顿消，神物自定，则其心虚矣。 庄子曰：虚室生白； 吉祥止止。 谓心虚则纯白自生，福庆留止也。 实其腹。 夫圣人道德内充，五神安静，憺泊自足，贪爱不生，故曰实其腹。 弱其志。 志者心之事，事在心曰志。 欲令举心行事，当守谦静柔弱，则道全矣。 强其骨。 骨者体之干。 夫淳和足则体润，精神壮则骨强，亦自然之理也。 常使民无知无欲。 圣人所以常修身虚心者，欲令百姓反朴守淳，悦然自化也。 语曰：苟正其身矣，於从政乎何有？ 使夫知者不敢为也。 民虽有贵尚之知、饰伪之迹者，然已被其清静之风、淳朴之化，而自灰心槁体，不敢与动有为之欲心也。 为无为则无不治矣。 为无为，犹言行无为之道也。 无为者，谓不越其性分也。 性分不越则天理自全，全则所为皆无为也。 物物无为，则贵尚贪求之心泯然都忘，故淳风大行，谁云不治？
chunks.translated_text:
How could *non-action* ever be mistaken for mere *inaction*? The Dao ever flows naturally—then nothing remains ungoverned.

If you grasp the One, all things are complete.
Then how could it not be joyous?

Chen Bi Xu said:
*"Do not exalt the worthy, and the people will not contend.*
For when the ruler is humble, yielding, and tranquil—
not boasting of his own virtue and ability—
the people follow his transformation like wind sweeping grass,
guarding with gentleness and submission—
what room is there for contention?

The Classic says:
*'I act with non-action, yet the people transform themselves;
I love tranquility, yet the people align themselves.'*

It is further explained:
*'When the ruler is tranquil, ministers are clear;
punishments do not spare the noble, blessings do not exclude the lowly;
the worthy and unworthy each fulfill their roles—
then the scholars will not contend.*

But if the ruler is indecisive, ministers flatter and deceive,
even if he exalts the worthy and seeks talent,
those with outward loyalty but inward deceit—
poisonous in intent yet harmonious in speech—
will arrive, and then deceit and strife will arise.

Yan Jun Ping said:
*'The virtuous rule as sovereigns, the lesser serve as ministers.
The worthy are not one in ten thousand, sages do not appear in every age.
The worthy are not produced by exaltation—
this is natural, not contrived.'*

He further said:
*'As if driving a poor horse and a fine steed together on a level road,
or letting a wild goose and a partridge fly side by side in the blue sky—
then the worthy and unworthy become apparent.*

This is natural, not the result of exaltation.
Thus it is said:
*"Do not exalt the worthy, and the people will not contend;
do not prize hard-to-obtain goods, and the people will not steal.*
Hard-to-obtain goods are gold, jade, pearls, and rhinoceros horn.
When the ruler’s transformation is pure and tranquil,
the people attend to farming and weaving,
burying gold in the mountains and casting pearls into the depths,
finding no profit in wealth or attraction in riches—
then the people’s hearts will harbor no greed or theft.

It is further explained:
*"The black dragon’s night-light pearl,
gold, jade, brocade, and embroidered adornments—
if the ruler does not prize them,
the subjects will not covet them,
then where would thieves and robbers arise?
The saying goes:
*'If a man does not desire it, even if rewarded, he will not steal.'*

*The Hong Lie Jie* cites the laws of Shennong:
*'If men of strength do not till the fields, there will be those who starve in the world;
if women of childbearing age do not weave, there will be those who freeze in the world.
Thus, let the ruler himself plow and his wife weave,
setting an example for the world.*

In guiding the people, he does not prize hard-to-obtain goods,
nor does he display desirable things to keep their hearts undisturbed.
Desirable things are those external objects or passions
that stir the heart to admiration or lust.
Yet *not seeing* does not mean banishing them from sight—
it means not letting them be seen as desirable,
but rather embracing *non-action* toward them.

If the ruler, seeing external things, harbors no admiration or lust,
then he is untouched by the defilements of form,
and his original purity—tranquil, serene, and restored to its true unity—
remains unshaken.

When the ruler guards this true unity,
the people’s hearts will not be disturbed,
and the wind of simplicity and sincerity will prevail.

Yan Jun Ping said:
*'If the age does not exalt the worthy, the people will not vie;
if they do not vie, they will not contend;
if they do not contend, there will be no disorder.
If the age does not prize wealth, the people will not desire;
if they do not desire, they will not seek;
if they do not seek, they will not steal.
If the age abandons the five flavors, the people will have no joy;
if they have no joy, they will have no pleasure;
if they have no pleasure, they will not indulge in licentiousness.
This is the natural order.'*

*The Hong Lie Jie* says:
*'When Zi Pei requested permission to drink with King Zhuang of Chu,
the king granted it. Zi Pei bowed and stood facing north in the hall,
saying: "Earlier, the king granted my request,
yet now you do not fulfill it—
have I committed some offense?"

The king replied: "I heard you were enjoying yourself at Jiang Tai.
Jiang Tai overlooks the mountains to the south,
commanding the vast lands, with the Yangtze to the left and the Huai to the right—
its pleasures make one forget death.
A man of my meager virtue cannot bear such joys.
I fear that if I stay, I will not return."
Thus it is said: *"Do not display desirable things, lest the heart be disturbed."*

Fu Yi’s *Yin Yi* says:
*"The ancient text reads: 'Make the people’s hearts undisturbed.'
The River Shore Master and Kai Yuan Imperial editions read: 'Make the heart undisturbed,' which is also acceptable."*

Thus, the Sage’s governance begins with emptying the heart.
The governance of the Great Sage first refines the self,
then extends to family and state.

To empty the heart is to banish all deceitful thoughts,
not to let the mind chase after external things,
but to remain inwardly still—
where desires vanish, the spirit settles naturally,
and the heart becomes empty.

Zhuangzi said:
*"In an empty chamber, purity arises;
auspicious omens linger."*

This means that when the heart is empty, pristine whiteness emerges,
and blessings take root.

To fill the belly:
The Sage’s virtue and power are internally abundant,
the five spirits tranquil,
contentment effortless and self-sufficient,
with no room for greed or love—
thus it is said: *"Fill the belly."*

To weaken the will:
The will is the mind’s affair—
when the mind acts, it is called will.
To ensure that every thought and deed
adheres to humility, tranquility, gentleness, and weakness—
then the Dao is preserved.

To strengthen the bones:
The bones are the body’s framework.
When harmony and sufficiency are complete,
the body is nourished, and the spirit robust—
then the bones naturally grow strong.

Always let the people be without knowledge and without desire:
The Sage’s constant cultivation of the self and emptying of the heart
is to restore the people to simplicity and sincerity,
so they transform joyfully of their own accord.

The saying goes:
*"If one first rectifies himself,
what difficulty is there in governance?"*

Though the learned may possess knowledge of exaltation
or feign deceitful appearances,
once they are touched by the wind of tranquility and simplicity,
their hearts grow dull, their bodies wither—
they dare not stir their restless, desiring minds.

To act with *non-action* is to govern without fail.
To act with *non-action* is to walk the Dao of *non-action*.
*Non-action* means not overstepping one’s nature.
When nature is not overstepped, the natural order is complete—
and when complete, all actions are *non-action*.

If all things act with *non-action*,
then the hearts of exaltation, prizing, and greed
are naturally extinguished,
and the great wind of simplicity prevails—
who would say governance fails?"

chunks.original_text: 谢图南曰：不尚贤至使心不乱。 任贤使能，人君当然之事，但不当有好尚之名。 好尚之名立，则小人将假托贤者之名以争之矣。 难得之货物之无益，而反贵之重之，无好下甚，则有盗思夺之者矣。 可欲之境事之无补，而耳目与接，反动其心，则将有变乱其所为者矣。 在上意向，岂可不谨。 是以圣人至其骨。 虚其心则不使人欲入於内，实其腹则不使天理馁於中，弱其志则意向不流於骄伏，强其骨则躬行不惮於勤劳。 此所以为圣人之治。 常使民至不治矣。 欲生於知，无知则无欲矣。 故上以无知无欲化，则下以无知无欲应。 或未能使之无知，而其间有矜知逞能者，亦必阴消潜化，而俾之退听於不敢为之地。 此所谓知者，乃私心血气之知，非良知也。 若使敢为，必至害治。 故在上者为之以无为，则在下者无不治矣。 盖尝论之，民之於上不从其令，而从其所好，意向之不谨，则视仪听唱必有甚者。 古之圣人诚意以正心，正心以修身，修身以治国、平天下，精神念虑密运於一堂之上，而风声气习奔走於四方万里之远，应感一机不疾而速。 后世人主穷情极欲，靡所不为，而反归咎於天下之难化，人情之难驯。 吁，亦惑矣。 林庸斋曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 尚，矜也。 我以贤为矜尚，则必起天下之争。 禹惟不矜，天下莫与汝争能。 便是此意。 我以宝货为贵，则人必皆有欲得之心，其弊将至於为盗。 此二句发下面可欲之意也。 人惟不见其所可欲，则其心自定。 不见可欲，使心不乱。 此八字最好。 虚其心，无思慕也。 实其腹，饱思食也。 弱其志，不趋竞也。 强其骨，养其力也。 言太古圣人但使民饱於食寸，无他思慕，力皆壮而无所趋竞，故其民纯朴而无所知无所欲，虽其间有机巧之心者，所知虽萌於心，而亦不敢有作为也。 圣人之治天下也如此，而圣人於世亦无所容心。 其为治也，皆以无为为之，所以无不治也。 不见可欲，使心不乱。 言圣人之教其民如此。 使者，使其民也。 不尚贤，不贵难得之货，皆恐有以动其欲心也。 动其欲亦不止此二事，但以二者言之耳。 老子愤末世之纷纷，故思太古之无事。 其言未免太过，所以不及吾圣人也。 范应元曰：不尚贤，使民不争。 尚，好也。 贤，能也。 又《说文》多才也。 争，竞也，谓偏尚才能之人，则民必竞习才能以争功名，而不反求自然之道也。 且小才小能可用於人而不可用人，务才而不务德，非君子也。 人君不偏尚小才小能之人，而民自不争。 不贵难得之货，使民不为盗。 难得之货谓金玉之类，傥贵之则民爱其物，而患其无，以至为盗。 是以圣人之治至强其骨。 治理也，理身以理天下也，上无贵尚则民不妄想，人欲去也，兹不亦虚其心乎？ 上怀道德则民抱质朴，天理存也。 兹不亦实其腹乎？ 上守柔和则民化，而相让气不暴也，兹不亦弱其志乎？ 上无嗜欲则民化，而自壮体常健也，兹不亦强其骨乎？ 能如是则可使民无知无欲也。 此四句有专就修养上解者，然前后文皆有正己化民之意。 常使民无知至不敢为也。 盖民知贵尚、见可欲，则有争有食而为乱，故常宜使之无妄知无妄欲，而使夫智巧之人不敢妄为也。 为无为则无不治矣。 圣人无贵尚之述，而不见可欲，循自然之理以应事物，莫不有当行之路，则为出於无为也。
chunks.translated_text:
「When Xie Tunan said: *"If one does not exalt the worthy, the hearts of the people will not be disturbed."*

For a ruler to employ the worthy and utilize their abilities is a natural duty, but he must not establish the name of exaltation. Once the name of exaltation is set, then the petty will seize upon it to claim the title for themselves. If one prizes and honors things of rare value that bring no benefit, then those who covet what is difficult to obtain will inevitably think of stealing and taking by force. If one exposes the senses to what is merely desirable yet unprofitable, it will stir the heart and lead to those who seek to disrupt what is done.

The ruler’s intentions must be cautious indeed. Therefore, the sage acts with utmost sincerity—
to empty the heart is to prevent desires from entering within,
to fill the belly is to ensure that the Dao’s nourishment does not fail within,
to weaken the will is to let intentions not stray into arrogance or submission,
to strengthen the bones is to cultivate vigor without weariness in labor.
Thus does the sage govern—
ever making the people reach the state of *non-treatment*.

Desires arise from knowledge;
without knowledge, there are no desires.
If the ruler transforms with *non-knowledge* and *non-desire*,
then the people respond with *non-knowledge* and *non-desire*.
Even if he cannot make them utterly free of knowledge,
those among them who boast of cleverness and display ability
will still be subtly diminished and transformed,
until they retreat to the point where they dare not act.
This so-called "knowledge" is but the private scheming of blood and *qi*—
not the true *virtue* of the heart.

If they dare to act, it will surely harm governance.
Therefore, when the ruler governs with *non-action*,
there is nothing the people cannot be brought to *non-treatment*.

Indeed, the people follow not the ruler’s commands,
but his inclinations.
If his intentions are not cautious,
then his words and deeds will inevitably invite excess.
The sages of old sincerely cultivated their intentions to rectify their hearts,
rectified their hearts to cultivate their persons,
cultivated their persons to govern the state and pacify the world—
their spirit and thought concentrated in one hall,
while their moral influence spread far and wide across the ten thousand *li*,
responding to the slightest movement without delay.
Later rulers, however, exhausted their emotions and indulged their desires,
doing whatever they pleased,
and yet blamed the world for its difficulty to transform,
and the people for their stubbornness.
Alas, how confused they were!

Lin Yongqing said: *"If one does not exalt the worthy, the people will not vie—
then there will be nothing that is not governed."*

*Exaltation* means *boasting*.
If I boast of the worthy, then I will surely arouse contention throughout the world.
Yu alone did not boast, and thus none could vie with him in ability.
This is the meaning.

If I prize rare treasures,
then all will have desires to obtain them,
and the consequence will be theft.
These two lines reveal the intent of what follows:
*"If one does not see what is desirable, then the heart naturally settles.
Not seeing what is desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed."*
These eight characters are most excellent.

To empty the heart is to have no thoughts of admiration.
To fill the belly is to satisfy hunger for food.
To weaken the will is to avoid striving for competition.
To strengthen the bones is to nourish one’s vitality.
It speaks of the sages of antiquity,
who merely ensured the people were well-fed,
with no other thoughts of admiration,
and whose strength was robust yet unspent in competition—
thus their people were pure and simple,
without knowledge or desire,
though cleverness might occasionally stir within them,
their knowledge, though sprouting in the heart,
would not dare to manifest in action.

The sage’s governance of the world was thus,
and yet the sage himself had no place in the world for his heart.
In his governance, he acted entirely with *non-action*,
and thus there was nothing that was not governed.
*"Not seeing what is desirable prevents the heart from being disturbed."*
This describes how the sage taught his people.

*To employ* means to guide the people.
Not exalting the worthy,
not honoring rare treasures—
all these stem from fear of stirring desires.
Stirring desires is not limited to these two matters;
they are merely stated as examples.

Laozi lamented the confusion of the later ages,
and thus pondered the simplicity of antiquity.
His words, however, were somewhat excessive,
and thus did not fully capture the sage’s Way.

Fan Yingyuan said: *"Not exalting the worthy prevents the people from vying.*
*Exaltation* means *preference*.
The worthy are those with *ability*.
Again, according to the *Shuo Wen* ["Explanations of Texts"], they are those with *many talents*.
*Vying* means *competition*—
if one favors those with slight talents and abilities,
then the people will compete to cultivate these talents and abilities,
and not seek the natural Way.

Moreover, slight talents and abilities can be used by others,
but those with slight talents and abilities cannot be relied upon to use others.
To strive for talent while neglecting *virtue* is not the conduct of a gentleman.
If the ruler does not favor those with slight talents and abilities,
then the people will not vie.

Not honoring rare treasures prevents the people from becoming thieves.
Rare treasures refer to gold and jade—
if one honors them, then the people will love the objects
and suffer from their lack,
leading them to theft.

Therefore, the sage’s governance reaches its peak in strengthening the bones.
*Governance* means *order*—
ordering oneself to order the world.
If the ruler has no exaltation,
then the people will not indulge in vain imaginings—
desires are removed,
is this not also emptying the heart?

If the ruler cherishes *Dao* and *virtue*,
then the people will embrace simplicity—
the natural order is preserved.
Is this not also filling the belly?

If the ruler maintains gentleness and harmony,
then the people will be transformed,
and their *qi* will not be violent—
is this not also weakening the will?

If the ruler has no fondness for desires,
then the people will be transformed,
and their bodies will naturally be robust and healthy—
is this not also strengthening the bones?

If one can achieve this,
then one can make the people without knowledge or desire.
These four lines have those who interpret them solely in terms of personal cultivation,
yet the text before and after clearly conveys the idea of rectifying oneself and transforming the people.

Ever making the people without knowledge—
then they dare not act.
For the people, when they know of exaltation,
when they see what is desirable,
they will vie and steal,
and bring chaos.
Therefore, one must always guide them to have no false knowledge or false desires,
and prevent clever and cunning men from acting presumptuously.

To govern with *non-action* is to have nothing that is not governed.
The sage has no words of exaltation,
yet the people do not see what is desirable—
following the natural order in responding to things,
there is always a proper path to take,
and thus it is *non-action* that prevails.»

To act with *non-action* is to walk the Dao of *non-action*.
*Non-action* means not overstepping one’s nature.

chunks.original_text: 为出於无为，则事无不成，物无不和，乃无不为矣。 薛庸斋曰：不尚贤使民不争至使心不乱。 不尚世俗之贤，则民不致争矣。 不贵难得之货，则民不为盗矣。 不见可欲之事，则使心不乱矣。 是以圣人之治至强其骨。 圣人治国犹治身，虚其心则德大有容矣，实其腹则境土不贪矣，弱其志则治道尚柔矣，强其骨则股肱不惰矣。 常使民无知无欲至则无不治矣。 同乎无知，其德不离，同乎无欲，是谓素朴。 能使民若此，虽有智者不敢为也。 夫无欲而天下足，无为而万物化，渊静而百姓安，非无为之治乎？ 休休庵曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 抱道行不言之教者，中虚外顺，无所好恶，是以不尚贤，不贵难得之货。 有所好尚者，情识使然也，未免使人生能所生、贪求或争功、或为盗。 进道育德者又当一念不生，致于虚极，微妙玄通，然后自已。 灵明不亦贵重，若有可爱可欲之念，则忘情作，惑乱真心矣。 是以圣人修身齐家、治国平天下，虚其心，无我而量宽，其无为而物自化。 以道为怀，实其腹也。 弘无诤之德，弱其志也。 力行此道，强其骨也。 能如是者，使其识灭而无所知情亡。 褚伯秀曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 古人所宝性贤，见贤思齐。 此云不尚何耶？ 为时人多尚己贤以启争，嫉乱所由生，惟其不尚己贤，斯能识天下真贤。 非谓弃贤於野，而不用也。 世道交丧，所谓贤者未必真，尚者未必诚。 君衒求贤之名，士负自贤之志，以诈逆诈沦胥于恶，而贤为虚器矣，於家国乎何济？ 训以不尚己贤，是澄清源流，而开四海来贤之路也。 货之於天下贸迁有无，以给民用。 此云不贵者，特谓难得之珍奇，寸珠尺璧，南金大贝，声色禽兽，玩好之物，无益於家国，无补於饥寒，上好下承，残暴以取，鼓动天下之贪心，上下相交盗矣。 若夫流行泉布、丝麻粟帛，民资以生养者，未尝一日废，是谓不贵异物贱用物，适宜利用，家给户足，亦何盗之有？ 后世贪奢败度，利欲蚀心，天下滔滔，如出一律，惟学而知道，界限分明，必不至越分，苟求玩物丧志。 食取充饥，衣务适体，室庐蔽风，两吉凶称有无，所享有限，所求易足，心无企羡，何所动乱哉？ 上不尚贤，则下不争名。 上不贵货，则下不争利。 上不见可欲，使民心不乱。 是皆原於心虚不受物，故可欲无自入焉。 心虚则元神居，腹实则元气聚。 志好强而使之弱，所以召和。 骨任劳而使之强，所以有立。 虚心弱志，使民无知。 实腹强骨，使民无欲。 则虽有知者，亦不敢以有为干上之无为。 在上能主无为之道，行其所无事，则天下事无不可为者。 末句古本作无不为矣。 义长於治。 牛妙传曰：不尚贤，使民不争。 夫贤者明敏聪慧，才能也。 不尚者，不自矜尚，谦辞也。 既谦则光矣，天下何争之有哉？ 是故君子不自大其事，不自尚其功，让於贤，卑己以尊人。 盖自卑则民敬尊之。 先儒有言曰：我贤能矣，贤能於我何有哉？ 我崇高矣，崇高於我何有哉？ 我尊於人矣，而我宁自尊哉？ 苟於此振而矜之，则我之不贤矣。 若我之不贤，则人将拒我，非争而何耶？ 此不尚贤使民不争之说也。 不贵难得之货，使民不为盗。 如夜光之珠、明月之璧，斯可谓难得之货也。
chunks.translated_text:
For the Way to emerge from *non-action*,
then all undertakings are accomplished,
all things fall into harmony,
and thus nothing remains undone.

Xue Yongzai said:
*"To not exalt the worthy makes the people not contend—*
*then their hearts are not disordered.*
*To not exalt the worldly worthy,*
*then the people will not contend.*
*To not prize rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,*
*then the people will not steal.*
*To not display what is desirable,*
*then the hearts of the people will not be disordered.*
Thus, the sage’s governance is to fortify their resolve—
*to govern the state is like governing oneself.*

*Empty their hearts,*
*then their virtue has ample capacity.*
*Fill their bellies,*
*then they will not covet lands.*
*Weaken their wills,*
*then the Way of governance remains gentle.*
*Strengthen their bones,*
*then their limbs will not grow slack.*

*Always make the people without knowledge and without desire—*
*then nothing will remain ungoverned.*
*In accord with ignorance,*
*their virtue does not stray.*
*In accord with desirelessness,*
*this is called natural simplicity.*

If one can make the people thus,
even the wise will not dare to act presumptuously.

*Without desire, the world is sufficient.*
*Without action, all things transform.*
*Depth and stillness bring the people peace—*
is this not the governance of *non-action*?

Xiu Xiu An said:
*"To not exalt the worthy makes the people not contend—*
*then nothing will remain ungoverned.*

Those who embrace the Way and practice the teaching of *non-speech*,
*are internally empty and externally compliant,*
*without likes or dislikes,*
*thus they do not exalt the worthy,*
*nor prize rare and difficult-to-obtain goods.*

If one has likes or exalts,
*it is due to emotions and perceptions,*
*and one cannot avoid*
*giving rise to ability,*
*to greedy pursuit,*
*or to contention for merit,*
*or to theft.*

For those advancing the Way and nurturing virtue,
*they must first let no thought arise,*
*reach the state of utmost emptiness,*
*refined subtlety and mysterious penetration,*
*and then attain self-cultivation.*

*Is not the spirit of clarity precious?*
If there are thoughts of love or desire,
*then emotions will be stirred,*
*and the true heart will be confused.*

Thus, the sage cultivates oneself, harmonizes the family,
governs the state, and brings peace to the world—
*emptying their heart,*
*without self, their measure is vast,*
*their governance is *non-action*, yet all things transform naturally.*

*To hold the Way in one’s bosom,*
*is to fill their belly.*
*To expand the virtue of non-contentiousness,*
*is to weaken their will.*
*To vigorously practice this Way,*
*is to strengthen their bones.*

If one can do this,
*they extinguish perception and have no knowledge,*
*and emotions are annihilated.*

Zhu Boqiu said:
*"To not exalt the worthy makes the people not contend—*
*then nothing will remain ungoverned.*

The ancients treasured innate worthiness,
seeing the worthy and striving to emulate them.
But here it says ‘not exalt’—what does this mean?
*For those of this age,*
*many exalt their own worthiness,*
*thus stirring contention,*
*and jealousy arises from disorder.*
*Only by not exalting one’s own worthiness*
*can one recognize the true worthy of the world.*

It does not mean to abandon the worthy in the wild,
*nor to not employ them.*
*In times of moral decay,*
*so-called worthy ones are not necessarily true,*
*and those who are exalted are not necessarily sincere.*
*The ruler feigns seeking worthy men,*
*the scholars bear the ambition of their own worthiness,*
*with deceit meeting deceit,*
*all sink into vice,*
*and worthiness becomes an empty title—*
*how can it benefit the family and state?*

To teach ‘not to exalt one’s own worthiness’
*is to clarify the source and open the path*
*for the four seas’ worthy to come.*

*Goods circulate in the world,*
*abundant or scarce,*
*to provide for the people’s use.*
*Here, ‘not to prize’ refers*
*specifically to rare and costly treasures—*
*inch-long pearls, foot-wide jade,*
*southern gold, great cowries,*
*beautiful sounds and beasts,*
*and objects of indulgence,*
*which bring no benefit to the family and state,*
*no relief to hunger and cold.*
*If the ruler takes them,*
*the people below will follow,*
*leading to violence and theft,*
*and the world’s hearts will be stirred by greed,*
*with theft spreading between ruler and people.*

But as for flowing circulation,
*like water and grain,*
*silk, hemp, rice, and cloth—*
*the people rely on these for life and sustenance.*
*They are never neglected,*
*thus it is said:*
*‘Not to prize rare goods,*
*but to value useful ones,*
*to appropriately employ and utilize,*
*ensuring abundance in homes—*
*then where is the theft to come from?’*

In later ages, greed and extravagance ruined standards,
*while lustful desires eroded the heart.*
*The world was in chaos,*
*all alike in one pattern.*
*Only those who study and know the Way*
*have clear boundaries,*
*and will not overstep them.*
*If one seeks indulgence and loses resolve,*
*then food is taken merely to fill hunger,*
*clothing is worn only for warmth,*
*homes shelter against wind,*
*and the two blessings of joy and fortune*
*are measured by abundance or scarcity.*
*What they enjoy is limited,*
*what they seek is easily satisfied,*
*their hearts harbor no covetousness—*
*what can stir disorder in them?*

*The ruler does not exalt the worthy,*
*then the people below do not contend for renown.*
*The ruler does not prize goods,*
*then the people below do not contend for profit.*
*The ruler does not display what is desirable,*
*then the hearts of the people are not disordered.*

All this stems from *emptying the heart,*
*so it does not receive external things,*
*and thus what is desirable finds no entry.*

*Empty the heart,*
*then the original spirit dwells.*
*Fill the belly,*
*then the original qi gathers.*

*To strengthen their resolve while weakening their will,*
*is the means to invite harmony.*
*To strengthen their bones while letting them bear labor,*
*is the means to stand firm.*

*Empty the heart and weaken the will,*
*to make the people without knowledge.*
*Fill the belly and strengthen the bones,*
*to make the people without desire.*

Then even if there are those with knowledge,
*they will not dare to intrude*
*with their own actions*
*upon the ruler’s *non-action*.*

*If the ruler can uphold the Way of *non-action*,*
*practice what they have no need to do,*
*then all undertakings in the world*
*are without fail.*

*The final sentence in the ancient text reads:*
*‘nothing remains undone.’*
*Its meaning extends beyond mere governance.*
*Niu Miaozhuan said:*

*"To not exalt the worthy,*
*to make the people not contend.*
*The worthy are bright, sensitive, and wise—*
*their talents and abilities.*
*‘Not to exalt’ means*
*not to boast of oneself,*
*a humble phrase.*
*If one is humble,*
*then they shine.*
*Why would the people contend?*

Thus, the gentleman does not magnify their own deeds,
nor exalt their own merits,
*yielding to the worthy,*
*lowering themselves to honor others.*
*If one lowers themselves,*
*then the people will respect and honor them.*

The earlier scholars said:
*"I am worthy and capable—*
*what worthiness or capability do I have beyond myself?*
*I am exalted—*
*what exaltation do I have beyond myself?*
*I am honored above others—*
*yet why should I honor myself?*
*If I boast of this,*
*then I am not worthy.*
*If I am not worthy,*
*then people will reject me—*
*is this not contention?"*

This is the saying of *"to not exalt the worthy, making the people not contend."*

*"To not prize rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,*
*to make the people not steal.*
*Like the night-light pearl,*
*or the moonlit jade—*
*these are indeed rare and difficult-to-obtain goods."*

chunks.original_text: 苟子之不欲，虽赏之不窃，天下何盗之有耶？ 故儒有不宝金玉而忠信以为宝者。 昔宋人以玉遗子罕，子罕曰：我以不贪为宝，子以玉为宝。 以与我皆丧宝也。 却而不受。 此可谓不贵难得之货之说也。 庄子曰：绝圣弃智，大盗巧止。 擿玉毁珠，小盗不起。 此非使民不为盗之谓欤？ 不见可欲，使心不乱。 夫心者一身之主也，欲者意之所迁也。 大凡目有所见则必心有所思，心有所思则必意有所为，意有所为则是之谓欲也。 夫欲之所蔽心而得而清矣，岂不乱耶？ 《乐记》云：人生而静，天之性也。 感於物而动，性之欲也。 故大修行人常谨外视，使不见可欲之事，则自然身心清静，烦恼不侵，毋致於乱也。 孟子亦曰：养心莫善於寡欲。 此之谓也。 是以圣人之治虚其心。 圣人者，渊懿聪明者也。 其能继天体道，故常虚其心也。 所谓虚心者，遣其实也。 盖天下无心外之理，而圣人有穷理之心。 凡天下之理，皆吾心之所有也。 惟虚以养之，使无一毫私意挠乎其间，则天地之奥皆可以察之也。 老君曰：身之虚而万物至，心之无而和气归。 此圣人治身虚心之义也。 实其腹。 夫实腹者，非饱膏粱，充实其五脏也，谓积精累气以成其真也。 是以圣人故常尊其气，贵其形，宝其命，爱其神，使真境长守，生气有精，九户不塞，体得生神，此圣人之治也。 老君曰：我命在我，不属天地。 我不视不听，使神不出身，与道同久。 吾与天地分，一气而治，自守根本。 夫根本者，即神气精之说，实其腹之谓也。 弱其志。 弱者，谓持也。 志者，气之帅也。 气，体之充也。 今夫蹶者趋者，是气也。 善存养者，常於平旦未与物接之时，其气清明之际，常持其志，无暴其气，使浩然充塞，不致梏亡。 则庶几三百六十骨节之间，无诸滞碍也。 孟子曰：苟得其养，无物不长。 苟失其养，无物不消。 孔子曰：操则存，舍则亡。 出入无时，莫知其乡，惟心之谓欤。 此弱其志之说也。 强其骨。 夫强其骨者，谓握固趺足，升腰凸胸，此修行之道也。 盖圣人之治，先虚心以造其理，又实腹以固其精，复弱志以存其气，令强其骨以行其道。 然夫强其骨之道可无说耶？ 盖大修行人行功既毕，乃退火抽铅，使元气自尾闾夹脊上关透入泥丸，气化为津，从上腭出，满口含津，几三叩齿，分为三咽，以意送之，丹田复以周天火候养之，是名玉液还丹。 此则强其骨之说也。 常使民无知无欲。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Master Mencius** said: *"If one does not covet, even if rewarded, they will not steal—how then could there be thieves in the world?"* Thus, the **Rujia** treasure not gold and jade but take **loyalty and trustworthiness** as their treasure.

In ancient times, a **Song man** presented a jade to **Zi Han**, who said: *"I take ‘not being greedy’ as my treasure, while you take jade as yours. If we exchange, both of us lose our treasures."* He declined and did not accept it. This is truly the saying of *"not prizing rare and difficult-to-obtain goods."*

**Zhuangzi** said: *"Abandon the sage’s wisdom, and great thieves will cease their craft. Shatter jade and destroy pearls, and petty thieves will not rise."* Is this not the meaning of *"making the people not steal"*?

*Not seeing what is desirable* prevents the heart from being disordered.
The heart is the sovereign of the body, and desire is where the mind wanders.
Generally, when the eyes see something, the heart must ponder it;
when the heart ponders, the mind must act;
when the mind acts, that is called desire.
When desire obscures the heart, clarity is lost—how could it not be disordered?

The *Record of Music* states:
*"Man is born tranquil—this is Heaven’s nature.
When stirred by things, he moves—this is the nature of desire."*
Thus, those who practice greatly must always be cautious in their outward gaze,
so as not to see desirable things,
then naturally the body and mind will be serene,
free from vexation and untroubled.
This is called *"not seeing what is desirable."*

**Mencius** also said: *"Nothing nourishes the heart better than few desires."*
This is the same meaning.

Therefore, the **Sage’s governance** lies in keeping the heart empty.
The Sage is one of profound virtue, wisdom, and clarity.
Because they follow Heaven and embody the **Dao/Way**, they always keep their heart empty.
What is meant by *"empty heart"* is to discard the false.
For there is no principle outside the heart,
yet the Sage possesses a heart that exhausts principle.
All principles under Heaven are what the heart contains.
Only by keeping it empty can they be nurtured,
so that no private intention obstructs them,
then the mysteries of Heaven and Earth can all be discerned.

**Laozi** said:
*"When the body is empty, all things come.
When the heart is without, harmonious qi returns."*
This is the meaning of the Sage’s cultivation—
emptying the heart and governing the body.

**Filling the abdomen.**
By *"filling the abdomen,"* it is not meant to gorge on rich foods
and stuff the five viscera,
but to accumulate essence and gather qi to form the **True Self**.
Thus, the Sage always honors their **qi**, values their form,
treasures their life, and cherishes their spirit,
so that the **True Self’s realm** is long preserved,
vital energy is refined,
the nine orifices are unobstructed,
and the body attains **born-again spirit**—
this is the Sage’s governance.

**Laozi** said:
*"My life is in myself, not given by Heaven and Earth.
I neither see nor hear,
so my spirit does not leave the body,
and I endure with the Dao.
I divide with Heaven and Earth,
governing with one breath,
preserving my root foundation."*
The **root foundation** refers to the doctrine of **spirit, qi, and essence**—
this is the meaning of *"filling the abdomen."*

**Weakening the will.**
*"Weakening"* means *"holding firm."*
The **will** is the leader of **qi**,
and **qi** is what fills the body.
Now, those who stumble or rush—
this is **qi**.
Those who practice well
must, at dawn before engaging with things,
when **qi** is clear and bright,
constantly hold their will,
not exhausting their **qi**,
so that it becomes vast and unobstructed,
not leading to stagnation or loss.
Then, perhaps, within the three hundred sixty bones,
there will be no blockages.

**Mencius** said: *"If nourishment is obtained, nothing fails to grow.
If nourishment is lost, nothing fails to wither."*
**Confucius** said: *"Hold fast, and it remains; release, and it perishes.
Its coming and going have no fixed time—
who knows its direction?
Only the heart is like this."*
This is the saying of *"weakening the will."*

**Strengthening the bones.**
By *"strengthening the bones,"* it is meant to grasp firmly, steady the feet,
raise the waist and arch the chest—
this is the path of cultivation.
For the Sage’s governance
first empties the heart to establish principle,
then fills the abdomen to solidify essence,
weakens the will to preserve **qi**,
and strengthens the bones to walk the **Dao**.

Yet, is there no explanation for the way of *"strengthening the bones"*?
When great practitioners complete their work,
they then withdraw fire and extract lead,
allowing the **Original Qi** to ascend from the **Tailbone** along the **Spinal Column** and **Upper Gate** into the **Mud Ball**,
where **qi** transforms into **saliva**,
which is then drawn from the upper palate,
held in the mouth,
swallowed three times after gently tapping the teeth,
and directed with intent to the **Elixir Field**,
where it is further nurtured by the **Fire and Water** cycles—
this is called *"Jade-Liquid Reverted Elixir."*
This is the meaning of *"strengthening the bones."*

Always let the people be without knowledge and without desire.

chunks.original_text: 无知者淳也，无欲者朴也，淳朴者无为也。 常使民者，谓圣人先能服行，然后使民无知无欲，淳朴无为也。 盖以其昭昭，方可使民昭昭也。 如玄古之君，天下无为也，盖上无为，则下亦无为也。 君犹风也，民犹草也。 草上之风不偃，天下无之然。 夫无知之俗、淳朴之风，玄古至德之世是也。 庄子曰：至德之世不尚贤、不使能，上如标枝，民如野鹿，端直而不知以为仁，相爱而不知以为义，实而不知以为忠，当而不知以为信，蠢动而相使不以为赐。 是故行而无进，事而无传，孝子不谀其亲，忠臣不谄其君，此可谓淳朴之俗也。 然则先自上以风化下，故云常使民无知无欲也。 使夫知者不敢为也。 谓上古之世风淳，无君臣、父子、夫妇三纲之可知，无仁义礼智信五常之可见，同焉皆得，而不知所以得，诱然皆生，而不知所以生，同与禽兽居，族与万物并，恶知其君子小人哉？ 同乎无知，其德不离，同乎无欲，是谓素朴，而民得性矣。 设使淳散朴之人，特达聪明之士，虽有其知，无所用矣。 故曰使夫知者不敢为也。 为无为则无不治矣。 夫帝王之德，以天地为宗，以道德为主，以无为为常。 无为也，则用天下而有余。 有为也，则为天下用而不足。 无为者，天地之平，道德之至也，明此而南面，尧之为君也。 明此而北面，舜之为臣也。 以此而处上，则帝王天子之德也。 以此而处下，玄素圣王之道也。 以此而退居闲游，江海山林之士服； 以此而进为抚世，则功大名显而天下一。 故云为无为，则无不治矣。 杨智仁曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 不尚贤者，富贵非所欲，爵禄非我有，上不朝天子，下不谒公卿，如是有不争之德。 不贵难得之货者，奇珍异宝，良金美玉皆外物耳。 我心坦然，民心怡怡，外不见欲，内心不乱。 盖明了之人见亦非见，纵横自在。 古云：我若无心於万物，不妨万物常围这。 圣人之行，虚其心而不挂一物，实其腹而养乎至精，弱其志而常处谦和，强其骨而养吾浩然。 我心淳淳，民心朴朴，无欲无知，使夫知者不敢为也。 无为而无不为，则无不治矣。 《书》曰颜子罢肢体，黜聪明，离形去智，不尚贤也。 草食瓢饮，在陋巷，人不堪其忧，回也不改其乐。 不贵难得之货不为盗，不见欲心不乱是矣。 颐以养正，谦； 卑而尊，此圣人虚心实腹，弱志强骨，无知无欲，无为而无不治矣。 喻清中曰：不尚贤使民不争至则无不治矣。 不尚贤使民不争，即汝惟不矜，天下莫与汝争能之意也。 不贵难得之货，使民不为盗。 即苟子之不欲，虽赏之不窃之意也。 不见可欲使心不乱，此一语乃太上教人最吃紧处。 子贡出见纷华盛丽而悦，见可欲而心乱也，入闻夫子之道而乐，不见可欲而心不乱也。 达磨少林而面壁九年，亦是此意。 贤训如我独贤劳之贤，大抵事事有求胜之心，皆谓之贤，如好大喜功，穷兵黩武，每每欲加於前人，非特矜尚智力而已。 汉文慕黄老之清静，卑辞厚礼，和亲远人，而曰朕高皇帝侧室之子，不尚贤也。 齐高帝曰：使我治天下十年，当使黄金与土同价。 不贵难得之货也。 大抵好色，人之所欲也。 富贵，亦人之所欲也。 犬马声色，子女玉帛，峻宇雕墙，皆足以启人之欲心，惟目无所睹于外，则心自不摇于中。
chunks.translated_text:
The unknowing is purity, the desireless is simplicity, and purity and simplicity are the Way of *wuwei*.

To always govern the people thus means that the Sage first practices it himself, and only then can he make the people unknowing and desireless, pure and simple in *wuwei*.

For only when the ruler’s virtue is manifest can he make the people’s virtue manifest.

As in the age of primal antiquity, when the world was in *wuwei*—when the ruler above was in *wuwei*, then those below were also in *wuwei*.

The ruler is like the wind, the people like the grass.
When the wind does not bend the grass, such a thing does not exist in the world.

The customs of the unknowing, the winds of simplicity and purity—these belong to the age of supreme antiquity and its virtue.

Zhuangzi said: In the age of supreme virtue, the worthy are not honored, the capable are not employed. The ruler is like a branch of a tree, the people like wild deer—straightforward without knowing it as *ren*, loving one another without knowing it as *yi*, sincere without knowing it as *zhong*, faithful without knowing it as *xin*. They move clumsily yet govern one another without calling it a blessing.

Thus, they act without striving, serve without leaving a trace. Filial sons do not flatter their parents, loyal ministers do not fawn on their lords—this is the custom of purity and simplicity.

Therefore, the Sage first transforms himself from above, and thus it is said: *"Always govern the people by making them unknowing and desireless."*

To make the wise dare not act.

In the age of antiquity, the customs were pure, and there were no distinctions of *san gang*—lord-subject, father-son, husband-wife—and no visible *wu chang*—*ren, yi, li, zhi, xin*. All shared equally, yet did not know how they obtained it; all were born naturally, yet did not know how they came to be. Dwelling with beasts, mingling with all things, how could they know of noble and base?

In their shared unknowing, their virtue did not depart; in their shared desirelessness, this is called *suzhu*—the uncarved block—and the people returned to their nature.

If such pure and simple folk were to encounter clever and bright scholars, though they possessed knowledge, they would have no use for it.

Thus it is said: *"To make the wise dare not act."*

To practice *wuwei* is to have nothing that cannot be governed.

The virtue of the Sage-King takes heaven and earth as its root, *Dao* and virtue as its master, and *wuwei* as its constant.

To be in *wuwei* is to govern the world with abundance.
To act with *wei* is to be used by the world yet remain insufficient.

*Wuwei* is the balance of heaven and earth, the ultimate of *Dao* and virtue. To understand this and sit in the south-facing hall is to be Yao as sovereign.
To understand this and face north is to be Shun as minister.

To hold this in high station is the virtue of the Emperor and Son of Heaven.
To hold this in low station is the *Dao* of the ancient and pure Sage-Kings.

To retreat and dwell in leisure among rivers, seas, mountains, and forests is the way of the recluse.
To advance and govern the world is to achieve great deeds and a resounding name, uniting all under heaven.

Thus it is said: *"To practice wuwei is to have nothing that cannot be governed."*

Yang Zhiren said: *"To not honor the worthy makes the people not contend, and thus nothing remains ungoverned."*

To not honor the worthy means that wealth and nobility are not desired, titles and emoluments are not possessed. One does not attend the Son of Heaven above, nor pay respects to ministers below. Thus one possesses the virtue of non-contention.

To not prize rare goods means that strange treasures, precious metals, and fine jade are but external things. The heart is serene, the people content. Externally, no desires are seen; internally, the mind is undisturbed.

The enlightened see yet do not see, moving freely in all directions.
The ancients said: *"If I have no mind toward all things, how can all things not surround me?"*

The Sage’s practice is to empty the heart of all attachments, fill the belly to preserve the essence, weaken the will to remain humble, and strengthen the bones to nurture the boundless.

My heart is pure, the people’s hearts are simple. Without desire, without knowledge, the wise dare not act.

To be in *wuwei* yet accomplish all is to have nothing that cannot be governed.

The *Book of Documents* says: *"Yanzi’s limbs were exhausted, his brilliance discarded, his form abandoned, his wisdom set aside—this is to not honor the worthy."*

Eating coarse grains, drinking from a gourd, dwelling in a humble lane—though others could not endure the hardship, Yan Hui did not change his joy.

To not prize rare goods is to not steal; to not see desire is to not be disturbed—this is the way.

To nourish the proper with ease is humility;
to be lowly yet honored is the Sage’s way of emptying the heart, filling the belly, weakening the will, and strengthening the bones—without knowledge, without desire, in *wuwei* yet without failing to govern.

Yu Qingzhong said: *"To not honor the worthy makes the people not contend, and thus nothing remains ungoverned."*

To not honor the worthy makes the people not contend—this means that if you do not boast of your abilities, none will contend with you in skill.

To not prize rare goods makes the people not steal—this means that if one does not covet, even if rewarded, one will not take it, as Gongsun Long said.

To not see what is desirable makes the heart not disturbed—this is the most critical teaching of the *Taishang*.

Zigong, seeing the splendor of the capital and taking delight, saw what was desirable and his heart was disturbed. Yet upon returning and hearing the Master’s *Dao*, he found joy—seeing no desire, his heart was undisturbed.

Damo faced the wall at Shaolin for nine years—this too was the meaning.

The training of the worthy is like my sole virtue being laborious. Generally, those who seek to excel in all things are called worthy—such as those who love grandeur and achievement, who exhaust armies and wage wars, always seeking to surpass predecessors, not merely boasting of cleverness and strength.

Han Wen, emulating the Yellow Emperor and Laozi’s quietude, used humble words and thick gifts, and pacified distant peoples, yet said, *"I am a concubine’s son of the High Emperor"*—this was to not honor the worthy.

Qi Gaozu said: *"If I were to govern the world for ten years, I would make gold as common as dirt."* This was to not prize rare goods.

Generally, women are what people desire, as are wealth and nobility. Dogs, horses, music, and women; sons, daughters, jade, and silk; towering halls and carved walls—all are enough to arouse desire. Only by seeing nothing externally can the mind remain unshaken within.
