chunks.original_text: 大昌於是参万理以观，而自主其见。 曰谷外无响，则响外亦复无神也。 彼其专主一虚以为之义者，推而致之，老语则其谓不死也，若存也，皆无归宿也。 是故不敢苟随也。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 凡谓之元，皆取窈深暗晦之义。 元德，元同、元览，与此之玄牝，皆为夫德同览牝四则者，已涉乎有而可见，故从四则之上，又益深晦焉，乃遂加元以究命，其宿也，推而高之，常无之上其妙已甚矣。 而遂去无之目，单命为玄，则其象可想矣。 牝也者，应而不唱，谷之蕴响待声者是矣。 声苟不感，则响终不出，其可谓不为物先也矣。 夫惟天下之雄且强者，已皆知之，而能自屈於牝，则其虚已甚矣。 於虚之上，更加元焉，则其变化所出，是为生天生地之所也。 故前章曰无名，天地之始。 而此言天地之根也。 是皆探端命初，而知夫无之受感而应者，其於凡有，皆得命其宗而司其出者也。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 有形有质，目可睹，手可捉，则谓之存可也，若谷之能应也，以为序耶，则漠乎其无有，以为不存耶，则前响已绝，后声再触，其应如故。 故以若存言之也。 绵绵者，仅得相属而不绝也。 庄子之谓际者，此其地也。 际者，两异之交也。 姑即四序之易见者明之，春之已季，即夏之欲孟也。 季孟之间则际也。 有季则必有孟，而元气未尝自为季孟也，则列子之命往复而曰其际不可终者是也。 从其际而观之，则今之为孟者，即昔名为季者之代也。 孟者起而季者去，则夏应春往也。 惟夫制往复以出生化者，则无际而无终，是其所以常存也。 此之存者，虽常不亡而不可得见，故绵绵相属，若存而不见其序也。 故以若存言之也。 夫其生生化化，无时或息，无时或留，若甚劳矣，而先后有序，虽有作用而不费运动也。 自生自化，自消自息，元无劳也。 庄子曰：阴阳四时运行，各得其序。 悟兮若亡而存，油然不形而神，万物蓄而不知。 此之谓本根。 此非夫能神而不亡、若劳而寔不勤者耶？ 论列子之生化本於老氏之作复，老氏之作复本於《易》之消息，而其所以生化作复，则皆不出乎阴阳之进退也。 阴退而阳进，则为生为作； 阴升而阳降，则为化为复。 自进退之渐而言之，则为消为息也。 此《易》《老》之所同言，而老氏则常探夫《易》之所不肯尽者，而既言之，故越消息而言有无也。 有无也者，又其制消息之机，而不自囿於消息之数者也。 故作复之证，则为刍狗； 消息之机，则为橐钥； 而生化之原，则为谷神。 此其浅深之辨也。 詹秋圃曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 成象章言凡物谷养神气，则生生不灭，是谓天主阳为玄，地主阴为牝。 玄牝为品物生育之门，是谓根於天地，而生物成象无穷已也。 张冲应曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 我有此身禀天之气，含地之精，即此五脏之神也。 鼻者气之升降所系，口者精之运行所关。 气五十一动息，从鼻而为之升降。 精一刻凡七十四运，从口而为之运行。 则谷神得此精气所养，而不死也，是谓玄牝故也。 玄牝之门者，乃鼻为天气之门，口为地精之门。 运动有常，则肾不虚海不塞，而天地之所以根也。 诚能息其精气，绵绵如常，用之无穷，享年为无已矣。 此乃男女通行之法，切宜详味而养之，则成真入圣，皆以之也。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the Great Master [参] examined myriad principles [万理] and observed,
yet held firm to his own insight [自主其见].
He said: *"Beyond the Grain’s Spirit [谷], there is no echo [响],
then beyond the echo, there is also no Spirit [神]."*

Those who rigidly uphold a single void [一虚] as its meaning,
when extended to its limit,
Lao’s words then speak of the *Unperishing* [不死],
or of *storage* [若存],
all lacking a final resting place [无归宿].
Therefore, he did not dare to follow blindly.

The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门],
this is called the *Root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根].
All that is termed *Origin* [元],
take the meaning of *profound, dark, and obscure* [窈深暗晦].
*Origin-Virtue* [元德],
*Origin-Sameness* [元同],
*Origin-Viewing* [元览],
and this *Mysterious Female* [玄牝],
all belong to the four categories of *Virtue-Sameness* [德同] and *Viewing-Female* [览牝],
already touching upon the *existent* [有] and thus visible [可见].
Therefore, beyond these four categories [四则之上],
he further deepens into the *obscure* [深晦],
and thus adds *Origin* [元] to explore the *command* [命].
Its *foundation* [宿],
when elevated to its utmost,
the *Miracles of the Nonexistent* [无] are already profound.

Then, discarding the label of *Nonexistent* [无],
and solely designating it as *Mysterious* [玄],
its *image* [象] can be imagined.

The *Female* [牝] is one who *responds without initiating* [应而不唱].
The Grain’s Spirit [谷] that *harbors the echo awaiting sound* [蕴响待声] is exactly this.

If *sound is not stirred* [声苟不感],
then the *echo never emerges* [响终不出],
and thus it can be said to *not act before things* [不为物先].

Only those who are the *mighty and strong of the world* [天下之雄且强],
already knowing this,
and yet can *bow to the Female* [自屈於牝],
have reached the utmost *void* [虚].

Above this *void* [虚],
further adding *Origin* [元],
then the *transformations and changes* [变化] that arise,
are the *source of Heaven and Earth’s birth* [生天生地].

Thus, the previous chapter says: *"The Nameless* [无名] *is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.*
And here, it speaks of the *Root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根].
All this is *probing the ultimate and commanding the initial* [探端命初],
and knowing that the *Nonexistent’s response to stimulation* [无之受感而应]
is the *foundation of all existence* [凡有]—
it *grants the primal command* [命其宗] and *governs their emergence* [司其出].

Continuous yet as if existing [绵绵若存],
its use is not exhausted [用之不勤].
With *form and substance* [有形有质],
it is *visible to the eye* [目可睹] and *graspable by the hand* [手可捉],
so it is called *existing* [存]—
if the Grain’s Spirit [谷] can *respond* [能应],
then it is said to *sequence things* [以为序],
but it is *indistinctly nonexistent* [漠乎其无有],
or if it is said to *not exist* [不存],
then the *echo before ceases* [前响已绝],
and the *sound after strikes* [后声再触],
its response remains unchanged [其应如故].
Therefore, it is spoken of as *existing yet indistinct* [若存].

*Continuous* [绵绵] means merely *holding to connection without cessation* [相属而不绝].
Zhuangzi’s *threshold* [际] is exactly this.
The *threshold* is the *intersection of opposites* [两异之交].
Let us clarify it with the *plainly seen* [易见] four seasons [四序]:
when *spring’s season ends* [春之已季],
it is the *summer’s season about to begin* [夏之欲孟].
The *space between the end and the beginning* [季孟之间] is the *threshold* [际].
There is an *end* [季], then there must be a *beginning* [孟],
but the *Origin-Qi* [元气] never *makes itself into end or beginning* [自为季孟].
Thus, the Listed Child’s words on *eternal return* [命往复]
and saying that its *threshold cannot be exhausted* [际不可终] are correct.

Observing from the *threshold* [际],
what is now called *beginning* [孟]
is the *substitution of what was once called end* [昔名为季].
The *beginning* arises [起], the *end* departs [去],
and thus *summer follows spring’s departure* [夏应春往].

Only those who *establish eternal return to give birth and transform* [制往复以出生化],
have *no threshold and no end* [无际无终],
and this is why they *remain everlasting* [常存].
This *everlasting existence* [存],
though *constant and never perishing* [常不亡],
is *yet unseen* [不可得见],
so it *continuously connects* [绵绵相属],
as if existing yet *no sequence is apparent* [不见其序].
Therefore, it is spoken of as *existing yet indistinct* [若存].

Its *eternal birth and transformation* [生生化化],
never *ceasing or lingering* [无时或息, 无时或留],
as if *laboring greatly* [甚劳],
yet *with sequence in precedence and succession* [先后有序],
though there are *actions and functions* [有作用],
they do not *exhaust movement* [费运动].
*Self-birth, self-transformation* [自生自化],
*self-consumption, self-rest* [自消自息],
there is *no labor at all* [元无劳].

Zhuangzi says:
*"The interplay of yin and yang, the four seasons’ progression,
each attains its order.*
*Awaken! As if perishing yet existing,
effulgent yet formless—its spirit,
all things nurtured yet unaware.*
This is called the *Origin-Root* [本根].
Is this not the *spirit that perishes not* [能神而不亡],
as if *laboring yet truly not exhausted* [若劳而寔不勤]?"

Discussing how the Listed Child’s *birth and transformation* [生化]
originate from Laozi’s *action and return* [作复],
and Laozi’s *action and return*
originate from the *Classic of Changes’* *eclipse and growth* [消息],
yet the *means by which they birth, transform, act, and return* [所以生化作复],
all do not exceed the *advance and retreat of yin and yang* [阴阳之进退].

When *yin retreats and yang advances* [阴退而阳进],
it becomes *birth and action* [为生为作];
when *yin ascends and yang descends* [阴升而阳降],
it becomes *transformation and return* [为化为复].
Speaking of this *gradual advance and retreat* [进退之渐],
it is *eclipse and growth* [消息].

This is what the *Classic of Changes* and Laozi *speak in common* [所同言],
yet Laozi *constantly probes what the Classic does not fully reveal* [探夫《易》之所不肯尽],
and having spoken of it,
he *transcends eclipse and growth to discuss existence and nonexistence* [越消息而言有无].

*Existence and nonexistence* [有无] are again
the *mechanism governing eclipse and growth* [消息之机],
yet not *confined to the cycles of eclipse and growth* [自囿於消息之数].
Thus, the *evidence of action and return* [作复之证] is the *straw-dog* [刍狗];
the *mechanism of eclipse and growth* [消息之机] is the *bellows-key* [橐钥];
and the *source of birth and transformation* [生化之原] is the Grain’s Spirit [谷神].
This is the *distinction between shallow and deep* [浅深之辨].

Zhan Qiu Pu said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit perishes not—its use is not exhausted.*
The *Chapter of the Manifested* [成象] states that all things
are *nurtured by the Grain’s Spirit and Qi* [谷养神气],
thus *eternally born and unperishing* [生生不灭],
this is called *Heaven’s Mysterious Female as Yang* [天主阳为玄],
and *Earth’s Mysterious Female as Yin* [地主阴为牝].
The *Mysterious Female* is the *gate through which all things are born and transformed* [品物生育之门],
this is called the *rooted in Heaven and Earth* [根於天地],
and the *endless generation and manifestation of things* [生物成象无穷]."

Zhang Chong Ying replied:
*"The Grain’s Spirit perishes not—its use is not exhausted.*
I possess this body,
*endowed with Heaven’s Qi* [禀天之气],
and *containing Earth’s essence* [含地之精],
this is the *Spirit of the Five Viscera* [五脏之神].
The *nose* [鼻] is where *Qi’s ascent and descent* [气之升降] are hinged,
the *mouth* [口] is where *essence’s circulation* [精之运行] is linked.
*Qi moves fifty-one times before resting* [气五十一动息],
ascending and descending through the *nose* [鼻].
*Essence circulates seventy-four times in a moment* [精一刻凡七十四运],
circulating through the *mouth* [口].
Thus, the Grain’s Spirit [谷],
*nourished by this essence and Qi* [得此精气所养],
*perishes not* [不死],
this is why it is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝故].

The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门],
is the *nose as Heaven’s Qi’s gate* [鼻为天气之门],
and the *mouth as Earth’s essence’s gate* [口为地精之门].
If *movement is constant* [运动有常],
then the *kidneys do not empty and the seas do not block* [肾不虚海不塞],
and this is the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之所以根].
If one can *rest the essence and Qi* [息其精气],
*continuously as normal* [绵绵如常],
using them *endlessly* [用之无穷],
then *longevity will be without end* [享年为无已].
This is the *law of male and female interplay* [男女通行之法],
and it is imperative to *deliberate and nurture it* [详味而养之],
then one will *attain true humanity and sainthood* [成真入圣],
all through this." [皆以之也。]

chunks.original_text: 不然精耗气亏，谷神无所养，则颜无光采，而气化雄，精化雌，神化鬼，即谓三尸者也。 人生于世，身有此妙，而不能保养之。 惜哉。 张灵应曰：玄为天属阳，而为元气。 牝为地属阴，而为元精。 元气以子时而升，此一阳生也。 由肾宫从左道流入五脏，卯时与精会於腹，入肝，是谓春阳分也。 巳时至天门，鼻为出入之门，而升於顶，至午时降居右道，入骨络，复还肾宫。 元精以午时而升降，此一阴生也。 由命元从右道流入骨络，酉时与气会於背，入肺，是谓秋阴分也。 亥时至地户，口为出入之门，而升於顶，至子时降居左道，入五脏，复还命元。 精与气一升一降，玄牝交合，不亏不盈，则神居天谷，守卫此形，而后可以见调理不死之方。 白玉蟾曰：谷神不死，此心本无老死。 是谓玄牝，同此一天。 玄牝之门，念头动处。 是谓天地根，惟心。 绵绵若存，只是如此。 用之不勤，无为而已。 廖粹然曰：谷神不死。 空气在身为神之母，子母相养，形神长生。 是谓玄牝。 万物之母。 玄牝之门。 生生化化，众妙之门。 是谓天地根。 万象之本。 绵绵若存。 左右逢原，这是本来面目之为。 用之不动。 周行不殆，绵亘古今，不消用力。 陈碧虚曰：谷神不死，是谓玄牝。 夫大人以太虚为空谷，以造化为至神。 空谷至神，乃道之体用，岂有死乎不死之理？ 既而深冥，又能母养，故曰是谓玄牝。 或谷喻天地，神喻大道。 今说者以山谷响应为喻，不其小哉？ 且人能怀豁无方，法太虚之广，存任神真，资造化之灵，自然形与道合，何死之谓乎？ 如是则冥 然茂养，物受其赐也。
chunks.translated_text:
「If not so, then *essence will be depleted and Qi will be exhausted* [精耗气亏],
and the *Grain’s Spirit* [谷神] will have no nourishment to sustain it—
then the face will lack luster and vitality [颜无光采],
and *Qi will transform into the Yang Male* [气化雄],
*essence into the Yin Female* [精化雌],
*Spirit into the Ghostly* [神化鬼],
which is called the *Three Corpses* [三尸者也].

Humans live in this world,
possessing this wondrous *essence-Qi-Spirit* [此妙],
yet cannot preserve and nurture it.
Alas.

Zhang Lingying said:
*"Xuan* [玄] is Heaven’s domain, the Yang,
and is the *Primordial Qi* [元气].
*The Female* [牝] is Earth’s domain, the Yin,
and is the *Primordial Essence* [元精].
The *Primordial Qi* [元气] ascends at the *Child Hour* [子时],
this is the *birth of one Yang* [一阳生也].
From the *Kidney Palace* [肾宫], it flows through the *Left Path* [左道] into the *Five Zang Organs* [五脏],
and at the *Maocheng Hour* [卯时] meets with *essence* in the abdomen,
entering the *liver*—this is called the *Spring Yang Division* [春阳分也].
By the *Wucheng Hour* [巳时], it reaches the *Heavenly Gate* [天门],
the *nose as the gate for its entry and exit* [鼻为出入之门],
and ascends to the *crown* [顶],
until the *Wuhou* [午时], when it descends, residing in the *Right Path* [右道],
entering the *bone networks* [骨络], then returning to the *Kidney Palace* [肾宫].

The *Primordial Essence* [元精] ascends and descends at the *Wuhou* [午时],
this is the *birth of one Yin* [一阴生也].
From the *Command Essence* [命元], it flows through the *Right Path* [右道] into the *bone networks* [骨络],
and at the *Yousheng Hour* [酉时] meets with *Qi* in the back,
entering the *lung*—this is called the *Autumn Yin Division* [秋阴分也].
By the *Haicheng Hour* [亥时], it reaches the *Earthly Portal* [地户],
the *mouth as the gate for its entry and exit* [口为出入之门],
and ascends to the *crown* [顶],
until the *Child Hour* [子时], when it descends, residing in the *Left Path* [左道],
entering the *Five Zang Organs* [五脏], then returning to the *Command Essence* [命元].

When *essence ascends and Qi descends* [精与气一升一降],
the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝] interplays,
neither depleted nor excessive [不亏不盈],
then the *Spirit dwells in Heaven’s Grain* [神居天谷],
guarding and sustaining this form [守卫此形],
and only then can one perceive the *method of regulating and attaining non-death* [调理不死之方].

Bai Yushan said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit does not perish"* [谷神不死],
this is because the *heart is originally without aging and death* [此心本无老死].
This is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝],
unified in this *One Dao* [同此一天].
The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门]
lies where the *mind’s movements arise* [念头动处].

This is called the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根],
for it is the *heart* [惟心].
Continuously as if preserved [绵绵若存],
it is simply *this* [只是如此].
Using it without strain [用之不勤],
is to act *without effort* [无为而已].

Liao Cuiran said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit does not perish"* [谷神不死].
*Empty Qi* [空气] within the body is the *mother of Spirit* [神之母],
and the *mother and child mutually nourish* [子母相养],
thus *form and Spirit attain longevity* [形神长生].
This is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝],
the *mother of all things* [万物之母].
The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门]
is the *gate of all transformations and marvels* [生生化化，众妙之门].
This is called the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根],
the *source of all phenomena* [万象之本].
Continuously as if preserved [绵绵若存],
*left and right find their origin* [左右逢原],
this is the *original face of suchness* [本来面目之为].
Using it without exertion [用之不动],
it *circulates endlessly without pause* [周行不殆],
extending through ancient and modern times [绵亘古今],
*requiring no effort to consume* [不消用力].

Chen Biuxu said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit does not perish"* [谷神不死]—this is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝].
The *Great Person* [大人] takes *Great Emptiness* [太虚] as the *Empty Grain* [空谷],
and *Creation* [造化] as the *Supreme Spirit* [至神].
The *Empty Grain* and *Supreme Spirit* [空谷至神]
are the *body and function of the Dao* [道之体用],
how could there be a principle of *perishing or not perishing* [有死乎不死之理]?
Moreover, it is *deep and hidden* [深冥],
and yet can *mother and nourish*—
thus it is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝].
Some say *Grain* [谷] symbolizes *Heaven and Earth* [天地],
and *Spirit* [神] symbolizes the *Great Dao* [大道].
But those who speak of *Grain’s Spirit* as a metaphor for *mountains and valleys echoing in response*—
is this not too trivial?

Furthermore, if humans can *embrace openness without bounds* [怀豁无方],
aligning with the *Great Emptiness’s vastness* [法太虚之广],
and *preserve the true and genuine Spirit* [存任神真],
drawing upon *Creation’s vitality* [资造化之灵],
then *form naturally harmonizes with the Dao* [自然形与道合],
what is there to speak of *death* [何死之谓乎]?
Thus, one *flourishes in hidden cultivation* [冥然茂养],
and *all things receive its blessings* [物受其赐也].」

chunks.original_text: 故曰玄牝。 河上公《章句》谷音育，训养也。 人能养神则不死。 神谓五藏之神，肝藏魂，肺藏魄，心藏神，肾藏精，脾藏志。 夫人能清静虚空，以养其神，不为诸欲所染，使形完神全，故不死也。 若触情耽滞，为诸境所乱，使形残神去，则何道之可存哉？ 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 夫太虚造化，万类之以出入。 既有出入之名，放谓之门。 且根者，本也，天地虽大，不能逃其有形，有形之类，咸以虚空太和为其根本。 故曰是谓天地根。 河上公曰：不死之道在玄牝。 玄，天也，於人为鼻。 牝，地也，於人为口。 天食人以五气，从鼻入，藏於心，五气清微，为精神聪明，音声五性，其鬼曰魂。 魂者，雄也，主出入人鼻，与天通，故鼻於玄也。 地食人以五味，从口入，藏於胃，五味烛辱，为形骸骨肉、血脉六情，其鬼曰魄。 魄者，雌也，主出入人口，与地通，故。 为牝也。 根者，元也，言鼻。 之门，乃是通天地之元气所从往来也。 且上言谷神不死者，劝人养神之理，此曰玄牝之门者，示人炼形之术也。 故形神俱妙者，方与道同也。 夫人有身有神，则有生有死。 有生有死，不可言道也。 流动无常，岂得言静也。 若乃空其形神，忘其物我，是以出无根，故气聚不以为生； 入无窍，故气散不以为死。 不死不生，其谷之神也。 生死无常，其浮动之物也。 幽深雌静，湛然不动，其玄牝之谓也。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 绵绵，不绝之貌，此结上养神炼形之义也。 夫养神则深妙冥极，清静虚空，绵绵若存，感物而起，无有绝时也。 炼形则呼吸太和，导接血气，饮难终之泉，咀延年之草，使其支节通畅，而不勤劳也。 此方可与天地同根，众妙共门也。 谢图南曰：谷神不死至用之不动。 经曰谷得一以盈，神得一以灵，天地有之，人亦有之。 陈希夷曰：山自天之上而坠，故观艮画则知山自天来。 人之首象天顶，曰昆仑。 鼻口山根，神藏其间，是曰谷神，一身之主宰也。 实未尝死。 玄牝者，指乾坤二元。 而言乾为首，坤为腹，二元之气升降往来，在乾曰玄，在坤曰牝。 玄牝即二元之气，二元即谷神之主也。 邵康节诗云：一物元来有一身，一身还有一乾坤。 正谓此尔。 门则指两鼻也。 天地清宁之气，自人之鼻而入，流布身中，乾首坤腹，胥此养之，故谓之根。 是气之入，绵绵不绝若存者，顺其自然而存之，不必劳力也。 故曰用之不勤。 或者过於闭其气，非徒无益，而又害之。 盖尝论之，太极肇分，人与天地并立为三，此三才之道也。 首为天，腹为地，心居其中，吾身之三才也。 康节诗曰：天向一中分造化，人从心上起经纶。 心居首腹之中，以弥纶上下，使玄牝升降，精神往来，吾身可以常存矣。 存养既深，体认既熟，则惚兮恍兮，其中有象，恍兮惚兮，其中有物，窈兮冥兮，其中有精。 三者可识矣。 视之不见名之曰夷，听之不闻名之曰希，搏之不得名之曰微，三者可想矣。 知其雄，守其雌，知其白，守其黑，知其荣，守其辱，三者可存矣。 反观内察，天地与我相似。 其曰谷神不死，老氏岂欺我哉？ 林鬳斋曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 此章乃修养一项功夫之所自出。 老子之初意，却不专为修养也。 精则实，神则虚。 谷者，虚也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus it is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝]. The *Master of the Yellow River* [河上公] in his *Commentary* [《章句》] explains that *Grain* [谷] refers to the *nourishing sound* [育], meaning *nourishment* [养]. When humans can *nourish their Spirit* [养神], then they do not *perish* [死].

The *Spirit* [神] here refers to the *Spirits of the Five Viscera* [五藏之神]:
- the *Liver Spirit* [肝] harbors the *ethereal soul* [魂],
- the *Lungs Spirit* [肺] harbors the *corporeal soul* [魄],
- the *Heart Spirit* [心] harbors the *Spirit* [神],
- the *Kidneys Spirit* [肾] harbors the *Essence* [精],
- the *Spleen Spirit* [脾] harbors the *Will* [志].

When humans can *cleanse and still their form within the Great Emptiness* [清静虚空], *nourishing their Spirit* [以养其神], and not be *defiled by the myriad desires* [不为诸欲所染], their *form remains whole and their Spirit intact* [使形完神全], and thus they do not *perish* [死]. But if one *entangles with emotions and lingers in indulgence* [触情耽滞], *disturbed by the myriad phenomena* [为诸境所乱], their *form decays and their Spirit departs* [使形残神去], then how can the *Dao* [道] be preserved?

The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门] is called the *Root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根]. The *Great Emptiness* [太虚] and *Creation* [造化] are the means by which *all things enter and exit* [万类之以出入]. Since there is the name of *entry and exit* [出入], it is called the *Gate* [门]. Moreover, *Root* [根] means *origin* [元], and the *Gate* [之门] refers to the *two nostrils* [两鼻], which serve as the passage for the *Essential Qi of Heaven and Earth* [天地之元气] to circulate within the body.

The earlier statement that *Grain’s Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死] exhorts humans to *the principle of nourishing the Spirit* [养神之理], while this passage on the *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门] illustrates *the technique of refining the form* [炼形之术]. Thus, those who *perfectly nourish both form and Spirit* [形神俱妙] alone may *align with the Dao* [与道同].

Humans possess both *form* [身] and *Spirit* [神], and thus they have *birth and death* [生有死]. With *birth and death* [生有死], one cannot speak of the *Dao* [道]. *Flowing and shifting without constancy* [流动无常], how can it be called *stillness* [静]? If one *empties their form and Spirit* [空其形神], *forgets the distinction between self and things* [忘其物我], then *their exit lacks a root* [出无根], and thus *the Qi does not gather to form life* [气聚不以为生]; *their entry lacks an orifice* [入无窍], and thus *the Qi does not disperse to cause death* [气散不以为死]. Without *life* [生] or *death* [死], this is the *Spirit of Grain* [谷神]. *Birth and death are without constancy* [生死无常], for they are but *floating and shifting things* [浮动之物]. *Deeply hidden and feminine stillness* [幽深雌静], *serene and unmoving* [湛然不动], is what is meant by the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝].

*Continuous as if ever-present* [绵绵若存], yet *its use requires no exertion* [用之不勤]. *Continuous* [绵绵] describes its unending nature—this passage ties together the earlier teachings on *nourishing the Spirit and refining the form* [结上养神炼形之义].

To *nourish the Spirit* [养神] is to attain *profound subtlety and hidden stillness* [深妙冥极], *cleansing and emptiness* [清静虚空], *continuous as if ever-present* [绵绵若存], yet *responding to things without ceasing* [感物而起], *uninterrupted in time* [无有绝时].

To *refine the form* [炼形] is to *breathe in the harmonious Great Emptiness* [呼吸太和], *guide and connect the blood and Qi* [导接血气], *drink the elixir of the endless spring* [饮难终之泉], and *chew the herb of longevity* [咀延年之草], so that *their limbs and joints remain unobstructed* [使其支节通畅] and *they experience no exertion* [而不勤劳]. Only then can they *share the same root as Heaven and Earth* [与天地同根] and *enter the same gate as all marvels* [众妙共门].

*Master Xie Tuonan* [谢图南] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is the *ineffable function’s non-exertion* [至用之不动]. The *Classic* [经] states: *Grain is filled by the One* [谷得一以盈], *Spirit is made agile by the One* [神得一以灵]; *Heaven and Earth possess this* [天地有之], and *humans also possess it* [人亦有之].

*Master Chen Xiyi* [陈希夷] says: *Mountains fall from Heaven’s heights* [山自天之上而坠], so when one *observes the trigram *Kān* [艮] and its lines* [画], one knows *mountains originate from Heaven* [山自天来]. The *human head symbolizes Heaven’s apex* [人之首象天顶], called *Kunlun* [昆仑]. The *nose and mouth are the roots of mountains* [鼻口山根], and the *Spirit dwells between them* [神藏其间], thus it is called *Grain’s Spirit* [谷神], the *master of the body* [一身之主宰]. Indeed, it *never truly perishes* [实未尝死].

The *Mysterious Female* [玄牝] refers to the *Two Primordial Elements* [乾坤二元]. The *head* [首] is *Kān* [乾], the *abdomen* [腹] is *Kūn* [坤]; the *Qi of these two elements ascends and descends, circulating* [二元之气升降往来], called *Mysterious* [玄] when in *Kān* [乾], and *Feminine* [牝] when in *Kūn* [坤]. The *Mysterious Female* [玄牝] is the *Qi of the Two Primordial Elements* [二元之气], and the *Two Primordial Elements* [二元] are the *masters of Grain’s Spirit* [谷神之主].

*Master Shao Kangjie’s* [邵康节] poem states:
*"One thing originally has a body, a body still has a Heaven and Earth"* [一物元来有一身，一身还有一乾坤].
This is precisely what is meant.

The *Gate* [门] refers to the *two nostrils* [两鼻]. The *pure and tranquil Qi of Heaven and Earth* [天地清宁之气] enters through the *human nostrils* [自人之鼻], *circulating and permeating the body* [流布身中]. The *head* [乾首] and *abdomen* [坤腹] are both *nourished by this* [胥此养之], hence it is called the *Root* [根]. The *Qi’s continuous entry* [是气之入], *unending as if ever-present* [绵绵不绝若存], is *preserved by following its natural flow* [顺其自然而存之], requiring *no exertion* [不必劳力].

Thus it is said: *Its use requires no exertion* [用之不勤]. Some may *overclose their Qi* [过於闭其气], which is not only *without benefit* [非徒无益] but also *harmful* [而又害之]. Indeed, it has been discussed: *The Great Ultimate* [太极] *begins to differentiate* [肇分], and humans stand alongside Heaven and Earth as *the Three Talents* [三]. This is the *Dao of the Three Talents* [三才之道].

The *head* [首] is Heaven, the *abdomen* [腹] is Earth, and the *heart* [心] resides between them—*the Three Talents within the human body* [吾身之三才]. *Master Shao Kangjie’s* [康节] poem states:
*"Heaven divides Creation within the One, humans weave the loom from the heart’s apex"* [天向一中分造化，人从心上起经纶].
The *heart* [心] resides between the *head* [首] and *abdomen* [腹], *weaving the threads of the above and below* [以弥纶上下], so that the *Mysterious Female ascends and descends* [使玄牝升降], the *Spirit and Qi circulate* [精神往来], and thus *the body may endure perpetually* [吾身可以常存矣].

When *preservation and nourishment are profound* [存养既深] and *understanding and recognition are mature* [体认既熟], then *it appears vague and indistinct* [惚兮恍兮], yet *therein lies an image* [其中有象], *indistinct and vague* [恍兮惚兮], yet *therein lies a thing* [其中有物], *deep and hidden* [窈兮冥兮], yet *therein lies a precision* [其中有精]. These three may be *perceived* [可识].

*It cannot be seen* [视之不见], thus it is called *Yí* [夷];
*it cannot be heard* [听之不闻], thus it is called *Xī* [希];
*it cannot be grasped* [搏之不得], thus it is called *Wēi* [微].
These three may be *imagined* [可想].

*Know its masculine aspect* [知其雄], yet *hold to its feminine aspect* [守其雌];
*know its white* [知其白], yet *hold to its black* [守其黑];
*know its prosperity* [知其荣], yet *hold to its adversity* [守其辱].
These three may be *preserved* [可存].

When one *reverses their gaze inward and inspects* [反观内察], *Heaven and Earth resemble oneself* [天地与我相似]. Is it not true that *The Spirit of Grain does not perish* [谷神不死], and *Master Lao* [老氏] does not *deceive me* [欺我]?

*Master Lin Yinshi* [林鬳斋] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is the *ineffable function’s non-exertion* [至用之不勤]. This section arises from *one practice of cultivation and nourishment* [修养一项功夫之所自出]. *Master Lao’s* [老子] original intent, however, was not *exclusively for cultivation and nourishment* [却不专为修养].

*Essence* [精] is *substantial* [实], *Spirit* [神] is *ethereal* [虚]. *Grain* [谷] refers to *the ethereal* [虚].」

Furthermore, if humans can *embrace openness without bounds* [怀豁无方],
aligning with the *Great Emptiness’s vastness* [法太虚之广],
and *preserve the true and genuine Spirit* [存任神真],

chunks.original_text: 谷神者，虚中之神者也。 言人之神自虚中而出，故常存而不死。 玄，远而无极者也。 牝，虚而不实者也。 此二字只形容一个虚字。 天地亦自此而出，故曰根。 绵绵，不已、不绝之意。 若存者，若有若无也。 用於虚无之中，故不劳而常存，即所谓虚而不屈，动而愈出是也。 晦翁曰：至妙之理，有生生之意存焉。 此语亦好，但其意亦近於养生之论。 此章虽可以为养生之用，而初意实不专主是也。 范应元曰：谷神不死，是谓玄牝。 谷神，犹言虚灵也。 不死，犹言无极也。 玄牝，言其生物而不见其所以生也。 谓虚灵无极，此乃生物之牝，而不见其所以生，故曰玄。 谷神二字，傅奕云幽而通也。 司马温公曰：中虚故曰谷，不测故曰神。 苏曰：谷至虚而犹有形，谷神则虚而无形也。 虚而无形尚无有生，安有死邪？ 谓之谷神，言其德也； 谓之玄牝，言其功也。 牝生万物而谓之玄，焉见其生之而不见其所以生也。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 门者，指阴阳也。 以其一辟一阖，往来不穷而言也。 阴阳者，以道之动静而言也。 动而曰阳，动极而静曰阴，动极而静，静极复动，开阖不忒，生育无穷。 根者，谓天地本於此也。 人能於此心之初得之，则知天地之根，无根之根也； 玄牝之门，无门之门也； 谷神，不神之神也。 岂有穷尽哉？ 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 谓谷神之在天地，绵绵密密而无极也。 然视之不可见，听之不得闻，用之不可既，故曰若存，天地用之而四时行、百物生，未尝劳也。 谷神在人亦然。 绵绵密密，生生无穷，以为本无孰主此身，以为本有竟居何所？ 故曰若存。 善用之者未尝劳也，何有终穷哉？ 此章宜深体之，或有专就修养上解者，然必须认得谷神方可。 薛庸斋曰：谷神不死至是谓天地根。 谷者，神所居。 神者，形所载。 以形养气，以气含神，不死之道也。 神本无死，赋于形而有死，虽死而未尝死也。 谷神因玄牝不死，天地以玄牝为根。 玄牝者内焉，而藏精外焉，而调息一开一阖，一呼一吸，呼则至於深根，吸则至於固蒂。 於是有神入焉，离斗辗历天廷，骑日月披云雾，腾腾乎会归于大有之室，亦犹姑射山有神人居焉。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 绵绵，调息似有若无，用之要不至勤劳尔。 休休庵曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 虚明谓之谷，灵妙谓之神。 虚明灵妙无穷谓之不死，即玄牝也。 玄者，大道也。 牝者，母也。 一气生於虚明之中，然后分清浊立天地，故云玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 妙道无为，一气运行不绝，是谓绵绵若存。 应时应机，利生济物，不劳而办，故云不劝。 虚明灵妙，在人曰心。 心为万法王，能生育天地，运行日月，玄机妙用，任运无穷，随缘应感，不劳而办，悟明者不言而知已。 褚伯秀曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 谷虚而善应，神灵而无方，人能以至灵之物藏至虚之所，则随感而应。 应已无迹，生尚不知，死乎何有？ 玄谓道妙难测，牝乃化育之地。 其为用也，妙万物而能生生，是之谓不死。 此发明虚心养神之道，借天地造化为言，始於虚心而任化，终於无心而化自己出。 凡物之生，本莫不由斯，故称门焉。 庄子云：天门者，无有也二万物出於无有。 以《易》言即太极，以人言即性。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Spirit of Grain* [谷神] is the *divine essence within the void* [虚中之神者也]. It is said that *human spirit emerges from the void* [人之神自虚中而出], hence it *endures perpetually without perishing* [故常存而不死].

*Mysterious* [玄] is that which is *remote and boundless* [远而无极者也]. *Feminine* [牝] is that which is *void and unsubstantial* [虚而不实者也]. These two characters merely describe the *void* [虚].

*Heaven and Earth* [天地] arise from this, hence it is called the *root* [根]. *Continuous* [绵绵] conveys the meaning of *unceasing, unbroken* [不已、不绝]. *As if existing* [若存] means *as if present, as if absent* [若有若无]. When applied within the *void and nothingness* [虚无之中], it *endures without labor* [不劳而常存], thus it is said: *void yet unyielding, in motion yet ever emerging* [虚而不屈，动而愈出].

*Master Huì* [晦翁] says: *The most wondrous principle* [至妙之理] contains the *intent of eternal generation* [有生生之意存焉]. This passage is well-phrased, though its meaning leans toward *theories of nourishing life* [养生之论]. Though this chapter may be applied to *cultivation and nourishment* [修养], its original intent was not *exclusively for this purpose* [实不专主是].

*Master Fàn Yīngyuán* [范应元] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is called *the Mysterious Feminine* [是谓玄牝]. *The Spirit of Grain* [谷神] is akin to *void luminosity* [犹言虚灵也]. *Not perishing* [不死] is akin to *boundlessness* [犹言无极也]. *The Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] speaks of *that which generates all things yet remains unseen in its generation* [言其生物而不见其所以生也]. It is said: *void luminosity, boundlessness*—this is the *feminine principle of generation* [虚灵无极], which is unseen in its generation, hence it is called *mysterious* [玄]. *The Spirit of Grain* [谷神]—*Fù Yì* [傅奕] says it is *profound yet penetrating* [幽而通也].

*Sīmǎ Wēngōng* [司马温公] says: *It is called Grain because it is centrally void* [中虚故曰谷], *it is called Spirit because it is unfathomable* [不测故曰神]. *Sū* [苏] says: *Grain is supremely void yet still retains form* [谷至虚而犹有形], *but the Spirit of Grain is void and formless* [谷神则虚而无形也]. If it is *void and formless*, how could there be *anything to die* [虚而无形尚无有生，安有死邪]? Calling it *the Spirit of Grain* [谷神] speaks of its *virtue* [言其德也]; calling it *the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] speaks of its *function* [言其功也]. The *Mysterious Feminine* generates all things yet *remains unseen in its generation* [牝生万物而谓之玄], how could one see its generation without seeing *how it generates* [焉见其生之而不见其所以生也]?

*The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝之门] is called *the root of Heaven and Earth* [是谓天地根]. *Gate* [门] refers to *yin and yang* [指阴阳也]. It is said that *one opening, one closing*—*endless coming and going* [以其一辟一阖，往来不穷而言也]. *Yin and yang* [阴阳者] are spoken of in terms of *the Dao’s motion and stillness* [以道之动静而言也]. When in motion, it is called *yang* [动而曰阳]; when motion reaches its extreme and stillness ensues, it is called *yin* [动极而静曰阴]. Motion reaching its extreme turns to stillness, stillness reaching its extreme turns back to motion—*opening and closing without error* [动极而静，静极复动，开阖不忒], *generation and nurture without end* [生育无穷]. *Root* [根] means *Heaven and Earth originate from this* [谓天地本於此也].

If a person *first attains this in their heart* [人能於此心之初得之], they will know that *the root of Heaven and Earth is a root without root* [天地之根，无根之根也]; *the Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is a gate without gate* [玄牝之门，无门之门也]; *the Spirit of Grain is a spirit without spirit* [谷神，不神之神也]. How could it ever be exhausted?

*Continuous, as if existing* [绵绵若存], *used without exertion* [用之不勤]. It is said that *the Spirit of Grain in Heaven and Earth is continuous and boundless* [谓谷神之在天地，绵绵密密而无极也]. Yet *it cannot be seen when viewed* [然视之不可见], *cannot be heard when listened to* [听之不得闻], *cannot be exhausted when used* [用之不可既], hence it is said: *as if existing*—*Heaven and Earth use it, and the four seasons proceed, all things flourish, yet they never labor* [故曰若存，天地用之而四时行、百物生，未尝劳也]. The *Spirit of Grain in humans* [谷神在人] is likewise.

*Continuous and boundless* [绵绵密密], *eternally generating* [生生无穷], *as its origin*—who could claim dominion over this body? *As its origin*—where could it ultimately reside? Hence it is said: *as if existing* [故曰若存]. Those who *skillfully use it* [善用之者] *never labor* [未尝劳也], how could it ever be exhausted? This chapter should be *profoundly understood* [宜深体之]. Some may interpret it *exclusively for cultivation and nourishment* [或有专就修养上解者], yet one must *first recognize the Spirit of Grain* [然必须认得谷神方可].

*Xuē Yōngzhāi* [薛庸斋] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is called *the root of Heaven and Earth* [至是谓天地根]. *Grain* [谷] is where *the spirit resides* [神所居]. *Spirit* [神] is what *the form carries* [形所载]. *Nourishing the form to vitalize the qi, containing the qi to harbor the spirit*—this is the *Way of non-perishing* [以形养气，以气含神，不死之道也]. *Spirit inherently does not perish* [神本无死], yet when *assigned to form, it has death* [赋于形而有死], though even in death it *has not truly died* [虽死而未尝死也]. The *Spirit of Grain* [谷神] *does not perish because of the Mysterious Feminine* [因玄牝不死], and *Heaven and Earth take the Mysterious Feminine as their root* [天地以玄牝为根].

*The Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] is *internal* [内焉], yet *harbors essence externally* [而藏精外焉], *adjusting breath*—*one opening, one closing* [而调息一开一阖], *one exhalation, one inhalation* [一呼一吸]. Exhaling reaches *the deep root* [呼则至於深根], inhaling reaches *the firm base* [吸则至於固蒂]. Thus *the spirit enters* [于是有神入焉], *revolving through the Dipper* [离斗辗历天廷], *riding the sun and moon, parting clouds and mists* [骑日月披云雾], *soaring and returning to the Hall of Great Possession* [腾腾乎会归于大有之室], much like the *divine beings dwelling on Mount Gūshè* [亦犹姑射山有神人居焉].

*Continuous, as if existing* [绵绵若存], *used without exertion* [用之不勤]. *Continuous* [绵绵] means *adjusting breath as if present, as if absent* [调息似有若无], *its use requires no labor* [用之要不至勤劳尔].

*Xiū Xiū’ān* [休休庵] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—*used without exertion* [至用之不勤]. *Void and luminous* [虚明] is called *Grain* [谓之谷], *subtle and wondrous* [灵妙] is called *Spirit* [谓之神]. *Void, luminous, subtle, and wondrous without end* [虚明灵妙无穷] is called *not perishing* [谓之不死], which is the *Mysterious Feminine* [即玄牝也]. *Mysterious* [玄] is the *Great Dao* [大道也]. *Feminine* [牝] is the *Mother* [母也]. *One vital breath* [一气] *generates within the void and luminosity* [生於虚明之中], then *clears and turbid divide to establish Heaven and Earth* [然后分清浊立天地], hence it is said: *The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is the root of Heaven and Earth* [故云玄牝之门，是谓天地根].

*The wondrous Dao acts without action* [妙道无为], *one vital breath runs unceasingly* [一气运行不绝], hence it is called *continuous, as if existing* [是谓绵绵若存]. *Responding to the times, adapting to circumstances* [应时应机], *benefiting life and aiding all things* [利生济物], *accomplished without labor* [不劳而办], hence it is said: *not exerting* [故云不劝].

*Void, luminous, subtle, and wondrous* [虚明灵妙] in humans is called *heart* [在人曰心]. The *heart is sovereign over all phenomena* [心为万法王], capable of *generating Heaven and Earth, running the sun and moon* [能生育天地，运行日月], *wondrous mechanisms and marvelous functions* [玄机妙用], *effortlessly boundless* [任运无穷], *responding to circumstances and sensations* [随缘应感], *accomplished without labor* [不劳而办]. Those who *awaken and clarify* [悟明者] *understand without being told* [不言而知已].

*Zhù Bóxìu* [褚伯秀] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—*used without exertion* [谷神不死至用之不勤]. *Grain is void yet responsive* [谷虚而善应], *Spirit is luminous yet boundless* [神灵而无方]. If a person *harbors the most luminous essence within the most void place* [人能以至灵之物藏至虚之所], then *they respond to sensations without trace* [则随感而应]. *Response leaves no mark* [应已无迹], *life does not even know its own generation* [生尚不知], *how could death exist* [死乎何有]?

*Mysterious* [玄] refers to *the Dao’s profound, unfathomable nature* [道妙难测], *Feminine* [牝] is *the realm of transformation and nurturing* [化育之地]. Its *function* [其为用也] *is wondrous in generating all things yet eternally generates* [妙万物而能生生], hence it is called *not perishing* [是之谓不死].

This elucidates *the Way of void-hearted spirit-nourishment* [此发明虚心养神之道], borrowing *Heaven and Earth’s creative transformation* [借天地造化为言], beginning with *void-heartedness and yielding to transformation* [始於虚心而任化], ending with *effortless self-transformation* [终於无心而化自己出]. All things’ generation *originates from this* [凡物之生，本莫不由斯], hence it is called *Gate* [故称门焉].

*Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子] says: *The Heavenly Gate* [天门者]—*there is no such thing* [无有也]—*all things emerge from non-being* [二万物出於无有]. In terms of the *Yì* [《易》], this is the *Tàijí* [太极]; in terms of humans, this is *nature* [以人言即性].

chunks.original_text: 初乃一化之所待，万理众甫之都会也。 人人具足而放不知求，则谷非其谷，神不自神，如天地万物何？ 夫形者生之，含气者生之，元神者生之。 制三者住而生道昌，身中玄牝见矣。 绵绵守而无失，若存恍惚之间，则亦何动之有？ 此章语简意深，犹孟子论浩然编之气，在人充养而后见，通身是道，悟者自得，非语言所能尽也。 前辈议方外，谈道多详其精，而略其粗，有上达而无下学。 混元置此章於美恶贤货橐钥之后，亦该贯而无间，但语极玄奥，学者惮其高远，而不敢即。 今不揆浅陋，僭於影外描影，云谷神犹无极，玄牝犹太极，绵绵法太极之氤氲布化，而生道不息也。 谷神言其体，玄牝言其化，绵绵言其用。 人能反求诸身则自已。 天地之根，不言而喻。 今世之养生家，其论亦以谷神玄牝为主，但泥於形质，取诸心肾上下口鼻呼吸之间。 此皆后 天之土苴耳。 至於天地根、万物宗者，皆遗而弗究，何足以明谷神之妙？ 按《列子》称《黄帝书》云，乃全载此章。 盖古有此语，混元亦述而不作之意。 牛妙传曰：谷神不死，是谓玄牝。 谷者，养也。 神者，上药三品中之一也。 玄牝者，鼻之左右孔也。 故大修行人有胎息法，从外玄牝通内玄牝，导引太和真气，注想丹田，久而行之，则其身长存，故云不死也。 《玉清胎元内养经》云：胎元妙道，以外玄牝合内玄牝，以外真神补内真气，聚集天之万宝我胎之元精，使神生於胎，气恋於神，心君潜御，气息调匀，绵绵若存而不息，用之不穷而见功。 谷神不死，合我真宗。 此之谓也。
chunks.translated_text:
The beginning is the *one source* [一化] *awaiting transformation*, the *gathering place of myriad principles and myriad things* [万理众甫之都会].

If each person possesses it fully yet ignores its pursuit, then *the Valley* [谷] *is not truly the Valley*, *the Spirit* [神] *does not manifest itself as Spirit*—how can one relate to Heaven and Earth, to all things?

The *form* [形] *nourishes life*, *the contained qi* [含气] *nourishes life*, and *the primordial spirit* [元神] *nourishes life*.
When these three are regulated and abide, the *Dao flourishes* [生道昌].
Within the body, the *Void-hearted Mother* [身中玄牝] is seen.

Continuously guarding it without loss,
like preserving something in the realm of *faint and elusive* [恍惚],
then what movement could there be?

This chapter’s words are *concise yet profound* [语简意深],
akin to *Mencius* [孟子] discussing the *浩然* [浩然] *qi of righteousness*—
it manifests only after cultivation within the person,
permeating the body as the *Dao itself*.
Those who awaken grasp it naturally;
it cannot be fully exhausted by mere words.

Earlier masters, discussing *Dao* from beyond the orthodox [方外],
often elaborated its *refined essence* [精] yet neglected its *coarse manifestations* [粗],
achieving *transcendence* [上达] but lacking *foundational study* [下学].

*Huǐnyuán* [混元] placed this chapter after *Beauty and Evil, Virtue and Wealth, and the Keys to the Mysteries* [美恶贤货橐钥],
unifying them without separation,
but its language is *profoundly abstruse* [玄奥],
so scholars fear its *height and distance* [高远] and dare not approach it directly.

Now, without heeding my own *shallow inadequacy* [浅陋],
I presume to sketch beyond the shadow—
*the Valley-Spirit* [谷神] *is akin to the Non-ultimate* [无极],
the *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] *is akin to the Tàijí* [太极].
The *continuous method* [绵绵] *mirrors the Tàijí’s* [太极] *pervasive diffusion* [氤氲布化],
giving rise to an unceasing *Dao* [生道不息].

*The Valley* [谷] refers to its *substance* [体],
the *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] to its *transformation* [化],
and *continuous* [绵绵] to its *application* [用].
If one can *inwardly seek it within oneself* [反求诸身],
then self-transformation is achieved.

The *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之根] is *implied without words* [不言而喻].
In the present age, those who practice *life-nourishment* [养生家],
their teachings also center on *Valley-Spirit and Void-hearted Mother* [谷神玄牝],
yet they fixate on *physical form and material essence* [形质],
extracting it from the *kidneys and heart* [心肾], or from *breathing through mouth and nose* [口鼻呼吸].
These are but *later Heaven’s crude residues* [土苴] after all.

As for the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之根] and the *origin of myriad things* [万物宗],
they are abandoned and not explored—
how can they illuminate the *wondrous essence of Valley-Spirit* [谷神之妙]?

According to *The Liezi* [《列子》], it cites *The Yellow Emperor’s Book* [《黄帝书》],
which preserves this chapter entirely.
Evidently, these words existed in antiquity,
and *Huǐnyuán* [混元] merely *recounted them without original composition* [述而不作].

*Niú Miào* [牛妙]’s transmission states:
*The Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死], hence it is called *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝].
*The Valley* [谷] is *nourishment* [养].
*Spirit* [神] is one of the *three highest elixirs* [上药三品] in the *Daoist canon*.
*The Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] refers to the *two nostrils* [鼻之左右孔].

Thus, *great cultivators* [大修行人] practice the *method of fetal breathing* [胎息法],
from *external Void-hearted Mother* [外玄牝] to *internal Void-hearted Mother* [内玄牝],
guiding and drawing the *true qi of Supreme Harmony* [太和真气],
focusing intent on the *elixir field* [丹田].
With prolonged practice,
their bodies endure eternally—
hence it is said, *the Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死].

*The Jade Purity Fetal Essence Inner Nourishment Classic* [《玉清胎元内养经》] states:
*The wondrous Dao of the Fetal Essence* [胎元妙道],
uniting *external Void-hearted Mother* [外玄牝] with *internal Void-hearted Mother* [内玄牝],
supplementing *external true spirit* [外真神] with *internal true qi* [内真气],
gathering *Heaven’s myriad treasures* [天之万宝] and *my own fetal essence* [我胎之元精],
so that *spirit is born from the fetus* [神生於胎],
*qi clings to the spirit* [气恋於神],
the *heart-sovereign* [心君] *governs in concealment* [潜御],
*breathing is smooth and even* [气息调匀],
*continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing* [绵绵若存而不息],
*endless in its application yet manifesting its efficacy* [用之不穷而见功].
*The Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死] is the *union with my true origin* [合我真宗].
This is the meaning.

chunks.original_text: 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 夫玄牝之说，有内有外。 外则前已释过，内则乃口口相传之机，不记文字。 所以张平叔《悟真篇》有曰：玄牝者，非心非肾、非肝非肺、非脾非三焦、非膀胱非丹田。 然则审何所耶？ 又曰：玄真玄牝，真牝玄牝，都来共一窍。 然此奥理，不遇明师终是难知。 愚尝读《道藏修行论》，有曰玄牝者居二肾之间，号称神室，乃神明所会之府，精气交感之区，人之命门，故称天地根。 盖人身号小天地也。 绵绵若存，用之不动。 此言胎息导引之法，不紧不缓，若存若亡之间，任其鼻息绵绵来往，不待驱而使之。 故云用之不勤也。 《玉帝心印经》 云：上药三品，神与气精。 恍恍惚惚，杳杳冥冥，存无守有，顷刻而成。 回风混合，百日通灵。 出入玄牝，若亡若存。 绵绵不绝，固蒂深根，人各有精，精极成神。 神合有气，气合体真。 神依气生，精依气盈。 其聚则有，其散则零。 三品一理，妙不可听。 一得永得，自然身轻。 太和充溢，骨化寒琼。 此之谓也。 杨智仁曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 谷神者，天谷元神也。 鸿蒙始判，先有此神。 与太虚同体，与天地同生。 神之来则生，神之去则死。 然生亦未尝生也，死亦未尝死也。 为阴阳之主，为万灵之尊。 渊渊浩浩，日月不得此则不能耀明，五行不得此则不能发生，万物不得此则不能长育。 其不死者，玄牝也。 玄为真阳，牝为真阴。 上通於天，下蟠於地，周流六虚，上下无常。 在丹为真铅汞，在《易》为坎离，在象为龙虎。 人能修之，坎离消长於一身，风云发泄於七窍，真炁熏蒸而无寒暑，纯阳流注而无死生，是谓玄牝之功也。 且门者，乃日月之门户也。 非心肾，非口鼻，非泥丸，非脐下，非脐中一寸二分圆如环者，非夹脊双关，非心上一穴，非闭炁而行之，若执此则谬之甚矣。 何不返观天地之根乎？ 《易》 曰寂然不动者诚也，感而遂通者神也，玄牝之门也。 动而未形之间者，几也，天地之根也。 诚精故明，神应故妙，几微故幽，诚几曰圣。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 喻清中曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 老氏一书，治国爱民，修心养性，服气炼神，精粗毕举，本末兼该。 此章大槩主於修养，当合儒道之书而互相发明之。 自儒家之说言之，谷者，虚也； 神者，虚中之神也。 自道家之说言之，谷，天谷也； 神者，一身之元神也。 元神所住之宫，其空如谷而神居之，故谓之谷神，泥丸宫是也。 神存则生，神去则死，谷神之所以不死者，由玄牝也。 阳神为玄，阴息为牝，神气交感，自然成真。 与道为一，而入於不死不生，故曰谷神不死，是谓玄牝。 《黄帝阴符经》曰：口通五脏，出者重浊之气属阴，谓之地根。 鼻通六腑，出者轻清之气属阳，谓之天根。 口鼻二者，阳神阴息，往来之门，故曰玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 圣人运用此气於升降之顷，存炼此气於呼吸之间，绵绵续续，勿令间断，存者顺其自然而存之，神久自宁，息久自定。 未尝至於勤劳迫促。 故曰用之不勤。 儒道之书，共归一揆，列子全引此章，指为黄帝曰，则老氏之言似有所自。 或人谓人身中自有一窍，非口鼻也，非心肾也，非谷道也，其要未易言，俟与谈玄者商之。 胥六虚曰：谷神不死，是谓玄牝。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Now, the discourse on the Mysterious Female has **inner and outer** aspects. The **outer** has already been explained above; the **inner** is a **mouth-to-mouth transmitted** secret, not recorded in texts. Thus, Zhang Pingzhong’s *Awakening to the True* [《悟真篇》] states:

*The Mysterious Female*—
not the heart, not the kidneys,
not the liver, not the lungs,
not the spleen, not the Triple Burner,
not the bladder, not the elixir field [丹田].

Then what is it?
It is further said:
*The True Mysterious Female, the Mysterious True Female*—
all converge at a single orifice.

Yet this profound principle,
without an enlightened teacher, is difficult to know.

I once read the *Daoist Canon on Cultivation* [《道藏修行论》], which states:
*The Mysterious Female resides between the two kidneys,*
called the **Divine Chamber**—
the **Palace where the Spirit-Sovereigns assemble**,
the **Region where essence and qi intermingle**,
the **Gate of Life**—
thus called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

For the human body is a **miniature Heaven and Earth**.

Continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing—
this speaks of the **Fetal Breath cultivation method**:
neither strained nor slack,
as if present yet as if absent,
letting the nasal breath flow gently in and out,
without forcing it.
Thus it is said: *its use requires no effort* [用之不勤].

The *Jade Emperor’s Heart-Seal Scripture* [《玉帝心印经》] states:
*The three supreme elixirs*—
**Spirit, Qi, and Essence**.
Vague and indistinct,
dim and obscure,
preserved yet not held,
instantly perfected.

The **cyclic winds merge**—
in a hundred days, the **Spirit becomes luminous**.
Entering and exiting the **Mysterious Female**,
as if absent yet as if present,
endlessly unbroken,
firmly rooted—
each person has their **essence**,
and when essence is perfected, **spirit is born**.

When spirit unites with **qi**, and **qi unites with the body’s true nature**,
spirit depends on qi to manifest,
essence depends on qi to flourish.
When gathered, it exists;
when scattered, it dissipates.

The three elixirs share one principle—
wondrous beyond words.
Obtain it once, and it is eternal—
naturally, the body becomes light.
The **Great Harmony** overflows,
bones transmute into **frosted jade**.

This is the meaning.

Yang Zhiren says:
*From "Valley-Spirit does not perish" to "its use requires no effort."*
The **Valley-Spirit**—
this is the **Heavenly Primordial Spirit** [天谷元神].
At the **Hun-Dong’s** [鸿蒙] initial division,
this spirit existed first.
It shares substance with the **Great Void**,
and is born with Heaven and Earth.
When the spirit arrives, life begins;
when the spirit departs, death comes.
Yet life is never truly born,
and death is never truly death.

It is the **Sovereign of Yin and Yang**,
the **Exalted Lord of all Spirits**.
Profound and vast—
without it, the sun and moon cannot shine,
without it, the Five Phases cannot flourish,
without it, all things cannot grow.
Its immortality lies in the **Mysterious Female**.

*Mysterious* is **True Yang**,
*Female* is **True Yin**.
Above, it connects to Heaven;
below, it coils within Earth,
circulating through the **Six Voids**,
without fixed abode above or below.

In the elixir, it is **True Lead and Mercury** [真铅汞];
in the *I Ching*, it is **Kan and Li** [坎离];
in the symbols, it is **Dragon and Tiger**.
When a person cultivates it,
Kan and Li wax and wane within the body,
winds and clouds surge through the **Seven Orifices**,
true *qi* steams and warms without cold or heat,
pure Yang flows and nourishes without birth or death—
this is the **function of the Mysterious Female**.

Moreover, the **Gate**—
this is the **portal of the sun and moon**.
Not the heart or kidneys,
not the mouth or nose,
not the **Cinnabar Field** [泥丸],
not the **elixir field below the navel**,
not the **one-inch circular orifice within the navel**,
not the **double gate between the shoulder blades**,
not the **orifice above the heart**,
nor is it a matter of **closing the breath and forcing it**—
to fixate on these is utterly mistaken.
Why not return to the **Root of Heaven and Earth**?

The *I Ching* says:
*The still and unmoving is sincerity* [诚],
*responding and thus communicating is spirit*—
this is the **Gate of the Mysterious Female**.
*The movement before form takes shape is the subtle*—
this is the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Sincerity is refined, thus clear;
spirit responds, thus wondrous;
the subtle is profound, thus mysterious.
Sincerity and subtlety—this is **sagacity**.

Continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing—
its use requires no effort.

Jù Qīngzhōng says:
*From "Valley-Spirit does not perish" to "its use requires no effort."*

The *Book of Laozi* treats **governance and benevolence**,
**cultivating the heart and nurturing nature**,
**breath-work and spirit-refining**—
both coarse and subtle, beginning and end,
all encompassed.
This chapter primarily concerns **cultivation and nourishment**,
and should be harmonized with **Confucian and Daoist texts** for mutual elucidation.

From the **Confucian perspective**:
*Valley* means **emptiness**;
*Spirit* means **the spirit within emptiness**.

From the **Daoist perspective**:
*Valley* is the **Heavenly Valley**;
*Spirit* is the **Primordial Spirit of the body**.
The **Palace where the Primordial Spirit resides**—
its emptiness is like a valley, yet the spirit dwells within—
thus it is called **Valley-Spirit**, the **Cinnabar Field Palace** [泥丸宫].
When the spirit is preserved, life continues;
when the spirit departs, death comes.
The reason the **Valley-Spirit does not perish**
lies in the **Mysterious Female**.

The **Yang Spirit** is *Mysterious*,
the **Yin Breath** is *Female*—
when spirit and breath intermingle,
true essence naturally forms.
Uniting with the **Way**, it enters **neither death nor birth**—
thus: *Valley-Spirit does not perish*—
this is the **Mysterious Female**.

The *Yellow Emperor’s Secret of Yin* [《黄帝阴符经》] states:
*The mouth connects to the five viscera*—
the exhaled breath is **heavy and turbid**, belonging to **Yin**—
called the **Earthly Root**.
*The nose connects to the six bowels*—
the exhaled breath is **light and pure**, belonging to **Yang**—
called the **Heavenly Root**.
The mouth and nose—
the **Yang Spirit and Yin Breath**—
are the **passageways of their coming and going**,
thus called the **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

The Sage **directs this breath** during **ascent and descent**,
**preserves and refines it** within **inhalation and exhalation**,
continuously, without interruption.
Preserve it by following its natural course—
over time, the spirit naturally settles,
the breath naturally steadies.
It is never forced or hastened.
Thus it is said: *its use requires no effort*.

The **Confucian and Daoist texts** converge in principle.
Liezi fully cites this chapter, attributing it to the Yellow Emperor,
suggesting Laozi’s words may have had an origin.

Some say the human body contains **one orifice**—
not the mouth or nose,
not the heart or kidneys,
not the **Valley Passage** [谷道]—
yet its essence is difficult to articulate.
Let those who discuss the **Mysterious** deliberate further.

Xū Liùxū says:
*Valley-Spirit does not perish*—
this is the **Mysterious Female**.

chunks.original_text: 谷取其虚，神言不测，不死谓常存也。 言虚谷之中，其中有神，阴阳不测，古今常存，故曰谷神不死。 以其不死，是以谓之玄牝。 玄，远也。 牝，生也。 谓自古以来不知其几亿万年，深远难测，其生生之理无有穷尽，故曰玄牝。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 门，通出也，根本也。 谓玄牝之门，天地由兹而出，万物由兹而生，乃天地万物之根本。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 绵绵者，微而不绝，言玄牝之体也。 不勤者，玄牝之功用也。 谓玄牝之门，自古迄今，微而不绝，虽视之不见，其生生之妙用，显若存焉耳，曷尝见其有辞劳乎？ 此章从首至末只是一谷神，圣人铺舒如此，奇哉。 噫，此一谷神，人自生至老须臾不可离者，其容状功能，与此更无毫分差忒。 信之者不劳余力，领解将去。 若生拟议，鹞子已过新罗。 李是从曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 谷神不死，是谓玄牝者，谷乃空虚也，天地大谷也，山泽小谷也。 神乃灵性，神在空虚，藉气而响，山泽无情，呼之应呜。 我神非形，赖气而声不死者，常存不亡也。 玄，灵心也。 牝，意气也。 心用未发而人不知曰玄，气化未成而事不见曰牝。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根者，用舍出入放去收来之门，道从此一气而生，天地、万物、人从此一心而生出，用在万事机发所由之根本也。 绵绵若存，用之不勤者，继续不断，常存不亡也。 施用徐缓，勿可动劳，伤损神气也。 柴元皋曰：谷神不死，是谓玄牝。 谷，虚也，不死，常惺惺也。 万念动底根本，物欲昏了时便见，虚时便活。 玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 乾辟坤阖出入处。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 真人息，以踵不勤也。 常人息，以喉勤也。 必有事焉而勿正心、勿忘、勿助长，此不勤之用也。 非乾坤易之门邪？ 苏敬静曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 此章以养气为言者。 河上公、张冲应皆以玄牝为鼻口。 鼻口为呼吸出纳之门。 根，元也。 言鼻口乃通天地元气所从往来。 绵绵不绝，其微妙若无又若存，气得其养，则用之不劳余力，自然长生久视。 至唐明皇方以谷之应声，莫知所以，有感则应，其应如神。 老子书中取谷为喻不一也，曰旷兮其若谷，曰谷得一以盈，曰为天下谷，曰江海能为百谷王，皆以其能下也，惟此特曰谷神不死，曰绵绵若存，从其不死若存而求之，则能下不足以尽之。 必如明皇应声出响为义，方可尽不死若存之意。 夫影响一也，影之写形，日月水火也，若夫声之出响，发於野则散，触乎山则窒。 惟声出於空谷，则能出响於无而若有神，然后知其不死若存者，真为不妄。 黄帝曰：形动不生形而生影，声动不生声而生响，无动不生无而生有。 则谷之能神，信可推矣。 当其空也则无也，及其声之触也，则应感而能有者也。 有触斯应，此其不死而若存之神也。 玄者，妙也。 牝者，应而不倡。 谷之蕴响待声是不倡也。 苟声不感，则响之应终不出； 声出，则响应。 神妙如此，是谓天地根。 天地生於太极，太极本於无，无能生有，有生於无。 响能应声，即无能生有，不谓之天地根而何故？ 前章言无名，天地之始。 而此言天地之根，根与始一也。 绵绵者，前响已绝，后声再触，其应如故。 故以若存言之，谷神不亡。 若用而愈有，似劳如实不勤，动以其虚，以其无，虚能生实，无能生有，非神而何？
chunks.translated_text:
The **Valley** takes its emptiness—
the **Spirit’s** words are unfathomable.
*"Not dying"* means it abides eternally.

Speaking of the emptiness within the **Valley**,
within it resides the **Spirit**—
unfathomable in yin and yang,
eternal from ancient times to now.
Thus it is said: *"The Valley-Spirit does not die."*

Because it does not die,
it is called the **Mysterious Female**.
*"Mysterious"* means distant.
*"Female"* means birth.
It speaks of the countless eons since antiquity,
profound and unfathomable,
its principle of generation endless—
thus it is called the **Mysterious Female**.

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.
*"Gate"* means passage and foundation.
The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
from it Heaven and Earth emerge,
from it all things are born—
the very foundation of Heaven and Earth.

Continuous as if preserved,
its use requires no effort.
*"Continuous"* means subtle yet unbroken—
the very body of the **Mysterious Female**.
*"No effort"* is its function—
the **Gate of the Mysterious Female**,
from antiquity to now,
subtle yet unbroken,
though unseen in sight,
its wondrous generative power
manifests as if present—
how could it ever be said to labor?

This chapter, from beginning to end,
speaks only of the **Valley-Spirit**—
the Sage unfolds it thus, how marvelous!
Ah! This **Valley-Spirit**,
from birth to old age,
never for a moment departs from man—
its form, function,
differ not in the slightest.

Those who believe need no further force;
those who grasp it will depart.
If one speculates while alive,
the falcon has already passed beyond Silla.

Li Shifu says:
From *"The Valley-Spirit does not die"* to *"its use requires no effort"*—
*"The Valley-Spirit does not die"* is called the **Mysterious Female**,
for the **Valley** is emptiness—
the great **Valley** of Heaven and Earth,
the small **Valleys** of mountains and marshes.
The **Spirit** is the numinous essence—
the **Spirit** abides in emptiness,
borrowing *qi* to resonate.
Mountains and marshes, though lifeless,
when called, respond with echoes.
My **Spirit** is formless,
relying on *qi* to sound—
undying, eternally preserved.

*"Mysterious"* is the subtle heart.
*"Female"* is the intent of *qi*.
Before the heart’s use manifests,
men do not perceive it—*"Mysterious."*
Before *qi* transforms,
the deed remains unseen—*"Female."*

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**—
the passage of giving and receiving,
of release and return.
From this single *qi*, the Dao is born;
from this single heart, Heaven, Earth, and all things emerge—
the foundation of all affairs’ mechanisms.

Continuous as if preserved,
its use requires no effort—
unbroken and eternal,
unwaning.
Apply it gently, never forcing,
lest the **Spirit** and *qi* be injured.

Chai Yuangao says:
*"The Valley-Spirit does not die"*—
this is called the **Mysterious Female**.
The **Valley** is emptiness,
*"not dying"* is perpetual wakefulness.
When the myriad thoughts stir,
the root is revealed—
when emptiness prevails, it revives.

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.
The opening and closing of *Kàn* and *Hūn*.
Continuous as if preserved,
its use requires no effort.
The **True Person’s** breath—
resting on the heels, effortless.
The common man’s breath—
through the throat, labored.
There must be action, yet
the mind must not be fixed,
forget not,
nor force growth—
this is the effortless use.

Is it not the Gate of *Kàn* and *Hūn*?

Su Jingjing says:
From *"The Valley-Spirit does not die"* to *"its use requires no effort"*—
this chapter speaks of nurturing *qi*.
The Master of the Yellow River and Zhang Chong
both took the **Mysterious Female** as the nose and mouth—
the passage for inhaling and exhaling.
*"Root"* means origin.
The nose and mouth are the passageways
through which Heaven and Earth’s primal *qi* circulates.
Continuous and unbroken,
its subtlety is as if nonexistent yet present—
when *qi* is nourished,
its use requires no extra force,
naturally extending life and vision.

Even the Tang Emperor Minghuang,
when the **Valley** responded to sound,
knew not how—
when stimulated, it responded,
as if divine.
In Laozi’s text, the **Valley** is used as metaphor repeatedly:
*"Vast, like the **Valley**,"*
*"The **Valley** that holds One is full,"*
*"Be the **Valley** of the world,"*
*"The rivers and seas can be kings of the **Valleys**,"*
all because of their ability to descend.
Yet here it uniquely says:
*"The Valley-Spirit does not die,"*
*"Continuous as if preserved."*
If one seeks it from its undying, as-if-preserved nature,
descending alone cannot exhaust it.
Only as the Emperor’s responsive echo
can the meaning of *"not dying yet as-if-preserved"* be fully grasped.

Echo and shadow are one—
shadows trace form,
from the sun, moon, water, fire.
But sound’s resonance:
when uttered in the wild, it scatters;
when striking mountains, it is stifled.
Only when sound emerges from an empty **Valley**
does it resonate as if from nothing—
divinely so.
Then one knows that *"not dying yet as-if-preserved"*
is truly without deceit.

The Yellow Emperor said:
When form moves, it does not generate form—
it generates shadow.
When sound moves, it does not generate sound—
it generates resonance.
When the void moves, it does not generate the void—
it generates the existent.

Thus the **Valley’s** ability to manifest as **Spirit** is indeed verifiable.
When it is empty, it is void;
when sound strikes it, it responds—
sensing, it manifests.
This sensing-response is its undying, as-if-preserved **Spirit**.

*"Mysterious"* is subtlety.
*"Female"* is responding without initiating.
The **Valley’s** storing of resonance awaiting sound—
this is *"not initiating."*
If sound does not strike,
the resonance’s response never emerges;
when sound strikes, the resonance responds.
So subtle is its **Spirit**—
thus it is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Heaven and Earth are born from the **Supreme Polarity**,
the **Supreme Polarity** originates from the void,
the void can generate the existent,
the existent is born from the void.
Resonance responds to sound—
the void generating the existent—
if not called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**, why?

The previous chapter speaks of the *Nameless*,
the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
This speaks of the **Root of Heaven and Earth**—
root and beginning are one.

*"Continuous"*—
when the prior resonance fades,
the next sound strikes,
its response remains unchanged.
Thus it is said to *"as-if-preserve"*—
the **Valley-Spirit** does not perish.
If used, the more it is applied,
it seems labored yet truly requires no effort—
move with its emptiness,
with its void.
The void generates the real,
the nonexistent generates the existent—
what else could it be but **Spirit**?

The **Confucian and Daoist texts** converge in principle.
Liezi fully cites this chapter, attributing it to the Yellow Emperor,
suggesting Laozi’s words may have had an origin.

Some say the human body contains **one orifice**—
not the mouth or nose,
not the heart or kidneys,
not the **Valley Passage** [谷道]—
yet its essence is difficult to articulate.
Let those who discuss the **Mysterious** deliberate further.

Xū Liùxū says:
*Valley-Spirit does not perish*—
this is the **Mysterious Female**.

chunks.original_text: 若夫养气之说，又是人推广以为言也。 吴环中曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 环中吴埈曰：老子一书中寓仙意，魂常养魄不耗散，而水火交。 其说甚异。 愚闻之师曰：谷神先天一气，神气归虚玄牝，念头动处假神托用，非口鼻也。 玄，阳也，牝，阴也，真阴真阳也。 庄子云：万物莫不有生而莫知其根，有乎出而莫知其门。 然天地之所从出者，玄牝是已。 金丹大药，其要不出乎精神魂魄意。 神，火也； 精，水也； 乃真一之精。 魂，木也； 魄，金也； 意，土也。 五行非土不成洁，意以养气。 养气以凝精，凝精以姤神，四象和合，打成一片，工夫纯熟，专气致柔，久则凝结。 绵绵若存，不可间断。 用之不勤，昼夜一致，自然之理。 古仙隐显，其言体之为阴阳，拟之为铅汞，喻之为日月，效之为男女，比之为龙虎，曰震兑，曰坎离，曰金砂，甲庚，丙壬，戊己，水火，君臣，子母，婴儿妮女，刀圭金木，温养主宾，浮沉沐浴，生杀刑德战斗，圆缺抽添，文武炎凉，进退斤两等语，皆玄牝上事。 故立象以寓言，欲人之自得也，只可身上讨，不可身外求。 岂不闻虚静先生神御气，气留形不须杂术自长生之旨乎？ 今学道者虽识药材，无下手处。 既知下手，不识法度，於玄牝上茫然莫知。 神者，生之本。 形者，神之合。 神全则气全，气全则精全，精全则形全，形全则神旺，神旺则气灵，气灵则神彻。 始与道为一，神亏则精不复，精弊则魄不宁。 公读书岂不晓物交物之际，每胶扰於旦昼夜寐之时，视听言动之间，又复来往於耳目心思之所不及。 此古昔上仙屏弃利欲，超出物表，虽是刚毅壁立万仞，然后能之。 苟神不能御气，气不能固形，既不能安其居，又自毁坏其宅，欲求一得永得之妙，难矣。 子闻师语，心悟神会，笑而不言。 师索酒满泛，歌《楚词》一章：道可受兮不可传，其小无内兮其大无垠，无滑而魂兮彼将自然，岂气孔神兮於中夜，若虚以待之兮无为之先。 一揖而去，予因暇日吟三颂以自警：未必邪魔果若重，来向伸前说痴梦。 谢仙举火本同心，杨子江头看一。 独运之时正好看，霏霏霏霏不为难。 自有青铜三二百，时时浇善语喉乾。 雨不雨风不风，无疑无虑笑烘烘。 团乐看取丹砂地，独自开来独自封。 又一诗云：下手莫教迟，金丹有甚疑。 一团和气定，火候谨差池。 四象才和合，灵机自可窥。 欲知真妙处，孤月照潭时。 月屋刊石潭所注《道德经》，埈僭易附此章于谷神章后，悟真先生诗曰：莫怪天机都漏泄，为缘学者太迷蒙。 呵呵。 本一庵居士曰：谷神不死至用之不勤。 谷，虚而有形，谷而神则有而无也。 玄，深而无体，玄而牝则无而有也。 有而无，所以不死，无而有，所以能生。 此亦形道之体也。 推其出之自曰门，厚其生之本曰根。 首章言天地万物。 而此不言万物者，有天地则有万物。 根者，所以生生不穷，则物在其中矣。 人能体道於身，绵绵若存，则谷神玄牝亦将在我，而道不可胜用矣。 绵绵，无而非无。 若存，有而非有。 不勤，不劳也。 若曰取之左右，逢其原为耳。 老子之意，大抵推本道妙於天，天地万物之初，反之於身，体而存之。 孟子之过化存神，谷神近之。 释氏之真空妙有，玄牝近之。
chunks.translated_text:
The cultivation of *qi* is but another extension by humans of their own reasoning.

Wu Huanzhong said: *"The Valley-Spirit does not die—its use requires no effort."*

Wu Huanzhong’s disciple, Wu Zhen, remarked: *"The *Laozi* contains hidden Daoist intent—when the spirit is ever-nourished, the *po* does not dissipate, and water and fire harmonize. His words are most unusual."*

I once heard my teacher say: *"The Valley-Spirit is the primordial *qi* of Heaven-before-Heaven. Spirit-*qi* returns to the Mysterious Feminine, and wherever the mind moves, it borrows spirit to act—not through mouth or nose. Mysterious, it is Yang; Feminine, it is Yin—true Yin, true Yang."*

As *Zhuangzi* says: *"All things are born, yet none know their root; they emerge, yet none know their gate. But the source from which Heaven and Earth arise is the Mysterious Feminine."*

The essence of the Great Elixir lies not beyond the spirit, soul, *po*, and intent. Spirit is fire; essence is water—true unity’s essence. The soul is wood; the *po* is metal; intent is earth. The Five Phases cannot be pure without earth, and intent nourishes *qi*. Nourishing *qi* condenses essence; condensing essence awakens spirit. When the Four Symbols harmonize into one, refined practice makes *qi* soft and enduring—unbroken, like thread. Its use requires no effort; day and night, it flows naturally.

Ancient immortals, whether hidden or revealed, spoke of *yin-yang* as substance, likened it to lead and mercury, compared it to sun and moon, modeled it on male and female, likened it to dragon and tiger—*Zhen* and *Dui*, *Kan* and *Li*, gold and cinnabar, *Jia* and *Geng*, *Bing* and *Ren*, *Wu* and *Ji*, water and fire, sovereign and minister, child and mother, infant and maiden, knife and scale, metal and wood, warmth and cold, host and guest, floating and sinking, bathing and rinsing, birth and death, punishment and virtue, battle and retreat, waxing and waning, addition and subtraction, *wen* and *wu*, hot and cold—all these are matters of the Mysterious Feminine. Thus, they established symbols in metaphor, urging one to self-realization: seek it within, not without. Have you not heard the saying: *"The Master of Emptiness and Stillness governs spirit, spirit retains *qi*—no need for external arts to attain longevity?"*

Today’s seekers of the Dao may recognize medicinal herbs but lack the means to apply them. Even if they know where to begin, they fail to grasp the method, wandering lost in the Mysterious Feminine’s domain. Spirit is the root of life; form is the vessel of spirit. When spirit is whole, *qi* is whole; when *qi* is whole, essence is whole; when essence is whole, form is whole; when form is whole, spirit thrives; when spirit thrives, *qi* is refined; when *qi* is refined, spirit transcends. At first, it aligns with the Dao as one. But when spirit is diminished, essence cannot recover; when essence is depleted, the *po* is restless.

You study texts—do you not understand the interplay of things? Yet in waking and sleeping, in seeing, hearing, speaking, and moving, your mind wanders beyond the reach of ears, eyes, heart, and thought. This is what ancient immortals, having cast aside desires and transcended the mundane, achieved only through unyielding resolve. If spirit cannot govern *qi*, and *qi* cannot solidify form, how can one dwell in peace, much less preserve their dwelling? To seek enduring attainment is difficult indeed.

You heard my words, and with a smile of sudden understanding, said nothing.

The teacher then poured wine and sang a chapter from *The Songs of Chu*:

*"The Dao can be received but not transmitted,
Its smallness has no bounds within,
Its greatness knows no limits without.
Without deceit, the spirit is pure—
Then it follows its natural course.
How could it be that *qi* is so refined,
That at midnight, in emptiness, it waits—
Before action, in non-doing’s embrace?"*

With a bow, he departed. On a leisurely day, I composed three stanzas to caution myself:

*"Not all demons are heavy burdens,
Coming forward to speak of foolish dreams.
Xie the Immortal lights the fire with shared intent,
Yangzi’s riverbank watches one *liang* of gold.
When alone, the work is just right—
Concealed, concealed, concealed, yet not difficult.
There are hundreds of green-copper vessels,
Often poured with kind words to quench my thirst.
Rain or no rain, wind or no wind,
Without doubt, without worry, laughter rings warm.
Clustered joy on cinnabar’s earth,
Sealed alone, opened alone."*

And another poem:

*"Do not delay in beginning—
What doubt remains of the Golden Elixir?
A single ball of harmonized *qi*—
Mind the fire’s precision.
When the Four Symbols unite,
Divine insight naturally appears.
To grasp its true mystery,
Observe the lone moon over the pool."*

*—Moon House carving on Stone Pool’s annotation of the* Dao De Jing*, appended by Zhen to this chapter on the Valley-Spirit. Master Wu Zhen’s poem reads:*

*"Do not blame Heaven’s secrets for leaking—
It is because seekers are too bewildered.
Hahaha."*

Master Benyuan said: *"The Valley-Spirit does not die—its use requires no effort. The Valley is empty yet formed; the spirit within it is formless yet present. Mysterious, it is deep yet intangible; as the Feminine, it is void yet substantial. Formless yet present—thus it does not die; void yet substantial—thus it can generate. This too is the body of the Dao.*

*Its emergence is called the Gate; its sustaining root is called the Root. The first chapter speaks of Heaven, Earth, and all things. But here, it does not mention all things—for where there are Heaven and Earth, there are all things. The Root is that which endlessly generates, and thus all things are within it. If one embodies the Dao in the body, unbroken as thread, then the Valley-Spirit and the Mysterious Feminine will reside within you, and the Dao’s use will know no end.*

*Unbroken—neither void nor not-void.
As-if-preserved—neither present nor not-present.
Without effort—without toil.
If one says it is taken from left or right,
It is but returning to its origin.
The *Laozi*’s intent is, broadly, to trace the Dao’s mystery back to Heaven—Heaven and Earth’s beginning—and then reflect it within the self, embodying and preserving it. Mencius’ *xiao-hua cun-shen* is akin to the Valley-Spirit. The Buddhist *zhēnkōng miǎoyǒu* aligns with the Mysterious Feminine."*

**Chapter on Eternal Heaven and Earth (天长地久章)**

*Considerations of Differences (考异):*
The River Upper Master (河上公) composed *The Chapter of Concealing Brilliance (韬光章)*, while Zhao Shizhan (赵实庵) titled it *The Chapter on Eternal Generation Without Generation (生生不生义章)*.

Emperor Ming of Tang (唐明皇) commented:
In the previous chapter, the **Daoist Mystery of the Eternal Valley Spirit (谷神不死)** was illuminated through its hollow response—this hollow response is the very **unexhausted source**. This chapter elucidates the **impartiality of Heaven and Earth**, for their impartiality is why they endure eternally. It begins by setting forth Heaven and Earth as an analogy, then proceeds to cite the Sage (圣人) to further clarify, concluding with the principle that impartiality fulfills private ends, urging diligence in this practice.

Du Guangting (杜光庭) remarked:
The previous chapter expounded upon the **Daoist Mystery of the Eternal Valley Spirit**, illustrating how Heaven and Earth **nurture qi** through natural spontaneity. This chapter emphasizes **Eternal Heaven and Earth (天长地久)**, aligning with the **practice of natural spontaneity**. The Sage, too, by **applying the Way with impartiality**, ensures that all things converge—thus attaining **harmony and national tranquility**. Heaven and Earth endure eternally because they **do not selfishly assert their own generation**; the Sage **abandons his own self** while his self persists, and **sets aside his own self** while his self remains. Is this not because of their **impartiality**? Thus, they fulfill their **private ends**.

*Considerations of Differences (考异):*
The River Upper Master (河上公) and Yan Junping (严君平) originally read, *"Is this not because of their **impartiality**?"* (非以其无私邪), but Wang Bi’s (王弼) ancient version read, *"Is this not because of their **lack of impartiality**?"* (不以其无私邪). The Kaiyuan Imperial Edition (开元御本) restored it to *"Is this not because of their **impartiality**?"* (非以其无私邪).

The River Upper Master (河上公) said:
**Eternal Heaven and Earth (天长地久)**—this expounds upon the **longevity of Heaven and Earth**, serving as a metaphor for instruction. Heaven and Earth endure eternally because they **do not selfishly assert their own generation**. Their singular capacity to endure long is because they **remain tranquil**, act without expectation of reward, and do not **reside like mortals**, nor **covet private benefits** by seizing others’ blessings. Thus, they attain **eternal longevity**. Since they **do not seek their own generation**, they can **endure without ceasing**.

Therefore, the Sage **abandons his own self**—this is the practice of **prioritizing others before oneself**. Yet his self **persists first**—for the world reveres him foremost, deeming him eternal. He **sets aside his own self**—this is the practice of **neglecting oneself for others**. Yet his self **remains preserved**—for the people love him as a parent, and the spirits nurture him like an infant, so his self **endures perpetually**. Is this not because of their **impartiality**? Thus, they fulfill their **private ends**. What others consider **private** is the **desire to enrich oneself**. The Sage, being impartial, yet **enriches himself**, thus fulfilling his **private ends**.

Wang Fu’s (王辅嗣) commentary:
**Eternal Heaven and Earth (天长地久) because they do not selfishly assert their own generation**—to selfishly assert one’s own generation is to **contend with all things**; not to do so is for all things to **converge naturally**. Thus, they endure eternally and fulfill their **private ends**. **Impartiality** is to **act without selfish regard for oneself**; when one’s self **persists first** and **remains preserved**, it is said that one fulfills their **private ends**.

Emperor Ming of Tang (唐明皇) said:
**Eternal Heaven and Earth (天长地久)**—by setting forth Heaven and Earth’s eternal endurance, it is made clear that **impartiality and lack of desire** lead to **eternal longevity**. The conclusion of the metaphor and its meaning lie in the Sage’s **abandoning and setting aside his own self**, wherein **impartiality fulfills private ends**.

Commentary (疏):
This chapter begins with a **posed question**. Heaven is called **long** because of its **vital qi (气象)**, and Earth is called **durable** because of its **substance and form (形质)**. Heaven and Earth endure eternally because they **do not selfishly assert their own generation**. Their **virtue and power** in nurturing all things are vast, yet they endure long because they **draw from the Dao’s foundation**, not **boasting of their own generative function**.

Commentary (疏):
The opening sentence poses a question; the following is a hypothetical response: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally because they **cover and nourish all things**, fostering the myriad materials, all of which **draw from the Dao’s foundation**. They do not **boast of their own generative function**, thus their longevity enables them to **generate all things**."* Another interpretation states: *"Not selfishly asserting their own generation"* means that Heaven and Earth **only generate and nourish all things**, without **privately enriching their own existence**. Thus, they attain **eternal longevity**.

Therefore, the Sage **endures while his self persists**—**abandoning his own self** leads others to **delight in promoting him**, so his self **persists first**. **Setting aside his own self** results in **tranquil forgetfulness**, so his self **remains preserved**. Commentary (疏):
Thus, the Sage **imitates Heaven and Earth**, ensuring **equitable coverage** and **nurturing without selfishness**, so he **prioritizes others first**. The people **rejoice and rely upon him**; he is revered by those below, so his self **persists first**. He **does not boast or blame himself**; when the world **converges upon his virtue (仁)**, he faces **no fear or harm**, so his self **remains preserved**.

Is this not because of their **impartiality**? Thus, they fulfill their **private ends**. Heaven and Earth **forget their generative function**, being impartial yet enduring eternally—this is fulfilling their **private ends**. The Sage **abandons and sets aside his own self**, embodying **impartiality**, yet **persists first and remains preserved**—this is fulfilling his **private ends**.

Commentary (疏):
Heaven and Earth endure eternally, and the Sage’s self **persists first and remains preserved**, not because of their **lack of self-interest**, but because of their **impartiality**, thus fulfilling this **eternal longevity** and **prioritized preservation**.

Du Guangting (杜光庭) remarked:
**Eternal Heaven and Earth (天长地久)**—The **Venerable Master Laozi** seeks to elucidate Heaven and Earth’s eternal endurance to instruct the rulers of the world, thus beginning the chapter with his own question. *"Heaven, by its **accumulation of qi (气)**, is called **long**"*—as *Liezi* states: *"Heaven accumulates qi; without qi, there is no qi."* *"Earth, by its **accumulation of matter (块)**, is called **durable**"*—as *Liezi* states: *"Earth accumulates matter; without substance, there is no matter."* **Qi accumulates to form the ethereal (象)**, and **matter accumulates to form the solid (形)**. The *Appendix to the Yijing (易□系辞)* states: *"In Heaven, it manifests as **symbols (象)**; on Earth, it manifests as **forms (形)**."* When **symbols transform above and forms solidify below**, **change and response** are evident, and **prolific generation** ensues.

Heaven and Earth endure eternally because they **do not selfishly assert their own generation**. The **Venerable Master Laozi**, intending to clarify this **eternal principle**, poses the question himself—just as literary scholars invoke **the absent Prince Gong (亡是公子)**, **Mr. Wu You (乌有先生)**, or **the owner of the Eastern Capital (东都主人)** as stylistic conventions.
