chunks.original_text: 立题发问，自答之以显其事尔。 为前句既问天长地久，此句方答云以天地运元和冲用之气，生育群品，群品得生，天地不恃其德，不有其功，故能长久。 若恃其功则功细矣，若恃其德其德薄矣。 不恃故德广功大，万物归宗，而天地长久也。 人君理国当法天行化，任物无为，众庶熙熙，自臻平泰。 理身无劳心役虑之事，无矜名徇欲之功，神安於中，气和於内，如此则国祚长远，身寿遐延，亦如天地无私，乃能长久也。 是以圣人至而身存。 理国不矜贵以有为，不劳人以自奉，所谓后身外身也。 太古之君志包天地，泽及天下，而不知其谁氏，其生无爵，不有其位也； 其死无谥，不名其功也。 其实不聚，其名不立，天下乐推，万物欣戴。 可谓后身而身先，外身而身存也。 世之衰也。 其君则不然。 恣身之欲而役於人，殚人之力以奉其己，人劳政弊，天下去之。 此所谓失外身后身之道也。 岂若碎琥珀之枕、焚雉头之裘、罢一台之费、却千里之马，德垂当代，名光竹帛乎？ 修身之士不嗜荣爵，外其身也； 不为躁进，后其身也。 如此，则身存而德充，德充则人服，可谓身先身存矣。 反於此者，道远乎哉。 非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 圣人之理也，任自然之化，无独见之专，不厚其生，不伐其善，不为天下之先，故能处人之上，不为天下之贵，故能享祚久长。 所以亿兆宅心，夷蛮稽颡，干戈止息，宗庙安宁。 此之为私也大矣。 由其不以私为私，故成此光大。 理身则德充人服，道契神明，身寿长生，其私大矣。 亦由其不以徇私逐欲，成就此大私也。 《灵宝经》云：居世之人贪欢逐欲，前乐后苦。 何哉？ 极其逸乐而坠於三涂也。 学道之士绝利忘名，寒栖炼行，终得仙道。 先苦后乐，何者？ 积其功行，升乎九天也。 宋道君曰：天长地久至故能长生。 天穹窿而位乎上，经为日月，纬为星辰，而万物覆焉。 地磅礡而位乎下，结为山岳，融为川泽，而万物载焉。 万物覆载於天地，天地无心於万物，故天确然而常运，地颓然而常处，所以能长且久也。 天地有心於万物，则天俄而可度，其覆物也浅矣； 地俄而可测，其载物也薄矣。 若是则有待也，而生乌能长生？ 是以圣人至而身存。 天运乎上，地处乎下，圣人者位乎天地之中，达而为三才者，有相通之用； 辨而为三极者，有各立之体； 交而为三灵者，有元妙之神。 然天地之与圣人，咸得乎道。 而圣人所以治其身者，亦天地而已。 故此章先言天地之不自生，而继之以圣人不自有其身也。 人皆取先，己独取后，曰受天下之垢，是谓后其身，则不与物争，而天下莫能与之争。 故曰后其身而身先。 枉涂不争险易之利，冬夏不争阴阳之和，外生死，遗祸福，而神未尝有所困也。 是谓外其身而身存。 夫圣人之所以治其身者如此，况身外之事物乎？ 遭之而不运，过之而不守，体性抱神，以游古俗之间，人将自正，物我为一，先天地生而不为久，长於上古而不为老。 此其效欤。 非以其无私耶？
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus, the question is posed and answered by oneself to reveal its meaning. Having already asked in the previous verse—*"Why does Heaven endure and Earth last so long?"*—this one responds: *"Because Heaven and Earth utilize the **Dao/Way's** primordial harmony (运元和) and the **cosmic surge** (冲用) of **qi**, nurturing all existences (群品). Though all existences thrive, Heaven and Earth do not claim their **virtue/power** (德) nor possess their **achievement** (功), and thus they endure eternally.*

*If they claimed their achievement, their **virtue/power** would dwindle; if they possessed their **virtue/power**, it would grow shallow. By not claiming, their **virtue/power** is vast and their **achievement** grand—all things return to their source, and thus Heaven and Earth endure.*

*The sovereign who governs his realm should follow the Dao/Way of Heaven, acting without contrivance (无为), letting all flourish in ease (熙熙). When the people naturally attain peace (平泰), then the nation’s blessings will stretch far, and his own lifespan will extend long—just as Heaven and Earth endure through their lack of selfishness.*

*The sage who cultivates himself avoids laborious schemes and vain pursuits of name, nor does he exhaust his **qi** with ambitious deeds or indulgent desires. His spirit remains tranquil within, his **qi** harmonious within, and thus his nation’s fortune endures, his body thrives—just as Heaven and Earth, without selfishness, endure eternally.*

*Therefore, the sage arrives while his body still lives. In governing the realm, he does not arrogantly seek noble status through action nor burden the people for his own gain—this is what is called **posterity’s body** (后身) and **external body** (外身).*

*The sovereigns of the **Age of Great Clarity** (太古) encompassed the will of Heaven and Earth, their benevolence extending to all under Heaven, yet they were unknown by name. In life, they held no rank, no station; in death, no posthumous title, no record of their deeds. Their substance did not gather, their fame did not stand—yet all under Heaven willingly honored them, and all things joyfully revered them. Truly, they embodied **posterity’s body while their own body led** (后身而身先), **external body while their own body endured** (外身而身存)!*

*But in the world’s decline, such sovereigns no longer exist. Instead, they indulge their own desires, enslaving the people, and drain their strength to serve themselves. The people grow weary, governance falters, and all under Heaven abandons them. This is what is called **losing the way of external and posterity’s body** (失外身后身之道).*

*How much better to discard the **broken jade pillow** (碎琥珀之枕), abandon the **fine furs of the wild goose** (焚雉头之裘), cease the extravagance of a **single grand hall** (罢一台之费), and reject the **thousand-mile horses** (却千里之马)—thus, his **virtue/power** shines through the age, his name gleams on bamboo and silk. The scholar who refines himself does not covet honor or rank—this is **externalizing his body**; he does not rush for advancement—this is **postponing his body**. Thus, his body endures while his **virtue/power** is full; when his **virtue/power** is full, all submit. This is truly **body leading while body endures** (身先身存).*

*To invert this is to stray far from the Dao/Way. Is it not because they lack selfishness that they achieve such greatness?*

*The sage’s cultivation of himself is thus: he aligns with Nature’s transformations, neither monopolizing singular insights nor hoarding his life’s blessings. He does not arrogate his own virtue, nor does he claim precedence over all under Heaven—yet he stands above all, enjoys long fortune, and all people find solace in their hearts, while the uncivilized bow in reverence. Weapons fall silent, ancestral temples stand secure. This is the greatness of his lack of selfishness!*

*For it is because he does not cling to selfishness as selfishness that he attains such brilliance. In cultivating himself, his **virtue/power** is full and all submit; his **Dao/Way** resonates with the divine, his body thrives eternally—this is the greatness of his lack of selfishness! It is also because he does not yield to selfish cravings that he achieves this vast lack of selfishness.*

*The **Scripture of the Spirit Jewel** (灵宝经) says: *"Those who dwell in the world, chasing pleasures and indulging desires, find joy now and suffering later. Why so? Because they reach the extreme of ease and fall into the three abysses (三涂)."* The scholar of the Dao/Way cuts ties with worldly gains, forgets fame, endures cold lodgings, and refines his conduct—ultimately attaining the **Dao/Way of transcendence** (仙道). First suffering, then joy—why? Because he accumulates his deeds and ascends to the **Nine Heavens** (九天).*

*The **Venerable Sovereign of the Dao/Way** (宋道君) said: *"Heaven endures and Earth lasts long because they do so eternally. Heaven’s vault is vast and its station above, with the **celestial axis** (经) as the sun and moon, and the **celestial loom** (纬) as the stars and constellations, sheltering all things beneath. Earth’s foundation is firm and its station below, forming mountains and valleys, blending into rivers and marshes, bearing all things upon it. All things are sheltered and carried by Heaven and Earth, yet Heaven and Earth have no concern for them—thus, Heaven moves ceaselessly yet remains steadfast, Earth stands firm yet endures without change, and so they last long and endure.*

*If Heaven and Earth had concern for all things, then Heaven would soon be measured, its sheltering shallow; Earth would soon be fathomed, its bearing thin. If so, they would rely on others—how could they then endure eternally?"*

*Therefore, the sage arrives while his body still lives. Heaven moves above, Earth rests below; the sage stands between them, embodying the **Three Powers** (三才) in harmony, distinguishing the **Three Poles** (三极) in their essence, and uniting the **Three Spirits** (三灵) in their **primordial marvel** (元妙之神). Yet Heaven, Earth, and the sage all attain the Dao/Way. And the sage’s method of governing himself is also that of Heaven and Earth. Hence, this chapter first speaks of Heaven and Earth not asserting their own generation, and then follows with the sage not possessing his own body.*

*All take precedence for themselves, yet the sage alone takes what comes later—saying, *"I bear all under Heaven’s filth"* (受天下之垢), which is called **postponing his body**, meaning he does not contend with others, and thus none can contend with him. Hence it is said: *"Postponing his body, yet his body leads."* He does not vie for perilous advantages nor struggle for ease in winter and summer, nor does he compete for the balance of **yin and yang**. He transcends life and death, abandons fortune and misfortune, and his spirit is never constrained.*

*This is called **externalizing his body while his body endures**. If the sage’s method of governing himself is thus, how much more so for external matters? He encounters them without clinging, passes them without retaining, his nature embracing the spirit, wandering between ancient customs and the present. The people will self-correct, distinctions between self and other dissolve, and he is born before Heaven and Earth yet does not age, enduring beyond the **Age of Great Clarity** (上古) without growing old. This is his effect! Is it not because he lacks selfishness?"*

chunks.original_text: 故能成其私。 天地之大德曰生，圣人之大宝曰位。 道者为之公，天地体道，故无私，无私故长久。 圣人体道，故无私，无私故常存。 自营为私，未有能成其私者也。 王介甫曰：天长地久至故能长生。 长者，言其远也。 久者，言其恒也。 以其不自生，故能长生。 天地所以长久者，以其不自生，任万物之所生。 既任万物之所生，乃能长生万物，而无生之累也。 又曰：於天言长，於地言久，则重於久可知也。 是以圣人至而身先。 圣人无我也，有我则与物构，而物我相引矣。 万物敌我也。 吾不与之敌，故后之。 外其身而身存。 万物莫不累我也，吾不与之累，故外之也。 故曰外其身而身存。 非以其无私耶，故能成其私。 《字说》韩非曰：自营为私，背公为私。 夫自营者，未有能成其私者也。 故其字为自营而不周之形。 故老子曰：夫非以无私也，故能成其私。 私从禾从ㄙ，ㄙ，自营也。 ㄙ不能不自营，然自营而不害於利物，则无怨於私矣。 苏颖滨曰：天长地久。 天地虽大，而不离於形数，则其长久盖有量矣。 然老子之言长久，极於天地。 盖以人所见者言之耳。 若夫长久之至，则所谓天地始者是矣。 天地所以能长至成其私。 天地生万物而不自生，立於万物之外，故能长生。 圣人后其身而先人，外其身而利人，处於众人之表，故能先且存。 如使天地与物竞生，而圣人与人争得，则天地亦一物耳，圣人亦一人耳。 何以大过之哉？ 虽然彼其无私，非以求成私也，而私以之成，道则固然耳。 吕吉甫曰：天长地久至故能长生。 长短形也，久近时也。 天以时行者也，嫌不足於形，故以长言之。 地以形运者也，嫌不足於时，故以久言之。 天地之根出於玄牝，玄牝之体立於谷神不死。 不死则不生，不生者能生生，天地之所以能长且久者，以其不自生，不自生故能长生。 犹谷神而已矣。 是以圣人至而身先。 圣人岂以有其身为累哉，绿於不得已，而物莫之上。 外其身而身存。 立於无何有，而物莫之能害，故曰外其身而身存。 非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 身者，吾之私也。 后其身、外其身，则公而无私矣。 无私也，故能成其私。 陆农师曰：天长地久至故能长生。 贪生者不生，遗生者不死。 故曰天长地久。 天地之所以能长且久者，以其不自生，故能长生。 是以圣人至而身存。 圣人者，天地之合也，屈己而已，以之先忘我而我之以存。 故曰圣人至而身存。 非以其无私耶，故能成其私。 非以其无私也，故能成其私。 然而屈己而易忘。 王元泽曰：天长地久至故能长生。 自生则有其生，有其生则生既丧矣。 惟无以生为则生未尝生。 生未尝生，则所寓之形虽生而无生之累，宜其长且久也。 天地之不自生，非利乎长久而然，道固如此而已。 所谓长久者，亦瞬息之间耳。 唯盖载倾陷而未尝坏者，乃其真也。 是以圣人后其身而身先。 圣人虽圣而形与物齐，唯体天道而不争，乃能独异於众。 使其立己而与众敌，则匹夫匹妇皆足以胜之。 外其身而身存。 有我而存之，则物皆吾敌。 夫惟超然自丧，不有吾身者，物莫能倾之。 非以其无私即＃2，故能成其私。 圣人无私，未尝有我故也。 使计而为之，则私孰甚焉？ 刘巨济曰：天长地久至故能长生。
chunks.translated_text:
The sage thus achieves his own ends.

The great **virtue/power** (德) of Heaven and Earth is called **generation** (生), and the great treasure of the sage is called **position** (位). The **Dao/Way** (道) is the public principle by which these are realized. Heaven and Earth embody the **Dao/Way**, hence they lack selfishness; lacking selfishness, they endure long. The sage embodies the **Dao/Way**, hence he lacks selfishness; lacking selfishness, he remains everlasting. To **self-cultivate for private gain** (自营) is selfishness, and none have ever succeeded in their selfishness. Wang Anshi said: Heaven and Earth endure because they can **long-generate** (长生). "Long" refers to their vastness, "durable" to their constancy. Since they do not **self-generate**, they can **long-generate**.

Heaven and Earth endure because they do not **self-generate** but allow all things to generate as they will. Having allowed all things to generate, they can then **long-generate** all things without bearing the burden of **generation** (生). Again, he said: When speaking of Heaven, one says "long"; when speaking of Earth, one says "durable," so it is clear that "durable" is the heavier term. Therefore, the sage arrives yet his body precedes. The sage has no **self** (我), for if he had a self, he would contend with things, and things would draw him into contention. All things oppose the **self** (我). If I do not oppose them, I follow them. **Externalizing his body while his body endures** (外其身而身存). All things burden the **self** (我), but if I do not burden myself with them, I externalize them. Therefore, it is said: **Externalizing his body while his body endures**. Is it not because he lacks selfishness that he can achieve his own ends?

The *Zi Shuo* (《字说》) says: "Self-cultivation for private gain" (自营) is selfishness, and turning one's back on the public is selfishness. Those who **self-cultivate for private gain** (自营) have never succeeded in their selfishness. Therefore, the character for "selfishness" (私) is composed of "self-cultivation" (自营) and does not include the shape of "harm." Hence, Laozi said: It is not because he lacks selfishness that he can achieve his own ends. The character "private" (私) is formed from "禾" (*hé*, grain) and "ㄙ" (*sī*, self-cultivation). Self-cultivation cannot avoid being selfish, but if selfishness does not harm the utility of things, then there is no grievance toward selfishness.

Su Yingbin said: Heaven and Earth endure. Though vast, their endurance is not separate from form and number, so their long-lasting nature is limited. Yet Laozi’s words on endurance extend to Heaven and Earth. This is merely from the perspective of what humans perceive. As for the ultimate endurance, it is what is called the **beginning of Heaven and Earth** (天地始). Heaven and Earth thus achieve their own ends through **long-endurance**. Heaven and Earth generate all things yet do not **self-generate**; they stand outside all things, hence they can **long-generate**. The sage follows his own body yet precedes others; **externalizes his body while his body endures**, benefiting others. He stands apart from the crowd, hence he can both precede and endure.

If Heaven and Earth were to contend with things for **generation**, and if the sage were to compete with others for **virtue/power**, then Heaven and Earth would merely be one thing among many, and the sage merely one person among others. How could this be considered a great transgression? Though they lack selfishness, it is not to seek their own ends that they succeed in achieving them—this is simply the **Dao/Way** as it is. Lü Jiufu said: Heaven and Earth endure because they can **long-generate**. "Long" and "short" refer to form, "durable" and "near" to time. Heaven acts according to time, yet since time is insufficient to describe its form, one speaks of it as "long." Earth acts according to form, yet since form is insufficient to describe its duration, one speaks of it as "durable."

The root of Heaven and Earth lies in the **Dark Mother** (玄牝), and the essence of the **Dark Mother** is established in the **Valley Spirit** (谷神), which is **not-death** (不死). **Not-death** means **not-generation**, and those who do not generate can generate **generation**. This is why Heaven and Earth can endure both long and durable—because they do not **self-generate**, and not **self-generating**, they can **long-generate**. It is as if they were the **Valley Spirit** itself. Therefore, the sage arrives yet his body precedes. The sage does not consider his body as a burden, though it is unavoidable, and nothing can surpass it. **Externalizing his body while his body endures**. He stands in the **non-existence of existence** (无何有), and no thing can harm him, hence it is said: **Externalizing his body while his body endures**. Is it not because he lacks selfishness that he can achieve his own ends?

The body is my own selfishness. To **follow his own body** (后其身) and **externalize his body** (外其身) is to act publicly and without selfishness. Without selfishness, he can achieve his own ends. Lü Nongshi said: Heaven and Earth endure because they can **long-generate**. Those who cling to life do not generate, and those who abandon life do not die. Hence it is said: Heaven and Earth endure. Heaven and Earth endure because they do not **self-generate**, hence they can **long-generate**. Therefore, the sage arrives yet his body endures. The sage is the **harmonious union of Heaven and Earth** (天地之合), and his only task is to **bend himself** (屈己). By this, he first forgets the **self** (我), and thus the **self** (我) is preserved. Hence it is said: The sage arrives yet his body endures. Is it not because he lacks selfishness that he can achieve his own ends?

It is not because he lacks selfishness that he can achieve his own ends. Yet bending himself is easy to forget. Wang Yuanzhe said: Heaven and Earth endure because they can **long-generate**. If one **self-generates**, then one has one’s own **generation**, and having one’s own **generation** means that **generation** is already lost. Only he who does not take **generation** as his standard has never **generated**. **Generation** never **generated**, so though his form may **generate**, it does not bear the burden of **generation**, and thus it is fitting that he endure both long and durable. Heaven and Earth’s not **self-generating** is not for the sake of enduring long and durable—this is simply the **Dao/Way** as it is. What is called "long-durable" is also but a fleeting moment. Only what **covers and sustains** (盖载) without ever failing is its true nature.

Therefore, the sage **follows his own body** yet his body precedes. Though the sage is sage, his form is equal to that of things; only by embodying the **Dao/Way** of Heaven and not contending does he alone differ from the crowd. If he were to establish himself and oppose the crowd, even an ordinary person would be sufficient to overcome him. **Externalizing his body while his body endures**. If he has a **self** (我) and preserves it, then all things become his enemies. Only he who transcends and **self-destroys** (自丧), who does not possess a **self**, can none of the things overturn him. It is not because he lacks selfishness that he achieves his own ends. The sage lacks selfishness because he has never possessed a **self**. If he were to scheme and act thus, then how much more selfish would he be?

Liu Jujie said: Heaven and Earth endure because they can **long-generate**.

This is his effect! Is it not because he lacks selfishness?"*

chunks.original_text: 天地燮之和也，物物我生也矣，不能不衰以敝。 惟不我其生为以成理造物，则能长生矣。 天积气也，以远为幸，故言长。 地积块也，以固为幸，故言久。 不言久生者，以长久之故也。 积气积块，虽理无不坏有存，焉知天地之有坏？ 遂以长久者为妄者，观有而已。 是以圣人至而身存。 圣人与天地同则后身，则身犹之不自生也。 身生身存，犹之长生也。 后身谓屈己也，外身谓忘我也。 屈己则人下之，故先。 忘我，故以外其身为存。 非以其无私耶，故能成其私。 天地不自生，与圣人之后外其身，皆无私也。 然天地以此长生，而圣人以此存，则皆成其私者也。 然不私之为私大矣。 庄子曰：无私焉，乃私也。 前章言天地根，故次以长久。 刘骥曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 天无为以之清，故能确然而常运。 地无为以之宁，故能颓然而常处。 皆以其不自生，故能长生。 若有心於自生，则智有所不周，力有所不及，乌能长且久也？ 人处天地之中，与天地分一气而治，所以不能与天地同其长久者，以其有为有欲，而贪生太厚故也。 是以圣人后其身而不敢有为，外其身而不敢有欲。 人皆求福，己独曲全； 人皆取先，己独取后。 是谓后其身也。 忘其肝胆，遗其耳目，外死生，遗祸福，是谓外其身也。 后其身而不先，外其身而不有，芒然彷徨乎尘垢之外，逍遥乎无为之业，隳支体，黜聪明，离形去智，同於大通，与道同久，则身不期先而先，不期存而存。 非以其无私邪？ 故能成其私。 圣人之后其身、外其身，以濡弱谦下为表，以虚空不毁万物为实。 故次之以上善若水。 赵实庵曰：初示因有三：一、举天地长生之理。 天长地久。 道因象显而不知其终，火以薪传而不知其尽。 物生而有象，道与之俱。 生而生生者未尝生。 火传而为明，薪化而火隐焉，昭昭者未尝昧。 故前章示谷神不死，是谓玄牝，玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 而其政不死之理，在不勤故也。 继之天地长久，取其征也。 二、明本无心生於物。 天地所以能长且久者，一炁既分两仪，奠位虽有高卑之间，同乎得一之灵。 以天得一，固自长也。 以地得一，固自久也。 长之与久，义同一体。 天何以长言，地何以久言？ 盖天以气言，故言长也。 地以形言，故言久也。 清气升而上有形，而同乎无形也。 苍苍者，其正色邪。 浊气降而下有气，而不能逃形也。 广大者，其自任邪。 然天地者道之所生，大道无形，生育天地，天地以无形者为之父母。 无形则无名，无名天地之始。 原天地之本，以虚受性，以性化虚，此从有入无也。 以虚化气，以气生形，此从无入有也。 所谓得一者，真元也。 真元者，一气也。 以其能长且久者，二气交合，不失於常也，故能生生而不穷。 苟以交合变化为无动无静，则天有时而裂，地有时而发。 当其一阖一辟、一动一静，运日月以分昼夜，变温凉而定寒暑，凡以绵绵若存。 故列子曰一气不顿进，一形不顿亏，是其有节也。 非虚极而运神，静笃而专气，其能与道同流乎？ 天以气运，故穹窿而在上。 地以形处，故磅礡而在下。 此天地自然之位也。 乾其静也专，坤其动也辟。 此天地自然之德也。 以万物为刍狗，此天地自然之公也。 以应物为橐钥，此天地自然之理也。

「Heaven and Earth endure through their **harmonizing** (燮) and **unity** (和). When things **generate one another** (物物我生), they must inevitably **decay** (衰) and **be consumed** (敝). Only when one does not **self-generate** (不我其生) to fulfill the **principle** (理) of creation does **long-generation** (长生) become possible.

Heaven **accumulates qi** (气), and its fortune lies in **dispersion** (远), hence its association with **length** (长). Earth **accumulates mass** (块), and its fortune lies in **solidity** (固), hence its association with **duration** (久). They do not say **"long-generation"** (久生) because of their **length and duration** (长久).

Though Heaven and Earth **accumulate qi** and **mass**, their **principle** (理) remains unbroken while their **substance** (有) endures—how can one know that Heaven and Earth will ever **be consumed** (坏)? Thus, those who claim **length and duration** (长久) are **deluded** (妄者), for they only **observe substance** (有).

Hence, the sage **embodies** (至) the Dao while his body **endures**. When the sage **aligns with** Heaven and Earth, he **sacrifices his body** (后身), and his body, like theirs, does not **self-generate** (自生). For his body to **generate** (生) and **endure** (存) is akin to **long-generation** (长生). **"Sacrificing his body"** (后身) means **yielding to others** (屈己), and **"externalizing his body"** (外身) means **abandoning the self** (忘我). To **yield to others** (屈己) is to be **subdued by others** (人下之), hence he **takes precedence** (先). To **abandon the self** (忘我) is to **externalize his body** (外其身) while it **endures** (存).

Is it not because he **lacks selfishness** (无私) that he achieves his own ends? **Long-generation** (长生) is not **self-generation** (自生), and **endurance** (存) is not **possession** (有). The sage **sacrifices his body** (后其身) yet does not **take precedence** (先), **externalizes his body** (外其身) yet does not **possess** (有). He **wanders beyond** the dust and filth, **unbound in the realm of non-action** (无为之业), **discarding his frame** (隳支体), **abandoning keen senses** (黜聪明), **separating from form and intelligence** (离形去智), **uniting with the Great Thoroughfare** (大通), and **aligning with the Dao in duration** (与道同久). Thus, his body does not **await precedence** (期先) yet **precedes**, does not **await endurance** (期存) yet **endures**.

Is it not because he **lacks selfishness** (无私) that he achieves his own ends? The sage’s **sacrificing his body** (后其身) and **externalizing his body** (外其身) are **expressed outwardly** (为表) in **gentleness, weakness, and humility** (濡弱谦下), yet **substantiated inwardly** (为实) in **emptiness and non-destruction** (虚空不毁) of all things. Thus, the next section speaks of **"the highest goodness is like water"** (上善若水).

Zhao Shizhang said: The opening presents three causes:
1. **Illustrating the principle of Heaven and Earth’s long-generation**. Heaven is **long**, Earth is **durable**. The Dao **manifests through symbols** (因象显) yet its end is unknown; fire **transmits through fuel** (以薪传) yet its exhaustion is unseen. When things **generate with form** (有象), the Dao **accompanies them**. That which **generates and continually generates** (生而生生) has never truly **generated**; fire **transmits yet becomes illumination** (传而为明), fuel **transforms while fire remains hidden** (薪化而火隐), and the **radiant** (昭昭) has never been **obscured** (昧). Thus, the previous section demonstrates **the Spirit of the Valley does not die** (谷神不死), which is called the **Mysterious Female** (玄牝). The **Gate of the Mysterious Female** (玄牝之门) is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth** (天地根). The **principle of its non-dying governance** (政不死之理) lies in **non-exertion** (不勤).

Continuing with **Heaven and Earth’s long duration**, it takes their **manifestation** (征) as evidence.

2. **Clarifying that self-generation originates from the absence of a fixed heart**. Heaven and Earth’s ability to be **long and durable** (能长且久) comes from the **original qi** (一炁) being **divided into the two polarities** (两仪), and though their **positions** (奠位) differ in **high and low**, they **share the essence of obtaining the One** (同乎得一之灵). Heaven, by **obtaining the One** (得一), is **naturally long** (固自长). Earth, by **obtaining the One** (得一), is **naturally durable** (固自久). **Long** (长) and **durable** (久) share the same **principle** (义) of **unity with the One** (同一体).

Why does Heaven speak of **long** (长), and Earth speak of **durable** (久)? Heaven is described through **qi** (气), hence **long**; Earth is described through **form** (形), hence **durable**. **Clear qi** (清气) ascends, and above it **form emerges** (上有形) while **uniting with the formless** (同乎无形). The **vast and boundless** (苍苍) is its **true color** (正色). **Turbulent qi** (浊气) descends, and below it **substance emerges** (下有气) yet cannot **escape form** (形). The **vastness** (广大) is its **self-sustaining nature** (自任).

Yet Heaven and Earth are **generated by the Dao** (道之所生). The **Great Dao** (大道) is **formless**, and it **nurtures** Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth regard the **formless** (无形) as their **parents** (父母). The **formless** (无形) is **nameless** (无名), and the **nameless** (无名) is the **beginning of Heaven and Earth** (天地之始). To **trace the origin of Heaven and Earth** (原天地之本) is to **receive emptiness in essence** (以虚受性), and to **transform essence into emptiness** (以性化虚)—this is **entering from substance into non-substance** (从有入无). To **transform emptiness into qi** (以虚化气), and to **generate form through qi** (以气生形), is **entering from non-substance into substance** (从无入有).

The **obtaining the One** (得一) refers to the **True Primordial Essence** (真元). The **True Primordial Essence** (真元) is the **Original Qi** (一气). Because the **two qi** (二气) **intermingle harmoniously** (交合) and do not **deviate from constancy** (失於常), they can **generate without end** (生生而不穷). If one were to regard their **intermingling and transformation** (交合变化) as **neither movement nor stillness** (无动无静), then Heaven would have **times of rupture** (有时而裂), and Earth would have **times of eruption** (有时而发). When the **One opens and closes** (一阖一辟), when it **moves and stirs** (一动一静), it **cycles the sun and moon** (运日月) to **divide day and night** (分昼夜), it **varies warmth and coolness** (变温凉) to **determine cold and heat** (定寒暑). All this is **continuous and enduring** (绵绵若存).

Hence, Liezi said: **"The Original Qi does not advance suddenly** (一气不顿进), **and form does not diminish suddenly** (一形不顿亏)—this is its **moderation** (有节)." Is it not because of **reaching the utmost emptiness and nurturing the spirit** (虚极而运神), **deep stillness and focused qi** (静笃而专气), that one can **flow with the Dao** (与道同流)?

Heaven **cycles qi** (以气运), hence its **vaulted expanse** (穹窿) above. Earth **dwells in form** (以形处), hence its **solid bulk** (磅礡) below. This is the **natural position** (自然之位) of Heaven and Earth. **Qian** (乾) embodies **stillness and concentration** (静也专), while **Kun** (坤) embodies **movement and expansion** (动也辟). This is the **natural virtue/power** (自然之德) of Heaven and Earth. To **regard all things as grass and dogs** (刍狗), this is the **natural equity** (自然之公) of Heaven and Earth. To **respond to things with adaptability** (应物), this is the **natural principle** (自然之理) of Heaven and Earth, like the **key of a bellows** (橐钥).」

chunks.original_text: 然天以运言，则运居乎中，而六气为之用，动者未尝不静焉。 地以处言，则险然不动，而含洪为之德，静者未尝不动焉。 然天地之所专者，专乎气而未尝专乎物。 气专则物自遂矣，夫何容心哉？ 道法自然，天地亦尔。 故生者自生，化者自化。 万物植植，吾且生而不有之； 万事总总，吾且为而不恃之。 兹所以为长时生化之道也。 故曰天地所以能长且久者，以其不自生，故能长生。 能者，指人而对天地也。 何以知其然邪？ 天地无为而无不为，无能与不能、有能与不能者指人也。 谓天地能者不向有其生故长生，谓人有不能者认物为己有故丧生。 所以天地能长且久也，又何以言且乎？ 夫形之大者莫大於天地，寿之永者孰过於乾坤。 且者，且而已。 然天地虽大，以道观之，未离乎形。 有形者不能以长存，有数者不能以固久，大劫之交必归变坏，然而未坏者，特曰且而已。 夫不坏者，天地之性。 形亏者，天地之数。 观乎杞国之忧，答者未及于此。 三、故无终穷。 以其不自生，故能长生。 《仙经》曰：形以道立，神以空生。 盖人之生与天地同得一气，而人不能与天地长存者，守之不得其道也。 天地自然还丹，以铅龙汞虎，卯酉隐藏，上升下降，天阳地阴，两至之所归，坤艮之所会，行之有度，运之有时，坤巽行乎天，乾艮历乎地，乃自然还返也。 故天长而地久。 夫人者一体之中，五藏之内，上法天地，中合六气，无不合乎此道也。 所失之由，在乎不能专气以自御，守气以自持，行气以合道，终日驰逐妄境，蹙趋之不正，则气亡矣，焉能与天地同为长生邪？ 《黄庭》曰：气亡液漏非己形。 是使人内不失其气，外不失其形，形以化神，神以化道，则形不失道，气不失神。 二明忘己而显德：是以圣人至而身存。 前二句先以天地得长生之道，在乎不自生。 不自生者专气而不专物，专气则静定，静定则能应神不劳，而用有余也。 天地生化之道如斯而已。 太上欲显圣人后身之义，先明天地而继之圣人，是以字牒前故也。 夫智彻为明，天下不见其智而见其明； 位极而尊，天下不知其尊而见其位。 圣人於此，每每藏其明而隐其智，贱其位而卑其身，则明者不为物所蔽，尊者不为卑所逾。 如是则智愈远而明愈博，位愈固而身愈安。 此持后处先之道也。 列子曰：天下有常胜之道曰柔。 若夫处物之先，以谓天下莫我及，尊我之身，以谓天下莫我逾，则争者起而为敌矣，贱者僭而逾尊矣。 位且不固，身亦危然。 此太上欲圣人明谦下之义，使天下莫先焉。 此存身之道也。 孔子曰：有礼则安，无礼则危。 谦下者，礼也。 又曰：君使臣以礼。 亦足以锄骄人之色也。 然则此义初以天地长存，往不生后，以圣人久於其道在谦逊，先言后其身，是不敢为天下先，后言外其身不私於己也。 圣人处己临物，舍此而不可。 非徒治己，道由此而宁，亦可以致长生，符天地之妙用矣。 后结成其志也，非以其无私邪，故能成其私。 御注日：自营为私，非以其无私邪？ 即圣人之成能尔。 以后其身而先其身，外其身而存其身是也。 私者机也，机者微也，事谋於心则微，微显於用则机。 机微者，心之私也。 私出於事始，事成而为公，私之为用，在心谋之以成在身，身显而后公名立焉。

Yet when Heaven is spoken of in terms of its **cycling**, its motion resides in the center, while the **Six Qi** serve as its functions—movement never lacks stillness within it. When Earth is spoken of in terms of its **dwelling**, it stands firm and unyielding, yet **embracing vastness** as its virtue—stillness never lacks motion within it.

Yet what Heaven and Earth truly **concentrate upon** is **qi**, never upon things. When **qi** is concentrated, things naturally follow—what need is there for the mind?

The **Dao** follows **nature**; Heaven and Earth do likewise. Thus, **life emerges on its own**, and **transformation unfolds on its own**. All things flourish in their own way—**I nurture them yet do not claim them**; all affairs unfold in their own way—**I act yet do not rely upon them**. This is how one abides by the **Dao of enduring life and transformation**.

Thus it is said: *"Heaven and Earth endure long because they do not **self-generate**—thus they attain long life."* The term **"able"** refers to humans in contrast to Heaven and Earth.

How do we know this to be so? Heaven and Earth act without acting, yet nothing remains undone; they possess neither ability nor inability, neither having ability nor lacking it—this refers to humans. To say Heaven and Earth are **"able"** is to say they do not cling to their own life, hence they attain long life. To say humans are **"unable"** is to say they cling to things as their own, hence they lose life. Thus Heaven and Earth endure long—why then speak of **"yet"**?

Among forms, none is greater than Heaven and Earth; among lifespans, none surpasses **Qian** and **Kun**. **"Yet"** means **"yet"** and nothing more. Yet even Heaven and Earth, though vast, when viewed through the **Dao**, do not depart from form. What has form cannot endure forever; what is fated cannot last eternally. At the great cycle’s turn, all must return to decay—yet what has not yet decayed is merely said to **"yet"** endure.

What does not decay is the **nature of Heaven and Earth**; what decays is their **fated measure**. To observe **the worries of the State of Qi**, the answer does not reach this depth.

**Thus, there is no ultimate end.**

Because they do not **self-generate**, they attain long life.

chunks.original_text: 言圣人我欲成圣道，不以我身而先人，此私也，动容周旋不失谦逊之礼，人反推之以为先也。 是用后而取先，岂不私邪？ 至於外身而身存，夫不外其身则置身於可欲之地，欲胜则害生，害生则伤身。 今外其身者，是欲其身而不欲於物，然后能存其身。 存其身者，是以身为私也。 至於身无所害而得长存，乃为公也。 夫圣人之所行，不当言私，而以私者，原其初不敢正言之，故曰邪。 邪者，疑似之也。 经所以指圣人之私，谓非以其无私邪，勿谓圣人无私，以私故能成公。 故之字谓以后身外身而成私。 许由不受无为之名，后其身也，许由得其私。 鲍叔有分财之义，外其身也，疱叔成其公。 然天地之私者又在乎不自有其生，而孰知道者为之公欤？ 邵若愚曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 天长地久而不知虹蜕云雾，风雨四时，积气成乎天。 山岳江海，金石草木，积形成乎地。 夫有形者，岂得不坏？ 天地所以能长而且久者，四时之运，察道为生化之主，天地以其不自生，故能长生。 是以圣人效之，处谦下不敢自尊。 后其身而身反在人先，以世利皆为身外之物，缘外其身不为物累，而能身存得久。 夫圣人后其身、外其身，非以其无私耶，效天地为而无为，故能成其私。 王志然曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 道贯四大者也，四大中得道而大者，莫大乎天地圣人焉。 而夫得一以清，穹窿而位乎上，以乾为体，刚健中正，万物资始，确然而常运。 庄子曰：天道运而无所积也。 《易》曰：示人以易矣。 地得一以宁，磅砖而位乎下，以坤为贞，承天厚载，万物资生，颓然而常处。 《庄子》曰地道运而无所积也。 《易》曰示人以简矣。 以言乎天地之间则备矣，乾则天之象，坤则地之象。 夫乾其静也专，其动也直，是以大生焉。 夫坤其静也翕，其动也辟，是以广生焉。 故天得之所以长清，地得之所以久宁。 天地既得夫至简至易之道，故历浩劫以长存，亘万世而无坏。 而老子所谓天长地久者，以其不自生，故能长生。 欲以圣人况天地，然天地能长且久，盖本之於真一自然之妙气，与道同体，故能覆载万物，长养万物，成就万物，斡化四时，运量无穷，以至生之畜之，长之育之、成之熟之、养之覆之，初不容心，功成自去，未尝自有其功。 及其生也，亦未尝知其所以生之者。 而圣人体天地造化，而位乎中，达而为三才，辨而为三极，交而为三灵，俯视天下而无两心，常以百姓心为心，而百姓仰视圣人而无二道，常以圣人道为道。 天下无为而自治。 圣人果不得已而临淮天下，是以后其身未尝先人，而身自先，外其身未尝先物，而天下乐推而不厌。 《诗》所谓自东自西，自南自北，无思不服是也。 於戏，天地之大德曰生，圣人之大宝曰位，天无私覆，地无私载。 然天能覆不能载，地能载不能覆，是亦天地之功未全也。 以人观之，天地能长且久，固不可得而拟议。 以道观之，天地之长久如此，亦犹瞬息之间耳。 是以圣人亦不世出之才，藏大有为之用，至公无私，谦以自牧，游心於世俗吉凶，与民同息，继之以圣人不自有其身。 是果有私也耶？ 果无私也耶？ 庄子曰：无为无形如无私焉，有情有信如有私焉。 故曰非以其无私耶？

「Speaking of the Sage’s desire to attain the **Dao/Way of Sageship**, he does not place his own body before others—this is **selfishness**. Yet in his movements and interactions, he never fails to observe the rites of **humility and deference**; others, in turn, regard him as placing theirs first.

This is **acting last yet taking precedence**—could it not be **selfishness**? As for **placing the body externally yet preserving it**, if one does not place the body externally, it will be set in a realm of **desired things**; if **desire overcomes**, harm arises, and harm to the body **injures life**.

Now, those who place their bodies externally do so to **desire their own bodies** yet not to be **ensnared by external things**—only then can they preserve their bodies. To preserve one’s body is to **regard the body as private**.

When the body suffers no harm and thus attains **long preservation**, this is **public virtue**. The Sage’s actions should not be said to be **selfish**, yet when he acts with **selfishness**, it is because at their origin he did not dare speak of them openly—thus they are called **"deviant"**.

**"Deviant"** means **doubtful and seemingly contradictory**. The **Scripture** points to the Sage’s **selfishness**, saying: *"Is it not because he lacks selfishness that he attains public virtue?"* Do not say the Sage lacks selfishness; it is **through selfishness that he achieves public virtue**.

Thus, the term **"deviant"** refers to **placing the body last and externally** to attain selfishness. **Xu You** did not accept the name **"Non-Action"**—this was placing his body last, and Xu You attained his selfishness. **Bao Shu** had the **principle of sharing wealth**—this was placing his body externally, and Bao Shu attained his public virtue.

Yet, the **Dao/Way of selfishness** in Heaven and Earth lies in their **not self-generating**—who then knows how the **Dao** makes this **public virtue**?

**Shao Ruo Qu** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure long and last because they attain selfishness."* Heaven and Earth endure long and last, yet they do not know of **rainbow transformations** or **misty vapors**; winds and rains follow the four seasons, and **accumulated qi** forms Heaven. Mountains and rivers, seas and lakes, metals and stones, grasses and woods—**accumulated forms** constitute Earth.

What has form, how could it not decay? Heaven and Earth endure long and last because the **cyclical movements of the seasons** follow the **Dao/Way** as the **master of life and transformation**; Heaven and Earth, not self-generating, thus attain **long life**.

Therefore, the Sage imitates them, dwelling in **humility and deference** yet never **self-exalting**. Placing his body last, his body is yet **regarded by others as first**; considering all worldly benefits as **external to the body**, he does not let them **burden him**, and thus his body is preserved for long.

The Sage’s **placing his body last** and **externally**—is it not because he has **selfishness**? He imitates Heaven and Earth in their **action-yet-non-action**, thus attaining his selfishness.

**Wang Zhi Ran** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure long and last because they attain selfishness."* The **Dao/Way** permeates the **Four Great Elements**—within the Four Great Elements, those who attain the **Dao** and thus become great, none greater than Heaven, Earth, and the Sage.

Heaven attains **One** to become **clear and pure**, its **vaulted dome** positioned **above**, its **body** as **Qian**—**unyielding, vigorous, and upright**, all things **begin from it**, **steady yet eternally in motion**. **Zhuangzi** said: *"The **Dao/Way of Heaven** moves yet **accumulates nothing**."* The *I Ching* says: *"It **simplifies** for people."*

Earth attains **One** to become **tranquil and enduring**, its **vast expanse** positioned **below**, its **constancy** as **Kun**—**receptive and enduring**, it **supports Heaven and nourishes all**, all things **find life from it**, **relaxed yet eternally at rest**. **Zhuangzi** said: *"The **Dao/Way of Earth** moves yet **accumulates nothing**."* The *I Ching* says: *"It **simplifies** for people."*

In speaking of Heaven and Earth, this is **complete**. **Qian** is the **symbol of Heaven**, **Kun** the **symbol of Earth**. When **Qian** is **still**, its **specialization** is complete; when it moves, it is **direct**—thus **great life** arises. When **Kun** is **still**, its **gathering** is **concentrated**; when it moves, it **expands**—thus **broad life** arises.

Therefore, Heaven attains this to **endure in clarity**, Earth attains this to **endure in tranquility**. Heaven and Earth having attained the **most simple and easy Dao/Way**, thus **survive through vast calamities** and **endure eternally**, spanning **ten thousand ages** without decay.

Yet what **Laozi** called *"Heaven and Earth enduring long"* was because they **do not self-generate**, thus they attain **long life**. To compare the Sage to Heaven and Earth—though Heaven and Earth endure long and last, their **origin is rooted in the subtle and natural essence of True One**, sharing **the same body as the Dao**, thus they **cover and load all things**, **endure and nourish all things**, **complete and perfect all things**, **guide and transform the four seasons**, their **movements and measures are boundless**—in **life**, they **store and accumulate**; in **endurance**, they **lengthen and cultivate**; in **completion**, they **perfect and ripen**; in **nourishment**, they **cover and sustain**, never once **inviting the mind**, yet **effortlessly fulfilled**, never **claiming ownership of their actions**.

Even when they give life, they do not know **how they give life**. The Sage embodies Heaven and Earth’s **creative transformations**, yet **resides in the middle**, **harmonizing the Three Powers**, **discerning the Three Poles**, **uniting the Three Spirits**, **gazing upon the world below without duality**, always **taking the hearts of the people as his own**, while the people **look up to the Sage without two Daos**, always **taking the Sage’s Dao/Way as their own**.

The world **governs itself without action**. The Sage, when **forced to govern** the **State of Qi**, never **placed his body before others** though his body was yet **regarded as first**; he **externally placed his body** yet never **prioritized external things**, and the people **joyfully followed him without wearying**. As in the *Book of Poetry*: *"From the east and from the west, from the south and from the north, none do not submit without thought."*

Ah! The **greatest virtue of Heaven and Earth** is **generation**; the **greatest treasure of the Sage** is **position**. Heaven **covers without selfishness**; Earth **loads without selfishness**. Yet Heaven can **cover** but not **load**, Earth can **load** but not **cover**—this is also **Heaven and Earth’s incomplete virtue**.

Observing this from a **human perspective**, Heaven and Earth endure long and last—**indeed, they cannot be imitated or reasoned with**. Observing this from the **Dao/Way**, Heaven and Earth’s endurance is thus, yet it is **but a fleeting moment**.

Thus, the Sage is **not a talent born in every age**; he **harbors the potential for great action**, **public yet without selfishness**, **humble to preserve himself**, **wandering in the world’s joys and sorrows**, **sharing breath with the people**, continuing with the Sage’s **not self-possessing his body**.

Is this **indeed selfishness**? Or **indeed without selfishness**? **Zhuangzi** said: *"Non-Action and no form are like without selfishness; emotions and trust are like with selfishness."* Thus it is said: *"Is it not because he lacks selfishness?"»

chunks.original_text: 故能成其私。 学者其谓如何哉。 黄茂材曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 万物莫不资天地以生，而天地实未尝生之。 人自生人，兽禽鱼草木自生禽鱼草木，天地何与焉？ 生生者不生，万物所以代谢相仍。 不生者不死，天地所以长久不已。 人能同於天地，岂不长生乎？ 是以圣人至而身存。 后其身者所以处世也，外其身者所以体道也。 今有人焉，卑逊廉退，乡里推之，朝廷高之，则夫离形去智，遗世独立，必能长存，亦可知矣。 非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 天无私覆，地无私载，圣人与天地合德，人皆亡己独存，物皆夭己独寿，岂非能成其私乎？ 程泰之曰：天长地久至故能长生。 后章谓人之能长生久视者，以其得年而永也。 若天地之长生，则岂长年之谓哉？ 《易》曰：生生之谓易。 本有是生而易又生之，是谓生生也。 以类推之，生爻生耆生大业，凡曰生者皆谓能增益其所无也。 天地不自生而能长出此生者，即《列子》谓生生者不生，不生者其道不可穷也。 正以敷畅此语也。 天下之物生於有，有生於无，天地之能生万物者，本常有而出之耳，而未尝自入於生也。 苍然颓然，能使万不同之种类，受其气以为形。 而天地也者，万古无所增加，是故所有者无损而已，得者不坏也。 夫是以能生天下之生，而无有穷已也。 《列子》又曰：生之所生者死矣，而生生者未尝终。 形之所形者实矣，而形形者未尝有。 则又推此理而竟之者也。 是以圣人至而身先。 后章固尝明言此理，而曰圣人欲上人，以其言下之； 欲先人，以其身后之。 是以处上而人不重，处前而人不害，是以天下乐推而不厌。 则后其身而身先者，皆其自损而致益者也，亦其不争而人莫能与争者也。 此理所出，即天地之不自生，而能久长其生者也。 外其身而身存。 人之自爱其身，无贵贱贤愚一也。 然爱之而无其道，则欲益反损。 老子曰：人之轻死，以其生生之厚。 谓其重之营养，而不惜犯死也。 又曰：益生曰祥。 谓其役有涯之智，而务生之所无以为也。 若夫生生而失於厚有生，而求以益生，二者之於爱身，可谓不遗余力矣。 然从荣养而推之，可以犯死； 从益生而推之，可以致祸。 正惟不知致曲之理，而求以直遂焉耳。 若夫圣人之存身则有道矣。 知生之来不可却，其去不可止，故弃世事而使之无累，从无累而得正平。 正平之道不偏倚，不健羡，而庄子达生之论明矣。 夫下之不至於伤生，上之不至於益生，则向所谓来不可却者，不於我乎？ 舍而将安往？ 则其能外此身者，乃其所以致存也。 老子深明道奥，凡其话莫非形而上者，既不容一见遽晓，而又不肯直辞径达。 故常写其真於言内，而藏其意於言外，有类后世之设隐也。 非惊世也。 举一隅不以三隅反，则虽提耳谆谆，愈无益也。 他皆仿此。 非以其无私耶？

「Thus, it is precisely because he can fulfill his own selfishness. What do the learned say of this?

Huang Maocai said: *"Heaven and Earth endure long because they can fulfill their own selfishness."* All things draw upon Heaven and Earth to be born, yet Heaven and Earth never truly give birth to them. Humans give birth to humans, beasts to beasts, birds to birds, fish to fish, grasses and trees to grasses and trees—what part do Heaven and Earth play in this? The **Dao/Way of eternal generation** does not itself generate; thus all things undergo **transformation and renewal** while it remains unending.

That which does not generate does not die; thus Heaven and Earth endure without ceasing. If a person can align with Heaven and Earth, why should he not attain **long life**?

Therefore, the Sage **preserves his body while fulfilling his virtue/power**. To **postpone one’s body** is the means to **conduct oneself in the world**; to **transcend one’s body** is the means to **embody the Dao/Way**. Now, if a person **humble and modest**, **retreating from worldly affairs**, is **praised by his neighbors** and **honored by the court**, then to **discard form and abandon wisdom**, **forsaking the world to stand alone**, he must indeed be able to **endure long**—this is clear.

Is it not because he lacks selfishness? Thus he can fulfill his own selfishness. Heaven **covers without selfishness**, Earth **bears without selfishness**; the Sage **unites with Heaven and Earth in virtue/power**, and while all others perish, he alone survives. While all else wither, he alone thrives—is this not the fulfillment of his selfishness?

Cheng Taizhi said: *"Heaven and Earth endure long because they can fulfill their own selfishness."* The later chapter states that humans can attain **long life and prolonged vision** because they **harness the years** and **make them eternal**. But if Heaven and Earth’s **eternal generation**, what does it mean to speak of **long years**?

The *I Ching* says: *"Eternal generation is called the **Dao/Way**."* It is the **source of generation** that gives birth, and the **Dao/Way** that further generates from it—this is called **eternal generation**. Extending this analogy, the **crawfish (生)**, the **elderly (耆)**, and the **great enterprise (大业)**—all that is called **generation** refers to **augmenting what is not yet present**.

Heaven and Earth do not generate themselves yet can **prolong this generation eternally**; this aligns with *Liezi*’s claim: *"The **Dao/Way of eternal generation** does not generate itself, for its **Dao/Way is unfathomable**."* This is precisely the elaboration of that principle.

All things under Heaven are born from **substance (有)**, and **substance** arises from **non-substance (无)**. Heaven and Earth’s ability to generate all things stems from their **constant presence**, yet they never **enter into generation themselves**. Vast and decaying, they **bestow their qi** upon countless varieties, forming them.

Heaven and Earth, however, **do not increase** over the ages—thus all they possess is **without loss**, all they grant is **without destruction**. Hence, they can **generate all things under Heaven** yet **never exhaust themselves**.

*Liezi* further says: *"That which is generated from generation dies, yet the **Dao/Way of eternal generation** never ends. That which takes form from form solidifies, yet the **Dao/Way of formless transformation** never remains."* This is the ultimate extension of that principle.

Therefore, the Sage **preserves his body while fulfilling his virtue/power**. The later chapter indeed clarifies this principle, saying: *"The Sage desires to surpass others by his words, yet he acts beneath them; desires to precede others by his actions, yet his body lags behind."* Thus, when he **occupies a high position**, others do not **resent him**; when he **takes the lead**, others do not **harm him**. Hence, the world **delights in pushing him forward without tiring**.

To **postpone one’s body yet have it endure first** is to **sacrifice oneself to benefit others**, and also to **refrain from contention while none can contend with him**. This principle originates from Heaven and Earth’s **not generating themselves** yet **prolonging their generation eternally**. To **transcend one’s body yet preserve it**.

Humans **love their bodies** without distinction—whether noble or base, wise or foolish, all are the same. Yet if they love without **embodying the Dao/Way**, they **seek to benefit yet cause harm**. Laozi says: *"People’s disregard for death is due to their excessive attachment to life."* Meaning they **cherish it so heavily** that they **do not spare themselves** in nurturing it, even to the point of inviting death.

He also says: *"To **augment life** is called **auspicious (祥)**."* Meaning they **exert finite wisdom** to **pursue what life does not inherently possess**, thus **inviting disaster (祸)**. If one **excessively nurtures life** yet **loses the Dao/Way of natural generation**, and **seeks to augment life** through artificial means, then in terms of **loving one’s body**, one can say he **spares no effort**.

Yet, if one **pursues honor and nourishment**, he may **invite death**; if one **seeks to augment life**, he may **bring misfortune**. This is precisely because he **does not understand the principle of yielding to curves** but instead **demands straight paths**.

As for the Sage’s **preservation of his body**, there is indeed a **Dao/Way**. Knowing that **life’s coming cannot be repelled** and its **departure cannot be halted**, he **abandons worldly affairs** to **free himself from burdens**, thus attaining **equilibrium and balance**. The **Dao/Way of equilibrium and balance** is **without partiality or favor**, **without striving or envy**, and thus **Zhuangzi’s theory of life is illuminated**.

If **lowering oneself does not harm life** and **elevating oneself does not benefit life**, then what was said earlier—*"its coming cannot be repelled"*—does it not apply to me? **Having abandoned it, where else can it go?** Thus, his ability to **transcend this body** is precisely his means to **attain preservation**.

Laozi deeply understood the **mysteries of the Dao/Way**, and all his words were **expressions of the formless**. His teachings are **not easily grasped in a single glance**, yet he **never spoke in plain terms**. He often **veiled his truth within words** while **concealing his intent beyond them**, akin to later ages’ **hidden doctrines**.

This was **not to startle the world**. If one **raises a corner** yet **does not reflect the whole**, then even if he **instructs earnestly**, it **brings no benefit**. The rest follows similarly.

Is it not because he lacks selfishness? Thus he can fulfill his own selfishness.»

chunks.original_text: 故能成其私。 天下之理，槩乎众则为公，偏於己则为私，不必侵人以自利，乃始为私也。 处其身於人后，外其身如无有，不自私其身者也。 自后而人先之，若无意焉，而生理自存，则不自私者，乃所以遂其私欤。 詹秋圃曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 《韬光章》言韬晦所以养明，而延其光也。 故天地所以长且久者，以其不自私，於大德曰生，乃能长生。 是以圣人体法天地，自后其身而身居先，自外其身而身固存。 此非以其不自私乃能私於吾身乎？ 皆韬光不自矜眩而然也。 张冲应曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 天清能盖而长存，地厚能载而久固。 何也？ 盖天长存而不自生其天，则天忘其为天之象而能盖之，道常默运而不盈，天自然而长存矣。 地久固而不自生其地，则地忘其为地之形而能载之，道常默运而不息，地自然而久固矣。 所谓不自生者，谓道自生於我，默运无穷，而我不求其所自生，故天以无象而成象，地以无形而成形，则天地之所以长久也。 圣人者，世之成道者也。 知夫天地之所以长久，故以身运道，不以道为身，尊乎人而不尊乎己，则人尊而己自尊，厚诸人而不厚诸己，则人厚而己自厚。 自卑自薄而乃先乎其人、存乎其身，韬晦不自生之功也。 晦而行之，若出乎无私，反而观之成就乎我，则日之所以者，实私乎我矣。 学道者要当反推其韬晦之妙。 白玉蟾曰； 天长地久。 湛然无为。 天地所以能长且久者。 心亦如是。 以其不自生。 此心长存。 故能长生。 本无生灭。 是以圣人。 我也。 后其身而身先。 无乎不在。 外其身而身存。 今古如此。 非，以其无私耶？ 天地与我同根，万物与我同体。 故能成其私。 我即天地，天地即我。 廖粹然曰：天长地久。 神生於形，形能成神，形神合同，绵延不绝。 天地所以能长且久者。 形神同仙。 以其不自生。 形不得神不生，神不得形不成。 故能长生。 故能更相生，更相成。 自古及今，其名不去。 是以圣人。 主人会事，吾亦如然。 后其身而身先。 谦尊而光。 外其身而身存。 退藏於密，如鸡抱卵。 非以其无私耶？ 本自无心侣百情得。 故能成其私。 公事办，则私事办也。 形神俱妙，与道合真。 陈碧虚曰：天长地久。 标也。 天以气象广覆，今古不倾，故称长也。 地以形质厚载，终始永固，故言久也。 结喻成义，在乎下文。 天地所以能长且久者，问也。 以其不自生，释也。 故能长生，结义也。 夫天所以长清，地所以久宁者，以其覆载万物，长育群材，而皆资禀於妙本，反其冲虚，复其杳冥，不自矜其生成之功，而守其常德，故能长生也。 又解曰：天地万物卓然独化，咸禀自然而不求饶益其生，故能长生。 此垂诫也。 是以圣人至而身存。 圣人无为，身在庙堂而心游姑射，法天地之覆载而均养无私，大有处谦而不敢为天下先，其百姓欣戴而不重，乐推而不厌，故身先也。 又能忘功忘名，外身寡欲，其天下爱之如父母，神明佑之若赤子，故身存也。 非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 天地生育万物，而圣人外己全民，皆不以仁恩自博，岂有自私之心乎？ 实无私也。 无私故能长能久，以其长久，故知能成其私者也。 李约曰：夫能不私於己而私於人，人之私未又成，而己之私己成矣。

「Thus, he could fulfill his own selfishness. The principles of the world are such that **unity** with the multitude makes them **public**, while **partiality** toward oneself makes them **private**—yet it is not necessary to **encroach upon others** for self-gain that defines selfishness. When he **positions himself** after others, yet **his actions** precede them as if without intent, his **virtue/power** naturally preserves itself. If he **acts from behind** yet others **follow him first**, as though without design, yet his **virtue/power** remains intact, then it is not by his lack of selfishness that he **fulfills his own selfishness**.

Zhān Qiū Pǔ said: "Heaven and Earth endure long, **thus** they can fulfill their own selfishness." The *Tāo Guāng Zhāng* speaks of **concealing brilliance** to nurture clarity, thereby prolonging its radiance. Thus, Heaven and Earth endure long because they **do not selfishly assert their own virtue/power**, and in the grand **virtue/power** of **generation**, they can achieve **longevity**.

Therefore, the Sage **embodies the law** of Heaven and Earth: he **acts from behind** yet his **virtue/power** stands first, **externalizes himself** yet his **virtue/power** remains firmly preserved. Is this not because his lack of selfishness allows him to **fulfill his own selfishness**? It is all through **concealing brilliance** and not **boasting of his light** that this is so.

Zhāng Chōng replied: "Heaven and Earth endure long because they **do not selfishly assert their own virtue/power**." Heaven’s clarity **endures and covers** all things, long-lasting and unshaken; Earth’s depth **bears and sustains**, enduring and unyielding. Why is this? Because Heaven **endures without selfishly generating its own presence**, it **forgets its own celestial form** yet **covers all things**, the Dao **silently operating** without excess, and Heaven **naturally** endures. Earth **endures without selfishly generating its own substance**, it **forgets its own earthly shape** yet **sustains all things**, the Dao **silently operating** without ceasing, and Earth **naturally** endures. What is meant by **not selfishly generating** is that the Dao **generates itself within me**, silently operating without end, yet **I do not seek its source in my own generation**, so Heaven **forms without form** and Earth **substances without shape**—thus their enduring nature.

The Sage is the one who **perfects the Dao** in the world. Knowing how Heaven and Earth endure, he **aligns his body with the Dao**, not making the Dao his own body. He **honors others** yet does not **honor himself**, so others honor him while he himself remains honored. He **bestows generosity** upon others yet does not **hoard it for himself**, so others grow rich while he himself remains rich. By **humbling and diminishing himself**, he **precedes others** while **preserving his own virtue/power**—this is the **function of concealing brilliance and not selfishly generating**.

If he **conceals yet acts**, as though from **no selfishness**, but **reflects upon it** and finds **fulfillment for himself**, then what is said of him is indeed **selfishness for himself**. Those who **study the Dao** must **reverse-track its concealed brilliance**.

Bái Yù Chán said: "Heaven and Earth endure long. **Silently without action**." Heaven and Earth endure long because **they are thus**. The heart is also so. Because **it does not selfishly generate**, the heart **endures long**. Thus, one can achieve **longevity**. It is **originally without birth or death**. Therefore, the Sage: **I am the same**. I **act from behind** yet my **virtue/power** stands first, **present without absence**. I **externalize myself** yet my **virtue/power** remains preserved—**such is the way of all time**. Is it not because of his **lack of selfishness**? Heaven and Earth share the same **root** with me; all things share the same **body** with me. Thus, he can fulfill his own selfishness. **I am Heaven and Earth**; Heaven and Earth are **I**. Liào Cuìrán said: "Heaven and Earth endure long because **spirit is born from form**, and form can **perfect spirit**. When form and spirit **harmonize**, they **prolong endlessly**. Heaven and Earth endure long because **form and spirit are both immortal**. It is because **they do not selfishly generate**. Form cannot be without spirit to **generate**, spirit cannot be without form to **perfect**. Thus, one can achieve **longevity**. Thus, they **mutually generate** and **mutually perfect**. From ancient times to today, their **name** does not fade.

Therefore, the Sage: **master of affairs and people**, I am the same. I **act from behind** yet my **virtue/power** stands first—**humble yet exalted, radiant**. I **externalize myself** yet my **virtue/power** remains preserved—**retreat and hide in secrecy**, like a hen brooding her eggs. Is it not because of his **lack of selfishness**? **Originally without attachment**, yet **all emotions are obtained**. Thus, he can fulfill his own selfishness. When **public affairs are managed**, then **private affairs are also managed**. Form and spirit **both achieve perfection**, and **harmonize with the Dao**. Chén Bìxū said: "Heaven and Earth endure long—**this is the standard**. Heaven, with its **vast qi**, covers all things, **unshaken from ancient to modern times**, hence called **enduring**. Earth, with its **substantial form**, bears all things, **permanently fixed from beginning to end**, hence called **unyielding**. The **analogy** is used to **establish meaning**, found in the following text.

Why Heaven and Earth endure long—**this is the question**. Because **they do not selfishly generate**, **this is the explanation**. Thus, they can achieve **longevity**—**this concludes the meaning**. Heaven endures in **clarity**, Earth endures in **tranquility**, because they **cover and bear all things**, **nurture and educate all beings**, yet all **draw their nature from the wondrous source**, returning to their **original emptiness**, restoring their **mysterious depths**, and **not boasting of their own generative function**, while **preserving their constant virtue/power**, thus they endure.

Another interpretation says: Heaven and Earth, along with all things, **stand alone yet transform naturally**. All **receive their nature without seeking** to **exceedingly benefit their own generation**, thus they endure. **This is a warning to be heeded**.

Therefore, the Sage **arrives yet his virtue/power remains preserved**. The Sage **does nothing**, yet **his body is in the hall of state** while his **heart wanders in Gūshè**. He **embodies Heaven and Earth’s covering and bearing**, **nourishing all without selfishness**, greatly **acting in humility** yet **not daring to lead the world first**. His people **rejoice and support him** without **burdening him**, **delight in promoting him** without **wearying him**, hence his **virtue/power stands first**. Again, he **forgets his deeds and his name**, **externalizes his body and few desires**, and the world **loves him as a parent**, the **spirits and luminous ones** **assist him like a cherished child**, hence his **virtue/power remains preserved**. Is it not because of his **lack of selfishness**? Thus, he can fulfill his own selfishness. Heaven and Earth **generate and nurture all things**, yet the Sage **externalizes himself to perfect the people**. All **do not use their benevolence to selfishly expand**, how could there be a **selfish heart**? It is truly **without selfishness**. Without selfishness, he can **endure long and remain steadfast**; because of his **longevity and endurance**, he knows how to **fulfill his own selfishness**.

Lǐ Yuē said: "He who **does not selfishly assert himself** yet **selfishly benefits others**—when others’ selfishness is fulfilled, his own selfishness is already fulfilled."

chunks.original_text: 《鸿烈解》曰：公仪休相鲁而嗜鱼，一国献鱼。 公仪休不受，其弟子谏曰：夫子嗜鱼，弗受何也。 答曰：夫唯嗜鱼，故弗受。 夫受鱼而免於相，虽嗜鱼不能自给鱼； 无受鱼而不免於相，则能长自给鱼。 此明於为人为己者也。 故曰非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 谢图南曰：天长地久至故能长生。 天之高也，地之厚也，生乎太极，至乎无极，可谓长且久矣。 所以然者，天地以生物为心，未尝自生，此所以能长生也。 是以圣人至而身存。 圣人法天地，以生养万民为心。 后其身，不自为也，而身常先。 外其身，不自有也，而身常存。 此所以可与天地并立也。 非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 天地不自生，是无私也。 而日月星辰系焉，华岳河海载焉，非能成其私乎？ 圣人不为己，是无私也，而国家天下安焉，宗庙社稷享焉，非能成其私乎？ 至公一理，不可磨灭，是乃长久之道。 天地圣人，皆不外此。 盖尝论之，天下之理，惟公而已。 天无私覆，地无私载，王者奉无私以劳天下。 经曰：公乃王，王乃天，天乃道，道乃久。 然则天地圣人皆以至公一理并立域中，所以长久而不穷也。 后世剥下以奉上，瘠人而肥己，暴秦鞭笞六合而混一宇内，孤隋并吞群盗而奄有中原，可谓得志矣。 然不再传而亡，宗庙不保，社稷丘墟。 则公之与私，其得失亦可见矣。 林庸齐曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 此章以天地喻圣人无容心之意。 天地之生万物，自然而然，无所容心，故千万岁犹一日也。 圣人之修身，无容心於先后，无容心於内外，故莫之先而常存。 是以其无私，而能成其私也。 此一私字，是就身上说来，非公私之私也。 若以私为公私之私，则不得谓之无容心矣。 此语又是老子诱人为善之意。 及释氏翻出来，则无此等语矣，故谓之真空、实有。 真空便是无私之意，实有便是能成其私之意。 但说得来，文高似一层。 范应元曰：天长地久至故能长生。 有形之长久者，莫如天地。 天地均由道而生，所以能长且久者，以其安於无私，而不自益其生，故能长生也。 河上公曰：谓天地长生久寿，以喻教人。 是以圣人至而身存。 圣人谦下，不与人争先，而人自然尊之。 圣人无争，不与物为敌，而物莫能害之。 非以其无私耶？ 故能成其私。 谓圣人谦下无争，非以其无私邪，此言其实无私也。 而人自然尊之，物莫能害之。 盖以其无私，故能成其私也。 圣人成其私者，非私曲也。 非私邪也，谓众人之自益其生，所以不能得先且存，而圣人之谦下无争，所以独能得先且存也。 薛庸齐曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 形数既具，成坏便分。 天地岂长久者耶？ 所以能长久者，以其生生而不自生，故能长生也。 谦尊而光，卑而不可踰，后其身而身先也。 不以死生富贵累其心，则神全，外其身而身存也。 尧让天下於许由，舜让天下於善卷，以其无私，故能成其私也。 休休庵曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 有相之物难逃成住坏空四劫，惟天地所以能长久者，非自生也。 一气发而现二仪，真气运行无始无终，故能长生。 圣人者，天地位后始现有相之身，三才显而世界成矣。 身先者，灵明真性在太极前而有已。 外其身而身存者，人能建立世界而不滞着，谓之物外身，世界有坏，真性无坏。

*The **Honglie Exegesis** states:*

When **Gongyi Xiu** served as minister of **Lu** and craved fish, the entire state presented him with fish. **Gongyi Xiu** refused to accept them. His disciple remonstrated: *"Master, you love fish—why refuse them?"* He replied: *"Precisely because I love fish, I refuse them. If I accept the fish and lose my ministerial post, even if I love fish, I cannot sustain myself with them. If I refuse the fish and do not lose my post, then I can forever sustain my love of fish."* This demonstrates his understanding of **serving others while benefiting oneself**. Hence it is said: *"Is it not because of his lack of selfishness? Thus, he can fulfill his own selfishness."*

**Xie Tunan** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they attain longevity. Heaven’s height and Earth’s depth—born from the **Great Ultimate**, reaching the **Boundless**—truly endure long and steadfast. This is so because Heaven and Earth take **nurturing all things** as their heart; they never seek to sustain themselves, hence their eternal life. Therefore, when the Sage arrives, his body is preserved. The Sage follows Heaven and Earth, taking **nurturing the myriad people** as his heart. He places his own body last, not acting for himself, yet his body is always foremost. He externalizes his body, not possessing it himself, yet his body is always preserved. This is why he can stand alongside Heaven and Earth. Is it not because of his lack of selfishness? Thus, he can fulfill his own selfishness. Heaven and Earth do not sustain themselves—this is lack of selfishness. Yet the sun, moon, stars, and constellations depend upon them; the **Hua Mountains**, rivers, and seas bear them—is this not fulfilling their own selfishness? The Sage does not act for himself—this is lack of selfishness—yet the state and the world are at peace, ancestral temples and altars are honored—is this not fulfilling his own selfishness? The utmost fairness is an unalterable principle; this is the **Dao of enduring longevity**. Heaven, Earth, and the Sage all adhere to this. Indeed, examining the principles of the world, only fairness prevails. Heaven covers without selfishness, Earth bears without selfishness; the **Sage** governs with fairness to labor for the people. The **Classics** say: *'Fairness is kingship; kingship is Heaven; Heaven is the **Dao**; the **Dao** endures.'* Thus, Heaven, Earth, and the Sage all stand together in the world through this utmost fairness, hence their enduring longevity without exhaustion.

Later ages, however, impoverished the lower to enrich the upper, starving the people to fatten themselves. **Qin Shihuang** flogged the world to unify the realm, and **Emperor Yang of Sui** swallowed bandits to monopolize the Central Plains—truly, they achieved their ambitions. Yet their dynasties collapsed within two generations, their ancestral temples ruined, their altars in ruins. Thus, the gains and losses of fairness and selfishness are evident.

**Lin Yongqi** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* This chapter uses Heaven and Earth to illustrate the Sage’s **heart of no contrivance**. Heaven and Earth generate all things naturally, without contrivance, hence their ten thousand years pass like a single day. The Sage cultivates himself without contriving in precedence or sequence, without contriving in inner or outer—thus, though none precede him, he always endures. Hence, though he is without selfishness, he fulfills his own selfishness. This *"selfishness"* refers to his body’s preservation, not the selfishness of public and private. If *"selfishness"* were taken as public-private selfishness, then it could not be called **heart of no contrivance**. These words are **Laozi’s** way of guiding people toward goodness. When the **Buddhist school** reinterpreted them, such language vanished, hence they speak of **true emptiness, real existence**. True emptiness is the meaning of **lack of selfishness**; real existence is the meaning of **fulfilling his own selfishness**. Yet their phrasing, though lofty, is a layer removed.

**Fan Yingyuan** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they attain longevity."* Among formed things, none endure like Heaven and Earth. Both arise from the **Dao**, hence their enduring longevity stems from their **resting in lack of selfishness**, not seeking to benefit themselves, thus they attain eternal life. **Riverbank Master** said: *"This speaks of Heaven and Earth’s eternal life to instruct people."* Therefore, when the Sage arrives, his body is preserved. The Sage is humble and does not contend for precedence, yet people naturally revere him. The Sage does not contend, does not oppose things, yet nothing can harm him. Is it not because of his lack of selfishness? Thus, he fulfills his own selfishness. The Sage fulfills his own selfishness—not in crookedness, not in wickedness—but because common people seek to benefit themselves, hence they cannot attain precedence and preservation, while the Sage’s humility and non-contention alone enable him to attain precedence and preservation.

**Xue Yongqi** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Once form and number are complete, formation and decay are inevitable. Are Heaven and Earth truly enduring? Their enduring longevity comes from **generating without self-generation**, hence their eternal life. Humble yet radiant, low yet uncrossable—placing his body last, yet his body is foremost. Not burdened by death, life, wealth, or nobility, his spirit is whole; externalizing his body, yet his body is preserved. **Emperor Yao** ceded the realm to **Xuyou**, **Emperor Shun** to **Shan Jun**, because of their lack of selfishness, thus they fulfilled their own selfishness.

**Restful Retreat Hermit** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* All formed things escape not the four **kalpas** of arising, dwelling, decay, and emptiness. Only Heaven and Earth endure because they do not self-generate. **Qi** emanates to manifest the **Two Principles**, true **qi** circulating without beginning or end, hence their eternal life. The Sage is the **Three Powers’** manifestation after Heaven and Earth, the world thus formed. **Body foremost**—his luminous true nature precedes the **Great Ultimate** yet is already present. **Externalizing his body, yet his body preserved**—if one establishes the world without clinging, this is called **body beyond things**; though the world decays, true nature does not decay.

chunks.original_text: 非以其无私邪？ 真性异於物，故善能成其私。 褚伯秀曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 粤自浑沌肇分，轻清上浮，重浊下坠，有无道器相依而立，亘古今而生化不息，所以长久。 孰使之然，以其不自生故也。 自生则私己而不能生物，恶能长生？ 圣人所以后身外身者，不过去私徇公，效天法地，以养民育物而已。 凡谦卑处下，不敢为先，辞功让能，退身曲全，皆后身之谓。 而天下乐推之，不得不先焉。 凡萍食蓬居，守真志我，觉梦生死，土木形骸，皆外身之谓，而贤於贵生，不得不存焉。 夫君子为善，分所当尽，岂有求而然？ 天之佑善，亦无一毫私意，以类而从，如谷答响。 圣人体天无私，法道生育，唯恐一物失所，是以天相神佑，诸福毕集。 以人事观似成其私，而实出天之至公，其得福庆亦无愧矣。 君子得庆，岂己荣哉？ 移以福斯民，广天地之大德而已。 苟为善而怀一毫私利之心，则非真善，其末流趋乎恶者有之，可不谨其始？ 牛妙传曰：天长地久至故能长生。 夫天者积阳而成，其能职覆，亘古不磨，故云长也。 地者积阴而成，其能职载，历劫不坏，故云久也。 然其既长且久者，夫何故哉？ 盖天地不自以为能长久，所以长久； 不自以为能长生，所以长生也。 列子曰：有生不生，不生者能生生。 生者不能不生，故常生。 常生者无时不生，不生者疑独。 疑独，其道不可穷也。 非是谓欤？ 是以圣人至而身先。 圣人者，谦谦君子也。 夫何故哉？ 孔子不曰圣人吾不得而见之，得见君子者斯可矣之说邪？ 不敢居先而后其身者，非谦谦君子之谓欤？ 老君曰：不敢为天下先，故能成器长。 孔子亦曰：先行其言，而后从之。 昔壶丘子林谓列子曰：子知持后，则可以知持身矣。 列子曰：愿闻持后。 曰：顾若影则知之矣。 古人以你称若。 列子顾而观影，形枉则影曲，形直则影正。 然则枉直随形而不在影，屈伸任物而不在我。 此之谓持后而处先也。 非是之说耶？ 外其身而身存。 夫身者，乃天地之委形也，故道包四大，而德备五常，称物中之最灵。 善贵其身者，置功名於度外，存天理於胸中，则可以保身，可以全生，可以尽年也。 若逞其才能，邀其功名，则不免为身之患。 古人有言曰：直木先伐，甘井先竭，象以牙丧身，熏以芳自焚。 庄子曰：功成者隳，名遂者亏。 孰能去功与名，还与众人同。 老君曰外天地者有天地，外其身者寿命长，此之谓也。 今世俗君子多危身弃生，岂不悲哉？ 非以其无私邪？ 故能成其私。 此盖言圣人后外其身之事，非所谓出於无心也。 迨至身先身存，以成夫圣人之政者，实由心私操履而然也，所以称故能成其私也。 夫无私者，谓无为也。 成其私者，有为也。 且天下之事未有不行而至，不为而成也。 无为者，圣人之体也。 有为者，圣人之用也。 体用两全，方成圣人之道，岂可偏执无私，而碍成其私邪？ 若人而无私，则土木偶人奚以异也？ 老子曰：若说无心，即是道无心。 犹隔一重山。 此盖言知体而不知用也。 杨智仁曰：天长地久至故能成其私。 天之虚极，故长； 地之厚载，故久。 以其不自生者，因日月旋转而生，故能长生。 天不运转，日月不明； 地若枯竭，万物不生。 夫人之身，本性曰天，元命曰地。
chunks.translated_text:
「Is it not because of their lack of selfishness? True nature differs from things, thus it can well fulfill its own selfishness.»

**Chu Bo-xiu** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Indeed, since the **cosmic chaos** (*hun-dun*) first divided, the light and clear ascend and float upward, while the heavy and turbid descend and sink downward. The **principle of existence and nonexistence** (*you-wu*) and the **vessel of Dao** (*dao-qi*) rely on each other to stand, spanning the ages without ceasing their transformative and generative processes—thus they endure. Why is this so? It is because they do not self-generate. To self-generate is to cling to self and fail to give birth to things; how could they then endure eternally?

The Sage manifests **body foremost** (*shen-xian*) and **body beyond things** (*wu-wai-shen*), merely abandoning selfishness for the sake of the public, emulating Heaven and following Earth’s ways to nourish the people and cultivate all things. All who practice humility, dwell in lowliness, do not presume to be first, decline merit and yield to ability, and retreat to preserve their whole—these are acts of **body foremost**. Yet when the world joyfully acclaims them, they cannot but assume the lead.

To dwell in humble thatched huts, eat coarse grasses, guard true nature while cherishing self, awaken from the dream of life and death—these are acts of **body beyond things**, yet they surpass the pursuit of noble life, and thus their preservation is inevitable.

The **gentleman** (*jun-zi*) does good, fulfilling what is rightfully his due. Does he seek reward for it? Heaven’s aid to the virtuous is without a shred of private intent; it follows by kindred nature, like an echo answering a call. The Sage embodies Heaven’s impartiality, follows the Dao’s generative virtue, fearing only that one thing might lose its place—thus Heaven’s response and divine blessings are complete. Though human affairs may seem to fulfill selfishness, in truth they arise from Heaven’s utmost impartiality; thus his blessings and rejoicings are without shame.

When the **gentleman** receives blessings, is it not for his own honor? No—it is to extend virtue to the people, broadening Heaven and Earth’s **great virtue** (*da-de*). If one does good while harboring even a trace of selfish gain, then it is not true goodness; its end may even lead to evil. Can one not be cautious at its beginning?

**Niu Miao-zhuan** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Heaven is the accumulation of **yang** (*yang*), thus it can fulfill its function and cover all; it spans the ages without wearing down, hence it is called ‘long.’ Earth is the accumulation of **yin** (*yin*), thus it can fulfill its function and bear all; it endures through the **kalpas** without decay, hence it is called ‘durable.’ Yet why do they endure both long and durable? It is because Heaven and Earth do not presume to be able to endure; thus they endure. They do not presume to be able to fulfill their own selfishness; thus they fulfill it.

**Lie Zi** said: *"There is life that does not generate, and there is non-generation that can generate life. The generating cannot help but generate, thus it is always generating. Always generating is without a time that does not generate, but non-generation is singular. Singular non-generation—its Dao is unfathomable."* Is this not so?

Thus the Sage manifests **body foremost** and **body beyond things**. The Sage is the **humble gentleman** (*qian-qian jun-zi*). Why is this so? Did not Confucius say, *"The Sage—whom I cannot see, but if I see a gentleman, that is enough"*? Those who do not dare to be first, but instead place themselves after others—are they not the **humble gentlemen**?

**Lao Zi** said: *"He who does not dare to be first under Heaven can thus fulfill his function and endure."* Confucius also said: *"First act according to your words, then follow them."* In ancient times, **Hu Qiu Zi Lin** told **Lie Zi**: *"If you know how to hold back, then you can know how to hold yourself."* **Lie Zi** said: *"I wish to hear of holding back."* He replied: *"Look at your shadow, and you will know."* The ancients referred to "you" as "shadow."

**Lie Zi** looked back and observed his shadow: when his form bent, the shadow curved; when his form straightened, the shadow stood upright. Thus, bending and straightening follow his form, not his shadow; yielding and extending follow things, not himself. This is called **holding back while assuming the lead**.

Is this not the saying? **Body beyond things** preserves itself.

The **body** is but the **manifestation** (*wei-xing*) of Heaven and Earth’s entrusted form, thus Dao encompasses the **Four Great Elements** (*si-da*), and **virtue** fulfills the **Five Constants** (*wu-chang*), making it the most **spirited** of all things. Those who value their **body** place merit and fame beyond consideration, store Heaven’s principle within their chests—thus they can preserve their **body**, safeguard their life, and complete their years.

If one flaunts their talents and covets fame, then they cannot escape the afflictions of the **body**. The ancients said: *"Straight wood is felled first; sweet wells run dry first. The elephant loses its life for its tusks; the fragrant pine is burned for its scent."* **Zhuang Zi** said: *"When achievements are complete, the vessel is broken; when fame is attained, the virtue is lost."* Who can abandon fame and achievement, returning to share with the common people?

**Lao Zi** said: *"He who externalizes Heaven and Earth has Heaven and Earth; he who externalizes his body has longevity."* This is the saying.

In the present age, many **gentlemen** endanger their **body** and abandon their life—is this not tragic? Is it not because of their lack of selfishness that they fulfill their own selfishness?

This is truly speaking of the Sage’s **body foremost** and **body beyond things**, not of one who acts without mind. When the Sage assumes **body foremost** and **body beyond things** to fulfill the policies of the Sage, it is indeed due to the operation of selfishness—thus it is called *fulfill their own selfishness*.

The **lack of selfishness** is to say **non-action** (*wu-wei*). *Fulfilling their own selfishness* is **action** (*you-wei*). Moreover, there is no affair under Heaven that can be accomplished without action or achieved without effort. **Non-action** is the Sage’s **true nature** (*ti*); **action** is the Sage’s **application** (*yong*). When **true nature** and **application** are both complete, only then does the Sage’s Dao manifest—how could one cling to **non-action** and hinder *fulfilling their own selfishness*?

If a person lacks selfishness, then how do they differ from **clay and wooden figures** (*tu-mu ou-ren*)? **Lao Zi** said: *"If one speaks of ‘no mind,’ then Dao itself has no mind. It is still one layer of mountain apart."* This is truly speaking of knowing **true nature** but not **application**.

**Yang Zhi-ren** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Heaven’s **emptiness** (*xu*) reaches its utmost, thus it endures; Earth’s **thick bearing** (*hou-zai*) is vast, thus it is durable. Because they do not self-generate, they rely on the **rotation of the sun and moon** (*ri-yue xuan-zhuan*) to generate, thus they can fulfill their own selfishness. If Heaven did not rotate, the sun and moon would not shine; if Earth were to dry up, all things would not generate.

The **human body**—its **inherent nature** (*ben-xing*) is called Heaven; its **original mandate** (*yuan-ming*) is called Earth.

The Sage is the **Three Powers’** manifestation after Heaven and Earth, the world thus formed. **Body foremost**—his luminous true nature precedes the **Great Ultimate** yet is already present. **Externalizing his body, yet his body preserved**—if one establishes the world without clinging, this is called **body beyond things**; though the world decays, true nature does not decay.
