chunks.original_text: 论八十一章，其申言不争之益者凡六。 曰：不自伐故有功，不自矜故长，夫唯不争，故天下莫能与之争。 是其一也。 欲上人而下之，欲先人而后之，以其不争，故天下莫能与之争。 则其二也。 天道不争而善胜。 三也。 圣人之道为而不争。 四也。 战而不武，胜而不与，是谓不争之德。 五也。 与此之不争无尤者，凡六也。 夫其谓争者，非必至於斗且战也，彼己四对两不相下，斯为争矣。 天之阴阳，至神而无着也，然常以冬夏二至而争，盖己居其地者未退，而方来待代者欲前，此之谓争。 故争者，对起而不退听之谓也。 有得乎道者则不然矣。 知雄守雌是能为而能不为者也。 功能可以加人，而付之无有； 智力足以盖世，而韬藏不用。 其所操蕴常不肯为天下先，则安得有争也哉？ 盖列子尝言常胜常不胜之道矣，曰：古之言强，先不己若者，至於若己而殆矣。 夫若己而殆，是好胜而必遇其敌者也，会必至於不胜也。 又曰：言柔，先出於己者亡所殆矣。 是不与之争，而彼自无所与争也。 此其胜所以可必也。 用此理也推而极之，则虽两陈相加，己战而胜，犹得谓之不争也。 主柔以待须其可毙，而后从而乘之，则皆名为不争。 此所以为常胜之道也。 虽然，此之谓常胜者，主我而言也。 利则进，不利则姑自保己，是重於独善而轻於为人者也。 其在老语虽其深妙者，亦常先存此身不殆之理，乃肯出身而任事。 不然则否。 盖古之为是学者，必已多矣。 故晨门之讥孔子曰：是知其不可而为之者欤。 荷蒉者亦曰：鄙哉硁硁乎莫己知也，斯已而已矣。 此二子者非无忧世之意，而度天下莫与己合则舍之，而听其自然尔。 凡此类疑皆治道家语，而不肯任事者也。 乃若孔子之规模，则不然矣。 既闻荷黄之语，则自叹曰果哉，末之难矣。 夫爱一身而忘天下，此岂孔子不能哉？ 盖重於救世，宁有不可即而即之，未有可即而不即者也。 此五就五去与夫七十二聘者，皆能任天下於其身者也。 故夫老氏之见虽不失为道，而孔子之所忍也，若揆之其身，则重於为己者，祸辱决不能及也。 故削迹伐木，老氏之所不遭也。 詹秋圃曰：上善若水至故无尤。 易性章欲以吾性而易利物之水性，故曰上善若水。 水善利万物而不争。 然水利万物，而水溢水涸，亦害物，惟善处众人之所恶，则几近於道。 何则？ 人善处身於平土而居。 心善渊。 深而静，与博施以仁立。 言善主以信，善治本乎正，善能办乎事，善动顺乎时。 无非兼利物我而安，便所以天下自无怨尤。 且人性本善，上善何取於水，此又不易之易，而持以类求之耳。 张冲应曰：上善若水至故无尤。 水之为性，卑下而柔顺也。 探之而虚，视之而明，运之於天则为雨为露，运之於地则为江为河。 动者以之而浮，植者以之而生，污者以之而洁，刚者以之而柔，万物藉之以有成也。 是以万物归之，咸被其泽，而无此可入彼不可入之争辩也。 众人者，谓世之众人，孰不归尊，而视卑恃，持刚而侮柔，殊不知夫水之所以卑下而柔顺，其中有妙用存焉。 此无物不为水之所制也。 人生而长，所为之性有如水之性，则为上善之人矣。 故其妙几微而日进於道，凡见之所居则润泽滂流，而居善地矣； 运之於心则虚明沉深，而心善渊矣；
chunks.translated_text:
**Discourse on Eighty-One Chapters: Sixfold Elucidation of the Benefits of Non-Contention**

First, it is said:
*"He who does not vaunt himself has merit,
He who does not boast endures long.
Only because he does not contend,
the world cannot contend with him."*
This is the first.

Second:
*"To place oneself above others yet serve them,
To precede others yet follow them—
because he does not contend,
the world cannot contend with him."*
This is the second.

Third:
*"The Way of Heaven acts without contention yet achieves victory."*

Fourth:
*"The Sage’s Way acts without contention."*

Fifth:
*"To wage war without force,
To win without claiming victory—
this is the virtue of non-contention."*

Sixth:
*"Thus, the sixfold non-contention incurs no blame."*

Now, what is called *contention* is not necessarily war or battle.
When two opposing forces refuse to yield—
this is contention.
Though Heaven’s yin and yang are most subtle and ungraspable,
they still contend at the winter and summer solstices—
for the departing force has not withdrawn,
while the incoming force presses forward.
This is called contention.
Thus, contention is when opposing forces arise and neither yields.

But those who grasp the Dao are otherwise.
Knowing to embrace the feminine while guarding the masculine,
they act yet do not act.
Their abilities could benefit others, yet they withhold them;
their wisdom could overshadow the world, yet they conceal it.
They never seek to lead the world first—
how then could there be contention?

Indeed, Liezi spoke of the Dao of perpetual victory and perpetual defeat:
*"The ancients spoke of strength—
those who do not yet surpass me,
when they surpass me, are in peril.
To surpass me and yet be in peril—
this is one who loves victory and must meet his match,
and thus must surely be defeated."*

Again, he said:
*"The gentle one—
those who act first perish,
while those who do not contend face no peril.
Thus, their victory is certain."*

Pushing this logic to its extreme:
Even if two armies clash and I win,
it may still be called non-contention.
I wait in gentleness until the moment of collapse,
then strike—
and this too is non-contention.
Thus is the Dao of perpetual victory.

Yet this is perpetual victory from my perspective alone.
I advance when advantageous,
and withdraw when not—
prioritizing self-cultivation over benefiting others.
Though Laozi’s words are profound,
his approach preserves the self at all costs,
only acting when peril is absent.
Otherwise, he refrains.

Indeed, many ancient scholars were like this.
Morning Gate mocked Confucius:
*"Is this not knowing the impossible yet doing it?"*
The man with the basket also said:
*"How vulgar! Stubborn and unrecognized—
this is enough!"*
These two, though concerned with the world,
when they found none to align with them,
simply let things be.

All such doubts belong to the Daoist path,
those unwilling to take action.

But Confucius was otherwise.
Hearing the basket-man’s words, he sighed:
*"Ah, the end is indeed difficult!"*
Though loving one’s life while neglecting the world
was not beyond Confucius,
he prioritized saving the world—
approaching what must be approached,
never shirking what must be done.
Thus, the Five Approaches, the Five Withdrawals,
and the seventy-two visits—
all bore the world upon his shoulders.

Though Laozi’s view was not without merit,
Confucius endured what he could not.
If measured by self-preservation,
misfortune and disgrace could not touch him.
Thus, he was spared the fate of being hacked to pieces or felled like wood.

Zhan Qiupu said:
*"The Supreme Good resembles water—
thus it incurs no blame."*
In the chapter *"Changing Nature,"*
it says to replace my nature with water’s nature of benefiting others—
hence, *"The Supreme Good resembles water."*
Water benefits all things without contention.

Yet water, though it benefits all,
when it floods or dries, harms them.
Only by dwelling where others abhor
does it nearly approach the Dao.

Why?
The body thrives on level ground,
the mind on depth.
Deep and still, it aligns with broad benevolence.
Speech thrives on trust,
governance on rectitude,
action on timely opportunity.
All these harmonize self and others,
bringing ease—
thus the world naturally holds no grievance.

Moreover, human nature is inherently good.
Why then compare the Supreme Good to water?
This is the most natural of transformations,
yet it is sought through analogy.

Zhang Chongying said:
*"The Supreme Good resembles water—
thus it incurs no blame."*
Water’s nature is lowly and yielding.
Probed, it is empty;
observed, it is clear.
In Heaven, it becomes rain or dew;
on Earth, rivers and streams.
The moving rely on it to float,
the rooted rely on it to grow,
the impure rely on it to cleanse,
the rigid rely on it to soften—
all things depend on it to flourish.
Thus all things turn to it,
all are nourished by its grace,
yet there is no contention—
no *"this may enter, that may not."*

The common folk—
the world’s masses—
who does not revere the high and despise the low,
who does not wield rigidity to humiliate the gentle?
They fail to see that water’s lowliness and yielding
hold a wondrous efficacy—
nothing resists it.

When a person’s nature aligns with water’s nature,
they become the Supreme Good.
Thus, its subtlety grows daily with the Dao.
Wherever they dwell, they nourish and flow—
dwelling in the best places.
In the heart, they are empty, clear, and profound—
the mind is deeply settled.

chunks.original_text: 交之於物则物因以成，而与善仁矣； 发之於言则真实不妄，而言善信矣； 用以正人则彼非此是，自然明白，而正善治矣； 用以处事则方圆曲直泛应而当，而事善能矣。 晨昏昼夜，升降消息，不耗不为，动有其时矣。 七善既备，默运於中，恶性易而善性生，斯不校於人，亦无所尤於人。 则进於其道深矣。 斯曰夫唯不争，故无尤。 白玉蟾曰：上善若水。 性犹水也。 水善。 不为物所件而已。 利万物而不争。 初何心哉？ 处众人之所恶。 於我何有？ 故几於道。 心亦如此。 居善地。 无所择也。 心善渊。 有所养也。 与善仁。 无分彼此。 言善信。 真实。 正善治。 无往不正。 事善能。 无为无所不为。 动善时。 与时偕行。 夫唯不争。 方寸不竞。 故无尤。 亦不以为福也。 廖粹然曰：上善若水。 大道妙用，如水之行。 水善利万物而不争。 以柔弱，故任人所为。 处众人之所恶。 百姓日用而不知，是道体。 故几於道。 可谓真常。 居善地。 故能处平。 心善渊。 方寸澄澈，常能清浄。 与善仁。 利济一切。 言善信。 谓能中正。 正善治。 常主公平。 事善能。 清净道炁。 动善时。 行止有节。 夫唯不争。 任人所使，何尝逆人？ 故无尤。 终无怨憾。 人若如之，故能成道也。 陈碧虚曰：上善若水。 上善者标人也。 若水者，举喻也。 夫至人虚怀无欲，应变随时，不逆诸缘，处善忘善。 故曰上善。 夫水能方圆疑释，深浅浮沉，顺道涵虚，咸有其理，唯圣人兼而通之。 故曰若水。 且水蕴三能之近道，七善之利物，谓下文也。 水善利万物至故几於道。 此三能之近道也。 夫水性平静，散润一切，故天无水则阳旱，地无水则尘飞，利泽万物，故曰善利。 此一能也。 天下柔弱莫过於水，去实归虚，背高趋下，壅之则止，决之则流，听从於人，故曰不争。 此二能也。 人之情恶处下流，好居上位，而水则就卑受浊，处恶不乱，令物洁白，独纳污辱，故曰处众人之所恶。 此三能也。 几，近也。 夫水利物则其仁广大，不争则其德谦光，处恶则其量忍垢。 举水性之三能。 唯至人之一贯德行如斯，去道不遐。 故曰近尔。 又解曰：水为气母，王於北方，其数六。 北方者，阳德之始，阴气之终也。 生数一，与道同也。 道亦谓之一，道一者即无一之一也，水一者即有一之一也。 无一之一为道之体，有一之一为道之用。 明水者道之用也，故曰几於道也。 居善地至动善时。 至人所居善执谦下，顺物自然，化及乡党，如水在地，善就卑下，滋润群物。 故曰居善地。 此一善也。 至人之心善保虚静，洞鉴幽微，湛然通彻，如水渊澄，波流九变，不失明静。 故曰心善渊。 此二善也。 至人若与善行仁慈，惠及天下，不怀亲爱，如水膏润，善能升降，无不沾济。 故曰与善仁。 此三善也。 至人之言善守诚信，不与物期，自然符契，如水影物。 妍丑无差，流满辄移，行险不失。 故曰言善信。 此四善也。 至人从政善治於民，正容悟物，物自顺从，如水清平，善定高下，涤荡群物，使无尘秽。 故曰政善治。 此五善也。 至人临事善能任物，随器授职，不失其材。 如水柔性，善事方圆，能随形器，无用不成。 故曰事善能。 此六善也。 圣人动静善观其时，出处应机，能全其道，如水之动，善随时变，冬凝夏液，不差其节。
chunks.translated_text:
When applied to things, it nurtures them to completion—
thus aligning with virtue and benevolence.
When expressed in speech, it is true and unfeigned—
thus aligning with sincerity and trust.
When used to rectify others, it clarifies right from wrong—
naturally clear and just—
thus aligning with righteous governance.
When applied to affairs, it adapts to square and round, straight and curved,
responding flexibly yet appropriately—
thus aligning with skillful action.

At dawn and dusk, day and night,
rising and falling, ebbing and flowing—
it neither depletes nor overacts,
moving only at the proper time.

When the seven virtues are complete,
silently operating within,
evil nature fades while virtuous nature arises—
thus, no contention with others,
no blame to bear.

This is called: *"Only the non-contending thus has no blame."*

White Crane of Jade said:
*"The Supreme Good is like water.
Its nature is like water—
water is good.
It is not hindered by things—
benefiting all things yet not contending.
What initial motive could there be?
It dwells where others revile—
to me, what matter is there?
Thus, it approaches the Dao.
The heart is likewise:
dwelling in the best places,
choosing nothing.
The heart is deeply settled—
nurtured by something.
Aligning with virtue and benevolence—
no distinction between self and other.
Speech aligns with sincerity—
true and real.
Governance aligns with righteousness—
nowhere unrighteous.
Affairs align with skill—
effortless yet nothing left undone.
Action aligns with timing—
moving with the times.
Only the non-contending—
the mind uncompeting.
Thus, no blame.
Nor is this taken as fortune."*

Liao Cuiran said:
*"The Supreme Good is like water.
The Dao’s wondrous operation,
like water’s flow.
Water benefits all things yet does not contend.
Through its yielding weakness,
it submits to all things.
Dwelling where others revile—
the common folk use it daily without knowing,
this is the Dao’s essence.
Thus, it approaches the Dao.
It may be called the True Constant.
Dwelling in the best places—
thus able to remain balanced.
The heart is deeply settled—
the mind ever-clear, perpetually pure.
Aligning with virtue and benevolence—
benefiting all beings.
Speech aligns with sincerity—
meaning uprightness.
Governance aligns with righteousness—
ever upholding fairness.
Affairs align with skill—
pure Dao qi in action.
Action aligns with timing—
movement and rest in measure.
Only the non-contending—
submitting to all uses, never opposing.
Thus, no blame.
No lingering resentment.
If one follows this,
thus the Dao is achieved."*

Chen Bixu said:
*"The Supreme Good is like water.
The Supreme Good is the standard for humanity.
'Like water' is a metaphor.
The perfected one holds an empty heart, no desires,
adapting to change with the times,
not opposing any conditions,
dwelling in goodness while forgetting goodness.
Thus, it is called Supreme Good.
Water can conform to square and round,
deep and shallow, floating and sinking,
following the Dao, embracing emptiness—
all things have their principles.
Only the sage encompasses and harmonizes them.
Thus, it is called 'like water.'

Moreover, water embodies the three near-Dao abilities,
the seven virtues benefiting things—
as elaborated below.
Water benefits all things supremely,
thus approaching the Dao.
This is the first near-Dao ability.
Water’s nature is tranquil and even,
spreading nourishment everywhere—
heaven without water brings drought,
earth without water raises dust.
It benefits all things,
thus it is called 'beneficial.'
This is the first ability.
Nothing is softer or weaker than water,
abandoning solidity for emptiness,
rejecting high for low—
blocked, it stops;
unblocked, it flows,
submitting to others.
Thus, it is called 'non-contending.'
This is the second ability.
Human nature dislikes lowliness,
prefers high positions,
yet water seeks the base, receives filth,
dwelling in evil without disorder,
making things pure and white,
alone bearing defilement and humiliation.
Thus, it is called 'dwelling where others revile.'
This is the third ability.

*'Near'* means *approaching*.
Water’s beneficence broadens its benevolence,
non-contention radiates its virtue,
dwelling in evil expands its tolerance—
the three abilities of water’s nature.
Only the perfected one’s unified virtue and conduct
thus approach the Dao without straying.
Hence, it is called *near.*

Further explanation:
Water is the origin of *qi*,
ruling the North.
Its number is six.
The North is the beginning of yang virtue,
the end of yin qi.
The generating number is one,
matching the Dao.
The Dao is also called *one*—
the *one* of non-*one*.
Water’s *one* is the *one* of *having one*.
The *one* of non-*one* is the Dao’s essence,
the *one* of *having one* is the Dao’s function.
Thus, water is the Dao’s function,
hence it is said to *approach the Dao.*

From *dwelling in the best places* to *action aligns with timing*—
the perfected one’s dwelling is in humble submission,
following things naturally,
transforming even the neighborhood,
like water on earth,
dwelling in lowliness,
nourishing all things.
Thus, it is said: *dwelling in the best places.*
This is the first virtue.

The perfected one’s heart preserves emptiness and stillness,
penetrates profundity,
deeply clear and unobstructed,
like a watery abyss,
waves flowing in nine transformations,
never losing clarity and stillness.
Thus, it is said: *the heart is deeply settled.*
This is the second virtue.

The perfected one, if practicing virtue and benevolence,
benefits all under heaven,
without partiality,
like water’s oily nourishment,
skillfully ascending and descending,
nothing left untouched.
Thus, it is said: *aligning with virtue and benevolence.*
This is the third virtue.

The perfected one’s speech upholds sincerity,
does not bargain with things,
naturally harmonious,
like water’s reflection—
beauty and ugliness make no difference,
flowing and filling, it moves,
risky yet unerring.
Thus, it is said: *speech aligns with sincerity.*
This is the fourth virtue.

The perfected one governing affairs
rectifies the people,
upright in demeanor, understanding things,
things naturally comply,
like water’s clarity and balance,
skillfully settling high and low,
purifying all things,
leaving no filth.
Thus, it is said: *governance aligns with righteousness.*
This is the fifth virtue.

The perfected one, when handling affairs,
skillfully employs things,
assigning roles according to ability,
losing none of their potential.
Like water’s yielding nature,
skillfully serving square and round,
adapting to form and vessel,
nothing left unfinished.
Thus, it is said: *affairs align with skill.*
This is the sixth virtue.

The sage’s movement and stillness
observe the proper time,
emerging and retiring according to circumstances,
preserving the Dao,
like water’s movement—
skillfully adapting to change,
freezing in winter, flowing in summer,
never missing its measure.
Thus, it is said: *action aligns with timing.*"

chunks.original_text: 故曰动善时。 此七善也。 夫唯不争，故无尤。 唯，独也。 此结上三能七善之辞也。 夫至人之所用心行事，出处语默，皆全于妙道，合乎物宜，而常守雌静，不与物争。 物既不争，安有尤过之地？ 又尤，怨也。 言天下独有不争之人，无所怨尤之者。 谢图南曰：上善若水至几於道。 《大学》之道，在止於至善。 此曰上善，其至者夫。 孟子曰性无有不善，水无有不下。 经曰江海所以能为百谷王者，以其善下之也。 则以水喻善，皆取其能下者。 人惟能下，所以众善归之。 水惟能下，所以众流归之。 其趋一也。 水能滋利万物而不争，其利利物而不自利者也。 众人之所恶者，卑污洼下之地，而水乐处之，行乎自然，无所次择。 故可几及於道。 此虽言水，其实为善人言之也。 居善地至故无尤。 高下不择地，故居善於地； 澄清不可挠，故心善於渊； 随取随足，故与善於仁； 不平则鸣，故言善於信； 可鉴妍丑，故正善於治； 载况载浮，故事善於能； 流行不息，故动善於时。 利若是其广，功若是其大，而未尝与物有争焉，又何尤怨之有？ 此虽言水之善，而实言人之善也。 善也水也，无非道之所存也。 盖尝论之：天一生水，水为五行之宗，尊莫尊於水矣。 水行地中，水为万物之利，大莫大於水矣。 尊而不居其尊，大而不有其大，此所以为善而不争也。 所以不争而无尤也。 善人之为善也，友一乡之善以为未足，友一国之善犹以为未足，友天下之善则可以为上善矣。 而方宜善与人同，若次江河善世不伐，同流合污，不矜不伐，而天下莫与之争，则人之善，则水之善也。 水之善，即道之善也。 道在吾身，反而求之，育德於蒙泉，通气於咸泽，而收功於既济未济之水火，终焉则善在吾身，水在吾身。 吾善用之，可与斯道同其久矣。 不然水哉水哉，何取於水也？ 林庸斋曰：上善若水至故无尤。 此章又以水喻无容心之意。 上善者，至善也。 谓世间至善之理，与水一同。 水之为善能利万物，而何尝自以为能？ 顺流而不逆，不争也； 就卑就湿，不以人之所恶为恶也。 以此观水，则近於道矣。 几者，近也。 居善地。 言居之而安也。 心善渊。 言其定而静也。 与善仁。 言其仁以及物也。 言善信。 言出口皆实理也。 政善治。 以之正国，则必治也。 事善能。 以之处事，则无不能也。 动善时。 随所动而皆得其时也。 此七句皆言有道之士，其言如此，而不自以为能，故於天下无所争，而亦无尤怨之者。 此即汝惟不争，天下莫与汝争。 能解者多以此为水之小善七，故其多说牵强，非老子之本旨。 范应元曰：上善若水至故几於道。 几，近也。 水之为物得天一之气，无定形而靡不通，故润万物者莫润乎水，乃善利也。 遇方则方，遇圆则圆，何争之有？ 上善之人则微妙玄通，常善利於人物而不争，故善亦如水。 众人好高而恶下，水独处之，上善之人常谦下也，有此之德，故近於道。 《易》六十四卦，惟谦卦有吉而无凶悔吝。 河上公曰：上善之人如水之性。 故曰上善若水。 水者，自然而始成形，故其理同道，无所不在，无所不利，而水亦然。 然而既已丽於形，则於道有间矣。 故曰几於道。 然而可名之善； 未有若此者也，故曰上善。 居善地至故无尤。
chunks.translated_text:
The seventh virtue is thus said: *movement aligns with timing.*

This concludes the threefold discourse of the perfected one’s seven virtues. For the perfected one alone—
the one who does not vie—
there is no blame.

The perfected one’s thoughts, actions, comings, goings, words, and silences
all harmonize with the **Mysterious Dao**,
conform to what is fitting,
and perpetually maintain **feminine stillness**,
never contending with things.

If things are not contended with,
how could there be any ground for blame?

Moreover, *blame* is *resentment*.
It is said that in the world,
only the one who does not vie
has none to resent or blame.

**Xie Tuonan** said:
*The highest virtue is like water, approaching the Dao.*

The **Dao of the Great Learning** lies in stopping at the highest virtue.
This is called *highest virtue*—
its utmost is here.

**Mencius** said:
*Human nature has no unvirtuous aspect,
just as water has no place but to descend.*
The **Classics** state:
*Only because the rivers and seas can descend
do they become rulers over all the valleys.*
Thus, when virtue is likened to water,
it is taken from its ability to descend.

Only when a person can descend
do all virtues gather to them.
Only when water can descend
do all streams gather to it.
Their tendency is the same.

Water nourishes all things without contending,
its benefit lies in benefiting others, not itself.
What the multitude abhors—
low, vile, sunken places—
water delights in, moving naturally,
without choice or preference.
Thus, it approaches the Dao.
Though this speaks of water,
its true intent is for the virtuous person.

The virtuous person dwelling in the highest virtue
has no blame.

High and low without preference,
thus dwelling in the highest virtue.
Clear and pure, unshaken,
thus the heart is virtuous in the depths.
Take as you will, give as you will,
thus it is virtuous in kindness.
If not level, it resounds,
thus it is virtuous in truthfulness.
It reflects beauty and ugliness,
thus governance is virtuous in regulation.
It bears weight, it floats weight,
thus affairs are virtuous in capability.
Its flow is unceasing,
thus movement is virtuous in timing.

If benefit is so vast,
if achievement is so great,
yet it never contends with things,
how could there be blame or resentment?

Though this speaks of water’s virtue,
it truly speaks of human virtue.
Virtue is water—
none other than the Dao’s abiding presence.

Indeed, it has been discussed:
*Heaven first generates water,*
*water is the origin of the Five Phases,*
*none is more exalted than water.*
Water flows through the earth,
nourishing all things—
none is greater than water.
Exalted yet not claiming its exaltation,
great yet not possessing its greatness—
this is why virtue does not vie,
and why, not vying, there is no blame.

The virtuous person’s virtue,
if they befriend the virtue of one village, still consider it insufficient,
if they befriend the virtue of one nation, still consider it insufficient,
yet if they befriend the virtue of the world,
then they may attain the highest virtue.

Yet, the highest virtue is fitting to share with others,
just as rivers and streams do not boast of the world,
flowing together with the muddy—
not proud, not boastful—
and the world has none to contend with them.
Thus, human virtue is water’s virtue.

Water’s virtue is the Dao’s virtue.
The Dao dwells within me—
turn inward to seek it,
nurturing virtue in the **Mingyuan**,
harmonizing **qi** in the **Xianzai**,
and gathering its power in the **Water-Fire** of *Ji* and *Wei*.
In the end,
virtue dwells within me,
water dwells within me.

If I use this virtue well,
I may share in the Dao’s enduring presence.
If not, what is water?
What is water?
Why liken it to water?

**Lin Yongzhai** said:
*The highest virtue is like water, approaching the Dao.*
This chapter again uses water to illustrate the thought of having no self.
The highest virtue is the utmost virtue.
It is said that the world’s highest virtue
is the same as water’s nature.

Water’s virtue can benefit all things,
yet when has it ever considered itself capable?
Following the flow without opposing—
this is not vying.
Descending to low places, embracing dampness—
it does not regard what the world abhors as abhorrent.
Thus, observing water,
one comes near to the Dao.

*Approaching* means *near*.
Dwelling in the highest virtue—
it speaks of dwelling there and finding peace.
The heart is virtuous in the depths—
it speaks of its steadfastness and tranquility.
Kindness extends to all—
it speaks of its kindness reaching everywhere.
Truthfulness in speech—
it speaks of words always aligning with reality.
Governance is virtuous in regulation—
using it to govern the state,
the state will surely be well-ordered.
Affairs are virtuous in capability—
using it to handle affairs,
there will be nothing it cannot accomplish.
Movement aligns with timing—
it moves as circumstances dictate,
always finding the proper moment.

These seven lines speak of those with the Dao,
whose words are such,
yet they do not consider themselves capable,
thus in the world
they vie with none,
and none resent or blame them.
This is the meaning of:
*You alone do not vie,*
*thus the world has none to vie with you.*

Those who understand well
often mistake this as the *seven lesser virtues of water*,
thus their interpretations are strained and forced,
not the original intent of **Laozi**.

**Fan Yingyuan** said:
*The highest virtue is like water, approaching the Dao.*
*Approaching* means *near*.
Water, as a thing,
receives the **Heavenly One’s qi**,
has no fixed form yet permeates all,
thus none can nourish as water does—
it is the utmost in benefiting others.
It is square when encountering square,
it is round when encountering round—
what vying is there?

The highest virtue in a person
is subtle, profound, and all-pervading,
constantly benefiting others without contending,
thus virtue is like water.
The multitude prefers high and abhors low,
yet water alone dwells there—
the highest virtue in a person
is always humble and lowly.
With such virtue,
they approach the Dao.

Among the **Sixty-Four Hexagrams of the *Yijing***,
only the **Modesty** hexagram has auspiciousness without misfortune, regret, or stinginess.
**River Master Gong** said:
*The highest virtue in a person is like water’s nature.*
Thus, it is said:
*The highest virtue is like water.*

Water is naturally formless,
thus its principle aligns with the Dao—
omnipresent, benefiting all,
just as water does.
However, once it has taken form,
it diverges from the Dao.
Thus, it is said:
*approaching the Dao.*

Yet it can still be named virtue—
none surpasses it,
thus it is called *highest virtue.*

Dwelling in the highest virtue,
thus without blame.

chunks.original_text: 居善地者，可止则止； 心善渊者，中常湛静； 与善仁者，称物平施； 言善信者，声不妄发； 政善治者，德惟无私，事善能者，无所不通； 动善时者，可行则行。 有是德而有是善。 夫惟不争，是以无过，而全德尽善也。 薛庸齐曰：上善若水至动善时。 上善之士性明而德清，故若水也。 雨露滋养，源泉灌溉，利万物也。 流湿润下，停污止坎，处众人之所恶也。 水生天一，道自无一，故言其近也。 界而为国之宝，决而为国之利，善地也。 鉴於止水，测之益深，善渊也。 滋荣万物，为而不恃，善仁也。 百川学海，而至於海，善信也。 秽污以涤之，高下以平之，善治也。 在盘则方，在盂则圆，善能也。 冬则凝然春则融然，善时也。 夫惟不争，故无尤。 天下柔弱莫过於水，故不争。 既不争，复何尤之有？ 休休庵曰：上善若水至故无尤。 道之至德，谓之上善。 喻之若水，水能利益万物而不与物争功，无我也。 水能就下，是谓处众人之所恶，水无心而有德。 故几於道。 几者，近也。 抱道有至德者，动静一如居善地也。 量包无外，心善渊也。 博施济众，而不矜，与善七也。 出语可法，言善信也。 道德之化，风行草偃，政善治也。 无为妙用，不劳而办，事善能也。 非理不言，非道不行，动善时也。 种种任道，物我无争，夫唯不争，故无过尤矣。 褚伯秀曰：上善若水至故无尤。 人能利物不争，谦卑处下，皆行之善者，上善则善中之最积久而成，犹云上德上仁之类。 夫天一生水，五行之首，离无入有之始，从气化形之初，有形若无，不可持捉，储积既久，势莫御焉。 人之积小善而成上善，理亦若此。 水之善利不争，纳污藏垢，世间何物得以及之？ 众人所恶者，秽污下湿，水则逶迤曲就而不辞，又於其中洗涤淘澄，化为清净，此所以为善之上，而近於道也。 居善地，所处而安。 心善渊，志存深静。 与善化，施恩不吝。 言善信，不与行违。 政善治，庶务毕理。 事善能，通乎适宜。 动善时，应机而发。 槩叙上善利物。 条目或指为水之七善，牵强求合。 若然，则经之宜云水若上善矣。 言有宗，事有君，观者当求立言本意。 以众善论之，不争为善之上，所以成众善也。 外而物无怨尤，内而己无过咎。 入道之要，莫先乎此。 牛妙传曰：上善若水至万物而不争。 夫善而又善，故谓之上善。 云若水者，谓天下之至善，莫若水也。 且万物之生，皆从阴湿而生，故云水善利万物也。 夫水之性，去留随机，不择好恶，器之大小方圆，盛之俱得其旨，任天下取与，未尝相拒。 故云不争也。 然则人之性善者，亦犹水焉。 其能随方逐圆，辞高就下，海涵川纳，不与世争，亦犹水之性，在天地间无往而不入矣。 处众人之所恶，故几於道。 夫众人之所恶者，恶居下流，且天下万物之生，皆冲而上之，水之德不好居高，惟能处下。 昔仲尼亟称於水曰：水哉水哉，何取於水也。 孟子曰：源泉混混，不舍昼夜，盈科而后进，放乎四海，有本者如是。 此其水之为德也。 然则何谓几於道耶？ 夫几者，近也。 道者，渊也。 盖水之用，在世间犹道之在天下，无物而不被沾需，无往而不被润泽，故云几於道也。 虽云水之性无有不下，然人之性亦无有不善。
chunks.translated_text:
The virtuous in dwelling choose the good ground—
when they may rest, they rest;
the virtuous in heart are deep—
their mind ever serene and still;
the virtuous in benevolence act justly—
measuring things and distributing fairly;
the virtuous in speech are trustworthy—
their words never false or idle;
the virtuous in governance rule with virtue—
their power is without private gain;
the virtuous in action are skilled—
in all things, they excel;
the virtuous in timing act decisively—
when they may move, they move.

With such virtue and such excellence,
they alone contend not—
thus they have no fault,
and their virtue is complete, their excellence perfect.

Master Xue Yongqi said:
*The highest virtue is like water—
its excellence lies in timely action.*

The noble of highest virtue are clear in nature and pure in virtue,
thus they are like water.

Rain and dew nourish,
springs and streams irrigate—
benefiting all things.
Flowing, they moisten what is low,
stagnant, they gather filth—
dwelling where all others abhor.
Water generates *Heaven One*,
the Dao is without singularity—
thus it is said to approach the Dao.

Dammed, it becomes a nation’s treasure;
released, it becomes a nation’s benefit—
this is the good ground.
Reflected in still waters, its depths are measured—
this is the deep heart.
Nourishing all things, yet claiming no credit—
this is benevolence.
All rivers learn from the sea,
yet they reach the sea—
this is trustworthiness.
Filth is cleansed, high and low are balanced—
this is good governance.
In a square vessel, it is square;
in a round vessel, it is round—
this is skill.
In winter, it congeals;
in spring, it melts—
this is timely action.
For it does not contend,
thus it has no blame.

Under heaven, none are softer or weaker than water—
thus it does not contend.
Since it does not contend,
what blame could there be?

Master Xu Xiuxian said:
*The highest virtue is like water—
thus it has no blame.*

The Dao’s supreme virtue
is called highest excellence.
Water can benefit all things
yet does not vie for merit—
no selfishness.
Water seeks what is low—
this is dwelling where all others abhor.
Water has no mind yet possesses virtue.
Thus it approaches the Dao.
*Approach* means *near*.

Those who embrace the Dao with supreme virtue,
in action and stillness alike,
are like those who dwell in the good ground.
Their measure encompasses all—
this is the deep heart.
They bestow widely and aid the masses,
yet take no pride—
this is benevolence.
Their words are models for others—
this is trustworthiness.
The transformation of virtue and the Dao
spreads like wind through grass—
this is good governance.
Effortless yet wondrous,
achieving without labor—
this is skill.
They speak not against reason,
act not against the Dao—
this is timely action.
Following the Dao in all things,
with no contention between self and other—
thus they have no fault or blame.

Master Zhu Bo-xiu said:
*The highest virtue is like water—
thus it benefits all without contention.*

Excellence upon excellence,
thus it is called highest excellence.
To say *like water* means
that under heaven, no excellence surpasses water.
Moreover, all things arise from yin and moisture—
thus it is said water benefits all things.
Water’s nature follows circumstances,
neither choosing nor rejecting good or ill,
whether in large or small, square or round vessels—
all receive its full measure.
It yields to all taking and giving,
never resisting.
Thus it is said to contend not.

Then too, the nature of the virtuous person
is like water.
Their ability to conform to square or round,
to decline high and embrace low,
to contain rivers and accept all—
not contending with the world—
is like water’s nature,
spread throughout heaven and earth without exclusion.

Dwelling where all others abhor,
thus it approaches the Dao.
For what all others abhor
is to dwell in low places,
and though all things under heaven strive upward,
water’s virtue does not delight in height—
it alone can dwell low.

Confucius often praised water, saying:
*"Water, water—
what can be learned from water?"*
Mencius said:
*"The springs surge ceaselessly,
day and night without pause,
filling each basin before advancing,
flowing unrestrained to the four seas—
such is the way of those with roots."*

This is the virtue of water.
Yet what does *approach the Dao* mean?
*Approach* means *near*.
The Dao is the deep source.
Water’s use in the world
is like the Dao’s presence under heaven—
no thing escapes its nourishment,
no place its moistening.
Thus it is said to approach the Dao.

Though water’s nature is always descending,
human nature is also without fail virtuous.
chunks.overlap_context:
**River Master Gong** said:
*The highest virtue in a person is like water’s nature.*
Thus, it is said:
*The highest virtue is like water.*

Water is naturally formless,
thus its principle aligns with the Dao—
omnipresent, benefiting all,
just as water does.
However, once it has taken form,
it diverges from the Dao.
Thus, it is said:
*approaching the Dao.*

Yet it can still be named virtue—
none surpasses it,
thus it is called *highest virtue.*

Dwelling in the highest virtue,
thus without blame.

chunks.original_text: 孟子曰人性之善，犹水之就下。 恶得而不几於道哉？ 居善地。 谓水之为德，其有七善。 居五行之首，为百谷之王，不决之不行，不盈科不进。 地稍峻则无回澜既倒之说，地稍高则有川流不息之义。 惟平稳处方停注，故云居善地也。 心善渊。 心者，谓水之中也。 如江海之中渊源浩渺，搅之不浊，澄之愈清，其能容纳百川，靡所不载，随形见影，鉴物无私，故云心善渊也。 与善仁。 仁者，生生不息之谓也。 盖水之德周流不息，运化无穷，泛地载形，浮天浴日，取之无禁，用之不竭。 其德可并天地生生不息之机，故云与善仁也。 言善信。 言其水之为德不约而信，古人称大信不约是也。 观其为用，则有东海中去，西海中来，往来循环，未尝愆忒，如尾闾泄水之运，上流银汉，下至海隅，一年一周，靡有失於信也，故云言善信也。 政善治。 夫水之为德，其能泛十洲於物外，浮六合於寰中，几更变於桑田，屡迁移於岛屿，洪纤兼纳，净秽靡遗，称天下之至柔，骋天下之至坚，无有入於无间。 故云政善治也。 事善能。 谓水之为用，柔而能刚，弱而能强，霈泽群生，沾濡九有，周流天地，贯穿坚刚，转陆为沉，钻崖透石，移高作下，汰浊留清，乾坤资运载之功，动植荷润渥之赐。 故云事善能也。 动善时。 盖水之为用，无时不流，无时不动。 古人称流水不腐，岂不善耶？ 经称天下柔弱莫过於水，而攻坚强莫之能胜。 其无以易之，如海水之潮必待时而至，如人水火之济亦待时而动也。 故云动善时也。 夫唯不争，故无尤。 夫唯，语助。 尤，悔吝也。 此言水之德不与物争，故无悔吝也。 昔子贡问：君子见大水必观焉，何也？ 孔子曰：大水似乎德似道，似勇似怯，似正似察，似志似善化。 水之德有若此者，是故君子必观焉。 由是之言，何悔尤之有哉？ 杨智仁曰：上善若水至故无尤。 谓抱道君子，其性若水。 善济人民，善利万物，挠之而不浊，澄之而不清，性能就下而傲上，盛之斗则方，盛之盂则圆。 江河因斯而长，五行因斯而立。 《化书》云：水窦可以下溺者，故几於道。 能长养万物，居善地。 深而空明，心善渊。 万物得水而生，与善仁。 影照其形，不失其情，言善信。 清且平顺，政善治。 能方能圆，能曲能直，事善能。 夏散冬凝，动善时。 夫唯不争。 其道渊深。 故无尤也。 孟子曰：人性之善也犹水之就下也。 人无有不善，水无有不下也。 喻清中曰：上善若水至故无尤。 水曰润下，处至卑至湿之地，众人之所恶也。 水无情之物也，天下之至平者莫如水，上善之人实似之。 上善者，上德至善之人也。 按旧说，水蕴三能之近道，七善之利物。 何谓三能？ 水性平静，散润一切，天无水则亢旱，地无水则枯竭，利泽万物，故曰善利。 此一能也。 天下柔弱莫过於水，舍实归虚，背高趋下，壅之则止，决之则流，听命於人，故曰不争。 此二能也。 凡人之情而恶居下流，水则处卑就湿，令物洁鲜，自纳污秽，故曰处众人之所恶。 此三能也。 几，近也。 天一生水，一者道也。 道一者即无一之一，水一者为有一之一。 无一之一为道之体，有一之一为道之用。 故曰几於道。 何谓七善？ 至人所居，善执谦下，顺物自然，化及乡党，如水在地，善就卑下，滋润群物。
chunks.translated_text:
Mencius said: *"Human nature’s goodness is like water’s tendency to descend. How could it not approach the Dao?"*
**Reside in virtuous places.**
It is said that water’s virtue has seven excellences.
It stands first among the Five Phases and is the sovereign of all grains—
it does not flow unless released,
it does not advance until its basin is full.
If the land grows slightly steep, there is no talk of backflow or reversal;
if the land rises slightly, there is the meaning of unceasing streams.
Only in level, stable places does it rest—
thus it is said to reside in virtuous places.

**The heart is virtuous in depth.**
The heart refers to water’s core.
Like the depths of rivers and seas—
vast and boundless,
stirred yet never turbid,
settled yet ever clearer—
it can contain all rivers,
carrying everything without discrimination,
reflecting forms without bias—
thus it is said the heart is virtuous in depth.

**Generosity is virtuous in kindness.**
Kindness means unceasing life-giving.
Water’s virtue flows ceaselessly, transforming without end,
spreading across the land, bearing forms,
floating beneath the sky, bathing in the sun—
its use is unrestricted, its benefit inexhaustible.
Its virtue matches the Heaven-Earth’s unceasing life-giving mechanism—
thus it is said generosity is virtuous in kindness.

**Speech is virtuous in trustworthiness.**
Its meaning is that water’s virtue is sincere without constraint—
as the ancients praised: *"Great trustworthiness requires no oaths."*
Observe its function:
East Sea departs, West Sea arrives,
cycling endlessly without fail—
like the Tailu’s drainage, flowing from the Milky Way’s heights
to the ocean’s depths,
completing a cycle each year,
never failing in sincerity—
thus it is said speech is virtuous in trustworthiness.

**Governance is virtuous in order.**
Water’s virtue can float the Ten Isles beyond things,
suspend the Six Directions within the cosmos,
alter the mulberry fields into sands,
relocate islands time and again—
accepting both vast and minute,
cleansing impurities without omission,
embodying Heaven’s utmost softness,
conquering Earth’s utmost firmness,
penetrating even the unyielding—
thus it is said governance is virtuous in order.

**Action is virtuous in capability.**
Water’s use is soft yet strong,
weak yet powerful—
nourishing all life,
moistening the Nine Realms,
circulating through Heaven and Earth,
piercing firmness and hardness,
turning land into depths,
boring through cliffs and stone,
leveling heights to lows,
discarding filth while preserving clarity—
Heaven and Earth rely on its transformative function,
creatures and plants benefit from its sustenance—
thus it is said action is virtuous in capability.

**Movement is virtuous in timing.**
Water’s function is ever-flowing, ever-moving.
The ancients said: *"Flowing water does not rot"—
how could it not be virtuous?*
The Classics state: *"Nothing under heaven is softer or weaker than water,
yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming firmness."*
Its operation cannot be altered—
like tidal seas arriving only at their appointed time,
like human reliance on water and fire moving only when needed—
thus it is said movement is virtuous in timing.

**Only the non-contending has no regrets.**
*Only*—a particle of emphasis.
*Regrets*—remorse and grudges.
This speaks of water’s virtue not contending with things,
thus having no remorse or grudges.
Once, Zigong asked: *"Why does a gentleman observe great waters?"*
Confucius replied: *"Great waters resemble virtue, resemble the Dao,
resemble courage yet seem timid,
resemble rectitude yet seem discerning,
resemble resolve yet seem benevolent in transformation."*
Water’s virtue is such—
thus a gentleman must observe it.
From this, how could there be regrets or grudges?
Yang Zhiren said: *"The utmost goodness is like water—thus no regrets."*
It means the Dao-holding sage’s nature is like water:
kind to the people, beneficial to all things,
perturbed yet not defiled, clarified yet not artificially pure,
naturally descending while disdaining elevation—
when poured into a square vessel, it becomes square;
when poured into a round vessel, it becomes round.
Rivers and streams grow long because of this,
the Five Phases stand firm because of this.
*The Book of Transformation* says:
*"Water’s hollows can drown one—
thus it approaches the Dao."*
It nourishes all things, resides in virtuous places.
Deep and luminous, the heart is virtuous in depth.
All things gain life from water—
generosity is virtuous in kindness.
It reflects forms without losing their essence—
speech is virtuous in trustworthiness.
Clear and smooth, governance is virtuous in order.
It can be square or round, curved or straight—
action is virtuous in capability.
It melts in summer and congeals in winter—
movement is virtuous in timing.
Only the non-contending—
its Dao is profound.
Thus there are no regrets.

Mencius said: *"Human nature’s goodness is like water’s tendency to descend.
No one is without goodness, just as water is without fail descending."*
Yu Qingzhong said: *"The utmost goodness is like water—thus no regrets."*
Water is called *"moistening the low"*—
dwelling in the most humble, damp places,
which all people despise.
Water is an emotionless thing—
nothing under heaven is as level as water.
The truly virtuous person resembles it.
The *utmost goodness* refers to those of supreme virtue and perfection.
According to old teachings, water embodies three near-Dao abilities and seven virtues beneficial to things.
What are the three abilities?
Water’s nature is tranquil and disperses to nourish all—
Heaven without water would be parched,
Earth without water would wither—
benefiting all things—
this is the first ability.
Nothing under heaven is softer or weaker than water—
it abandons solidity for emptiness,
rejects height for lowliness—
blocked, it stops;
released, it flows;
submitting to human command—
this is the second ability.
Though people dislike dwelling in low places,
water seeks the low and damp,
making things pure while receiving filth—
this is the third ability.
*Near*—meaning *close*.
Heaven generates water—*one*—the Dao.
The Dao’s *one* is the non-dual *one*,
water’s *one* is the dual *one*.
The non-dual *one* is the Dao’s essence,
the dual *one* is the Dao’s function—
thus it is said to approach the Dao.

What are the seven virtues?
The sage’s dwelling is virtuous in humility,
following things naturally,
transforming even the neighborhood—
like water on the earth,
virtuous in descending to low places,
nourishing all things.

chunks.original_text: 故曰居善地。 此一善也。 至人之心洞鉴幽微，湛然通彻，如水渊澄，不失明静，故曰心善渊。 此二善也。 至人施与，慈惠及众，不间迩遐，如水膏润，普沾群物，无有限止。 故曰与善仁。 此三善也。 至人之言，诚悫不移，与物符契，如海潮应候，昼夜盈虚，不差时刻。 故曰言善信。 此四善也。 至人从政，平心待物，自然顺从，无有不治，如水清平，善定高下，妍丑自别，物无遁形。 故曰政善治。 此五善也。 至人临事，善能任物，随器授职，各当其材，如水柔性，方圆长短，惟器是适，无施不可。 故曰事善能。 此六善也。 至人动静，与世推移，出处应机，不滞於物，如水之动，随时变迁，冬凝夏液，不爽其节。 故曰动善时。 此七善也。 凡物之不平者，取决於水而争心息，又何尤焉，观水有术，可谓善於形容矣。 孔子观於东流之水，子贡问曰：君子所见大水必观焉，何也？ 孔子曰：以其不息，夫水似乎德。 其流也则卑下，锯邑必修其理，此似义。 浩浩乎无屈止之期，此似道。 流行赴百仞溪而不惧，此似勇。 至量必平，此似其盛。 而不求溉，此似正。 绰约微达，此似察。 发源必东，此似志。 以出以入，万物就以化，此似善化也。 水之德若此，故君子必观焉。 古人有取於水，良有以也夫。 胥六虚曰：上善若水至故几於道。 言夫有道者，谓之上善。 上善者，谓其善无以加，唯水可喻也。 故曰上善若水。 水之善利润万物而不争，舍高趋下而自若不争者，谓无大小高下之二。 天下之人出幽谷迁乔木，乃其所喜； 舍其高趋於下，乃其所恶。 水独居之，是故近於道。 故曰几於道。 居善地至动善时。 水固几於道，圣人则之，又推而扩之，以明夫有道者之善，略言有七。 居善地谓有道之士，平险方圆，所遇皆适，若水之居善地也。 鉴照万象，湛然不扰，若水之心善渊也。 怀抱慈爱，亲疏平施，若水之与善仁也。 至诚内修，号令外发，若水之言善信也。 操守公平，赏罚善恶，若水之政善治也。 利济日用，为而不辞，若水之事善能也。 否泰有数，行藏无必，若水之动善时也。 夫唯不争，故无尤。 尤，罪过也。 夫唯有道之士，若水之善也，而不与物争，故天下亦无可责其过矣。 柴元皋曰：上善若水。 水德无以加。 水善利万物而不争。 泽润而就下。 处众人之所恶。 凡有秽恶，皆从而洁之。 故几於道。 去道几微之间。 居善地。 止坎就下。 心善渊。 澄湛鉴照。 与善仁。 济物利用。 言善信。 潮侯及时。 政善治。 平则无声。 事善能。 灌溉有功。 动善时。 春生秋涸。 夫惟不争，故无尤。 以善为体，以不争为用，故每用无过。 苏敬静曰：上善若水至故无尤矣。 此章老子之意，只在不争。 上善者，世间第一最善之理也。 譬之物莫如水，万物皆以得水而生，是善利万物。 而水何尝争言利邪？ 人恶居下流，惟水流湿，处众人所恶之地，而不嫌，人能如水有济世润泽之利，而无好高慕远之心，则为上善，亦几近於有道矣。 有道之士如之何，能与水同为善哉？ 所居必就下，如水济物； 存心必渊静，如水停涵； 所与必博施，济众如水灌溉枯槁； 立信必务信实，如水冲激必作声； 为治必有修理，如水顺流下处； 处事必任才能，如水湍流迅快；
chunks.translated_text:
「Hence it is said: *Dwelling is virtuous in the land*.
This is the first virtue.

The sage’s heart is clear and deep,
penetrating to the most subtle depths,
tranquil and unobstructed—
like a watery abyss, undisturbed,
never losing its clarity and stillness—
hence it is said: *The heart is virtuous in its depth*.
This is the second virtue.

The sage’s giving is benevolent and kind,
extending to all without distinction of near or far—
like the grease of water, nourishing,
permeating all things universally,
without limit or restraint.
Hence it is said: *Giving is virtuous in its kindness*.
This is the third virtue.

The sage’s words are sincere and steadfast,
unalterable, harmonizing with all things—
like the tides responding to celestial cues,
swelling and receding day and night,
never missing their appointed moments.
Hence it is said: *Speech is virtuous in its trustworthiness*.
This is the fourth virtue.

The sage governs with equanimity,
treating all with a balanced heart,
naturally yielding to order—
nothing remains ungoverned,
like clear water, virtuous in stabilizing high and low,
distinguishing beauty and ugliness on its own,
with no thing escaping its form.
Hence it is said: *Governance is virtuous in its efficacy*.
This is the fifth virtue.

The sage confronts affairs,
virtuous in its ability to adapt to things,
assigning roles according to capacity,
each fitting their measure—
like water’s yielding nature,
accommodating to square or round,
long or short,
adapting to every vessel,
with no application beyond its reach.
Hence it is said: *Affairs are virtued in their ability*.
This is the sixth virtue.

The sage’s movement and stillness,
align with the world’s shifts,
emerging and retiring as circumstances demand,
never stagnating in things—
like water’s motion,
changing with the seasons,
congealing in winter and flowing in summer,
never deviating from its course.
Hence it is said: *Movement is virtuous in its timing*.
This is the seventh virtue.

All things that are not level,
find their resolution in water and cease their striving—
how then could there be blame?
To observe water is an art,
and it may be said to be masterful in its form and function.

Confucius observed the flowing waters of the east,
and Zigong asked: *"Why does the gentleman always observe great waters?"*
Confucius replied: *"Because it never rests—
water seems to embody **virtue** (德).
Its flow is low and humble,
and when it carves through cities,
it must first smooth its path—
this seems like **righteousness** (義).
Its vastness knows no end,
this seems like the **Dao/Way** (道).
It rushes to depths a hundred fathoms high without fear,
this seems like **courage** (勇).
When measured, it is always level—
this seems like its **fullness** (盛).
Yet it does not seek to irrigate—
this seems like **rectitude** (正).
Its subtle currents reach everywhere—
this seems like **perception** (察).
Its source always flows east—
this seems like **purpose** (志).
It emerges and withdraws,
and all things conform and transform—
this seems like **virtuous transformation** (善化).
Thus, water’s virtues are such—
the gentleman must observe them.
The ancients indeed took inspiration from water,
and there was good reason for it.

Xú Liúxū said: *"The highest virtue is like water—
thus it approaches the Dao.
The one who embodies the Dao is called the highest virtue.
The highest virtue is beyond compare—
only water can illustrate it.
Hence it is said: **The highest virtue is like water** (上善若水).

Water’s virtue is beyond improvement:
it benefits all things without striving,
nourishes with its dampness and seeks low places,
dwelling where people abhor.
All filth and evil,
it receives and purifies—
thus it approaches the Dao.

The Dao is but a hair’s breadth away.
**Dwelling is virtuous in the land**—
resting in the **Kàn** (坎), descending to low places.
**The heart is virtuous in its depth**—
tranquil and clear, reflecting all things.
**Giving is virtuous in its kindness**—
benefiting and nourishing all things.
**Speech is virtuous in its trustworthiness**—
tides and currents come on time.
**Governance is virtuous in its efficacy**—
level, it makes no sound.
**Affairs are virtued in their ability**—
irrigating with purpose.
**Movement is virtuous in its timing**—
spring rises, autumn ebbs.
Since it does not strive,
there is no blame.
It takes virtue as its essence,
and non-striving as its function—
thus in every use, there is no fault.

Sū Jìng said: *"The highest virtue is like water—
thus it is without blame.
This passage of Laozi’s intent
lies solely in **non-striving** (不争).
The highest virtue is the foremost and most excellent principle in the world.
Compare it to nothing like water:
all things rely on water to flourish—
this is its virtue in benefiting.
Yet water never claims to be of benefit—
people abhor dwelling in low places,
but water flows where it is damp,
dwelling where people abhor,
yet never complains.
If one can embody water’s virtue—
to benefit the world with nourishment—
and yet lack the desire to seek high or distant things,
then they are the highest virtue,
and also approach the Dao.

How does the one who embodies the Dao
compare to water in virtue?
Their dwelling must always be in low places—
like water benefiting things.
Their heart must always be deep and still—
like water’s tranquil repose.
Their giving must always be expansive and beneficent—
like water irrigating the withered.
Their trust must always be in truth—
like water’s surge and ebb, which must make sound.
Their governance must always be orderly—
like water flowing smoothly downward.
Their handling of affairs must always suit their abilities—
like water’s swift and rapid currents."*

The Dao’s *one* is the non-dual *one*,

chunks.original_text: 动必善识时，如水夏涨秋涸。 此七者皆如水之善矣，而未如水之善也。 水之上善，其在不争言利乎？ 夫惟不争，故亦无愆尤。 此即禹惟不矜，天下莫与禹争能； 禹惟不伐，天下莫与禹争功。 非天下之上善而何？ 老氏之学莫切於不争，曰不尚贤，使民不争； 日夫惟不争，故天下莫能与之争； 曰是谓不争之德； 曰天道不争而善胜； 曰圣人之道为而不争； 与此不争无尤者凡六。 心声之发，自不能掩。 凡渫辱可耻，皆能忍而容之，是能为而能不为者也。 功能可以加人，而付之无有； 智力足以盖世，而韬藏不用。 其所操蕴常不肯为天下先，则安得有争哉？ 宜其为上善也。 本一庵居士曰：上善若水至故无尤。 无善之可名，至矣。 有善之可名，而若水之安行乎自然，则善之上也。 夫能利万物则有功，有功则必争。 有功而不争难矣。 然且居众人之所恶不以为 ，岂不又难乎？ 曰几於道者，次於至道无名也。 居也，心也、与也、言也、政也、事也、动也七者，人事也。 善地者，水之高下因地也； 善渊者，水之静深、不挠也； 善仁者，水之利泽无穷也； 善信者，水之行止不欺也； 善治者，水之洗涤无滞也； 善能者，水之能流能胜也； 善时者，水之时盈时涸也。 人之七事兼水之七善，而又持之以水之不争，然后为善。 若有七善而不能去一争，能无尤乎？ 石潭曰：上善若水。 水善利万物而不争，处众人之所恶，故几於道。 居善地，心善渊，与善仁，言善信，正善治，事善能，动善时。 夫惟不争，故无尤。 上善若水，以水之善喻人之善也。 水善利万物，物得水而无不生也。 不争者，水虽有利於万物，而未尝与物为竞也。 处众人之所恶者，水性润下，人则恶居下也。 惟其不争而居人所恶之下，故近於道。 人能居善地，如水之能济物； 心善渊，如水之止而不波； 言善信，如潮之应侯不失其期； 政善治，如水之鉴物，高下妍丑，无有遗形； 事善能，如水之於器，方圆曲直，随其所适； 动善时，如水之春盈秋涸，不爽其节。 是皆各任其自然，而与物无竞者，所以未尝有一毫之愆尤也。 此章自居善地以下，本谓人之上善与水相似，若但於水求之，则於所谓言，所谓政不通矣。 上文水善利万物而不争，故几於道，是言水之善也。 居善地等七善，是以人之善如水之善者言也。 其大意则在於不争而已。 道德真经集义卷之十三竟 凝远大师常德路玄妙观 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易东校正 持而盈之章
chunks.translated_text:
The virtuous in action must discern the times well—
like water swelling in summer and receding in autumn.

These seven virtues are all like water’s goodness,
yet they do not yet reach water’s highest virtue.
Water’s supreme virtue lies in not contending for gain?
For only by not contending does one avoid blame.

This is how Yu was without arrogance—
none in the world dared contend with his virtue.
Yu was without self-praise—
none in the world dared contend with his deeds.
What is this if not the world’s highest virtue?

The teachings of Laozi are most profound in "not contending":
"Hold not the worthy in high esteem, so the people do not contend."
"Only by not contending can one be uncontested in the world."
"This is called the virtue of not contending."
"The Dao of Heaven is uncontested yet triumphs."
"The Sage’s Way acts without contending."
These six all speak of the virtue of not contending without blame.

The utterance of the heart cannot be concealed.
All insults and humiliations, though shameful,
can be endured and borne—
this is the ability to act and yet not act.
One’s talents and strength may suffice to surpass the world,
yet they are concealed and unused.
Their actions never seek to lead the world,
how then could there be contention?
Thus, they are truly the highest virtue.

Master Ben-yuan of the Upper Hut said:
"The highest virtue is like water—
so perfect that there is no blame.
Without virtue to name, it is perfect.
With virtue to name, yet acting as water does naturally—
this is the virtue beyond virtue.

To benefit all things is to have merit,
and having merit invites contention.
To have merit yet not contend is difficult.
Yet to dwell where others abhor, without complaint—
is this not even more difficult?

The one approaching the Dao
is second only to the nameless Dao itself.

Residence, heart, giving, speech, governance, affairs, and action—
these are human matters.
The good at choosing dwelling are like water’s high and low,
following the land.
The good at depth are like water’s stillness and profundity,
unshaken.
The good at benevolence are like water’s boundless nourishment.
The good at trust are like water’s unerring course,
neither deceiving nor delayed.
The good at governance are like water’s cleansing flow,
unobstructed.
The good at ability are like water’s adaptability—
to vessels, square or round, straight or curved.
The good at timing are like water’s ebb and flow,
spring’s fullness and autumn’s retreat,
never missing its measure.

All these follow their natural course,
competing with nothing—
thus, they never incur the slightest blame.

Stone Pool says:
"The highest virtue is like water.
Water benefits all things yet does not contend,
dwelling where others abhor—
thus, it approaches the Dao.

Residence is good at choosing dwelling,
the heart is good at depth,
giving is good at benevolence,
speech is good at trust,
governance is good at order,
affairs are good at ability,
action is good at timing.

Only by not contending does one avoid blame.
The highest virtue is like water—
using water’s virtues to illustrate human virtue.

Water benefits all things,
and all things thrive where water flows.
The uncontested—
though water benefits all things,
it never competes with them.
Dwelling where others abhor—
water’s nature is to nourish the low,
yet people despise the low.
Only by not contending and dwelling in the place others abhor
does one approach the Dao.

If one’s dwelling is good like water’s nourishment,
the heart is deep like water’s stillness,
giving is benevolent like water’s boundless flow,
speech is trustworthy like the tides’ punctuality,
governance is orderly like water’s reflection of all things—
high and low, fair and foul—
without omitting a form,
affairs are handled with ability like water’s adaptability—
to square or round, straight or curved—
actions are timed like water’s spring swelling and autumn’s retreat,
never missing its rhythm—
all these follow their natural course,
competing with nothing—
thus, they never incur the slightest blame.

From *Residence in Good Dwelling* onward,
this chapter speaks of human highest virtue resembling water.
If one seeks only in water, then speech and governance are not addressed.

The earlier text says:
"Water benefits all things yet does not contend—
thus, it approaches the Dao."
This speaks of water’s virtue.
*Residence in Good Dwelling* and the seven virtues
speak of human virtue resembling water’s virtue.
Its essence lies in not contending.

chunks.original_text: 考异：河上公作《运夷章》，赵实庵作《观退为进义章》。 唐明皇疏：前章明至人善行柔弱，故无尤。 此章明凡俗溺情憍盈故有咎。 首标持盈揣锐，示其难保。 次云金玉富贵，戒在贪求。 结以名遂身退，令忘功而不处也。 杜光庭曰：前章举水为喻，显明修学之行。 此以持盈为首，更彰贪滞之非，欲使忘功退身，以符至人之美尔。 张冲应曰：夷者，谓太空虚明而无采色，人不可得而窥之也。 人之运通虽如太空虚明，益使夫人不得而窥之，则藏其神而不害其身矣。 持而盈之，不如其已。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 富贵而骄，自遗其咎。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 考异：严遵、杨孚、王弼并同古本。 河上公曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 盈，满也，已，止也。 持满必倾，不如止也。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 揣，治也。 先揣之后必弃捐。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 嗜欲伤神，财多累身。 富贵而骄，自遗其咎。 夫富当赈贫，贵当怜贱，而反骄恣，然必被祸患也。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 言人所为功成事立，名述称遂，不退身避位，则遇於害。 此乃天之常道也。 譬如日中则移，月满则亏，物盛则衰，乐极则哀生。 王辅嗣曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 持谓不失德也，既不失其德，又盈之，势必倾危。 故不如其已者，谓乃更不如无德无功者也。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 既揣末令尖又锐之，令利势必摧衄，故不可长保也。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 不若其已。 富贵而骄，自遗其咎。 不可长保也。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 四时更运，功成则移。 唐明皇曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 执持盈满，使不倾失，积则为累，悔吝必生，故不如其已。 已，止也。 疏：持，执也。 盈，满也。 已，止也。 言人心贪爱，求取无厌，执守保持，更令盈满，积财为累，悔吝必生。 故圣人戒云，不如休止。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 揣，度也。 锐，铦利也。 揣摩锐利，进取荣名，富贵必憍，坐招殃咎，故不可长保也。 疏：揣，量度也。 锐，铦利也。 凡情滞溺，贪求荣利，故揣量前事，铦锐欲心，以撖人怨，坐招殃咎，故不可长保也。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 此明盈难久持也。 疏：假使贪求不已，适令金玉满堂。 象既有齿而焚身，鸡亦为仪而断尾。 且失不贪之宝，坐贻致寇之忧，以其贾害，岂云能守？ 此覆释持盈也。 富贵而憍，自遗其咎。 此明锐不可揣，憍由心生，故咎非他与也。 疏：富则人求之，故便欺物； 贵则人下也，故好凌人。 憍奢至而不期，殃咎来而谁与？ 因憍获咎，憍自心生。 故云自遗尔。 此覆释揣锐也。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 功成名遂者，当退身以辞盛，亦如天道盈虚有时，则无忧患矣。 疏：此举戒也。 夫满则招损，谦便受益。 惟彼天道尚不常盈，故功成者隳，名遂者亏，欲求长保，未闻斯语。 当须忘功与名，退身辞盛，如彼之天道。 不失盈虚，则无忧责矣。 杜光庭曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 持盈之喻，凡有四义。 一者坚持欲心，至於盈满。 二者保持世财，至於满盈。 三者执持恶行，至於盈满。 四者持权恃禄，至於盈满。 大凡知进忘退，不念善道，执滞不回，以至盈满者，皆当有报。 欲心盈满者，得羸疾伤生报。 世财盈满者，得攻劫侵夺报。

「Comparative Analysis: Master He Shang composed *The Chapter of the Wandering Yi* (《运夷章》), while Zhao Shixian wrote *The Chapter of Observing Retreat as Advancement* (《观退为进义章》).

Emperor Xuanzong of Tang explained: The previous chapter elucidates the virtuous conduct of the sage—gentle and yielding, hence free from blame. This chapter clarifies how the common folk, drowned in desires and arrogant with excess, inevitably incur fault.

It begins with the admonition **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已。 揣而锐之, 不可长保), showing how such states are hard to preserve. Next, it warns of gold and jade, wealth and honor, cautioning against greed. It concludes with **"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw"** (功成名遂身退), urging one to forget merit and avoid harm.

Master Du Guangting remarked: The previous chapter used water as an analogy to illustrate the Way of cultivation. Here, with **"Hold and it will overflow"**** as its opening, it further reveals the folly of greed and stagnation, urging one to forget merit and retreat, thus aligning with the sage’s perfection.

Zhang Chongying stated: *Yi* refers to the boundless void of the cosmos—clear and luminous yet without form or color—unfathomable by humans. Though human affairs may flow like that void, if one prevents others from perceiving them, it is akin to concealing one’s spirit and avoiding self-harm.

**"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已。 揣而锐之, 不可长保).
**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).

Comparative Analysis: Yan Zun, Yang Fu, and Wang Bi all concurred with the ancient text.

Master He Shang said: **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已).
*Sweng*, meaning "full," *ji*, meaning "stop."
To hold what is full is to risk collapse—better to stop.

**"Grasp and it will blunt"** (揣而锐之, 不可长保).
*Chuai*, meaning "to refine."
After refinement, it must be discarded—its sharpness cannot endure.

**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
Lustful desires harm the spirit, riches burden the body.

**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
If one is wealthy, they should relieve the poor; if noble, they should pity the lowly. Yet if they instead grow arrogant, calamity will surely befall them.

**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).
It means that when a person’s deeds are accomplished and their reputation secured, if they do not retreat and relinquish their prominence, they will meet misfortune. This is Heaven’s constant Way.

As the sun reaches its zenith and begins to decline, the moon wanes after fullness, things flourish only to decay, and joy reaches its peak before sorrow follows.

Wang Fu’s commentary: **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已).
*Chi* means "to hold without losing virtue," but if one holds virtue while also filling oneself with excess, collapse is inevitable. Thus, it is better to stop—meaning to be even worse than having no virtue or merit at all.

**"Grasp and it will blunt"** (揣而锐之, 不可长保).
If one refines and sharpens it further after already making it sharp, its force will only be exhausted and ruined—thus it cannot be long preserved.

**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
It is better to stop.

**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
It cannot be long preserved.

**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).
The seasons cycle in turn, and when merit is fulfilled, one must withdraw.

Emperor Xuanzong remarked: **"Hold and it will overflow; grasp and it will blunt"** (持而盈之, 不如其已).
To grasp and fill with excess, lest it topple—if one accumulates, it becomes a burden, and regret will arise. Hence, it is better to stop.
*Ji*, meaning "to stop."

Explanation: *Chi* means "to grasp," *sweng* means "full," *ji* means "to stop."
It speaks of how human hearts, greedy and insatiable, grasp and hoard, filling themselves with wealth. Accumulation brings burdens, and regret will inevitably follow. Thus, the sage warns: It is better to cease.

**"Grasp and it will blunt"** (揣而锐之, 不可长保).
*Chuai* means "to measure or refine," *rui* means "sharp and keen."
To refine and sharpen desires for fame and honor, to cling to power and rely on wealth—if one accumulates to fullness, arrogance will arise, and ruin will follow. Thus, it cannot be long preserved.

Explanation: *Chuai* means "to measure or assess," *rui* means "sharp and keen."
All who are mired in desires, greedy for fame and gain, assess past deeds and sharpen their ambition, provoking resentment and inviting ruin. Hence, it cannot be long preserved.

**"Gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can keep them"** (金玉满堂, 莫之能守).
This illustrates how excess is difficult to sustain.

Explanation: Suppose one’s greed knows no bounds, filling their halls with gold and jade. Even elephants are tamed by fire, and roosters mutilated for ritual propriety. Yet, by losing the treasure of non-greed, one invites the anxiety of bandits. With such harm, how can they be guarded? This reverses the meaning of **"Hold and it will overflow."**

**"Wealth and honor breed arrogance, inviting self-blame"** (富贵而骄, 自遗其咎).
This reveals how sharpness cannot be grasped—arrogance stems from the heart, so blame is not from another.

Explanation: Wealth attracts envy, so one easily oppresses others. Honor demands deference, so one readily domineers over others. Arrogance and excess arise without warning; calamity follows without cause. Regret comes from arrogance itself, born of the heart. Hence, it is said: one invites blame upon themselves. This reverses the meaning of **"Grasp and it will blunt."**

**"When achievements are complete and name is fulfilled, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven"** (功成名遂身退, 天之道).
Those whose achievements are complete and reputation secured should retreat and avoid excess—just as Heaven’s Way follows the cycles of fullness and emptiness. Thus, there will be no misfortune.

Explanation: This is an admonition. Fullness invites loss, while humility brings benefit. Even Heaven does not remain perpetually full, so those who achieve will be humbled, and those who gain fame will suffer decline. To seek long preservation is unheard of. One must instead forget merit and fame, retreat, and relinquish excess—like Heaven’s Way. Only by not defying the cycles of fullness and emptiness can one avoid calamity and censure.

Master Du Guangting said: The analogy of **"Hold and it will overflow"**** encompasses four meanings.
One: Clinging to desires until they reach fullness.
Two: Hoarding worldly wealth until it overflows.
Three: Persisting in evil deeds until they swell.
Four: Grasping authority and relying on office until they become excessive.

In general, those who know only advancement and forget retreat, who do not reflect on the Dao of virtue, who cling stubbornly without turning back—all such as reach fullness will meet retribution. Those whose desires overflow will suffer from feebleness and illness, harming their lives. Those whose worldly wealth overflows will face plunder and loss.

chunks.original_text: 恶行盈满者，得刑厄残害报。 权禄盈满者，得倾覆沦灭报。 所以老君戒之，不如休止。 不休不止，斯报必验。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 夫王者锐於开疆拓土，则人怨国亡； 人臣锐於贪利图名，即身危祸及。 纵或苟得，安能长久？ 况进无所补，退有忧患。 故云不可长保。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 假令明能揣度，锐解贪求，金玉珍奇，满堂润屋，必政攻夺之害，岂能保而守之乎？ 况人生有限，情欲无厌，既不救其死亡，岂得保乎金玉。 象有齿而焚身者，《春秋》襄公二十四年，晋范宣子为政，诸侯之弊重＃1，郑人病之。 二月，郑伯如晋。 子产寓书於子西以告宣子曰：子为晋国，四邻诸侯不闻令德，而闻重弊，侨也惑之。 憍闻君子长国家者，非无贿之患，患无令名之难。 夫诸侯之贿聚於公室，则诸侯贰。 若吾子赖之，则晋国贰。 诸侯贰则晋国坏，晋国贰则子之家坏。 何没没也！ 将焉用贿，夫名，德之舆也。 德，国之基也。 有基无坏，无亦是务乎？ 有德则乐，乐则能久，《诗》云：乐只君子，邦家之基。 而有令德也夫。 恕思以明德，令名载而行之，是以远至迩安。 无宁使人谓子：子实生我，而谓子浚我以生乎？ 象有齿以焚其身，贿也。 宣子悦，乃轻弊。 是行也，郑伯朝晋，为重弊故也。 鸡断尾者，春秋周景王子子朝之传篇#2，孟适郊，见雄鸡自断其尾，叹曰：牺牲之用，存乎全而肥硕。 今自断其尾，使己不全，冀免为牺之用，鸡之保其身也如此，况於人乎？ 贪利而忘其身，志不及鸡矣。 不贪之宝者，郑人有得玉，献於子罕曰：此宝也，将以献之。 子罕曰； 汝以玉为宝，我以不贪为宝。 我若取玉，俱丧宝矣。 不如两全之。 遂不受玉。 政寇者。 《易》解卦九三词#3曰：负且乘，致寇至。 负者，小人之事也，负檐於物，合是小人乘者，君子之器也。 今小人舍负檐而乘车，是小人而乘君子之器矣。 故窃盗之人，思夺之矣。 富贵而憍，自遗其咎。 财多曰富，故人求之。 位高曰贵，故人下之。 满而不溢，所以长守富也。 高而不危，所以长守贵也。 谚曰：富贵不与憍奢期，憍奢自至。 憍奢不戒，凌侮於人，人以报之，祸将及矣。 遗，与也。 咎非外来，由自己浇慢致之尔。 故云憍，自心之生也。 若能贵而不危，富而不溢，人无咨怨，灾害不兴，安国修身，斯为至矣。 憍，矜也。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 御灾除患曰功，富贵尊荣曰名。 功既成矣，名既遂矣，而不知退者，鲜不及祸。 夫何故哉？ 宠则有辱，盛则有衰，亢极则悔。 高鸟尽而良弓藏，校免死而猎犬烹，势使然也。 范蠡扁舟而脱祸，大夫种固位而丧身，此之谓矣。 日中则反，月满则亏，暑往即寒来，春荣则秋落，天道然也。 人能体盈虚於天道，忘成遂之功名，子房绝粒以优游，疏广解印而高尚，固无上蔡华亭之追痛矣。 况乃居九五之位而临亿兆之人，光宅万方，廊废四海，而不守持盈满堂之戒乎？ 宋道君曰：持而盈之至不可长保。 盈则溢矣，锐则挫矣。 万物之理，盈必有亏，不知持后以处先，执虚以驭满，而湛溺满盈之欲，是增倾覆之祸，有不如其已。 物之变无穷，吾之智有尽。 前识者道之华，愚之始也。 揣物之情，而锐於近取，则智有时而困，可长保乎？

The evil deeds that reach fullness will meet retribution through punishment, calamity, and harm.
Those whose power and emoluments overflow will face ruin and annihilation.
Thus, the Venerable Lord Lao admonishes: *"It is better to cease than to persist in holding fullness.*
If one neither ceases nor stops, retribution will surely manifest.
To sharpen and press forward is not something that can be long preserved.

When a ruler sharpens his ambition to expand territory and seize land, the people will resent it and the state will perish.
When a minister sharpens his greed for profit and fame, his own life will be endangered and disaster will follow.
Even if he temporarily gains what he desires, how can it last?
Moreover, advancement brings no benefit, while retreat brings only worry and misfortune.
Hence, it is said: *"It cannot be long preserved.*

Gold and jade filling the halls cannot be guarded forever.
Even if one could measure and discern, and sharply curb avarice, filling the halls with treasures and ornaments—
there will still be plunder and attack, how could one preserve and guard them?
Much less can one, with a limited lifespan and insatiable desires, hope to preserve gold and jade when death cannot be averted.

There is the parable of the elephant burning itself with its own tusks:
In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Shànggōng Year 24, when the Jin minister Fán Xuānzǐ governed, the burdens on the allied states grew heavy, and the people of Zheng lamented.
In the second month, the Duke of Zheng visited Jin.
Zǐchǎn entrusted a letter to Zǐxī to convey to Xuānzǐ:
*"You govern Jin, yet the neighboring states hear only of heavy burdens, not of virtuous governance. I am perplexed by this.
I have heard that those who govern states must fear not the lack of wealth, but the difficulty of earning a virtuous name.
When wealth accumulates in the lord’s halls, the states grow disloyal.
If you rely on it, Jin will become disloyal.
When the states are disloyal, Jin will collapse; when Jin collapses, your house will fall.
Why would you court such ruin?
Wealth is but a vehicle for virtue, and virtue is the foundation of a state.
With a foundation, there is no collapse—why not strive for this?
Virtue brings joy, and joy ensures longevity. The *Odes* say:
‘Joy belongs to the virtuous; it is the foundation of the state.’
Thus, it is the virtuous name that matters.
Reflect deeply to cultivate virtue, let your virtuous name spread far and near, and all will be at peace.
Would you rather have people say, ‘You gave life to us,’ or ‘You drained us to death?’
The elephant burns itself with its own tusks—wealth is like that.
Xuānzǐ was pleased and lightened the burdens.
This was the reason the Duke of Zheng visited Jin—because of the heavy burdens.

The rooster that cuts off its own tail:
In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ transmission of Zǐzhāo, son of King Jìng of Zhou, Mèng Shì went to the suburbs and saw a rooster cut off its own tail, sighing:
‘The use of sacrificial animals depends on their completeness and fatness.
Now it cuts off its own tail, making itself incomplete, hoping to avoid being used as a sacrifice.
Thus does the rooster preserve its life—how much more so for humans?
To covet gain and forget oneself is even worse than the rooster’s folly.

The treasure of non-covetousness:
A man of Zheng found a jade piece and offered it to Zǐhǎn, saying:
‘This is a treasure. I would present it to you.’
Zǐhǎn replied:
‘You consider jade a treasure, but I consider non-covetousness a treasure.
If I take the jade, we both lose our treasures.
It is better to preserve both.’
Thus, he did not accept the jade.

The thief who invites plunder:
The *Yì* explains the third line of the *Guà* hexagram:
‘*Bearing and mounting, bringing thieves upon oneself.*’
Bearing refers to the petty man’s burden—carrying burdens for others.
Mounting refers to the noble’s carriage.
Now the petty man abandons his burden and takes the noble’s carriage—
this is the petty man riding in the noble’s instrument.
Thus, thieves will think to seize it.
Arrogance in wealth and rank invites one’s own downfall.
Abundance is called wealth, so people seek it.
High position is called rank, so people submit to it.
If one is full without overflowing, this is how one long preserves wealth.
If one is high without peril, this is how one long preserves rank.
The saying goes: *"Wealth and rank do not last for the arrogant and extravagant—
arrogance and extravagance bring their own ruin.
If one does not guard against them, contempt and insults will follow,
and disaster will surely come.
‘Hereditary’ means ‘given by oneself.’
Blame does not come from outside—it arises from one’s own arrogance and negligence.
Hence, it is said: *"Arrogance comes from the heart.
If one can be high in rank without peril, wealthy without overflowing,
free from grievances, and disaster-free,
then governing the state and cultivating oneself is perfect.

Arrogance is pride.
When achievement is complete and fame is fulfilled, one should retreat—this is the Way of Heaven.
To avert disaster and eliminate misfortune is called *achievement*,
wealth, rank, honor, and glory are called *fame*.
If achievement is complete and fame is fulfilled, yet one does not know when to retreat,
few escape calamity.
Why is this?
Favor invites disgrace, fullness invites decline, and extremism invites regret.
When fine birds are exhausted, the good bow is hidden;
when the hare is killed, the hunting dogs are boiled—
this is the inevitable course of things.
Fàn Lì escaped disaster in a small boat, while Dàfū Zhōu lost his life clinging to his position—
this is the lesson.

The sun reaches its zenith and then declines,
the moon is full and then wanes,
heat gives way to cold,
spring’s flourishing turns to autumn’s fall—
this is the Way of Heaven.
If one aligns with the cycles of fullness and emptiness in Heaven’s Way,
forgets the pursuit of achievement and fame,
and like Zǐfáng abstains from food to wander freely,
or like Cú Guāng resigns his seal to live in refinement,
then there will be no regret like that of Cāi Huàtíng or Huàtíng’s pursuit.
How much more so for one who holds the *jiǔwǔ* position and governs the myriad people,
illuminating the four quarters and regulating the seas,
yet does not heed the warning against holding fullness to excess?

The Lord of Song’s Way says:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Fullness leads to overflow, sharpness leads to blunting.
The principle of all things is that fullness must have its deficiency.
If one does not know to hold emptiness in readiness for fullness,
or to grasp emptiness to govern fullness,
and instead indulges in the desires of overflow and sharpness,
one only increases the calamity of ruin.
The changes of things are boundless, but human wisdom is limited.
Preemptive knowledge is the flower of the Way, the beginning of folly.
If one measures things by their nature yet sharpens his pursuit of immediate gain,
his wisdom will falter at times—
how can such a state be long preserved?*

chunks.original_text: 金玉满堂至自遗其咎。 金玉富贵，非性命之理也。 外物不可恃而有者也，宝金玉者累於物，累於物者能勿失乎？ 莫之能守。 富贵而骄，则害於德。 害於德者，能免於患乎？ 故曰遗其咎。 圣人不拘一世之利以为己私分； 不以王天下以为己处显。 夫岂金玉以为宝、富贵之足累乎？ 故至富，国财并焉； 至贵，国爵并焉。 其贵无敌，其富无伦，而道不渝。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 功成者隳，名成者亏，日中则昃，月盈则食，物之理也。 圣人睹成坏之相，因识盈亏之有数，超然自得，不累於物，无复骄盈之患，非知天者孰能与此？ 故曰功成名遂身退，天之。 四时之运，功成者去之，是天之道。 知进而不知退，知存而不知亡，知得而不知丧，能勿悔乎？ 伊尹曰：臣罔以宠利居成功。 王介甫曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 抱持其器之盈者，必易覆。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 揣摩其物之锐者，不可长保。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 堂者，虚而受物者也。 金玉满之，则是盈矣，故不能守。 富贵而骄自遗其咎。 大富贵不期於骄而骄自至，所以遗咎患也。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 夫圣人功既成，名既遂，则身退之者矣。 此乃天之道也。 夫天之道，高者抑之，下者举之。 又曰天道亏盈而益谦。 《书》又曰谦受益满招损之谓也。 苏颖滨曰：持而盈之至不可长保。 知盈之必溢而以持固之，不若不盈之安也。 知锐之必折而以揣先之，不如揣之不可必恃也。 若夫圣人有而不有，尚安有盈？ 循理而后行，尚安有锐？ 无盈则无所用持，而无说则无所用揣矣。 金玉满堂至身退天之道。 日中则移，月满则亏，四时之运，功成者去之，天地尚然，而况於人乎哉？ 吕吉甫曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 持所以防溢而盈之，则重溢也。 如欲勿溢，则如勿满。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 揣所以虑失而锐之，则重失也。 如欲勿失，则如勿锐。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 满而不溢，所以长守富也。 持而盈之，则金玉满堂，莫之能守矣。 富贵而骄，自遗其答。 高而不危，所以长守贵也。 揣而锐之，则富贵而骄，自遗其咎矣。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 然则何以免此患哉？ 法天之道而已。 盖功成名遂身退，天之道，此所以无私而成其私也。 封人之告尧曰退已，其法天之道之谓也。 王元泽曰：持而盈之不如其已。 持而盈之，有意於有，所以失之。 唯忘有有之为有，而有之以无有，则无失无溢矣。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 揣者巧於度情，锐者利於入物，且事物无尽，而吾持一身以遇其变，则持说之工有时困矣。 岂可长保乎？ 故圣人因时乘理而接之以无我，则其出无方，而可应不穷也。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 宝外物而守之，所守非所有也。 岂能外乎？ 富贵而骄，自遗其咎。 骄生於恃外，恃外之人何足算乎？ 四者皆以有物，与为骄者何异？ 然自持盈而下，每失弥甚。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 寒暑相推，物极则反，阴阳代运，天道固然。 而世之愚者一遭其变，一犯其名，则终身有之，诏以为己，曾不知造化之密移，吉凶之倚伏，故终至於坐蒙忧患，无以自存。 惟圣人不然。 藏金玉而不宝，居富贵而不荣。 凡物之来寄者，如阴影集身，窅然不知其在彼耶，在我耶。 然则岂持盈以为，揣锐为工乎？
chunks.translated_text:
The Lord of Song’s Way says:
*"Gold and jade filling the halls—this is how one invites his own calamity.
Wealth and noble rank are not the Dao of life and nature.
External things cannot be relied upon as one’s own.
Treasure gold and jade, and you are burdened by things;
burdened by things, how can you avoid loss?
None can guard them.
Rich and noble yet proud, you harm your virtue.
He who harms his virtue—how can he escape misfortune?
Thus it is said: *‘He invites his own calamity.’*

The Sage does not cling to the gains of a single age as his private possession,
nor does he take ruling the world as his own display of honor.
What need has he for gold and jade as treasures,
or for wealth and rank as burdens?
Thus, when wealth is supreme, the state’s resources are exhausted alongside it;
when rank is supreme, the state’s honors are depleted alongside it.
His nobility is unmatched, his wealth unparalleled,
yet the Way remains unshaken.
When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
When achievement is complete, it collapses;
when name is fulfilled, it falters.
At high noon, the sun declines;
when the moon is full, it wanes—
this is the nature of things.
The Sage perceives the signs of rise and decay,
discerns the inevitable cycles of fullness and deficiency,
and stands apart, unburdened, free from the calamity of pride and excess.
Who but one who knows Heaven could attain this?
Thus it is said: *‘When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.’*

The revolutions of the four seasons—
when achievement is complete, it departs—
this is the Way of Heaven.
To know advancement but not retreat,
to know preservation but not ruin,
to know gain but not loss—
how can one avoid regret?

Yi Yin said:
*The minister does not dwell on success through favor and gain.*
Wang Anshi said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.*

He who clings to his vessel’s fullness
will easily overturn it.
He who sharpens his grasp
cannot long preserve it.
He who sharpens his grasp
cannot long preserve it.
Gold and jade filling the halls—
none can guard them.
The halls are empty receptacles for things.
When gold and jade fill them, they are full—
thus they cannot be guarded.
Rich and noble yet proud—
he invites his own calamity.
Great wealth and rank do not seek pride,
yet pride arrives naturally—
this is how calamity is invited.

When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
For the Sage, when achievement is complete and name is fulfilled,
he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.

The Way of Heaven:
The high are humbled, the low are raised.
It is also said: *‘Heaven diminishes fullness and benefits the modest.’*
The *Book of Documents* says: *‘The modest receive benefit; the proud invite loss.’*

Su Yingbin said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Knowing fullness must overflow yet clinging to it—
it is better not to fill at all.
Knowing sharpness must blunt yet sharpening it—
it is better not to sharpen at all.
As for the Sage, possessing yet not possessing,
how could there be fullness?
Following principle before acting,
how could there be sharpness?
Without fullness, there is no need to cling;
without excess, there is no need to guard.
Without excess, there is no need to sharpen.

Gold and jade filling the halls—
this is the Way of Heaven when he withdraws.
The sun at its zenith declines,
the moon at its full wanes.
The revolutions of the four seasons—
when achievement is complete, it departs.
Even Heaven and Earth follow this—
how much more so for humans?

Lu Jifu said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Clinging to prevent overflow yet filling—
this only invites greater overflow.
If one wishes to avoid overflow,
it is better not to fill at all.
Sharpening to prevent loss yet sharpening—
this cannot be long preserved.
Sharpening to anticipate loss—
this only invites greater loss.
If one wishes to avoid loss,
it is better not to sharpen at all.

Gold and jade filling the halls—
none can guard them.
To remain full without overflowing—
this is how wealth is long preserved.
Holding fullness to excess—
then gold and jade fill the halls,
and none can guard them.
Rich and noble yet proud—
he invites his own calamity.
To be high yet not perilous—
this is how nobility is long preserved.
Sharpening to excess—
then wealth and rank bring pride,
and he invites his own calamity.

When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
Then how does one avoid this calamity?
Only by conforming to the Way of Heaven.
For when achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven,
the means by which the private is accomplished without selfishness.
The *Book of Documents* says: *‘The Sage withdrew himself.’*
This is to follow the Way of Heaven.

Wang Yuanzai said:
*Holding fullness to excess cannot be long preserved.
Clinging to fullness with intent—
this is how one loses it.
Only by forgetting the act of possessing as possession itself,
and holding through non-possession,
can one avoid loss and overflow.
Sharpening to excess cannot be long preserved.
The cunning measure emotions,
the sharp exploit things,
yet affairs are boundless,
and one holds a single life to meet their changes—
then the skill of clinging and sharpening will falter at times.
How can it be long preserved?
Thus the Sage follows the times, rides the principle,
and meets them with non-self—
his actions are boundless,
his responses inexhaustible.

Gold and jade filling the halls—
none can guard them.
Treasuring external things and guarding them—
what is guarded is not truly possessed.
How could it be guarded?
Rich and noble yet proud—
he invites his own calamity.
Pride arises from reliance on externals—
what use are those who rely on externals?
The four [wealth, rank, clinging, sharpening]—
all stem from having things—
what difference is there between them and pride?
Yet clinging to fullness only leads downward,
each loss growing worse.

When achievement is complete and name is fulfilled, he withdraws—
this is the Way of Heaven.
Cold and heat succeed one another,
things at their extreme reverse,
yin and yang alternate—
the Way of Heaven is thus.
Yet the foolish of the world,
once encountering change,
once transgressing its name,
cling to it for life,
taking it as their own,
unaware of the subtle shifts of creation,
the hidden patterns of fortune and misfortune—
thus they inevitably invite calamity,
unable to preserve themselves.

The Sage is not thus.
He hides gold and jade yet does not treasure them,
dwells in wealth and rank yet does not glory in them.
All things that come as guests
are like shadows gathering at his feet—
vague, unknown whether they belong to him or to another.
Then how could he cling to fullness as a burden,
or sharpen his grasp as a skill?"

chunks.original_text: 苟非无我之妙，其何以与於此？ 天之道大矣，而莫尚乎是。 刘巨济曰：持而盈之，不如其已。 言力持而满之，求铃富．者也。 满而能虚，则何所事？ 持有不胜，持则覆矣。 故曰不如其已。 已，止也。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 言情度而入之，求必贵者也。 锐而能锐，则何所事？ 度有不胜，度则数矣。 不可长保，非谓可以幸保，谓虽得之必失之也。 金玉满堂，莫之能守。 此申不如其已之义。 堂奥足以藏金玉而守者也，其害在满，苟非天殃，必有人祸。 富贵而骄，自遗其咎。 此申不可长保之义。 富贵则慢生，慢生则过生，以骄与人则以名自与矣。 功成名遂身退，天之道。 利人曰功，闻誉施身曰名，功譬则富贵之实也，名誉则富贵之华也。 功欲就，名欲达，夫富贵功名，圣贤之不免。 然而不倾败。 其苟满，非以其时得也，其利入，非以揣得也，而又能虚守之，不骄保之，则身退是已。 盖据功成名遂之基，众人以此进而圣贤以此退，则非体天道者能若斯乎？ 日月代明，四时代叙，天之道也。 前章言上善若水，则可以处富贵。 故次以此篇章也。 刘骥曰：持而盈之至身退天之道。 大道甚爽而民好径，以其贪生之厚，惑於有为以要近功，不知自然之妙用，执持以致其盈，盈则亏矣，故不如其已。 揣度以成其锐，锐则挫矣，故不可长保金玉满堂，累於物也。 累於物则欲之者多，故莫之能守。 富贵而骄，害於德也。 害於德则攻之者众，故自遗其咎。 圣人处富贵之极，而无盈满之累者，以其功成名遂而身退也。 岂持其盈而揣其锐乎？ 日月代明，四时代叙，功成者退，天之道也。 圣人法天之道，所以难进而易退，舍诸人而求诸己，故次之以载营魄。 赵实庵曰：初四不居：四一、非至虚之道。 持而盈之，不如其已。 一身不难治，大道不难穷。 不难者在乎识心而已。 心者，本无也。 始也因爱而生身，四大之所聚，五蕴之所集，血气依倚，百体互成，皆因妄念而有也。 今既识心，百骸九窍六脏骸而存焉，吾谁与为亲？ 诏而有之，皆惑也。 以心执妄，惑则生焉。 以心识虚，妄自破矣。 圣人知其然，则曰我既有身，身已是妄，外物傥来，我忘外物。 身与外物二者兼忘，诚忘之中，天光内发，不知物之忘我，我之忘物，虚室生白，道自来矣。 乌睹所谓持盈者耶？ 持盈则有物也，有物则去道远矣，经持而盈之，盈则器之满也。 持则手之用也，无中取有以实充虚，倾之则不忍，执之则不忘。 其行也，步不能扬尘，其坐也，身不敢侧视。 劳神苦心，在於一器，物未有损，身已焦劳。 妄计偏执，有如此者，盖不以身观之，身本无身，物焉所寄？ 我自忘我，物奚为焉？ 举其亲者，疏者可知。 能已之者，是名解脱。 二、铦利自伤。 揣而锐之，不可长保。 性欲静，不静则吉凶悔吝生； 气欲平，不平则愤怒爱欲起。 敌物之心必务求胜，不动则不获，欲其获则静者起而为争矣； 不利则不入，欲其利则平者锐而致铦矣。 伤廉而得，岂能保乎？ 盖知静者则息争，不争则与物无伤。 和平则自宁，自宁则与神为守，不以利累形，不以养伤身，批大却导大窍与一世，而得淡漠之中，此古人存生之德也，岂可觊觎小利，狠狼贪，见利而忘身，贪权而取竭，坐取危亡之道哉？
