the middle scholar cultivates their form (修其形).

Can one embrace *Oneness* without separation (抱一能无离)?
To carry and sustain the *vital energies and spirit* (载营魄),
their practice lies solely in embracing *Oneness* (抱一).
The Dao generates *Oneness* (道生一),
*Oneness* generates *Water* (一生水),
*Water* generates *Essence* (水生精),
and *Essence* is the substance of *Oneness* (精者一之物).
To embrace *Oneness* is to unite with *Essence* (与精合),
while to abandon *Oneness* is to separate from *Essence* (脱一则与精离矣).」

chunks.original_text: 专气而不杂，致柔而不暴，所以如婴儿也。 婴兄居不知所为，行不知所之，终日视而目不瞬，终日号而嗌不嗄，和之至也。 圣人以此洗心，退藏於密，则涤除万念，而玄览妙理，何疵之有？ 此老氏方言其反本，而继之以爱民治国，何也？ 盖一身之设，一国之象也。 圣人以心为君，以身为国，以气为民，无为而尊君之道也。 心无为而尊於上，万气自行，百体自治，保气所以爱民，全形所以治国。 无为也，则用天下而有余； 有为也，则为天下用而不足。 故爱民治国，能无为乎？ 无为则无不为。 天门自开，地户自闭，天门者，精神往来之所。 天门开阖，则神能出入，可坐於一席之间，神游於无方之境。 然神游不已，则神有所不及，所以欲其静，而与阴同德也。 故能为雌乎？ 元神既静，真性自明，可以鉴天地，可以照万物。 然用智不已，则智有时而困。 故明白四达，能无知乎？ 所谓聪明圣智，守之以愚也。 慧而不用，实智若愚，定慧相资，知恬交养，与天地同其体，与造化同其功，其道可以生万物，其德可以畜天下。 故曰生之畜之。 生之而不有其功，为之而不恃其为，长之而不为之宰。 此经所谓功盖天下而似不自己，化贷万物而民不恃也。 赵实庵曰：初起根宗：金火夺形。 载营魄。 识天时之有限，知外物之无常，去彼取此，有长生之道焉。 故继之以载营魄。 《易》曰：立天之道日阴与阳。 阴阳者，相求之物也。 一身之神曰魂与魄，魂魄者相交之道也。 魂为阳，魄为阴，魄资阳而生，魂因魄而立。 魂满而魄生，魂消而魄入。 乃日月往来之数，阴阳消息之期，兹天之常也。 《书》曰哉生魄，谓月也。 生明於东，哉魄於西，谓一月三十日，五六之数也。 后晦三日，前朔三日，除六日也。 上下二弦，四六二十四也。 前后六日，合三十日也。 自初生至上弦有满之渐，则曰魂。 自十六转巽位有缺之渐，则曰魄。 渐缺几晦，魄乃亡也。 是时太阴在艮，与日合气，震来受符，以炼生魄，至于三日，哉生庚地，此乃载营魄也。 虽谓之魄，其实魂也。 谓其有质，质自阳来。 今谓之魄者，月属金也，金主肺，肺主魄，从其体言，止云魄也。 方其生明於西而望东，是金夺火也。 东方木，木主震，木生火，火为阳。 木为肝，肝者阳中之阴，肝主魂，为阳。 阳属火，是金得火而成形。 自初三至望，魄中魂满，乃具乾体。 乾之六位皆言九，九阳也。 阳，火也。 月之圆也，乃具乾体。 金夺火形，即四九生金。 九居离位，虚以象月，故离为中女，女乃象阴。 又震受庚符，西方之坤一变成震，三日当初九也。 八日出辛，再变成兑，乃九二也。 至十日乾体既成，满甲东方。 乾主六甲，飞龙在天。 九三之位，盖阴阳消长见於月也。 一月三十日，三百六十时，应一年之数也。 炼丹必先火侯，火有从天而得，故卦为天符。 《火记》取《易》为准，六十四卦，乾坤坎离不预焉，止六十卦。 朝屯暮蒙为首，前十五日进至大壮终焉。 退十五日自晋至未济终焉。 火候之进退，气候之推迁，以日为准，见乎太阴之圆缺也。 上弦则进，下弦则退。 经载营魄，为虎龙交合，婴姹夺神，炼成玉液。 药苗初新，初九进火。 慎护之时，不可差失。 故抱一也，脱之则亡，失之则死。
chunks.translated_text:
---

Cultivate the *qi* without admixture,
nurture softness without violence—
thus one is like an infant.

An infant in its cradle knows not what to do,
walks without knowing where it goes,
all day gazes yet its eyes never blink,
all day cries yet its throat never grows hoarse—
this is the utmost harmony.

The Sage washes his heart with this,
retires and hides within the profound,
thus purging all thoughts,
and perceiving the subtle and wondrous *Dao*—
what flaw could remain?

This is Laozi’s teaching of returning to the origin,
followed by loving the people and governing the state—
why so?

Because the body is a microcosm of the state.
The Sage takes the heart as sovereign,
the body as the realm,
*qi* as the people—
thus, *wuwei* is the way to honor the sovereign.

When the heart practices *wuwei*, it is exalted above all,
and the myriad *qi* move spontaneously,
the hundred limbs govern themselves.
Preserving *qi* is how one loves the people,
nurturing the form is how one governs the state.

In *wuwei*, one governs the world with abundance;
in *youwei*, one serves the world yet lacks sufficiency.
Thus, to love the people and govern the state—
how could one not practice *wuwei*?

*Wuwei* means *wuwei*—yet nothing remains undone.
The Heavenly Gate opens of its own accord,
the Earthly Gate closes itself.
The Heavenly Gate is where spirit enters and departs.
When the Heavenly Gate opens and shuts,
the spirit can move freely,
sitting in one place yet wandering boundless realms.

Yet if the spirit wanders without restraint,
there are places it cannot reach—
thus, it must be still,
and align with *yin*’s virtue.

When the primal spirit is still,
true nature shines forth,
capable of mirroring Heaven and Earth,
illuminating the ten thousand things.

Yet if wisdom is overused,
it will falter at times.
Thus, clarity and openness—
how could one not embrace *wu*?

What is called "clever, enlightened, and wise"
is guarded by *yū* (primordial stupor).

Wisdom unused is true—
stillness and tranquility nourish each other,
knowing and serenity cultivate one another,
aligning with Heaven and Earth in essence,
matching Creation in function—
its *Dao* can generate the ten thousand things,
its *virtue* can nourish the world.

Thus it is said: *"To generate and to nourish."*
To generate without claiming the deed,
to act without relying on action,
to foster without ruling—
this is the *Classic*’s teaching:
*"Its achievements cover the world yet seem not its own,
its transformations benefit all things yet the people do not depend on them."*

Zhao Shizhan says:
At the outset, the root principle:
*"Gold and Fire seize the form."*
Then comes *"loading the *hun* and *po*."*
Recognizing the limits of Heaven’s timing,
knowing the impermanence of external things—
discarding the former, taking the latter—
thus lies the *Dao* of longevity.

Hence, it continues with *"loading the *hun* and *po*."*

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Establish Heaven’s *Dao*—*yin* and *yang*.*
*Yin* and *yang* are things that seek each other."

The spirit of one’s body is called *hun* and *po*;
*hun* and *po* are the *Dao* of mutual exchange.
*Hun* is *yang*, *po* is *yin*;
*po* draws from *yang* to manifest,
*hun* depends on *po* to stand.
When *hun* is full, *po* is born;
when *hun* fades, *po* retreats.
This is the rhythm of the sun and moon’s passage,
the ebb and flow of *yin* and *yang*—
Heaven’s eternal order.

The *Book of Documents* says: *"Zāi, the birth of *po*—*
this is the moon.
It shines bright in the east,
and *zāi* (wanes) in the west—
meaning a month of thirty days,
the numbers five and six.
Three days before the waning,
three days before the new—
subtracting six days.
The upper and lower crescents—
four and six, twenty-four.
The six days before and after—
totaling thirty days.

From its birth to the upper crescent,
gradually full—this is *hun*.
From the sixteenth day, turning to the *xùn* position,
gradually waning—this is *po*.
As it nears the waning, *po* vanishes.
At this time, the Great *Yin* is in *gèn*,
and aligns with the sun’s *qi*.
*Zhèn* arrives to receive the talisman,
refining the born *po*—
until three days pass,
when *zāi* is born in *gēng*’s earth.
This is *"loading the *hun* and *po*."*

Though called *po*,
in truth it is *hun*.
For it has substance, substance coming from *yang*.
Now called *po*—
the moon belongs to Metal,
Metal governs the lungs,
the lungs govern *po*—
speaking of its form, it is called *po*.

When it shines bright in the west and gazes east,
this is Metal overcoming Fire.
The east is Wood,
Wood governs *Zhèn*,
Wood generates Fire,
Fire is *yang*.
Wood is the liver,
the liver is *yin* within *yang*,
the liver governs *hun*—*yang*.
*Yang* belongs to Fire—
thus Metal seizes Fire to take form.

From the third day to the full moon,
*po* within *hun* is full—
now possessing the *Qián* body.
The six positions of *Qián* are all called *jiǔ*—
*nine*, the ultimate *yang*.
*Yang* is Fire.
When the moon is full,
it possesses the *Qián* body.
Metal seizing Fire’s form—
this is the four *jiǔ* generating Metal.
*Nine* resides in the *Lí* position,
empty to symbolize the moon—
thus *Lí* is the "central maiden,"
the maiden symbolizing *yin*.

Again, *Zhèn* receives the *gēng* talisman—
the *Kūn* of the west transforms into *Zhèn*.
Three days mark the initial *jiǔ*.
On the eighth day, *xīn* emerges—
a second transformation into *Duì*—
now the *jiǔ* of the second position.
By the tenth day, the *Qián* body is complete,
filling the east with *jiǎ*.
*Qián* governs the six *jiǎ*,
the Flying Dragon in Heaven.
The third position of *jiǔ*—
this is the waxing and waning of *yin* and *yang* seen in the moon.
A month of thirty days,
three hundred sixty moments—
matching the year’s count.

Refining the elixir must first attend to the Fire’s timing—
Fire can be drawn from Heaven,
thus the trigrams are Heaven’s talismans.
The *Fire Record* takes the *Classic of Changes* as its standard:
sixty-four trigrams, excluding *Qián*, *Kūn*, *Kǎn*, and *Lí*—
only sixty remain.
*Lún* at dawn, *Méng* at dusk mark the beginning;
fifteen days advance to *Dà Zhàng*’s end.
Fifteen days retreat from *Jìn* to *Wèi Jì*’s end.
The Fire’s timing advances and retreats,
the *qi*’s shifts follow the day—
seen in the moon’s waxing and waning.
When the upper crescent comes, advance;
when the lower crescent comes, retreat.

The *Classic* speaks of *"loading the *hun* and *po*"*—
this is the Tiger and Dragon’s union,
the infant and maiden seizing the spirit,
refining into *yù yè* (jade fluid).
The medicine’s sprout is fresh,
the initial *jiǔ* advances the Fire.
A time to guard with care—
no deviation allowed.

Thus, *"embracing Oneness"*—
to abandon it is to lose,
to neglect it is to die.

chunks.original_text: 使确乎不可拔，至于阳胎下投，其息自任，道乃成也。 故经不言数而言数，不言药而言药。 铅汞之理，尽在此矣。 次甲亟养：六。 一、驯致金虎。 抱一能无离乎？ 六易者，道也。 易之字，日月合体。 未合则无阴阳，既合则配水火。 此天地自然还丹也。 自然还丹天地固有，不抱亦不脱。 此言抱者，谓人不得同天地之自然。 以水火金三物托於易象，以夺自然之气，运变炉鼎，修成至药。 故法天地自然。 以人言之，故抱一能无离乎，是未许之词也。 凡人言抱一，孰为一邪？ 以一为有数，或者曰丽乎数也； 一为有进，或者曰泥乎迹也。 当灭其一，以证湛静。 此皆灭法，而非生生变化之道也。 故太上曰：能知一，万事毕。 不能知一，无一之可知。 此妙言也。 以数言之，因一有二，因二有三。 以气言之，一为始气，始即先天，与道为体。 与人为命。 欲立命本，非一而何？ 一虚无形，散乎万物。 今之抱一，乃抱阳也。 性命由此而生焉。 列子曰：易无形乎？ 谓之抱虚而非虚，象不可欺； 谓之抱实而非实，道本无情。 此有无不能以自存，乃道之妙也。 由是则知一即道也。 道即易卜也，易即阴阳也。 故一阴一阳之谓道，又曰生生之谓易。 言阴阳相生，变易不穷，如彼日月离合有度，消息自然。 於是月之初生夺火为养，一变而九，九即九阳，故抱一而不可离也。 《火记》曰：天有象，日月星； 地有象，水火金。 月虽为金，金岂有形？ 乃西方之气也。 神和子曰：西方无金元借气，北方之气为水，水亦无形，南方之气为火，火亦无象。 此真水真火也。 故《仙经》曰：黑铅水虎者，天地妙化之根，无质有气。 红铅火龙者，是天地之妙用发生之气，有气而无质。 盖人以有形之躯，虚一心而夺天地自然之气，取金於月，互用水火，水火炼金，乃成丹也。 则知易为阴阳之体，一为水火之原。 乾体是金，资火为养，欲夺其气，非一不全。 谓太阴初生即魄也，非魂不致其明，魂为火，非抱一不足以取太阳之气。 又以金水两半而圆满。 今不言水而言火，以运言，太阳，水也。 《火记》曰：星因日月而生，金因水火而成。 故藉三光以明。 至道之用，非徒得象，就亦忘形，兹其妙乎？ 二、喜怒为戒。 专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 一者，阳之始生也。 如子在母胎，以柔守之，故谓之专气。 所谓听之以气也。 经曰绵绵若存，用之不勤。 此专气之道也。 盖阳之初生，以有刚性，当慎其初。 方复之时，专以柔御，浸而刚长，过则失中，乃所以致之也。 致，取也。 取柔以御刚，不欲以失其和也。 月之既望，金水两半。 上弦如绳平而直也，不可差胜。 和理出於性，性与情合，阴阳之道焉。 金之得火，体变为乾，乾转巽，方变体归坤，五能养一，母立牝基。 经所谓而贵求食於母，不可不致柔，是故如婴儿无蹶暴之理也。 三、深明色空。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 心化而为性，利欲之情泯迹而不见，性隐而心生妄想之缘，触涂而拥底。 欲穷道要，深察天机。 外境未忘，邪心愈胜。 盖大道在虚心而得天机，斯莹浄而明。 原夫一自无生，匪凝然而无由索隐。 乾从坤变须智彻，而可以观微句嗜欲之昏理，乃天机之蹇浅。 涤除二字，务在刳心。 玄览之功，必先忘己，所以水澌流动，海莹天空，澡雪精神，疏明究竟，非玄不览，惟道是从。

「Thus, when the foundation is firmly established and cannot be uprooted,
until the moment when the **yáng** embryo descends into the lower furnace,
its breath is left to its own accord,
and the **Dao** is fulfilled.

Therefore, the *Classic* does not speak of *numbers* but speaks of *numbers*,
does not speak of *medicines* but speaks of *medicines*.
The principles of **Lead (Qīan)** and **Mercury (Gǒng)** are fully contained here.

**Next, the method of refining with the *jiǎ* (metal):**
Six stages in total.
1. **Taming and subduing the Golden Tiger (Jīn Hǔ).**
   Can one who embraces Oneness remain undivided?

   The six transformations are the **Dao**.
   The name of the transformation is the union of **sun and moon**.
   Before their union, there is no **yin and yang**;
   after their union, they correspond to **water and fire**.
   This is the **Heaven and Earth’s natural Elixir (Huán Dān)**.

   The natural Elixir of Heaven and Earth is inherently possessed,
   neither abandoned nor detached.
   When we speak of "embracing," it means
   that humans cannot align with Heaven and Earth’s natural spontaneity.
   By relying on the three substances—**Lead, Mercury, and Metal (Jīn)**—
   through the symbols of the transformation,
   we seize the natural **qi** of Heaven and Earth,
   manipulate the furnace and crucible,
   and refine the supreme medicine.
   Thus, we emulate Heaven and Earth’s natural spontaneity.

   When speaking of humans, "embracing Oneness" means
   to remain undivided—
   this is yet unpermitted speech.

   In general, when people speak of "embracing Oneness,"
   what constitutes this "One"?

   If "One" is taken as a *number*, some say it is akin to **four (Lì)**;
   if "One" is taken as *advancement*, some say it is like **muddying the tracks (Nì)**.
   One must extinguish this "One"
   to verify the essence of **profound stillness (Zhàn Jìng)**.
   These are all methods of annihilation,
   not the **Dao of eternal transformation**.

   Therefore, the **Supreme Sage (Tài Shàng)** says:
   *"To know the One is to complete all things.
   To not know the One is to have nothing to know.
   This is a profound statement."*

   When speaking of *numbers*, from One comes Two,
   from Two comes Three.
   When speaking of **qi**, the One is the **original breath (Shǐ qì)**,
   the original being **pre-Heaven (Xiān Tiān)**,
   the same as the **Dao’s substance (tǐ)**.
   For humans, it is the **foundation of life (mìng)**.
   To establish the root of life,
   what is more fundamental than the One?
   The One is formless and boundless,
   dispersed throughout all things.

   Today’s "embracing Oneness" is actually the **embracing of yang**.
   Life and vitality arise from this.
   **Liezi** says:
   *"Is the **Dao** formless?
   It is called embracing the **void (xū)** yet not the void—
   the **symbols (xiàng)** cannot be deceived;
   it is called embracing the **real (shí)** yet not the real—
   the **Dao’s essence** is without attachment.
   This is the mystery of having and not having,
   which cannot be preserved by itself—
   this is the **Dao’s subtlety**."*

   Thus, one knows that the One is the **Dao**.
   The **Dao** is the **principle of yin and yang (yáng)**.
   The **Dao** is **yin and yang** themselves.
   Therefore, the **Dao** is called **One yin and One yang**,
   and it is also said, **"transformation is called eternal generation."**
   The **yin and yang** generate each other,
   their transformations endless,
   like the **sun and moon’s** separation and union,
   their **eclipse and manifestation** following natural law.

   Hence, at the moon’s initial birth,
   seizing fire for **nourishment (yǎng)**,
   one transformation leads to **nine (jiǔ)**,
   nine being **nine yangs (Jiǔ yáng)**,
   so embracing Oneness cannot be abandoned.

   The *Fire Record (Huǒ Jì)* says:
   *"Heaven has symbols—**sun, moon, and stars**;
   Earth has symbols—**water, fire, and metal (jīn)**.
   Though the moon is metal,
   where is its form?
   It is the **qi of the west**.
   **Shén Hé Zǐ** says:
   *"The west lacks the **original qi of metal (yuán)** borrowed from the east,
   the north’s **qi** is **water**,
   water also has no form,
   the south’s **qi** is **fire**,
   fire also has no **symbol**.
   These are **true water and true fire**."*

   Therefore, the *Immortal Classic (Xiān Jīng)* says:
   *"Black Lead is the **Water Tiger (shuǐ hǔ)**,
   the root of Heaven and Earth’s subtle transformations,
   without substance yet with **qi**.
   Red Lead is the **Fire Dragon (huǒ lóng)**,
   the **qi** of Heaven and Earth’s subtle transformations arising,
   with **qi** yet without substance.
   Indeed, humans with their **substantial bodies (yǒuxíng zhī qū)**,
   emptying their **One Heart (yī xīn)**,
   seize Heaven and Earth’s natural **qi**,
   extract **metal** from the moon,
   and interchange **water and fire**.
   When **water and fire** refine **metal**,
   the **Elixir (Dān)** is formed.
   Thus, one knows that the **Dao** is the **substance of yin and yang (tǐ)**,
   and the One is the **origin of water and fire (yuán)**.

   The **Qián** essence is **metal (jīn)**,
   sustained by **fire** for nourishment.
   To seize its **qi**, one must not abandon the One.
   The **moon’s initial birth** is the **arcane (pò)**,
   without the **hun** (ethereal soul) it lacks clarity,
   the **hun** being **fire**,
   without embracing Oneness it is insufficient to capture the **sun’s qi (Tài yáng zhī qì)**.
   Again, **metal and water** must be balanced and complete.

   Now, instead of speaking of **water**, we speak of **fire**,
   invoking the **sun** as **water**.

   The *Fire Record* says:
   *"Stars arise from **sun and moon**,
   **metal** is formed from **water and fire**.
   Therefore, we rely on the **three luminaries (sān guāng)** for illumination.
   The **Dao’s** application is not merely to obtain **symbols (xiàng)**;
   even if one attains them, one must forget their forms—
   this is its mystery."*

2. **Guard against joy and anger.**
   Concentrate the **qi** to achieve **softness (róu)**,
   can one be like an infant?

   The One is the **yang’s initial birth**.
   Like a child in the womb,
   it is guarded by **softness (róu)**,
   hence called **concentrating the qi**.
   The saying *"listen to it with the qi"* is the **Dao** of this.

   The *Classic* says:
   *"Continuous as if it exists,
   yet used without exertion.
   This is the **Dao** of concentrating the **qi**."*

   Indeed, the **yang’s** initial birth is marked by **rigidity (gāngxìng)**,
   and one must be cautious at its beginning.
   During the **returning phase (fāng fù)**, concentrate on **softness** to govern it;
   as it gradually strengthens, **rigidity** grows.
   If overdone, the **center is lost**,
   and this is the method of achieving it.

   *"Achieving"* means *"taking."*
   Taking **softness** to govern **rigidity**,
   one must not lose the **harmony (hé)**.

   After the full moon, **metal and water** are balanced.
   The **upper crescent** is like a taut string—
   straight and unyielding.
   One must not deviate or overpower it.
   **Harmony** arises from **nature (xìng)**,
   nature and **emotion (qíng)** merging,
   forming the **Dao of yin and yang**.

   When **metal** receives **fire**,
   its **substance** transforms into **Qián** (creativity),
   **Qián** shifts to **Xùn** (wind),
   and the **five phases** complete their cycle,
   returning to **Kūn** (receptivity).
   The five can nourish the One,
   and the **mother establishes the foundation (mǔ lì pín jī)**.

   The *Classic* says:
   *"Thus, the noble one seeks nourishment from the mother,
   and one must not fail to concentrate on **softness**—
   hence, like an infant without **stumbling or violence (jué bào)**."*

3. **Profoundly understand the emptiness of forms.**
   Purify and eliminate, observe the **mystery (xuán)**—
   can one remain without flaw?

   When the **heart (xīn)** transforms into **nature (xìng)**,
   desires and utilitarian emotions vanish,
   yet **nature** is hidden while the **heart** generates **delusive thoughts (wàng xiǎng)**.
   These thoughts cling to **impurities (tú)**,
   accumulating like sediment at the bottom.

   To exhaust the **Dao’s** essence,
   one must deeply inspect **Heaven’s mechanisms (tiān jī)**.
   As long as external phenomena are not forgotten,
   **evil thoughts (xié xīn)** will prevail.

   Indeed, the **Great Dao** is attained through an **empty heart**,
   thereby grasping **Heaven’s mechanisms**—
   this is **pure and clear**, and **illuminated**.

   Originally, the One arises from **non-generation (wúshēng)**,
   not solidifying yet without means to conceal its **mystery**.
   The **Qián** phase must derive from **Kūn** through **enlightenment (zhì chè)**,
   and only then can one perceive the **subtle words of the Dao (wēi jù)**,
   the **obscured desires (xī yù zhī hūn)**,
   and the **dimness of lustful reasoning (lì yù zhī chǎn)**.

   The two characters *"purify and eliminate"* emphasize **excavating the heart**.
   The **function of observing the mystery** requires first forgetting oneself,
   so that **water flows freely**,
   the **sea’s clarity** reflects the **sky’s vastness**,
   and **spirit is renewed like snow after a bath**.
   **Dispelling delusion** and **clarifying the ultimate (shū míng jiù jìng)**,
   one cannot observe the **mystery** without **Dao**,
   and follows only the **Dao**.

chunks.original_text: 此荣趎问卫生之经，颜回契心斋之妙。 四、字言治道。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 经之大旨，在治身治家、治国治天下。 疏之所归，在性宗命宗，常道轮贯，玄显单修齐修。 不能会之，则分流。 以理达之，则一致。 此篇初言载营魄，其理在日月往来，交合火候，药物进退。 次以专气致柔，涤除玄览，皆原性命之本。 至此忽言爱民治国，言涉世法，何支离邪？ 不然，以一身之言，心为君也，血气犹民也。 心浄神和，神合则荣卫周流，而血气条达，阴阳四时，自得其序。 不驰不骤，是犹爱神贵气，一心融和而政无为之道也。 《灵枢》曰：天地潜冥，六元自经。 此天之自然，无为以至。 治世之道，以民为本，爱之则子来，利之则麋至，诚而服之，悦而使之，不淫其性，不迁其德，陶陶焉居仁寿之域，岂有为哉？ 所以与阴阳合，用天地同功，其於治道，又何间焉？ 五、调御刚气。 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 柔者不能刚，雄者不能雌，性也。 能柔能刚，知雄守雌，道也。 一於性而不合於道，非圣人也。 圣人动与道合，用与道同。 庄子曰：天门者无有也。 以无有为开阖，则不见为雌之义。 夫天门者乾也。 乾以六气言之，至巽己为天门。 以八卦定位言之，戌亥为天门，巽为地户，即坤也。 乾至己为纯阳，可谓雄也。 而居坤位，是不离於雌也。 当刚之时，与柔合德，岂不曰能为雌乎？ 戌亥乾之位，自午分六气，亥为纯坤，乾居坤位，得非为雌乎？ 此乾坤自然之理。 故东南巽，阳气所出，天门开也。 西北乾，阴气所入，天门阖也。 又自东辟至巳，巳乃未也，未为人门，所以巽为地户。 非特正未是也。 至於人用之亦然。
chunks.translated_text:
This text expounds on the **Jīng** of nurturing life’s essence and **Yán Huì’s** grasp of the **heart-fasting** subtlety.

**IV. The Dao of Governance Through Character**

*"To love the people and govern the realm—*
*can one truly do so without action?"*

The **Jīng’s** grand intent lies in governing the body, the family,
the realm, and the world.
Its threads converge in the **doctrines of nature and fate**,
where **Dao** cycles through **mystery and clarity**—
whether practiced in **unity or division**.
If one fails to harmonize them, they scatter.
If guided by **principle**, they align.

This passage first speaks of **nourishing the spirit and vital essence**,
its logic rooted in the **sun and moon’s interplay**,
the **conjunction of fire’s timing**,
the **advance and retreat of medicines**.
Next, it speaks of **concentrating qi to attain softness**,
**purifying and observing the mystery**—
all tracing back to the **origin of nature and fate**.

Yet suddenly it speaks of *loving the people and governing the realm*—
a shift to worldly law. How disjointed!

Not so. When speaking of the self,
the **heart is sovereign**, the **blood and qi are the people**.
A **pure heart and harmonized spirit** mean
the **honor and defense circulate freely**,
and the **blood and qi flow in order**.
The **yin and yang of the four seasons**
then follow their natural course—
neither hastening nor lagging.
This is akin to *cherishing the spirit and valuing qi*,
a **unified heart** merging with the **Dao of effortless governance**.

The *Língshū* states:
*"Heaven and Earth in hidden stillness,*
*the Six Celestial Stems weave themselves."*

This is **Heaven’s natural way**—
**effortless and complete**.

The **Dao of governing the world**
takes the people as its root.
Love them, and they gather like children.
Benefit them, and they come like deer.
With sincerity, they submit.
With joy, they obey.
Do not pervert their nature,
do not alter their virtue.
Thus they dwell in **Ren’s domain of longevity**—
where is there any *action*?

Hence, it aligns with **yin and yang**,
harmonizes with **Heaven and Earth’s function**—
what separation exists in governance?

**V. Harmonizing the Rigid Qi**

*"The Heavenly Gate’s opening and closing—*
*can one avoid being feminine?"*

The soft cannot dominate the rigid,
the masculine cannot submit to the feminine—
this is **nature**.
To be both soft and rigid,
to know masculinity while guarding femininity—
this is **Dao**.

To adhere to **nature** yet not align with **Dao**
is not the **Sage’s way**.

The Sage’s movements merge with **Dao**,
his actions resonate with **Dao**.
Zhuangzi said:
*"The Heavenly Gate has no form."*

To treat its *non-existence* as opening and closing
is to overlook its feminine essence.

The **Heavenly Gate** is **Qián**.
When spoken of through the **Six Qi**, it reaches **Xùn** as the Heavenly Gate.
When defined by the **Eight Trigrams’ positions**, **Xū-Hài** are the Heavenly Gate,
**Xùn** is the Earthly Door—**Kūn** itself.

**Qián** at **Jǐ** is pure yang—
truly masculine.
Yet it resides in **Kūn’s** position—
never detached from femininity.

At times of rigidity, it merges with softness in **virtue**—
is this not *being feminine*?

**Xū-Hài**, **Qián’s** positions,
from **Wǔ** dividing the Six Qi,
**Hài** is pure **Kūn**.
**Qián** in **Kūn’s** position—
is this not *being feminine*?

This is the **natural logic of Qián and Kūn**.

Thus, **Xùn** in the east-south—
where **yang qi** emerges—
the Heavenly Gate opens.
**Qián** in the west-north—
where **yin qi** enters—
the Heavenly Gate closes.

From **Dōngbì** to **Sì**, **Sì** is **Wèi**,
**Wèi** as the **Human Gate**—
thus **Xùn** is the Earthly Door.
Not only does this apply to **Wèi** itself.

Even in human application, it holds true.

chunks.original_text: 凡言能与不能，化性而入道也。 盖营魄为月，坤主月也，非炼四象而入中宫欤？ 盖道能生物，雄则独阳不生，托乎阴阳，以生为义。 故取其母。 经曰有名万物之母，是为法则。 阴阳以月为准，一月之内自朔既晦，乾坤互体而成其道。 月之初三日，再生震，震受庚符，坤一变为震。 八日变丁，坤再变成兑。 十五日变乾，十六日转巽，乾之一变，十六日出辛。 二十三日乾再变艮。 平明出丙，三十日甲地丧明，三变坤没乙，至于晦。 阳德以亏，会阳於艮，资阴以养，日月炼形。 阴阳相夺，月得魄而生。 庚日得魂而告朔。 俱自艮始，艮为门阙。 庄子曰：入出而无见其形，是谓天门。 天门者，无有也。 夫乾坤者，画卦则显象，不画卦则象安在焉。 六阳为乾气之变也，六阴为坤时之行也。 乾复变坤，乾何有也？ 坤复变乾，坤何存也？ 不一其形，且何定位？ 一出一入，物自乘之。 故万物出乎无有，无有一无有，圣人藏乎是。 六、脱落知见。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 知者，自知也。 见者，自见也。 自知者有所悟，因知而发天光。 自见者有所明，因心而探妙本。 见无所见，洞然通照。 非徒无法也，而法法无遗焉。 阴阳之变化，日月之交合，乾坤之互用，出入之有无，了乎一心，曲尽其妙，则可谓明白矣。 夫智以自知，在内而不在外也。 见以自见，在己而不在人也。 若以智为谋，所谋在物，非盗机也。 以明为见，所见在事，非了知也。 当用其光，而复归其明，岂可昭昭然如揭日月？ 虽自知自见，亦不可以知见自知也。 《楞严》曰：知见立知，即无明本，解脱知见，即为真如。 聪明其可不诎乎，言辩其可不忘乎。 则知至人之心，知之而不言，而言者不知矣。

**All** who speak of **ability** and **inability**—
this is the **transformation of nature** entering the **Dao/Way**.

Indeed, **Yíng-Pò** is the **moon**,
and **Kūn** governs the **moon**—
is this not the **refinement of the Four Symbols** to enter the **Central Palace**?

Indeed, the **Dao/Way** can give birth to things,
and pure **yang** alone cannot generate—
it relies upon **yin-yang**,
and **generation** is its meaning.
Thus, one takes its **mother**.

The **Classics** say: *"There is a named **mother** of all things—*
this is the **law**."

**Yin-yang** take the **moon** as their standard,
and within one **moon**,
from **new moon** to **full moon** and then to **waning**,
**Qián** and **Kūn** interpenetrate
to complete their **Dao/Way**.

The first three days of the **moon**,
**Zhèn** is reborn twice—
**Zhèn** receives the **Gēng** talisman,
and **Kūn** undergoes its first **transformation** into **Zhèn**.

On the eighth day, it **transforms** into **Dīng**,
and **Kūn** undergoes its second **transformation** into **Duì**.

On the fifteenth day, it **transforms** into **Qián**,
and on the sixteenth day, it shifts into **Xùn**—
the first **transformation** of **Qián**,
and on the sixteenth day, **Xīn** emerges.

On the twenty-third day, **Qián** undergoes its second **transformation** into **Gèn**.

At **cockcrow**, **Bǐng** appears,
and on the thirtieth day, **Jiǎ** loses its **brightness**—
**Qián**’s third **transformation**,
and **Kūn** **vanishes** into **Yǐ**,
until it reaches **waning**.

When **yang virtue/power** is diminished,
it **converges** with **yang** in **Gèn**,
and **nourishes** **yin** with **yang**—
the **sun** and **moon** **refine** their forms.

**Yin-yang** **interact** and **deplete** each other,
and the **moon** **obtains** its **arc** to **generate**.
On the **Gēng** day, it **receives** its **soul** and **announces** the **new moon**.

Both commence from **Gèn**,
and **Gèn** is the **threshold**.

**Zhuāngzǐ** says:
*"To enter and exit without seeing its form—*
this is called the **Heavenly Gate**."

The **Heavenly Gate** is **emptiness**.
**Qián** and **Kūn**—
when **hexagrams** are drawn, their **forms** appear,
but if **hexagrams** are not drawn, where are their **forms**?

The **Six Yang** are the **transformations** of **Qián qi**,
and the **Six Yin** are the **movements** of **Kūn’s** time.

When **Qián** **transforms** back into **Kūn**,
what **Qián** remains?
When **Kūn** **transforms** back into **Qián**,
what **Kūn** remains?
If it does not **unify** its form,
how can it **settle** its position?
One **emerges**, one **enters**,
and things **multiply** themselves.

Thus, all things **emerge** from **emptiness**,
**emptiness** **contains** **emptiness** and **emptiness**—
the **sage** **hides** within this.

**Liú**, **Tuō**, **Zhī**, **Jiàn**—
**knowing** and **seeing** **fall away**—
how can one **clearly** **perceive** all four directions?
How can one **not** **know**?

**Knowing** is **self-knowing**,
and **seeing** is **self-seeing**.
Those who **self-know** have **awakening**,
and through **knowing**, they **emanate** **Heavenly Light**.

Those who **self-see** have **clarity**,
and through the **heart**, they **delve** into the **wondrous root**.

To **see** without **seeing**—
**penetrating** and **illuminating** without obstruction.
This is not merely **lawlessness**,
but rather, **law** **pervades** all **laws**.

The **transformations** of **yin-yang**,
the **conjunctions** of **sun** and **moon**,
the **interactions** of **Qián** and **Kūn**,
the **emergences** and **entries** of **having** and **emptiness**—
**comprehended** within **one mind**,
**fully** **exhausting** their **mysteries**,
then one may be called **clear**.

**Wisdom** lies in **self-knowing**,
within **inner** **virtue/power**—
not in the **outer**.

**Seeing** lies in **self-seeing**,
within **oneself**—
not in **others**.

If **wisdom** is used for **scheming**,
what is schemed is in **things**—
this is not **stealing** the **mechanism**.

If **clarity** is used for **perception**,
what is perceived is in **affairs**—
this is not **true understanding**.

When the **time** is right to **apply** its **light**,
and then **return** to its **clarity**—
how can it be **radiant** like the **sun** and **moon**?
Even if **self-known** and **self-seen**,
one still cannot **self-know** through **knowing** and **seeing**.

The **Lengyán** **Sutra** says:
*"To establish **knowing** and **seeing** is to establish **ignorance**,
and to **liberate** from **knowing** and **seeing** is to attain **True Suchness**."*

**Keen intelligence**—
how can it not **be bent**?
**Eloquence**—
how can it not **be forgotten**?

Thus, one **knows** the **heart** of the **perfected sage**—
**knowing** yet **not speaking**,
and **speaking** yet **not knowing**.

chunks.original_text: 后总言妙用：用一、功用在物。 生之畜之。 道者，天地待是而后生，日月者，万物待是而后作。 阳唱於始，《易》曰首出庶物是也，阴成於终，无成有终是也。 万物由之以生以化，故道为物之母，生之也。 德有成之理，畜之也。 非道无以生，非德无以畜。 畜，养也。 物在天地之中，道乃涵养之也。 又曰：畜以聚之。 然一性之大道以具矣。 非德成之，性或亏矣。 此篇自载营魄以至抱一、专气、涤除、爱民，皆自有为而至无为也。 何哉？ 天地有自然还丹之道，人法金火，修成自然之道，故以无为终之。 又天门开阖，独守其母，不浮不动，若无知者，则道尽於此矣。 魄营则生之，成魄则畜之，为而至於不为，知而自为不知，则还全之道。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，有无为功焉。 夫无为则道之妙也。 二、不居其功。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰。 此三句义重明无知字也。 夫学道者初贵乎忘物，次贵乎无心。 所谓金丹之道，与天同功。 虽存师法，而毕竟执天之行，不可拂其自然之理也。 然不可不知，不可不为。 知其至要则反乎无知，始於有为终合无为。 金夺火也，岂有取之之心？ 取犹不取也。 故生而不有，为而不恃者，存乎阴阳之妙用也。 岂以其功有所恃邪？ 此道虽用之以阴阳，而其运机也，阴阳不可测。 长而不宰，言月之初及其圆成也，何加手焉？ 杨雄曰：圣人以不手焉，圣人宜与於斯乎。 三、牒前言。 不有其德，是谓玄德。 是谓者，牒前也。 总结一章之义，赞叹其微也。 谓前文露天地还丹之旨，乾坤爱炼之机，不测其渊，徒为世法，岂知药物备具，火候无差，造化不能隐其微，体用无以出乎此。 《阴符》曰：知之修练，谓之圣人。 乃玄德也。 邵若愚曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 心无定名，随处而立。 心动则着物，着物便见心。 心动则属阳，其名曰神，又名曰心。 心不动则属阴，其名曰精，又名曰性。 心向外也，为视为听，其名曰魂，又名曰情。 心向内也，收视反听，其名曰魄，又名曰意，皆随处立名。 总名曰心。 乃知心者载身之主，无不经营。 本言魄者，为魄属阴，阴以静为法制。 心为内，静则精魄住。 精魄住，则神魂住。 精神魂魄，混融相合为一，谓之抱一。 抱一虽能治二炁於黄道，会二性於元宫。 攒簇五行，合和四象。 此长生之术，未极於道者，缘心着一故也。 老子叹曰：能无离乎？ 离有入无，令心廓彻清静。 始曰无为，此名真心，乃大道也。 如专气政柔者，既言专气，使是用心。 有心则不得致柔，能比如婴儿无心乎？ 若涤除万境，一心览玄，如玉有疵，能有心执玄，能无瑕疵乎？ 夫爱民治国之心，经营天下之政，事彰於迹，有迹则有忧，而能显诸仁，藏诸用，而无为乎？ 天然机解之门，心也。 开阖应务之际，能随顺物情，而为雌乎？ 心本浄明洁白，四方通达，缘染知见，情解至碍，不能虚静，能无知见乎？ 夫一者，攀缘之本，生灭之根，既有一系着，即非无为之道。 能离抱一之迹，方合於玄德。 玄德者，生育之，畜养之，夫生之者，道而不见其有为之者，德而不见其恃，至於长成而不为主宰，是谓玄德。 故庄子曰：通於一，万事毕。 若无心得一，而鬼神报。 此之谓也。

「The **Way**’s **mystic** **application** is then summarized:

1. **Application** of the **One**—its **function** lies in **things**.
   To **generate** and to **nurture**.
   The **Dao/Way** is what the heavens and earth **await** before **generation**,
   what all **things** **await** before the **sun** and **moon** **manifest**.
   The **Yang** **resonates** at the **beginning**—*"The **Easy** [Yijing] says: 'The first emergence of all things is this,'"*—
   while the **Yin** **materializes** at the **end**—*"There is no end without completion."*—
   All **things** arise and transform through it,
   thus the **Dao/Way** is the **mother** of **things**, the **generator**.
   **Virtue/power** has the principle of **completion**—the **nurturer**.
   Without the **Dao/Way**, there is no **generation**,
   and without **virtue/power**, there is no **nurturing**.
   **Nurturing** is **cultivation**.
   Within the heavens and earth, the **Dao/Way** is the **encompassing** **cultivation**.
   It is also said: *"**Nurturing** is to **gather** [qi].*
   Yet, the **Great Dao/Way** of **One**’s **nature** has already been **fulfilled**.
   Without **virtue/power**’s **completion**, **nature** may be **impaired**.
   This chapter, from **loading** the **vital breath** [yìng] and **vital essence** [pò] to **embracing the One**, **concentrating qi**, **purifying** [díchú], and **loving the people**,
   all **proceed** from **action** to **non-action**.
   Why so?
   The heavens and earth have the **natural** **elixir** [huán’dān] **Dao/Way**,
   while humans **follow** the **metallic fire** [jīnhuǒ].
   By **refining** the **natural Dao/Way**, one **concludes** with **non-action**.
   The **Celestial Gate** [Tiānmén] **opens** and **closes**—
   **solely guarding** its **mother**,
   **not floating**, **not moving**,
   like one **without knowing**—
   then the **Dao/Way** is **exhausted** here.

   **Loading** the **vital breath** and **vital essence** is **generation**,
   **completing** the **vital breath** is **nurturing**,
   **acting** yet **reaching non-action**,
   **knowing** yet **acting as if in ignorance**—
   this is the **Dao/Way** of **restoring** the **whole**.

   **Generating** yet **not possessing**,
   **acting** yet **not relying**,
   **nurturing** yet **not dominating**—
   here lies the **function** of **non-action**.

   **Non-action** is the **mystic** **application** of the **Dao/Way**.
   The three phrases—*"**generating** yet **not possessing**, **acting** yet **not relying**, **nurturing** yet **not dominating**"*—
   emphasize the **importance** of the **character** "without knowing."

   Those who **study** the **Dao/Way** first **value** **forgetting things**,
   then **value** **having no mind**.
   The **Dao/Way** of the **Golden Elixir** [jīndān]
   **harmonizes** with the **heavenly function**.
   Though following the **master’s teachings** [shīfǎ],
   one must ultimately **conform** to **heaven’s operation** [Tiānxíng],
   **not defying** its **natural principle**.
   Yet, one **must not** **fail** to **know**,
   nor **fail** to **apply**.
   **Knowing** its **most vital essence** leads to **returning** to **non-knowing**,
   **beginning** with **action** and **concluding** in **non-action**.

   **Fire** **consumes** **metal**—
   how can there be a **mind** of **taking**?
   **Taking** is **yet not taking**.
   Thus, *"**generating** yet **not possessing**, **acting** yet **not relying**"*
   lies in the **mystic** **application** of **Yin** and **Yang**.
   How can one **rely** on its **function**?
   This **Dao/Way**, though **applied** through **Yin** and **Yang**,
   its **mechanism** is **unfathomable**—
   **Yin** and **Yang** **cannot** be **measured**.
   *"**Nurturing** yet **not dominating**"*—
   this refers to the **moon’s** **beginning** and its **fullness**,
   why **add** a **hand**?
   **Yang** **Xiong** said: *"The **perfected sage** **acts** without **handling**,
   the **perfected sage** **should** **align** with this."*

   **Revisiting** what was said before:
   **Not possessing** its **virtue/power**—
   this is called **mystic virtue/power**.
   This is said **to revisit** what came before.
   Summarizing the **essence** of this chapter,
   **praising** its **subtlety**:
   The **previous** text **revealed** the **intent** of the **heavenly elixir Dao/Way**,
   the **mechanism** of **love** and **refinement** in **bukan** [乾坤, Heaven-Earth],
   yet **unfathomable** in its **depth**,
   merely **conforming** to **worldly methods**—
   how can one **know** that the **medicines** are **complete**,
   that the **fire** and **refinement** are **without flaw**?
   The **Dao/Way** of **creation** and **transformation** **cannot** **conceal** its **subtleties**,
   and **body** and **application** **cannot** **emerge** beyond this.

   The *Yīnxíng* [阴符, *Yin Symbol* **Sutra**) says:
   *"**Knowing** and **refining**, this is called the **perfected sage**.
   It is the **mystic virtue/power**."*

   **Shào Ruòyú** said:
   *"From **loading** the **vital breath** and **vital essence** to this is called **mystic virtue/power**.
   The **heart** has **no fixed name**, **establishing** itself **according to circumstances**.
   When the **heart** **stirs**, it **adheres** to **things**,
   and **adhering** to **things** reveals the **heart**.
   When the **heart** **stirs**, it **belongs** to **Yang**,
   and is named **spirit** [shén], or also named the **heart**.
   When the **heart** is **still**, it **belongs** to **Yin**,
   and is named **essence** [jīng], or also named **nature** [xìng].
   When the **heart** **turns outward**, it becomes **vision** and **hearing**,
   and is named **soul** [hún], or also named **emotion** [qíng].
   When the **heart** **turns inward**, it **withdraws** **vision** and **returns** **hearing**,
   and is named **vital breath** [pò], or also named **intention** [yì],
   all **establishing names** **according to circumstances**.
   In total, it is named the **heart**.
   Thus one **knows** the **heart** as the **master** **bearing** the **body**,
   **without fail** **cultivating** [yíng].

   Originally, the **vital breath** is **Yin**,
   and **Yin** **follows** the **principle** of **stillness**.
   The **heart** is **internal**,
   and **stillness** allows the **vital breath** and **essence** to **settle**.
   When the **vital breath** and **essence** **settle**,
   then the **spirit** and **soul** **settle**.
   The **spirit**, **essence**, **soul**, and **vital breath**—
   **blended** and **harmonized** into **One**, called **embracing the One**.

   Though **embracing the One** can **adjust** the **Two Qi** [liǎngyì, Yin-Yang] at the **Yellow Dao/Way** [Huángdào],
   and **unite** the **Two Natures** [liǎngxìng] at the **Primordial Palace** [Yuāngōng],
   **concentrating** the **Five Phases** [wǔxíng] and **harmonizing** the **Four Symbols** [sìxiàng]—
   this is the **technique** of **longevity**,
   yet **not ultimate** in the **Dao/Way**,
   because the **heart** **adheres** to **One** [object].

   **Lǎozǐ** sighed and said: *"Can one **not depart** from it?
   **Departing** from **having** and **entering** **non-having**,
   **emptying** the **heart** to **clarity** and **stillness**.
   Initially it was called **non-action**,
   this is the name of **true heart**,
   the **Great Dao/Way**.
   Like **concentrating qi** and **governing softness** [zhìróu],
   once **concentrating qi** is spoken of,
   this **application** **depends** on the **heart**.
   With the **heart**, one **cannot** **achieve softness**,
   can it be **like** an **infant** **without heart**?
   If **purifying** all **realms**,
   **one heart** **beholding** the **mystic**,
   like **jade** **having a flaw**,
   can one **with heart** **cling** to the **mystic**,
   yet **not** **be free** of **flaws**?
   The **heart** of **loving the people** and **governing the state**,
   **cultivating** the **affairs** of the **world**,
   **manifest** in **traces**,
   with **traces** comes **worry**,
   yet **can** it **display** in **benevolence** [rén],
   **conceal** in **application**,
   and **still** **achieve non-action**?

   The **gate** of **natural** **mechanism** and **understanding**,
   the **heart** is this.
   **Opening** and **closing** to **respond** to **circumstances**,
   can it **follow** the **nature** of **things** and **emotions**,
   and **act** as **feminine** [cī]?
   The **heart** is originally **pure** and **clear**,
   **white** and **unobstructed** in all **directions**,
   yet **stained** by **knowing** and **seeing**,
   **emotional** **entanglements** **reaching** **obstruction**,
   unable to **be empty** and **still**—
   can it **be free** of **knowing** and **seeing**?

   The **One** is the **root** of **clinging** and **wandering**,
   the **source** of **generation** and **extinction**.
   Once **clinging** to **One** [object] **persists**,
   it is **not** the **Dao/Way** of **non-action**.
   To **depart** from the **trace** of **embracing the One**,
   only then does it **align** with **mystic virtue/power**.
   **Mystic virtue/power** is **generating** and **nurturing**,
   **generating** yet **not seen** in **action**,
   **virtue/power** yet **not seen** in **relying**,
   **nurturing** to **completion** yet **not dominating**—
   this is called **mystic virtue/power**.
   Hence, **Zhuāngzǐ** said: *"**Penetrating** the **One**, all **affairs** are **completed**.
   If **without heart** one **attains** the **One**, then **ghosts** and **spirits** **respond**.
   This is what is meant."*

chunks.original_text: 王志然曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 至人以体性抱神为入道之序，以寂然至无为体道之用。 夫载营魄者，以雌静为体，柔伏为用。 控适制御，必待阳魂为之配。 魄则依形而能静，不能动者也。 魂则载形而能动，不能静者也。 离合自然，唯神是主，亦犹车之有轮，毂辐虽具，何因自行？ 当其无车之用，方其用也，是须臾不可得而离之。 故曰抱一能无离乎？ 尝试论之，神不一之谓罔，精不一之谓两。 由物而之於罔两，何灵之有？ 盖以人之有生不明此道，自丧己灵，殆其将启手足之际，精华耗散，魂魄悠扬。 魂必随识而散於空，魄则随尸而沉於地。 举皆不得其归真之趣，与夫静曰复命之说不可同日而语。 施肩吾曰：精住则气住，气住则神往。 庄子：精全则气全，气全则神全，神全则道全。 三者既全，所谓形精复形神，俱妙与道合，真心志久，宁天光自发学者所患乎？ 有学道之心，无学道之质，有学道之质，无学道之心尔。 畏所失者，失其所以治心养性之本。 故老子设问曰：专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 喜怒不形乎色，好恶不入乎心，诸境对忘，不立一尘，何疵之有？ 身犹国也，国犹身也。 未闻身治而国不治也，国治而身不治者也。 始於有为，终於无为。 外虽淡於有为之末，内必保乎无为之本。 故曰爱民治国，能无为乎？ 《大易》以乾坤为门户，谷神以玄牝为门户。 天地阴阳，卷舒启闭，出入开阖，不失其时。 人之有身，不失其为天地阴阳之用。 每顺乎天，未尝违天； 每下於物，未尝先物。

King Zhìrán said: *"To bear the **spirit-soul** (*yíngpò*) until this is called **mystic virtue/power**.*

The **Perfect Person** (*zhìrén*) takes **embracing one’s innate nature** and **harboring the spirit** as the sequence of entering the **Dao/Way**, and **stillness** and **non-action** as the application of embodying the **Dao/Way**.

Now, to bear the **spirit-soul** (*yíngpò*)—its **substance** is **yin-stillness**, its **function** is **gentle submission**. To **control** and **guide** it properly requires the **yang-spirit** (*hún*) as its complement. The **spirit-soul** (*pò*) depends on form to achieve stillness, yet cannot move on its own. The **spirit** (*hún*) rides the form to move, yet cannot still itself. Their **separation** and **union** occur naturally, with the **spirit** (*shén*) as their sovereign—just as a chariot needs wheels. Though the hub and spokes are present, how could it move without a **chariot**? When the **chariot** is not in use, yet when it is used, for an instant it cannot be separated from it.

Thus, it is said: *‘Can one embrace the One without separation?’*

Let us examine this: **Spirit** not unified is called **emptiness** (*wǎng*), **essence** not unified is called **duality** (*liǎng*). From **things** one falls into **emptiness-duality**—what **spirituality** remains?

Indeed, because humans with life do not understand this **Dao/Way**, they lose their own **spirituality**. By the time they begin to move their hands and feet, their **essence** dissipates, their **spirit-soul** (*húnpò*) drifts away. The **spirit** (*hún*) must scatter with **perception** into the void, while the **spirit-soul** (*pò*) sinks with the corpse into the earth. All fail to return to their **true nature**—this cannot be compared to the saying of **stillness as returning to one’s original nature**.

Shī Jiānwú said: *"When **essence** abides, **qi** abides; when **qi** abides, **spirit** departs."* **Zhuāngzǐ** said: *"When **essence** is complete, **qi** is complete; when **qi** is complete, **spirit** is complete; when **spirit** is complete, the **Dao/Way** is complete."* When these three are complete, it is called **restoring form and essence**, **unifying form and spirit**, all perfectly aligning with the **Dao/Way**. Yet those who long for **true heart-mind** and **resolve**—why do they not naturally emit **heavenly radiance**?

There are those with the **heart** to learn the **Dao/Way** but lacking the **nature** to learn it; there are those with the **nature** to learn the **Dao/Way** but lacking the **heart** to learn it. Those who fear what they lose have already lost the **root** of **calming the heart** and **nurturing nature**.

Thus, **Lǎozǐ** posed the question: *"Can you concentrate your **qi** and soften like an infant? Can you keep **joy** and **anger** from showing on your face, **likes** and **dislikes** from entering your heart? When all **phenomena** confront you, you forget them—no dust of **attachment** arises. What **flaws** remain?*

The **body** is like a **state**; the **state** is like the **body**. One has never heard of the **body** being governed yet the **state** not governed, or the **state** governed yet the **body** not governed. It begins with **action** and ends with **non-action**. Though externally one may be indifferent to the **outcomes of action**, internally one must preserve the **root of non-action**.

Thus, it is said: *‘To love the people and govern the state—can one do so without non-action?’*

The *Great Clinging* (*Dà Yì*) takes **Heaven** and **Earth** as gateways; the **valley-spirit** (*gǔshén*) takes the **mysterious female** (*xiánpò*) as its gateway. **Heaven** and **Earth**, **yin** and **yang**—their **rolling**, **unfolding**, **opening**, and **closing**, their **emerging**, **entering**, **expanding**, and **contracting**—never fail their **timing**. The human body, too, does not fail to embody the **functions of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang**. Always in harmony with **Heaven**, never defying it; always yielding to **things**, never preceding them."*

**Pliancy and wisdom**—these are the true accomplishments of the **noble man** (*dàzhàngfū*). When he is **enlightened**, he **saves all within the Dao**; when he **applies** them, they **manifest**; when he **conceals** them, they **remain hidden**. He does not **transpose** anger, nor does he **repeat** faults.

**Abundant virtue and sage appearance**—yet throughout the day he acts as though **foolish**. Among the **Confucian disciples**, only **Yan Yuan** (*Yán Yuān*) truly attained this. To **discard** pliancy and **abandon** the body, to **separate** from form and **lose** wisdom, and thus **harmonize** with the **Great Unification** (*Dàtōng*).

**Great brightness** seems like **shame**; the **Dao** revealed appears as though **obscured**. Thus it is said: *‘When clarity is fourfold, can one not be without knowledge?’*

If so, then all **virtues and wondrous actions** are fully **possessed** by me—this is to **assist the Creator** in its **functions**. The **Dao** gives birth to ten thousand things; its **abiding** in me is such.

To **nurture** and **cherish** them—what difficulty is there? To **give birth** and **fulfill** their **nature**, to **cherish** and **exhaust** their **nourishment**, without **partial love** or **selfish gain**, so **giving birth** is not **possessive**. Without **self-praise** or **self-denigration**, so **action** is not **self-reliant**. Without **petty cleverness** or **trickery**, so **long** does he **endure** without **being slain**.

His **benefits and blessings** flow to all ages, yet he does not **claim** them as his own—**merits** cover the **world**, yet he **seems** not to **boast**. Who could **attain** and **name** him?

**Magnificent indeed!** The **Dao** suffices to **benefit things**; **virtue** suffices to **benefit people**; **action** suffices to **benefit oneself**, yet again he does not **possess**, does not **rely** upon himself, nor does he **boast** of his own. This is called **human semblance yet Heavenly**—**Heavenly virtue** is profound, distant, vast, and great.

chunks.original_text: 凝远大师常德路玄妙观 提点观事刘惟永编集 前朝奉大夫太府寺簿兼 枢密院编修丁易东校正 载营魄章 黄茂材曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 营，动也。 魄，阴也。 阴属形，形本不能动，气载之而动。 人能习使气不离其形，是谓抱一。 不言气者，唯此为可以生，无有二也。 专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 能抱一矣，久而自能忘形而专养乎炁，故不言形，凡人所以与物争者，累於形也。 能忘其形，归於婴儿，则无争之之息，故曰致柔。 柔者，生之徒。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 夫至此，并与形气而忘之矣。 洗涤其心，虑尽垢除，等於太空，岂复有疵？ 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 夫学道而至於无为，岂一日之积哉？ 抱一矣，致柔矣，玄览无疵矣，然后可以至於无为。 傥未能是，而强欲至於无为之地，夫是之谓坐驰，去道益远。 国譬则其身也，民譬则其神也，爱民治国，与其身同。 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 天门，门也。 今婴儿脑中开阖不住，修真至此，可以上通天道，故谓之天门。 雌与牝同。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 无知者，无所不知，犹人开眼而视，无所不见。 何尝曰吾有见焉，有见有不见，谓之眼病。 有知有不知，谓之心病。 自抱一，凡六进而后至於无知，是以啮缺问於王倪，四问而四不知，啮缺因跃而大喜，良有以也。 生之畜之至是谓玄德。 经凡两言此矣。 前者所言道也，今之所言德也。 道降而为德，德之妙者复与道合，故谓之玄德。 程泰之曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 一者，总万之名也。 方言喜怒哀乐，欲发而未发，聪明知虑，欲形而未形，管万为一，精粹无离，即由道出一之初也，道一而已。 本道而着诸事，其可名以德者，则固异於道矣。 由所得之德，而分仁义礼智信以名之，则原远而末益分。 向之着进而全者，今遂列敌为五，而五之支裔又有不可胜数者焉。 故老子，薄之，而为之言曰：失道而后德，失德而后仁义礼也。 夫其谓失者，非亡逸之谓也。 去本转远，则命数愈多，益与一戾也。 是以老子之所最贵，有存乎妙徼混同之初。 而伊尹自言其得，则亦属乎德善克协之地也。 稽合初终，率皆准一以为之则也。 列子之论，多岐亡羊也。 曰惟反同归一为无得丧。 庄子曰德总乎道之所，一曰总曰归。 则皆从夫命复也，故此之体道必以抱一为首也。 人之神气为魂，形体为魄，月之质不受日光者，亦命之为魄。 此之营魄，即《易》之游魂而对出者也。 游者能轻扬入出。 而营魂之营，则如营合屯聚，然有所拘制而不能自主其运动矣。 故形神之或升或降，最为一身机要也。 神能载形，则趋向施为惟我所运，若神之不王，反为形体之所屈伸，则衰矣。 今也以神为车，以形体为物，车行而物乘其上，是其神已能载形矣。 人而能此，则意之使形，如车运物，欲东而东，欲西而西，惟所欲之，有听无拒。 以之抱一，殆不难矣。 特不知其於载形而抱一也，能终不舍去以否焉耳。 故乎之乎之者，疑之也。 以疑辞审谂末者，使之循以自省也。 故庄子论卫生之经曰：能抱一乎，能无失乎？ 正此意也。 凡此章皆为望道已见，而守之未坚者言之也。 若抱一而能不离，致柔而能如婴儿，直与道一矣。 若使老子从此地置言，则疑辞当为决辞矣。

**Chapter on Nourishing the Vital Essence**

Master Yinyuan, whose profound virtue traverses the Mysterious Path, oversees the compilation of affairs.
Sifu Liu Weiyong assembles the text.
Formerly honored official Ding Yidong, Director of the Imperial Treasury and Compiler of the Secretariat, verifies the text.

**On Nourishing the Vital Essence:**

Huang Maocai says:
*"Can one who nourishes the vital essence and embraces unity ever separate?"*
**Vital essence**—this is motion.
**Spirit**—this is yin.
Yin belongs to form; form, by nature, cannot move. Yet **qi** bears it and sets it in motion.
When a person cultivates and directs **qi** so it never departs from form, this is called *embracing unity*.
It is not spoken of as **qi** because only this can sustain life—there is no second way.

**Concentrating qi to achieve softness—can one be like an infant?**
Having embraced unity, over time one naturally forgets form and focuses solely on nurturing **qi**, hence form is not mentioned. What ordinary people contend for is the burden of form.
To forget one’s form and return to the state of an infant means no breath of strife remains—thus it is called *achieving softness*.
Softness is the companion of life.

**Purifying and gazing into the Mysterious—can one be without blemish?**
By this stage, both form and **qi** are forgotten.
Washing the heart clean, exhausting all filth, equal to the boundless void—how could there still be blemish?

**Loving the people and governing the state—can one act without doing?**
To study the Dao and reach *wuwei* is not the work of a single day.
Only after embracing unity, achieving softness, and gazing into the Mysterious without blemish can one attain *wuwei*.
If one has not yet reached this and yet forces oneself to *wuwei*, this is called *riding at a gallop*—ever more distant from the Dao.
The state is like the body; the people are like the spirit. Loving the people and governing the state is the same as tending to oneself.

**The Heavenly Gate opening and closing—can one avoid the feminine?**
The Heavenly Gate is the **fontanel**.
Now, the infant’s fontanel opens and closes uncontrollably. When cultivation reaches this stage, one can ascend to communicate with Heavenly Dao—thus it is called the Heavenly Gate.
**Feminine** is the same as **yin**.

**Clarity and openness in all directions—can one avoid knowing?**
To be without knowing is to know all things, like a person opening their eyes to see—nothing is unseen.
How could one say, *"I have perception"*? To have perception and lack perception is called *eye disease*.
To have knowing and not knowing is called *heart disease*.
From embracing unity, six stages progress until one reaches *wuwei*—thus, Kexue questioned Wangni four times, and four times Wangni answered, *"I do not know."* Kexue then leapt for joy—there was good reason.

**To nurture life to this point is called Mysterious Virtue.**
The Classic speaks of this twice.
The first mention refers to the **Dao**; this refers to **virtue**.
The **Dao** descends as **virtue**; the subtlest **virtue** merges once more with the **Dao**—thus it is called *Mysterious Virtue*.

Program Tai said:
*"Can one who nourishes the vital essence and embraces unity ever separate?"*
Unity is the name that encompasses all things.
When joy, anger, sorrow, and delight are about to emerge but have not yet formed,
When wisdom and insight are about to manifest but have not yet taken shape—
All these are unified into One, refined and without separation, returning to the origin where the **Dao** first emerges as One.
The **Dao** is One alone.
To ground the **Dao** in affairs and name what can be called **virtue** is already distinct from the **Dao**.
From the **virtue** one attains, one divides it into *ren, yi, li, zhi, xin* to name it—
The source grows distant, and the branches multiply beyond count.
Earlier, it was spoken of as a unified whole; now it is divided into five, and their offspring are innumerable.
Thus, Laozi thins it out, saying:
*"When the **Dao** is lost, **virtue** arises; when **virtue** is lost, *ren, yi, li* arise."*
When he says *"lost,"* he does not mean *gone*—
Rather, moving away from the root, the commandments multiply, ever more contrary to Unity.
Thus, what Laozi most treasures is the subtle, indistinct, and undifferentiated origin.
Yet Yi Yin, speaking of his attainment, places it in the realm of **virtue**, harmony, and accord.
Examining beginning and end, all conform to Unity as their standard.

Liezi’s theory is like a lost sheep with many paths:
*"Only by returning to Unity and merging can one avoid gain or loss."*
Zhuangzi says, *"**Virtue** is the totality of what the **Dao** encompasses."*
Unity is called *totality*; merging is called *returning*.
Both stem from the restoration of the Mandate—
Thus, cultivating the **Dao** must begin with embracing Unity.

The human spirit and **qi** are called *hun* and *po*.
The moon’s substance, which does not receive sunlight, is also called *po*.
This **vital essence** and **spirit** are the *young hun* and *po* paired in opposition from the *Yijing*.
The *young hun* can ascend and descend lightly, entering and exiting freely.
But the *po*’s **vital essence** is like encampment, gathering, and clustering—
Yet it is bound and constrained, unable to govern its own movement.
Thus, the ascent or descent of spirit and form is the most critical mechanism of the body.
If the spirit governs the form, all actions follow its will—
If the spirit does not reign, it is instead bent by the form, and decay follows.
Now, let the spirit be the chariot, the form the load—
The chariot moves, and the load is borne upon it—
This is the spirit already governing the form.
If a person achieves this, their will directs the form like a chariot moving its load—
Desire east, and it goes east; desire west, and it goes west—
Whatever is willed, there is compliance, no resistance.
To embrace Unity from here is not difficult.
It is only that one does not know whether, in governing the form and embracing Unity, one can persist without abandoning it.

Thus, the hesitant tone—this is doubt.
Using doubtful language to examine the superficial—
It is to make one reflect upon themselves.
Hence, Zhuangzi’s discussion of the *Yashengjing* says:
*"Can one embrace Unity? Can one avoid loss?"*
This is the very meaning.

All this chapter speaks to those who have glimpsed the **Dao** but whose guardianship is not yet firm.
If one embraces Unity and does not separate,
Achieves softness and is like an infant—
Then one is already One with the **Dao**.
If Laozi were to speak from this ground,
The doubtful language would become decisive.

chunks.original_text: 凡此章下文设乎以示疑者，其义皆类此也。 专气致柔，能如婴兄乎？ 列子之形容婴孩也，曰气专致一，和之至也。 物不伤焉，德莫加焉，言其生厚而未迁於物也。 孟子曰：大人者，不失其赤子之心者也。 言其虽已交物而不忘其初也。 合二者而言，故惟常德不离者，为能复归於婴儿也。 人之将有为也，气实奉志而行焉，其於政志如风之畅达寒暑也。 苟惟气不他用，专以致柔，及其致之，而至则和不伤物者复矣。 特不知其能及此否耳。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 玄者，窈深不测之谓也。 玄牝、玄德、玄同、玄览，皆从窈深而形容其地也。 览者，以瞻视言之也，冥冥之中独见晓焉，是其见之窈深者也。 是见也，人皆有之，惟其心源不清，随物而往，则耳目之官且复蔽翳，而何晓之能见也哉？ 南荣趎之问老子曰：目之与形，吾不知其异也，而盲者不能自见。 老子略举性情之本以警之，趎遂有寤，於是退而就舍，召其所好，去其所恶，十日而复见老子。 老子嘉其能自洒濯也。 趎之问者目力也，而老子所告则性情也。 趎能洒濯其性情，则蔽翳自去，得其本矣。 故夫涤除玄览者，非致力於目也。 究其何以致翳，从而洒濯之，则凡其可以见晓者，还复其初矣。 复初而其览玄矣。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 爱民治国必有具以行，其意乃能有成，则凡立政立事皆其具也，既以有具而又戒其作为者，庄子固尝明之矣。 曰：闻在宥天下，未闻治天下也。 其在宥之说，则黜聪明，屏赏罚，顺性命之情而安，安之从容无为，而万物不累焉。 有超乎纪纲法度之上者矣。 此其所谓无为者也。 故夫务因循者则不能，以有为而求治甚力，则常失诸多事。 故此之致戒，犹曰孰能爱民治国，而不至於出意作为也乎？ 夫任理无作，则后章之治大如烹鲜者是也。 是其所以得云无为也。 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 庄子尝指宇宙万物生死有无出入之地，以为天门，则是天之天门也。 又尝论道之不可言传者曰：其心以为不然者，天门不开矣。 则又以人心为天门也。 天之天门既为生化出入之地，故人之天门亦其天机出入之所也。 造物者之翕张阴阳、迭运生化也，是为能制天门之出入者也。 人之涉世能谨存亡於操舍，审当否而迎拒，则一身之天门，亦能制其开阖矣。 存养至此，固已盖天下而出其表，尚能当可而动，不为物先，岂不益善乎？ 明白四达，能无知乎？ 明则无所蔽障，白则不至黯暗。 四达者，无门无旁，四皆通彻也。 所谓远在八荒之外，近在眉睫之间，介然之有唯然之音来干我者，我必知之，是明白而能四达者也。 人之能及乎此也，患在锐於用智。 无事则太察，遇事则太凿也。 若有得乎道，则不然矣。 未尝有见也，而见因物生。 着龟之智，水镜之明，皆其则也。 苟其持养未及乎此，则聪明睿智而愚以守之，或能不暴其有也乎？ 生之畜之。 本无而创有，故得云生。 如道生一，一生二者是也。 因其已生而坚凝之，则为畜。 如以畜其德者是也。 几此章所指，自抱一致柔已下，皆其执德而求复乎道者也。 一柔元达之求，以德言也，无离无疵之是冀，则求复乎道也。 载专涤除之类，所以致其德也。 能致则能生矣，一柔元达於我乎，居则其能畜者也。
chunks.translated_text:
「凡此章下文设疑以示者，其义皆类此也。
To embrace Unity and achieve softness—can one persist like a newborn babe? The *Liezi* describes the infant thus: *"Qi is focused and harmonized to its utmost."*
Nothing harms it, no virtue can surpass it—this speaks of its innate thickness, untainted by external things.
Mencius says: *"The noble person is one who does not lose the heart of their infant self."*
This means though they engage with the world, they do not forget their original nature.

Combining both, only those whose virtue remains unseparated can truly return to the state of the infant.
When one is about to act, their *qi* carries out their intentions as if wind conveys the chill and heat of seasons.
If one’s *qi* is not diverted elsewhere, and they focus solely on achieving softness,
Then when this softness is attained, the harmonized state that harms nothing returns once more.
It is only that one does not know whether they can reach this state.

To purify and perceive the profound—can one remain without flaw?
The profound is that which is deep and unfathomable.
*Xuànpín* (玄牝), *Xuàndé* (玄德), *Xuàntóng* (玄同), and *Xuànguān* (玄览) all describe this unfathomable realm.
To perceive the profound is to gaze within the dark and see the luminous.
This kind of perception, all have it—yet if the heart’s source is unclean,
And one’s mind wanders with external things,
Then the senses are obscured, and how can the luminous be seen?

Nánróng Zī asked Laozi: *"What is the difference between the eye and its form?
Yet the blind cannot see themselves."*
Laozi briefly illuminated the nature of innate disposition and emotions to awaken him,
And Zī thus retreated to his dwelling, called forth what he loved,
And banished what he hated—
After ten days, he returned to see Laozi.
Laozi praised his ability to purify himself.

Zī’s question concerned vision, yet what Laozi taught was about innate disposition and emotions.
If Zī could purify his disposition and emotions,
Then the obscurations would vanish on their own, and he would recover his original nature.
Thus, to purify and perceive the profound is not to exert oneself upon the eyes.
To investigate why obscurations arise and then purify them,
Then all that can be seen and known will return to its original state.
Returning to the original, one’s perception of the profound will be restored.

To love the people and govern the state—can one act without doing?
Loving the people and governing the state must involve means to execute,
And only then can intentions bear fruit—
Yet all establishing laws and affairs are but these means.
If one has means yet still warns against deliberate action,
Zhuangzi has already made this clear.
He said: *"I have heard of nurturing the world, but never of governing it."*
In the way of nurturing, one discards cleverness,
Sets aside rewards and punishments,
Follows the natural flow of life and disposition,
And finds ease in effortless harmony—
Thus, all things are not burdened.

There is one who transcends the rules and measures of law and order.
This is what is called *wuwei* (无为).

Thus, those who strive to follow the established ways cannot,
And those who seek governance through deliberate action often fail in many matters.
Hence, the warning here is like asking: *"Who can love the people and govern the state
Without resorting to contrived schemes and actions?"*
To act in accordance with nature, without deliberate intervention,
Is the very essence of the next chapter’s governance—
As vast as simmering fresh meat.

The opening and closing of the Heavenly Gate—can one avoid bias?
Zhuangzi once pointed to the realm of birth and death, existence and nonexistence,
As the Heavenly Gate—
This is the Heavenly Gate of Heaven.
He also discussed the Dao that cannot be spoken or transmitted:
*"If one’s heart rejects it, the Heavenly Gate will not open."*
This also speaks of the human heart as the Heavenly Gate.

Since the Heavenly Gate of Heaven is the realm of birth and transformation,
Then the human Heavenly Gate is also the passage of their innate vitality.
The Creator’s contraction and expansion of yin and yang,
Their successive nurturing of birth and transformation,
Is the ability to regulate the opening and closing of the Heavenly Gate.
If one’s engagement with the world is cautious,
Preserving life and death through moderation,
Judging what is appropriate and welcoming or rejecting accordingly,
Then the Heavenly Gate of one’s self
Can also regulate its opening and closing.

Cultivating to this degree is already to surpass the world and reveal its essence—
Yet to act only when appropriate, never leading the way of things,
Is not this even more excellent?

Clarity and openness in all directions—can one avoid knowing?
Clarity means no obstruction, whiteness means no darkness.
To be open in all directions is to have no closed doors or blind spots—
All four ways are thoroughly illuminated.
The distant lies beyond the eight extremes,
The near is within the space between one’s eyebrows—
If there is a distinct sound that comes to disturb me,
I must know it—
This is the clarity and openness that reaches in all directions.

When one attains this state, the danger lies in being too sharp in applying wisdom.
Without affairs, one becomes overly observant;
Encountering affairs, one becomes too probing.
Yet if one has attained the Dao, this is not so.
They have never deliberately sought to see—
Yet seeing arises from the things themselves.
The wisdom of divining from tortoise shells,
The clarity of the water mirror,
Are all its manifestations.

If one’s cultivation has not yet reached this state,
Then even with keen intelligence and sharp insight,
They may guard it with foolishness—
Could one not expose their own nature?

To nurture and accumulate life.
Originally, there is nothing—yet through creation, something arises—
Thus, it can be called *shēng* (生).
Like the Dao giving rise to Unity, and Unity to Duality.
To take what has already been born and solidify it,
Is to *chù* (畜) it.
As when one cultivates their virtue.

Nearly all the teachings in this chapter,
From embracing Unity and achieving softness onward,
Are about holding fast to virtue and seeking to return to the Dao.
The pursuit of Unity, softness, and elemental clarity is through virtue—
To hope for no separation and no flaw is to seek return to the Dao.
The methods of focusing *qi* and purifying obscurations,
Are all ways to attain virtue.
If one attains virtue, one can nurture life—
Unity, softness, and elemental clarity—
Do they come to me?
If they dwell, then I am the one who can accumulate them.»

chunks.original_text: 孝悌之生仁，可欲之生信也，皆其所谓生也。 仁既生矣，而有以乐之，使不去善。 既信矣，有以充之，而至实则生，而又畜之谓也。 生而不有，本无也，而我为生之，顾不肯搅为己有，此体道者之高致也。 前之生畜以成德也，此之不有者，有而若无，实而若虚，不居其成者也。 为而不恃。 庄子所谓当而不自得，故不恃也。 长而不宰。 高出其上而默运之，不明施其宰制之方也。 若真付之不宰，则孰斡其柄？ 是谓玄德。 前之八乎而八疑者，虑其未能有及也。 苟皆确乎能之，则其德备矣。 备此八德，而又将之以不有不恃不宰，则其为德窈然幽深矣，故揆诸众德，而此独为玄也。 德者道之着乎事者也，非与道异也。 谓失道而后德者，恶其迹之着耳，若上德不德，则其进藏而深矣。 故凡言玄德者，其名固不离德，而其深与道等矣。 庄子设为孙扁问答曰：至人忘其肝胆，遗其耳目，芒然彷徉乎尘俗之外，逍遥乎无事之业。 是谓为而不恃，长而不宰。 今汝饰智以惊愚，修身以明污，昭昭乎若揭日月而行，何暇乎天之怨哉。 於是从其揭日月者，对观而反求之，则玄德之地可想矣。 论后章之言道生德畜也，又极诸不有不恃不宰者，正此章之复出而详尽者也。 而有异焉，此章道德之在人者也，后章则夫人交具也。 於是老氏之言有及乎天地圣人者，或时不加别异，槩而言之，以示天人无二致也。 此又其一书之通例也。 不可谓言天则专於天，言人则专於人也。 朱紫阳曰：屈子载营魄之言，本於老氏。 而杨雄又因其语以明月之盈缺，其所指之事虽殊，而其立文之意则一。 顾为三书之解者，皆不能通其说。 故今合而论之，庶乎其足以相明也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Ren arises from filial piety and fraternal respect,
Trust arises from what is desirable—
Both are what is called *shēng* (生).

Ren has already arisen,
Yet there is a way to delight in it,
So that it does not abandon virtue.
Trust has already been established,
Yet there is a way to fulfill it,
And when it reaches reality, it is *shēng* (生),
And then to *chù* (畜) it—
That is what is meant.

To *shēng* (生) without possession,
Is the original *wú* (無).
Yet I am the one who brings forth *shēng* (生),
And yet I do not stir to claim it as my own—
This is the lofty aspiration of those who embody the Dao.

What was spoken of before as *shēng* (生) and *chù* (畜) to attain virtue,
Is now spoken of as *bù-yǒu* (不有)—
To possess yet appear as though not possessing,
To be real yet appear as though empty,
To not dwell upon what has been attained.

To act yet not rely upon it.
As Zhuangzi said: *"When one is in harmony yet does not claim self-possession, one does not rely upon it."*

To grow yet not dominate.
To rise above and yet silently guide,
To not reveal the means of one's governance.
If one truly entrusts without dominating,
Then who shall wield its reins?
This is called *Xuán Dé* (玄德).

What was spoken of before as the eight *shēng* (生) and eight *yí* (疑),
Was because they feared one could not yet *bù-yǒu* (不有).
If one could firmly grasp all eight,
Then one’s virtue would be complete.

To complete these eight virtues,
And yet further them with *bù-yǒu* (不有), *bù-shì* (不恃), and *bù-zǎi* (不宰),
Then one’s virtue becomes profound and unfathomable—
Thus, when comparing it to all virtues,
This alone is called *Xuán* (玄).

Virtue is the Dao manifested in affairs,
Not separate from the Dao itself.
To say one loses the Dao and then attains virtue,
Is to dislike the traces of its manifestation—
If the highest virtue is not virtue,
Then its advancement is hidden and deep.

Thus, whenever one speaks of *Xuán Dé* (玄德),
Its name does not stray from *Dé* (德),
Yet its depth equals that of the Dao itself.
Zhuangzi posed the question to Sun Xian and Bian Que:
*"The Perfect One forgets their liver and gallbladder,
Discards their ears and eyes,
Lost in the world yet drifting beyond dust and filth,
Free in the realm of no affairs—
This is called acting yet not relying upon it,
Growing yet not dominating.*

Now you adorn your wisdom to astonish the simple,
Refine your conduct to expose the impure,
Shining brightly like one displaying the sun and moon—
How shall you avoid the resentment of Heaven?

If one follows your way of displaying the sun and moon,
And instead reflects inward to seek its source,
Then the realm of *Xuán Dé* (玄德) may be glimpsed.

In discussing the later chapter’s words—
That the Dao *shēng* (生) and virtue *chù* (畜)—
And further elaborating on *bù-yǒu* (不有), *bù-shì* (不恃), and *bù-zǎi* (不宰),
This is the repeated and detailed exposition of this chapter.

Yet there are differences—
This chapter speaks of virtue and Dao within the person,
While the later chapter speaks of their mutual possession by humanity.

Thus, when Laozi’s words encompass Heaven, Earth, and the Sage,
Sometimes he does not distinguish them,
Speaking broadly to show that Heaven and humanity share no different aim—
This is the general pattern of his book.

One cannot say that when speaking of Heaven, he speaks only of Heaven,
Or that when speaking of humanity, he speaks only of humanity.

Jú Zǐyáng said:
*"Qu Yǔ’s words about the spirit and the corporeal form
Originate from Laozi’s teachings.
And Yáng Xióng further expounded upon his words,
Illustrating the waxing and waning of the moon—
Though the matters they describe differ,
The intent behind their compositions is the same.*

Yet those who interpret these three texts
Cannot harmonize their meanings.
Thus, I now combine them to discuss,
Hoping that this may suffice to clarify them."*

chunks.original_text: 盖以车承人谓之载，古今世俗之通言也。 以人登车亦谓之载，则古文史类多有之。 如《汉纪》云刘章从谒者与载，《韩集》云妇人以孺子载。 盖皆此意。 而今三子之言，其字义亦如此也。 但老子，屈子以人之精神言之，则其所谓营者，字与荧同，而为晶明光炯之意。 其所谓魄则亦若余之所论於《九歌》者耳。 杨子以日月之光明论之，则固以月之体质为魄，而日之光耀为魂也。 以人之精神言者，其意盖以魂阳动而魄阴静，魂火二而魄水一。 故曰载营魄抱一，能无离乎，言以魂加魄，以动守静，以火迫水，以二守一，而不相离。 如人登车而载，载於其上则魂安静而魄精明，火不燥而水不溢，固长生久视之要诀也。 屈子之言虽不致详，然以其所谓无滑而魂，虚以待之之语推之，则其意当亦出此无疑矣。 其以日月言者，则谓日以其光加於月魄，而为之明，如人登车而载於其上也。 故曰月未望，则载魄于西； 既望，则终魂于东。 其遡於日乎，言月之方生，则以日之光加被於魄之西，而渐满其东，以至於望而后园。 及既望矣，则以日之光终守其魄之东，而渐亏其西，以至於晦而后尽。 盖月遡日以为明，未望则日在其右，既望则日在其左。 故各向其所在而受光，如民向君之化而成俗也。 三子之言虽为两事，而所言载魄，则其文义同为一说。 故丹经历术皆有纳甲之法。 互相资取，以相发明，盖其理初不异也。 但为之说者，不能深考。
chunks.translated_text:
The essence lies in the term *zài* (載), which carries the meaning of "bearing" or "supporting" by vehicle—this is the common usage of antiquity and the present world.

When it comes to a person ascending a carriage and being borne, the ancient texts and histories frequently employ this same term.
For instance, the *Hàn Jì* (漢紀) says, *"Liú Zhāng followed the envoy and was borne"* (劉章從謁者與載),
and the *Hán Jì* (韓集) says, *"Women carried the young child"* (婦人以孺子載).
These are all of the same intent.

Yet in the words of these three masters today,
the meaning of the character *zài* is likewise so.

But **Lǎozǐ** and **Qū Zǐ** speak of the human spirit,
and thus their term *yíng* (營) shares the same character as *yíng* (荧), meaning
the luminous brilliance of a crystal’s clarity.
Their term *pò* (魄) is much like what I have expounded upon in my discussion of the *Jiǔ Gē* (九歌)—
the spirit’s essence.

**Yáng Zǐ** (杨子) speaks of the luminosity of the sun and moon,
and thus takes the moon’s substance as *pò* (魄),
while the sun’s radiance is *hún* (魂).

When speaking of the human spirit,
their intent is that the *hún* (魂) is the active yang fire,
while the *pò* (魄) is the tranquil yin water,
the *hún* being twofold and the *pò* singular.
Hence, they say, *"Bearing the yíng (營) and embracing the pò (魄),*
*how could it depart?"*
They mean that the *hún* (魂) reinforces the *pò* (魄),
the active sustains the tranquil,
the fire presses the water,
the two guard the one—
and thus they do not separate.

When a person ascends a carriage and is borne,
being carried above, the *hún* (魂) is tranquil while the *pò* (魄) is clear,
the fire does not wither, nor the water overflow—
this is indeed the vital principle for longevity and enduring vision.

Though **Qū Zǐ**’s words are not fully detailed,
from his phrases *"without slipping, the hún (魂) is steadfast;
empty, to await it,"*
one may infer that his meaning aligns with this explanation beyond doubt.

When speaking of the sun and moon,
they say that the sun’s light bears upon the moon’s *pò* (魄),
illuminating it—
just as a person ascending a carriage is borne above.

Thus, *"Before the full moon, the moon is borne in the west"* (月未望，則載魄於西);
*"After the full moon, the hún (魂) remains in the east"* (既望，則終魂於東).

When tracing to the sun,
they say that as the moon waxes,
the sun’s light bears upon the *pò* (魄) in the west,
gradually filling the east,
until it reaches the full moon and then returns to its original state.

And when the moon wanes,
the sun’s light remains to guard the *pò* (魄) in the east,
gradually diminishing the west,
until it reaches the dark moon and then fully departs.

The moon thus follows the sun for its illumination—
before the full moon, the sun is on its right;
after the full moon, the sun is on its left.
Hence, it receives light from its respective position,
as the people turn toward the ruler’s transformation to form customs.

Though these three masters speak of two distinct matters,
their discussion of *zài pò* (載魄) shares the same meaning in their texts.
Thus, alchemical scriptures and Daoist practices all employ the *nà jiǎ* (納甲) method—
mutually supplementing each other to elucidate their principles,
for their fundamental logic is not truly divergent.

But those who expound upon them
fail to delve deeply into their meaning.

Hoping that this may suffice to clarify them."*

chunks.original_text: 如河上公之言老子以营为魂，则固非字义，而又并言人载魂魄之上以得生，当爱养之，则又失其文意。 独其载字之义粗为得之。 然不足以补其所失之多也。 若王辅嗣以载为处，以营魄为人所常居之处，则亦河上之意。 至於近世，而苏子由、王元泽之说出焉。 则此二人者平生之论，如水火之不同，而於此义皆以魂为神，以魄为物，而欲使神常载魄以行，不欲使神为魄之所载。 洪庆善之於此书，亦谓阳气充魄为魂魄，能运动则其生全矣。 则其意亦若苏、王之云，而皆以载为以车承人之义矣。 是不唯非其文意，且若如此，则是将使神常劳动，而魄亦不得以少息。 虽幸免於物欲沉溺之累，而窈冥之中精一之妙，反为强阳所挟，以驰骛於纷华胶扰之涂，卒以陷於众人伤生损寿之域，不自知也。 其於二子之意何如哉？ 若其说杨子者，则皆以载为哉，固失其指，而李轨解魂为光尤为乖谬，至来贯之、司马公始觉其非，然遂欲政魄为胐，则亦未深考此载字之义，而失之愈远矣。 唯近岁王伯照以为未望则魂，为明所载，似得其理。 既而又曰既望则明，为魄所终，则是下句当曰终明，而不当为终魄矣。 以此推之，恐其於上句文义之乡背，亦未免如苏氏王氏之云，为自下而载上也。 大抵后人读前人之书，不能沈潜，反覆求其本义，而辄以己意轻为之说，故其卤莽有如此者。 况读《楚辞》者徒玩意於浮华，宜其於此尤不暇深究其底蕴。 故余因为辩之，以为览者能因是而考焉。 则或沂流求源之一助也。
chunks.translated_text:
To speak as the Master of the Yellow River did,
when he said that Laozi took *yíng* (营) as *hún* (魂),
this is not the literal meaning of the characters,
yet he further claimed that people ride upon *hún* and *pò* (魄)
to obtain life, and should cherish and nourish them—
then he has lost the true intent of the text.
Only when considering the meaning of *zài* (载)
as roughly "to carry" does he come somewhat close.
Yet this still fails to remedy the many deficiencies in his interpretation.

If Wang Fu-si took *zài* (载) to mean "to dwell,"
and said that *yíng* (营) and *pò* (魄)
are the places where people commonly reside,
then this also aligns with the Master of the Yellow River’s view.
But in recent times, the teachings of Su Shi and Wang Yuanze emerged,
whose lifelong theories differed like water and fire,
yet both held that *hún* (魂) is the spiritual essence,
while *pò* (魄) is mere physical substance,
and sought to make the spiritual essence perpetually ride upon *pò* (魄) to act—
not to let the spiritual essence be borne by *pò* (魄).
Hong Qing-shan, in his commentary on this text,
also said that when *yángqì* (阳气) fills *pò* (魄),
it becomes *húnpò* (魂魄), and if it can move,
then life is complete.
His intent is also like that of Su and Wang,
all taking *zài* (载) to mean "to bear as a carriage carries a person."
This not only contradicts the original meaning,
but if taken thus, it would force the spiritual essence to labor constantly,
while *pò* (魄) never gains respite.
Though it may avoid the burden of material desire’s entanglement,
the profound mystery of the spiritual essence’s unity
is instead seized by overbearing *yáng* (阳),
and driven to race through the chaotic, tumultuous path of worldly distractions—
ultimately falling into the realm of common injury to life and loss of vitality,
without even knowing it.
How does this compare to the views of the two masters?

If one speaks of Yangzi’s interpretation,
then all take *zài* (载) to mean "to dwell,"
which already strays from its true indication.
Li Gu’s explanation of *hún* (魂) as *guāng* (光) is even more absurd,
until Lai Guan and Sima Gong realized its error.
Yet then they sought to correct *pò* (魄) as *bì* (胐),
which also failed to deeply examine the meaning of *zài* (载),
and thus erred even further.

Only in recent years did Wang Bo-zhao suggest
that before the full moon, *hún* (魂) is borne by *míng* (明),
seeming to grasp its meaning.
Then he further said that after the full moon,
*míng* (明) is borne to its end by *pò* (魄),
but this should read "to its end" for *míng* (明),
not "to bear *pò* (魄) to its end."
By this reasoning, it seems he also reverses the original meaning of the first clause,
falling into the same mistake as Su and Wang—
to bear from below upward.
In essence, later readers of the ancients’ texts,
unable to delve deeply,
repeatedly seek their original meaning,
yet hastily impose their own interpretations,
leading to such reckless explanations.
Worse yet, those who read *Chu Ci* (楚辞) merely indulge in its superficial brilliance,
least of all probing its profound depths.
Therefore, I have set forth this clarification,
hoping that those who peruse it may reflect upon it.
This may serve as a small aid in tracing the currents back to their sources.

Though these three masters speak of two distinct matters,
their discussion of *zài pò* (載魄) shares the same meaning in their texts.
Thus, alchemical scriptures and Daoist practices all employ the *nà jiǎ* (納甲) method—
