chunks.original_text: 詹秋圃曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 《能为章》谓人能有取於无知无雌，乃能终始相忘於无事也。 广推爱惠以安民治国者，吾能使之不知其所自来。 天，玄也。 雌，牝也。 天门开阖，而能使之不为雌牝随声以相应和。 此心已各明白四达，而能使之泯其知识，终始相安。 是能无为而无不能为矣。 张冲应曰：载营魄抱一至是谓玄德。 魂属於肝，魄属於肺，魂以天之炁而为魂，魄以地之精而为魄。 人有此身包载其魂以营守其魄也，有能抱天地纯一之精炁，交感相生，不相乖离，则专气政柔而精化为炁，阴消阳长而魄宁魂清，寂然其中，神如婴孩，尘垢除涤，无所揉杂，耳聪目明，所览玄矣。 安有疵病其身哉？ 推而用之，以之治国，则属我之精，生民之炁，而爱民治国自有不可知之妙。 反而行之，天门开辟则百窍不塞，而雌魄化为雄炁，雌魄不可得而乱。 地户潜通则不言而化行，明白四达而道满天下，人有不可得而知。 故曰生之畜之，谓之真炁既生，则加畜养之。 又曰生而不有，谓炁生矣，不可有亏耗之失。 又曰为而不恃，谓精化为炁，不可恃其已化而起雕害之心。 又曰长而不宰，谓之生而必养之，养之而又加爱护之，毋容宰割其炁，以害其生。 则其玄，我得之矣，是谓玄德。 张灵应曰：人有此身，得天之一而有此元炁，得地之一而有此元精。 子时而一阳初动，午时而一阴初生，把握得此，精不失炁不损，这我神如何得而不宁也？ 藏精养无，工夫只在子午一升一降时，抱负得稳，却从渐而入，自然日积成功。 白玉蟾曰：载营魄。 安心抱一。 能无离乎。
chunks.translated_text:
Zhān Qiūpǔ said:
To bear and nurture *pò* (魄) until this point is called *xuán dé* (玄德, "Mysterious Virtue").
In *"The Chapter of Ability"* (《能为章》), it is said that when a person can take from the state of *wúzhī* (無知, "no-knowing") and *wúcī* (無雌, "no-femaleness"),
they can then forget their beginning and end in the state of *wúshì* (無事, "no-affairs").
Those who broadly extend love and benevolence to settle the people and govern the state—
I can make them unaware of where these virtues originate.

Heaven is *xuán* (玄, "Mysterious").
Femaleness is *pǐn* (牝, "vulva").
When the *tiānmén* (天門, "Heavenly Gate") opens and closes,
it can prevent *pò* (魄) from responding like a female to sounds and harmonizing in disorder.
Once this mind is already clear and open in all directions,
it can extinguish all knowledge,
and remain at peace from beginning to end.
Thus, one can do without doing and yet be able to do all things.

Zhang Chōngyìng said:
To bear and nurture *pò* (魄) while embracing *yī* (一, "Oneness") until this point is called *xuán dé* (玄德, "Mysterious Virtue").
The *hún* (魂, "ethereal soul") belongs to the liver,
while *pò* (魄, "corporeal soul") belongs to the lungs.
The *hún* is formed from Heaven’s *qì* (炁),
while the *pò* is formed from Earth’s essence.
A person’s body contains and nurtures their *hún* while guarding their *pò*;
if one can embrace the pure and unified essence-*qì* of Heaven and Earth,
interacting harmoniously without contradiction,
then by refining *qì* and softening essence,
the essence transforms into *qì*,
as *yīn* (陰) wanes and *yáng* (陽) flourishes—
the *pò* becomes tranquil, the *hún* becomes clear.
Within, it is serene as a newborn babe;
all filth is cleansed, nothing is mixed.
Ears are sharp, eyes are bright—
what one perceives is profound.
How could there be any flaw or illness in the body?

Extending this principle to governance,
if one aligns with the essence of *wǒ* (我, "self")
and cultivates the *qì* of the people,
then loving the people and governing the state will naturally possess an ineffable efficacy.

Conversely, if practiced in reverse:
when the *tiānmén* (天門, "Heavenly Gate") opens,
all orifices remain unobstructed,
and *cīpò* (雌魄, "feminine *pò*") transforms into *xióngqì* (雄炁, "masculine *qì*"),
so that *cīpò* cannot bring chaos.
When the *dìhù* (地户, "Earthly Portal") opens subtly,
transformation occurs without words,
and clarity spreads universally—
people become unknowable.
Thus it is said:
*"To generate and nurture"*—
once true *qì* (真炁) is generated,
it must then be further nurtured.
*"To generate but not possess"*—
once *qì* is generated,
it must not be depleted or wasted.
*"To act but not rely"*—
once essence transforms into *qì*,
one must not arrogantly harm it.
*"To lengthen but not dominate"*—
it must be generated and then nourished,
and then further protected—
do not slaughter the *qì* and harm its growth.
Thus, its mystery—I have attained it—
this is called *xuán dé* (玄德, "Mysterious Virtue").

Zhang Língyìng said:
A person’s body contains
Heaven’s *yī* (一, "One"), giving rise to *yuánqì* (元炁, "Original *qì*"),
and Earth’s *yī* (一, "One"), giving rise to *yuánjīng* (元精, "Original Essence").
At the *zǐ* hour (子, midnight), *yī yáng* (一陽, "One Yang") first stirs,
and at the *wǔ* hour (午, noon), *yī yīn* (一陰, "One Yin") first emerges.
If one grasps this,
essence will not be lost, *qì* will not be diminished—
how could the spirit not be at peace?
To store essence and nurture *wú* (無, "Non-being"),
the practice lies in the gradual ascent and descent of the *zǐ* and *wǔ* hours,
holding steady while embracing it—
entering gradually, naturally accumulating success day by day.

Bái Yùxiān said:
To bear and nurture *pò* (魄).
To settle the heart and embrace *yī* (一, "Oneness").
To be able to remain undivided.

chunks.original_text: 甚处去来。 专气致柔。 纯清绝点。 能如婴儿乎。 混然一片。 涤除玄览。 无心於事，无事於心。 能无疵乎。 身心如一。 爱民治国。 怡神养气。 能无知乎。 无念无为，无思无虑。 天门开阖。 心地开明。 能无疵乎。 一而不二。 明白四达。 一理烛物，冰融月皎。 能无知乎。 终日如愚。 生之畜之。 一心所存，包含万象，生而不有。 心同太虚。 为而不恃。 智周万物。 长而不宰。 泰然无我。 是谓玄德。 廖粹然曰：载营魄。 既知其子，复守其母。 抱一。 静心。 能无离乎。 道不可须臾离。 专气致柔。 用志不分，乃凝於神。 能如婴儿乎。 返归童蒙，无欲无为。 涤除玄览。 不见不闻，内外清虚。 能无疵乎。 故无病患。 爱民治国。 人主以道爱天下，吾亦爱神而守神。 能无为乎。 故不妄作。 天门开阖。 顶门擘破，阳神出入。 能无雌乎。 阴鬼自消，决无魔障。 明白四达。 神光烜赫，流盻八方。 能无知乎。 自然而然，不得而知。 生之畜之。 道自生我，德亦成我。 生而不有。 返本归根，忘形忘我。 为而不恃。 施恩於我，不望我报。 长而不宰。 长我成我，故无害我。 是谓玄德。 所谓有道德自成矣。 陈碧虚曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 道家以阳神曰魂，魂乐其生。 阴鬼曰魄，魄好其杀。 魂则游，魄则静。 《白虎通》曰：魂者，云云也。 营者，营营不定貌。 故谓魂为营也。 旧说曰：载，乘也。 营，魂也。 又谓营护阳气也。 夫魂为阳精，魄为阴灵，阳精喜动逝，故仙书有拘留之术。 阴灵喜浮惑，故仙书有制伏之法。 使其形体常乘载阳精阴灵，抱守太和纯一之气，令无散离，永保长年矣。 夫道之抱一，如鉴之含明，明岂离鉴乎？ 此教人养神也。 今解曰：能无离乎者，老氏审问之辞也。 犹如说戒曰能持否之例是也。 夫人欲要抱一之术，当能心无散离乎。 若无散离者，即是乘载魂魄，抱守纯一之道也。 能如婴儿乎？ 下皆以此义释之。 专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 旧说曰：专，一也，任也； 气者，冲和妙气也，又自然之气也。 夫人卓然独化，禀自然冲和妙气，气降形生，自无染杂。 若乃专任冲妙，知见都忘，使气自纯和，形自柔弱，不为众恶所害，是得婴儿之全和也。 此教人养气也。 今解曰：能如婴兄乎者，言人欲专气致柔之术，当能如婴儿纯和乎，若能如婴儿之纯和，即是得专气致柔之术也。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 旧说曰：涤，洗也。 除，遣也，理也。 渊览，心照也。 疵，瑕病也。 夫人当洗涤尘垢，除遣五情，内外清虚，心照万事，瑕疵之病莹然不生。 此教人修心也。 自此上三事，约人修身。 自此下三事，劝人治国也。 经曰修之身，其德乃真。 修之天下，其德乃溥也。 今解曰：能无疵乎者，言人欲要洗心除垢，冥察内外之事，当能自省己躬，无有疵瑕之病乎。 若能无疵瑕之病，即是涤除玄览之法也。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 旧说曰：爱民者当爱民如赤子，临政不可苛虐，赋役不可伤性，治国者当务农简事，使民各遂其业而安其生，斯无为之化也。 今解曰：能无为乎者，言人君欲爱养万民，令不伤天性，治国务农，使无繁细，当能清静无为乎。 若能清静无为，即是爱民治国之术也。 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 天门者，自然之门也。 自然生太极，太极生天地，天地生阴阳，阴阳生万物、死万物，生死由之而往来，故谓之天门。
chunks.translated_text:
「Where does one depart and where does one return?
To focus the *qi* and attain softness.
To purify the clear and eliminate all impurities.
Can one be like an infant?
Mixed and undivided as one whole.
To wash away and transcend the subtle and profound.
To have no mind in affairs, no affairs in the mind.
Can one be without flaw?

Body and mind as one.
To love the people and govern the realm.
To delight the spirit and nourish the *qi*.
Can one be without knowledge?

To have no thought, no action,
no consideration, no worry.
The *Tiānmén* (天門, "Heavenly Gate") opens and closes,
The heart’s foundation becomes bright and clear.
Can one be without flaw?

One without division,
Illuminating all with clarity.
Like ice melting beneath the moon’s brilliance.
Can one be without knowledge?

All day as a fool—
Life nurtures and accumulates within me.
One mind’s dwelling, containing all phenomena,
Life gives yet does not possess.
The heart aligns with the *Tàixū* (太虚, "Great Emptiness").
Act yet do not claim credit.
Wisdom encompasses all things.
Lengthen yet do not cut short.
Calm and unselfed, this is called *Xuándé* (玄德, "Mysterious Virtue").

Lǎo Cùirán said:
To bear and nurture *pò* (魄, "Ethereal Soul").
Now knowing its *zǐ* (子, "child"), again guarding its *mǔ* (母, "mother").
To embrace *yī* (一, "Oneness") and quiet the mind.
Can one remain undivided?

The Dao/Way cannot be separated for even a moment.
To focus the *qi* and attain softness.
To direct one’s intent without division—
thus, the spirit is concentrated.
Can one be like an infant?

Return to childlike simplicity,
Desireless and actionless.
To wash away and transcend the subtle and profound.
Neither seeing nor hearing,
Inner and outer emptiness and clarity.
Can one be without flaw?

Thus, no sickness or affliction.
To love the people and govern the realm—
A ruler governs the world with the Dao/Way,
I too love the spirit and guard the spirit.
Can one be without action?

Thus, no reckless deeds.
The *Tiānmén* (天門, "Heavenly Gate") opens and closes—
The crown of the head splits apart,
The Yang spirit enters and departs.
Can one be without duality?

The *Yīnguǐ* (陰鬼, "Yin Ghost") dissipates,
No demonic hindrance remains.
Illuminating all with clarity—
The divine light radiates resplendent,
Flowing in all eight directions.
Can one be without knowledge?

Naturally and effortlessly,
Beyond what can be known.
Life nurtures and accumulates within me—
The Dao/Way of itself generates me,
*Virtue/Power* (德) also completes me.
Life gives yet does not possess—
Returning to the root, forgetting form and self.
Act yet do not claim credit—
Enlightenment bestows upon me,
Yet expects no recompense in return.
Lengthen yet do not cut short—
It lengthens and completes me,
Thus no harm comes to me.
This is called *Xuándé* (玄德, "Mysterious Virtue").
So it is said: "With virtue, one's Dao/Way is naturally fulfilled."

Chén Bìxū said:
To bear and nurture *pò* (魄) while embracing *yī* (一, "Oneness"),
Can one remain undivided?

The Daoists say the Yang spirit is called *hún* (魂, "Corporeal Soul"),
And the *hún* delights in life.
The *Yīnguǐ* (陰鬼, "Yin Ghost") is called *pò* (魄),
And the *pò* prefers death.
The *hún* wanders, the *pò* remains still.
*The Bái Hǔ Tóng* (白虎通, "White Tiger Discourses") says:
*The hún* is like clouds—
*Yíng* (營, "Ethereal Soul") is the restless, unsettled form.
Thus, the *hún* is called *yíng*.
The old sayings state:
"To bear" means "to ride," and *yíng* is the *hún*.
It is also said that *yíng* protects the Yang *qi*.
Now, the *hún* is the Yang Essence,
The *pò* is the Yin Spirit.
The Yang Essence thrives on movement and dissipation,
Thus Daoist texts have methods to restrain and retain it.
The Yin Spirit is prone to confusion and disturbance,
Thus Daoist texts have laws to subdue and control it.
If one’s form constantly rides the Yang Essence and Yin Spirit,
Embracing and guarding the pure, harmonious *Tàihé* (太和, "Great Harmony") *qi*,
So that it does not scatter or separate,
Then one will forever preserve longevity.

The Daoist practice of embracing *yī* (一, "Oneness")
Is like a mirror containing clarity—
Clarity does not separate from the mirror.
This teaching is about nurturing the spirit.
Now I explain:
"Can one remain undivided?" is the Master Lao’s questioning tone,
Like asking, "Can one uphold the precepts?"
Now, if one wishes to practice the art of embracing *yī*,
One must be able to keep the mind undivided.
If one can keep the mind undivided,
Then one is riding the *hún* and *pò*,
Embracing the pure, harmonious Dao/Way.

Can one be like an infant?
All the following points are explained with this meaning.

To focus the *qi* and attain softness—
Can one be like an infant?
The old sayings state:
"To focus" means "to be one" and "to entrust."
*Qi* is the *Chōnghé miàoqì* (沖和妙氣, "Unifying and Harmonious Marvelous *Qi*"),
Also the natural *qi*.
A person stands alone, transformed by nature,
Receiving the natural, unifying, harmonious marvelous *qi*.
As the *qi* descends and the form is born,
It remains untainted and pure.
If one entrusts to the unifying marvelous *qi*,
Forgets all knowledge and perception,
Allows the *qi* to naturally purify and harmonize,
And the form to naturally soften and weaken—
Unharmed by all evil,
This is attaining the complete harmony of an infant.
This teaching is about nurturing the *qi*.

Now I explain:
"Can one be like an infant?" means,
When one desires to focus the *qi* and attain softness,
Can one be like an infant in pure harmony?
If one can be like an infant in pure harmony,
Then one has attained the art of focusing the *qi* and attaining softness.

To wash away and transcend the subtle and profound—
Can one be without flaw?
The old sayings state:
"To wash away" means "to cleanse."
"To transcend" means "to dispel" and "to regulate."
*Xuánlǎn* (玄覽, "Subtle Perception") is the illumination of the mind.
*Cī* (疵, "flaw") refers to imperfections and diseases.
A person should cleanse dust and filth,
Dispel the Five *Emotions* (五情),
Inner and outer emptiness and clarity,
The mind illuminated over all things—
Imperfections and diseases do not arise.
This teaching is about cultivating the heart.

From these three matters above,
It concerns oneself in cultivating the body.
From these three matters below,
It encourages governing the realm.
The Classic says:
"Cultivate it in oneself, and its virtue is true.
Cultivate it in the world, and its virtue is universal."

Now I explain:
"Can one be without flaw?" means,
When one desires to cleanse the heart and dispel impurities,
To introspect all inner and outer matters,
One must be able to self-examine,
To have no flaws or imperfections.
If one can have no flaws or imperfections,
Then one has attained the method of washing away and transcending the subtle and profound.

To love the people and govern the realm—
Can one be without action?
The old sayings state:
"To love the people" means to love them as one’s own children,
In governing, one must not be harsh or cruel,
Taxes and labor must not harm their nature.
"To govern the realm" means to focus on agriculture and simplify matters,
Allowing the people to pursue their vocations and live in peace—
This is the transformation of *Wuwéi* (無為, "Non-action").

Now I explain:
"Can one be without action?" means,
When a ruler desires to love and nurture all people,
To not harm their natural inclinations,
To govern by focusing on agriculture,
To avoid unnecessary complexity,
One must be able to remain calm, clear, and without action.
If one can remain calm, clear, and without action,
Then one has attained the art of loving the people and governing the realm.

The *Tiānmén* (天門, "Heavenly Gate") opens and closes—
Can one be without duality?
*The Tiānmén* is the gate of nature.
Nature generates the *Tàijí* (太極, "Supreme Pole"),
The *Tàijí* generates Heaven and Earth,
Heaven and Earth generate Yin and Yang,
Yin and Yang generate all things and destroy all things—
Life and death proceed through this gate,
Thus it is called the *Tiānmén* (天門, "Heavenly Gate").」

chunks.original_text: 开谓散施，阖谓歙敛。 开则生成，阖则衰灭。 虽生万物，而未见其生生者； 虽死万物，而未见其死死者。 生生死死而莫见其形，得不谓之自然乎？ 能体自然者，其唯大人乎。 夫大人量包宇宙，气含阴阳，所为雌静，则生死王衰不入于胸中。 雌静者，自然之妙用也。 此戒治身治国者，当以雌静是守。 旧说曰：天门者，北极紫宫之门也。 天有北极星，在紫宫之内。 宫内又有五帝迭相休王，故门有开阖也。 开则为泰，阖则为否。 故春时青帝门开，余门皆阖。 四时之例如此，且五运终始，历数之变兴废不常，唯圣人知天知命，常守雌静，则不为变动所倾。 故永亨元吉也。 或以治身论者，天门谓鼻口也。 开阖谓喘息呼吸也，言人雌静柔和则气息深远，绵绵微妙，致其精神恬然，自在无为也。 今解曰：能为雌乎者，言天门开阖休王者，乃历数之常，唯能雌静谦下，故阴阳不能移，寒暑不能变也。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 旧说曰：明谓慧照也，治身者虽有慧照之心，聪明通达若无见闻，治国者其德明白，如日月之照，四达海内，当塞聪蔽明，能如无知，使天下百姓日用不知，是谓有道。 今解曰：能无知乎者，欲得智慧明白、四达天下者，先须收视反听，当能常守无知乎。 若能无知者，即是智慧明白，四达之原也。 生之畜之至是谓玄德。 言修身治国，能行上六事，即如道之生物，不塞其原，任其自成而已； 德之养物，不禁其性，全其素分而已。 夫万物卓尔独生，圣人岂有乎哉？ 群类各自营为，圣人何恃乎哉？ 且物自长养，圣人安所主宰乎哉？ 斯乃忘功忘物，洞入冥极，是谓渊德也。 王弼曰：渊德者，有德而不知其主，出乎幽冥也。 谢图南曰：载营魄至无离乎。 《书》曰：哉生魄，指月十六日也。 月自既望之后，魄生则明死，阴初长也。 人之一身，魂为阳，而魄为阴。 当阴生之时，魄方营营求进，而能守一不离，则不为阴所胜矣。 一者，天之玄也，阳也。 施之国家，则小人不得以胜君子，同一道也。 专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 黄石公曰：柔能胜刚，弱能胜强沁养身之道，以柔为本。 其气不专，则强暴之阳得以间之。 当如婴儿之未孩，柔之至也。 人之多欲，必为强阳所使，不可不戒也。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 经曰：圣人虽有荣观，燕处超然。 则玄览之谓也。 垂旒蔽目，不欲目与物交。 盖外交乎物，则内心从之，修身之道不见可欲，使心不乱。 涤除其外则接乎吾前，皆玄微矣。 无疵者，人欲不得以问天理也。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 修身所以为治国乎。 天下之本，内心清明，不为嗜欲所夺，则以之爱一一民，以之治国，可以为无为，事无事矣。 尧之非心，舜之恭己，皆此道也。 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 经曰塞其兑，闭其门，终身不动。 天门指在上乾宫也，雌，阴也。 天门开阖，贵有常度，而阴邪之气不得以间之，则吾身理矣。 施之国家，则辟四门而小人勿用者是也。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 视非以目而以道，则明可四达。 疏通无蔽，而物来能名也。 私欲间之，近在目睫且不及见，而况於远乎？ 能无知者，不求知也。 不出户而知天下，不窥牖而见天道。 此岂可以有知知之乎？ 《关尹子》曰：一情冥为圣人。 生之畜之至玄德。

「Opening refers to *sànshī* (散施, "dissemination and giving"), closing to *xīlǐn* (歙敛, "withdrawal and restraint"). When the gate opens, all things flourish; when it closes, they wither and perish. Though it generates myriad beings, one does not see its *shēngshēng* (生生, "life-giving life"); though it destroys all things, one does not see its *sǐsǐ* (死死, "death-dealing death"). Life and death proceed through this gate unseen—is this not called *natural* (自然)?

Those who embody *natural* (自然) are none other than the *Dàrén* (大人, "Great Person"). The *Dàrén* measures the cosmos with their breadth, their *qi* (氣) encompasses Yin and Yang. When they act with *qīngjìng* (清静, "serene stillness") and *wéijìng* (雌静, "receptive quietude"), the cycles of life and death, flourishing and decline, do not enter their mind.

*Wéijìng* (雌静) is the subtle *mystic application* (妙用) of *natural* (自然). For those who cultivate the self and govern the realm, they must always uphold *wéijìng* (雌静) as their principle.

The old saying explains:
*The Tiānmén* (天門) is the gate of the *Zǐgōng* (紫宫, "Purple Palace") at the *Beǐjī* (北极, "North Pole"). In the heavens, the *Beǐjī* (北极星, "North Pole Star") resides within the *Zǐgōng* (紫宫). Within this palace, the *Wǔdì* (五帝, "Five Emperors") succeed one another in their reigns of rest and rule (*xiūwáng* 休王), thus the gate has opening and closing.

When it opens, it aligns with *Tài* (泰, "Harmony"); when it closes, it aligns with *Pǐ* (否, "Disharmony"). Hence, in spring, the *Qīngdì* (青帝, "Green Emperor")’s gate opens while the others close. Such is the example of the four seasons, and likewise, the *Wǔyùn* (五运, "Five Phases/Processes") of completion and renewal, the shifts in *lìshù* (历数, "cosmic cycles") and their rise and fall—these are not constant. Only the *sage* (圣人) knows *Tian* (天, "Heaven") and *Mìng* (命, "Fate"), perpetually guarding *wéijìng* (雌静) and *qiānxìa* (谦下, "humble receptivity"), thus they are not swayed by change. Therefore, they attain *Yǒnghéng Yuánjí* (永亨元吉, "eternal prosperity and primal auspiciousness").

Some discuss this in terms of self-cultivation: *Tiānmén* (天門) refers to the nose and mouth. Opening and closing mean *chuǎnxī* (喘息, "breathing") and *hūxī* (呼吸, "respiration"). When one embodies *wéijìng* (雌静) and *róuhé* (柔和, "gentle harmony"), their breath becomes deep and expansive, continuous and subtle, nurturing their *spirit* (精神) into *tiánrán* (恬然, "tranquil repose"), free and effortless.

Now I explain:
Those who can practice *wéijìng* (雌静) speak of the *Tiānmén* (天門) opening and closing in rest and rule (*xiūwáng* 休王)—this is the constant of *lìshù* (历数). Only those who guard *wéijìng* (雌静) and *qiānxìa* (谦下) can thus prevent Yin and Yang from altering them, nor can cold and heat change them.

*Míng* (明, "illumination") and *Sìdá* (四达, "fourfold penetration")—can one truly be without knowing (*wúzhī* 能无知)?

The old saying explains:
*Míng* (明) means *huìzhào* (慧照, "wise illumination"). For self-cultivation, even with a mind of *huìzhào* (慧照), one’s *cleverness* (聪明) and *Sìdá* (通达) should be as though without perception or hearing. In governance, one’s *virtue* (德) should be *míngbái* (明白, "clear and luminous"), like the sun and moon’s radiance, penetrating the four seas. Yet, one must block their *cleverness* (塞聪) and obscure their *illumination* (蔽明), achieving *wúzhī* (无知, "non-knowing") so that the people of the world live their daily lives unaware—this is called *having the Dao* (有道).

Now I explain:
Those who seek *zhìhuì míngbái* (智慧明白, "wise illumination") and *Sìdá* (四达) must first practice *shōushì fǎn tīng* (收视反听, "withdrawing sight and inverting hearing"). Only then can they perpetually uphold *wúzhī* (无知). If one attains *wúzhī* (无知), then it is the *source* (原) of *wise illumination* (智慧明白) and *fourfold penetration* (四达).

To *nurture* (畜) life is the ultimate *Xuándé* (玄德, "mystic virtue"). It means that in cultivating the self and governing the realm, one can enact the six affairs above—like the Dao’s *shēngwù* (生物, "life-giving"), not obstructing its source, allowing it to flourish naturally; or *virtue’s* (德) *yǎngwù* (养物, "nurturing beings"), not restraining their nature, preserving their innate essence.

The myriad things arise singularly—does the *sage* (圣人) not rely on them? All classes pursue their own endeavors—does the *sage* (圣人) depend on them? Moreover, things grow and nourish themselves—where does the *sage* (圣人) preside over them? This is the *forgetting merit and forgetting things* (忘功忘物), penetrating the *míngjí* (冥极, "profound depths"), called *yuāndé* (渊德, "abyssal virtue").

*Wang Bi* (王弼) says:
*Yuāndé* (渊德) is *having virtue without knowing its master* (有德而不知其主), emerging from the *yōumíng* (幽冥, "mysterious darkness").

*Xiè Túnán* (谢图南) says:
*To bear the spirit and the vital force* (载营魄) until there is no separation (*wúlí* 无离).

The *Shū* (书, *Book of Documents*) says:
*"O! the spirit is born"* (哉生魄), pointing to the sixteenth day of the month. After the *jìwàng* (既望, "full moon"), the *spirit* (魄) is born as the *light* (明) dies, marking the initial growth of *Yin* (阴).

In a person’s body, the *soul* (魂) is *Yang* (阳), while the *vital force/spirit* (魄) is *Yin* (阴). When *Yin* (阴) is growing, the *vital force/spirit* (魄) is restless and strives forward, yet if one guards *unity* (一) without separation, they will not be overcome by *Yin* (阴).

*Unity* (一) is the *Xuán* (玄, "mystic") of Heaven, the *Yang* (阳). Applied to the realm, it means that the *small people* (小人) cannot overcome the *gentlemen* (君子), for they share the same Dao.

*Concentrating qi to achieve softness* (专气致柔)—can one be like an *infant* (婴儿)?

*Huáng Shígōng* (黄石公) says:
*Softness can overcome hardness* (柔能胜刚), *weakness can overcome strength* (弱能胜强). The *method of nourishing the body* (沁养身之道) takes *softness* (柔) as its foundation. If one’s *qi* (氣) is not concentrated, then the *strong and violent Yang* (强暴之阳) will exploit it. One must be like an *infant* (婴儿) before they are *cháibéi* (孩, "childlike"), the ultimate of *softness* (柔). Human desires, if many, will surely be controlled by the *strong Yang* (强阳)—this must be guarded against.

*Washing away and penetrating the mysterious* (涤除玄览)—can one be without *flaws* (疵)?

The *classic* (经) says:
*"Though the sage may have splendid dwellings, their repose is lofty and detached"* (圣人虽有荣观，燕处超然). This is the meaning of *Xuánlǎn* (玄览, "mystic penetration").

*垂旒蔽目* (Chuíliú bìmù, "hanging tassels to blind the eyes") means not desiring one’s eyes to engage with external things. Engaging externally with things, one’s internal mind follows suit. The way of cultivating the self is to *not see what is desirable* (不见可欲), so the mind does not stray. Washing away the external, one’s vision aligns with *Xuánwéi* (玄微, "mystic subtleties"). To be without *flaws* (疵) means that human desires cannot intrude upon Heavenly principle (*Tiānlǐ* 天理).

*Loving the people and governing the realm* (爱民治国)—can one be without action (*wúwéi* 能无为)?

Cultivating the self is the foundation for governing the realm. The root of the world lies in a *clear mind* (内心清明), not being seized by *sìyù* (嗜欲, "greedy desires"). Then, one can love each and every person, govern the realm, and achieve *wúwéi* (无为, "non-action"), making *no action* (事无事) into *action* (事).

*Yáo’s* (尧) *fēixīn* (非心, "non-attachment") and *Shùn’s* (舜) *gōngjǐ* (恭己, "self-respectful humility") are all of this Dao.

*The Tiānmén* (天門) opens and closes—can one be without *Yin* (雌)?

The *classic* (经) says:
*"Block the *Yuè* (兑, "Joy/Compliance") and close the gate, and one will move not all their life."* (塞其兑，闭其门，终身不动)

*The Tiānmén* (天門) refers to the *Shàngqián Gōng* (上乾宫, "Upper Qian Palace"). *雌* (Wéi, "receptive") is *Yin* (阴). The opening and closing of *Tiānmén* (天門) is to have a *constant measure* (常度), preventing *Yin* (阴邪, "perverse Yin") from exploiting it—then one’s body is in harmony.

Applied to the realm, this means *excluding the four gates* (辟四门) and *not employing the small people* (小人勿用).

*Míngbái Sìdá* (明白四达)—can one be without knowing (*wúzhī* 能无知)?

*Viewing* (视) is not with the eyes but with the *Dao* (道), then *illumination* (明) can be *fourfold* (四达). *Open and unobstructed* (疏通无蔽), yet one can name what comes—*private desires* (私欲) cannot interfere. Even what is near, at the edge of one’s sight, is not seen—how much more so with what is distant?

Those who attain *wúzhī* (无知) are not *seeking to know* (不求知). *Not stepping outside the door yet knowing the world* (不出户而知天下), *not peering through the window yet seeing Heavenly Dao* (不窥牖而见天道)—how can this be achieved by *knowing through knowing* (有知知之)?

*The Guān Yǐn Zǐ* (关尹子) says:
*"One emotion, one vital force—this is the sage"* (一情冥为圣人).

*Nurturing life* (生之畜之) reaches the ultimate of *Xuándé* (玄德, "mystic virtue").」

chunks.original_text: 人伪既销，天理自长。 施之吾身，则积善在身，日加益而不自知者也。 施之天下，无一民一物不在生育长养之内，而未尝以功自居。 此所以为玄德。 玄，天也。 宰，主也。 盖尝论之，阳之有阴，阴之有阳，不能免也。 而圣人常欲进阳而退阴，岂非阳为君子，阴为小人乎？ 阴在吾身，则足为吾身之累，小人在国家，则足以为国家之害。 治身治国，无二道也。 是故无思无为，而不失赤子之心，不识不知，而尽屏外邪之气，则一身可以优游矣。 推之天下国家，复何为哉？ 茫然天运，窈尔神化，盖有不知其所以然而然者，岂非玄德乎。 舜之天德，出宁文王之顺天理物，其谓是乎？ 林庸斋曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 营，魂也，神也。 魄，精也，气也。 此三字，老子之深意。 载犹车载物也。 安一载字在上，而置营魄二字於下，如谜语然。 魄以载营，则为众人； 营以载魄，则为圣人。 合而言之，则营魄为一。 离而言之，则魂魄为二。 抱者，合也。 其意盖曰能合而一之，使无离乎。 将离而二之乎，故曰抱一能无离乎。 此六字，意亦甚稳，正要人自参自悟也。 婴儿未有闻见，则其气专。 政者极也，柔者顺也。 能如婴兄专气致柔，则能抱一矣。 故曰能如婴儿乎。 此老子设问之语也。 盖曰人能如此乎。 此下数句皆然。 荡涤瑕垢而观览玄冥，则必有分别之心。 无疵者，无分别也。 虽荡涤瑕垢，而有不垢不净之心，则能抱一矣。 有爱民治国之功，而有无为而为之心，则能抱一矣。 阴阳阖辟，有雌雄交感之理，而无雌雄交感之心，则能抱一矣。 天门，即天地间自然之理也。 此亦借造物以为喻。 缘此等语遂流入修养家，或有因是而为邪说者，误世多矣。 明白四达，无所不通也。 而以无知为知，则抱一矣。 生之畜之。 言造化之间，生养万物也。 造化何尝视之以为有？ 何尝恃之以为能？ 虽为万物之长，而何尝有宰制万物之心？ 如此而后谓之玄妙之德。 此章之意，大抵主於无为而为，自然而然，无为自然，则其心常虚。 故以神载魄，而不以魄载神。 此圣人之事。 以魄载神，则着迹矣。 《老子》一书，大抵只是能实而虚，能有而无，则为至道。 从说横说，不过此理。 范应元曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 营魄，魂魄也。 《内观经》曰：动以营身之谓魂，静以镇形之谓魄。 河上公曰：营魄，魂魄也。 魂属阳，魄属阴。 一者，道之一也。 谓身载魂魄，抱道之一，顷刻无离，人能之乎？ 专气数柔至能无疵乎。 专者，静定不挠之义。 疵，黑病也。 夫婴儿气专而和柔，谓不挠其炁，以致和柔。 俾常如婴兑之时，人能之乎？ 心不虚则不明，不明则不通，谓涤除私欲，使本心精明，如玉之无瑕疵，鉴之无尘垢，则冥观事物、皆不外乎自然之理。 人能之乎？ 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 谓抱一、专气、涤除等事，既以修身明心，可推充此道以及人物，即爱民治国之本也。 循自然之理，以应事物，莫不有当行之路。 则何以智为爱民者，非区区爱之，但不害之，即爱之至也； 治国者非区区治之，但不乱之，即治之至也。 人能之乎？ 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 天门者，以吾之心神出入而言也。 心神本不可以出入言，然而应物为出，应己为入。 出则开，而入则阖。
chunks.translated_text:
When falsehoods are extinguished, Heavenly Principle flourishes naturally.
Applied to oneself, it means accumulating virtue within, growing daily without self-awareness.
Applied to the world, it means every person and thing is encompassed within nurturing and growth, yet never claiming credit for it.
This is what constitutes *Xuándé* (玄德, "mystic virtue").
*Xuán* (玄) is Heaven; *zǎi* (宰) is Master—
Indeed, when examined:
the Yang cannot exist without Yin, nor Yin without Yang—this is inevitable.
Yet the Sage ever seeks to advance Yang and suppress Yin—is this not Yang as the Noble, Yin as the petty?
Yin within oneself becomes a burden to the body;
petty men in the state become a harm to the nation.
The Way of cultivating the self and governing the state is one and the same.

Thus, with no thought and no action,
yet never losing the heart of the innocent child—
unaware and unknowing,
while utterly repelling all external malevolent *qi*,
one’s body may then attain ease and freedom.
Extended to the world and the state—what further effort is needed?

Vast as Heaven’s movement, profound as divine transformation—
there exists an unknowable yet natural operation—
is this not *Xuándé*?

Shùn’s Heavenly Virtue lies in his harmonizing with Heaven’s Principle and the affairs of things—
is this not the case?

Lín Yōngzhāi says:
*"To bear the *yíngpò* (营魄) is called *Xuándé*."*
*Yíng* (营) is *hún* (魂, spirit), *shén* (神, mind);
*Pò* (魄) is *jīng* (精, essence), *qì* (气, vital force).
These three characters hold the profound intent of *Lǎozǐ*.
*"To bear"* is like a cart bearing goods—
placing *"bear"* above and *"yíngpò"* below, like a riddle.
If *pò* bears *yíng*, it is the common man;
if *yíng* bears *pò*, it is the Sage.
Together, they form a unity;
separated, they are two.
*"Bao"* (抱) means unity—
its meaning is: *Can one embrace unity and remain undivided?*
Would one allow division into two?
Thus it asks: *Can one embrace unity without separation?*
These six words hold deep meaning—
they urge self-reflection and enlightenment.

An infant, untouched by perception, possesses concentrated *qi*.
*Zhèng* (政) means extreme; *róu* (柔) means yielding.
If one can, like the infant, concentrate *qi* and attain supreme yielding,
then one can embrace unity.
Thus it asks: *Can one be like the infant?*
These are *Lǎozǐ*’s questioning words—
meaning: *Can people truly achieve this?*
The following sentences are the same.

To purify flaws and contemplate the profound darkness,
one must have a discriminating mind.
The flawless is without discrimination—
even when purifying flaws, if one holds no notion of impurity or purity,
then one can embrace unity.

If one has the merit of loving the people and governing the state,
yet holds a heart of *wuwei* (无为) while acting,
then one can embrace unity.

In the interplay of Yin and Yang, the principles of male and female,
though there is the natural interplay of attraction and response,
one must lack the discriminating mind of attraction and response—
then one can embrace unity.

The *Tiānmén* (天门, Heavenly Gate) refers to the natural principles between Heaven and Earth—
this is a metaphor borrowed from creation.
Because of such language, it has entered the realm of cultivation,
and some have mistakenly used it for heretical teachings,
thus misleading many.

*Míngbái Sìdá* (明白四达)—
to be open and unobstructed in all things,
yet to regard *wúzhī* (无知) as knowing—
this is to embrace unity.

*Shēng zhī xù zhī* (生之畜之)—
speaking of the interplay of creation,
which nurtures all things.
How does creation ever regard them as existing?
How does it ever rely on them as capable?
Though it is the sovereign of all things,
how does it ever hold the heart of controlling them?
Only thus can it be called the profound and mysterious virtue.

The intent of this chapter is, broadly,
to emphasize *wuwei* (无为) while acting,
to be natural and effortless—
for the heart to remain ever empty.
Thus, the mind bears the *pò* (魄),
not the *pò* bearing the mind—
this is the Sage’s affair.
If the *pò* bears the mind, it becomes attached to form.
The *Lǎozǐ*’s text, broadly,
is about being able to be real yet empty,
able to have yet be without—
this is the ultimate Dao.
From all angles, it speaks of this principle alone.

Fàn Yìngyuán says:
*"To bear the *yíngpò* and embrace unity—can one remain undivided?"*
*Yíngpò* is *húnpò* (魂魄, spirit and vital force).
The *Nèiguān Jīng* (内观经) says:
*"Movement to nourish the body is called *hún* (魂);
stillness to settle the form is called *pò* (魄)."*
Hé Shànggōng says:
*"Yíngpò* is *húnpò*—
the *hún* belongs to Yang, the *pò* to Yin.
*Yī* (一) is the Dao’s unity—
meaning the body bears the *húnpò*,
embracing the Dao’s unity,
never separating for an instant.
Can people achieve this?"

To concentrate *qi* and attain extreme yielding—
can one be without flaws?
*Zhuān* (专) means steadfast and unyielding.
*Cī* (疵) is blemish or disease.
The infant’s *qi* is concentrated and harmoniously yielding—
meaning it does not resist *qi*,
thus attaining harmony and yielding.
To always remain as in infancy—
can people achieve this?

If the heart is not empty, it cannot be clear;
if unclear, it cannot be penetrating—
meaning to eliminate private desires,
to refine the original heart to pristine clarity,
like jade without flaws,
like a mirror without dust—
then in contemplating affairs,
all are within the natural Principle.
Can people achieve this?

To love the people and govern the state—
can one act without acting?
Meaning that embracing unity, concentrating *qi*, purifying desires,
after cultivating the self and clarifying the heart,
one can extend this Dao to all people—
this is the foundation of loving the people and governing the state.
Following natural principles to respond to affairs,
there is always the proper path to take.
Thus, for those who love the people,
it is not mere partial affection,
but to not harm them—this is the ultimate love;
for those who govern the state,
it is not mere partial governance,
but to not let it fall into chaos—this is the ultimate governance.
Can people achieve this?

The opening and closing of the *Tiānmén* (Heavenly Gate)—
can one avoid the male?
The *Tiānmén* refers to the entry and exit of one’s mind and spirit—
though the mind and spirit cannot truly be said to enter or exit,
yet responding to things is exit,
responding to oneself is entry.
Exit is opening,
entry is closing.

Those who attain *wúzhī* (无知) are not *seeking to know* (不求知). *Not stepping outside the door yet knowing the world* (不出户而知天下), *not peering through the window yet seeing Heavenly Dao* (不窥牖而见天道)—how can this be achieved by *knowing through knowing* (有知知之)?

chunks.original_text: 不可不如是而言也。 《庄子□天运篇》载：正者正也，其心以为不然者，天门弗开矣。 成玄英注亦云：天门者，心也。 雌者，言其主静而和柔也。 亦感而后应之义。 河上公并苏注皆作为雌。 一本或作无雌，恐非经义。 盖当经中有知其雄，守其雌也。 理亦当作为雌，谓吾之心即天之心，当於一动一静之际常为雌柔，使神气和顺，则阴阳之炁一开一阖，亦和顺矣。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 明白，虚也。 四达，通也。 谓此心虚明坦白，四达皇皇，感而后应，而常虚无，以私意为之，人能之乎？ 盖此心无为而无不为也，无为是本，无不为是末。 然本末一贡，得其本则以一行万，而逐处皆是； 通乎末则会万归一，而无时不中。 但人当守其本，则末自归一尔。 生之畜之至是谓玄德。 畜，养本也。 盖谓万物皆根於道而生，本於德而养，然生之而不以为己有，为之而不恃其功，至於长成而不为之主，故万物各得其所，而不知所以然而然。 是谓玄德也。 圣人体道而无迹，大而化之，是以百姓不知帝力，玄之德也。 薛庸斋曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 文玄先生曰：运载魂魄，抱守真一，能不相离乎？ 至阴肃肃，至阳赫赫，肃肃出乎天，赫赫发乎地。 两者之交通也。 然后运载日月之精华，呼吸天地之根蒂，子母相守，犹鱼在水，此长生久视之道也。 王褒谓：聚精会神，得非有所知乎？ 专气政柔，能如婴儿乎？ 专一养气，而致骨弱筋柔，能如婴儿乎。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 能玄览万物之化，而不能无瑕疵者，犹有玄览在焉耳。 若能涤除玄览，则无瑕疵矣。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 心，君也。 身，国也。 精气，民也。 君能无为而治，则国以富而民以安。 其或有为，非徒无益，而返害也。 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 天门开阖，元神所以出入也。 若静而有其静，则神其窒也。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 神室廓然无一物，则明白四达矣。 或有所知，其能明白乎？ 生之畜之至是谓玄德。 生畜万物，不恃赖其功； 成长万物，不宰割而用。 使万物莫知所谢，岂非玄远之德邪？ 老子之道，长於治身，除清静无为之余，清深隐奥莫之能测者，其惟名神载营魄乎？ 古今解义各不相师，论理性者讥其小工，修炼者失之粗殊，不知此圣人之机要也。 文人不能骋其辞，谈士不能利其辩，会当耳授心听，志励力行，然后可与释其义尔。 休休庵曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 人之灵明，字之曰心曰神。 神俗谓之魂。 神气曰魄。 前因妄为，劳神而气衰。 今知其非，息念寝机，营养神气，契合情冥大道，是谓抱一。 能永无失乎？ 专一真气而致柔顺，能无念无欲，如出胎之婴儿。 又当洗涤玄妙，见解莹净，无一点瑕疵，乃见了事。 修身齐家、治国平天下，能任无为之道、无作之德者，内则心情气顺，外则民安国治也。 天门开阖，能为雌乎？ 天者，心也。 门者，万法由是而出。 开阖者，放收也。 雌者柔也，玄机妙用，或收善柔和而无刚利之害，履践相应，微妙玄通，廓达无碍，而不自矜自伐，兀兀然如无所知者，三才任道而生，万物以德畜养。 虽然生之畜之，而不言有其功； 为造化之主，而不恃其尊；
chunks.translated_text:
One must speak thus—it cannot be otherwise.

The *Zhuangzi* ["Heaven’s Operation" chapter] states:
*"Zheng* is uprightness—if one’s heart rejects this,
the *Tiānmén* will not open.
Chéng Xuányīng’s annotation also says:
The *Tiānmén* is the heart.
*Rú* (雌) means to abide in stillness and gentle harmony—
it is the principle of responding only after being moved.

Héshànggōng and Sū Zhì both interpret *rú* as *rú* (雌).
Some manuscripts read *wú rú* (无雌), likely not the original intent.
For the text indeed speaks of ‘knowing the *xióng* (雄) while guarding the *rú* (雌).’
By *rú*, it means: the heart is the Heavenly Heart—
at every moment of motion and stillness,
one must remain *rú* (gently yielding),
so that the spirit and *qi* flow harmoniously,
and thus the opening and closing of yin and yang *qi*
are also in harmony.

Can one be without knowing?
*Míngbái* (明白) is emptiness;
*Sìdá* (四达) is openness.
This heart, empty and luminous, vast and unobstructed,
responds only after being moved—
yet remains ever empty and without self,
acting without acting—
can people achieve this?

For this heart does nothing yet accomplishes all—
non-action is its root,
omni-action its manifestation.
Yet root and branch are one:
grasp the root, and one act moves all things,
and everywhere is correct;
master the branch, and all things return to unity,
and never stray.
But one must guard the root—
then the branch will naturally return to unity.

*"Shēng zhī xù zhī zhì shì wéi xuándé"*—
*"Nurturing life and fostering growth until this point is called the Mysterious Virtue."*
*"Xù"* means to nourish the root.
All things arise from the Dao and are born,
and are sustained by virtue—
yet they are born without being claimed,
nurtured without reliance on merit,
and when fully grown, are not dominated.
Thus all things find their place,
and yet they do not know why—
this is called the Mysterious Virtue.

The Sage embodies the Dao without trace,
transforming all things broadly—
thus the people do not know the Emperor’s power;
this is the Mysterious Virtue.

Xuē Yǒngzhāi says:
*"Nurturing the spirit and embracing the One—
can one avoid separation?"*
Wén Xuán’s Master says:
*"Cultivating the spirit and embracing the True One—
can one avoid their separation?"*

The utmost yin is solemn and still,
the utmost yang is radiant and vast—
solemn stillness issues from Heaven,
radiant vastness arises from Earth.
Their interaction—
then the essence of the sun and moon is carried,
and the breath of Heaven and Earth is drawn—
mother and child guard each other,
like fish in water—
this is the Dao of eternal life and longevity.

Wáng Bǎo says:
*"Gathering essence and converging spirit—
is there not some knowing involved?"*
*"Specializing in *qi* and attaining gentleness—
can one be like an infant?"*
To focus on nurturing *qi* until bones weaken and sinews soften—
can one be like an infant?
*"Purifying and gazing into the Mysterious—
can one be without blemish?"*
To gaze into the transformations of all things yet remain without flaw—
this is only because the gaze into the Mysterious still lingers.
If one purifies and discards the Mysterious gaze,
then there will be no blemish.

Loving the people and governing the state—
can one act without acting?
The heart is the sovereign,
the body is the state,
essence and *qi* are the people.
If the sovereign governs without acting,
the state grows rich and the people are at ease.
If one acts instead,
not only is it unbeneficial—
it brings harm.

The opening and closing of the *Tiānmén*—
can one remain *rú* (gently yielding)?
Heaven is the heart,
the Gate is where all laws emerge.
Opening and closing are release and withdrawal.
*Rú* is gentleness—
the Mysterious Mechanism’s subtle operation
sometimes withdraws in gentle harmony,
without harshness or injury,
walking in accordance with response,
subtle and penetrating, boundless and unobstructed,
yet without self-praise or arrogance—
steadfastly, as if without knowing—
the Three Powers act through the Dao and give birth,
all things are nurtured by virtue.
Though they are born and nurtured,
one does not claim the merit;
though they are the masters of transformation,
one does not rely on one’s exalted status—

for those who govern the state,
it is not mere partial governance,
but to not let it fall into chaos—this is the ultimate governance.
Can people achieve this?

The opening and closing of the *Tiānmén* (Heavenly Gate)—
can one avoid the male?
The *Tiānmén* refers to the entry and exit of one’s mind and spirit—
though the mind and spirit cannot truly be said to enter or exit,
yet responding to things is exit,

Exit is opening,

chunks.original_text: 万物承恩，皆得生长，而不作主。 任其自然生长成化，是谓大道之得也。 褚伯秀曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 篇首载字，诸解难通。 盖以前三字为句，抱一属下文，与后语下类所以费辞津合。 尝深考其义，得之郭忠恕《佩解集》引开元诏语云：朕钦承圣训，覃思玄宗，顷改正《道德经》十章载字为哉，仍属上句。 及乎议定，众以为然。 遂错综真诠，因成注解。 此说明当可去千载之惑。 盖古本不分章，后人误以失之道哉句末字#1，加次章之首，传录又讹为载耳。 五十三章末非道也哉，句法可证。 今按玄宗《道德经》亦是作载，以载初解。 杜光庭又以运载解。 《不曾离章》作哉。 不知郭忠恕集中所出。 合以褚氏引用，姑存其说。
chunks.translated_text:
All things receive the grace of Heaven,
and thus grow and flourish—
yet none claim dominion.
To let them grow and transform naturally
is called attaining the Great Dao.

Master Chu Bo-xiu remarked:
*"The phrase '载营魄' signifies the Mysterious Virtue."*

The opening character *zài* (載) in the chapter’s title
has long baffled interpreters.
It seems the first three characters form a clause,
with *"bào yī"* (抱一) belonging to the following text,
akin to the structure of later passages—
thus requiring careful parsing to align meaning.

Upon deep reflection,
I found in Master Guo Zhong-shu’s *Pèi Jiě Jí* (佩解集),
quoting the Kaiyuan Edict:
*"With reverence for the Sacred Teachings,
I pondered the Profound Essence,
and recently altered the tenth chapter’s
original *zài* (載) to *zāi* (哉),
restoring it to the preceding sentence.
When the matter was deliberated,
all agreed it was correct.
Thus, the true meaning was clarified,
and the commentary was refined.
This resolves a thousand years of confusion."*

For the ancient text was unchaptered;
later scholars mistakenly severed the phrase
*—the Dao, the virtue—*
at the end of the sentence,
then appended the next chapter’s opening,
and in transcription, *zài* (載) was corrupted to *zāi* (哉).
The structure of Chapter 53’s closing
*—not the Dao—*
proves this error.

Now, examining the Kaiyuan Emperor’s *Daodejing*,
it also renders *zài* (載) at the start,
with the initial interpretation.
Du Guangting further expounds it as *"to bear and convey."*
In *Bùcéng Lí Zhāng* (不曾离章),
it reads *zāi* (哉).
Yet I do not know the source of Guo Zhong-shu’s citation.
Given Master Chu’s reference,
I provisionally retain this view.

chunks.original_text: 《定观经》云：动以营身谓之魂，静以镇形谓之魄。 魂阳清而升，魄阴浊而坠。 阳动阴静，互成造化。 二气寄形推运，不能反归其根，日消月杀，叶去树枯矣。 圣人教使魂魄皆抱于一。 一者，道之所生，为数之始，为物之元。 在人则性初是也。 魂魄抱一，不离则动静两忘，去道不达。 专守其气使无间断。 故能致极乎柔，不为喜怒所动。 守气不专，则强阳得以间之，遇触而发暴，逸散荡气，非形有神，亦不能自存矣。 可不慎诸。 如婴儿，言其无知识，喜怒纯然，一团和气而已。 此是玄门秘密工夫，世传炼气调息法，出於此。 多流入旁门，罕得其正。 道本乎夷，恬淡不离日用，虚心无为，道自居之。 而学者多存玄妙之见，求诸寥廓之表，愈求愈疏。 涤除去尽，归其本初，道体自全，何雌之有？ 国以喻身，民喻神气。 能无以知乎？
chunks.translated_text:
The *Dingguan Jing* states:

*"Movement nourishing the body is called the soul (魂),
stillness governing the form is called the spirit (魄).
The soul, bright and yang, ascends;
the spirit, dark and yin, descends.
Yang moves, yin stirs—
together they forge transformation.
The two qi lodge in form and circulate,
yet if they cannot return to their root,
day by day they dwindle, month by month they perish—
leaves fall, the tree withers.

The Sage teaches the soul and spirit to both embrace *One*.
*One*—that from which the Dao is born,
the origin of numbers, the source of all things.
In humankind, it is the primal nature.
When soul and spirit cling to *One*,
they do not depart—
then movement and stillness are both forgotten,
and the Dao remains unattained.
If one steadfastly guards the qi without interruption,
then one attains the utmost softness,
unmoved by joy or anger.

If guarding the qi is not steadfast,
then forceful yang can intrude,
and at the slightest provocation, it erupts violently—
the scattered, dissipated qi cannot sustain life,
nor can the form endure without spirit.
How could this not be taken with utmost care?

Like an infant—
though it lacks knowledge,
its joy and anger are pure,
a single harmonious breath.
This is the secret work of the Mysterious Gate,
the method of refining qi and regulating breath
passed down through the ages.
Yet most stray into false paths,
few attain the true way.

The Dao lies in simplicity,
in tranquil stillness, never straying from daily life.
With an empty heart and non-action,
the Dao naturally abides.
But scholars often seek esoteric wonders,
pursuing what lies beyond the void—
the more they seek, the more distant they grow.
When all is stripped away and returned to its origin,
the Dao’s essence remains whole—
what need for duality?

A kingdom is a metaphor for the body,
its people for the vital qi.
How could one not know this?"*

chunks.original_text: 古本如此，后文以知治国国之贼可证。 天门者，万物万化出入於斯，阳开阴阖以神其用。 圣人密弘此道，必以雌静为主，故烛理明而应物不劳，以至明白四达。 能无以为乎？ 古本如此，俗行河上本爱民下作无为，明白下作无知二字，正相反。 无以为犹云无所为。 恐聪明妨道，故教令无为。 已上皆治身事。 到此当以生物为心。 生而不有其功，为而不恃其力，端居物长，不以宰制自尊，是谓深玄至妙之德。 非世人所能测识也。 牛妙传曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 载者，再也。 营者，生也。 魄者，月也。 抱一者，月之始生也。 夫魄消谓之月尽，魄载营谓之月一。 盖月之初生，始有一点之明月，能抱之渐而增长，以至於圆满着明也。 由是观之，月尚不能离乎一点之明，而常抱之，而况於他乎？ 此善言从微方成着，从一方到万。 夫一者，道也。 凡天下事物，何莫由斯道也。 孔子曰：道也者，不可须突离也。 夫人有道则生，无道则死。 曰生曰死，在夫能抱一与不能抱一之间耳。 专气致柔，能如婴儿乎？ 专者，一也。 气者，体之充也。 盖人生天地间，呼吸往来而为命者，不过气而已矣。 夫所谓婴兄者，天理纯全，人欲未萌。 及其既长，感物而动，人欲渐起，以失其固有之良心，遂政好恶无节於内，声色知诱於外，由是衰相自见也。 人能一其志，无暴其气，则其体和而柔，轻而健，其犹婴而处子也。 列子曰：婴孩也，气专志一，和之至也。 物不伤焉，德莫加焉。 此之谓也。
chunks.translated_text:
The ancient text reads thus, and later passages confirm that knowing this proves the ruin of the realm.

The Heavenly Gate—through it all things and transformations enter and exit. The sun opens, the moon closes, and through this the divine functions are manifested. The Sage expounds this Dao in secret, taking *yin* stillness as the foundation. Thus, when the principles are illuminated, responding to things requires no effort, and one attains perfect clarity and boundless understanding.

How could one fail to recognize this?

The ancient text reads thus, but the vulgar *He Shang* version alters "love the people" to "non-action," and "clear and bright" to "without knowledge"—directly contradictory. "Without doing" is akin to "without purpose." Fearful that cleverness would obstruct the Dao, the teaching thus advocates non-action.

All above pertains to cultivating the self.

Now one must take nurturing life as the heart.

To give birth without claiming its merit,
to act without relying on its strength—
settled yet expansive,
not lording over others with tyrannical pride—
this is called the profound and wondrous virtue beyond mortal comprehension.

The *Niu Miao* Transmission says:
*"Carrying the spirit-soul, embracing the One—
how could one stray from it?"*

*Carrying* means "repeatedly."
*Camp* means "life."
*Po* means "moon."
*Embracing the One* refers to the moon’s first emergence.

When the *po* dissipates, it is called the moon’s end.
When *po* carries *ying*, it is called the moon’s unity.

Indeed, at the moon’s birth, there is but a single point of luminosity.
If one clings to it, it gradually grows until full and radiant.
Thus observed, even the moon cannot depart from that single point of light, always embracing it—
how much more so for all else?

This is the art of nurturing the subtle to achieve the manifest,
from one to myriad things.

The One is the Dao.
All things under heaven—what does not arise from this Dao?

Confucius said:
*"The Dao is never to be abandoned, even for a moment."*

When a person has the Dao, they live.
When they lack it, they die.
"Live" and "die" depend solely on whether one can embrace the One or not.

Can one concentrate the qi and attain supreme softness,
as an infant does?

*Specialization* is *oneness*.
*Qi* is the body’s fullness.
Truly, between heaven and earth, what sustains life and breath
is nothing but qi.

The so-called "infant brother" retains pristine nature,
untainted by human desires.
As one grows, however, external stimuli stir the mind,
and desires gradually arise,
corrupting the innate pure heart.
Thus, internally, preferences and aversions become unchecked,
while externally, sounds and colors ensnare the senses—
from this, decline naturally follows.

If a person unifies their will
and does not violently disrupt their qi,
their body becomes harmonious and supple,
light and vigorous—
like an infant or maiden.

*Liezi* said:
*"An infant’s qi is concentrated, its will unified—
the pinnacle of harmony.
Nothing harms it,
and no virtue surpasses it."*

This is what is meant.

chunks.original_text: 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 涤者，洗涤。 除者，蠲除。 玄者，道也。 览者，观也。 疵者，瑕疵，谓过失也。 言为人之道，常洗涤身心，蠲除外虑，览观道妙，使为穷理尽性之人，於天地之间，可以无大过矣，安有瑕疵之称哉？ 庸常论天心其犹镜也，不涤除不明，道犹影也，不观览不见。 是以道学君子常加存养省察之功，使无少有间断，则明德常明，不复为嗜欲所昏。 如人之一日沐浴，而日日沐浴，又无日而不沐浴，使其疏瀹澡雪之功无少间断，则身常洁清，而不复为旧染之污，则鉴明尘浄，心照道明。 此则涤除玄览之说矣。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 夫民为邦本，本固邦宁。 故治国者必先於爱民，爱民之道在乎无为也，无为者不挠也。 如昔者唐太宗尝谓侍臣曰：君依於国，国依於民，刻民以奉君，犹割肉以充腹。 腹饱而身毙，君富而国亡，故人君之患不自外来，常於中出。 於是轻徭薄赋，选用良吏。 自是之后，海内升平，人民衣食有余，外户不闭，行旅野宿。 此非爱民治国，无为不挠之说乎？ 天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 天门者，口也。 盖口为一身之门户。 人头圆象天，故以口为天门也。 开阖者谓呼吸也，雌者雌雄也。 夫开阖、呼吸、雌雄谓阴阳也。 阴阳者，动静也。 《易》曰：一动一静，互为其根。 一阴一阳，是之谓道。 能继之者善也。 此盖言人孰能有呼而无吸耶，有静而无动耶？ 故曰天门开阖，能无雌乎也。 《真定经》云：夫动二以为阴，静一以为阳。 阳一则有变，阴一则守常。 知常悟明，抱一契灵，坎离交固，变化自然。 此论阴阳不偏枯、动静等对。 故云天门开阖，能无雌乎。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 明者，聪察也。 白者，明敏也。 达，谓通也。 夫聪察明敏之人，其能四通而八达，不出户，可以知天下，不窥牖，可以见天道。 其孰谓之无知乎？ 夫知者，谓能察四方，咨四岳，知四民也。 非明白四达之君，不能知之矣。 如尧之辟四门，明四目，达四聪是也。 夫君天下者，以四方之耳为耳，而不私其耳，故能通天下之志，尽天下之情； 以四方之目为目，而不私其目，则天下之明，皆我之明也。 是以明无不鉴，聪无不闻，其孰谓之无知乎？ 此明白四达之义也。 生之畜之。 生而不有生者，谓生成也。 畜者，谓长养也。 不有者，谓不自有其功也。 且如天地也，天地生成万物，而万物未尝以为天下之功； 如圣人也，圣人仁育天下，而天下未尝以为圣人之惠。 非天地无功，圣人无惠也。 盖功深而形不露，惠博而体不显。 是以蒙其功而不知其功，受其惠而不感其惠。 於此见天地圣人之大矣。 向使天地圣人自矜以为功，则非所谓生而不有也。 经曰天地不仁，又曰圣人不仁。 此皆生而不有之说也。 为而不恃至是谓玄德。 夫圣人者为人中之尊，然其未尝矜以自恃。 盖圣人制世御俗，独化於陶钧之上，不牵乎卑辞之语，不夺乎众多之平，故为而不恃，长而不宰也。 然圣人未尝自尊，而未尝不遵圣人之德。 愈大愈小，愈高愈下，愈明愈晦，此其所以为圣人也。 故云玄德。 《易》曰：谦谦君子，卑以自牧也。 非斯之谓乎？ 杨智仁曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 营魄者，魂魄也，当爱养之。 喜怒亡魂，惊悸伤魄，安靖则寿命延长。
chunks.translated_text:
「Purge and illuminate the Dao/Way—
could there be any flaw?

*Purge* is cleansing.
*Except* is removing.
*Playen* is the Dao/Way.
*Lan* is observation.
*Flaw* is blemish, meaning error.

Speaking of the Dao/Way for humanity,
it requires constant cleansing of body and mind,
removal of external distractions,
and observing the subtleties of the Dao/Way,
so that one may become a person who exhausts principles and fulfills nature*—*
between heaven and earth,
they can avoid great errors.
How could they be called flawed?

The vulgar speak of the "Heavenly Heart" as a mirror—
without cleansing, it cannot be clear;
the Dao/Way is like a shadow—
without observation, it cannot be seen.

Thus, the Dao/Way scholar always cultivates and reflects,
without any interruption,
so that their *virtue/power* remains luminous
and is not obscured by cravings.

Like a person bathing once a day—
or bathing daily,
never ceasing their bathing,
if their cleansing and purifying rituals are uninterrupted,
then their body remains pristine and clear,
not stained by past impurities,
and their mirror reflects without dust,
their heart illuminates the Dao/Way.

This is the meaning of *purge and illuminate the Dao/Way*.

Loving the people and governing the state—
could there be any *action/doing*?

Truly, the people are the foundation of the state;
if the foundation is secure, the state is at peace.
Thus, one who governs the state must first love the people,
and the way to love the people is through *non-action*.
*Non-action* means not to obstruct.

As in the past, when Tang Taizong once told his attendants:
*"The ruler depends on the state,
the state depends on the people.
If you exploit the people to serve the ruler,
it is like cutting flesh to fill the belly.
The belly may be full while the body dies,
the ruler may grow rich while the state perishes.
Thus, the ruler’s misfortune does not come from without,
but arises from within."*

Afterward, he lightened taxes and burdens,
selected capable officials.
From then on, the empire flourished in peace,
people had abundant clothing and food,
outer doors remained open,
and travelers lodged freely in the wilds.
Is this not the saying of loving the people and governing the state
through *non-action* and non-obstruction?

The opening and closing of the *Heavenly Gate*—
could there be any imbalance?

The *Heavenly Gate* is the mouth.
Truly, the mouth is the gateway of the body—
the head round as heaven,
so the mouth is called the *Heavenly Gate*.

*Opening and closing* refers to breathing,
*imbalance* means the lack of harmony between yin and yang.

Truly, opening and closing,
breathing,
yin and yang—
these refer to *dynamic and static*.
*Dynamic and static* are the interplay of movement and stillness.

*The Classic of Changes* says:
*"One dynamic, one static—
mutually their roots.
One yin, one yang—
this is called the Dao/Way.
Those who follow it are good."*

Who could have inhalation without exhalation?
Who could have stillness without movement?
Thus, it is said: *The Heavenly Gate opens and closes—*
could there be any imbalance?

*The True Definition Scripture* states:
*"Two movements constitute yin,
one stillness constitutes yang.
Yang alone brings variation,
yin alone maintains constancy.
Understanding constancy and awakening to clarity,
embracing unity and resonating with the spirit*—*
the interplay of *kan* and *li* is fixed,
transformation and change occur naturally."*

This discusses the balance of yin and yang,
movement and stillness.
Thus, it is said: *The Heavenly Gate opens and closes—*
could there be any imbalance?

Clear and penetrating, fourfold and boundless—
could there be any ignorance?

*Clear* means keen perception.
*White* means bright sensitivity.
*Boundless* means thoroughness.

A person with keen perception and bright sensitivity,
whose understanding is fourfold and boundless,
can know the world without stepping outside their door,
can see the Dao/Way without peering through windows.
Who would call them ignorant?

*Knowledge* means the ability to perceive the four directions,
consult the four cardinal officials,
and understand the four kinds of people.
Only a ruler who is clear and boundless
can truly know them.

As with Yao’s opening of the four gates,
illuminating the four eyes,
and attuning the four ears—
this is the case.

A ruler of the world,
using the four directions’ ears as their own,
not hoarding their ears,
can thus communicate the world’s intentions
and grasp the world’s emotions.

Using the four directions’ eyes as their own,
not hoarding their eyes,
then the world’s clarity becomes their own clarity.
Thus, their vision is never unreflective,
their hearing is never unperceptive.
Who would call them ignorant?
This is the meaning of *clear and boundless*.

To nurture and sustain life—
to generate without possessing generation,
to sustain without claiming credit for nurturing.
*Not possessing* means not taking ownership of the deed.

Take heaven and earth, for instance—
they generate all things,
yet all things never claim it as heaven’s and earth’s work.
Take the sage, for instance—
the sage nurtures the world with benevolence,
yet the world never credits it as the sage’s favor.
It is not that heaven and earth have no work,
nor that the sage offers no benefits—
their deeds are profound yet unmanifest,
their benefits vast yet unapparent.
Thus, they receive the work without knowing its source,
they accept the benefits without feeling gratitude.

Here, we see the grandeur of heaven, earth, and the sage.
If heaven, earth, and the sage had boasted of their work,
then it would not be called *generating without possessing*.

The *Scripture* says: *"Heaven and earth lack virtue/power,"*
and again: *"The sage lacks virtue/power."*
This is the saying of *generating without possessing*.

To act without relying—
this is what is called *Playen Virtue/Power*.

The sage is the most noble among people,
yet they never rely on their nobility.
Truly, the sage governs the world and directs customs,
transforming alone in the *Dao/Way’s* shaping*—*
they do not cling to lowly words,
nor do they seize the common level of the multitude,
thus they act without relying,
they grow without harvesting.
Yet the sage never claims their own nobility,
nor do they ever fail to follow the sage’s virtue/power.

The greater they are, the smaller they seem;
the higher they rise, the lower they appear;
the clearer they become, the more obscure they are—
this is how they become sage.
Thus, it is called *Playen Virtue/Power*.

*The Classic of Changes* says:
*"Modest, modest, the noble person—
humble to cultivate themselves."*
Is this not the same meaning?

Yang Zhiren said:
*"To sustain the spirit*—
this is what is called *Playen Virtue/Power*.
The *spirit* refers to *hun* and *po*—
these must be nurtured.
Excessive joy or anger harms the *hun*,
excessive fright or terror harms the *po*.
Peace and tranquility extend longevity."*

chunks.original_text: 人身如船筏屋宇，能包载其魂，以营守其魄，使之归一，不可须臾离也。 出为行，布为德，专而无二之谓也。 使一炁柔和，抱纯素而守之，其性如赤子之慕慈母，若婴儿之未孩。 涤除心垢，不染一尘，善恶俱泯，心意双亡。 藏其器而待其时。 爱民治国，喻一身也。 治身者爱炁即身全，治国者爱民则国安。 其人之自性辉辉朗朗，纯清绝点，内则明彻，外则如愚。 天者，本性也。 门者，收放之谓也。 明白四达者，天之明无非日月辉光，人之明一性湛然。 虽然恁么亦有无知暗昧者。 《易》曰：阖户谓之坤，辟户谓之乾。 一阖一辟谓之变，往来不穷谓之通。 生畜之说生阴阳而畜至精，向无中生有。 为而不自恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德之妙也。 《中庸》曰：君子尊德性而道问学，致广大而尽精微，极高明而道中庸。 温故而知新，敦厚以崇礼，是故居上不骄，为下不倍。 国有道，其言足以兴国。 无道，其默足以容。 《诗》云：既明且哲，以保其身。 其此之谓欤。 喻清中曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 肤齐林氏曰：营，魂也，神也。 魄，精也，气也。 此三字老子之深意。 载犹车载物也，安一载字在上，而置营魄二字於下，如谜语然。 魄以载管则为众人，营以载魄则为圣人。 合而言之则营魄为一，离而言之则营魄为二。 抱者合也，人能常合而一之，则真精不散。 不然，则一者离矣。 故老子痛下钳椎而曰：能无离乎？ 如说戒曰能持否之例是也。 惟大人不失赤子之心。 赤子之心，良知良能，其气静而专，又能柔顺以致之，谓无暴其气也。 是能合而一之矣。 涤除邪妄，观览玄冥，岂无瑕疵之可指？ 治国爱民必如文帝，躬修玄默，是盖传黄老之清静。 外此则皆有作为之劳。 天门开阖，乃精气出入之关。 纯阳用事，雌阴也。 能无雌乎者，虑阴气以乘之耳。 明白四达，固无所不通矣，不在乎察察以为知也。 毓之养之，生机流动，而不有其功，事卒能应，而不恃其长。 道心常为一身之主，而无宰制群动之劳，是谓之玄妙之德。 此章是修心养性工夫，中有治国爱民之方。 老子勉时君以无为自然之治，故发为能无乎之语，皆警省之言也。 三代而下，惟文帝知之。 说天门者，北极紫宫之门也。 天有北极星在紫宫之内，宫内又有五帝迭相休王。 故门有开阖，开则为泰，阖则为否，故春时青帝门开，余皆阖。 四时之例如此，或是一说。 今并存之。
chunks.translated_text:
The human body is like a boat, a raft, or a dwelling—
it must contain the *hun* to nurture and guard the *po*,
so they may return to unity, never to be parted even for a moment.

To act outwardly is to embody *De* (virtue/power),
to spread inwardly is to manifest *De*—
this is called singularity without division.

Let the *qi* be soft and harmonious,
embracing purity and guarding it,
so that one’s nature is like an infant’s longing for its tender mother,
or a babe yet unspoiled by the world.

Wash away the filth of the heart,
untainted by even a speck of dust—
both good and evil vanish,
mind and intention dissolve.

Hide your vessel and await its time.

To love the people and govern the realm
is but an extension of cultivating oneself.
He who governs his body by cherishing his *qi* preserves his life,
he who governs the state by loving his people secures its peace.

The true nature of such a person shines luminous and clear,
pure and unblemished—
within, it is radiant and transparent;
without, it appears as simple as the unlearned.

*Heaven* is one’s innate nature.
*The Gate* refers to the opening and closing [of *qi*].

The enlightened see all paths as open—
Heaven’s light is never without the radiance of sun and moon,
while human enlightenment is the singular, undivided nature.

Yet there are those who remain ignorant and obscured.
*The Classic of Changes* says:
*"To close the door is called *Kun* (Earth),
to open the door is called *Qian* (Heaven).
Opening and closing is called *change*,
forward and backward without end is called *communication*.
The theory of *sheng-chu* (nourishing life) generates yin and yang
and preserves the utmost essence—
from non-being arises being."*

To act without self-reliance,
to grow without domination—
this is the subtlety of *Playen Virtue/Power*.

*The Doctrine of the Mean* states:
*"The noble person honors innate virtue/power
and follows the Way of inquiry and learning,
realizing the vast and exhausting the subtle,
attaining the highest clarity while embodying the Middle Way.
Revering tradition while knowing the new,
cultivating sincerity to uphold propriety—
thus, though in high station, they are not proud,
though in low station, they do not rebel.
When the state has the Way, their words suffice to revive it.
When the state lacks the Way, their silence suffices to contain it."*

*The Odes* say:
*"Both wise and enlightened,
they preserve themselves thus."*
Is this not what is meant?

Yù Qīngzhōng said:
*"To sustain the *hun* and *po* is what is called *Playen Virtue/Power*."*

Fū Qí Línshì said:
*"*Hun* is the soul, the spirit.
*Po* is the vital essence, the *qi*.
These three characters hold the profound meaning of *Laozi*.
*Load* is like a cart bearing goods—
placing *load* above and *hun* and *po* below,
it is like a riddle.
If *po* bears the *hun*, it becomes the common person;
if *hun* bears the *po*, it becomes the sage.
Together, they are one;
separately, they are two.
*Embrace* means to unite—
if one can always unite and make them one,
the true essence will not scatter.
Otherwise, unity is lost.
Thus, *Laozi* sternly warns:
*'Can one truly avoid separation?*
This is like the precept in the *Sutra of the Ten Wholesome Actions*—
one must hold fast to *non-doing*.'"

Only the sage retains the heart of the infant.
The infant’s heart is innate knowing and innate capacity—
its *qi* is still and focused,
yet gentle and yielding—
this is to say, it does not violently exhaust its *qi*.
Thus, it unites and makes them one.

Purifying falsehoods, gazing into the mysterious—
how could there be any flaws to point out?

To govern the state and love the people,
one must be like Emperor Wen—
personally cultivating silent stillness,
transmitting the *Yellow Emperor-Laozi* tradition of pure tranquility.
Beyond this lies only the toil of artificial action.

The opening and closing of the *Heavenly Gate*
is the passage for the circulation of vital essence.
When pure yang prevails, it is the receptive yin.
Can one truly avoid the yin?
It is only a concern that yin *qi* might overpower it.

Though all paths are clear and open,
true understanding lies not in prying scrutiny.
Nurture and cultivate—
life’s vitality flows naturally,
yet one does not claim its merit;
things are accomplished effortlessly,
yet one does not rely on one’s strength.

The *Dao-heart* eternally governs the body,
without the labor of controlling all movements—
this is called the profound and mysterious virtue/power.

This chapter speaks of the practice of cultivating mind and nature,
within which lie the methods for governing the state and loving the people.
*Laozi* exhorts the rulers of his time to govern through natural *wuwei*,
thus issuing warnings like *"Can one truly avoid..."*—
all are words of admonition.

Since the Three Dynasties, only Emperor Wen understood this.

Speaking of the *Heavenly Gate*—
it is the gate of the Purple Palace at the North Celestial Pole.
Heaven has the North Star within the Purple Palace,
and within the palace, the Five Emperors reign in succession.
Thus, the Gate opens and closes—
when open, it is *Tai* (harmony);
when closed, it is *Pi* (obstruction).
Hence, in spring, the Green Emperor’s Gate opens,
while the others remain closed.
The example of the four seasons is such—
perhaps another interpretation exists.

Now, I preserve both.

chunks.original_text: 胥六虚曰：载营魄抱一，能无离乎？ 人之形备载魂魄，犹车之载物。 经曰营魄不曰魂魄者，盖魂主动，动者能营运一切。 故曰营魄也。 《内观经》曰：动以营身谓之魂，静以镇形谓之魄。 抱一能无离乎者，非别有个一可抱，使之不离也。 言其魂魄二义不一者，魂则变游无定，魄则固凝不化，故教之抱持为一，则魂魄无偏间之失。 若然者，其动也一，其静也一，无所往而非一，何离之有哉？ 专气政柔，能如婴儿乎？ 夫精专气浩，极致柔和，如婴儿乎者，婴儿终日不知不识，淳全朴全，气专志一，骨弱筋柔，而握固也。 涤除玄览，能无疵乎？ 涤谓洗涤其嗜欲之心，除谓去其好恶之情。 玄，天也。 览，照也。 嗜好既亡，天光自发。 照览真源，能使无一点之疵，则善矣。 疵，病也。 如或去之有一点不浄，乃世世生生沉迷之病根矣。 已上三节，语进志於道者之要。 已次论国君爱民，治国之道也。 爱民治国，能无为乎？ 爱民治国，事分二义。 一以无为言者，盖爱民以无为则民安，治国以无为则国宁。 夫无为者，非拱默端坐也，谓因民之所利而利之，其爱博，因国之当治而治之，其治大。 此能无为也。 《通玄经》曰：夫无为者，不先物为也。 又曰：因即大，作即细。 如欲以小惠为爱民，以严峻刑法为治国，其细也。 夫天门开阖，能无雌乎？ 天门者，天下之大本，吉凶治乱之所从出，造化自然之门户也。 夫道有通塞，时有否泰，此造化自然之理。 犹门户之辟阖，不可得而度也。 知者居雌静以俟之，则无不善； 否则作雄作倡，多见其殆矣。 明白四达，能无知乎？ 人君聪明博识，无所不通，明白四达也。 能韬晦其知，而委贤受能，端拱垂裳，国治而心不劳，寿长而天下泰。 生之畜之至长而不宰。 人君牧民任其自生自养，安於无事，故曰生之畜之也。 虽宽之宥之，由其生养，亦不以为有其恩，上下相忘，民受其赐，故曰生而不有。 凡所施为，无非泽利天下，及其功成事遂，不以为己有，故曰为而不恃。 君者，兆民之长也。 居民之长，而宰制之令不施，民知有其君而已矣。 优哉游哉，故曰长而不宰。 是谓玄德。 玄，天也。 君修若此，是之谓与天同德也。 柴元皋曰：载营魄。 身载魄即车载物也。 魄识好营扰，谨载之常防覆身。 抱一能无离。 心不二用，则谷神活。 专气致柔，能婴儿。 气不从鼻散，则胎息全。 涤除玄览，能无疵。 神不从眼漏，则慧志圆。 爱民治国，能无为。 主宰不为形体役，则筋骨强。 天门开阖，能无雌。 阖辟无间断，则不离母。 明白四达，能无知。 精气不为聪漏，则心识渊。 生之畜之。 善於保养。 生而不有至是谓玄德。 常存其体以制其用，则不矜而魄安矣，故养成圣德。 苏敬静曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 此章老子本意只在生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，着意却以载营魄抱一为题。 营，舍也。 魄，气也。 魂，神也。 载犹车之载物，营犹合之。 居人魄虽为魂之营舍，然魂所欲行，则魄无不从，犹载之以车而行也。 此为魂魄合一。 魂魄二者当合而为一，不当离而为二。 离而为二则有魂无魄，有魄无魂，人非其人而死矣。 老子遂设譬，言魂魄抱一五事。 婴儿纯一柔善，其气专，其柔致。 致，极也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Xú Liùxū said: *"Carrying the vital essence and embracing unity—can one truly avoid separation?"*

A person’s form carries soul and vital essence,
just as a carriage carries goods.
The scripture speaks of *yíngpò* (vital essence) rather than *húnpò* (soul and vital essence),
for the soul governs movement—
movement is the capacity to vitalize and regulate all things.
Hence, it is called *yíngpò* (vital essence).

The *Nèiguān Jīng* (Scripture of Inner Observation) states:
*"Movement that vitalizes the body is called the soul;
stillness that steadies the form is called the vital essence."*
To *"embrace unity and avoid separation"* is not to seek a separate *one* to hold,
so that it does not depart.
It refers to the dual meanings of soul and vital essence diverging—
the soul wanders and shifts without constancy,
while the vital essence remains fixed and unyielding.
Thus, the teaching is to hold them as one,
so that soul and vital essence suffer no fault of deviation.
If so, then in movement, they are one;
in stillness, they are one.
Wherever one goes, it is not separate from this unity—
how could there be any separation?

To concentrate *qi* and cultivate softness—
can one attain the state of an infant?
When *jing* (essence) is concentrated and *qi* is vast,
reaching the utmost in softness and harmony—
like an infant, who throughout the day
knows nothing and recognizes nothing,
pure and complete, unspoiled and unspoiled,
*qi* concentrated, mind unified,
bones frail, sinews soft, yet grasp firm.

To purify and survey the mysteries—
can one remain without flaw?
*Purification* means washing away one’s cravings and desires;
*removal* means eliminating one’s likes and dislikes.
*Mysteries* are Heaven;
*survey* is illumination.
When cravings and desires are extinguished,
Heaven’s light naturally shines forth.
To illuminate the true source—
if one can make it so that not a single flaw remains,
then it is well.
*Flaw* is *disease*.
If even a single point is not cleansed,
it becomes the root of the disease of confusion across lifetimes.

The above three passages speak of the essentials
for advancing one’s aspiration toward the Dao.

The following discusses the ruler’s love for the people
and the Way of governing the state.
To love the people and govern the state—
can one truly avoid *wuwei* (inaction)?

To love the people and govern the state
are two distinct matters.
One speaks of *wuwei* (inaction)—
for if a ruler loves the people through *wuwei*,
the people will be at ease;
if a ruler governs the state through *wuwei*,
the state will be tranquil.
*Wuwei* (inaction) is not passive silence or idle sitting—
it means to benefit the people by what benefits them,
so that love is vast;
to govern the state by what the state requires,
so that governance is grand.
This is true *wuwei*.

The *Tōng Xuān Jīng* (Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious) says:
*"Wuwei* means not acting before things have acted themselves."
It also says:
*"To follow is great; to act is petty."
If one seeks to love the people with small favors,
or to govern the state with harsh laws and punishments,
then it is petty.

As for the *Heavenly Gate* opening and closing—
can one truly avoid *cī* (passivity/femininity)?
The *Heavenly Gate* is the great root of all under Heaven,
the source from which auspiciousness and inauspiciousness,
order and chaos arise—
the natural doorway of creation and transformation.
The Dao has its passages of flow and blockage;
time has its *pǐ* (obstruction) and *tài* (harmony).
This is the natural principle of creation and transformation.
Just as doors and gates are opened and closed,
their timing cannot be measured.
The wise dwell in *cī* (passivity) and stillness,
awaiting its course—
then nothing will fail to be good.
Otherwise, they act as *xióng* (masculine/forceful) or as leaders,
and often see disaster.

To be clear and open in all directions—
can one truly avoid *zhī* (knowing)?
A ruler is intelligent, well-informed, and knows all things—
clear and open in every direction.
If one can conceal one’s knowledge,
entrusting it to the worthy while receiving their abilities,
upright and dignified, with sleeves drawn low,
then the state is governed without laboring the mind,
longevity is extended, and all under Heaven is in harmony.
To nurture and preserve life until it reaches its utmost—
then it is not slaughtered.
A ruler tends to the people,
letting them live and nourish themselves naturally,
content in tranquility—
thus, it is said to nurture and preserve life.
Though lenient and forgiving,
it is because of their natural growth and sustenance—
one does not claim credit for it.
Above and below forget each other,
the people receive their blessings—
thus, it is said to give life without possession.
All actions undertaken,
without exception, are to benefit all under Heaven.
When the work is accomplished and the affairs fulfilled,
one does not claim them as one’s own—
thus, it is said to act without reliance.
The ruler is the leader of all the people.
As the leader of the people,
yet issuing no commands to slaughter them—
the people know only of their ruler.
Thus, it is said: *"Comfortably at ease"*—
hence, *"long while not slaughtered."*
This is called *Xuān Dé* (Mysterious Virtue).
*Xuān* is Heaven.
If a ruler cultivates himself thus,
it is called *"harmonizing with Heaven’s virtue."*

Chái Yuángāo said:
*"To carry the vital essence"*—
the body carries the vital essence, just as a carriage carries goods.
The vital essence perceives likes and disturbs the body—
one must be cautious in carrying it,
constantly guarding against its overturning.
*"To embrace unity and avoid separation"*—
the mind does not split its focus,
so that the *Gǔshén* (Vital Spirit of the Valleys) remains active.
*"To concentrate qi and attain softness"*—
*qi* does not disperse through the nose,
so that *tāixī* (womb-breathing) is complete.
*"To purify and survey the mysteries"*—
the spirit does not leak through the eyes,
so that wisdom and resolve are perfected.

*"To love the people and govern the state"*—
the ruler is not enslaved by physical form,
so that sinews and bones grow strong.

*"The Heavenly Gate opens and closes"*—
if opening and closing proceed without interruption,
then one does not depart from the Mother.

*"To be clear and open in all directions"*—
if essence and *qi* do not leak from cleverness,
then the mind’s perception is profound.

*"To nurture and preserve life"*—
to excel in preservation and nourishment.
*"To give life without possession"* is the utmost called *Xuān Dé* (Mysterious Virtue).
If one constantly preserves its essence
and regulates its use,
then one’s virtues are not vainglorious
while the vital essence is secure—
thus, the cultivation of a sage’s virtue is achieved.

Sū Jìng said:
*"From ‘carrying the vital essence’ to ‘this is called Mysterious Virtue.’*
This chapter’s original intent by *Laozi*
lies solely in *"giving life without possession,"*
*"acting without reliance,"*
and *"long while not slaughtered."*
Yet the emphasis is placed on
*"carrying the vital essence and embracing unity"* as the topic.
*Yíng* means *dwelling*;
*Pò* means *qi*.
*Soul* is *spirit*.
To *"carry"* is like a carriage carrying goods;
*"yíng"* is like *enfolding*.
The vital essence dwells within the body,
though the soul’s movements
are always followed by the vital essence—
just as goods are carried in a carriage when moving.
This is the unification of soul and vital essence.
The soul and vital essence should be united as one,
not separated into two.
If separated into two,
there may be soul without vital essence,
or vital essence without soul—
the person is no longer a person and dies.

*Laozi* thus sets forth analogies,
speaking of the five matters of soul and vital essence embracing unity.
An infant is pure, unified, soft, and good—
its *qi* is concentrated, its softness extreme.
*Extreme* means *ultimate.*»

chunks.original_text: 故能使魂魄合而不离。 此纯固也。 涤瑕除垢，览观玄冥，则多索疵求。 若涤除玄览，而不索疵求，则能使魂魄合一而不离。 此无心也。 爱民治国而能以无为而为，则清静自然，自能使魂魄合而不离。 此清浄也。 天门开阖，天理所从出也。 雌雄交感，阴阳相配，有其理而无其心，则魂魄合一而不离。 此无欲也。 明白四达而能若无知无识，则藏明於晦，自能使魂魄合一而不离。 此藏明也。 大抵纯固、无心、清浄、无欲、藏明，则魂魄二者自能抱一。 魂魄抱一，为生生之源。 天道以生养万物为心，而尤以人为心。 生之畜之者，天道也，而魂魄相离则不能生。 老氏以五事教人，而天地生物之仁为无穷。 然天道生而不有，何尝自有其生之之功？ 为而不恃，何尝自恃其为之之功？ 虽为万物之长，而无主宰之心，是谓玄妙之德。 以魂魄抱一为生生之本，而以不有不恃不宰为无容心。 生养之恩，天与圣人一而已矣。 本一庵居士曰：载营魄至是谓玄德。 魂魄之义，先儒辩之详矣。 愚按记礼祭义，孔子曰：魄者，鬼之盛也。 郑氏注曰：耳目之精明为魄。 此语最为简功。 朱氏谓营与荧同，为精明光炯之意，是营魄者形体之神灵也。 夫人形生神，发耳目鼻口之精明，皆本於一性。 释氏所谓元。 依一精明分成六和合者是也。 惟其为物所引，流荡忘返，是以形弊於外，识乱於内，忽焉而死。 魂升魄降，不可复合。 欲其死而不忘，难矣。 故知道者收视返听，回光返照，以复一性之源。 载者，安住而不驰之谓。 抱者，保合而不失之谓。 一则性也。 释氏所谓返流全一，六用不行，明不循根，寄根明发者是也。 寄根明发，载营魄也。 返流全一，抱一不离也。 此复性践形之要道，非真修炼形神长生久视而已。 专，不杂也。 致，至也。 婴儿无知思之诱以动其气，故其气也专。 无物我之竞以伤其柔，故其柔也至。 人之持气尚柔者，能勉於暂而不能常，必如婴儿然后为至也。 此二者皆反之於有生之初，惟涤除玄览乃神圣之极功。 盖涤除尘垢，固真见所自出，外物有一尘之不尽则明睿，有一毫之未了惟涤除之，至使吾心目朗然，则洞视万物，浄者固浄，秽者亦浄，无所拣择，不见瑕疵，是为至也。 治身既至於是，推而治世应物，爱民治国，其常也。 天门开阖，其变也。 《易》所谓一阖一辟谓之变是也。 为雌者和而不倡，后而不先之义。 其处常也，无有为之迹。 其临变也，无先物之心。 盖无将无迎，安乎自然而已。 明白四达而能无知，则所谓聪明睿智，守之以愚也。 生之畜之者，德也。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，是德之而无德之之心，乃德之玄也。 老子此章#2，身治国之道备矣。 《拾遗》陆曰：载由天也。 发语之端也。 石潭曰：载营魄抱一，能无离。 营，古注以为魂。 盖魂即月之明也，魄即月之魄也。 月受日光以为明，魄必载魂则生而不死。 抱一者，魄与魂合为一，未尝离也。 专气致柔，能婴儿。 人赋形气以生，阳气既盛不能自制，未免流荡，而失其真。 惟能专守其气，而使之柔如婴儿之虽而未尝知牝牡之合，则善矣。 即下文含德之厚，比於赤子之意。 涤除玄览，能无疵。 古说谓心览於万事，易於感物而动，故必涤除外欲，而无一毫疵病可也。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, one may make the soul and vital essence unite without separation—
this is *purity and firmness*.

To purify flaws and remove defilements, to gaze into the profound and obscure,
is to seek out faults and blemishes.
But if one purifies and gazes without seeking faults,
then the soul and vital essence may unite without separation—
this is *non-attachment*.

To love the people and govern the state while acting through *wuwei* (non-action),
then clarity and stillness arise naturally,
and the soul and vital essence may unite without separation—
this is *purity and clarity*.

The opening and closing of the *Heavenly Gate*,
through which *Heavenly Principle* emerges—
when *yin* and *yang* interact in harmony,
when *male* and *female* resonate together,
with principle present yet the mind absent,
then the soul and vital essence unite without separation—
this is *desirelessness*.

To be bright and far-reaching yet appear as if without knowledge or awareness,
then one conceals brilliance in obscurity,
and the soul and vital essence may unite without separation—
this is *concealing brilliance*.

In essence, *purity and firmness*, *non-attachment*, *purity and clarity*,
*desirelessness*, and *concealing brilliance*—
these five make the soul and vital essence naturally embrace unity.
When the soul and vital essence embrace unity,
they become the source of *generative life*.

*Heaven’s Dao* takes nurturing all things as its intent,
yet especially cherishes humanity.
To give birth and nourish is *Heaven’s Dao*,
yet if the soul and vital essence separate,
life cannot endure.
*Laozi* teaches these five matters to humanity,
while *Heaven and Earth’s* benevolent generation is boundless.
Yet *Heaven’s Dao* gives birth without possessing—
how could it claim credit for its generative power?
It acts without relying—
how could it boast of its deeds?
Though it stands as sovereign over all things,
it harbors no masterful intent—
this is called the *mysterious virtue*.

To take the unity of soul and vital essence as the root of generative life,
and to possess without claiming, act without relying, govern without dominating,
is to have no room for the mind.
The grace of giving birth and nourishing
is shared equally by *Heaven* and the *Sage*—
thus speaks *Ben Yi An*, the recluse of the *One Root Lodge*:
*"From ‘carrying the vital essence and soul’ to this point is called the *Mysterious Virtue*."*

The meaning of *soul* and *vital essence* has been thoroughly expounded by earlier scholars.
In my view, regarding the *Rites’* sacrificial rites, *Confucius* said:
*"The vital essence is the flourishing of the spirit."*
*Zheng Xuan* annotated:
*"The vital essence is the luminous clarity of the ears and eyes."*
This is the most concise explanation.
*Zhu Xi* said that *vital essence* (*ying*) is akin to *ying* (glowing),
meaning radiant brilliance—
thus, *vital essence* and *soul* are the spiritual essence of the form.
Human form gives rise to spirit,
and the luminous clarity of the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth
all originate from *One Nature*—
what the *Buddhist School* calls *Elemental Essence*.
It divides into the six harmonized faculties from a single clarity—
yet because it is drawn by external things,
it drifts and forgets its return,
thus the form decays externally while awareness falters internally,
and suddenly, death comes.
The soul ascends, the vital essence descends—
they can no longer reunite.
To die without forgetting is difficult indeed.

Thus, the enlightened one gathers vision and returns hearing,
reverses light to illuminate the source,
and restores the origin of *One Nature*.
*"Carrying"* means dwelling steadfast without scattering.
*"Embracing"* means preserving unity without loss.
*One* refers to *Nature*—
what the *Buddhist School* calls *Returning the Flow to Wholeness*,
where the six faculties do not act,
and clarity does not follow the roots—
this is *illuminating the root and emitting light*.
To illuminate the root and emit light is to *carry the vital essence and soul*.
To return the flow to wholeness is to *embrace unity without separation*.
This is the essential path to *restoring Nature and embodying form*—
not merely the true cultivation of refining form and spirit for longevity and sharp vision.

*Specialization* means *unmixed*.
*Extreme* means *ultimate*.
An infant, untempted by knowledge or thought to disturb its *qi*,
thus its *qi* is *specialized*.
Unburdened by competition between self and other to harm its softness,
thus its softness is *extreme*.
Though humans may strive to maintain gentle *qi*,
they can manage it temporarily but not perpetually—
only as an infant is it truly *extreme*.
These two aspects both return to the beginning of life,
and only through purification and profound contemplation
does the divine attain its ultimate function.
For purification removes dust and defilement—
truly, the original clarity emerges from this.
If even a speck of external filth remains unexhausted,
then wisdom is obscured;
if even a hair’s breadth of imperfection lingers,
only purification can resolve it—
until the mind and eyes become luminously clear,
then one perceives all things with penetrating vision.
The pure remain pure,
the impure become pure—
no selection, no perception of flaws—
this is *ultimate*.

Having perfected self-cultivation thus,
one extends it to govern the world and respond to affairs,
loving the people and ruling the state—
this is the norm.
The opening and closing of the *Heavenly Gate*—
this is its transformation.
As the *Yijing* says:
*"One closing, one opening—this is called transformation."*
To be *female* is to be harmonious without initiating,
to follow without leading—
in its constancy, there is no trace of action.
In its response to change, there is no intent to precede things.
For there is neither anticipation nor resistance—
one simply abides in natural ease.

To be bright and far-reaching yet appear without knowledge,
this is called *"wise and insightful, yet guarded by simplicity."*
To give birth and nourish is *virtue*.
To give birth without possessing,
to act without relying,
to lead without dominating—
this is *virtue* without the mind of *virtue*—
this is the *mysterious virtue* of *virtue*.

*Laozi’s* this chapter #2
encompasses the *Dao* of governing the body and the state.

*Lu Yu* of *Shi Yi* says:
*"‘Carrying’ originates from *Heaven*—
the beginning of the discourse."*
*Shi Tan* says:
*"Carrying the vital essence and soul, embracing unity—
how could they separate?"*
*Vital essence*, in ancient annotations, is taken as *soul*.
For the *soul* is the moon’s luminosity,
the *vital essence* is the moon’s shadow.
The moon receives sunlight to become luminous,
the shadow must carry the luminosity to live without dying.
*Embracing unity* means the vital essence and soul merge as one,
never separating.
To specialize *qi* and achieve ultimate softness,
one must be like an infant.
Humans are endowed with form and *qi* to live,
yet when *yang qi* flourishes uncontrollably,
it cannot be self-regulated and inevitably drifts,
losing its true essence.
Only by specializing and guarding one’s *qi*,
making it soft as an infant—
though it may move, it does not know the union of *male* and *female*—
is this well done.
This aligns with the later text:
*"The depth of virtue is compared to that of an infant."*

To purify and gaze profoundly,
one must be without blemish.
The ancients said:
*"The mind perceives all things,
easily moved by external influences—
thus, one must purify external desires,
leaving no trace of flaw or defect."*
